situation_y: ADC Telecommunications Inc. announced that it is cutting 225 jobs and closing two facilities in an effort to cut costs. The job cuts will be made across all geographic regions, including the Americas.

ADC Telecommunications Inc. announced that it will spend $900,000 to $1.2 million to eliminate about 25 jobs at the telecom services business in Germany. ADC announced that it notified workers of the terminations, which will begin on June 1, 2007 and finish by July 31, 2007. The company will not close any facilities as part of the restructuring plan.

ADC Telecommunications Inc. announced that it will cut about 50 jobs in Germany as part of a restructuring. The company, which has about 8,600 employees, announced the cuts will only affect services units in Germany and will not lead to any facility closings. The job cuts will occur between Aug. 1 and Dec. 31. ADC expects future cash expenditures, mostly from the job cuts, of about $3.2 million to $3.6 million.
AMR Corp. announced that it will layoff approximately 20,000 employees, as a result of the September 11th terrorist attacks.

AMR Corp. announced it would cut 20,000 jobs at American, commuter airline American Eagle and Trans World Airlines, which has since been folded into American. Fewer employees were needed because American cut its flight schedule in the face of declining travel after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

AMR Corporation announced that it is eliminating about 13,000 jobs - while increasing flying by 20% and annual revenue by $1 billion. The proposed job cuts would include 4,600 mechanics and related workers; 4,200 fleet service and other Transport Workers Union members; 2,300 flight attendants; 1,400 management and support staff workers; 400 pilots; and a still undetermined number of agents, customer service representatives and planners. The company reported that it plans a 20% labor cost reduction - as well as more flying - by 2017.
Even though AVX Corporation's fiscal 2001 earning met Wall Street projections, the company cut 500 people from its staff, due to a slowing economy.
AVX has announced plans to shed 92 jobs from its Northern Ireland workforce.

Pinnacle West Capital Corp. announced that cut between 500 and 600 jobs or 7 percent to 8 percent of its work force citing weaker margins of profit from energy sales. The job cuts, designed to save $30 million to $35 million a year starting in 2003, will occur during the second half of this year. Pinnacle said it expects 2002 earnings to fall below those of 2001 because of lower power marketing margins. The earnings contribution from power marketing in 2002 is expected to be down 75 percent from 2001, when the segment reported net income of $172 million, or $2.03 per diluted share, the company said.

Pinnacle West Capital Corp. said its third-quarter profit fell 33 percent as the company reeled from a sharp decline in the Western wholesale electric market. Net income fell to $100.9 million, or $1.19 a share, from $150.1 million in the same quarter a year ago. Revenue fell to $873 million from $1.16 billion a year earlier. 

The results for the latest quarter include a $25 million charge for a work force reduction the company announced during the summer. The company said in July it planned to cut 600 jobs, about 8 percent of the total, by the end of this year through voluntary retirements.
Abbott Laboratories plans to close its manufacturing plant in Whippany, New Jersey, within two to three years and probably will cut all 220 jobs there.

Abbott Laboratories is laying off less than 200 people from its pharmaceutical discovery operations, including workers in Worcester, as it restructures to focus on fewer disease categories. The cuts primarily affect scientists who work on compounds at their earliest stages. About 16 to 20 workers in Worcester are expected to lose their jobs. Abbott will focus its drug-discovery efforts on immunology, infectious disease, neuroscience and cancer. That leaves out metabolics, an area in which Abbott has developed drugs such as Meridia for obesity and Synthroid for hypothyroidism.

Abbott Laboratories announced that it will have fully exited its Hollywood and Weston facilities by the end of the year, resulting in layoffs of about 120 people. Eighty people have already been laid off at the Chicago-based company's Hollywood and Weston facilities, which focused on research and development and corporate jobs. About 40 remain in Weston, which will be shut by the end of the year. All the employees were made aware of the layoffs months ago.

Abbott Laboratories is understood to be planning a meeting with staff on December 4, 2007 afternoon to outline details of the cuts. The company employs more than 3,500 people in six plants around Ireland and is believed to be planning significant redundancies. The Galway plant in Mervue is expected to be the focus of the lay-offs.

Abbott Laboratories announced it will cut 1,000 jobs as part of a multiyear effort to lower spending on its medical testing business. The plan will save the company $150 million before taxes, primarily by transferring manufacturing operations to Europe. The company said the actions will cost $370 million before taxes, with about $150 million of that amount falling in the second half of 2008. Only about 100 jobs will be cut in 2008, with all 1,000 jobs eliminated within four years. The jobs to be cut represent less than 2% of Abbott's 68,000-person global work force. As part of the restructuring plan, it will close its Pasadena, Calif., manufacturing site and eliminate positions at sites in Santa Clara, Calif., and Lake Forest, Ill.
Abbott Laboratories has laid off about 80 temporary workers from its giant medical device factory on Ynez Road. The layoffs were a normal part of ongoing adjustments of its temporary work force.

Abbott Laboratories announced that it will lay off 700 employees as part of ongoing restructuring efforts. Most of the layoffs will affect employees who manufacture the company's heart stents and diagnostic tests. About 300 of the eliminated positions are at the company's stent business in Southern California. Less than 200 others involve the company's diagnostic business in Lake County, Illinois. Other layoffs affect the company's pharmaceutical manufacturing operation in Puerto Rico, among other places.

Abbott announced that it plans to cut 200 jobs in Clonmel. Abbott is to lay off the workers at its Clonmel manufacturing plant after a downturn in demand for its older products. Several dozen staff who work on a contract basis will not have their contracts renewed at the end of March 2013. Abbott's vascular facility in Clonmel currently employs more than 1,400 people.

Abbott Laboratories is closing one of its manufacturing plants in the Puerto Rico town of Barceloneta 2015, delivering another blow to the U.S. territory's once-thriving pharmaceutical sector. It is unclear how many workers will be affected, although Barceloneta Mayor Wanda Soler told The Associated Press that the plant is the smallest one of several that Abbott operates in the north coastal town. The plant would cease manufacturing in mid-2015.
Advanced Micro Devices Inc. has announced that it has shutdown two smaller chip factories in Austin, laying off 1,000 employees as a part of its plan to cut costs.

Chip maker Advanced Micro Devices Inc. laid off 300 people in Austin in the start of worldwide cutbacks that will cost 2,000 people their jobs. AMD has been unprofitable for five straight quarters because of weak demand for personal computers and intense price pressure from rival Intel Corp. The company cut 1,000 workers including 300 in Austin who did marketing, finance, human resources and administrative jobs. Another 1,000 workers will be cut companywide before the end of June. The job reductions are part of the company's pledge to trim $350 million from its spending next year.

Advanced Micro Devices Inc. has laid off about 80 employees in Austin as part of a larger cost-cutting plan. The 80 employees losing their jobs here are among roughly 430 being laid off throughout the entire company. The layoffs include sales, marketing, administration and some engineering jobs.

Advanced Micro Devices Inc., reported that will cut 1,680 employees, or about 10% of its worldwide workforce, between now and September. The company announced that move was part of a cost-cutting plan to help return the company to profitability. The company doesn't know how many will be affected at its two Silicon Valley campuses.
Advanced Micro Devices Inc. announced that it will cut 500 jobs as part of the company's bid to reduce expenses.
Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported that it plans to cut its workforce by 9%, or roughly 1,100 positions, in the first quarter the company struggles to lower costs in an economic downturn.

Aetna Inc. posted a smaller loss for the fourth quarter and said Thursday it expects to return to profitability this year on an operating basis. Aetna lost $187.6 million, or $1.30 a share, in the October-December period in contrast to a loss of $406.3 million, or $2.87 a share, a year earlier. In December, Aetna's operating loss for the quarter was $84.6 million, or 56 cents per share. That was larger than the consensus forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call for a loss of 42 cents a share. Revenues for the quarter were $6.043 billion, down 8.4 percent from $6.6 billion in the same quarter of 2000. 
 
 
 
 For the full year, Aetna lost $279.6 million, or $1.95 per share, compared with profits of $127.1 million, or 90 cents per share, in 2000. Revenue for all of 2001 totaled $25.2 billion, down from $26.8 billion in 2000.
 
 
 
 In December, Aetna said it would cut its work force by an additional 6,000 workers.

National Auto Credit Inc. announced that it had discontinued operations of its ZoomLot subsidiary. The company's decision followed an extensive strategic review of ZoomLot's prospects in light of various factors, including the evolving market conditions of the used car dealer and financing industries, the current market demand for and penetration of ZoomLot's e-commerce solution, current operating losses and forecasts of future operating results and the availability of other strategic opportunities. The company previously announced that it had written down the goodwill associated with ZoomLot's assets.
Airborne Inc. announced that it will cut approximately 640 employees representing 2.5% of its total work force.

Alaska Air Group Inc. proceeds to cut 900 jobs and close its Oakland, Calif., maintenance facility in an effort to cut costs. Many of the jobs are being cut as the carriers hire outside vendors to perform heavy maintenance work, clean the planes and handle some customer service activities.

Alaska Air Group Inc. announced earnings results for the second quarter of 2008. For the quarter, the company reported loss of $14.1 million, after special items.The company plans to cut 850 to 1,000 Jobs, including flight crews, mechanics and agents between November and early 2009. In August, the company shed 80 management positions. The company reported that, it will trim capacity by 8% in the coming months due to high fuel prices, a slowing economy and tough West Coast competition. The capacity cuts will lead to 15% fewer departures and a work force reduction of 9% to 10%.

Alberto-Culver Co. announced a reorganization that will eliminate about 90 jobs and result in restructuring charges of approximately $13 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2007 and $3 million in the second quarter. The reorganization follows Alberto-Culver's recent spin off of Sally Beauty Holdings Inc. (sbh) into a separate, publicly traded company.

Alberto-Culver Co. plans to close a Toronto manufacturing plant by the end of its fiscal second, eliminating about 115 jobs. As a result of the closing, the company expects to record pretax restructuring and other charges of about $8 million in fiscal 2008, of which about $6 million will be recognized in the first quarter. The majority of production at the plant will be shifted to other manufacturing facilities. The new charges include $4 million for fixed asset impairments, $2 million in severance and other employee benefits, and $2 million of other exit costs, including costs to transfer equipment to other Alberto-Culver plants.

New Albertsons Inc. is closing its grocery store in Dickinson later February 2008. The Dickinson outlet has about 60 employees, with about 45 of them full time. The company is offering transfers if it has openings elsewhere. The company issued a statement saying the closing is an effort to maximize its return on invested capital.

Albertsons LLC announced that it has begun closing 100 low-performing grocery stores in 12 U.S. states. The 100 stores, set to close by early August, comprise 16.2% of the company's units but only 9% of sales.
Albertson's Inc. will close three unprofitable grocery stores on the South Side as part of its restructuring efforts. The stores employ 240 people.

New Albertsons Inc. has announced plans to close its Temple City store at 5595 Rosemead Blvd. The closure date is slated for April 2009. Albertsons has also announced the closing of stores in Rancho Cucamonga, Lancaster, Lakewood, Cathedral City and San Diego. The chain has 278 stores in Southern California.
According to unconfirmed reports, Albertsons Inc. laid off about 90 workers at its headquarters this week, apparently as part of its campaign to cut $750 million in costs by the end of next year.

New Albertsons Inc. announced that it has notified the state that it will be closing its store at 1901 Military Trail, in West Palm Beach, and laying off 87 employees. The company also plans to close a store in Ocala, where 107 people will be let go. Publix has announced it would be holding job fairs and interviewing the estimated 5,000 Albertsons workers whose jobs are being eliminated.
Albertsons Inc. officials met with employees in Idaho, Utah and Montana to outline a management restructuring that will eliminate about 50 jobs across the three states.

New Albertsons Inc. store in East Whittier will close on July 24, 2008. The 30,000 square-foot store, 15055 Mulberry Drive, opened in 1970 as a Lucky's market. It was converted to an Albertsons in the 1990s. Albertsons still has stores in nearby La Habra, La Mirada and Whittier.
Alcan Inc. announced that it will close one foil plant and two packaging plants in North America in an effort to lower costs and increase profits amid a downturn in demand.

Alcan Inc. expects to close a regional head office in Chicago and two administrative offices in Europe as it looks to find savings from its purchase of French aluminium producer Pechiney SA last year.

Alcan Inc. may close its Saguenay alumina refinery in Quebec if costs aren't reduced. The plant's closure may be considered by 2007 if improvements aren't made, the news agency quoted Claude Patry, the president of a union affiliated with the Canadian Auto Workers union.

Alcan (al) announced that it was looking to cut approximately 520 jobs and close three plants as part of its efforts to restructure nine European sites. Alcan, which said it has begun consultations with employee representatives, said it planned to close three plants in Belgium, France and Italy, sell two other plants in France and downsize sites in Italy, Czech Republic, France and Switzerland.

Alcan Inc. may shutter some of its tobacco, food and beauty packaging plants in Europe and eliminate about 350 jobs as part of a restructuring plan. The company has proposed closing two food packaging plants in Germany, cutting 211 jobs, as a result of weakening demand in the region and overcapacity in the western European food packaging market. Under the restructuring, Alcan would also shut an Amsterdam tobacco packaging facility with 47 employees and reorganize its beauty packaging operations, which could lead to about 100 job cuts in several European countries. In addition, Alcan said it is considering selling its beauty packaging plant in Provins, France, where it employs 168 workers, as well as its food packaging plant in Zaragoza, Spain, where it employs 152 people.

Alcan Inc. will close its Plastic & Laminate Tubes plant in Lincoln Park, New Jersey (USA) as part of the continued optimization of its Tubes manufacturing network in the Americas to better serve its customers. With 2005 revenues of $17 million, the Lincoln Park plant manufactures plastic and laminate tubes primarily for the cosmetics market. Production will be transferred to the nearby facility in Washington, New Jersey and to the facility in Reynosa, Mexico depending on product specifications. In both cases, plans have been made to ensure a smooth transition for customers. This closure is expected to be completed by the end of January, 2007. A variety of support programs have been developed to assist the 71 affected employees during this period.

Rio Tinto Alcan (Alcan) has laid off 28 people at its plant in the southeast Nebraska town of Syracuse. Nebraska Department of Labor officials say the 28 had worked at Alcan Global Pharmaceutical Packaging. That leaves 68 still on the local payroll, down from 150 in 2002.

Alcan Global Aerospace, Transportation and Industry (ATI), part of Alcan Engineered Products-a business unit of Rio Tinto Alcan will implement a workforce reduction plan at its Ravenswood facility in West Virginia. The plan is expected to impact 168 roles (140 permanent and 28 temporary employees) and is based on Alcan Global ATI's current vision of the economic conditions weakening the aerospace and general engineering markets. The complete adaptation program is a combination of non-workforce related cost-cutting measures and a reduction of approximately 15% of the current workforce. It also takes into account the strategic decision in 2007 to exit the brazed aluminum sheet market and focus on higher added value products.

Rio Tinto Alcan announced that about 140 jobs will be cut at Maison Alcan, the Montreal head office of the company, between mid-April and Dec. 31, 2009. Staff have been notified of the job losses as has the provincial government. The job cuts will 'touch every function' within the head office, where there are now about 645 permanent positions. The company is still deciding exactly which positions will be cut.

Rio Tinto Alcan Inc. is shedding 350 jobs in France to reduce costs as it reorganizes to address a deteriorating competitive position. The job losses will be spread among seven French locations. Initial efforts will be to reduce employment through voluntary departures.
Ikon Office Solutions Inc. has announced that it will close its telephone dispatching center in Chesterfield thereby laying off 24 employees.

IKON Office Solutions Inc. announced that it has discontinued its Business Document Services unit, Mimeo.com and announced an IKON Conversion Program offering affected customers instant access to Mimeo.com services.

Alexander & Baldwin Inc. provided earnings guidance for the first quarter of fiscal 2009. For the period, the company expects performance to be negatively impacted by increased weakness in its transportation segments and by workforce reduction restructuring costs. Net income is expected to approximate break-even in the quarter, and is expected to include two commercial property sales currently in escrow and a workforce restructuring charge of $5-6 million. These results may be further impacted by market conditions and the timing of the aforementioned property sales.

In anticipation of these earnings challenges, the company took deliberate steps to strengthen its cost and capital structure. The company reducing its non-union workforce by approximately 10%, which is expected to save about $8 million annually.

The shipping company serving Hawaii will end its molasses operation in the state and pay millions of dollars as compensation for spilling 1,400 tons of the sugary substance in Honolulu Harbor. State Attorney General Doug Chin on Wednesday called the $15.4 million settlement with Matson Navigation Co. for an environmental violation. Matson is also agreeing to cease its molasses operation in Hawaii and pay for removal of its molasses tanks and any remaining molasses. The company will pay $5.9 million to the state, and the costs related to ending the molasses operation are estimated between $5.5 million and $9.5 million, which would put the total settlement amount between $11.4 million and $15.4 million. The 2013 spill killed more than 26,000 fish and other marine life. The molasses oozed from a section of pipe that Matson thought had been sealed. The sticky molasses suffocated marine life and discolored the water as it sank to the bottom of the harbor. The spill, in an industrial area about 5 miles west of Waikiki's hotels and beaches, shut down much of Honolulu Harbor for nearly two weeks. Reaching a settlement allowed the state to avoid a lawsuit that would have taken years to resolve in court.
Honeywell announced that it plans to layoff 5,500 employees as part of the company's plan to cut costs.

Honeywell International Inc. announced it expects to generate incremental pretax savings of around $800 million in 2002 as a result of 1,300 previously announced job cuts and plant closings in Minnesota and elsewhere. These layoffs are expected to be completed by March 3.
Honeywell has announced that it plans to layoff 180 employees at its plant in Mars Hill over the next 15 months as it relocates assembly operations to Mexico.

Honeywell International Inc. plans to shut down its underused aviation manufacturing plant in Teterboro, shift some operations elsewhere and sell the property to a development company. Honeywell has a proposed agreement to sell the 68-year-old manufacturing plant - a key parts factory during World War II - to Catellus Development Group. The plant's manufacturing work is to be transferred a factory in Albuquerque with similar operations.

Honeywell International Inc. will close a Sarasota County plant that makes speed and direction sensors, costing Southwest Florida another 125 manufacturing jobs. The first phase of the plant's closing will begin as early as this summer and will be completed sometime next year. Work will be moved to Freeport, Ill., or to Juarez, Mexico.

Honeywell International Inc. (Honeywell Turbo Technologies) announced that up to 100 employees of Honeywell in Waterford City are to be made redundant. Talks with the Technical Engineering and Electrical Union are due to begin shortly over the proposal to cut between 80 and 100 staff by the end of the year.

Honeywell International Inc. is seeking a further 50 job cuts on top of 100 which were announced in July. The company is also introducing short-time working until Christmas at least. The firm said that due to instability and continued declines in demand in the car market, an additional 50 jobs were at risk, as well as a possibility for other action to address the loss of volume.

Honeywell Hobbs expects to complete the phase-out of its Springfield manufacturing plant and eliminate approximately 120 jobs by the end of the year. The closing would end the company's more than 70-year run in Springfield. A second plant in Spring Valley, about 60 miles northeast of Peoria, will be shut down by midyear. Both operations are moving to Juarez, Mexico.

Honeywell International Inc. announced that it will close its Cranston plant by the end of next year 2016. The company, which makes safety equipment at the Cranston plant, said it will phase out operations starting later this year, ending in 2016. Manufacturing and distribution employees will be laid off, but non-production employees will be moved to Honeywell's Smithfield site.

Honeywell International Inc. has laid off at least 9,929 people worldwide in its repositioning in the wake of the recession from the Covid-19 pandemic. That is about an 8.8% reduction in what had been a 113,000 person workforce at the beginning of the year.
Alltel Corporations said that it will reduce its workforce by 1,000 employees through a combination of early retirements and layoffs. It is not targeting one specific department.

Alltel announced that it is closing its call center in Raleigh, laying off 125 employees by June 7, 2002. The company is also closing four other call centers in Bedford, Ohio, Grand Island, Nebraska, Tallahassee, Florida, and Kittanning, Pennsylvania as i
Alltel Corp. plans to eliminate about 160 jobs in Lincoln and southeast Nebraska on June 30, 2003.

Alltel Corp. announced that it will eliminate as many as 600 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force. The elimination of between 400 and 600 positions comes as Alltel makes regional and corporate structural changes expected to be in place late next month.

Alltel Corp. announced that it expects to earn between $3.10 and $3.30 per share for 2004 on revenue growth of between 2 percent and 5 percent. Analysts were looking for earnings of $3.24 a share for the year.

Alltel announced it would buy back $750 million of its shares, about 5 percent of outstanding shares at current prices.

Alltel Corp. announced that it is cutting 40 people from its Nebraska work force, part of the telephone company's elimination of 600 jobs systemwide. Thirty jobs were cut from among 700 positions in the Lincoln area and 10 from among 300 elsewhere in Nebraska.

Skyworks Solutions Inc., the newly formed wireless semiconductor company, will begin life after its merger Wednesday by cutting 350 workers to trim costs. Skyworks which began trading Wednesday on the Nasdaq Stock Market under the ticker symbol SWKS, will close a test and assembly facility in Haverhill, Mass., by the end of 2002. Skyworks said the work force cuts represent about 8 percent, or 350 workers, and will lower its number of employees to 3,850 from about 4,200.
 
 
 
 Some of these operations will be transferred to the company's wafer fabrication facility in Woburn, Mass., as well as to Skyworks' high-volume assembly and test operation in Mexicali, Mexico. The company's Newport Beach, Calif., facilities will be consolidated into one location in Irvine, Calif. In addition, the company will close the Frederick, Md., facility operated by its subsidiary, Trans-Tech Inc. and fold the operation into the nearby Adamstown, Md. location by the end of this year.
Skyworks has announced that the company has laid off 100 additional employees.

Alcoa Primary Metals (Alcoa Inc. ) will eliminate 110 jobs at its East Smelter plant in northern New York, but officials said that a new power contract and a joint labor-management restructuring effort would allow the plant to continue operations. The cuts will include both hourly and salaried jobs. The plant has 550 workers.

Alcoa Inc. announced plansto cut 8,000 jobs this year and sell several less profitable, noncore businesses. In addition to the job cuts, which account for 6 percent of the company's global work force and come on top of 10,000 cuts in 2002.

Alcoa Inc. announced that it is laying off 200 of the 600 workers at its Intalco aluminum smelter and cutting production in half because of high electricity costs. The Pittsburgh-based company initially planned to close the plant near Bellingham on Sept. 30, but delayed the decision until Wednesday to give elected officials and others in the region time to work to mitigate a rate increase from the BPA.

Alcoa Inc. will cut 400 jobs and will not reopen an aluminum smelter in Washington due to a labor impasse. Alcoa will record a pretax charge of $20 million in the third quarter to pay for the layoffs. Workers have refused the make the concessions, including a contribution to health care plans that amounted to an average of $72 per month.

Alcoa Inc. laid off 12 workers and expects to let another eight go in the near future because of a seven-week strike that has slashed output. The process technicians and office workers are part of the Syndicat des employees de l'Aluminerie de Becancour, the same union that launched the strike on July 7 over job security, outsourcing and pension.
Alcoa Inc. will close its KAMA Global plant in Elyria by Sept. 30, eliminating 66 jobs. The plant southwest of Cleveland makes plastic sheeting for deli trays and clamshell sandwich containers.

Alcoa Inc. has announced plans to close its unprofitable Swansea facility, with the loss of nearly 300 jobs. The Swansea site, acquired by Alcoa in 1968, is primarily a producer of tab ends for aluminium cans. The company said it plans to close the facility next March with the loss of 298 jobs.

Alcoa Inc. announced that thirty seven workers have lost their jobs at a production company in south-west Victoria. The workers made redundant by Kelcar Materials Management had worked at the Alcoa Inc. The job losses are on top of at least 18 redundancies announced by Alcoa last week, when it said it was reducing aluminium production.

Alcoa Inc. plans to slash its quarterly dividend. The company is reducing its quarterly dividend to 3 cents a share from 17 cents.The company plans to cut costs by more than $2.4 billion annually by 2010. The company plans to lay off about 13% of its global workforce by the end of 2009, further cut production and spending, and sell four of its subsidiaries.
Alcoa Inc. said it plans to cut 13,500 jobs, or 13% of the workforce, because of the global slowdown.

Alcoa, Inc. is eliminating 90 jobs at its operations in the Smoky Mountains foothills. Workers were told the cuts affect the can sheet operations in the Rigid Packaging Division. The latest layoffs come a year after ALCOA eliminated 450 jobs and stopped production on two pot lines, also in the city of Alcoa. The company also announced that it was cutting 145 jobs at its plant in Evansville, Ind.

Alcoa Inc. announced Portovesme aluminium smelter in Italy has been completely closed, marking a key step in the company's schedule of capacity curtailments. The smelter was slated for closure in a plan to reduce company global output by 12%. The closure removes 150,000 tonnes of capacity, and accounts for most of the 240,000 tonnes of the company's European output slated for closure.

Alcoa Inc. announced it is postponing construction of a new potline at its Baie-Comeau smelter in Quebec as part of a revised modernization plan for the smelter, but will begin preparations for the upgrade by investing $100 million in the smelter over the next three years and by permanently closing the plant's two Soderberg potlines. The new potline is now expected to be in service in 2019 instead of 2016, subject to board approval. The change is due to current market conditions. The $100 million investment includes $30 million that will be used to upgrade the plant's casthouse facilities in support of the growing automotive market. This is in addition to the $75 million already dedicated to rebuild the port facilities to better meet the future needs of a modernized plant. The closure of the two Soderberg potlines, which are among the highest-cost smelting capacity in the Alcoa system, will be complete in August. The two lines represent 105,000 metric tons of capacity, and are part of the 460,000 metric tons of smelting capacity Alcoa announced was under review on May 1.

Alcoa Inc. announced it will permanently close the remaining two potlines at its Massena East smelter in New York in the first quarter of 2014. The decision was made because the potlines are no longer competitive. Alcoa operates two facilities in Massena - Massena West, an integrated aluminum smelting and fabricating facility, and Massena East, a smelting and casthouse facility. The company will work with local unions to minimize the impact on jobs. Massena West will continue to operate. The closure will reduce Alcoa's smelting capacity by 84,000 metric tons. Alcoa expects the total restructuring-related charges for the first quarter of 2014 associated with the closure to be between $60 and $70 million after-tax, or 6 cents per share, of which about 40% is non-cash.

Alcoa Inc. will close one of its upstate NY aluminum manufacturing plants, eliminating 332 jobs. The company, notified the state Department of Labor, that it will begin closing the factory in April. Fifty employees are expected to be retained for up to two years while Alcoa decommissions the plant. Alcoa said the factory in Massena, NY, St. Lawrence County, is no longer competitive. The aluminum maker plans to keep its other Massena plant running. That factory employs 670 people.

Alcoa Inc. announced that it will close an aluminum smelter and two mills in Australia by the end of the year. Alcoa announced that it has been studying options for a 50-year-old smelter in Geelong, Victoria, for two years and will close it in August. The smelter has about 500 workers. A rolling mill near the smelter and another mill and recycling center in Yennora, New South Wales, will close by year end. They employ an additional 480 people. Faced with stubbornly low prices for aluminum due to global overcapacity, Alcoa has been idling and closing smelters to reduce capacity.

Alcoa's aluminium smelter in Victoria will be shuttered from August 1, 2014, the factory closing after more than 40 years of operation. The final production lines will be cleared and the workforce will clock off for the final time. About 500 workers have lost their jobs. The company has announced it will close its Point Henry smelter, a rolling mill in Geelong and its Yennora rolling mill and recycling facility in NSW, by the end of 2014.

Alcoa announced it has laid off about 50 workers at its Technical Center in Westmoreland County as part of an internal reorganization. The affected employees received severance pay and help finding new jobs. Following the cuts, Alcoa employs more than 550 at the research center and a total of about 2,000 in the region.

Hess Corporation announced the plans to close its London office, following pressure from activist investor Elliott Management to break up the business for shareholders' benefit. Employees at the $23 billion market cap company's London operation, Hess Limited, have been put on a 90-day consultation period. Subject to the outcome of the consultation, the London business, which focuses on UK oil and gas exploration and production, will cease trading by the end of the year.

American Electric Power Co. Inc. said it would reduce its trading and wholesale marketing operation. AEP is reducing its exposure to speculative energy trading markets. He did not offer a number or range on the job cuts.
American Electric Power Company Inc. in announcing huge losses Friday for the fourth quarter and entire year of 2002, sCompany also announces that it has eliminated 1,300 jobs.

American Electric Power (AEP) announced that it would close and downsize three plants in Ohio at a loss of 157 jobs, to comply with the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) new coal-fire plant regulations.

American Express Co. announced that it is cutting 5,500 to 6,500 more jobs, mostly because of the drop-off in travel since the Sept. 11 attacks. The slump has hurt the company's travel-planning services, which include vacation-package sales and online plane ticketing. The layoffs come on top of 7,700 cuts previously announced this year. Altogether, the 13,200 to 14,200 jobs eliminated amount to a 15 percent reduction in the American Express work force, which totaled 88,500 at the start of 2001.

The company also warned that its earnings in the October-December period are likely to be in a range of 34 cents to 36 cents per share, below the 40 cents expected by analysts.

The American Express Company said that its fourth-quarter profit fell 56 percent as fewer people traveled by air after the terrorist attacks in September. Net income dropped to $297 million, or 22 cents a share, compared with $677 million, or 50 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. For all 2001, the company reported net income of $1.31 billion, down 53 percent from 2000 and the first decline since 1994. Net income in the travel and card subsidiary fell 64 percent, to $170 million, and the company said it set aside more money for credit card losses. The fourth-quarter results fell short of analysts' expectations of 23 cents a share in profit, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.

American Express is eliminating about 15 percent of its work force and cutting expenses as it deals with an economic slowdown that has hurt its credit card and asset management businesses. American Express said severance and related costs to eliminate about 6,800 jobs reduced profit in the quarter by $279 million before taxes. But the company also said it would save $280 million in 2002 from those cuts.
American Express plans to cut about 2,000 technology employees including about 1,500 workers at its U.S. data centers and about 500 workers at American Express facilities overseas.
American Express Co.  has notified the state that it will lay off 124 employees on Central Avenue in St. Petersburg by early 2016.

American Greetings Corp. announced closing one Tennessee plant and transferring the work to another facility. It spent six months studying what to do with three Tennessee PlusMark plants, subsidiaries that make holiday gift wrap, boxed cards and accessories. The closing of the Franklin plant, which employs about 450 people, will begin immediately, according to a statement from Cleveland-based American Greetings.

American Greetings Corp. has announced that it reached a deal with party goods maker Amscan Inc. and will stop making its own party goods. The move will result in a plant closing and about 225 facility-related job cuts. The Kalamazoo facility employs 225 people. Approximately 12 jobs will also be eliminated from the company's Cleveland headquarters. All of the positions are expected to be phased out between December and March.

Wyeth announced that it is discontinuing clinical development of PTP-112. The decision was based on unsatisfactory Phase II clinical efficacy, as well as the occurrence of dose-limiting side effects among several trial participants. The Company has notified all clinical trial investigators and has provided instructions regarding patient follow-up. The Company also has informed the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).
Wyeth has announced that it plans to layoff employees in an effort to cut costs.

Wyeth said it has trimmed its Marietta work force by more than half since November, leaving roughly 700 people remaining on the job here. The company last fall announced that it planned to stop making influenza vaccine and that it intended to lay off part of the work force here. Company spokesman Doug Petkus said Wednesday that somewhere between 800 and 900 people were laid off. The payroll cuts in Lancaster County are part of Wyeths overall staff reduction of 3,150 worldwide.

Drug maker Wyeth will shut down a biopharmaceutical plant in Berkeley and lay off about 300 workers. The plant makes ReFacto, a drug used to treat hemophilia. Production will be consolidated at a plant in Stockholm, Sweden. The company plans to lay off about two-thirds of employees by mid-February and most of the rest by mid-April, Antonacci said. last month, Wyeth laid off about 100 employees here as part of cost-cutting efforts.

Wyeth announced that it is to lay off 250 workers at its Wyeth Medica facility in Co. Kildare as part of a rationalisation programme. Wyeth said it had experienced a reduced demand for several products manufactured at the plant.

Wyeth confirmed it is eliminating or contracting out an undetermined number of jobs in Chester County, part of an ongoing cost-cutting effort. The drug-maker employs about 5,000 people in Chester and Montgomery counties, with global pharmaceutical division based in Collegeville. It has about 52,000 employees worldwide, headquartered in Madison, N.J.Christopher Garland, a Wyeth spokesman, called the job cuts limited in scope but said the exact number to be eliminated or outsourced was not yet known. The cuts, implemented on the advice of the consulting firm Accenture, are part of a campaign announced in June 2005 that also involved cutting or outsourcing about 15% - or roughly 750 - of sales jobs.

Wyeth announced that it will lay off 124 workers at its facility in Sanford. The company said that the cuts represent about 10% of the jobs at the site, where it has more than 1,000 workers. The Sanford campus manufactures vaccines including Prevnar, which protects against common bacterial diseases. Wyeth is going through a period of cost-cutting that will see the company shed roughly 10% of its global work force, or 5,000 jobs, over a long-term time frame. Various job functions were affected in the layoff. Affected workers will be given severance packages as well as job placement and counseling services.

A Plymouth Meeting home-mortgage finance company owned by American International Group Inc. to cut 335 jobs by the end of this year as it stops buying loans from brokers and makes fewer loans to consumers. The cuts are the latest step in AIG's retreat from the business of investing in loans to home buyers with bad credit and high debt.

American International Group announced that about 50 Tampa Bay workers were laid, as the company announced nationwide office closures and job cuts. AIG was shuttering all but four of its financial network offices in the United States, effective immediately.

American International Group (AIG) announced in July 2017 its plans to reduce its staff in Vilnius by 214. At the end of June 2017, AIG said was moving its service center operations out of Vilnius, with plans to relocate its operations to other countries of the AIG network by March 2018.

American Standard Companies Inc. announced that it will cut 286 jobs as it reorganizes its European bath and kitchen fittings operations. The company reported in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission it expects the moves to cost about $9 million in the second quarter 2005.
According to unnamed sources, AT&T Corp. announced that the company is eliminating 22 supervisory jobs at its Local Network Services Center in East Mesa.
AT&T Corp. announced cutting of 10,000 jobs at the nation's largest long-distance carrier and cable television provider.

AT&T Corp. plans to shut a customer service center in downtown Kansas City due to declining call volume, eliminating 179 jobs. The call center will close Sept. 13. The move, part of a plan announced in January to cut 5,000 jobs nationally, comes less than two months after AT&T laid off 63 employees at the center.

AT&T Corp. said Monday it will slash 3,500 jobs in its business services division and take $1.5 billion in fourth-quarter charges, mainly to reflect losses on investments in its Latin America subsidiary.AT&T had disclosed last month that it would be cutting jobs in the business division but had not revealed the number, which represents nearly 5 percent of the phone company's work force.

AT&T Corp. seeking to expedite its decision-making process, said it began streamlining its organizational structure, which will result in some job changes and losses. The company declined to say how many jobs would be lost but that it doesn't expect to incur any charges from the streamlining. AT&T said it's still assessing the amount of money it will save from the changes. This effort is separate from AT&T's announcement in January that it was cutting 3,500 jobs, primarily at its business-services division.
According to AT&T's Chief Financial Officer Thomas Horton, AT&T Corp. will probably eliminate 5,000 more jobs, or about 7 percent of its workforce, as prices and demand fall.

AT&T Corp. expects to save roughly $650 million in 2004 from its job cuts, according to a regulatory filing. The telecommunications giant has virtually completed its 10 percent reduction in work force this year, bringing the number of employees to roughly 65,000 from 71,000, the Securities and Exchange Commission filing said.

AT&T Corp. announced that it is reducing its work force by 12 percent instead of a previously announced 10 percent. The nation's largest long-distance carrier began the year with 71,000 employees, meaning roughly 8,500 jobs are being cut.

AT&T Corp. eliminated 229 jobs at its Syracuse call center. The company, citing a policy not to discuss specific job cuts, declined comment. The cuts were confirmed by workers and union officials at Local 1152 of the Communication Workers of America.

AT&T Corp. announced that it would cut 94 jobs at its Station Square customer service center and 35 positions at its Grant Street location on June 17. AT&T is planning to cut 5,100 jobs across its system this year.

Amgen Inc. laid off 23 workers in Colorado as part of the company's efforts to reduce costs. Amgen's sites in Longmont and Boulder fared well in the round of cuts compared with the firm's Thousand Oaks, Calif., headquarters and offices in Rhode Island, which bore the brunt of the 1,500 layoffs. In addition to the cuts, about 700 Amgen workers nationwide took a voluntary transition package.

Amgen Inc. that cut spending and staff. The cuts were in response to reduced revenue after anemia drug safety concerns led to warning labels and reduced use of the company's top-selling drug. The company offered voluntary buyouts to about 700 employees and laid off about 1,350 workers throughout the company. About 675 of the layoffs were in Thousand Oaks. The company did not break down the voluntary buyouts by location. Amgen previously had about 8,200 employees in Thousand Oaks; it now has about 6,800.Countrywide Financial Corp. announced it would cut up to 12,000 jobs in response to the housing slump and shakeout in subprime lending. Countrywide has headquarters in Calabasas. In October, Countrywide had 7,100 employees in Ventura County and Westlake Village. By the end of November, it had 6,300.

Amgen Inc. that cut spending and staff. The cuts were in response to reduced revenue after anemia drug safety concerns led to warning labels and reduced use of the company's top-selling drug. The company offered voluntary buyouts to about 700 employees and laid off about 1,350 workers throughout the company. About 675 of the layoffs were in Thousand Oaks. The company did not break down the voluntary buyouts by location. Amgen previously had about 8,200 employees in Thousand Oaks; it now has about 6,800.Countrywide Financial Corp. announced it would cut up to 12,000 jobs in response to the housing slump and shakeout in subprime lending. Countrywide has headquarters in Calabasas. In October, Countrywide had 7,100 employees in Ventura County and Westlake Village. By the end of November, it had 6,300.

Amgen Inc. will cut about 300 jobs and close a facility of its Onyx subsidiary in South San Francisco amid a restructuring of the biotechnology company's cancer business. About 250 field staff will be retained. In the restructuring, Amgen plans to combine its cancer business with the one it acquired by buying Onyx Pharmaceuticals for $10.4 billion in 2013.

Amgen announced plans to move 100 employees from its headquarters in Thousand Oaks to offices in San Francisco and Cambridge, Mass. Amgen did not provide a break down of how many workers would go to each city, but the move is part of a larger restructuring that also laid off 500 California workers at its headquarters. Amgen employs around 5,500 people in Thousand Oaks, but will roll out the layoffs over the next 12 to 18 months, while relocating 100 to the Bay Area and Massachusetts to join teams with whom they already work.

Analog Devices Inc. announced that it is shutting down its 30-person digital signal processing operation in Austin. Workers were notified on December 2, 2008, of the job cuts which are scheduled to take place through the first quarter 2009.
Analogic Corporation announced that it lay off about 70 workers, representing 4% of its work force, due to slowing business.
Analysts International Corporation has eliminated about 80 administrative and management positions to lower overheads and contain costs.

The Andrew Corporation, a maker of wireless network components, said that it had higher net income and sales in its fiscal third-quarter and that profit might beat analysts' estimates. It also said it would cut 400 jobs as a result of its purchase of Allen Telecom.

The Andersons, Inc. announced its retail store in Northwood will close in February 2013. The mall's closing last December and the building's continuing deterioration led to the decision. The store will operate as usual through the end of 2012, then begin a 60-day store liquidation.

The Andersons, Inc. announced its plans to exit the retail business and close its remaining four retail stores in the second quarter of 2017. The retail closings will have no impact on the company's grain, ethanol, plant nutrient and rail operations. The closing will eliminate approximately 650 positions in the Toledo area and 400 positions in Columbus, of which approximately 75% are part-time positions. The company will provide employees with severance packages and outplacement services to assist them in their career transitioning.

The Andersons Inc. announced that it would close all four of its superstores in the Columbus and Toledo, Ohio areas and exit the retail business. Its stores, located in Maumee, Ohio, Toledo and in two locations in Columbus, would close in the second quarter which begins in April.

Anheuser-Busch plans to lay off dozens of people at its Newark brewery. The Newark brewery's general manager, said 60 hourly positions are being cut because the company has decided to stop producing a bottle line at the site. The exact date of the planned layoffs has not been determined, but the company is aiming for the end of the quarter. The company would meet with employees on each shift Tuesday to discuss the layoffs. It is also talking with local union leadership about the changes.
According to unnamed sources, Apple Computers plans to layoff an undisclosed number of employees.

Apple Inc. is eliminating 174 sales and support jobs at its Elk Grove facility and transferring the work to a site in Austin, Texas. Apple says the laid off workers will be given opportunities to relocate or apply for another Apple job in Elk Grove. Apple employs more than 1,100 workers in Elk Grove.

Apple (AAPL) named Beats Music CEO Ian Rogers to head up iTunes Radio but will keep the Beats Music brand for the time being.Apple is also eliminating about 200 of Beats' 700 full-time jobs, but will place some of those displaced workers elsewhere within Apple.
Applied Materials announced the implementation off lay-offs due to a decrease in capital.

Applied Materials Inc. said Tuesday that the semiconductor equipment company has dismissed as many as 150 employees in Austin, about 6 percent of the local work force. Several Applied workers said Tuesday that as many as 150 jobs were cut. Applied, the worlds largest maker of chip manufacturing equipment, laid off 200 workers in Austin in early November as part of a companywide reduction of 1,750 workers.
Applied Materials Inc. has announced a reduction in the workforce and the consolidation of facilities during the third fiscal quarter, 2003.

Applied Materials Inc. announced a global cost reduction plan that primarily affects its semiconductor equipment and services businesses and related support organizations. As part of the plan the company will reduce its global workforce by approximately 1,000 positions or about 7%, through a combination of job elimination and attrition. Applied expects to record charges of approximately $20 million related to the plan, with the majority of the charges being recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 2008, and to complete the plan by the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008. The plan is expected to result in annualized savings of about $150 million from fiscal 2007 spending levels.

Applied Materials Inc. reported that it intends on cutting about 12% of its workforce or about 1,800 jobs, as part of efforts to reduce its overall expenses by $400 million annually. The company would make the job cuts 'through a combination of attrition, voluntary separation and other workforce reduction programs'.

The company expects its first-quarter of fiscal 2009 revenue to fall between 25% and 35% from its fourth quarter, and that its earnings will be between breakeven and 4 cents a share. Such a forecast results in a revenue range of $1.33 billion to $1.53 billion.

Applied Materials Inc. announced a plan to realign its global workforce and enhance its ability to invest for growth. Applied will implement a voluntary retirement program and other workforce reduction actions that are expected to affect approximately 900 to 1,300 positions, or 6% to 9% of its global workforce.

Applied Materials, Inc. has notified state and local officials it cut 20 jobs in Austin. The workers have been notified and the cuts are permanent, according to a Sept. 18 letter to the Texas Workforce Commission.
Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. announced that it has laid off 178 employees. The reason for the layoffs is that it recently acquired Farmland Industries Inc.

The Archer Daniels Midland Company announced that it will discontinue operations indefinitely at its Savannah, Georgia cocoa processing plant, effective April 1, 2002. This facility, acquired in 1997 from ED&F Man Company, produced cocoa butter and cocoa powder and will continue to be used as a warehouse. This plant closure is part of ADM's continuing review of all manufacturing assets. ADM is committed to improve returns by closing under-performing plants.

The Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. announced that it will discontinue operations indefinitely at its Koscian, Poland cocoa processing plant, effective July 15, 2002. This facility was acquired in 1997 and produces cocoa butter, powder and liquor. The site will continue to be used as a warehouse. This plant closure is part of ADM's continuing review of all manufacturing assets. ADM is committed to improve returns by closing under-performing plants.

Archer Daniels Midland Company announced that it will discontinue operations at its Baltimore, Maryland export grain elevator. Under the terms of a forty-year lease agreement with the Maryland Port Administration, ADM has operated the export grain elevator facility. During June 2001, a part of the pier collapsed into the water. This collapse severely impacted operation of the elevator and prevented export operations. Negotiations between ADM and MPA for restoration of the pier and extension of the lease agreement have been unsuccessful.

Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. announced that it will discontinue operations indefinitely at its soybean crushing and refining operation in Tres Passos, Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, effective immediately. The plant closure is due to poor crushing margins.

Archer-Daniels-Midland Co. announced that the plant was no longer viable due to intense international competition. 150 jobs are to be lost following the closure of a plant. This plant has been in operation since the early 1970s and was acquired by the US-based ADM in 1990. The closure of the plant will begin immediately and will take over a month to complete.

Archer Daniels Midland Company was eliminating 175 jobs in Decatur, the layoffs are effective immediately. The cuts come after 160 employees in Decatur have accepted ADM's voluntary early retirement offer. Earlier 2012, company announced plans to cut its total workforce by about 3%. The reductions in Decatur are helping the company meet its goal of cutting its global workforce by 1,000 jobs. The company will help employees losing their jobs work on their resumes and search for new positions. They'll also receive severance packages. The eliminated positions represent less than 4% of ADM's employees in Decatur.

Arrow Electronics Inc. is eliminating 100 jobs by closing its Lenexa assembly plant early next year, with some of the operations transferring to a new facility in Mexico.The company is opening a new plant in Nogales, Mexico, where most of the Lenexa plant's inventory will be transferred. Some of the Lenexa facility's equipment and operations will be transferred to an existing Phoenix site.

Arrow Electronics Inc. has eliminated about 150 jobs in North America, including 12 on the Island. The jobs eliminated, mostly back-office and sales positions, were at 44 locations in the United States and Canada. The company is attempting to find new positions at Arrow for people whose jobs have been eliminated.

Arrow Electronics Inc. announce that it will lay off 100 employees from its Melville headquarters in 2010. Arrow filed a notice with the New York State Labor Department that it would lay off nonunion workers in stages beginning in late January 2010, with the largest group, 45, to be terminated in July 2009. The company cited economic reasons for the change. A total of 543 employees work at the corporate office.

Arrow Electronics Inc. is closing its St. Paul facility and laying off the location's 77 employees. The asset disposition facility at 2299 Territorial Road will close March 27, 2015 the same date that layoffs will start. The remaining jobs will be eliminated in rounds scheduled for April 30, May 30, June 30 and September 30, 2015.
Ashland Inc. has announced that it will close its London office and will eliminate more jobs as a part of its plan to cut costs.

Ashland Inc. reported earnings results for the first quarter ended December 31, 2008. The company sales and operating revenue of $1,966 million, $238 million of which related to the acquired Hercules businesses; an operating loss of $7 million; and a net loss of $119 million, or $1.73 per share. In addition EBITDA were $65 million. A number of key items affected the quarter, including a $54 million loss or 51 cents earnings per share impact related to cross-currency swaps; a $32 million write-down or 45 cents earnings per share impact of auction rate securities; a $26 million severance charge or 29 cents earnings per share impact; and $31 million of nonrecurring purchase accounting adjustments 37 cents earnings per share impact. In addition to the above, the negative effect of certain other tax items increased the company's net loss by $25 million or 36 cents earnings per share impact.The company announced the elimination of approximately 500 employee positions through the end of the December quarter, with a total of 1,000 to be eliminated through fiscal 2009. By the end of fiscal 2010, the company should have reduced the global workforce by 1,300, or approximately 9% excluding the Valvoline retail employees.
Autodesk Inc. has announced that it plans to reduce its total workforce by approximately seven percent.

ADP has filed a notice that it will close its operation in Williamsville. The company filed a WARN notice on July 14, 2017 with the state Department of Labor, saying the office on Spindrift Drive will close on October 13, 2017. Layoffs involving 25 workers would begin on September 29.
Avery Dennison Corp. has announced that it plans to cut about 800 to 1000 jobs, or five percent of its combined workforce, by 2004.

Avery Dennison Corp. is planning to permanently shut down its Greensboro manufacturing facility and lay off 59 employees beginning in March, 2012. The company filed a notice with the N.C. Department of Commerce as part of a requirement by the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. The company expects to permanently eliminate job positions ranging from customer service representatives and machine operators to material handlers and managers. The company said it will close its facility located at 2100 Summit Ave. and relocate remaining operations to 2025 16th St. in Greensboro.
Avnet Inc. plans to cut more jobs and consolidate offices because of the sluggish technology market.
Avnet Inc. will cut about 500 jobs, 5 percent of its worldwide work force, and close a Chandler warehouse in a continuing effort to cut costs.

Avnet Inc. is closing one of its Texas facilities and moving its operations to a new facility in Chandler and another under construction in Nogales, Mexico. The company close its facility in Grapevine, Texas, just outside Dallas, over the next 18 months and transition a portion of the work for warehouse operations to Chandler and move its light assembly work across the boarder. The Grapevine facility employs about 370 people. They will be allowed to apply for other positions within the company. Chandler will pick up about 20 jobs with the transition, and the warehouse operations should see the change in March or April. There also will be a handful of management jobs at the Nogales facility.

Avnet Inc. plans to lay off 62 employees as it closes its Coppell facility. The company announced the plans in a recent Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) notice, which outlined the plans for the facility at 445 S. Royal Lane that employs 71 people. The company plans to keep six employees to help with wrap up-duties before laying them off Sept. 23. The remaining three will stay on board, but work from home or Avnet's Richardson facility. The closure also could impact Avnet's contract workers employed by Secure America and Regal Staffing Services. It is unclear whether the staffing companies will have alternative assignments for those who could be affected.

Avon Products Inc. announced that it will cut 2,400 jobs as part of its multiyear restructuring plan, which will cost more than originally expected and ultimately save the beauty products-maker $430 million annually. Avon unveiled its restructuring program in November 2005. It involved steep job cuts, the elimination of management layers and the realignment of manufacturing centers and outsourcing work to countries with cheaper labor costs. The restructuring plan will cost $530 million, up from a previous estimate of $500 million, of which $460 million will have been taken through the fourth quarter of 2007. The remainder will be recognized by the end of 2009. About 4,000 jobs globally will be cut by the restructuring, but new jobs will be created, resulting in a net reduction of 2,400 jobs. Avon expects it will save $430 million annually by 2011 or 2012.The company also said it will take a $110 million inventory write-off charge as part of its product-line simplification initiative.

The cosmetics company Avon Products Inc. said that it would close its plant in Montreal, eliminating about 150 jobs, as part of a restructuring program. The company said it would phase out its Montreal-based manufacturing operation by the first quarter of 2004, and transfer the production to Avon's larger plants in Springdale, Ohio, and Morton Grove, Ill.

Baker Hughes Inc. announced that it has started laying off a second round of employees. The company will cut another 1,500 jobs, or 4% of its work force. The additional reduction comes nearly two months after Baker Hughes announced it would lay off 1,500 employees. The company further reduced its employees in response to continued economic conditions and decreasing rig counts.
Baker Hughes Inc. announced that it is cutting 3,000 positions.

Baker Hughes Inc. will let go of more employees in December 2009 as part of an ongoing company reorganization. The company would lay off 62 people from its 15355 Vantage Parkway West location between Dec. 4 and Dec. 18. The jobs affected are mostly financial, and include accounting clerks and credit analysts.

Baker Hughes Inc. will close a plant at 2100 Industrial Blvd. in Alice, Texas, about 46 miles west of Corpus Christi. There is no work to be performed at the plant, Baker Hughes told the Texas Workforce Commission in a recent letter. The plant closure affects 51 employees. They will be paid for the 60-day period and benefits will continue for three months following the closure, which was expected to occur on or about Feb. 9. The eliminations are part of large-scale cuts the company is undergoing.
Baker Hughes Inc. decided to cut another 3,500 jobs in the first quarter, bringing total layoffs to 10,500, or 17% of its workforce.
Baker Hughes in the Four Corners region has laid off 67 workers citing low oil and gas prices. The layoffs included 39 field operators and other workers.

Baker Hughes was closing its Cement and Pumping Division facility in Crowley on January 12, 2017. About 35 employees had remained at the plant, which at one time had employed more than 100 and perhaps as many as 200.

Baldor Electric Co. announced that cost reduction efforts, including eliminating 425 jobs by June, and new sales initiatives are expected to help the company counter an economic slowdown. The company announced, it is using attrition, when workers retire or quit, to pare down its work force. The majority of 417 workers have already left the company across its 30 plants. The company said, another 425 jobs will be eliminated by June at a savings of $30 million.
Ball Corporation announced that it will close its aluminum beverage can manufacturing plant in Moultrie, Georgia by December 2001 or early 2002. The plant employs approximately 110 people.

Ball Corporation announced that by the end of the year it will close two manufacturing facilities in North America as part of the realignment of the company's Metal Food & Household Products, Americas. Ball will close a leased facility in Alliance, Ohio. Ball's Canadian subsidiary will close a metal food can manufacturing plant in Burlington, Ont.
Ball Corporation announced that it will lay off 37 workers on September 1, 2008 at its Ball Metal Food and Household Products facility at 4244 County V in DeForest.

Ball Corporation announced that it plans to close its metal beverage packaging manufacturing plants in Kansas City, Mo., and Guayama, Puerto Rico. The Guayama plant operates one production line capable of making 700 million 12-ounce cans annually and employs approximately 70 people. The plant is expected to close by the end of 2008.

Ball Corporation announced that it will cease production at the company's Weirton, West Virginia, flat sheet production and end-making plant by the first quarter of 2017. The plant's capacity will be supplied by other Ball facilities.

Ball Corp. announced that it will cease production at its Birmingham, Alabama, Chatsworth, California, and Longview, Texas, beverage packaging plants in 2018. Existing customers will be supplied by other Ball facilities. The Chatsworth plant, which opened in 1975, employs 118 people and produces beverage cans in multiple sizes, including standard 12-ounce cans, is expected to cease production by the end of the third quarter 2018. The Birmingham plant, which opened in 1952, employs 91 people and produces beverage can ends, is expected to cease production by the end of the second quarter 2018. The Longview plant, which opened in 1972, employs 100 people and produces cans in two sizes, is expected to cease production by the end of the second quarter 2018. All closure dates are subject to customer needs. The company noted that Birmingham, Chatsworth and Longview employees may be provided benefits and outplacement services in accordance with the bargaining process, and are eligible to apply for job openings within the company.The company also will begin construction on a new, beverage packaging facility in Goodyear, Arizona, which is expected to begin production in the second quarter of 2018 and will serve growing customer demand for specialty cans in the southwestern U.S.
Ball Corporation announced it will end production at its packaging plant in Cuiab, in Brazil's Mato Grosso state.

Constellation Energy Group Inc. announced that it will cut 8% of its global work force over the next year. The company with roughly 10,500 total workers, plans to slash about 840 jobs. About half of those positions will be lost in the Baltimore region.
Bank One announced it plans to layoff 200 employees at its loan center at Riverfront Plaza in Louisville as part of a plan to reduce real estate costs and consolidate operations.

The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation will cut its worldwide work force by 4%, or about 1,800 jobs, blaming the weak global economy. It's the latest in a string of banks to announce layoffs. The bank announced that attrition would reduce the number of layoffs. It has 43,000 employees worldwide.
Barnes Group Inc., a maker of parts used in automobiles and aircraft, said it eliminated about 150 positions in the first quarter, and profit fell 7.5 percent during the period.

Barnes Group Inc. Announced the closing the Foboha mold plant in Muri, Switzerland, and moving the operation into other facilities, including an Otto Mnner factory in Au, Switzerland. The closing of the Foboha plant in Switzerland, which employs 60, was done to improve profitability. The company is closing a 30-employee Associated Spring plant, which makes metal springs and stampings.

Barnes Group Inc. is laying off about 430 employees as part of a restructuring plan to offset weak industrial sales in its automotive and tooling markets as well as lower demand for aircraft. The workforce reductions will hamper some company locations from a capacity standpoint, William Pitts, investor relations director, told Plastics News in an email.
Barrick Gold Corporation cut more than 200 jobs and shut one of three pits at its North Mara mine in northern Tanzania after theft and vandalism increased costs.

Barrick Gold Corporation announced that the company is suspending construction work on the Chilean side of the Pascua-Lama project while working to address environmental and other regulatory requirements to the satisfaction of Chilean authorities. In the interim, activities deemed necessary for environmental protection will continue as authorized. Construction activities in Argentina, where the majority of Pascua-Lama's critical infrastructure is located, including the process plant and tailings storage facility, are not affected.
Bassett Furniture Industries Inc. plans to close its Macon, Ga., wood manufacturing facility, leading to about 180 layoffs.

Bassett Furniture Industries Inc. announced that it is closing its fiberboard facility in Bassett, Va. The plant, which began production in 1970, produces medium density fiberboard (MDF) made from wood fibers. The closure of the facility will occur by the end of the year, affecting approximately 45 employees. In connection with the closing of this facility, the Company expects to record a charge of approximately $1.0 million in the fourth quarter primarily associated with the writedown of property and equipment.

Bausch & Lomb Inc. said that it was cutting about 700 jobs, or 5.8 percent of its work force, and scaling back profit projections amid slowing demand for contact lenses and laser eye surgery equipment. The company, which employs about 12,000 people and makes a variety of eye care products, recently began shutting down contact lens manufacturing plants in Sarasota, Fla., and Madrid, and eliminated 250 jobs in the fourth quarter. Another 450 jobs will be cut throughout the company during the first three months of 2002.

Bausch and Lomb announced that 110 temporary employees at the Bausch and Lomb plant in Waterford are to lose their jobs. The first of the affected employees, who work as general operatives producing contact lenses, were informed of the move.

Bausch & Lomb Incorporated announced that 19 employees in pharmaceutical research and development will lose their jobs. The layoffs come as the eye care company changes its pharmaceutical R&D direction to focus less on pre-clinical research and more on mid-stage product candidates.
Bausch & Lomb will cut 96 out of 220 jobs at its production site in Montpellier, southern France.

Becton Dickinson and Company announced that the company would be closing down its Manatee County manufacturing plant in April 2002, thereby laying off 75 employees at its Ophthalmic Systems operations.

Becton, Dickinson and Company confirmed that it would be laying off 22 people from its Drogheda production plant. Becton Dickinson announced that the 'reduction in headcount' reflected the challenging and competitive global environment it is operating in. The 22 jobs there will be lost over the next six months.

Verizon Communications Inc., is planning to lay off 1,000 employees in a reorganization in the next few weeks. The cuts amount to less than 2 percent of the company's work force, which number more than 40,000 employees, divided equally around the South, West, Midwest and the Northeast, which includes Virginia.
Verizon Communications Inc. plans to reduce its statewide work force by 3,800 by early November. Verizon has 46,000 employees in New York, including its wireless division.
Verizon Communications plans to layoff about 1,250 employees based in New England citing the slow economy and growing competition from wireless phones and the Internet.

About 180 workers throughout Western New York received pink slips from Verizon Communications Inc. most of them repair and maintenance staff. The layoffs, part of a 2,400 cutback statewide, were the first for blue-collar phone workers since World War II, perhaps even before that, company and union officials said.

Verizon, the nation's largest phone company, has been preparing for a work stoppage for more than a year. It faces greater-than-ever competition in its local phone business, which caused it to warn that it may cut 5,000 jobs through layoffs, retirement and attrition by the end of the year. Workers are eyeing a national unemployment rate of 6.4 percent in June.

Verizon Communications Inc. announced that it has offered a voluntary buyout package to most of its 74,000 management employees nationwide in a sweeping cost-cutting move. The company also laid off 105 technology employees in the Verizon Information Services division.

Verizon Communications Inc. plans significant job cuts in its shrinking local-phone business to put more money into faster-growing areas. Verizon had 252,311 employees at the end of the first quarter, with about 140,000 in the local-phone business. The company had 217,000 employees at the end of 2005, before buying MCI Inc.
Verizon Communications Inc. laid off about 200 technicians in Massachusetts and Rhode Island as part of an effort to cut its workforce by 8,000 workers nationwide.

About 100 employees of Verizon Communications in Hampton Roads could lose their jobs as part of the company's plans to cut 8,000 workers by the end of January 2009. Word of the looming Verizon cutbacks caps a tough week for job losses in Hampton Roads.
Verizon Communications Inc. booked $329 million in severance, pension and benefit charges in the third quarter and expects to cut 2,500 jobs in 2011.

Verizon Communications Inc. is looking to cut its work force by 1,700 people, or almost 1%, through a buyout offer for technicians and call-centre employees. The company said that it could resort to involuntary layoffs if too few employees accept the voluntary package.

BellSouth Corp. will lay off 183 employees in North Carolina as part of a companywide consolidation of its call centers to increase efficiencies amid sluggish demand. The company announced it would consolidate its 75 call centers through the Southeast into 28 expanded offices. In North Carolina, BellSouth will shut down call centers in Raleigh, Asheville and Wilmington. The company's call center reorganization will cut 966 positions, but BellSouth expects some employees will transfer within its nine-state region, leaving a net loss of 650 to 700 people unemployed. The job cuts and consolidation are part of a plan to cut 4,200 jobs that BellSouth announced in October.
BellSouth has announced that the company laid off 4200 employees mostly in Georgia in order to cut costs.

BellSouth Corp. launched long-distance service in Georgia and Louisiana, hoping to lure customers who have relied on the company for local calls for years. BellSouth, the largest local phone provider in the Southeast wants to offer long-distance service in each of its nine states. Federal regulators granted approval for the first two states earlier this month. BellSouth plans to bait them with competitive calling plans and the prospect of an easier-to-understand phone bill. 

BellSouth announced a week ago that it was cutting 4,000 to 5,000 jobs because of the weak economy, regulatory pressures and tough competition. The cuts represent about 5 percent of the company's work force. BellSouth is offering severance packages to some workers and plans to begin layoffs in July if more cuts are needed.

BellSouth Corporation may cut more jobs this year, Chief Financial Officer Ron Dykes announced, speaking at the Morgan Stanley Global Media and Communications Conference in Boston. Spokesman Jeff Battcher confirmed the remarks, saying that if the Atlanta-based telecommunications company continues to lose market share to competitors in local service, it will have to make further cuts in capital spending and jobs. At the end of last year, BellSouth had 77,000 employees, down from 88,000 at the end of 2001.

BellSouth Corp. plans to eliminate another 778 positions by the end of June, citing low work volume. The jobs being eliminated include technical workers and employees in repair center positions, collections and clerical work. The largest number of cuts, 296, will come in Georgia. The rest will be spread among the other eight Southeastern states where Atlanta-based BellSouth is the dominant local phone provider. Workers who lose their jobs will be able to reapply for 540 non-management open positions in the company.

AT&T Inc. announced that it plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs, mostly through attrition, if its $67 billion purchase of BellSouth Corp. goes through. The work force reduction would take place over three years. Before the cuts, the combined company would have around 317,000 employees, including Cingular Wireless LLC, which is now an AT&T-BellSouth joint venture. The 10,000 planned cuts are in addition to the 26,000 job cuts AT&T has already announced 13,000 due to SBC's acquisition of AT&T Corp., which closed in November, and 13,000 due to operational initiatives. The combined SBC-AT&T took the name AT&T Inc.

AT&T Inc. announced that it plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs, mostly through attrition, if its $67 billion purchase of BellSouth Corp. goes through. The work force reduction would take place over three years. Before the cuts, the combined company would have around 317,000 employees, including Cingular Wireless LLC, which is now an AT&T-BellSouth joint venture. The 10,000 planned cuts are in addition to the 26,000 job cuts AT&T has already announced 13,000 due to SBC's acquisition of AT&T Corp., which closed in November, and 13,000 due to operational initiatives. The combined SBC-AT&T took the name AT&T Inc.

AT&T Inc. announced that it plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs, mostly through attrition, if its $67 billion purchase of BellSouth Corp. goes through. The work force reduction would take place over three years. Before the cuts, the combined company would have around 317,000 employees, including Cingular Wireless LLC, which is now an AT&T-BellSouth joint venture. The 10,000 planned cuts are in addition to the 26,000 job cuts AT&T has already announced 13,000 due to SBC's acquisition of AT&T Corp., which closed in November, and 13,000 due to operational initiatives. The combined SBC-AT&T took the name AT&T Inc.
