AT&T Inc. announced that it plans to cut up to 10,000 jobs, mostly through attrition, if its $67 billion purchase of BellSouth Corp. goes through. The work force reduction would take place over three years. Before the cuts, the combined company would have around 317,000 employees, including Cingular Wireless LLC, which is now an AT&T-BellSouth joint venture. The 10,000 planned cuts are in addition to the 26,000 job cuts AT&T has already announced 13,000 due to SBC's acquisition of AT&T Corp., which closed in November, and 13,000 due to operational initiatives. The combined SBC-AT&T took the name AT&T Inc.

Layoffs related to media company Belo Corp.'s scandal over inflated circulation have begun. The company restructuring will include 250 layoffs companywide; some of them will be at the Morning News and WFAA-TV in Dallas.
Best Buy Co. Inc. says it will close its 400-employee distribution center in Edina next spring, transferring the work to a much larger facility in Franklin, Ind.
Best Buy Co. Inc. has announced that it has laid off about 50 employees, approximately 1 percent of its total workforce, in efforts to contain costs amid weak consumer spending.

A decision by Best Buy Co. Inc. to close 110 stores has left market watchers wondering if other music retailers are poised to make similar moves; if they do, certain mall real-estate investment trusts could take a hit (M).

Best Buy Co. announced it is cutting 120 jobs in a reorganization of its marketing and retail support departments. However, only 60 people are expected to be laid off since the company had a number of jobs unfilled, a Best Buy spokeswoman said.

Best Buy Co. plans to close its Studio D concept store in Naperville when the lease expires at the end of the month. The company opened the 5,000-square-foot specialty shop in 2004 in an effort to capture middle-income to upper-income female customers. It was the only such store nationwide.

Best Buy Co. Inc. announced that it would close two repair centers by mid-August and eliminate 180 jobs in a cost-cutting move. The company announced that it will close repair centers in the Minneapolis suburb of Bloomington, which employs 140 people, and one in St. Louis, which employs 40. Both centers repaired audio-visual equipment such as camcorders and music players. The work would be done at a Best Buy repair center in Chicago. Best Buy Co. Inc. will still have 10 repair centers.

Best Buy Co. Inc. announced that 250 workers at its corporate headquarters in suburban Minneapolis would lose their current jobs as the electronics chain pares its work force, though most might get new positions with the company. The company hoped the displaced employees would fill 210 new jobs being posted by the retailer, for a net loss of 40 jobs.
Best Buy Co. Inc. closed their 45,000 sq ft store at Parkgate at the start of the year after it made the decision to close all 11 UK stores. It opened in June last year.

Best Buy Co. Inc. announced that it plans to close 50 U.S. stores in 2013. The company said it intends to grow its presence in China and will make cost-cutting moves to the tune of $800 million by fiscal 2015.

DDR Corp. confirmed that one store location within its portfolio will close among the 42 announced, April 14, 2012 by Best Buy Co. Inc. The 30,000 square foot store is located at Fayette Pavilion, a 1.5 million square-foot prime power center located in Fayetteville, Georgia. The center is anchored by Walmart, Home Depot, Target, Kohl's, Publix, Dick's Sporting Goods, Belk, Ross Dress For Less, T.J.Maxx, Bed Bath & Beyond, PetSmart and more. There is no co-tenancy impact related to this closing and the company remains responsible for all economic obligations of the lease until expiration in January 2013. In addition, DDR holds this asset in joint venture with a 15% share.

Best Buy Co. Inc. announced that No Valley Best Buy stores are on a list of locations slated to close. The company recently announced plans to close 50 stores nationwide and over the weekend released specific locations. The list includes seven in California, most in the Bay Area and Southern California. The company is reducing its square footage while increasing 'points of presence' with Best Buy Mobile stores.
Best Buy Co. will close its Vancouver store, one of 50 outlets it plans to shutter this year. The Mill Plain Boulevard location its only big box store in the city will shut down by May 12, 2012.

Best Buy Co Inc. plans to close some stores and consolidate its operations in Canada, in a move that will hurt earnings in 2015. The retailer said it will close 66 of its Future Shop brand stores in Canada and convert 65 of them to Best Buy brand stores. The move to a single brand will cut 500 full-time and 1,000 part-time jobs, and cost the company about $200 million to $280 million in restructuring charges.The company also announced that it plans to spend $160 million to improve its online operations in Canada, increase staffing at remaining stores, and launch a range of home appliances, among other initiatives.

Best Buy Co. Inc. will close seven of its big-box stores this fall in a slight shrinking of the company's national footprint. Six stores will close at the end of October. One is in Council Bluffs, Iowa; two are in the Baltimore area; one is in Topsham, Maine; one is in Beaufort, S.C.; and one is in Long Island, N.Y. A store in Willmar, Minn., will close in the next couple weeks. Two others, one in Chicago and one in Des Moines, closed earlier this year. In total Best Buy will close about 10 stores this year. Best Buy decided not to renew its leases, which has been the company's strategy for the past few years. Despite softness in electronics, the company under CEO Hubert Joly has resisted mass store closings.

Best Buy confirmed to the BBJ that the Alabaster and Fultondale locations will be closing at the end of business hours Oct. 28. Alabaster's location is on Colonial Drive, and Fultondale is on Lowery Parkway. Both are located in major power retail centers along Interstate 65. Roughly 50 full-time employees and a small number of part-time employees will be impacted by the decision, and those who do not stay on with the company in other locations will be offered a severance package.

Biomet Inc. announced that the UK operations of the company are being rationalized to a single location in South Wales. It has confirmed that it is to close its Swindon manufacturing facility and focus all production in the UK at its Bridgend plant where it employs 370. The closure in Swindon will result in 80 jobs being created in Bridgend. The move was in response to increasing global economic pressures and a need to deliver cost effective product solutions. Under this proposal, the company does not intend to reduce manufacturing at Swindon until April 2012. It is anticipated that the transition would take two years to complete, during which period many affected employees will have the opportunity to continue their employment with Biomet. It is estimated this may result in a reduction of approximately 220 employees over the next two years at the Swindon site, where it will retain commercial and R&D personnel.
Black & Decker Corp. announced that it again will cut its U.S. workforce-this time by 125.

Black & Decker Corp. announced that about 675 workers will lose their jobs when it closes its Fayetteville plant and moves operations out of state by December 2006. The plant's operations will move to Jackson, Tenn., and Reynosa, Mexico. The Fayetteville plant, which opened in 1967 and employed up to 1,500 people in the mid-1990s, will begin cuts over the next three months. The company announced that employees will be told about openings at other plants and will get severance pay and job placement assistance. Black & Decker last year cut 330 jobs at its Fayetteville plant as part of worldwide restructuring.

The Black & Decker Corp. will close its Easton plant, eliminating 1,300 jobs and leaving the toolmaker with virtually no manufacturing presence in its home state. Most of the Maryland jobs will move to Mexico; others will shift to Brazil and Fayetteville, N.C. The Towson, Md. -based company's layoffs could begin as early as January. The plant has 750 full-time employees and 550 contract workers. It produces the company's DeWalt tools and has been in operation since 1974. The company employs about 1,150 people at its headquarters and about 250 workers at a plant in Hampstead. About half of the toolmaker's nearly 23,000 employees worldwide are based in the United States.

The Black & Decker Corp. will cut about 2,400 jobs and close three plants in high-cost areas such as the United States and United Kingdom as part of a restructuring that dragged down fourth-quarter earnings, the tool and appliance maker announced. About 1,900 of the jobs will be replaced at lower-cost facilities it owns in China and Mexico, as well as at a new factory in the Czech Republic, said Barbara Lucas, a company spokeswoman.
 
 The cutbacks were announced as Black & Decker posted a $13 million, or 16 cents per share, loss for the fourth quarter. That compares with profits of $52.5 million, or 64 cents per share, in the year-earlier quarter. Sales during fell to $1.22 billion from $1.26 billion in the fourth quarter of 2000.
Black and Decker will close its plant in Wisconsin and move some of its operations to Tampa, Florida, citing economic slump.

Black Hills Corporation intends to decommission a coal-fired power plant in southern Colorado this year. The company will decommission two units at the W.N. Clark plant in Caon City. Black Hills, which last week closed a coal-fired power plant near Gillette, Wyo., also intends to decommission two other plants in Wyoming. The utility is moving toward natural gas to replace the coal-fired plants in the wake of new Environmental Protection Agency regulations targeted at reducing emissions.

H&R Block Inc. it will eliminate more than 500 corporate positions as part of an effort to slash expenses by $110 million a year. The bulk of the 325 filled and 180 open positions are at the company's headquarters in Kansas City, representing about 23% of its corporate work force. The cuts are expected to save $50 million a year in salary expenses. H&R Block also plans to cut an additional $60 million in other expenses, including consulting, travel and entertainment, representing about 18% of such costs.

H&R Block, Inc. announced that it will be eliminating 400 positions and closing approximately 400 underperforming tax offices out of its network of 11,000 locations. More than 40 offices will be closed across the state with eight in South Florida. The cuts are part of what the Kansas City, Mo.-based tax preparer said is a strategic realignment of its field and corporate support organization, which it expects will save the company $140 million to $150 million a year by the end of 2012. The company said it expects to incur a pre-tax charge for severance-related costs of approximately $28 million, most of which will be incurred in the fiscal quarter ending July 31, 2010.

H&R Block Inc. announced that it cut about 90 jobs at the height of the tax season, mostly at its Kansas City headquarters. The layoffs included 20 employees at other Block work sites that also perform corporate functions rather than tax preparation work.

H&R Block announced 250 layoffs. The company said it undertook the layoffs in Kansas City and at its field locations across the United States. Affected employees, which equaled 12.6% of its workforce.

On September 27, 2013, Bob Evans Farms, Inc. announced internally planned changes to its' food production operations. Management committed to the action on September 26, 2013. The company intends to close its food production plant in Richardson, Texas, in the second quarter of fiscal year 2014. Approximately 111 plant workers will be impacted by this closure. As part of the plan, the company will invest approximately $4.0 million of capital during fiscal year 2014, and approximately $10.0 million during fiscal year 2015 to add equipment to its food production facilities in Xenia, Ohio, and Hillsdale, Michigan, to absorb the Richardson capacity.

Bob Evans Farms, Inc. announced that it is closing 27 Bob Evans Restaurants. Twenty-one of the restaurants are owned and six are leased locations. The owned locations closed April 23, 2016 and April 24, 2016, and the remaining leased locations are expected to close during fiscal year 2017.
Boeing Co. announced that it will layoff 225 employees, approximately 15 percent of its work force at its Corinth plant, as a part of its plan to cut costs.
Boeing Co. has announced that it plans to layoff 5,200 employees in Wichita.

The Boeing Co. announced 1,700 Boeing employees were laid off bringing the total number of people cut from the aerospace company's payroll to 21,300 since last fall. About 1,350 of the layoffs were in the Puget Sound region and included 1,100 hourly workers and 250 salaried employees, said Boeing spokesman Bill Cogswell. Another 200 hourly and 150 salaried workers were cut from operations around the country.

The Boeing Co. will cut 100 jobs at its Macon assembly and maintenance plant next week, trimming more than 12 percent of the work force. Federal law requires companies with 100 or more workers to give 60 days notice of layoffs.

Layoff warning notices will be going to 650 Boeing workers as the company continues to scale back its work force. Of those workers getting 60-day-layoff warning notices, 620 work in the Puget Sound area, said Boeing spokesman Bill Cogswell. Those workers last day at Boeing will be March 21. Boeing has laid off about 30,000 workers since December 2001. The company expects to eliminate 5,000 more jobs this year.

Boeing Company will deliver dour Valentines to 890 Puget Sound area workers when it distributes its latest round of 60 day layoff warning notices in its campaign to downsize in response to slumping airplane demand. An additional 250 Boeing workers in other facilities around the country will also get notices, bringing the national total to 1,140. This is the largest round of warnings since Boeing declared in November it would cut another 5,000 jobs from its commercial airplanes group this year.

The Boeing Co. will lay off 80 employees at its spare parts manufacturing facility near Salt Lake International Airport in May. Director of communications Steven Hendrickson said the layoffs are part of a nationwide cutback announced last November that will reduce Boeings Commercial Airplanes segment workforce by 5,000 nationwide. Boeing has laid off more than 30,000 workers since the 9-11 terrorist attacks.

Boeing Company announced details of a plan to outsource more work from its Auburn fabrication plant, which will mean job cuts and selling off more facilities. The company projects 50 jobs will be lost this year, rising to 400 through the end of 2004. Most are expected to be shed through attrition, Boeing officials said.
Boeing Co. has issued 60 day layoff warning notices to 200 workers who help build C-17 military cargo jets. The C-17 plant in Long Beach employs about 7,000 people.
Boeing will cut 260 union jobs in St. Louis effective June 20 due to modernization of the St. Louis plants. The company employs about 15,000 workers in north St. Louis County and St. Charles.

Boeing Company has issued layoff notices to roughly 255 workers as it hires contractors for work that used to be handled by its own employees. Boeing is turning to Chicago-based Oce USA to take over much of its printing needs, which had been handled by employees in Boeing's Shared Services Group. Shared Services, based in Bellevue, manages communications, travel, security and other companywide needs for the aerospace giant.

Layoffs scheduled to begin for workers in the commercial aircraft division that Boeing Co. is selling to Onex Corp. have been delayed until next month. More than 8,000 workers were notified that their employement is ending and that they can apply to work for Onex. The layoffs were scheduled to start and continue through May 27, 2005. But workers received a memo informing them that the layoffs would occur between June 2, 2005 and June 15, 2005.

The 60-day layoff notices that were to have gone out to 240 Boeing Wichita workers this week have been delayed. The delays are due to attrition and to customer requirements. Notices will go out later in the year. The cuts are part of a larger plan to shed about 900 jobs -- about 25% of the work force -- at Boeing's military division in Wichita by the end of January 2007. That plan has not changed. The cuts will reduce employment at the plant from 3,600 to about 2,700. The job losses are due to cuts in the Department of Defense budget, program delays and contract completions. In April, Boeing issued 60-day layoff notices to 360 workers in its first round of cuts.

Boeing Co. announced that at least 140 employees at the company's C-17 plant are due to be laid off in late September. Company officials began distributing letters alerting workers that they would likely lose their jobs with the C-17 program in 60 days. An estimated 6,500 Boeing workers are linked to the C-17 program in Long Beach, making it the largest private employer in the city. The company will begin shutting down the production program if it does not get a commitment on C-17 orders from the military and government by mid-to-late August.

Boeing Co. will slash up to 600 jobs from its Melbourne plant at Fishermen's Bend by the end of 2009. All production at Boeing's Melbourne base, except for its Dreamliner contract, will be relocated to its Sydney plant, with 350 jobs immediately axed. Workers have been aware of the job cuts since May 2008.

Boeing Co. plans to cut about 4,500 jobs beginning February 2009 amid a weakening global economy. The job cuts will bring the unit's workforce to about 63,500, similar to the level it was at the start of 2008. Many of the job cuts will be in overhead functions and other areas not directly associated with airplane production. Most of the reductions are expected to occur in Washington state in the second quarter of the year, with affected employees to receive 60-day notices beginning in late February.

Boeing Co. has announced job cuts totaling 10,000. The news comes on top of waning demand for the company's commercial jets. Airlines are cutting spending and air travel has declined amid the global economic slowdown. Boeing plans to cut about 4,500 positions from its commercial aircraft business as a result of the worsening market conditions. Boeing said an additional 5,500 positions in other parts of the company, including its defense division, were to be eliminated through attrition and layoffs throughout the year.

Boeing Co. is laying off about 130 employees in Huntsville in response to proposed cuts and changes in the 2010 defense budget. The layoffs were largely in the Ground-based Midcourse Defense program. That program accounts for about 1,300 of the company's more than 3,200 workers in Huntsville. The cuts were part of 1,000 jobs the company's Integrated Defense Systems, it plans to eliminate at various locations because of changes in defense spending. The program is part of a 'layered' approach to missile defense, complementing other programs focused on the launch and terminal phases of enemy missile attack. Much of the reduction is in the ground-based program, which is managed by Boeing in Huntsville.

Boeing Co. announced that officials began notifying about 250 workers at the company's Global Services and Support center that they would be laid off in January after the company chose not to appeal the loss of a $3.8 billion maintenance and logistics services contract on the KC-10 fleet of aerial refueling tankers.

Boeing's Integrated Defense Systems in Wichita is taking longer than first planned to reduce employment by 800 jobs. A year ago, the company would cut 800 jobs by mid-2009 as work on some existing programs wound down. But by the end of 2009, Boeing Wichita will have cut 500 of the 800 positions. The company issued 60-day layoff notices to 77 employees on Friday. The remaining 300 or so layoffs will take place by mid-2010, when work on refueling tankers for Japan and Italy winds down.

Boeing Co. will lay off 527 employees in the Puget Sound area by April 23, 2010, most of them from its Engineering, Operations and Technology unit. The layoffs, detailed by Boeing in a WARN (Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act) notification, are part of a larger group of 1,020 workers companywide who received layoff notices. The 527 local reductions include mostly IT workers. The company now employs about 72,000 in Washington, and a total of 158,500.

Boeing Co. will cut back production of its C-17 military transport at its Long Beach, Calif., plant to 10 a year from 15 to keep the production line operating as the backlog of orders diminishes. Boeing will drop the production rate to 10 a year by mid-year in 2011 with 2012 being the first whole year in which the company produces just 10 of the aircraft. A production slowdown will mean layoffs at both Boeing and its suppliers.
Boeing Co. announced that it had managed to cut a planned layoff from 100 to 29 employees of Huntsville's layoff-shaken aerospace community .

The Boeing Company will shed 1,500 information-technology positions in the Puget Sound region over the next three years. The cuts will affect almost a third of the total 4,700 Boeing IT positions here, and continue a wave of job reductions that has hit several corners of the company since March 2013. The cuts will come through a combination of layoffs, attrition from retirements, and relocation of some jobs to two new IT centers Boeing is establishing in St. Louis, Mo., and North Charleston, S.C. The company will offer severance packages to some employees who volunteer for layoff. The first layoff notices under the plan went out in March 2013 to about 150 local employees, with those layoffs due this month. Another round of layoffs is set for September 2013. The cuts will come through attrition and as many as 700 layoffs.
Boeing Co. said the company expects to cut more jobs and will pressure more suppliers to cut their prices.

Boeing Co. plans to lay off 561 employees in Southern California in December 2014 and early 2015. The layoffs include 253 people at its Long Beach facilities, 154 in Huntington Beach and another 154 employees in El Segundo. The company has previously announced that it is closing its factory in Long Beach where it builds the C-17 cargo plane for the Air Force.

The Boeing Co. announced it is laying off 153 employees of its Commercial Airlines Division in the Puget Sound region. All of the employees are from the engineering, operations and technology, commercial and defense units. The layoffs are spread throughout three Boeing facilities in the Puget Sound area: Renton, Everett and Seattle. All 153 employees were issued 60-day advanced notifications of the layoffs last Friday. The layoffs are effective June 19.

Boeing announced that it expects to cut as many as 'several hundred' jobs in its satellite business through the end of 2015 due to a downturn in U.S. military spending and delays in commercial satellite orders. Some could find work in other parts of Boeing. Multiple commercial orders were being delayed by recent failures of launch vehicles and uncertainties about the future availability of financing from the U.S. Export-Import Bank, whose government charter lapsed on June 30, 2015.

The Boeing Co. announced some Oklahoma City employees could be laid off in the next 60 days. The company gave a small number of employees?a 60 day notice of possible layoffs. The notices were issued across Boeing's defense business, company wide.

Boeing has turned to job cuts at its Puget Sound airplane factories and corporate offices to cut expenses as the slowdown in wide-body jet sales continues. Boeing served layoff notices to 245 workers as recently as March 23, 2017 and filed a notice with the Washington state Employment Security Department. Their final day at work will be May 23, according Boeing's Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act notice. The law requires companies with 100 or more employees to give laid off workers 60 days?notice prior to their layoffs.

Boeing Co. handed out 429 new layoff notices to Washington state workers with the biggest cuts coming to the aircraft manufacturer's widebody operations in Everett. Of the 277 layoff notices to employees represented by the Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace, 191 work in Everett. That's where Boeing makes its 747 jumbo jets, some of its 787 long-range 777s and 767 jets. Another 35 SPEEA workers who got the 60-day notices work in Renton, where Boeing makes its smaller 737 jets. The remainder work in Tukwila (26), Bellevue (7), Kent (6), Mukilteo (5) Seattle (3), Bothell (2), Auburn (1) and Vancouver (1). The SPEEA cuts mostly affected Boeing Commercial Airplanes workers (246), followed by Boeing Defense, Space & Security (30) and one worker in a corporate unit. Engineers made up 194 of the cuts. The other 83 are technical workers. Boeing issued layoff notices to another 217 members of the International Association of Machinists union, the Seattle Times reported.

The Boise Cascade Corp. is expected to close 45 of its recently acquired OfficeMax stores in the second quarter and eliminate 1,100 jobs. Of the 1,100 employees whose jobs are to be eliminated, Boise Cascade said, 500 will be offered transfers to other OfficeMax stores.

OfficeMax Inc. announced that it would close 110 stores during the first quarter, stop operations at a building materials plant and record $187 million in pretax charges. The operating plan aims to reverse losses and lagging sales by focusing on three areas: improving corporate infrastructure, turning around its retail and contract businesses and cutting costs. A day after OfficeMax announced the plan, one of its largest investors, K Capital Partners, deemed the shake-up insufficient, and called on the board to sell the company instead. But so far, the plan seems to be working.

OfficeMax Inc. is cutting about 2,700 store management jobs. The 900-store chain is eliminating one of every two assistant store manager positions and two of every three store supervisor jobs per store.

OfficeMax Inc. has decided to close a customer call center in suburban Cleveland, affecting more than 200 workers. Employees at the facility in Mentor learned that their last day would be Oct. 31. The company says it will provide severance packages to workers who are eligible. OfficeMax will continue to operate four other call centers, in Illinois, Wyoming and Virginia.

OfficeMax Incorporated announced it will close more stores, shrink existing ones, curb expansion and look for more ways to cut costs as it tries to cope with weak sales. The office supply chain has decided against expanding into new geographies at the moment.
OfficeMax announced that the store at 24334 El Toro Road in Laguna Woods will close on November 12, 2016.
Borden Chemical Inc. said it initiated a restructuring program earlier this month that is expected to reduce its total worldwide employment by 8 percent, or about 200 people.
Borden Chemical has begun a restructuring that is expected to eliminate 200 jobs worldwide, including 26 at the company's Columbus headquarters.
Bowater Inc. has announced that it will cut 500 jobs in the United States and Canada by the end of 2003, including an undisclosed number at its Catawba paper mill in York County.

AbitibiBowater, Inc. in central Newfoundland wants to cut 171 jobs, more than one-third of its unionized workforce. The company has proposed cutting 171 unionized jobs under a restructuring plan to save the paper mill in Grand Falls-Windsor. Out of the 171 jobs to be cut, more than 100 will be positions from among 207 workers forming Local 63 of the Communications, Energy and Paper workers union.
AbitibiBowater, Inc. announced that it was shutting down a century-old mill in central Newfoundland, with the loss of nearly 800 jobs.

Resolute Forest Products announced that it is halting production on its last paper machine at its mill in Fort Frances on January 31, 2014. Resolute blames the shutdown on market conditions and says it will be laying off 150 workers in the northwestern Ontario town - leaving about 60 others to manage operations. The machine that produces specialty printing papers will be stopped on Jan. 31, 2014.

Resolute Forest Products decided to permanently shut down paper machine No. 9 at its Alma paper mill in Quebec, Canada, citing market weakness and fiber cost issues. The company has three paper machines at the Alma mill, with total capacity of 350,000 metric tons. The move reduces total production from the mill by 75,000 metric tons and cuts the company's workforce by 85 jobs.

Brady Corp0ration has eliminated 50 jobs in Milwaukee as part of the deepest round of layoffs in its 89-year history, company officials said Friday. About 37 of the jobs were salary positions in management, sales and marketing. The cuts were part of 300 layoffs that Brady had previously said were coming. About 40 percent of the 300 layoffs will take place in Europe, Herbstreit said.

Briggs & Stratton Corp. will cut more than 275 jobs in Wauwatosa by mid-2004 as the company stops doing die casting work for other businesses. The cuts are another blow for local manufacturing employment at Briggs, where hourly payroll has dropped by more than 2,000 jobs since 1997. 144 people who are scheduled to retire between now and June 30.

Briggs & Stratton Corp. has informed government officials that it's eliminating 78 jobs at its Milwaukee Engine Division, 53 in the die-casting department. The company expects to make the cuts late next month, affecting union employees at its Burleigh plant, at 3300 N. 124th St. in Wauwatosa.

Briggs & Stratton Corp. announced that it will close a plant in Tennessee and shift the work to Georgia, eliminating about 690 jobs in the U.S., as it adjusts to a changing market for outdoor equipment. The company is also closing a plant in the Czech Republic, which will result in 77 job cuts there. It is shifting that work to a Kentucky factory. The moves reflect sharp declines in demand for U.S. lawn and garden products. The changes will save the company $18 million to $20 million a year before taxes.

Briggs & Stratton Corporation announced that the company will temporarily shut down its production facility in McDonough, Georgia in order to reduce inventory levels of lawn and garden products that are produced at the facility. Market demand for lawn and garden equipment remains soft as a result of the ongoing drought that is affecting a large portion of the United States since May 2012. Production will be suspended from October 29 to November 25, 2012; however, shipments of products and service parts to customers will continue during this time. Plant personnel will also utilize the shutdown period to complete the movement of certain equipment from the company's recently closed Newbern, TN facility into the McDonough plant and to re-tool for new products for spring production.

Briggs & Stratton Corporation in McDonough will shut down its production, leaving 540 employees temporarily out of work until production resumes November 26. The drought that has hit major portions of the country has caused a dwindling in sales for lawn and garden equipment. Of the employees who will be laid off, 340 are hourly employees and 200 are temporary employees. Temporary employees are those who have been hired through staffing agencies to help during high production times when more labor is needed. The production facility works to manufacture products ahead of season, and right now the facility has completed producing its winter line of products. In the fall, spring and summer product manufacturing begins. While production has been halted, shipments of products and service parts will continue on as normal. Some staff has remained at the facility to facilitate those shipments, though the company could not say what percentage of the employees have remained. Also during the shutdown, the facility will prepare for spring and summer production.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. announced it was closing a plant in Candiac, Canada that employs 115 people. Some of the employees will be offered positions in New Brunswick, N.J., and other sites in the U.S. 75% of the employees at the site were involved in providing drugs and placebos for clinical trials, and Bristol-Myers is consolidating those operations. The company announced it had to consider the cost effectiveness of maintaining the Candiac facility after the consolidation and opted to close the operation.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. announced that it will close a plant that makes heart disease and diabetes medicine in western Puerto Rico, eliminating about 400 jobs. The closure, the result of reduced demand for the medication, will occur in stages and be completed at the end of 2008.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. is cutting jobs again, this time eliminating about 3% of its positions in its latest effort to streamline operations. The cut amounts to about 840 jobs out of 28,000 worldwide, and follows rounds of layoffs in 2008 and in 2007, when the company had about 41,000 employees globally. The company says the jobs will be eliminated over the next six months, and the cuts could be spread across all its businesses and geographic locations.

Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. plans to eliminate the jobs of about 200 support service workers at its Plainsboro and other central New Jersey offices. The cuts will take place over the next year as the pharmaceutical company's marketing, information technology and finance operations are consolidated at a new facility in the Tampa, Fla., area, where costs are lower. The company said the 200 workers losing their jobs include 100 contractors.
Brown-Forman Corporation has closed down three facilities to add value to the business.
Brown Shoe Co. plans to cut 650 jobs in the next 15 months, as part of its restructuring efforts.
The layoffs announced by the Brunswick Group, affected the workforce of Brunswick Boat Group, cutting its staff by 6%.
Brunswick Corp. will be closing its Newberry plant, which makes Sea Pro boats, putting 175 people out of work by July 14.

Brunswick Corp. announced that it will cut up to 2,700 jobs and close four plants to reduce its costs by $300 million in response to a continuing downturn in the marine market. The four plant closures come on top of eight plant closures previously announced. The company said it notified workers that its hourly and salaried work force will be cut by 1,000 and that further reductions of roughly 1,000 hourly and 700 salaried employees across its marine business units and staff functions are contemplated.
Brunswick Corp. announced the closing of its Sea Ray plant and cutting 575 jobs.

Brunswick Corporation said it will close its Cabo Yachts plant in Adelanto, Calif., by the end of 2010. Production will move to its Hatteras Yachts factory in New Bern, where 280 workers remain after several rounds of layoffs slashed the workforce from 1,400. Cabo and Hatteras already shared product design, engineering, marketing and sales services in New Bern. The move also brought production of Cabo vessels closer to the majority of the company's markets, trimming delivery time while allowing some deliveries via waterways, something that was not possible from the Southern California factory. The move means the New Bern plant is ramping up employment again after sharp layoffs in the past two years.The company will close its Cabo Yachts plant in Adelanto, Calif., by the end of 2010. Production will move to its Hatteras Yachts factory in New Bern, where 280 workers remain after several rounds of layoffs slashed the workforce from 1,400. Many manufacturing workers and some managers will be offered jobs and relocation help to move to North Carolina.

Unisys Corp. affirmed its outlook for the quarter that calls for earnings of 8 cents to 12 cents a share, excluding the impact of pension accounting. In the year-earlier period, earnings were 17 cents a share.The company has announced plans to cut around 4% of its 37,000 workers, resulting in a special charge for the third quarter.

Unisys Corp. expects lower fourth-quarter revenue from the same period in 1999 due to an unfavorable euro and the weak emphasis on low-margin businesses including PC selling. The company will also cut 2000 jobs worldwide and continue to explore strategic

Butler Manufacturing in San Marcos plans to lay off 64 employees in October. The company is scheduled to complete the layoffs on Oct. 24, according to an Aug. 23 filing with the Texas Workforce Commission. Following the layoffs, the San Marcos facility will employ about 51 workers.

Acxiom Corp., one of the world's largest database companies is laying off a number of workers as it adjusts to recent acquisitions and accounts for changes in the economy. The layoffs likely involved a figure between 300-500 people which would be between 5.5 percent and 9 percent of the company's 5,500-member workforce. The company has 4,500 employees in Arkansas and another 1,000 worldwide.

Acxiom Corp. announced that it will cut 265 positions, 140 of them in Arkansas. The workforce reduction, in addition to other targeted expense cuts, will position Acxiom to deliver improved financial results. The cut represents about 3.7% of the company's workforce.
Acxiom Corporation plans to cut 45 positions from its U.S. workforce, including 12 in central Arkansas.
Acxiom Corp. will layoff 25 employees in central Arkansas. The news about company's decision to lay off part of its workforce comes as the company accelerates the integration of LiveRamp Inc.

C-COR.net Corp. will close its recently acquired upstate New York cable television products plant and eliminate 250 jobs. The State College, Pa. -based company acquired the former Philips Broadband Networks plant in September. C-Cor officials said manufacturing will cease in February and the rest of the operation will be shut down by July. The company had planned to maintain its suburban Syracuse operations after merging with Philips, but a prolonged slump in sales changed their minds.

CDI Corp. said that it would cut 11 percent of its administrative staff and close 25 offices. The reduction, involving 370 jobs, will leave the Philadelphia personnel company with fewer than 3,000 workers and about 330 company-owned offices. One small office in Pennsylvania will be affected, but the company would not disclose its location. CDI offers temporary staffing, contract employees and permanent staff to its clients. It said the cutbacks should be completed by April 1.

CIGNA Corp.'s health insurance arm cut 700 jobs in a bid to help restore profit at the troubled employee benefits company. Most of the doomed jobs were in Connecticut, where Cigna HealthCare is based, and at field offices in other states. Fewer than 20 of the positions were in the Philadelphia area.
Cigna Corp. plans to cut another 2,150 jobs by the end of the first quarter. The remainder of the layoffs will be complete by the end of 2003.

CIGNA Corporation. will lay off about 10 percent of its New Hampshire work force, a little under 50 employees as part of 3,200 jobs being cut nationwide as part of a reorganization, company officials said. Its just under 50, and thats out of over 500 employees in New.

CIGNA Corp. said it is laying off 135 to 150 employees in information technology about half of them in Connecticut as the company continues to pare expenses. The company has more than 3,400 IT employees including about 2,000 in Connecticut. The 135 to 150 cuts are in addition to the previously announced 3,900 terminations companywide, and arent part of a $98 million after-tax charge in the fourth quarter of last year.

CIGNA Corp. announced that some 60 health insurance servicing employees are losing their jobs after Cigna's government services affiliate lost one of its federal Medicare contracts. The workers have 30 more days before the jobs in the Nashville office go away.

Cigna Corp. intends to terminate an undisclosed number of employees starting from May 2012 while it moves its accounting functions to a subcontractor in New Delhi. The report, which cites anonymous Cigna employees, stated that about 50 to 60 of the company's 3,900 employees in Connecticut might be laid off as part of the move.

CPI Corp. that owns portrait studios in Sears and Wal-Mart stores in Greater Cincinnati is shutting down its U.S. operations. CPI's interim president and chief executive officer, told employees that the business had been struggling in the past year, but company officials tried to keep the company afloat. During that time the company negotiated deals with hosts, secured additional funding from banks, and marketed company to potential purchasers. The company will be forced to discontinue U.S. operations effective April 3, 2013.

CNA Financial Corp. said it will cut 1,850 jobs During the first half of 2002, CNA said, it plans to consolidate from 169 to 68 sites in 63 cities. Head count is to be reduced to about 16,500. The largest number of layoffs will be in the insurer's Chicago headquarters.

CSX Corp. will announce a second round of job cuts, part of a management restructuring plan announced in November to cut the railroad's costs. A total of 800 to 1,000 managerial, or non-union, jobs will be eliminated. Most of those cuts will occur on the First Coast, where 60 percent of CSX's 5,000 non-union employees are based. Management layers will shrink from 11 to about 8.

CSX Corp. announced that a third round of layoffs is going on as the railroad company continues its management restructuring plan announced in November to cut 800 to 1,000 nonunion jobs. Only about 140 positions have been eliminated since last fall. CSX also announced that the cut backs will save CSX $80 million to $100 million annually. Management layers are being reduced from 11 to eight.
CSX Corp. will cut traffic in half and lay off more than 150 workers at its Buffalo rail yard as part of a companywide strategic review.

CSX Corp. announced that 132 workers at its Buffalo rail yard will be laid off by the end of this month. The company said that it would end its major switching operations at Frontier Yards by the end of May. CSX officials told union leaders that about 20% of the yard's employees would lose their jobs as the company eliminates jobs because of a decline in shipping volume caused by the economic downturn. CSX says more than 330 workers will continue to be based at the facility. About half of the work being done at the Frontier Yards is to be moved to other CSX facilities in western New York.

CTS Corporation planned to further restructure its operations, with plans to close its EMS operation in Tianjin, China, resulting in $3 million in fourth quarter charges. Combined with previous actions, the company will cut its global headcount by 10%.

CTS Corporation announced that it will implement additional organizational changes in North America. Starting next year, CTS will phase out production at its Elkhart plant by mid-2018 and transition the existing location into a Research and Development Center supporting the companys global operations. Certain actions are also being taken at other locations to simplify operations. Approximately 230 employees will be impacted over the course of the transition.

Cabot Corporation announced that it will stop production of carbon black at its Port Dickson facility, Malaysia, by the end of July 2013, following approval from the Board of Cabot Malaysia (CMSB). The closure, which will affect approximately 90 carbon black employees, is likely to result in one-time cash and non-cash charges to CMSB of around $13 million and $15 million, respectively.

UnionBanCal Corporation will trim its Pacific Northwest operations on April 30 by closing its lone downtown Eugene branch and a branch in Wenatchee, Wash. The San Francisco-based bank said it has shifted focus in the Northwest from trying to attract retail banking customers to stressing banking services to businesses and wealthy people. The closures will leave the bank with just four branches in Oregon and Washington.
Campbell Soup Co. is cutting about 400 jobs worldwide, reducing its work force by about 1.6% mostly through layoffs. The cuts are part of a corporate reorganization.

Campbell Soup Co. announced that it will eliminate up to 70 jobs at offices in Cherry Hill, N.J. The food company hired Accenture to handle certain financial services now handled internally by the office, which has 110 employees overall. Job cuts will be made over eight to 10 months.

The first major downsizing in the closure of the Campbell Soup Co. plant in Sacramento will be a loss of 290 jobs by Feb. 1. Campbell announced in October that it will close the Sacramento factory in phases for the ultimate shutdown in July. The closure of the plant this summer will cost 760 full-time jobs. According to documents filed with the state, 290 people will be let go by Feb. 1. Another 320 workers will be let go by May 1, and the final 150 employees will be done by July 1. The closure will mark the end of a six-decade run for one of the region's best-known businesses.

Campbell Soup Co. announced that it was eliminating 250 salaried positions as it tries to streamline operations and reverse a decline in sales. The company took a restructuring charge of $20 million to account for those positions. Through this and other measures, the company said, it expected annualized savings of $40 million.

Constellation Brands Inc. announced that it will cut 30 jobs at Widmer's Wine Cellars in Naples, Ontario County, by the end of May. The jobs represent one-third of the full-time staff working at the winery, located south of Canandaigua Lake. The elimination of jobs is not something the company likes to do.

Cardinal Health Inc. plans to cut 4,200 jobs, or about 7% of its work force, and close 25 offices as part of a three-year restructuring plan. Cardinal's 140 manufacturing and distribution facilities will take most of the job cuts and closings. About 1,000 jobs will be cut when Cardinal closes at a surgical glove plant in Malaysia. The rest of the job losses will be spread throughout the facilities, and the company has not decided which other sites will be closed.

Cardinal Health already warned investors to expect lower earnings for the first half of 2005. Before that warning, the company had expected 10% growth per share for all of 2005.

The company also announced a $500 million stock buy-back that will be funded through normal cash flow.

Cardinal Health Inc. announced that its board of directors has authorized the purchase up to $500 million of its common shares as management deems appropriate. 

The company expects to reduce its 58,000 global workforce by 4,200 during first phase, primarily through business consolidations and process improvements, resulting in the closing of approximately 25 facilities worldwide.

Cardinal Health Inc. will close a unit that trades in the secondary drug market where products are purchased from other drug wholesalers instead of directly from the drug makers. Cardinal Health will eliminate about 20 jobs by the end of June.

Cardinal Health Inc. announced that its Clinical and Medical Products businesses that are expected to be spun off later this year as CareFusion Corporation, will reduce its global workforce by approximately 800 over six months and eliminate an additional 500 positions through normal attrition and not filling open roles. In addition, Cardinal Health will implement cost control measures and additional reductions in discretionary spending across all of its businesses, primarily in response to a delay in hospital capital spending and the overall decline in the global economy. As part of the workforce reduction, Cardinal Health expects to record a restructuring charge of approximately $33 million for the remainder of fiscal 2009 and an additional charge of approximately $24 million in fiscal 2010. The company estimates this action will deliver annual savings of approximately $110 million to $130 million within two years.
Progress Energy has announced that it will lay off 80 to 100 telecommunications and information technology employees to cut costs.

Progress Energy cut 12 percent of the staff that oversees its data and phone systems. The Raleigh company dismissed 51 workers last week as part of an effort to streamline operations in the sluggish economy, spokesman Keith Poston said. That brings total reductions in the division to 96, counting 45 workers laid off in November. The company predicted in December that job cuts in the telecommunications division would affect 80 to 100 workers.

Florida Power Corp. reported that as part of a previously announced cost management initiative, the executive officers of Progress Energy Inc. approved a workforce restructuring. The restructuring will result in a reduction of approximately 450 positions and is expected to be completed in September of 2005. The cost management initiative is designed to permanently reduce by $75-100 million the projected growth in the Company's annual operation and maintenance expenses by the end of 2007. In addition to the workforce restructuring, the cost management initiative includes a voluntary enhanced retirement program. Approximately 3,500 of the Company's 15,300 employees are eligible to participate in the voluntary enhanced retirement program. The total cost management initiative charges could change significantly depending upon how many eligible employees elect early retirement under the voluntary enhanced retirement program.

Progress Energy Inc. has shut down its Shearon Harris nuclear plant in Wake County for a series of maintenance procedures that will include installing an electric generator from the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania. The 670-ton machine will give Wake County a historical link to the nation's only major nuclear accident, which disabled the Three Mile Island plant in 1979 and spread panic throughout the Northeast. The TMI generator is nearly in mint condition, having been used only a few months before the nuclear accident, then kept in storage for three decades. The equipment was brought to North Carolina this year by rail and by barge.

Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. have fine-tuned their staff-reduction estimates in their pending merger as the two North Carolina companies continue working on their merger integration plan. The companies told the N.C. Utilities Commission they expect to eliminate 1,860 positions over three years. That's down from an earlier estimate that placed the maximum potential staff reduction size at 2,000. The N.C. Utilities Commission, which is reviewing the proposed merger, requested the updated data. Merger critics argue that the enormity of the staff cuts during one of the most severe economic downturns in decades means the merger is not a public benefit for the state. Duke and Progress also disclosed that they expect to lay off about 347 people over the next three years. These will be redundant workers who did not take an early buyout offer or did not leave for another job. It's still not clear where the cuts will come from, but Progress has said it will shed hundreds of workers in downtown Raleigh as it dismantles its corporate headquarters here. The companies have been working on their integration since announcing in January they plan to form the nation's largest electric utility. The merger also requires approval from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, which has weighing concerns that the merger would give the combined company monopoly powers to manipulate electricity prices. The scope of layoffs is still unclear. It will ultimately be determined by the number of employees who voluntarily leave the company. The companies are encouraging workers to leave for other jobs so that they can limit the pain of layoffs and so that they can limit the amount of severance payments. Duke and Progress told the N.C. Utilities Commission that in November 2011, 8,177 employees at both companies have been offered a voluntary severance plan, also known as a buyout offer. These employees would be offered a severance payment.

Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. have fine-tuned their staff-reduction estimates in their pending merger as the two North Carolina companies continue working on their merger integration plan. The companies told the N.C. Utilities Commission they expect to eliminate 1,860 positions over three years. That's down from an earlier estimate that placed the maximum potential staff reduction size at 2,000. The N.C. Utilities Commission, which is reviewing the proposed merger, requested the updated data. Utilities Commission that in November 2011, 8,177 employees at both companies have been offered a voluntary severance plan, also known as a buyout offer. These employees would be offered a severance payment.
Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. expect to eliminate 1,860 positions in the three years following the merger.
Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. expect to eliminate 1,860 positions in the three years following the merger.

Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. have announced that they expect to eliminate 1,860 total positions over three years through voluntary departures, such as buyouts and retirements, and layoffs if needed. More than 300 positions are vacant. Buyout applications were accepted from November 7, 2011 to November 30, 2011. A total of 1,153 from both companies applied, very close to the 1,145 the companies expected based on similar previous programs. Of the 484 Duke employees applying for buyouts, 307 came from North Carolina, 61 from South Carolina and 113 from Indiana and Ohio.

Duke Energy Corporation and Progress Energy Inc. have announced that they expect to eliminate 1,860 total positions over three years through voluntary departures, such as buyouts and retirements, and layoffs if needed. More than 300 positions are vacant. Buyout applications were accepted from November 7, 2011 to November 30, 2011. A total of 1,153 from both companies applied, very close to the 1,145 the companies expected based on similar previous programs. Of the 484 Duke employees applying for buyouts, 307 came from North Carolina, 61 from South Carolina and 113 from Indiana and Ohio.
Carpenter Technology Corp. announced that its Specialty Alloys Operations unit will be laying off approximately 100 workers, in an attempt to reduce costs.

Carpenter Technology Corp. announced that it plans to reduce its salaried positions by about 200 or 10% of the total salaried workforce as part of a restructuring plan designed to reduce fixed overhead costs and position the company to drive long-term, profitable growth. The restructuring plan, which also includes the elimination of about 60 outsourced positions as well as other non-labor related costs, is expected to yield about $30 million of annual fixed overhead cost savings.
Cascade Corporation has announced that it has laid off 13 percent of its workforce as a part of its plan to reduce costs.
Cascade Corp. plans to close its Eldridge plant, laying off 23 workers. The workers make up about 22% of the company's wood-tress manufacturing staff.

Caterpillar Inc. is to axe 170 workers in the North East just months after making more than 130 staff redundant. This follows the loss of a 58 workers from the same site in June and the axing of 75 jobs at its sister fabrication facility in Stockton the same month.

Caterpillar Inc. announced another round of layoffs that will start next month at the Lafayette plant. About 106 production employees will be affected by the layoffs. The layoffs will start in November at the Large Engine Center on Indiana 26 East. Prior to the cuts announced, the company implemented a series of rolling layoffs for 985 employees at its Large Engine Center, where 580 workers already are on a layoff status that is expected to last at least through November.

The number of Caterpillar Inc. employees laid off June 12, 2009, at the Pontiac plant was not disclosed. Larry Stine, financial secretary for the United Auto Workers Local 2096, previously said 66 union members were to be laid off. June 12, 2009, was the last day for some, and June 19, 2009, will be the last day for the others.

Caterpillar Inc. announced that it laid off 100 of 1,100 production staff at its large- engine center in Lafayette, Indiana, and 200 workers at a Griffin, Georgia, generator plant, because of falling sales of generators and mining equipment.

Caterpillar Inc. announced that it will eliminate more than 900 jobs by closing an overseas plant and offering early retirement to some domestic workers. The company plans to cut 520 jobs through the previously-announced closure of its Perkins Engines manufacturing plant in Shrewsbury, U.K. Production from that plant will be shifted to other engine-making facilities. In the U.S., Caterpillar plans to cut about 420 jobs by June 30, through early retirement incentives in some of its divisions.
Caterpillar Inc. plans to eliminate about 940 of its 72,000 jobs world-wide and take related pretax charge of $55 million in fourth quarter.

Caterpillar Inc., is eliminating about 500 jobs as part of an effort to streamline operations at several plants, although the employees will be given the opportunity to seek positions elsewhere in the company, Caterpillar said. The action will affect salaried and management jobs, Caterpillar spokesman Ben Cordani said Tuesday. With 70,000 workers worldwide, the cuts represent less than 1 percent of its work foce.

Cato Corp. announced unaudited consolidated financial results for the fourth quarter and year ended January 29, 2011. For the quarter, the company reported total revenues of $227.334 million against $220.882 million a year ago. Income before income taxes was $12.807 million against $10.950 million a year ago. Net income was $7.924 million or $0.27 per diluted share against $7.311 million or $0.25 per diluted share a year ago. For the year, the company reported total revenues of $925.528 million against $883.995 million a year ago. Income before income taxes was $90.809 million against $68.914 million a year ago. Net income was $57.739 million or $1.96 per diluted share against $45.765 million or $1.55 per diluted share a year ago.The company provided earnings guidance for the first quarter and year of 2011. For the quarter, the company expects net income to be in a range of $27.4 million to $28.4 million, or $0.93 to $0.96 per diluted share, an increase of 9% to 13% over $0.85 in first quarter 2010 as restated. This estimate is based on same-store sales of down 2% to flat. For the year, the company estimates same-store sales will be in a range of down 2% to flat and its gross margin rate will decrease slightly to 38.1% from 38.4% in 2010 as restated, resulting in net income in a range of $59.2 million to $62.3 million, flat to a 5% increase over $59.2 million in 2010 as restated. The company estimates earnings per diluted share will be in a range of $2.00 to $2.11, flat to a 5% increase over $2.01 in 2010 as restated. Capital expenditures are projected to be approximately $32 million, including $17 million for store development. The effective tax rate is expected to be approximately 36.4%.The company expects to open 54 new stores during 2011. The expected new store openings include 10 new Cato stores, 34 new It's Fashion Metro stores (including opening approximately 17 Metro stores while simultaneously closing an existing It's Fashion store in the same market) and 10 new Versona Accessories stores. The company

Cato Corp. reported sales results for the five weeks and thirty-five weeks ended October 1, 2011. The company reported sales of $70.7 million for the five weeks ended October 1, 2011, a 2% decrease from sales of $71.9 million for the five weeks ended October 2, 2010. Same-store sales for the five-week period decreased 3% from the prior year.Sales for the thirty-five weeks ended October 1, 2011 were $636.4 million, a 2% increase over sales of $624.8 million for the thirty-five weeks ended October 2, 2010. The company's year-to-date same-store sales were flat to the prior year.During the month of September, the company opened 3 new stores, relocated 1 store and closed 1 store. New stores opened in Camden, AR and Jackson, TN and the company's first Versona store opened in Charlotte, NC. The relocated store was in Valley, AL. As of October 1, 2011.

Centex Corp. will cut about 100 jobs in Columbia and Greenville as it leaves for faster-growing areas elsewhere. Most of the jobs cuts will occur when sales cease on Sept. 30. Some workers will be offered transfers, others will work as homes are completed, and a few will stay two or three years to manage home warranties.

Centex Corporation announced it will cease its Colorado operations because of the struggling housing market in Denver. The company plans to close by spring of 2009. Centex has been calling home buyers with homes under contract that they will be closing their doors next year. The home builder has been in Colorado since 1981.
Centurytel Inc. laid off 65 employees at its call center. The laid-off employees will work until October.

CenturyLink, Inc. reported it is changing its operations in Denver in a consolidation that will lead to 170 job losses in Colorado and oust one of its Denver-based executives, Chris Ancell. The restructuring kicks in April 1, the first anniversary of its acquisition of Qwest Communications International Inc. The move will push out one of the former Qwest executives at CenturyLink and replace him in Denver with the top executive from Savvis, another company that CenturyLink acquired last year .

CenturyLink announced dozens of positions will be reduced in Louisiana as part of the company's proposal to eliminate 1,000 jobs companywide. The company will cut the headcount in Louisiana by about 55 positions. The company said earlier this month the cuts will affect CenturyLink's entire operations.

Champion Enterprises Inc. announced that it will close its manufacturing facility in Guin, Ala. as capacity utilization rate and profitability continue to run well below acceptable levels and any near-term improvement appears unlikely.
Charming Shoppes Inc., which operates Fashion Bug and Lane Bryant clothing stores, is closing 130 Fashion Bug stores as well as its Added Dimensions/Answer chain and its 77 stores.

Charming Shoppes Inc. announced that it plans to close 207 stores in the next year, including all its Added Dimensions and The Answer stores. The decision by the Bensalem-based retailer affects 1,900 workers, although company officials said job offers could be made in some of its remaining 2,300 stores. The targeted stores are losing money or are marginal performers, the company said. It did not disclose the locations of the stores to be closed. With the addition of the 651-store Lane Bryant chain purchased last year from The Limited Inc. Charming Shoppes has some 2,500 stores operating under seven brand names.
Charming Shoppes Inc. announced that it plans to discontinue its Lane Bryant Woman catalog and close about 100 stores in 2010. It sees $100 million to $125 million in savings from restructuring.
Charming Shoppes Inc. announced that it will shut about 100 stores in 2010 out of its 2,301 retail stores, pegging savings at $125 million.

Charming Shoppes Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the period, the company reported net sales of $559,105,000 compared to $575,831,000 a year ago. Loss from operations was $7,854,000 compared to $28,592,000 a year ago. Loss before income taxes was $10,916,000 compared to $31,976,000 a year ago. Net loss was $13,154,000 or $0.11 per basic share compared to $30,425,000 or $0.26 per basic share a year ago. Fourth quarter Adjusted EBITDA increased 18.7% to $12.7 million compared to $10.7 million a year ago. On a non-GAAP basis, net loss was $0.06 per diluted share for the fourth quarter, compared to a net loss of $0.08 per diluted share in the fourth quarter of the prior year.For the full year, the company reported net sales of $1,992,371,000 compared to $2,061,819,000 a year ago. Income from operations was $18,682,000 compared to loss from operations of $43,995,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $5,026,000 compared to loss before income taxes of $56,856,000 a year ago. Net loss was $2,017,000 or $0.02 per basic share compared to $53,982,000 or $0.47 per basic share a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $93,201,000 compared to $5,298,000 a year ago. Investment in capital assets were $34,932,000 compared to $35,778,000 a year ago. Fiscal year 2011 Adjusted EBITDA increased 62.3% to $81.4 million compared to $50.2 million a year ago. On a non-GAAP basis, net income was $0.03 per diluted share for the year, compared to a net loss of $0.26 per diluted share for the prior year. Net capital expenditures was $31.8 million, net of $3.1 million of landlord allowances.The company's consolidated net capital budget for 2012 is projected at $75 - $80 million, and includes capital for store growth of approximately $30 million, net of $5 million in landlord allowances, and capital for the transformation of IT and distribution operations, estimated at $30 million. The company is projecting depreciation and amortiza
Morgan OnLine has eliminated roughly 150 sales, marketing and other 'client acquisition' jobs.
J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. has announced that the company plans to cut unspecified number of jobs in Asia.

In Hong Kong, JP Morgan Chase & Co. announced it was laying off more than 100 investment bankers in the region in an effort to cut costs. The move by Morgan was the latest retreat by investment banks and brokerage firms the recovery at rushed into the region in 1999 and 2000, when markets from Seoul to Singapore were buoyed by an economic, surging technology shares and big public bailouts for ailing banks.
J.P. Morgan Chase Co. plans to complete its acquisition of Bank One Corporation corporate trust operations at the end of Octobe, 2003, and it will cut nearly half the Chicago unit's 525 workers.
JP Morgan Chase & Co. will reduce its worldwide work force by 22% to about 40,000, including a 30% cut in white-collar workers to 18,400.

JP Morgan Chase & Co. has told 600 Delaware workers their jobs have been eliminated due to the company's planned takeover of Bank One Corp. The banks employ 5,900 in Delaware; that will fall to about 5,300 by the end of the year, but may recover to as many as 5,700 next year as credit-card-management jobs, largely from New York, are consolidated in the Wilmington area. Both J.P. Morgan and Bank One have large credit-card operations in Delaware, a favorite of U.S. lenders because of its weak consumer-protection laws and low bank tax rates. J.P. Morgan plans to shut its card facility near Newark, Del., as it consolidates jobs at Bank One offices in the Wilmington area. Work will continue on two new Bank One transaction-processing facilities in Wilmington and Bear.

JP Morgan Chase & Co. announced that it is closing a credit service center and eliminating about 1,900 jobs by the end of the year as part of the restructuring that began when it merged with Bank One last year.

JP Morgan Chase & Co. plans to eliminate 20 jobs at its Orlando transaction-processing center over the next several months. The jobs, involved with the center's global funds clearing activity, overlap with work done elsewhere in the company, officials said. Affected workers were notified Friday and will be offered transfers to another Chase center in Tampa. The job cuts resulted from Chase's merger last year with Bank One, which formerly operated the Orlando site. More than 1,400 are employed there.

JP Morgan Chase & Co. plans to eliminate 170 jobs at Chase Tower in downtown Milwaukee by the end of February. The job cuts, which amount to about 12% of Chase's work force in Milwaukee, are in the home loan collections center. The positions will be transferred to offices in Columbus, Ohio; Dallas and Phoenix. All of Chase's 74 branches in Wisconsin will remain open, and Chase will continue operating a home loan processing center at the Chase Tower.

JP Morgan Chase & Co. announced that it will lay off 160 people from its Maywood office, as a result of the company's acquisition of a Bank of New York division last April. The layoffs will start March 25 and be completed in about two weeks.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced to lay off 300 Rochester-area customer service representatives who processed home equity loans. This decision was not made because of the quality of this work force. It was due to macro-economic factors such as the downturn in the national housing market, which led to a reduction in requests for home equity loans.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. is eliminating 71 jobs at its check-processing center in Cicero, a cutback that will leave just 50 employees at the facility. The job losses will start in September 2008 and continue until June 1, 2009. The company was giving advance notice of the action so employees will have the opportunity to apply for other jobs within Chase or seek jobs elsewhere. The employees who will lose their jobs are Chase employees.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced that it would shut down what remains of its wholesale mortgage channel.
J P Morgan Chase & Company announced that it would cut 12,000 jobs from the failed lender.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. has decided to close its warehouse lending division and is giving its nonbank customers just a few months to secure new lines. The New York banking company acquired the division last spring from Washington Mutual Inc. several months before it acquired the rest of Wamu's banking operations with government assistance. About 10 banks or thrifts are still active in warehouse lending, compared with roughly 30 a couple of years ago.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. will eliminate 2,800 jobs at Washington Mutual through attrition, bringing to 12,000 the total number of positions lost since the bank purchased the failed thrift in September. The bank may also cut head count in its investment bank to between 26,000 and 28,000.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. will lay off 19 employees and permanently close a Northeast Portland office. The layoffs in compliance with the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, which requires that employers give 60 days advance notice ahead of a plant closing or mass layoff. Employees of the centralized transaction operations office received notice of their terminations on April 2, 2009. Layoffs will begin June 5, 2009.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced that it is laying off 43 employees in its Treasury and Securities Services business in downtown Milwaukee as a result of a relocation of the business unit. Affected employees from its offices at 111 E. Wisconsin Ave. will be notified beginning September 2009 and continuing through November 15, when the first terminations will begin.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. has said that it was closing down its proprietary-trading operations and has given notice to its nearly 20 proprietary-commodities traders about the elimination of their jobs. JP Morgan has decided to exit all proprietary trading, impacting less than 100 traders within its investment bank.

JPMorgan Chase sent notice to the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services that it will close its Treasury and Security Services office at 303 Broadway in Cincinnati. The move affects 118 local employees, effective Dec. 16, 2011. The company, wrote in the notice that the company told employees about the office. Employees will start receiving formal termination notices Sept. 15 through Oct. 16.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. is likely to close its retail banking operations in Malaysia, in a bid to offload individual loans and deposits businesses, and to focus on wholesale banking across the globe.

A unit of JPMorgan Chase & Co. is closing a Coppell facility, a move that will affect 121 jobs. In a letter to the Texas Workforce Commission, the company announced that it will start layoffs around March 10 at the Coppell office at 1111 North Point Drive.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. plans to cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs, representing about 1.5% of company's overall workforce, in its consumer bank in 2013, as the bank tries to improve the profitability of its branches. The bank's branches have 63,500 employees, representing about a quarter of JPMorgan Chase's total employees.

With a decline in the demand for home mortgage services, JPMorgan Chase & Co. has planned the reduction of related positions. The bank aims to cut 435 positions across three Tampa, Fla., offices on Sept. 4, citing a Florida Department of Economic Opportunity worker adjustment and retraining notification notice. Meanwhile, some 400 workers in the company's Albion, N.Y. call center will also receive the pink slip, with the office's planned Sept. 3 shuttering. Remaining call center employees will be moved to Rochester units.
JPMorgan Chase will cut 450 mortgage servicing jobs at its CentrePort facility in northeast Fort Worth as the need for personnel to handle foreclosures decreases.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. will cut 300 jobs in Central Ohio as part of a wider swath of layoffs in its home mortgage division. The positions are all mortgage-related and spread across Columbus, Gahanna and Westerville. Employees were notified of the cuts, which take effect in 90 days.

JPMorgan Chase announced it plans to lay off 730 San Diego workers from its loan-servicing business as home refinances and foreclosures dry up. The local layoffs, to be completed by 2014, are part of a national plan announced six months ago by JPMorgan Chase to cut 15,000 jobs from its division that manages and receives borrowers?mortgage payments. The layoff is the large workforce reduction in San Diego County so far through 2013. JPMorgan will eventually close its entire office at 10790 Rancho Bernardo Road. The cuts will begin in 90 days, but some employees could be retained for up to a year. Layoffs will be complete by 2014.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. is laying off 186 Jacksonville workers. The workers are all in the bank's mortgage division, handling both origination and servicing of loans. The cuts are part of the company's previously announced plans to slash 13,000 to 15,000 jobs across the nation by the end of next year. The layoffs will be completed within 90 days and leave the bank with around 3,800 employee in the Jacksonville market. The move comes as the bank deals with fewer customers refinancing in the face of rising interest rates and a dwindling number of owners stuck in homes they can't afford.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. is shutting down a Lowell office and laying off all 60 people who work there. The first layoffs will take place in March, and the rest will be complete by the end of the year 2014. The closure of the office, on the 11th floor of 900 Chelmsford St. in Lowell, is characterized as a 'permanent shutdown' in the letter signed by Patricia Williamson, a Chase HR executive. The company official said that employees will be given 90 days notice and help finding new jobs. Of the 60 jobs being cut, many seem to be in IT, including nearly 30 applications developers. Several financialassociates and business analysts are also losing their jobs.

JPMorgan plans 8,000 layoffs this year 2014 as its mortgage and retail banking businesses shrink. About half of those job cuts had already been announced, but it is cutting more jobs than planned as it tries to keep expenses down. The new job cuts announced are split between its mortgage and retail banking businesses. They're on top of 16,500 layoffs last year in those areas. For years, low interest rates caused a boom in mortgage refinancing. But now interest rates are rising, and fewer Americans are refinancing. JPMorgan and other big banks reported double-digit declines in their mortgage business at the end of last year. JPMorgan Chase & Co. also says it will add about 3,000 jobs in other areas this year 2014.
JPMorgan Chase planed to lay off 155 employees in its Garden City mortgage operation. The layoffs at 900 Stewart Ave. are scheduled to take place by July 31, 2014.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. announced that the company is laying off hundreds of technology support employees within the company's corporate and investment bank on the back of a fall in revenue. Employees in New York, Tampa, Chicago and Dubai have been informed of the cuts. The cuts will see Luke Moranda, a managing director in charge of clearing technology, along with executive director Dan Cronin, leave the company.

JPMorgan Chase & Co. is set to terminate 163 mortgage servicing employees from its customer service office in Jacksonville, Florida. The job cuts is "just a responses to market dynamics," adding that fewer homeowners are having trouble with their mortgages.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. will lay off 65 employees in Tampa, Florida. The job cuts are part of its exit from the student loan business.

JPMorgan Chase is planning to close the technology center it opened at Syracuse University. The closure would eliminate 91 jobs, including 55 full-time positions, and included in the 91 jobs are 36 student internships. The internships are planned to end at the end of May. The JPMorgan Chase Technology Center in Lyman Hall will shut down on June 30. The move is part of JPMorgan Chase's efforts to centralize its cyber-related functions. The center was originally planned to be built near the Carrier Dome, but it was decided to have it in Lyman Hall instead.

JPMorgan Chase announced that it plans to close its offices in Garden City in December 2015 and lay off 195 employees. The company announced number of other workers, who are involved in activities including mortgages, are being transferred to other company locations in Manhattan, Brooklyn and elsewhere in the country. The company announced reason for the office closure is economic?and it stated in its notice to the state Department of Labor under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act, which requires businesses to give early warning of closings and layoffs.

JPMorgan Chase has shed 30 jobs at its Asia wealth management unit, as it refocuses on serving wealthier clients. The layoffs, which equate to 5% of its workforce in the region, mostly involved relationship managers in Hong Kong as well as Singapore. Over 10 employees had been laid off in Hong Kong. The move comes as JP Morgan shifts its focus to richer Asian clients with investable assets of over $10 million, up from the previous threshold of $5 million.

Chesapeake Corp. announced that it plans further plant closures and work force reductions as part of a broad cost-cutting program, announcing the restructuring in tandem.

The company reported earnings results for the third quarter of 2005. The company's third-quarter results are a sharp drop from year-ago profit of $5.4 million, or 28 cents per share. Revenue decreased to $254.8 million in the period from $256.6 million in the 2004 quarter.
