The company revised earnings guidance for the year 2005. The company slashed its year-end guidance by nearly half. Chesapeake now expects earnings of 45 cents to 60 cents per share, excluding costs associated with the restructuring and debt repayment. Previously, the company had forecast earnings of 80 cents to $1 per share.

Chesapeake Corporation announced that it has initiated a review and made a proposal to close its carton manufacturing plant in Brussels, Belgium. If the reorganization proposal is accepted and the Brussels plant closed, production will be transferred to Chesapeake's nearby carton operation in Gent, Belgium to support customer requirements.

Chevron Corp. announced that Some 76 Chevron workers in Concord associated with the two proprietary credit card businesses will be dismissed starting in February. All impacted employees will receive severance packages, which include educational reimbursement, redeployment and outplacement services. The staff reductions will continue as late as June.

Chevron Corp. will cut jobs from its worldwide refining, marketing and retail operations as the recession drags down gasoline sales. The impact on Chevron's extensive California operations, which include headquarters and two refineries, is unclear.
Chevron Corp. will cut 2,000 jobs in 2010 and sell some overseas operations as it revamps its struggling refinery, marketing and transportation operations.

Chevron Corp. will jettison 925 jobs in the East Bay, with the cuts coming in San Ramon and Concord. The job reductions are part of a previously announced effort by the company to restructure its marketing, retail, transportation and refinery operations, also known as its downstream business. The reorganization was triggered by difficult global market conditions affecting the downstream portion of the industry. Chevron expects those challenges will continue for the next few years. The reductions are part of a corporate gambit by Chevron to eliminate 2,000 jobs worldwide in its downstream businesses. Increasingly, Chevron has concentrated its initiatives on its exploration, development and production operations. Chevron's vast refinery in Richmond and its refinery in the Southern California city of El Segundo were spared in this round of cuts. Chevron is attempting to sell its Pembroke refinery in England.

Chevron Corp.'s Appalachian/Michigan division is cutting an estimated 162 jobs as part of its restructuring announced in November. The Appalachia business unit has about 700 employees in Pennsylvania.

Chevron is cutting 500 jobs from its headquarters in San Ramon as part of a global effort to slash costs by $1 billion. The layoffs already are occurring and the majority of them will be finished by November. In addition to the 500 job cuts in San Ramon, Ritchie said, the company will also cut its Houston office by 950 positions and trim 50 international jobs. The company will also eliminate 600 contractors.

Chevron is cutting staff in Perth as part of a global workforce cull to combat low oil prices. The company expects to slash its global workforce by between 6,000 to 7,000 employees over the next few years and reduce capital and exploration spending by billions of dollars. Perth employees have been notified of pre-Christmas staff cuts, just as oil prices hit a fresh low.

Brinker International Inc. will close 35 underperforming restaurants in the coming weeks as the economy continues its Darwinian sweep through the restaurant industry. The 35 restaurants, most of which will close before March 25, follow the 47 Brinker closed in the last year. The company's restaurants operate in one of the hardest-hit industry segments, casual dining.

Cincinnati Bell Inc. has offered 230 retirement eligible management employees an early retirement incentive, and announced that it will cut additional jobs over the next several years.Cincinnati Bell's board of directors authorized the decision December 7, requiring that eligible employees agree to the early retirement terms before December 31, 2007. The company expects that 25% to 45% of eligible managers will accept the offer, generating anywhere from $5 to $9 million in annual cost reductions, but costing the firm $9 million to $17 million in pre-tax benefits charges. Those numbers are also dependent on the age, salary and years of service of the employees. Cincinnati Bell did not disclose the number of additional jobs that would be cut or the expected economic impact of additional workforce reductions.
Milacron Inc. announced that it intends to step up its cost-reduction efforts by eliminating close to 300 positions in North America and in Europe.
Milacron Inc. announced that it will cut 130 positions, or about 10% of its work force, across its North American operations.

Circuit City Stores Inc. has quietly been laying off a dozen or so employees at a time at its corporate offices. The Richmond based retailer makes no bones about the job reductions. The most recent cuts came this week when one to two dozen workers got pink slips, according to employees. As of Jan. 1, Circuit City had the equivalent of 3,218 full-time employees working at its corporate offices. It employs the equivalent of 372 full time workers at its five area stores, a distribution center in northern Hanover County and a repair service center.

Circuit City Stores Inc. has shuttered 19 underperforming stores in 12 states, which CEO and chairman Alan McCollough says. The company is also planning to relocate seven stores this month, as part of its overall plan to move 18 units in fiscal 2004. Circuit City also anticipates opening 65 to 70 stores in its next fiscal year.

Circuit City Stores Inc. announced that it was laying off about 3400 sales employees in an effort to reduce costs and improve profitability. The store was laying off its highest-paid retail sales employees.

Circuit City Stores Inc. will cut 123 jobs in July as it shuts down the Firedog division's cable-TV installation business it was testing after it fell short of sales goals. The job cuts will be 'spread more or less evenly' in five states, Georgia, Maryland, Massachusetts, Texas and Virginia. Most were cable installers, though there also were a few managers and support staff.
Circuit City Stores Inc. is considering a plan to close at least 150 stores and cut thousands of jobs as an alternative to filing for bankruptcy-court protection.
Circuit City Stores Inc. announced that it is liquidating, closing all its U.S. stores and cutting 30,000 jobs after being hobbled, in part, by declining consumer spending.

Cliffs Natural Resources announced that the Wabush Scully Mine in Labrador is closing permanently. The mine in western Labrador was idled in the winter by Cliffs due to poor market conditions for iron ore. Local 6285 of the United Steelworkers estimates 350 workers were laid off but says many have found work since then either in the West or at the Muskrat Falls hydroelectric project.

Cliff Natural Resources has announced that it is permanently closing its Scully iron ore mine in Wabush, Canada, affecting about 500 mining workers. There are about 50 workers still working at the mine during the idling period, and the company plans to reduce the number of employees at the operation to ten by the end of 2014. No mining or processing operations haven taken place at the Scully Mine since February. As per the Mining Act, Cliffs Natural Resources is going ahead with its closure and rehabilitation plan.

Cliffs Natural Resources is starting to lay off workers at the Bloom Lake mine in Quebec in preparation for shuttering the operation next month. The Cleveland-based company said it will suspend activities at the mine, 30 kilometres southwest of Labrador City, by year-end. Cliffs said last week it would exit Eastern Canada amid low iron-ore prices after failing to find partners to share the cost of a $1.2 billion expansion required to make the operation viable.
Clorox Co. announced that it has reported to the EDD that it will chop 224 technology jobs, with the cut coming in Oakland and Pleasanton.

Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated announced that some 50 to 100 jobs will be cut at Coca-Cola Bottling Co. Consolidated as the company looks to drive efficiencies across the business. Coke Consolidated plans to trim its 6,000-strong workforce and streamline its management structure. The company said the changes would cost it US$2.5-3.5 million. Coke Consolidated wants to right-size the company. The company has developed new technology to speed up its distribution processes, which means there is a need for fewer jobs throughout the network.

Coca-Cola Co. announced that by year's end it will cut 100 to 125 jobs in its North America unit as part of a reorganization designed to spur growth and boost profits. Employees who lose their jobs will be offered severance packages. The cuts will be among the more than 3,500 full-time non-hourly U.S.-based employees in Coke's North America unit.

The Coca-Cola Co. announced that it would pay a former employee who blew the whistle on fraudulent activities at the soft drink giant $540,000 to settle a series of claims against the company. In return, ex-employee Matthew Whitley agreed to drop his complaints against the company and certain executives. In a joint statement, the two said Whitley will get the $140,000 entitled to him as severance from his layoff last spring, $100,000 to drop his cases in state and federal courts, and $300,000 to pay his attorneys fees. Whitley was seeking $44.4 million. 
 
 Whitley, a finance director for supply management at the fountain division, was among more than 1,000 people who lost their jobs in a sweeping reorganization in March. He claimed in the wrongful termination suit that he was fired because he complained about trumped-up numbers in a frozen Coke marketing test for Burger King five years ago, among other issues.

Coca-Cola Co. plans to shrink its work force at its massive accounting center in Brandon by 15%, outsourcing 150 white-collar jobs to Guatemala, India and Poland. With the goal of trimming millions of dollars in costs, the company announced plans to hire Capgemini. The company said the layoffs will affect neither the bottling operations in Tampa and St. Petersburg nor a 400-employee call center in Temple Terrace. The layoffs will begin at the end of the year and continue through June 2009. The company plans to shut down a shared services center in Dallas and downsize another in Toronto at the cost of 190 jobs.

The Coca-Cola Co. suspended production at its Perumatty plant, in Kerala, in response to an order by the provincial government. Local villagers opposed the plant on the ground that it was depleting the water table. The plant consumed 110,000 gallons of water a day and accounted for less than 2 percent of Coca-Cola's production in India.

Coherent Inc. revised earnings guidance for the fourth quarter ended September 27, 2008. For the quarter, the company expects its revenue to $141.0 million to $142.5 million, as compared to its prior revenue guidance of $154 million to $157 million. The company cited delivery push outs and lower orders predominantly from the microelectronics market as the primary reasons for the lower guidance.

The company also announced another major component of its EBITDA initiative. The company's excimer laser site in Munich, Germany will be closed and the operations of the site will be consolidated into the company's existing operation in Goettingen, Germany. The transfer will begin immediately and is scheduled for completion by the end of the company's third quarter of fiscal 2009.

Cohu Inc. announced that it plans to shut down its test equipment factory in Littleton, Mass., and move production to its Poway headquarters in order to cut costs in the wake of a lingering downturn in orders.

Colgate-Palmolive announced that its 2012 restructuring program, of which a plan for an expansion was approved by the board, will ultimately lead to a reduction in 3,300-3,800 positions from the global workforce.The company boosted its dividend by a penny, or 3%, to $0.39, payable on May 16, 2016 to shareholders of record as of April 22, 2016.

Aon Corp. announced that it would lay off 550 workers at its facilities in New York, Texas and Maryland. The company also will eliminate 50 jobs at its accounting facility in Owings Mills, Md. As part of the consolidation, 50 new positions would be created in Glenview. The layoffs were in keeping with a restructuring plan Aon announced in 2005, but did not specify if the job cuts were part of that plan or a later addition.

Comcast Corporation Cl A. has laid off 89 employees from the company still doing business under its former name, AT&T Broadband. Most of those laid off worked on upgrading the company's Twin Cities cable TV network, a project that is 95 percent completed and will be finished by next fall, said David Nyberg.

Comcast Corp. has eliminated one of its five operating divisions in a restructuring of its cable business. About 120 jobs will be lost in Michigan.Michael Doyle, the Eastern Division president whose wife, Lynn Doyle, hosts the popular CN8 show It's Your Call , is leaving the company as a result of the restructuring. The head of the Midwest Division, Bill Connors, will take the top job in Comcast's Eastern Division. The Eastern Division, with headquarters in Oaks, Montgomery County, comprises Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia and Ohio. The CN8 operation, which was part of Doyle's Eastern Division, will now report to Jeff Shell, president of the Comcast Programming Group.

Comcast announced that it closing a warehouse in South Jersey as part of a move to streamline its supply chain operations through a third-party logistics company and continue its customer service overhaul efforts. As a result of the move, 88 positions at the West Deptford facility are being eliminated as of June 16, 2017. All impacted employees will be given the opportunity to apply for positions with XPO Logistics, the global supply chain management corporation Comcast is contracting with, or another position within Comcast's large footprint in the region.

Comcast will lay off 72 employees this summer when it closes a Wixom warehouse to outsource that operation to an out-of-state firm. The company announced that it will close the Wixom warehouse at 49800 Martin Road, and lay off all the workers there between Aug. 17 and Aug. 30, 2017.

Comerica set to close 16 bank branches in Michigan. As part of an aggressive plan to cut costs, Comerica plans to consolidate a dozen banking centers in Michigan in 2017 and announced in an earnings conference call that it would save $42 million with a significant money-saving change to its pension plan. The cuts are part of a corporate restructuring effort announced in July called GEAR UP, focused on driving up Comerica's bottom line. The bank said it would reduce its head count throughout the corporation by 9%. Nationwide, Comerica plans to cut about 800 jobs and close 38 branches.
Citigroup Inc. announced that it plans to cut 2700 jobs in Mexico in order to reduce its merger-related expenses occurred due to the purchase of Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, in August 2001.

Citigroup Inc, rather than expanding its workforce by a few hundred people this year, CitiStreet will be laying off about 100 employees over the next several months. Across the company, the Quincy, Mass. -based global benefits management firm will cut about 3 percent of its 3,200-member workforce. One hundred of those jobs will come from the 1,000 employees in Jacksonville. Last year, CitiStreet said it planned to add about 200 jobs in 2003, following its hiring of 320 employees in 2002.

More than 800 jobs will be lost through the closure of a credit card customer service center owned by a major financial services conglomerate. Citigroup Inc. last week told employees that it would shutter its Sears credit card center by October. The office employs 847 workers who handle customer-service and collection calls. In addition to closing the New Orleans center, Citigroup has announced it will close call centers near Philadelphia and in Atlanta, Cleveland, Salem, Mass., and Tempe, Ariz.

Citigroup Inc. named Richard Burns to run a global team responsible for creating and marketing structured equity derivative products that can be sold to retail investors, according to an internal memo. Burns will also keep his current job as head of multi-asset and fund derivative products. Burns will report to Elmlinger in his new role, and continue to report to Elmlinger and Steve Jones in fixed-income for his existing job, the memo said.

The bank eliminated the jobs of Susan Lewis, head of European equity-linked capital markets, and Toby Smith, head of corporate equity derivatives in the region. It is cutting about 1,000 jobs, mostly in its corporate and investment-banking unit, to reach its target of increasing profit by at least 10% annually.

Citigroup Inc. announced that it is cutting structured corporate finance positions and folding the division into fixed income as part of a plan to eliminate about 1,000 jobs. Citigroup is eliminating 60 of the 300 structured finance jobs worldwide.
Citigroup Inc. is planning to cut costs drastically in 2007. The bank has unveiled plans to cut jobs and reduce costs by around USD 1 billion.

Citigroup Inc. announced that it plans to lay off 15,000 workers and take a $1 billion charge against earnings as part of a restructuring designed to cut costs. Citigroup will announce a restructuring on or before April 16. The company promoted Robert Druskin to a vacant chief operating officer position to sprearhead cost cuts. Druskin plans 5% reduction in Citigroup's 327,000-person work force. Aside from cutting jobs, Druskin is reviewing 150 to 200 areas of the company for possible cost cuts.

Citigroup Inc. announced that it expected to eliminate 300 more workers as part of its plan to save $4.6 billion over three years, bringing to 17,300 the total number of positions cut. The cuts resulted in $961 million in severance charges, part of a $1.38 billion pretax restructuring charge that Citigroup reported last month. The bank last month announced that it expected to trim around 5%of its global workforce of 337,000 full-time and part-time workers in a restructuring effort.
Citigroup Inc. has fired about 30 workers in the structured-credit group after the company suffered billions of dollars of mortgage losses. The firings cut the group's size by nearly a third.

Citigroup Inc. has revealed plans to close or sell some of its consumer finance businesses and retail units in Europe, Asia and the US. The moves come as part of the much-anticipated reshuffling program of Vikram Pandit, the lender's new chief executive. The reorganization scheme reportedly aims to bolster efficiency in Citigroup's global operations.

Citigroup Inc. is reportedly reducing its European leveraged finance team, which is based in London, from 27 to 14 staff as part of a plan to slash expenses after incurring billions of dollars in write-downs and losses. Those affected will be in junior positions, which could possibly be reassigned within the group.

Citigroup Inc. will dismiss thousands of investment-banking employees as part of plan to cut roughly 6,500-strong group by 10% in face of credit crunch; current round of layoffs will close some trading desks entirely and include dozens of senior managing directors.

Citigroup Inc., which announced that it would buy Wachovia in a $2.1 billion deal, has a much smaller retail-banking operation that may lead to relatively fewer job cuts here. From an employee standpoint, the people in the general bank are a lot safer now than if Wells had bought them. The company will cut approximately 3,000 jobs in Charlotte as it looks to eliminate overlapping functions between the two companies. Plath expects the move marks a significant change in Charlotte's status from a financial center to a retail-banking hub only.

Citigroup Inc. has issued notice to its entire staff of 12 investment bankers in Toronto, after opting to cover its Canadian operations from New York. Citigroup, which has announced a job-cut of 50,000 jobs, is planning to move its primary coverage of Canadian companies to its Toronto-based corporate lending group, which will be backed by US investment bankers on corporate finance, and merger and acquisition work.Among those leaving the firm by mid-December include president and CEO Robert Gemmell, and chairman Stanley Hartt.

Citigroup Inc. announced that it will close its downtown San Angelo bank branch and its branch in Ballinger. The actions will affect 10 employees. The last day for both banks will be March 27, 2009. Customers have been notified that their accounts will be transferred to the nearest Citibank location, which is 1609 Knickerbocker Road for San Angelo customers and the Citibank in Winters for Ballinger customers. The local closings are two of 14 that Citibank is doing in Texas. The downtown San Angelo location at 5 S. Chadbourne St. has six employees while the Ballinger bank at 718 Hutchins Ave. has four employees.

Citigroup, Inc. announced that it will be closing its Frederick, MD-based mortgage loan servicing office by the middle of 2010 and will move most of its 940 workers at the office elsewhere in the region. The relocated employees would either work from Citibanks larger Hagerstrown site or as remote workers from their homes. As part of the transition, about 40 positions will be cut. The shutdown of the Frederick office will help to increase the efficiency and cost-effectiveness of consumer banking operations while giving employees as many flexible work options as possible. The company said that it expects most of the relocating employees to work from home.

Citigroup, Inc. announced plans to cut 300 jobs in its sales and trading unit by year end. Its securities unit cut 900 jobs last year. The current round of layoffs is said to have been in the works before Vikram Pandit, Citigroup's former chief executive, left the company in October. The securities unit has about 17,000 employees.

Citigroup, Inc. has announced that about 1% of its 9,500 Florida employees are to be impacted by a reorganization plan. The company plans to cut about 11,000 jobs globally, as part of a move to trim expenses and improve efficiency. Most of the jobs impacted in Florida are in operations and technology. The company is planning to close 84 branches and scaling back consumer banking in Pakistan, Paraguay, Romania, Turkey and Uruguay to cut $1 billion in costs per year by 2014.

As part of its global cost cutting plan, Citigroup will be eliminating 50 positions in its Europe, Middle East and Africa division. About 50 investment banking positions in Citigroup Inc.'s Europe, Middle East and Africa division are facing imminent elimination as the bank goes through with its global cost cutting plan.

Citigroup Inc. announced on July 15, 2013 that it is set to shutter its call center in Danville, Ill., hence laying offapproximately 120 employees by the end of September. The facility, which opened in January 2012 to handle the increase in mortgage refinancing, is set to close due to the ongoing decline in refinance volume.

Citigroup, Inc. announced that it is slashing about 1,000 jobs in Nevada and Texas, citing decreased demand for home loans and mortgage refinancing. The company announced that about 760 of the jobs being eliminated are in Las Vegas, while another 100 are in Irving, Texas. The rest involve employees who work from home. Most of the employees being laid off will continue to work until Nov. 22, while some will stay on until March.

Citigroup announced it agreed to sell the mortgage-servicing rights to64,000 Fannie Mae homeloans with a balance of $10.3 billion.The salerepresents nearly 20% of the total loans serviced byCitiMortgage that are 60 days or more past due. The sale directly impacts about 200 workers at Citi's Fort Mill servicing operations. The employees will be laid off in the first quarter. Several hundred other jobs at the site serve different functions and are expected to continue.

Citigroup plans to cut 40 jobs in O'Fallon, Mo., as part of a broader restructuring of its mortgage business. The company plans to cut 950 jobs in that sector, of which about 650 will come from the closure of an office in Hagerstown, Md., that specializes in servicing home loans that have gone into default. Besides O'Fallon, offices in Las Vegas and Phoenix also will lose some jobs.

Citigroup Inc. has plans to lay off workers at its Hagerstown, Maryland office. The bank is said to have plans to dismiss about 100 employees from the office. The operations centre is located north of Hagerstown.

Commercial Metals Company announced the closure of its fence post operations in Magnolia, Arkansas. Production will be relocated to the San Marcos, Texas fence post production facility, as operations in Magnolia wind down and cease in their entirety by the end of the company's third fiscal quarter. Customers will not be impacted by this decision. In addition, CMC Steel Arkansas, a rerolling mill operated in Magnolia, Arkansas since 1987, will significantly reduce production levels over the same time period. These decisions are primarily the result of what CMC believes to be unfairly traded and illegally dumped steel products entering the US market.

Commonwealth Telephone Enterprises laid off 35 workers, or 3 percent of its local work force. Pat Amendola, director of corporate communications, said two bargaining unit positions were affected. The majority of the jobs were classified as management, professional and non-management suppport staff. Each person received a severance package, medical insurance coverage through Feb. 29 and outplacement services including career counseling. The layoffs were effective Monday. The company does not anticipate additional job cuts.
Unnamed sources have said that Cendant Corp. has cut about 6,000 jobs in response to the drop in the hotel occupancies and travel.

Computer Associates International Inc. announced a restructuring plan that would reduce its work force by 800 people worldwide, saving the business software maker $70 million annually once the plan is fully implemented.

Computer Associates International Inc. announced that it would again slash 5% of its workforce in a move expected to save it $75 million a year. The job cuts follow an earlier round of layoffs last September at the Islandia, N.Y., management software firm, under which it also handed pink slips to some 800 workers.

CA Inc. announced that it is planning to eliminate 400 more jobs than previously announced. The company said the cuts are part of a restructuring program launched in fiscal 2007, and take an additional $75 million to $100 million in charges tied to the reduction and the consolidation of global facilities.

CA Technologies announced 'fewer than 50 employees' on Long Island that their jobs would be eliminated. The company also announced that it would hire an equal number of employees over the next year for Islandia and other sites. Affected employees work in the company's Global Information Services unit.
Artesyn Technologies Inc. announced that it will be laying off approximately 12 to 15 percent of its workforce, due to lowered second-quarter earnings forecasts.
Artesyn Technologies has announced that it has laid off 28 employees at its Artesyn Communication Products division.

Artesyn Technologies Inc. has decided to move its production in Hungary to a partner in Romania, Karoly Hoffmann, who heads Artesyn's Hungarian unit. Production at the plant in Tatabanya (NW Hungary) will be outsourced to the Romanian unit of Canada's Celestica, one of Artesyn's partners. Artesyn will shut down the Tatabanya plant by the end of the year, laying of its 370 employees in phases.

Computer Sciences Corp. has laid off 200 employees including 165 in Greater Hartford, who worked on its contract with United Technologies Corp. The cuts represent about 17 percent of the company's workforce.

Computer Sciences Corporation announced that restructuring program, which is designed to streamline CSC's worldwide operation and leverage the increased use of lower cost resources, involves workforce reductions of approximately 4,300 employees during fiscal 2007, which began April 1, 2006, and approximately 700 employees in fiscal 2008. A majority of these reductions will occur in Europe, but plans will vary by country based on local legal requirements and consultation with works councils and employee representatives, as appropriate.

Computer Sciences Corp. announced that it plans to cut about 5,000 jobs, or about 6% of its work force, over two years and that a possible sale of the company is under consideration. Computer Sciences said it would cut its work force of 80,000 employees as part of a major restructuring to improve the company's cash flow and earnings. The restructuring plan involves 4,300 job cuts during fiscal 2007 and 700 job cuts in fiscal 2008. Most of the reductions will come in Europe.
Computer Sciences Corp. will lay off 53 employees at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. The cuts are effective May 31, 2008 and are due to business conditions.
Computer Sciences Corporation announced that it will lay off 146 employees in Cambridge on April 29, 2011.
Computer Sciences Corporation is planning to cut 92 jobs at a facility in Carrollton.
CTG has announced that it is laying off 42 employees, or 42 percent of its workforce, in Alaska.

ConAgra Foods Inc. has announced that it will layoff 100 workers at its Beatrice Cheese plant, approximately 45 percent of the workforce at the plant, at the end of November in an effort to cut costs.
ConAgra Foods Inc. will close a food service plant, move production to an existing plant in Texas and leave more than 200 employees without jobs by early next year.

ConAgra Foods Inc. announced plans to close five manufacturing plants and eliminate about 400 jobs as part of a long-term plan to cut costs. These closings are part of a reorganization plan the company announced earlier this year.

ConAgra Foods has officially shut down jelly operations in Placentia, its only Orange County manufacturing plant. The company already ceased production of Knott's Berry Farm products at the Placentia facility. Remaining employees are working to transition certain assets of the facility to J.M. Smucker and are preparing the plant for closing. Roughly 90 employees worked at the plant. Most have received severance packages and have already left the facility. Some people are still working at the plant, preparing it for closure sometime next year.

ConAgra Foods, Inc. has announced that it will complete the shutdown of its Garner Slim Jim production plant and lay off the remaining 394 employees there by May 27, 2011 nearly two years after a fatal explosion at the facility. Some 234 of the layoffs will take place by April 16, 2011. The remaining 160 employees at the plant will lose their jobs no later than May 27, 2011, which is the day the plant's permanent closure will take effect.

ConAgra Foods, Inc. announced that it laid off 35 of its 220 employees at its popcorn production plant Rensselaer. The decision was made as part of a shift reduction to "manage excess production capacity and to continue operating as efficiently as possible.

ConAgra announced to employees at its Carriage House Co. plants in Fredonia and Dunkirk that they will close the facilities, affecting 425 jobs. Employees International Chapter Union 266 NCFO President Tom Dickerson said that he suspected for a while that the plants would close. Dickerson said that employees were informed by ConAgra that the plant would begin a phased closing of departments in October, and that by February, operations would be moved to Buckner, where union spokesman Robert Dando said ConAgra runs a facility that manufactures similar items: tomato products, including sauces, jams, jellies, peanut butter, mayonnaise, chocolate syrup.

ConAgra plans to finish closing its Carriage House Companies plant in Fredonia on May 24, the company told the state Labor Department in a filing. ConAgra last March announced its plans to close the Fredonia plant.

ConAgra Foods announced that it is implementing a restructuring plan to improve profitability that will result in the elimination of approximately 1,500 jobs as well as non-recurring charges of approximately $345 million in order to realize at least $300 million on efficiency benefits within the next three years. The company announced job cuts represent approximately 30% of global office-based workforce, and excludes any impact from the planned divestiture of the private label operations. It will not eliminate plant positions in the restructuring. The charges, substantially all of which are expected to be cash charges, will be taken over the next two to three years. The company announced about $200 million of the cost savings will come from lower head count and non-headcount costs while $100 Million is expected to be realized from enhancements to trade spend processes and tools. The company announced plan will provide a modest benefit?to fiscal 2016 earnings. More than half the savings are anticipated to be realized by the end of fiscal year 2017 with the balance achieved in fiscal year 2018. The company announced these are in addition to $150 million in cost cuts achieved over the past two years.

Concord EFS Inc. announced that it plans to consolidate its operations following the acquisition of Star Systems Inc. In eliminating redundant positions, the company will lay off 250 employees which represents 10% of its workforce.

Steak n Shake Co. reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended July 2, 2008. For the quarter, the company reported total revenues decreased 6.1% to $144.3 million compared to $153.6 million in the comparable period last year. During the third quarter, same-store sales declined by 5.8%. Net loss for the fiscal 2008 third quarter was $9.8 million or $0.35 per diluted share. These figures compare to net earnings of $0.1 million or $0.00 per diluted share in the third quarter of the prior year. For the period, the company reported total revenues of $471,176,000 compared to $503,003,000 in the comparable period last year. Net loss was $13,794,000 or $0.49 per diluted share. These figures compare to net earnings of $10,281,000 or $0.36 per diluted share in the same period previous year.Current third quarter results included $14.1 million ($8.7 million, or $0.31 per diluted share, net of tax) of non-cash impairment charges, which include $4.8 million related to a group of 12 stores that it plan to close in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008, and $8.8 million related to 18 restaurants that were impaired because the carrying values of their underlying assets were more than the expected future cash flows. An additional $0.5 million related to three stores involved in a sale-leaseback whose net book values exceeded their fair values. The company plans to close 12 stores in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008.

The closing of an electrical product manufacturer here will leave 354 employees without jobs. Officials at Cooper Industries Ltd. said the 24-year-old plant will close by March 2003, but most of the employees are expected to be laid off by the end of this year. None of the employees have been promised transfers.

Cooper Tire and Rubber Co. has announced that it will layoff 60 employees at its El Dorado based Cooper Standard Automotive plant, approximately ten percent of the plant's workforce, due to economic factors.
Cooper Tire & Rubber Co. will close its distribution center on Dryden Road, moving it to another state, possibly Indiana. About 70 local jobs will be lost.

Molson Coors Brewing Company has announced that it is finalising plans for the closure of its brewing and packaging facilities in Memphis and the transfer of those operations to other units. The company announced in February that it planned to close the Memphis brewery in early-2007. It has now confirmed that it expects the phasing-out of operations to begin during the second half of the current fiscal year and to be completed by the first quarter of 2007. It expects to incur severance costs of between $15 million and $25 million other employee-related costs of about $10 million, with equipment relocation and other facility transition costs amounting to between $5 million and $15 million.
Molson Coors Beverage Company announced plans to cease production at its Irwindale, Calif., brewery by September 2020.

Corning Inc. announced that it will layoff 825 employees at its Photonic Technologies manufacturing sites in Benton Park, PA and Erwin Park, NY, due to a decline in the telecommunications industry. On February 1, Corning Inc. announced it will cut all 3

Corning Inc. announced plans to eliminate more than 600 jobs at its Corning Cable Systems plant in Hickory, N.C., by next summer. The layoffs are part of a major restructuring plan the company announced in April in response to the severe downturn in demand for fiber-optic network cables and other telecommunications equipment.
Corning Inc. on said it might eliminate more jobs and take other steps to cut costs amid further deterioration in the telecommunications business.

Corning Inc. announced it would shut down its picture tube plant. Coleman said the chamber is pursuing two tracks in trying to get the idle Corning Asahi plant back in America's economic production line exploring making it part of the homeland security product development center or as finding a traditional manufacturer interested in acquiring the plant.
Countrywide Financial Corp. announced that it will cut its work force by more than 2,500, or about 5%, even as growth in its loan servicing portfolio pushed its third-quarter profit up 2%.

Countrywide Financial Corp. announced that it cut 108 jobs in its wholesale Subprime division, citing a need to align the lender's 'workforce with the recent changes in the mortgage market.' As for the layoffs, the spokesman said the positions cut include area sales manager, area manager and junior area manager.

Countrywide Financial Corp. consolidated its wholesale lending operations in the Kansas City area, eliminating 16 jobs. It only affects loan fulfillment operations. The Kansas City operations were moved to 'nearby offices'.

Countrywide Financial Corp. is laying off 127 workers in Rolling Meadows, bringing to more than 1,370 the number of Chicago-area employees who have lost jobs at mortgage companies in the past nine months.

Crompton Corp. is cutting 18 salaried jobs at its Elmira chemical plant as part of a global restructuring strategy and a plan to make the Elmira operation safer. The plant now employs about 230 people. The 18 job cuts are among staff in areas such as accounting, engineering, human resources and environmental health and safety.

Chemtura Corporation announced that it will cut 10% of its staff as part of a larger restructuring project designed to save $50 million a year beginning in 2008. The job cuts will affect 620 positions and are expected to be completed by the end of the second quarter.

Chemtura Corporation announced that it plans to close its antioxidants plant at Pedrengo, near Milan, Italy, as part of a restructuring measure to lower costs. The company expected to complete the plant closure by the end of the first quarter of 2013. The company will switch production of the antioxidants made at Pedrengo to a toll manufacturer and to other company plants. The closure will reduce the costs of the products and provide greater flexibility in matching production volumes to customer needs.

Crown Cork & Seal Company Inc. announced that it has closed its plants in Modesto and Antioch, California; Fruitland, Maryland; Walla Walla, Washington; and a PET bottle plant in Hungary; and plans to close its European crown (bottle cap) operations in B

Crown Holdings Inc. plans to close its food can plant in Dorval, Canada and its beverage can and crown (bottle cap) plant in Montreal, Canada. There are approximately 175 employees who will be affected at the two plants, both of which are expected to close during the first quarter of 2009.The company provided earnings guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008 and full year 2009. In connection with the two plant closures, the company expects to record a pre-and post-tax charge of approximately $21 million (CAD 26 million) in the fourth quarter of 2008.For the full year 2009, the company expects to record a pre-and post-tax charge of approximately $4 million.
Cummins Inc. announced that it will cut at least another 500 jobs this year and terminate an engine-development project amid declining conditions in the heavy-duty truck market.

Cummins Inc. confirmed that it was making 180 workers redundant following a collapse in orders. The firm which had already shed 100 full-time staff and 111 temporary workers before Christmas, had fought to avoid making 130 of the 180 redundant, as production fell by more than two thirds. But with conditions worsening, it decided to axe all 180 jobs by April 7. The latest losses will reduce its headcount by almost half.

Cummins Inc. is laying off nearly 200 workers at its Columbus MidRange Engine Plant in response to a drop in orders by Chrysler Group LLC. The company announced that the 194 layoffs will take place, cutting the plant's employment to about 400 and paring its two shifts to one.

DST Systems Inc. cut 1% of its workforce and anonymous reported from employees it included about 150 people in the Kansas City area. The hardest hit by the layoffs was the DST Brokerage Solutions office in Baltimore, which now is closed.

The Wendy's Co. announce that the location at 7724 Crestwood Boulevard was closed after the undisclosed franchisee decided not to renew his lease with The Barber Cos.The company is hoping to open another Wendy's close to the closed location by early 2014, if not in 2013.

Dana reported earnings results for the second quarter of 2006. For the quarter, the company reported net loss of $28 million compared to net income of $30 million year-on-year, from sales of $2.3 billion. The company announced that $34 million in reorganisation charges were recorded this quarter, including $30 million in professional fees.The company also announced that it is currently looking to dispose of 44 facilities worldwide and is seeking to cut its retiree benefits to reduce its bottom line expenditure and enable it to emerge from Chapter 11 as a leaner, profitable concern.

The Dana Corp. said that it would close an Indiana foundry that makes engine cylinder liners for heavy-duty trucks next year and eliminate most of the plant's 210 jobs to reduce costs. The foundry, in Richmond, Ind., is unprofitable and the company has not been able to find a buyer for it. The closing is in addition to Dana's plan announced in October 2001 to trim 11,250 positions.

Dana Corporation is implementing restructuring plans due to a decline in its fourth-quarter net results. The company's plans include cutting its workforce by 10,000 people, closing 11 facilities worldwide, cutting net costs and consolidating operations.
Dana Corporation has announced that the company plans to layoff 15 percent of its workforce as a part of its restructuring, including the eight percent reduction already achieved.

Dana Corp. announced it will eliminate a total of approximately 800 jobs at one Canadian and three Australian plants in 2006. By December 2006, approximately 500 jobs will be eliminated at Dana's Structural Products plant in Thorold, Ont. This reduction results from the expiration of a supply agreement for truck frames. With the remaining work force of 180 people, this plant will continue to serve as a stamping operation supplying multiple Dana facilities. By mid 2006, the company will also cut as many as 300 jobs from its Traction Products facilities in Salisbury, South Australia; Cheltenham, Victoria; and Yennora, New South Wales.
Danaher Corp. will eliminate 1,700 jobs as part of a restructuring the company says will save it $100 million in 2009.

Target Corp. announced a workforce reduction at headquarters locations which affects 9% of headquarters population. This includes the elimination of approximately 600 employees and 400 open positions, primarily in the Twin Cities area. The majority of these changes are effective January 27, 2009. In addition, the company announced it will close its Little Rock, Ark. distribution center, which currently employs 500 people, later 2009. The company has recently undertaken other actions to manage expense and capital investment and minimize the number of affected employees. These actions include suspending salary increases for senior management, suspending share repurchase activity, tightening credit card underwriting and credit granting, implementing initiatives to improve store productivity, reducing planned new store openings, and cutting outside contractor support, travel, entertainment and other headquarters operating expenses. As a result of these actions, the company expects to record a charge of approximately 3 cents per diluted share, the majority of which will occur in the company's 2008 fourth quarter. The company believes the annualized benefit resulting from these actions will exceed the charge.

Target Corp. announced to close an underperforming store in Manassas after the first of the year, one of two locations it has there. The Target store at 8340 Sudley Road will close Feb. 2, 2013. The closing does not affect operations at its store at 9900 Sowder Village Square in Manassas.

Target Corp. announced that it is laying off 550 employees in its Minneapolis corporate offices, following its failed Canadian expansion. Of those 550 employees, the company said that approximately 350 Minnesota based positions are being eliminated on February 11, 2015. Most of the remaining 200 employees are needed through the closure of the Target Canada stores and their positions will be eliminated following the liquidation period.

Target Corp. laid off 100 administrative assistants and eliminated another 40 open positions from its Minneapolis headquarters. Target said it is restructuring its administrative support model to reduce its workforce and 'drive efficiencies.' Laid-off employees will get minimum of 15 weeks of pay and more severance based on years of service. Target will keep paying its portion of benefits for six months.

Target Corp. laid off 180 workers in India and eliminated another 125 positions there as part of the retailer's large workforce reduction that began in the U.S. in March. Until June 3, the job cuts hadn't touched the company's India operations, where about 2,800 people work for Target.

Target Corp. conducted another round of layoffs, eliminating 140 employees who primarily work in its Business Performance Optimization Center of Excellence. The company said the layoffs are part of the company's $2 billion restructuring plan announced in February 2015. The company's employees will receive the same severance package that previously laid off employees got. The company has now cut 2,360 jobs in the U.S., 17,600 in Canada and 350 in India in 2015.

Agricultural machinery giant Deere & Co. will close its Springfield electronics plant, eliminating about 200 jobs within nine months. The company's plan calls for Deere's Phoenix International plant to close by Nov. 30 and the work performed there to be eliminated or added to the workload at the Phoenix International plant in Fargo, N.D. Deere said layoffs at the nonunion pant could begin at the end of July, although some workers will remain until the plant closes. A limited amount of employees may transfer to the Fargo factory or other Deere plants, and the rest will receive severance pay and help finding new jobs.
Deere & Company has announced that it will layoff 50 salaried workers based at Horicon, Golden through voluntary retirement scheme.

Deere & Co. will close its plant in Woodstock, Ontario, Canada, later this year and move production to existing plants in Iowa. The Woodstock plant makes full-tree forestry products for Deere's Worldwide Construction and Forestry Division. It employs 325 people, and some of the workers will remain on the job until the plant closes in September. Production will be moved to plants in Davenport and Dubuque.

Deere and Co. announced that majority of the remaining 200-strong workforce at Woodstock plant will leave the factory for the last time when production there ends August 31. The company said that all plant employees should have their permanent layoff notices. Production at the Woodstock plant is shifting to factories in Dubuque and Davenport, Iowa. The closure is the result of a decision to consolidate the company's forestry division following a 2005 review of Deere operations.
Deere & Co. Dubuque plant laid off 50 manufacturing employees, following 25 job cuts in mid-September, as the unstable construction industry shakes up business at several local manufacturers.

Deere & Co. announced that it will lay off nearly 700 workers between factories in Brazil and Iowa. The company says it'll fire 502 workers at an agricultural harvesting equipment plant in Horizontina, Brazil. And 190 employees at a plant in Davenport, Iowa, which makes construction and forestry equipment, will be laid off or temporarily reassigned effective Feb. 16.

Deere & Co. announced that 40 employees of the John Deere Ottumwa Works will be placed on indefinite layoff later this month due to reduced market conditions for the factory's products. The layoff affects production workers with the least seniority. The company informed employees at the factory last week of the layoffs, which are effective April 20, 2009. The John Deere Ottumwa Works manufactures balers, mower conditioners, windrowers and pull-type forage harvesters used by hay and livestock producers.

Deere & Co. announced that 40 employees of the John Deere Ottumwa Works will be placed on indefinite layoff later in April 2009, due to reduced market conditions for the factory's products. The layoff affects production workers with the least seniority. The company informed employees at the factory of the layoffs, which are effective April 20, 2009.

Deere & Co. announced that about 800 salaried employees will leave as part of a voluntary program announced in April and the company will take a pre-tax charge of $100 million. The company previously forecast that 200 salaried positions would be cut.

Deere & Company announced that it will place approximately 460 employees who work in the company's Waterloo, Iowa operations on indefinite layoff in response to current market demand for its products. Employees were informed of the layoffs, which are effective October 20, 2014.

Deere & Co. announced the number of workers cut from its Iowa plants will grow to 1,000, raising concerns that a rock in Iowa's economy is beginning to wobble. The company announced that the layoffs and extended plant shutdowns are needed to match its workforce with softening demand for tractors and other machinery. Deere announced that it's cutting 460 workers from its Waterloo plant, and it announced it's laying off most of its 600 workers at plants in the Des Moines and Quad Cities areas. The reductions begin at the end of the month and run through October.

Deere &Company announced it will make workforce adjustments at several factories in Iowa and Illinois. The actions include indefinite layoffs at five locations that build agricultural equipment as well as an extended inventory adjustment shutdown at another factory. In addition, the company announced it has added new jobs at two locations that build construction and forestry equipment. The company said the workforce adjustments reflect the economic forecast included in the company's November 2014 earnings report as the company continues to align the size of its manufacturing workforce to market demand for products. The changes will place approximately 910 employees on indefinite layoff from facilities in Iowa and Illinois. Deere said the approximate number of layoffs at each location include 565 total at three locations in Waterloo, IA; 300 at the Des Moines Works in Ankeny, IA; and 45 employees at Harvester Works in East Moline, IL. In addition, approximately 500 employees at Deere's Seeding and Cylinder facility in Moline will go on an extended inventory adjustment shutdown. That location typically has a seasonal inventory adjustment this time of year. For Seeding and Cylinder employees, the adjustment shutdown is expected to end in late summer. The layoffs announced on January 23, 2015 are effective at different dates for each location. They begin in early February and most are effective in late March. Meanwhile, Deere has added 220 new jobs at construction and forestry factories in Iowa. These two factories - Dubuque Works and Davenport Works - have each added 110 new jobs. The company announced the nearly all of these positions have been filled by individuals who had been working for Deere at other locations but were laid off after the company announced workforce reductions at agricultural equipment factories in August.

Deere & Co. says it will lay off about 125 workers at two Iowa factories. The company announced that about 75 workers would lose their jobs at Deere's factory in Dubuque and 50 would be out of from their jobs in Ankeny. The Dubuque layoffs are effective April 29 and the Ankeny cuts are effective April 15. The company says it bases its manufacturing workforce based on market demand.

Due to a prolonged strike, Delta Air Lines Inc.'s regional-carrier division, Comair Inc., will layoff 200 of its 1,350 pilot jobs and cut its fleet by 14% or about 17 planes, in an effort to decrease costs.

Empty seats and a sluggish economy forced Delta Air Lines Inc. to cut another 7,000 to 8,000 jobs amid mounting losses, the airline announced Thursday. Delta, the nation's third-largest airline, has slashed 21,000 jobs, or about 25 percent of its work force, since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. The job cuts come two days after the Atlanta-based carrier posted a third-quarter loss of $326 million and said it did not see any improvement coming soon. Delta has furloughed 918 pilots since it announced up to 1,400 layoffs last year. ALPA is contesting the remaining furloughs.

In October 2002, Delta Air Lines Inc. announced it intended to reduce between 7,000 and 8,000 jobs from its workforce. Approximately 3,900 jobs will be reduced through voluntary programs.Up to an additional 4,000 jobs are expected to be reduced through involuntary programs. Most of these job reductions will be completed by May 1, 2003. The total cost of the job reduction program is estimated to be approximately $175 million, pretax.Delta will recognize $125 million of this amount as a one-time charge in the fourth quarter 2002 and the remaining $50 million in the March 2003 quarter.

People who fly Delta Airlines' service between Buffalo and Atlanta will soon have more daily flights to choose from, but fewer seats to book. The changes will also force Delta's 22 employees at the Buffalo Niagara International Airport to apply for other jobs. Starting June 1, the airline will switch all of its Buffalo-Atlanta service to Comair regional jets, and add two daily flights. Delta's 22 employees at the Buffalo airport will not be guaranteed jobs with Comair or Delta when the switch is made.

Delta Air Lines Inc. was shuttering one of its three call centers in India but declined to discuss whether the move was related to a survey asking customers if they would be willing to pay a fee to speak to a U.S-based agent rather than one in India. The question about the call fee was contained in an online survey sent earlier this summer to select frequent fliers. Delta is seeking to cut costs and raise additional revenue to avoid bankruptcy.

Delta Air Lines Inc. will cut up to 7,000 jobs, or 10% of its overall work force, during the next 18 months. There will be a 15% reduction in administrative overhead costs including management cuts. A reduction in wages will announced by the end of the month and employees will be expected to pay larger contributions for health insurance.
Delta Air Lines plans to shut its Boston reservations call center Sept. 1. The move will eliminate about 353 jobs.

Delta Air Lines Inc. reported that it would cut up to 7,000 jobs over 18 months. 

Delta reported that it would have to tap available cash and the final $250 million it borrowed late last year from American Express Co. to meet liquidity needs. But the company has $3.4 billion in obligations in 2005 related to leases, interest on debt, debt maturities and funding of employee pensions.

Delta Air Lines Inc. now expects to cut 9,000 jobs, the high end of its previous forecast, as it completes its bankruptcy reorganization. Delta filed for Chapter 11 protection on Sept. 14, beset by high fuel expenses and an inability to trim labor costs. The Delta bankruptcy plan anticipated to lay off between 7,000 and, now, 9,000 people,' and the airline, based in Atlanta, is 'on the road' to meet that target by the end of 2007.

Delta Air Lines announced that it is eliminating more jobs and cutting additional Memphis flights. The 126 positions to be cut are customer service and cargo jobs. The number is in addition to the 230 jobs the company announced in June that it planned to cut this fall. The company also said at the time it would go from 96 flights per day down to 60. Additionally, In-Flight Service will also close its Memphis flight attendant base.

Shutdown of the Deluxe Corp. plant will begin immediately and be completed within 18 months. Some of the work now done in Athens will be moved to a Deluxe facility in Streetsboro in northeast Ohio. Plant will close, cutting 360 jobs.

Deluxe Corp. announced that it is closing its small-business call center in Colorado Springs and laying off the 225 employees who work there as it shifts work to its other call centers, beginning in January, 2010. The company announced that another Colorado Springs center with 300 employees who handle calls from consumers for Deluxe's Checks Unlimited check-printing unit is not affected. That unit laid off about 100 employees in 2009 after consolidating check-printing operations in Salt Lake City and Kansas City, Mo., reflecting effects of consumers' shift from personal checks to electronic payments.

Twenty-seven employees at DTE Energy's Stoneman Station biomass plant were informed that the plant will shut down by the end of 2015. The DTE plant burns wood waste from many sources to produce up to 40 megawatts of electricity per day, which is enough to serve nearly 30,000 homes. This energy is purchased by Wisconsin-based Dairyland Power Cooperative.

About 160 full-time workers were laid off and sent home from DRS Technologies Inc.'s plant on Hibiscus Boulevard in Melbourne, a painful reminder that broader economic forces--not just the pending retirement of the space shuttle--will continue to buffer Brevard County's employment outlook. The recession and reduced orders for military hardware necessitated the layoffs, leaving about 900 employees. More than 1,200 space industry jobs have been lost this year.

Dillard's Inc. will leave South Square mall at the end of the summer, opening the door for the beleaguered mall's long-expected closing.Employees at the dying mall's last anchor tenant learned Thursday morning that the store will close on Aug. 17, salespeople said. That they will do best to offer positions to those 100 hardworking associates at other stores in the area, a Dillard's spokesman who confirmed the store will close in August.

Dillard's Inc. announced that its Westfield Midway store in Elyria that the location will close sometime this spring because of poor sales. The 150,000-square-foot Elyria store, which Dillard's acquired in 1992 from the Higbee Co., has about 100 full- and part-time employees.
Dillard's Inc. announced in a filing with the Texas Workforce Commission that it plans to eliminate 126 jobs.
Dillard's Inc. announced that it was closing its underperforming travel agency service. Dillard's has travel agency services in 43 of its 318 stores. About 160 are employed by the travel agency.

Dillard's Inc. to close its department store at Columbia Place before the holiday shopping season gets under way at Thanksgiving. The company plans to keep open its other Midlands store at Columbiana Centre. The 120 company's employees at Columbia Place were told the store would close Nov. 4 after 12 years. The company will try to place as many workers as possible at its Columbiana store.

Dillard's Inc. will lay off all 148 employees at its Ward Parkway Center store, effective Oct. 25, in preparation for converting the store to a clearance center. Ninety-five of the employees are sales associates, Michael Waltman, spokesman for the Missouri division of workforce development. Some of the laid-off employees will be retained to work at the clearance center. She had no estimate of how many employees will work at Ward Parkway store when it becomes a clearance center.

Dillard's Inc. announced a strategic staff reduction of approximately 500 associates as part of its ongoing efforts to reduce operating expenses. The workforce reduction includes approximately 60 associates in Little Rock, Arkansas. Dillard's employs approximately 60,000 associates nationwide and approximately 2,400 in the Little Rock area.

Dillard's Inc. announced that it has laid off 50 information technology workers as a new executive takes over the division. The cuts came in response to "changing technological needs." The work force reduction represents about 10% of the Little Rock-based information technology department.The company also announced that Woodrow Chin has succeeded Bill Holder as the new chief information officer.

Dillard's clearance center at Tri-County Mall in Springdale is expected to close later in 2015. The Springdale store occupies the most square footage among any mall tenant, and its closure helps accelerate redevelopment plans. The mall at 11700 Princeton Pike opened in 1960.The closure is part of the department store operator juggling its retail footprint as it plans an October 2015 opening for its new 155,000-square-foot store at the $350 million Liberty Center mall in Liberty Township.
Dillard's has announced the upcoming closure of its Paradise Valley Mall location in Phoenix, Arizona (200,000 square feet). The company expects to close the location by the end of the fiscal year.
Walt Disney Co. to close Boulevard Mall's Disney one of 98 stores nationwide.

Walt Disney Co. announced that its Disney Store in Weberstown Mall. The longtime store in that Stockton mall will close by month's end. The network of Disney stores has been operated by Disney since the third quarter of last year, when the company repurchased 220 Disney stores from the Children's Place Retail Stores Inc. while closing 98 U.S. stores. The stores have been suffering from declining sales. Children's Place bought the 313-store Disney Store retail chain in North America from Disney Co. in October 2004 but filed for bankruptcy protection in March. Disney has been a longtime retailer in that spot, in the Sears wing of the mall.

Walt Disney Co. plans to cut about 1,000 information-technology jobs and outsource them to two other companies beginning in mid-July. The long-anticipated cuts, outlined to employees on Thursday, affect one-third of the company's 3,000 IT jobs, which provide technical and network support at company offices in Orlando, Los Angeles and New York. The number of positions to be outsourced in Orlando is 230, according to a notice filed with the state.

Walt Disney Co. has halted all creative and design work on the expansion of Hong Kong Disneyland, cutting more than 30 jobs. The company acted after being told by the government that there was no timetable on the way forward.

Walt Disney Co. will lay off an unspecified number of workers as it restructures its U.S. theme parks in the wake of declines in attendance and revenue. The company announced global business and real estate development will be combined under a new team led by Executive Vice President Nick Franklin. 'Back-of-house' operations, such as menu planning or merchandise development, at Walt Disney World in Orlando, Fla., and Disneyland Resort in Anaheim, Calif., will be consolidated under Al Weiss, president of worldwide operations. Engineering and design teams also will be merged into a single unit.

The Walt Disney Co. Feature Animation will lay off 250 people, or 18.5 percent of the division work force, over the next 12 months, The move is part of an ongoing effort to shift Disney animation from having a large number of animators on staff to hiring on a per film basis, The cuts will mostly affect people working in Burbank. After the cuts are made, the animation division will have about 1,100 employees, down from a peak of 2,200 in 1999.
The Walt Disney Company announced that it laid off 4000 employees from its global workforce. It cited a weak economy as the reason for lay offs.
Walt Disney Company announced that it has laid off 100 of its craft/maintenance workers, or 2.5 percent of the craft/maintenance employees, at its theme park, Walt Disney World.

The Dixie Group Inc. announced that it would move carpet-making machines from Eton, Ga., to its Atmore plant as part of a restructuring. The 360-employee Atmore plant could gain workers under the company-wide cost-cutting plan, but there will be more losers than winners. The company aims to cut 5 to 7% of its workers. The new cuts will claim up to 90 of Dixie's 1,300 workers. From 30 to 40 workers are expected to be laid off in Georgia, though a distribution center there will remain open.
The Dixie Group Inc. announced that the company will cut about 75 to 80 positions on top of about 110 staffing cuts made in April, 2008.

Dollar General Corp. has announced that it will close eight Iowa stores. The company plans to close three stores in the Des Moines area along with stores in Clinton, Dubuque, Le Mars and two in Mason City. The Des Moines-area stores are in West Des Moines, Urbandale and Johnston.

Dominion Resources, Inc. announced that the State Line Power Station in Hammond, Ind., will close as soon as 2012 and no later than 2014. Dominion announced it was not worth upgrading the plant to comply with the federal Clean Air Act.

Dominion Resources Inc. announced that it will cut about 150 jobs companywide over about the next three months. The company is not eliminating whole departments or offices and it's trying to avoid layoffs. The company expects that fewer than 150 jobs will be eliminated out of a workforce of more than 15,500.

R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co. announced that it has consolidated work in fewer plants, reduced workweeks and laid off workers and temporarily idled equipment in selected locations. The company also announced that it will also cut 250 general and administrativ

RR Donnelley & Sons Co. announced that It will be cutting 89 jobs in Waterloo at the Former Perry Judd's. The jobs will be cut on or after March 26. It was unclear if the 89 jobs are all the positions in Waterloo.
Dow Chemical Company has announced that it plans to fire about 1500 employees, or about 40 percent of the workforce at its acquired companies.

Dow Chemical Co. will eliminate about 110 jobs from its Michigan Operations facility as part of an continuing cost-cutting plan. The cuts represent 3.6 percent of the facility's work force. The company said it plans to hire outsiders to do the jobs of seven maintenance work groups. In addition, two work groups will be combined into one as part of the cost cutting program. The affected units involved electricians, machinists, millwrights, riggers and fabricators.
Dow Chemical Co. has announced it would eliminate 110 jobs, approximately 3.6 percent of the work force, at its Michigan Operations plant as part of a cost-cutting plan.

Dow Chemical Co. will lay off 125 Michigan employees by May. Dow has about 3,000 employees at its Michigan Operations and another 3,000 at its headquarters in Midland. Veurink said the layoffs will mostly affect workers with the least seniority. About 30 employees will be laid off by the end of January, the company said.

Dow Chemical Co. won't invest in the Dutch rubber plant operated on its behalf by Shell Chemicals, and the factory will close, Dutch union CNV Chemie en Energie said in a statement. Closure of the general-purpose rubber plant in Pernis, Netherlands, will result in the loss of about 100 jobs, according to the union.

Dow Chemical Co. cut 147 positions in South Charleston in 2004. The company announced it would lay off about 160 people in South Charleston. But 17 people transferred from the facility and five people transferred to it, which also said 1,024 people now work for Dow in the Kanawha Valley. The 147 cuts represented more than 10% of Dow's West Virginia workforce. Dow cut about 3,000 jobs worldwide in 2004, a year in which the company recorded record profits.

Dow Chemical Co., The plans to close its South Charleston Alkyl Alkanolamines plant in the next two to three years and move production to a new facility in Louisiana. The new Specialty Alkanolamines plant is scheduled to open in Plaquemine, La., in early 2007. It will replace both the South Charleston plant and production at the company's operations in Midland, Mich., Dow stated. About 20 to 30 employees work at the South Charleston facility or provide support for it. Company officials do not know how many will be affected by the plant's closure. Dow said the new plant in Plaquemine will have extensive product-mix flexibility to meet changing market demands.

Dow Chemical Co. announced that it will pull out its 150 research and development jobs over the next two years. The jobs are expected to be relocated either to Dow's facilities in Texas and Michigan or moved to one of the company's international operations. Dow plans to keep about 100 workers on the site to support the gas-phase polyolefins pilot plants at the site. He also said Dow's South Charleston manufacturing plant will continue to have about 550 employees. The company's decision to move the R&D jobs out of South Charleston is part of a company-wide shift in employment that impacts 1,000 jobs worldwide. The impetus for the shift comes down to money and profits. He said the rising costs of natural gas, oil and other essential commodities has made it hard for the company to be able to justify 50 research and development labs around the world. Each person working in the labs costs the company about $250,000 in salary, equipment, research time and other costs. And those costs are growing every year.

Dow Chemical Co. shut down a Texas plant that makes chlorine and caustic soda because of a malfunction and said customers will receive only 90% of their caustic-soda orders. The factory in Freeport was closed after a production problem in a critical area.

Dow Chemical Co. to announce possible layoffs at the chemical producer's Freeport complex in Texas. More than 4,000 contract workers are currently employed at the plant. The company said the layoffs will occur in stages from 15 December through 5 January.

Dow Chemical Co. announced that it will lay off 5,000 full-time workers and reduce contractor workforce by about 6,000 as part of its cost cutting measures. The diversified chemical firm would trim 5,000 jobs, or 11% of its workforce, and close down 20 facilities in high-cost locations and also divest many 'non-strategic' businesses. The job reductions represent a reduction of roughly 11% of Dows global workforce.

Dow Chemical Co. announced that it was axing an eighth of its Teesside workforce. The company, which employs 230 locally, will make 29 redundant at Middlesbrough and Billingham. The move is part of a major reorganisation by the firm in an effort to save EUR 1.3 billion over the next 12 months. It will involve the closure of 20 plants, the temporary idling of 180 and the loss of around 5,000 jobs globally.

The Dow Chemical Company announced that it will wind down its Dow Fiber Solutions business, halting production of its olefin-based stretchable XLA fiber in the next 6 months to 18 months. Dow said that it would continue to operate the facility to meet customers' current and final order requirements. The facility would then cease to operate and an alternative use within Dow would be explored.

Dow Chemical announced that it will take charges between $330 million and $380 million in second quarter for asset impairments, severance and other costs related to measures to streamline the company in advance of the separation of a significant portion of its chlorine products business. The streamlining will result in 1,500 to 1,750 jobs being cut, representing 3% of the global workforce. The measures are expected to be complete within two years and Dow expects the actions to result in $300 million of annual operating cost savings.

DuPont Co. is cutting about 10% of its workforce worldwide as it prepares for the merger with Dow Chemical Co. The cuts are part of a plan to cut expenses in an effort to drive up share prices for investors, many who criticized DuPont's financial performance recently. The company announced the layoffs as part of a cost savings and restructuring plan that aims to reduce costs by $700 million in 2016 compared with 2015 and it will begin implementation of these changes immediately.

DuPont Co. is cutting about 10% of its workforce worldwide as it prepares for the merger with Dow Chemical Co. The cuts are part of a plan to cut expenses in an effort to drive up share prices for investors, many who criticized DuPont's financial performance recently. The company announced the layoffs as part of a cost savings and restructuring plan that aims to reduce costs by $700 million in 2016 compared with 2015 and it will begin implementation of these changes immediately.

DuPont Co. is cutting about 10% of its workforce worldwide as it prepares for the merger with Dow Chemical Co. The cuts are part of a plan to cut expenses in an effort to drive up share prices for investors, many who criticized DuPont's financial performance recently. The company announced the layoffs as part of a cost savings and restructuring plan that aims to reduce costs by $700 million in 2016 compared with 2015 and it will begin implementation of these changes immediately.
Because of a drop in advertising revenue, Dow Jones & Co. cut 500 people from its staff.
Dow Jones & Co. has announced that it may cut an unspecified number of jobs, as the company seeks to counter lower ad sales by cutting costs.

Dow Jones & Co. Inc. announced that it would cut 97 jobs as the company completed the purchase of the online news service MarketWatch. About half of the jobs will be eliminated immediately, and the rest throughout the year. The eliminated positions came from across the full range of operations, including from human relations, finance, technology, marketing and news. About 12 of the jobs to be lost are from Dow Jones operations.

Dow Jones & Co. Inc. will cut at least 21 union jobs at its Newswires and Factiva units. The move comes as Dow Jones says it will restructure its Enterprise Media Group, following the company's recent Factiva acquisition. The company consolidated its business product lines into Dow Jones Indexes and Reprints, Dow Jones Financial Information Services and Dow Jones Content Technology Solutions. The new structure combines Dow Jones Newswires, Dow Jones Licensing Services and Factiva into Dow Jones Content Technology Solutions.

Ascena Retail Group Inc. announced that it will close the hundreds of Fashion Bug stores by early in 2013. The company also announced that it will expand its reach into the women's plus-size market with the addition of Charming Shoppes' Lane Bryant and Catherines Plus Sizes stores.

Ascena Retail Group Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended October 27, 2012. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $1,137.5 million compared to net sales of $768.3 million for the same period a year ago. Operating income was $72.9 million compared to $76.5 million last year. Income from continuing operations was $46.2 million or $0.29 per diluted share compared to $47.5 million $0.30 per diluted share last year. Net income was $43.1 million or $0.27 per diluted share compared to $47.5 million or $0.30 per diluted share last year. Income from continuing operations before income taxes was $68.4 million compared to $77.2 million last year. Adjusted basis income from continuing operations before income taxes was $94.7 million compared to $84.0 million last year. Adjusted basis net income was $62.8 million or $0.39 per diluted share compared to $51.7 million or $0.33 per diluted share last year. Adjusted basis operating income was $99.2 million compared to $83.3 million last year. The decrease in operating income as a percent of sales on an adjusted basis was due largely to the initial increase in SG&A associated with the Charming Acquisition. The increase in net sales were largely driven by the inclusion of sales from the newly acquired Lane Bryant and Catherines businesses, along with a 9% increase in sales from the companys legacy family of brands. CapEx for the quarter was approximately $16 million for new store additions, store remodels and technology projects.The company reaffirmed guidance for adjusted earnings per diluted share from continuing operations for the year ending July 27, 2013 in the range of $1.45 to $1.55, excluding one-time, acquisition-related integration, restructuring and purchase accounting costs that may be incurred related to the Charming Acquisition. This estimate is based upon various assumptions, including a mid-single digit increase in consolidated comparable store sales. The fiscal 2013 CapEx spend is planned at $325 million

Ascena Retrail Group announced between 250 and 650 retail stores including Ann Taylor, Dress Barn, Loft and Lane Bryant are closing. The locations are closing over the next two years and also include Justice, Maurices and Catherines. It's unclear how many of each specific brand are expected to close, though 250 locations will definitely close. Up to 400 others are also being considered for shuttering.

Ascena Retail Group filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the Eastern District of Virginia last week. The company has disclosed the locations of more than 1,100 stores within its portfolio that are set to close. The company has about 2,800 stores across its footprint and 43,000 employees, according to the bankruptcy filing, and said it was culling underperforming stores. SB360 Partners, a Schottenstein Stores affiliate, will be helping the company with its store closing process, with each location taking 30 to 60 days to wind down. Filings show about $12.5 billion in liabilities for Ascena. It's already announced the closure of all stores in Canada and Puerto Rico in order to focus on business strictly in the United States.
