The company said in bankruptcy filings that it would close all Catherines stores and sell the intellectual property of Catherines in a court-supervised auction, with City Chic Collective Ltd. as "stalking horse bidder." Meanwhile, Justice would bear the brunt of a "significant" number of store closures as Ascena converts the tween brand to a mostly online retailer. Justice has 826 stores and accounted for $1.08 billion of Ascena's $5.49 billion in sales in the 2019 fiscal year. Lane Bryant has 721 stores - it and Catherines account for $1.24 billion in sales in the plus-size segment. The two Columbus-based brands are the of Ascena's brands by store count. Justice will close 619 stores, while Lane Bryant is closing 156 stores. The court has granted Ascena approval to access more than $430 million in cash collateral, including to continue paying employee wages and benefits, honor commitments to vendors and continue day-to-day operations. Ascena had reached a restructuring support agreement with 68% of its secured term lenders to reduce its debt by $1 billion and the company is also seeking authorization to access $150 million in a new money term loan from existing lenders. Use the maps and chart below to get the full scope of Ascena's planned domestic closures. The top map is focused

Nearly 19 stores will close in Alabama as major retail chain Ascena Retail Group navigates its bankruptcy. The locations of more than 1,100 stores within its portfolio that are set to close, and it includes a number of stores in metro Birmingham and across the state. The closures will include all Catherines locations, including five in Alabama. That list includes a store at the Colonial Promenade Hoover, as well as stores in Mobile, Tuscaloosa, Huntsville and Montgomery. Additionally, the Lane Bryant Outlet location at Outlet Shops of Grand River will close.
DuPont announced that it will reduce its global workforce by 4,000 employees, representing 4% of its workers. It will also shut down its less competitive assets.

DuPont has announced that it plans to layoff six percent of its workforce and exit its polyester and nylon businesses as a part of its plan to cut costs in order to cope with the increased competition from Asian manufacturers.

du Pont de Nemours & Company. DuPont Textiles and Interiors will cut 2,000 jobs and take a second-quarter charge as part of a restructuring effort expected to save $120 million a year, DuPont announced. More than two-thirds of the job cuts, which amount to about 10 percent of the company's work force, will be in the United States, with most of the balance in Europe.

In the United States, DuPont plans to shut down a manufacturing unit in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and parts of its spandex operation in Waynesboro, Va.

The DuPont Company instituted a restructuring program in its Textiles & Interiors unit to better align the business with accelerating structural changes to become a more competitive integrated enterprise and to respond to continuing weakening economic conditions, particularly in the U.S. textile business. Under the program, the company will terminate about 2,000 positions in technical, manufacturing, marketing and administrative activities and shut down operating facilities in an effort to transfer production to more cost effective facilities.

DuPont Co. and Dow Chemical Co. have decided to close their joint operation in the Rubbertown industrial complex in three years because of a decline in the segment of business, laying off 285 employees.
DuPont Co. plans to consolidate some of its coatings- and color-technologies assets, resulting in the elimination of about 650 jobs.
DuPont Co. announced that it would lay off 3,000 workers, eliminate 950 other jobs and shut a spandex plant in Canada as part of a plan to trim annual costs by $900 million.

Unifi announced the job cuts at DuPont textile plant in Lenoir County. 490 jobs will be cut at the facility next year to reduce the number of employees to 250. The move comes after Unifi cut wages at the plant by 20% in September.

DuPont Co. is cutting 1,500 jobs as it restructures its agriculture and nutrition division, putting the $100 million it expects to save into its seeds business, where it is in an increasingly tough battle with rival Monsanto. The changes announced by DuPont are expected to affect about 10 of the agriculture division's 250 sites worldwide, but DuPont spokesman Doyle Karr reported that the company was not disclosing which sites would be affected.
EI DuPont de Nemours & Co. will cut 1,500 jobs and consolidate manufacturing in its seeds unit in a move to lower operating costs by $100 million a year.

EI DuPont de Nemours & Co. announced that it will cut about 130 jobs at its plant in Circleville by the end of August. The move will leave fewer than 400 workers at the site. The company announced that this is part of a corporate restructuring in order to deal with the current economic situation and position ourselves for when the recovery occurs.
DuPont reported that third-quarter revenue from continuing operations fell 9% and that it would eliminate 2% of its employees, or 1,500 workers, to trim $450 million in costs.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company will cut jobs at its Yerkes plant in the Town of Tonawanda, as part of broader employment reductions. The company cited "continued low production volumes in the site's solid surfaces and polyvinyl fluoride films business units" as the reason for the cuts at the Tonawanda site, which is at Sheridan Drive and River Road. The cuts are expected to take effect at the end of the year and will be in jobs across the plant, in both union and nonunion positions.

E. I. du Pont de Nemours and Company plans to cut 64 jobs in the Richmond area as part of a larger corporate restructuring announced in October. The affected jobs are salaried positions. DuPont notified state officials through a WARN act notice, which said the cuts would by occur by December 31, 2012.

Trade union CNV Vakmensen expects the loss of 100 jobs at the Dordrecht chemicals plant of US industrial conglomerate DuPont in western Netherlands due to restructuring, union official Arjan Huizinga was cited as saying by news agency.

Duke Energy Corp. will cut at least 1,500 jobs, including up to 400 in the Charlotte area, as the company battles a weak economy and plunging returns from its wholesale energy divisions. The tough market dragged Duke's profit last quarter to $230 million, or 27 cents per share, down from last year's $796 million, or $1.02 per share. The bulk, 60 percent, will be in the energy services division, About 20 percent of Duke's cuts will be within Duke Power Co., the regulated Carolinas utility.

Duke Energy Corporation. will cut about 275 jobs in its North American merchant power and trading division, after consolidating its Salt Lake City and Calgary trading operations into its Houston base. The layoffs, virtually all in the three cities, are in addition to the 1,500 job cuts Duke announced earlier this year. About 50 of the layoffs will be within the trading organization, which has already endured about 75 job cuts this year. It will have about 250 employees after this round. The other 225 cuts will be in finance and other support divisions in Calgary, Houston and Salt Lake City.Duke Energy North America will employ just over 1,000 after the cuts.
Duke Energy Corp. unveiled a plan to reduce annual expenses by more than $200 million beginning in 2004. The plan calls for a reduction of 8 percent of its global work force - or about 2,000 jobs.

Duke Energy expects to close much of a coal-powered generating plant in western Indiana within the next few years. The company is watching new federal environmental regulations that are due for release in November and considering shutting down several of the six units at Wabash River Station near Terre Haute as soon as 2014.

Dun & Bradstreet Corp. announced that will cut 85 information technology positions in its Bethlehem and Parsippany, N.J., offices. The company will outsource some of the jobs to other companies. Other functions will be consolidated into fewer positions. The layoffs are part of a companywide effort to eliminate 400 positions.
Dun & Bradstreet Corp. announced that it plans to consolidate jobs in its customer service and technology teams, a move that would eliminate 125 to 150 jobs worldwide this year.
A Santa Fe company, Flowserve Corp., that makes industrial pumps, valves and seals plans to close Oct. 31, costing 48 jobs.

Acterna Corp. announces plans to slash 400 positions, or 8 percent of its global work force, through job consolidation, attrition and early retirement. During the last round of job cuts, in November, Acterna said at least 20 people would lose jobs at its Bradenton division. The cuts were among 500 the company made as part of a cost-cutting plan designed to save at least $115 million a year. That round represented about 9 percent of its global work force.

Acterna Corp. plans to cut about 400 jobs, or about 8 percent of its staff, while consolidating some of its locations. The Germantown, Md., high-tech company, formerly Dynatech Corp., expects to record restructuring charges of about $17 million for the job cuts, while realizing savings of about $75 million. The company now has reduced its headcount to about 4,100, or 36 percent of its staff, since the beginning of its fiscal 2002. As of March 31, Acterna had about 5,000 employees.
Eastman Kodak Co. has announced that it is cutting 7,000 jobs and closing plants due to declining sales.

Eastman Kodak Co. is closing its single-use camera plant here, affecting about 400 jobs, according to a Monroe County official. Kodak notified county officials it will shut down production at its Lee Road facility but didn't provide a timeline of when a shutdown would occur, Monroe County Executive Jack Doyle told the Rochester Democrat and Chronicle in editions. In October, Kodak announced it would cut between 1,300 and 1,700 jobs or up to 2.3 percent of its global payroll, as it struggles to rebound from a two-year slump in film sales it blamed largely on a downturn in the U.S. economy.

The economic woes at Kodak could end up costing 60 Colorado employees their jobs as the company shifts part of its health imaging production to Mexico. The employees will probably have the option to be reassigned to other positions in Windsor, Kodak spokeswoman Lucille Mantelli said If not, then they'll receive a termination package, she said. Eastman Kodak Company, based in Rochester, N.Y., announced in July it would cut between 4,500 and 6,000 employees worldwide as it fights for a piece of the digital imaging market. Kodak Colorado employees have been waiting to hear how the cuts might affect their plant.

Eastman Kodak Co. announced that it will cut 12,000 to 15,000 jobs, or up to 23 percent of its global work force, over the next three years. and announced that It will trim an estimated 2,500 to 3,500 jobs this year. Kodak eliminated up to 6,000 jobs in 2003, shrinking its payroll to 64,000 from a peak of 136,500 in 1983.

Eastman Kodak Co. announced that it will cut nearly 900 jobs at three of its manufacturing facilities in Europe as part of the company's shift from traditional film production to digital photography. The layoffs at the three plants are part of the 12,000 to 15,000 job cuts the Rochester-based photography giant announced earlier this year as part of its strategy to accelerate the transition from film-related products to digital imaging. Kodak announced that it will eliminate 250 jobs at its site in Harrow, England and will shut down its film production plant at Annesley, England, eliminating another 350 jobs. The Harrow facility will become the headquarters for operations in Britain, with about 300 jobs being transferred to the site from Kodak's other operations in the United Kingdom.

Kodak factory is to close Annesley plant next year in another jobs bombshell for the area that will leave around 350 people out of work. Employees discovered that around 100 jobs would go at the start of next year and the whole site will close for good at the end of September 2005. All employees will be treated with respect with Kodak ensuring they receive highly competitive severance terms, access to counselling support as well as access to an outplacement programmed to assist in identifying alternative employment.

Eastman Kodak Co. announced that it would cut 500 jobs in Britain because of declining demand for conventional film processing. Five overnight photo-finishing labs and a head office and call center in Britain will be closed by October 2005. Kodak announced a three-year plan in January to cut 12,000 to 15,000 jobs to cope with falling demand for conventional film.
Eastman Kodak Co. said it would close a photographic paper plant in Rochester, leading to about $50 million in charges and an unspecified number of job cuts.
Eastman Kodak Co. is eliminating 12,000 to 15,000 jobs by 2007, which will trim its work force to around 50,000. It has axed more than 11,000 employees already, including 1,650 this year.

Federal regulators have launched an informal inquiry into an Eastman Kodak Co. financial restatement that trimmed the photography company's profits by $105 million to fix accounting errors mainly in taxes and pensions over the last two years. Kodak, which is undergoing a dramatic overhaul as the digital-imaging revolution sidelines chemical-based film, said the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated the inquiry should not be construed as a sign that any legal violations have occurred.

The company is shutting film and other manufacturing operations around the world and eliminating 22,000 to 25,000 jobs by mid 2007. That will likely lower its global work force to less than 50,000, down from 75,100 in 2001 and a peak of 145,300 in 1988.

Eastman Kodak plans to reduce output and staff at its Xiamen plant, the firm's largest production base in Asia. According to a company official, the move is part of Kodak's plan to accelerate the transition from its traditional film based industry to the fast growing digital sector. The company plans to compete profitably in digital markets by the middle of 2007. The Xiamen plant will produce lower volumes of consumer film, paper, and single use cameras as production is consolidated nearer to major markets in the Americas and Europe. But Xiamen will continue to serve customers in the Asia-Pacific region and Japan for these traditional products, consistent with the market demand, said Ying Yeh, vice-president of Kodak Global and chairwoman of Kodak Greater China Region.

Eastman Kodak Co. will close its Middleway, WV, printing plate manufacturing plant by the end of the first quarter of 2006. The decision to close this facility is a result of the product rationalization activities that Kodak is undertaking as a result of the company's recent acquisitions in the graphic communications market. Kodak will discontinue the primary products manufactured at the plant, Mirus and Fortis thermal plates, Eternus conventional plates, and all associated chemistry. These products will not be available after production and inventory are depleted.

Kodak announced that the Harlow, Essex-based unit, which has 49 full-time and 68 part-time staff, was no longer part of its long-term strategy of digital imaging and would close at the end of 2006. But the decision leaves around 400 customers who had booked services for 2007 in limbo, although Kodak has pledged to help them find alternative photography services. Letters have been sent to couples whose plans have been disrupted by the closure and Kodak Weddings has promised to make direct contact to discuss their options.
Eastman Kodak Co. expects job cuts and will now be within the range of 25,000 to 27,000 positions.

Eastman Kodak Co. has completed the shutdown of its motion picture film finishing division in Northern Colorado. The division ceased operations on September 21, 2009. At least three other divisions are still operating at the plant in Windsor, about 50 miles north of Denver.

Eastman Kodak Co. has notified the state Labor Department that it plans to lay off more than 50 workers at its plant in Eastman Business Park in November. The move is the latest layoff planned by Kodak as it works to eliminate as many as 4,500 jobs worldwide this year. According to filings with the state, the other planned reductions-affecting a total of 23 jobs-are: eight workers at Eastman Business Park, 1669 Lake Ave., to occur from Oct. 29 to Nov. 8; two workers, including one telecommuter, at Kodak headquarters on State Street, Oct. 19 to Oct. 28; and 13 employees at Kodak headquarters, with two layoffs from Sept. 21 to Sept. 30 and 11 layoffs from Oct. 1 to Oct. 11.

Eastman Kodak Co. announced that it will be closing another Qualex office in Durham and outsourcing its work to another location. The move will result in the layoff of 48 employees in the Bull City. The company will close the Durham facility by June 11, 2011. The layoffs will affect 44 field engineer positions and four customer service supervisor positions.

Eastman Kodak Co. has laid off roughly 40 Rochester workers, most of them employed in film manufacturing. The layoffs in recent days mark perhaps the first sizable job cuts at the Rochester-based printing company post bankruptcy. Kodak exited its 20-month Chapter 11 bankruptcy in September. And that bankruptcy saw the company make numerous deep cuts in its workforce, as well as sell off a number of businesses, as it worked to get costs under control and to streamline itself. That number is now far smaller, as 2013 saw Kodak continue to cut costs and also sell its Personalized Imaging and Document Imaging businesses, which employed roughly 700 locally. Kodak said it would have updated local employment numbers after the end of the year.

Eaton Corporation, will consolidate five plants and cut an unspecified number of jobs after having completed the purchase of Deltas electrical unit. About 1,700 of Eatons 51,000 employees work at those five factories, which are in Britain, Australia and the Netherlands, Eaton said.

Eaton Corp. announced that it will close its local assembly plant next year at a cost of 39 jobs. Plant manager Andrew Lang said that there will be no layoffs before April 1 and the company will help employees find work. Pueblo employees also will be able to apply for jobs at other Eaton plants.

Eaton Corp. announced that Salford Factory is to close with the loss of almost 300 jobs, with some of its work moving to Poland. Staff at Eaton Transmissions in Walkden have been told production will end by Christmas. It is hoped some engineering and sales and marketing jobs will be relocated to a new site in the north west, but 30 production jobs will switch to the Eaton plant in Tczew, Poland. The decision to shift production to Poland comes just months after a government report revealed almost 265,000 Poles had been approved to work in Britain over the past two years. Of those, about 35,000 have moved to the north west.

Eaton Corp. will close a circuit breaker assembly plant in Puerto Rico and shift the work to another factory in the U.S. island territory and to the Dominican Republic. The production will be shifted to Eaton plants in Arecibo, Puerto Rico, and in Haina, Dominican Republic. The company's electrical division operates five assembly plants in Puerto Rico, including the one slated to close in Cabo Rojo, and one in the Dominican Republic.

Eaton Corp. announced that some workers at its Kearney and Hastings plants that they will be laid off. The company announced that 49 of 630 workers in Kearney and 64 of 88 in Hastings will temporarily lose their jobs as early as March 24, 2008. Their benefits will continue. The layoffs are blamed on a strike that began February 26 against Americal Axle & Manufacturing Holdings, which is a major supplier to General Motors. The strike has affected 29 GM plants and rippled over to GM suppliers such as Eaton.

Ecolab Inc. plans to cut 350 to 450 jobs, or about 2 percent of its work force, over the next year as it moves to reduce costs and streamline operations. The company, which makes cleaning, sanitizing and maintenance products, also said Thursday its earnings for 2001 were slightly below Wall Street expectations. It said the job cuts will affect employees of all levels and be accomplished through attrition, voluntary severance and layoffs.

Electro Scientific Industries Inc. announced a corporate restructuring that will streamline its manufacturing and development operations. The restructuring will result in the closure of the assembly plant and development center located in Chelmsford, Massachusetts, and overall staff reductions of approximately 45 employees. Products currently developed and manufactured in the Chelmsford plant will be transferred to other corporate facilities.

Electro Scientific Industries, Inc. announced a corporate reorganization that is designed to better position the company for the future. The objective is to simplify the structure, improve execution, and increase consistency of earnings. The company announced that it is reorganizing its management team from a business unit to a functional structure, relocating sales, service and operations leadership positions to Asia, closing its facilities in Montreal, Canada, and Napa, California, downsizing its Sunnyvale, California facility, and making other select reductions across the company. The actions are expected to be largely completed by the end of June 2017. The financial impact of the actions is expected to reduce the company's cost structure by $10 to $12 million on an annualized basis and lower its non-GAAP EBITDA breakeven point to approximately $35 million of quarterly revenue once the actions are fully implemented. The company expects pre-tax charges of $6.5 to $8.5 million, of which approximately $5 million is expected to be recorded in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2017.

Emerson announced that it plans to close 30 facilities by the end of September as part of a plan to move operations to low-cost countries, such as China, Mexico and the Philippines. The closures will occur in the company's network power business, where it

Emerson Electric Co., which last year announced plans to close 20 plants worldwide, has increased that total to 50 as it implements a plan to move more of its operations to countries with low labor costs. Emerson hopes to close the plants and move their operations to countries such as China, Mexico and the Philippines by Sept. 30. There was no word from the company on how many employees could be laid off. Emerson said it was cutting 4,000 jobs when it announced its initial plans in October to close 20 of its 350 plants.

Weatherford International Ltd. announced that it will cut 7,000 jobs in order to make its cost base more efficient. In order to make its cost base more efficient, the company has decided to reduce its workforce by 7,000 employees, primarily from its fixed support cost base. The company noted that the reduction will not affect its non-core businesses that have been earmarked for divestiture in 2014. The company expects the workforce reduction to be completed during the first half of 2014, resulting in annualized savings of $500 million, with roughly half of this amount impacting 2014 earnings. The company noted that actions will not affect or compromise in any way its accounting and tax processes.
Weatherford International announced plans to cut up to 8,000 jobs.

Equifax Inc. has laid off 190 workers as part of a reorganization effort. About 90 positions within the U.S. and 100 in the company's Latin America and United Kingdom operations are being culled primarily from its consumer information services business, as well as support functions for these operations. The layoffs have already been announced, and actual release dates are spread between early September and early October. Roughly 20 positions are being dropped from the company's three Atlanta locations, with the other 70 domestic cuts scattered across the U.S. Eliminated positions are primarily at the manager or director levels, along with associated support staff.
Ethyl Corporation announced a decline in profits compared to last year period. It also announced a plan to reduce its workforce, but did not disclose further details.

Insteel Industries Inc. has laid off 15 workers at its Sanderson, Fla., prestressed concrete (PC) strand plant. Due to several factors, 50 jobs have been eliminated at Insteel's wire operations over the past two to three months.
Exxon Mobil Corp. plan to close Monterey Coal Company in Carlinville after 35 years, a move that could affect the jobs of at least 365 workers.

Orthoxylene supply from Exxon Mobil Corp. and Petroleos de Venezuela, S.A.'s joint venture Chalmette chemical plant in Louisiana will stop by the end of the year as the company plans to shut down a paraxylene (PX) and an isomerisation unit. The company who buys OX from ExxonMobil, said the plans have been in the works for some time as the result of poor OX demand stemming from a sharp drop in phthalic anhydride production.
Exxon Mobil Corporation announced that it plans to cut 15% of its global workforce by the end of 2021, about 11,250 jobs.
FMC Corp. announced that it plans to layoff 18 employees at its trona mine in Sweetwater County by March 1, 2002 as a result of the economic downturn.
Jo-Ann Stores has announced that it has cut jobs by 8 percent over time as part of a transition plan.
FedEx Corp. announced plans to trim up to 14,000 jobs from its domestic express service by offering voluntary severance packages and early retirement in an attempt to cut long-term costs.

FedEx Corp. announced that it will close its Asian hub in the Philippines. The Subic Bay, Philippines, facility, located at a former U.S. naval base, will close by the end of 2008, by which time the Guangzhou operation will be in service.
Federal-Mogul Corp. has announced that it plans to close its plants in Orangeburg and Summerton as it is consolidating its operations to Mexico due to lower demand.

Federal-Mogul Corp. said that it is developing a three-year restructuring plan that may cut around 4,500 jobs, or 10% of its work force. The Southfield-based company, which makes headlights, windshield wipers and other products, said the restructuring plan isn't yet finalized, but could affect around 25 facilities. The company has 45,000 employees and 130 manufacturing sites worldwide. Federal-Mogul said its plan would cost between $125 million and $150 million because of severance payments and other factors.

Federal-Mogul Corp. announced it has laid off 103 workers at its Manitowoc plant that makes piston rings for heavy-duty diesel engines. The company previously announced it would cut shifts at the plant from three to two.
Federal-Mogul Corp. announced plans to cut jobs and production as it posts third-quarter loss, compared year earlier.

About 200 Orangeburg-area workers will lose their jobs over the next two years as Federal-Mogul closes its brake-pad facility there, shuttering the last of its S.C. operations. Plant officials began notifying employees on July 15, 2013, the plant ?which works around the clock with three shifts ?will be closed and its work moved to larger facilities in Smithville, Tenn., and Tepotzotlan, Mexico. The Michigan-based company will begin moving work to the larger facilities within the next couple of months. Layoffs will be staggered, based on customers?yet-to-be-determined schedules. About 160 full-time Federal-Mogul employees will lose their jobs over the next two years, as well as about 40 contractors and temporary workers.

Fannie Mae has eliminated 20 public affairs positions in its regional offices and created seven new ones elsewhere in an attempt to place an emphasis on the shift from lobbying operations to business communications. The posts that were eliminated had operated on a regional basis in five offices, supporting Fannie Mae's grassroots political operations across the country to advance the company's legislative agenda. The laid-off employees will be eligible to reapply for the new positions.
Federal Signal Corp. plans to cut 300 jobs, or 5 percent of its workforce, due to lower profits.
Macy's Inc. announced the closure of its catalog operation as part of the restructuring efforts announced by its parent company, Federated Department.

Federated Department Stores Inc. will curtail hiring and end plans to remodel or expand existing stores, the company's chairman, James M. Zimmerman said. The measures include plans to cut up to 60 union jobs at a distribution center. The company is also reviewing operations at all of its New Jersey locations.

Federated Department Stores Inc. will close its Macys in South Brunswick this March because of weak sales. Seventy five employees and 10 executives will lose their jobs when the store on Route 1 south near New Road closes on or around March 9.

Federated Department Stores Inc. plans to close five underperforming Rich's-Macy's and Lazarus-Macy's stores in Alabama, Georgia, Ohio and Pennsylvania by May nearly 369 employees will lose their jobs. The stores to be closed are Rich's-Macy's in Century Plaza, Birmingham, Ala. Rich's-Macy's, Cobb Center, in Smyrna, Ga. Lazarus-Macy's stores in Westerville and Oxford, Ohio, and Lazarus-Macy's in downtown Pittsburgh. The company also reiterated its plans to close the Lazarus-Macy's store in Heath, Ohio, in April.

The company said the one-time costs aren't expected to affect its fourth-quarter earnings view of $2.15 to $2.20 a share. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call forecast, on average, earnings of $2.19 a share for the fourth quarter and $3.41 a share for the year.
Federated Department Stores Inc. announced that it will close as many as 65 stores to help ensure that regulators clear its purchase May Department Stores Co. of St. Louis.
Federated Department Stores Inc., the new owner of Hecht's department stores, announced it would close the chain's Arlington headquarters early next year, eliminating 1,033 jobs as soon as March.

Federated Department Stores Inc. announced that it is selling chains it acquired as part of its $11 billion purchase of May Department Stores Co. and converting more than 400 May stores to the Macy's nameplate by September. 11 of May's nameplates, including Marshall Field's and Filene's, will disappear.Federated will shed 80 stores. It also has it will cut 6,200 jobs. The company had sales of $21.5 billion in the first 11 months of its fiscal year, which ends this month.

Federated Department Stores Inc. announced that it will close five distribution centers, affecting up to 750 jobs, as it strives to cut costs and realign its Macy's division following the acquisition of May Department Stores Co. last year. It also plans to close centers in Aurora, Colo.; Portland, Ore.; and Salt Lake City, Utah, in August. The company reported that it will try to find opportunities for affected workers at other facilities, and offer severance to workers who are laid off. The retailer reported that it has already included the expenses for closing the centers in an earlier estimate of $1 billion in one-time costs, spread over three years starting last year.

Federated Department Stores Inc. expects to cut 318 jobs when it closes a Kaufmann's outlet at a suburban Pittsburgh mall. Federated that it would trim 185 jobs with the closing of a Macy's at the Ross Park Mall and 368 with the closing of a Kaufmann's at South Hills Village.

Federated Department Stores Inc. plans to eliminate 595 jobs at Hecht's headquarters in Arlington during the first two weeks of May 2006. The positions range from entry-level staff members to executive management, including five senior vice presidents, 74 assistant buyers, five construction supervisors and one model. Clerical staff members face the largest reduction, with 259 jobs cut. Other job cuts include managers and merchandise coordinators. Federated also notified workers at three other chains that their jobs would be ending -- 582 at Filene's in Boston, 367 at Robinsons-May in Los Angeles, and 265 at Foley's in Houston., said Jim Sluzewski, a company spokesman.

Federated Department Stores Inc. announced that it will close five underperforming stores at its Lord & Taylor chain and convert one to a Macy's. The closings are expected to begin in late July or early August and include two stores in St. Louis, one in Newark, Del., one in Dearborn, Mich., and a store in Peabody, Mass. The 49 remaining Lord & Taylor stores will continue to operate, according to the company, as it continues to try and sell off its Lord & Taylor division as part of a previously announced divestiture plan.

Federated Department Stores Inc. announced that it plans to eliminate as many as 200 jobs in Chicago. Up to 174 of those positions will be eliminated in February as the retailer consolidates its distribution network. As a result plans to cut about 85 delivery and driver positions and 89 merchandise processing and furniture customer service positions in Chicago. It also plans to cut 9 interior designers at its Macy's furniture store in Schaumburg and eliminate 16 employee scheduling jobs at area stores between January and March. The company also plans to close three distribution centers in Kansas City, Kan.; Warren, Mich.; and Minneapolis early next year, eliminating 296 jobs. An additional 75 job cuts are slated for distribution centers in the St. Louis area.

Macy's Inc. announced that its plans to close the former Marshall Field's store in downtown Lake Forest at the end of January, citing rising costs and shifting shopping patterns. The small department store, Field's first suburban branch, has been a fixture in the wealthy suburban enclave since 1928, when Marshall Field III, the grandson of the retailer's namesake founder, decided he wanted his neighbors to be able to shop at the family store without having to go to Chicago. The store employs 24 workers. They are eligible to apply for open positions at other Macy's stores.
Macy's Inc. plan to eliminate 165 jobs within the next six months. The company is making the cuts after another 650 people were laid off in the Macy's North division, which has 64 stores.

Macy's Inc. announced that ninety-five people will lose their jobs as it closes its location at the Bellevue Center-19 more than had been expected. The 95 layoffs will begin March 13 and be complete by March 26.

Macy's, Inc. announced a series of Macy's and Bloomingdale's store openings and closings. The company said it will close certain stores in early spring 2012, including: A 234,000-square-foot Bloomingdale's store at General Growth Properties Inc.'s Perimeter Mall in Atlanta. Separately, General Growth on Jan. 5 said the Bloomingdale's space would be taken over by a Von Maur department store, which is projected to open in the fall. A 93,000-square-foot Bloomingdale's Home and Furniture Store at General Growth Properties' partially owned Oakbrook Center in Oak Brook, Ill. The company also plans to open new stores at various locations, including a 200,000-square-foot Macy's replacement store to be built at Westfield Group's South Shore mall in Bay Shore, N.Y. The store is expected to open in the fall of 2013. Also, two new Bloomingdale's stores are expected to open at Simon's Merrimack Premium Outlets in Merrimack, N.H., and Equity One Inc.'s Gallery at Westbury Plaza in Westbury, N.Y., during 2012. In addition, the company is planning to open a new 120,000-square-foot Bloomingdale's store at Simon's Stanford Shopping Center in Palo Alto, Calif., in spring 2014, subject to completion of a public approval process. The store will replace an existing 229,000-square-foot Bloomingdale's in the same shopping center, and the current store will remain in operation until the new store is constructed and opened. The current store will be razed and replaced by a new specialty retail development.

Macy's, Inc. announced March 16, 2013 is the last day of business for the department store at 411 Cedar St. in downtown St. Paul. The St. Paul store will close at 6 p.m. on March 16, 2013. The store opened as a Dayton's department store in 1963. While city leaders have touted the redevelopment potential of the site, plans aren't yet clear.

Macy's, Inc. announced that it will implement focused cost reductions, including organizational changes, as it prepares to sustain profitable sales growth in the years ahead. Changes being announced are estimated to generate savings of approximately $100 million per year, beginning in 2014. These savings are incorporated in the company's 2014 earnings guidance. Realigning, combining and reducing some positions in Macy's stores in a manner that improves productivity and efficiency while also fostering high standards for customer engagement and service. Trimming certain central office, administrative and back-of-the-house expenses across the company. This involves reductions in workforce, as well as in non-payroll costs. Approximately 2,500 employees are expected to be laid off and are eligible for severance as a result of these organizational changes. Other associates are being reassigned with new duties or transferred; some open positions will not be filled. Meanwhile, the company continues to add positions in other parts of the company -- such as in online operations, direct-to-consumer fulfillment and new stores. In total, the Macy's, Inc. workforce is expected to remain at a level of approximately 175,000 associates. The company is announcing that it will close the five Macy's stores in early spring 2014. Final clearance sales will begin on Jan. 13, 2014 and run for between 10 and 11 weeks. The stores were, Fiesta Mall, Mesa, AZ (159,000 square feet; opened in 1979; 98 associates); Metcalf South Shopping Center, Overland Park, KS (216,000 square feet; opened in 1967; 88 associates); Jamestown Mall, Florissant, MO (200,000 square feet; opened in 1994; 88 associates); Medley Centre, Irondequoit, NY (129,000 square feet; opened in 1990; 96 associates); Fashion Place Mall, Murray, UT (26,000 square feet; opened in 1988; 42 associates). The company is committed to treating associates affected by store closings with respect and openness. Associates displaced by store closings may be offered positions in nearby st

Macy's plans to restructure its merchandising and marketing and lay off of thousands of workers in response to changes in the way customers shop in stores and online. The company said that it will also close 14 department stores but open two new locations, resulting in annual savings of roughly $140 million. The company said that it plans to reinvest those savings into its business.

Macy's, Inc. is closing 14 retail stores as the company invests more in technology. The 14 stores are expected to close by early spring and do not include the retailers two Milwaukee-area locations. The stores to be closed account for $130 million in annual sales. The company expects some of that to be retained by nearby stores and online sales. The company said employees displaced by store closings will be offered positions in nearby stores where possible or be given severance benefits. The company also announced that it is laying off an average of two to three employees per store as it refocuses its staffing. The cut amounts to between 1,660 and 2,500 total workers. The 14 stores that are closing are: Metro Center, Phoenix; Cupertino Square Mall, Cupertino, Calif.; Promenade (main store), Woodland Hills, Calif.; Promenade (furniture gallery), Woodland Hills, Calif.; Gulf View Square, Port Richey, Fla.; Northland Center, Southfield, Mich.; Wendover, Greensboro, N.C.; Ledgewood Mall, Ledgewood, N.J.; ShoppingTown Mall, DeWitt, N.Y.; Rotterdam Square, Schenectady, N.Y.; Kingsdale Shopping Center, Columbus, Ohio; Richmond Town Square, Richmond Heights, Ohio; Upper Valley Mall, Springfield, Ohio and Southland Mall, Memphis.The company announced two new stores: a Bloomingdale's in San Jose, Calif., and a Macy's in Los Angeles, which will replace an existing one in Westfield Century City.

Macy's Inc. has announced plans to restructure its merchandising and marketing operations. With changes being announced, Macy's, Inc. will be increasing its workforce in some functions and locations while decreasing in others so all of the company's resources can be deployed for maximum results. In total, the Macy's, Inc. workforce is expected to remain at a level of approximately 175,000 associates. Both Macy's and Bloomingdale's are restructuring their respective central merchandising and marketing functions so each brand can develop and present its assortments seamlessly across channels and provide a single omnichannel view in all product categories. Simultaneously, Macy's will make selected changes to its merchandising-related functions in local districts (administrative grouping of Macy's stores) around the country as it continues to improve its ability to localize assortments by size, color, fabric weight, style, fit, category and brand. The company will discontinue district planner positions and reinvest in new regional teams devoted to specific themes of merchandise localization. These changes in merchandising and marketing are expected to affect approximately 115 associates in Macy's and Bloomingdale's central offices in New York City, as well as about 150 associates in local markets nationwide. Selling service and support is being modified to match business opportunity in each department. An average of two to three associates will be affected in each of Macy's and Bloomingdale's approximately 830 stores (out of an average workforce of approximately 150 associates in each store), for a total of about 2,200 affected associates nationwide. The company is working to place as many affected associates as possible in other open positions. Also, two existing Macy's stores districts are being merged into nearby districts thus reducing the ongoing number of stores districts to 58 from the current 60. In 2015, Macy's is expected to grow its San Francisco-based digital technology organization by hiring more than

Macy's Inc. will close its store at Country Club Plaza. The store opened in 1961 and covers 165,000 square feet. Located at Watt and El Camino avenues, it employs 111 people. Final clearance sales will begin on January 11, 2016 and last eight to twelve weeks.

Macy's, Inc. announced the closing of six Virginia stores. Three are in the Richmond area and another three are in Hampton Roads. The stores are among 40 stores that the company is closing nationwide as it tries to reduce expenses by $500 million. The stores in Virginia that are scheduled to close employ nearly 500 workers. The Virginia stores are: Chesapeake Square in Chesapeake (a 95,000-square-foot store that opened in 1999; it has 69 employees); Virginia Center Commons in Glen Allen (110,000 square feet; opened in 1993; 81 employees); Peninsula Town Center in Hampton (173,000 square feet; opened in 1977; 109 employees); Military Circle Mall in Norfolk, VA (153,000 square feet; opened in 1976; 95 employees); Regency Square main store in western Henrico County (100,000 square feet; opened in 1990; 100 employees); Regency Square furniture/home/men's store (124,000 square feet; opened in 1990; 35 employees).

Macy's to close Century III location. The company had a rough holiday shopping season and that means making changes in the new year - trimming thousands of jobs, restructuring administrative systems and taking a tough look at which of its hundreds of department stores aren't cutting it anymore. That's bad news for Century III Mall in West Mifflin, which has hung onto the 173,000-square-foot department store anchor despite years of watching other tenants move on. The company announced the Century III store open since 1979 - not always under the Macy's name - is one of 40 stores out of its 770 locations to be shuttered by sometime this spring. Final clearance sales at most of the stores slated for closure, including the Century III location, will begin on January 11 and run for between eight and 12 weeks. But the department store operator's changes won't just affect the 101 associates working at the West Mifflin site, some of whom may be able to move to the chain's other area locations at malls like South Hills Village and Monroeville Mall. The retailer also plans to trim about 3,000 jobs nationally from its Macy's and Bloomingdale's stores, a move that it said will affect an average of 3 to 4 positions in each of the stores staying open. In addition, about 165 senior executives will be offered buyouts and 600 back-office positions will be trimmed, with 150 of those workers to be reassigned.
Macy's Inc. plans to close 100 stores early 2017 as part of its cost-cutting effort.

Macy's, Inc. announced that it will close eight stores in Texas, including locations at Southwest Center Mall in Dallas and Collin Creek Mall in Plano. It will continue to operate 13 stores in North Texas. The only Macy's store in Tyler will close, and the Houston market was hit hard by the announcement. Macy's announced in August that it would close 100 stores in 2016 and 2017, and the 68 closings announced are part of that nationwide plan to streamline its business. The stores will close sometime in the spring.

Macy's announced that, it plans to close 65 stores nationwide, including three in the Houston area, as part of a plan to slash costs as sales continue to slide. The closures, part of approximately 100 announced last August, include locations at Greenspoint Mall, West Oaks Mall and Pasadena Town Square. Most will shut down this spring. Company is closing locations that are unproductive or are no longer robust shopping destinations due to changes in the local retail shopping landscape. The announcement came with news of a major restructuring plan expected to reduce the company's annual expenses by about $550 million a year after initial losses associated with the changes. Macy's expects to cut about 3,900 employees as a result of the closures and an additional 6,200 from its corporate operations. The latest round of closures reflects the company's ongoing effort to cut costs as consumer preferences change and e-commerce sales rise.

Macy's Inc. notified the state Jan. 6, 2017 that it would lay off 100 employees for its Oviedo Marketplace Store at 1400 Oviedo Marketplace Blvd. The layoffs will take effect starting March 6-19, 2017. The company, which has six stores in Central Florida, announced Jan. 4, 2017 that it was closing 68 stores, including five in Florida. The one in Oviedo Marketplace is the only one in Central Florida slated for closure. The company also has layoffs planned for a store in Sarasota, laying off 92 workers there, and another in Tampa, laying off 80 workers there. Both of those locations will close, as well.
Macy's moved forward with plans to close 68 stores and said it will cut more than 10,000 jobs.

Macy's, Inc. announced the closure of 11 stores, 4 of which were previously disclosed. With these closures, the company will have completed 81 of the approximately 100 planned store closures announced in August 2016. The company intends to close approximately 19 additional stores as leases or operating covenants expire or sale transactions are completed. These closures are part of a multi-year effort by the company to ensure the optimal mix of brick & mortar stores and digital footprint.
Macy's will cut 100 management-level jobs at it looks to trim $100 million in costs after a lackluster holiday shopping season.

Macy's Inc. is closing at least 11 new locations. Nine of those stores, however, had already closed in 2019. A corrected version follows: Cincinnati-based retail giant Macy's Inc. is closing at least two of its stores, including one in the company's hometown. Macy's confirmed to the Business Courier that it's closing its Northgate Mall store in Cincinnati, with a clearance sale beginning this month and running for up to three months. A final closing date has not yet been set. Macy's closed nine stores in 2019: Charleston Town Center, Charleston, S.C.; Casper Eastridge, Casper, Wyo.; Redmond Town Center, Redmond, Wash; Sunnyvale Town Center, Sunnyvale, Calif; Macy's Furniture Gallery, Westside Pavilion, Los Angele; Glendale Galleria, Indianapolis; Swansea, Mass; Tysons Galleria, McLean, Va; Nanuet Mall, Nanuet, N.Y. The last three-year plan was laid out at the company's 2017 annual meeting, where then-new CEO Jeff Gennette debuted what he called the North Star strategy, a five-point plan inspired by founder R.H. Macy's tattoo of a star, which inspired the company's logo. That plan included: It must be Macy's. "It's about delivering the products and experiences customers love and can only find with us. This includes styles and home fashion in every day and special occasions. This also includes iconic events and encompasses strategies to appeal to more valued consumers with Macy's Backstage and Last Act strategies." Every experience matters, both in-store and online. "competitive advantage is the ability to combine the human touch in physical stores with cutting-edge technology." Funding future. "Which represents the decisions and actions the company take to fuel growth focused on cost reduction and reinvestment and creating value from real estate portfolio." What's new. "What's next explores how the company innovates to turn customer and technology trends to advantage and drive growth, exploring previously unmet customer needs and making smart investment decisions based on customer insight and analytics. That pl

Macy's Inc. announced it is closing its Hanes Mall store, the second of five anchor tenants to depart in the past year. A clearance sale will begin this month and run about eight to 12 weeks. The company said an exact closing date has not been set and will depend mostly on the success of the clearance sale. The three-level Macy's store is 151,415 square feet, with the overall property contains 9.68 acres when including its parking lot. Macy's owns the property. The anchor space was added to Hanes Mall in 1990 - the same year as the Dillard's anchor store - and was originally owned by the Thalhimers department store chain. Thalhimers stores were converted to Hecht's in 1992 after a sale to the May Company. Hecht's became Macy's in 2006 after the merger of May and Federated Department Stores. Based on news reports, Macy's is closing at least 15 stores in early 2020. It announced plans in August 2016 to close at least 100 stores nationwide.

Nearly 16 years after Macy's opened a store at Antioch's Somersville Towne Center, the company has announced it will close its doors there. The announcement of the store closure comes only a few months after another of the mall's longtime anchor tenants, Sears, shuttered. Victoria's Secret is also expected to close in the mall as of Jan. 21. The only major anchor tenant remaining is Fallas, on the southern wing of the shopping center. The Antioch Macy's location is the only California one on a list of more than two dozen in several states that will be closed amid declining sales. Macys' most recent earnings report, showed a sales decline of 3.9% at stores open for at least a year. Although at 107,142 square feet, it was about half the size of other Macy's stores, it was hailed as an option for upscale fashion previously unavailable in the area. Until then, East County shoppers with disposable income had to travel to Concord's Sunvalley Shopping Center or beyond for designer clothes. The mall underwent a $6 million facelift in 2003, replacing the parquet floor with tiles, adding restrooms and new paint. Millions more went into building the two-story Macy's structure.
Macy's, Inc. announced that it will shutter its Burlington location in March. The Burlington store, which affects 114 jobs, is the latest in a spate of closures for the Cincinnati-based retailer.

Ferro Corp. announced that it plans additional restructuring that will include some job cuts to its global work force. The company would not say how many jobs would be trimmed but that the effect in Northeast Ohio will be negligible. He declined to say how many employees in the company work in the region. It has about 7,000 worldwide. The restructuring should save Ferro about $10 million a year.

Ferro Corp. announced that it will discontinue manufacturing porcelain enamel frit at a facility in the Netherlands, eliminating 84 jobs, and consolidate production at other European sites. The company said operations at the Rotterdam facility will be closed by the summer of 2008.

Ferro Corp. announced that it would be closing a plant in Washington County as part of a move to relocate jobs to Mexico. 160 jobs will be cut while another 50 employees will be offered positions at other Ferro locations or to work from home. The transition of shutting down the facility will begin shortly and will extend through the year and possibly into 2020. The facility in Washington County is among several plants being shut down by Ferro, including a facility in Cleveland and multiple sites in Latin America. This will allow the company to further consolidate work to the Villagran plant, where Ferro has had a presence since 1981.

Fifth Third Bancorp will cut 100 branch offices in response to mobile and online banking trends. The parent of Fifth Third Bank has not specified the locations to be closed or sold. In addition to the 100 targeted locations, Fifth Third will shed another 30 properties that had been purchased for future branch expansion.

Fifth Third Bank has closed 36 more branches, including some in Greater Cincinnati, marking the latest in its string of branch cutbacks. Fifth Third experimented with tellerless branches at both of the local offices it closed. It added advanced-technology ATMs at the Carew Tower location in 2013 and at the Glendale branch shortly after that. Fifth Third also said it closed 34 other branches across its 10-state footprint. Those closings include eight in Florida, seven in Michigan, seven in Illinois, four in Northeast Ohio, three in Kentucky, one in Central Ohio, two in Indiana and two in North Carolina.

Regions Financial Corp. plans to slash its work force by 4% across the Birmingham, Ala.-based company's 16-state foot print. The banking giant has 30,000 employees across 16 states. A 4% decrease of 30,000 employees means as many as 1,200 positions could be eliminated.

Regions Financial Corp. laid off at least seven workers at its local loan center in the Birmingham area as part of a minor work force adjustment. The bank recently announced plans to suspend its employees 401(k) matching contributions and pension plan accruals to avoid cutting 1,400 jobs.

Regions Financial Corp. said it will close 121 bank branches by early 2010, including one in Columbus. The Edgewood Columbus office at 3805 Macon Road will shut its doors by Jan. 10, 2010, with its operations being consolidated into a newer branch at 5555 Whittlesey Blvd., in the Columbus Park Crossing development. After the consolidation, there will be three Regions banking centers in Columbus and three in Phenix City. None of the outlets in nearby Auburn and Opelika, Ala., are affected. Regions branches typically employ between five and 10 people. The company is not anticipating any substantial job losses as a result of that consolidation. The company is working to find positions for associates whenever possible at other area locations. Of the 121 branches targeted for closure, 16 are in Georgia and three in Alabama.
FirstMerit Corporation has begun to lay off 119 employees. The 119 employees represent 29% of Midwest Banc's staff of 412 as of March 31.
Trustmark Corporation announced that it is expecting to lose about 50,000 jobs in Huston in 2009 or 2010.

M&T Bank Corp., which is expected to begin handing out layoff notices to Allfirst Financial employees this week, said fourth quarter 2002 profit rose 24 percent on increased loans. M&T plans to mail letters this week to inform Allfirst employees if they will be retained after the acquisition and, if not, when they will be laid off. When M&T bought Harrisburg based Keystone Financial two years ago, it laid off 780 Keystone employees, or 27 percent of the work force. If the same percentage and timetable are applied to M&Ts latest acquisition, 1,566 of Allfirsts 5,800 employees would lose their jobs by the end of the year.

M&T Bank Corp. plans to lay off more than 1,100 employees at Allfirst about 20 percent of the bank's work force as part of its $3.1 billion buyout of the Baltimore-based bank from Allied Irish Banks plc The majority of the cuts, 720 people, will be in Maryland. The layoffs make up about 20 percent of the bank's 5,553 employees in Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia and Washington, D.C., the bank announced Tuesday. Zabel said M&T hasn't yet determined the number of layoffs in Pennsylvania, Virginia and Washington.

M&T Bank will cut 1,132 jobs most of them in Maryland, in the 18 months after it acquires Allfirst. The layoffs make up about 20 percent of the bank's 5,553 employees in Maryland, Pennsylvania, Virginia, and Washington, D.C.

M&T Bank Corp. will cut 70 jobs in Blair County by 2006 due to a decline in check writing. Web banking and an increase in the use of check cards caused the loss of a branch balancing office in Altoona. There has been about a 10% decrease in check writing due to the new banking options.

M&T Bank Corporation planning to close one of its three Jamestown branches in May 2012, consolidating services to an existing full-service office and a walk-up location. The bank confirmed that it will close its office at 2-8 E. Third St., at Main Street, on May 25, 2012 although it will still conduct 'certain nonretail activities' at that office.

M&T Bank does plan to eliminate jobs. M&T has said it will cut 366 jobs - or 24% of Hudson City's workforce - through August of 2016. The jobs are mostly back-office administrative positions that already exist in Buffalo and other parts of M&T's footprint.
U.S. Bancorp announced that it is laying off about 1% of its workforce company wide.

First Horizon National Corp. will cut about 70 jobs at its check-clearing centers in Maryville and Memphis because of advances in processing technology. The bank announced that it will eliminate 60 jobs at its Maryville center by July and 10 jobs at a sister facility in Memphis. Fifty of the positions are full time.

First Horizon National Corp. announced that it is shuttering the national expansion of its retail banking operations in three cities to focus on its dominant Tennessee market. The closing of 34 branches in the Atlanta, Dallas and Washington/Baltimore areas will eliminate 360 jobs and plug a $30 million annualized drain on operations.
First Horizon National Corp. will cut 170 jobs statewide, including 85 in Memphis, from its about-to-be-sold mortgage operation.

First Tennessee Bank plans to eliminate around 40 mortgage jobs across the state, as part of an effort to cut costs. The company said that the branch-based loan officer positions will be eliminated at the end of the year, and customers will be directed to the Memphis-based sales team, via the phone or Internet. The employees whose jobs are eliminated will be encouraged to apply for other positions in the company. The move is aimed at cutting costs, and said five mortgage loan officers in the Knoxville area will be affected.
First Union Corp. has laid off 20% of its eChannels? workforce in an effort to reduce costs and streamline operations.

Wachovia Corp. has announced that the company plans to eliminate 400 jobs over the next few months as it merges the retail brokerage back-room operations of the former First Union Corp. and the old Wachovia.
Wachovia Corp. has announced plans to cut about 2,500 jobs in 2002 to cut costs.

Wachovia Corp. officials expect between 700 and 1,000 jobs will be cut in Winston Salem by the time its merger with First Union Corp. is completed in 2004. David Carroll and Bob McCoy, who are in charge of Wachovia's merger planning, told local employees of the possible job cuts at two information sessions.
Wachovia Corp. announced that it will close nine Palm Beach County branches and one Martin County office by November 15 as part of its merger with First Union.
Wachovia Corp. plans an undisclosed number of job cuts and other changes in its corporate and investment banking division as it tries to improve profits in the economic and market slowdown.
Wachovia will close 20 branches in South Carolina, including three in the Columbia area, as part of consolidation related to its 2001 merger with First Union.

Wachovia Corp. said that it would close 44 branches in May Including three in Forsyth County and nine in the Triad. The accounts serviced in those branches will be transferred the afternoon of May 8 to the nearest branch, typically within a half mile, and be available for customers on May 9.

Wachovia Corp. plans to close a string of branches in older suburbs and city districts, while opening new offices in wealthier or improving neighborhoods. The bank expects to shut its Coatesville, Clifton Heights, Five Points (Levittown), Lower Chichester, and Township Line (Drexel Hill) branches on December 6, 2006. It has previously announced it planned to close two Philadelphia branches, at Front Street and Allegheny Avenue and at Germantown and Lehigh Avenues, that day; two branches in Allentown will also be shut.Wachovia is planning to open new branches in Concordville, Delaware County; Warrington, Bucks County; and Audubon, Montgomery County. The bank had previously announced plans for branches in University City and Parkside, both sites of new commercial development in West Philadelphia. Wachovia is also considering new branches in the gentrifying Northern Liberties and Brewerytown sections of Philadelphia.

Wachovia Corp. confirmed that 42 employees who service mortgage loans are losing their jobs at the old World Savings operations center. The 42 employees were advised of the cutback about two weeks ago. They will receive retraining and placement assistance and a severance package and will be encouraged to pursue other openings at Wachovia when their jobs end next month. The affected employees handled calls from World Savings mortgage customers. The layoff comes on the heels of two announcements this year that the operations center would expand staff, adding more than 600 jobs.

Wachovia Corp. plans to cut 110 jobs in Charlotte as part of its recently announced plans to reduce its investment-banking division staff by 200. The unit has about 6,300 employees. The cuts will occur at offices around the globe. The bank began notifying employees of the layoffs.

Wachovia Corporation confirms it is getting out of the wholesale mortgage lending business, exiting a market cross-town rival Bank of America Corp. left several months ago. That means Wachovia will no longer offer mortgages through brokers. The move will result in job reductions at the bank, but the number has not been disclosed.

Wachovia Corporation is closing mortgage offices in 19 states where it has few or no retail branches. The move will cause the elimination of 125 jobs. The reductions are part of 6,350 previously announced full-time cuts, which include 4,400 mortgage jobs to be slashed over the next 12 months.

Wachovia Corporation plans to lay off 59 employees in Jacksonville, carrying out the bank's previously announced reduction in positions across the company. The bank announced that the state Agency for Workforce Innovation the layoffs will occur through the end of the year. Wachovia gave similar notice of 50 layoffs in Boynton Beach. In August, Wachovia announced it expects to eliminate 11,350 positions, including 6,950 employees and 4,400 open positions. The cuts in Jacksonville are focused in the bank's mortgage department.

Wachovia Corporation's child care center in north Charlotte plans to lay off its entire staff, a few months after learning Wells Fargo & Co. would eliminate a tuition subsidy. About 130 employees work at the center, which is currently open to only Wachovia families. In August, Wells said it would eliminate an income-based tuition subsidy for employees who use the Leslee Lloyd Child Development Center, a popular benefit in legacy Wachovia.
FleetBoston Financial Cororation announced its plans to layoff 500 people from its staff, in an effort to cut costs.
FleetBoston Financial Corp. announced that it will cut about 700 jobs, or 1.3 percent of its staff of 55,000 people.
FleetBoston Financial Corp. has announced that it plans to layoff 430 employees, approximately 19 percent of its workforce, as a part of its plan to reduce costs.
FleetBoston Financial Corp. has announced that the company will pare back its global banking services and also exit its Asian bond business.
FleetBoston Financial Corp. has announced that it has closed its corporate risk-management division as a part of its restructuring plan.
Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. has announced that it has closed down four Housing plants and some company-owned retail outlets.

Fleetwood Enterprises Inc. announced the closing of its Gold Shield Inc. facility in Fontana, California, which manufactures custom open-molded fiberglass parts. Employees were notified in July of the impending closure. Recreational vehicle industry pressures necessitated closure of the Fontana facility. The Fontana plant will be closed on or about September 28, 2007, and Fleetwood currently intends to make this property available for sale.

Fluor Corp. has reported the most layoffs - 4,003 in South Carolina. Those took effect Aug. 1 after S.C. Electric & Gas, a subsidiary of SCANA Corp. and Santee Cooper decided to stop construction at the plant. The two utilities had spent $9 billion on the plant at that point, but estimated that completing the two-reactor expansion at the existing nuclear plant would cost another $9 billion. The Fluor figures do not include the 100 employees impacted by Fluor's decision to close its Charlotte office, which housed construction support operations for Summer.

Ford Motor Company announced that it will eliminate one of the two production shifts at its pickup truck plant in Edison, New Jersey, effective Feb. 4, and layoff 600 hourly employees and an unspecified number of salaried workers, as part of its restruct

Ford Motor Company's plant in Edison, N.J, which makes Ranger pickups, might be shut down as part of the major reorganization the automaker is set to announce. Ford is expected to report a loss for 2001, its first annual loss since 1992. Under its new chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., the company has continued the cost cutting begun under his predecessor, Jacques A. Nasser, in an attempt to return to profitability and to stabilize its tumbling market share. Still, Ford seems to have tipped its hand in picking between Edison and St. Paul. In December, it announced it would shut down one of Edison's two shifts in February, idling some 600 of the plant's approximately 1,700 employees.

Ford Motor Co. will cut 17,000 jobs under a restructuring plan expected to be announced tomorrow, the Detroit News and London's Financial Times reported. The News, citing unidentified Ford executives, reported that three assembly plants will be shut down by 2003. The cost of the restructuring is likely to approach $4 billion.

The massive restructuring Ford Motor Co. announced it will prompt a work slowdown at its suburban Atlanta plant and cause about 125 workers to lose their jobs. The plant, which makes Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans, has 2,370 employees and produces about 1,000 cars per day with two work shifts. Ford also builds Taurus and Sables at its Chicago plant.

Ford Motor Co. announced a sweeping restructuring plan that aims to pare 35,000 workers, or 10 percent of its work force, with the bulk of those job cuts in North America. It's the first move by the new Ford-heir-led executive team to steer the money-losing automaker back to profitability. In connection with the plan, the Dearborn, Mich.-based Ford said it would take an after-tax charge of $4.1 billion in the fourth quarter and target 22,000 job cuts in the company's 120,000-strong North American ranks. Ford employs about 345,000 workers around the world.

Ford Motor Company will cut at least 1,500 more white-collar workers as part of the long-awaited restructuring plan announced. If enough workers don't accept a buyout, Ford would force some employees out the door. The automaker already has eliminated about 3,500 white-collar jobs under a voluntary buyout program announced in August and through other cost-cutting steps. The company plans to extend that voluntary program to reach its goal of 5,000 white-collar job cuts, Ford Chief Operating Officer Nick Scheele.

Ford Motor Company will mothball five plants and idle assembly lines at several others including Oakland County's Wixom Assembly Plant as part of a restructuring that will cost workers from New Jersey to Missouri their jobs. Eighteen plants including five in Ohio are affected by the Dearborn automaker's $4.1-billion retooling of its North American operations. The plant closings and 21,500 job losses in North America will hurt the most in towns like Oakville, Ontario and Avon Lake, Ohio, as Ford tries to return to profitability by cutting its overhead.

A Missouri delegation that met with Ford Motor Company executives is convinced that persuading the automaker to spare a St. Louis-area assembly plant from planned extinction is a long shot, but one still worth pursuing. Holden said Ford explained that it wants to pare capacity and consolidate production in plants it considers most flexible, while jettisoning the five plants as part of an unfolding restructuring process that also calls for 35,000 job cuts. Ford lost $5.45 billion last year including special charges - the company's first losing year since its $7.4 billion loss in 1992 - and looks to the restructuring, among other things, to stanch the red ink. They let us know they have made their decision to close the plant in around 2005, Holden said, though suggesting it's open for us to work them to give them other options.

Ford Motor Co. plans to begin mailing buyout offers this week. The Dearborn-based automaker cut 3,500 white-collar positions last year by offering early retirements and voluntary separation packages, and the company wants to trim 1,500 more by year's end. In August, Ford announced it planned to cut eliminate 4,000 to 5,000 salaried positions by the end of 2001.

The Ford Motor Company. assembly plant in Hazelwood, Mo. could have begun closing down immediately had the plant not been included in a new labor union agreement tentatively reached. Ford had announced in January 2002 that it intended to close the suburban St. Louis plant around 'mid-decade', but the company never provided a specific date.

Ford Motor Company is set to shed more than 12,000 jobs worldwide, mainly in the United States, Belgium and Germany. The Detroit-based company said it has reached an agreement with the United Auto Workers to close or sell four assembly or component plants in North America resulting in about 4,600 jobs lost. In addition, Ford said it would cut 3,000 salaried positions in North America, 1,700 jobs in Germany and 3,000 at its plant in Genk, Belgium, the London Financial Times reported.

Ford Motor Co. said it is laying off 262 workers at its Lima Engine Plant because of a drop in demand for the engine they produce. he indefinite layoffs, effective immediately, put the plant's total work force at a little over 1,300.

Ford Motor Co. plans to lay off 200 workers at its plant in this Kansas City suburb. Mike Perry local union president was informed that Ford plans to lay off 100 hourly workers on Feb. 6 and an additional 100 employees on Feb. 13. The Claycomo plant's approximately 5,600 hourly employees make Ford's Escape sport-utility vehicle and the F-series pickup.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will lay off about 1,000 workers at its St. Louis-area assembly plant, or about 37 percent of the plant's work force, in April. Displaced workers would be offered jobs at other Ford sites nationwide. Ford representatives were to spell out the layoffs with plant workers and managers Thursday. In 2002, Ford announced it would close the Hazelwood plant by mid-decade but reversed its decision last September, agreeing as part of its latest contract with the United Auto Workers to keep the site open at least through 2007.
Ford Motor Co. is cutting 1,150 jobs, closing a Jaguar plant and pulling out of Formula One auto racing in a bid to return the unit to profitability.

Ford Motor Co. to lay off about 200 employees at its Wixom Assembly Plant when it stops making the Ford Thunderbird this summer. The plant will stop making the Thunderbird just before the company's annual two-week shutdown in July. Ford announced Thursday that it was discontinuing the current-generation Thunderbird after the 2005 model year.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it would cut about 1,700, or 5%, of its white-collar jobs in North America. The company announced that it would no longer give bonuses to employees in those positions or make matching contributions to their 401(k) plans.

Ford Motor Co. is planning to cut 250 workers from its truck plant in eastern Jefferson County - a surprise to some who felt safe because of the popularity of its Super Duty trucks. The job cuts, the first by Ford in Louisville in four years, will come on September 30, when the company will halt production of the Excursion sport utility vehicle.

Ford Motor Co. fired an undisclosed number of public-affairs workers in what may be the first in a series of job cuts as the automaker speeds up cost- cutting measures after profit dropped two consecutive quarters. The company also wants to eliminate about 1,700 jobs, 5% of its North American auto positions by Oct. 1. Ford told employees in April that firings could occur if enough salaried employees didn't accept buyouts.

Ford Motor Co. has resorted to firing white-collar employees and immediately escorting them from corporate buildings. The job cuts are thought to be in response to the company's failure to reach the target of 2,750 white-collar job cuts through voluntary means.
Ford Motor Co. announced that the number of workers being laid off in Windsor has dropped from 335 to 250.

Delphi Corp., General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Visteon Corp. may cut wages and thousands of jobs in cost-saving restructuring plans. GM and Delphi, its former parts division, Ford Motor Co. and Ford's former parts unit Visteon Corp., form the largest employers of organized workers in the U.S. city of Detroit, and all plan to restructure.

Delphi Corp., General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Visteon Corp. may cut wages and thousands of jobs in cost-saving restructuring plans. GM and Delphi, its former parts division, Ford Motor Co. and Ford's former parts unit Visteon Corp., form the largest employers of organized workers in the U.S. city of Detroit, and all plan to restructure.
Ford Motor Co. announced plans to lay off 2,750 salaried employees in 2005.
Ford Motor Co. announced that it is planning to cut at least 2,000 jobs at its plants in Europe this winter. The company is likely to close factories and cut jobs in the US and continental Europe.

Ford Motor Co. is likely to close five plants that employ about 7,500 workers, about 6% of the company's North American workforce. The plans to shut the plants were still being formulated and were subject to change.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will close its main Explorer plant in St. Louis. It's part of a wider plan by Ford to idle 30,000 workers, shut 14 plants and wipe out 26% of the automaker's assembly capacity in North America. While Explorer production will continue in limited volumes at Louisville, Ky., the decision to close the sport utility vehicle's home plant is regarded as a clear signal that popularity for the hefty SUV.

Ford Motor Co. officials re-affirmed the closing of the Windsor Casting Plant by 2008 but also reported they remained committed to introducing a new engine project into Windsor by late next year. The new-generation V8 engine, expected to be a diesel, will be built at the Essex Engine Plant after its current V-6 production line is phased out by late 2007 or 2008. Closure of the casting plant and the loss of almost 700 jobs by late 2007 or early 2008 was announced last September as part of a collective agreement reached between the company and the CAW. In addition, production of V-6 engines at Essex Engine Plant will also be phased out during the same time period, resulting in an additional 400 job losses pending introduction of the new engine project.

Ford Motor Co. announced that assembly plant in Hazelwood built its last Ford Explorer sport utility vehicle, marking the end of 58 years of production at that facility. The final goodbyes meant even more because she had fought hard to get hired at the plant 20 years ago, dealing at the time with harsh treatment meted by supervisors still resisting the idea of hiring women. Entering as an outsider, she now considers Ford and the United Auto Workers as part of her family.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will lay off an undetermined number of workers at its Chicago assembly plant by October as it trims production of the Five Hundred sedan to match declining demand. The layoffs will be the first since the plant received a $400 million overhaul in 2004 to become a flexible manufacturing facility that can produce several models on the same production line. A 10% reduction in line speed would not mean that 10% of the 2,500 union workers at the plant would be laid off.

Ford Motor Co. announced plans to close a Norfolk, Va., assembly plant with 2,433 workers. The closing, expected to happen by 2008, also will affect 400 employees in the region who work at affiliated auto parts facilities, according to a statement by the United Auto Workers Local 919.

Ford Motor Co. said that it expected to take a charge of $2.4 billion this year to shut plants as part of its North American revamping. Ford plans to close 14 manufacturing sites and cut up to 30,000 jobs by 2012 under a plan announced this year. So far, Ford has announced plans to close plants in St. Paul, St. Louis, Atlanta, Norfolk, Va., Batavia, Ohio, Wixom, Mich. and Windsor, Ontario, by the end of 2008.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it would shut its Norfolk truck plant in 2008, the company is moving to transfer salaried employees to other facilities. Before the transfers, Norfolk Assembly Plant had 158 salaried employees alongside 2,275 hourly workers. Ford already has given transfers to a small portion of the salaried staff, with more expected over the next two years. The company is bridging the gap between the departures of salaried employees and the planned shutdown by bringing in temporary replacements. The transfers are part of a major reshuffling of Ford's manufacturing base. The company plans to close 14 plants by 2012, cutting the company's work force by as many as 30,000.

Ford Motor Co. could stand down up to 4500 workers on no pay after the collapse of Braeside parts firm Ajax Engineered Fasteners.
