Holden is desperately trying to stave off thousands of stand-downs by flying in parts from overseas. But the car giant has enough stock to last only until the end of the week. After that its 5000 workers in Victoria and South Australia may be told to take holidays and could eventually be laid off. The company announced up to 4500 workers in Broadmeadows and Geelong, earning an average $50,000 a year, could be affected. Ford makes 450 cars a day in Victoria.

Workers at a Ford Motor Co. stamping plant have agreed to work rule and other changes that will make the plant more efficient. United Auto Workers members at the Woodhaven Stamping Plant south of Detroit agreed to the changes in what is called a 'competitive operating agreement'. UAW Local 387 represents about 1,500 workers at the plant, which makes door panels, fenders, floor pans, hoods, quarter panels, roofs and tailgates. The agreement, which comes while the current UAW contract with Ford is in effect, allows Ford to offer more buyout packages to workers at Woodhaven.The company has announced plans to close eight plants by the end of 2008 and a total of 14 by 2012 as part of its restructuring plan. The company is working on accelerating the restructuring and may announce more plant closures next month. So far, Ford has announced plans to close plants in Wixom; St. Paul, Minn.; Norfolk, Va.; St. Louis, Mo.; Atlanta, Ga.; Batavia, Ohio; and Windsor, Ontario by the end of 2008. The company said the closures will reduce its North American manufacturing capacity by 26%. The company will offer buyouts to workers at the plants, which will be closed to bring Ford's production capacity more in line with demand for its products. The company plans to cut 12,000 hourly jobs with buyouts and through attrition by the end of the year.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it is offering buyouts to all of its 75,000 U.S. hourly workers and shutting down Maumee in 2008 and an engine plant in Essex, Ontario, in 2007. A transmission plant in Batavia in southwest Ohio that employs 1,480 hourly and 265 salaried workers is among the 14 plants that Ford said previously that it plans to close. It also plans to sell or close by the end of 2008 all facilities including a component plant in Sandusky with 1,700 workers that it took back as part of a bailout of Visteon Corp., a supplier spun off from the automaker. Under the buyout and early retirement plan, workers can choose among eight packages that offer from $35,000 to $140,000 depending on years of service, age and how close they are to retirement. Some packages will force workers to give up health benefits.

Ford Motor Co. to cut more than 10,000 additional salaried jobs, offering buyouts to all of its 75,000 U.S. hourly workers and shutting down two more plants, including one in Ohio, in a plan to end financial losses and remake itself into a smaller, more competitive car company. The company to close an assembly plant in Norfolk, Va., in 2007, a year earlier than previously announced and will cut a shift in January. An assembly plant in St. Paul, Minn., which is scheduled to close in 2008, also will have a shift reduction in 2007.The new cuts bring the total number of plant closures to 16, adding to the 14 plants announced previously. The company has identified nine of the plants to be closed through 2008 and would complete its cuts of about 30,000 hourly jobs by the end of the 2008, four years ahead of its previous target. The new cuts would reduce total North American work force by 29%, from the current level of about 130,000 to about 92,000 by the end of 2008. Ford plans to expand buyout and early retirement offers worth up to $140,000 to the company's U.S. hourly work force of more than 75,000 as part of the plan. The cuts are all due to consumers shifting from trucks and sport utility vehicles to smaller, more fuel efficient cars and crossovers, many made by Asian automakers.

The closure of the Essex Engine Plant and the loss of its 650 jobs. Ford Motor Co. has apparently lost confidence in Windsor workers' ability to produce cost-efficient, high-quality engines. The cuts, announced in Dearborn, Mich. are part of Ford's efforts to save $5 billion US while eliminating 25,000 to 30,000 hourly workers and 14,000 salaried employees while closing 16 plants. The engine plant on the city's east side, which produces V-8 and V-6 engines as well as cylinder heads and crankshafts, is slated to close next year as part of the slumping automaker's Way Forward restructuring plan. Earlier this year, Ford announced the casting plant would be shuttered next year. There are currently 484 production workers on layoff from Ford's operations here and another 561 on notice of layoff. Closure of the Engine Plant will eliminate 650 production jobs and another 550 will disappear when the casting plant closes.

Ford Motor Co.'s Indianapolis steering plant could close as the struggling automaker wipes out nearly 40% of its North American jobs. The plan seems certain to touch off hundreds of layoffs among Ford suppliers across Indiana, as well as on the city's Eastside. Ford's English Avenue steering systems plant, an Eastside economic mainstay will be closed or sold by the end of 2008, and early retirement packages will be offered to the 1,700 hourly workers, beginning in October. Conceding high gasoline prices are here to stay, Ford revealed it would refocus on fuel-efficient autos while it eliminates 54,000 hourly and salaried jobs and sheds 28 plants in the United States and Canada, including the Indianapolis steering plant.

Ford Motor Co. plans to close 16 plants in the next two years. It also plans to sell or close by the end of 2008 all facilities that it took back as part of a bailout of Visteon Corp. The company also is offering buyouts and early retirement to workers who can choose among eight packages that offer from $35,000 to $140,000 depending on years of service, age and how close they are to retirement. Some packages will force workers to give up health benefits. The 75,000 union-represented hourly workers must decide to take buyouts, early retirement or stick it out with Ford, facing an uncertain future.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it would slash its Australian workforce by about 10% or 640 jobs by Christmas. The job cuts follow an October announcement by the automaker that it was reducing daily car production from 450 units to 360 units by late November at two production plants in Victoria state owing to slowing sales. The automaker currently employs about 5,500 workers at its Broadmeadows and Geelong production facilities in Victoria. The jobs cuts will be voluntary and come from across the business.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it is settling buyout offers with its 75,000 unionized factory workers. All of Ford s blue-collar workers represented by the United Auto Workers union have been offered buyout packages. Ford also said it planned to cut one shift at its full-sized SUV plan in the second quarter of 2006. The move is the latest indication that the business model maybe changing at the auto maker and could lead to as many as 1,000 job cuts. Many of the buyout offers expire on Nov. 27. Employees electing to leave will have between January and September of 2007 to exit the company. Ford's North American operation aims to cut between 25,000 and 30,000 hourly jobs by 2008, and close seven assembly plants by 2010.

Ford Motor Co. announced that Ford and other domestic auto companies, Ford, General Motors Corp. and DaimlerChrysler Corp. will continue to employ 300,000 people in the United States. Ford expects to cut about 38,000 blue collar jobs by fall and 10,000 salaried jobs this quarter.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it is to close a foundry which makes parts for the firm's vehicles, with the loss of 365 jobs. The 126-year-old plant at Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, will close in July after the company decided it had become too uncompetitive. Workers will be offered early retirement, voluntary redundancy or redeployment and there will be no compulsory lay-offs.
Ford Motor Co. announced that it will close 16 plants. The company announced that nine of these plants will close by 2008 and the rest will close by 2012.

Ford Motor Co. ceased production at its casting plant in Windsor, Ontario, as part of the automaker's plan to exit the business of casting engine parts. The 500,000-square-foot plant employed about 450 people, making cylinder block castings for the company's 4.2-liter V-6 engines and crankshafts for the 4.2-liter, 5.4-liter V-8, 3.0-liter V-6, 4.6 liter V-8 and the 2.3-liter engines. The closure comes two days after thousands gathered for a rally in Windsor, located across the Detroit River from Detroit, to protest the loss of manufacturing jobs. Ford has identified 10 plants that it will close as part of a restructuring plan designed to shrink its production capacity to match reduced demand for its cars and trucks and return to profitability. The company has said it will close 16 facilities by 2012.
Ford Motor Co. announced in July it would sack 600 of its Geelong engine plant workers over the next three years.
Ford Motor Co. laid out plans for further hourly job cuts in a meeting between executives and the United Auto Workers union as the auto maker reduces production of slow-selling trucks.

Ford Motor Co. informed workers at the Kentucky Truck Plant in Louisville that falling consumer demand will force the company to make deeper cutbacks in production when the idled plant resumes operations on Aug. 4. Ford will scale work back from three shifts to two in its body stamping and paint department. The action will lead to the elimination of about 300 jobs. That would represent about 8.3% of the plant's 3,625 hourly workers.

Ford Motor Co. has announced it is cutting up to 350 jobs at its Geelong and Broadmeadows plants in Victoria. The company plans to start cutting production by 20 to 25% by mid-November. The cutbacks come as the industry faces financial losses and a slump in consumer demand.

Ford Motor Co. is cutting 600 part-time jobs at its Chicago assembly plant when it drops one of its two shifts by early November. The company also says an unspecified number of hourly and salaried employees could lose their jobs at the plant, which employs about 2,200 people. And Ford says some jobs may be eliminated at the company's Chicago Heights stamping plant, which produces body panels for the vehicles made in Chicago.
Ford Motor Co. announced that it will reduce its workforce at Almussafes by up to 1,300, albeit on a temporary basis from September 29 to December 17.

Ford Motor Co. is planning to cut 500 jobs at its Oakville, Ontario, plant. The facility produces the Flex, Edge, Lincoln MKX and upcoming MKT. The automaker will reduce the third body and paint shift at the Oakville plant. The company is offering retirement with a USD 75,000 allowance and a USD 35,000 credit towards purchasing a new Ford vehicle in order to reduce the number of employees.

Ford Motor Co. is planning to reduce its van production to more than half over the next three years at its Southampton plant. The automaker is planning to shift van production to Turkey. It is laying off 1,100 people working at the facility, which produces a range of Transit vans. The present Transit is to be produced at Southampton until 2011.
Ford Motor Co. plans to rein in output at its German plant in Saarlouis and will terminate in October 204 temporary jobs that were supposed to run until year's end.
Ford Motor Co. announced that it plans to cut more than 2,000 additional white-collar jobs.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will axe its credit arm by February, with 160 staff to lose their jobs. The decision, which comes as the Australian car industry faces its worst sales performance in 30 years, means private car buyers will no longer be able to seek finance from the company.

Management of the Ford Motor Co. plant based in Vsevolozhsk in the Leningrad region has filed an offer about possible reduction of over 500 employees to trade unions for agreement. Among these employees are people, who refused to switch to four-day operation mode.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will begin the gradual process of shutting down its Brook Park casting plant by the end of 2010, reducing the work force by an unspecified number. The company wants to get out of the business of making its own cast-iron engine blocks and vehicle parts, sending that work to suppliers in Canada and Brazil. With about 600 workers, Cleveland Casting is the largest of Ford's three Brook Park plants. Engine Plants No. 1 and No. 2 together employ about another 600. The company announced plans in 2007 to close the casting plant in 2009, but later agreed to extend its life another year. The company also does not have large layoffs scheduled before that date. The company does not classify ending the contracts of temporary workers as layoffs. Company and other union officials have argued that outsourcing all of Ford's engine-block castings is dangerous for the company because the automaker wouldn't have control over quality or pricing. The first casting to go will be the block for the 4.6-liter V-8 engine used in Ford's F-150 pickup and the outgoing version of the Explorer sport utility vehicle. Though jobs are leaving the casting plant, prospects are a bit better at Engine Plant No. 1. That facility makes the 3.7-liter V-6 engine used in the Mustang muscle car and the 3.5-liter EcoBoost V-6, a turbocharged engine used in the Ford Taurus SHO and several other specialty vehicles. The company expects to add a second shift to that plant later this year as the automaker gets ready to put the EcoBoost V-6 in the F-150. Engineers have said the V-6 truck will be more powerful and significantly more fuel-efficient than some V-8 versions of the F-150, Ford's best-selling product for decades. The company expects the second shift at Engine Plant No. 1 to be added about the same time the casting plant closes, so many workers will transfer instead of losing their jobs. Still, the Brook Park site will need more new products to protect jobs there in the future. At Engine Plant No. 2, which employs about

Ford will lay off 249 Indianapolis autoworkers in November, part of the shutdown of its massive English Avenue factory. The 2011 closing of the Eastside steering systems plant was revealed months ago by the automaker, which now has about 580 hourly workers on the site. Ford's announcement of more layoffs comes as General Motors stamping plant workers vote by mail on pay cuts intended to save the 650-employee plant near Downtown from closing. Instead of retooling the big Indianapolis plant for new electric steering units, Ford wound down the Eastside factory and turned to smaller outside suppliers, many operating at lower wages. The company announced layoffs of 249 production and skilled trades workers would occur on or about November 19, 2010. Ford labor affairs official Scott Laing disclosed the layoffs Thursday in a filing with the state required by the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act. Meanwhile, UAW dissident groups opposed to pay cuts pointed out that the GM stamping plant workers might reject the concessions requested by JD Norman Industries of Addison, Ill., as a condition of buying the plant from GM.

Ford Motor Co. plans to eliminate more than a third of its Lincoln dealers in large metropolitan areas over the next two years as part of its effort to revive the luxury brand. It plans to cut the 500 dealerships it has in those areas by 35%. Ford plans to release seven new or revamped Lincolns in the next four years, including Lincoln's first compact car.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it will lay off 150 people from its Buffalo Stamping Plant in September 2011 because of the planned closing of one of two Canadian assembly plants it supplies. The layoffs were disclosed on June 9, 2011 in a notice to the New York Labor Department. They will take effect September 5, 2011. The plant currently has 650 hourly workers. The Buffalo plant will continue to supply the company's Oakville, Ontario, assembly plant, which makes the Ford Edge and Ford Flex and Lincoln MKX and MKT. Laid-off workers could be recalled if the Buffalo plant lands more work.

Ford Motor Co. has proposed temporary layoffs for 4,000 of its 6,200 workers at its Spanish assembly plant in Valencia because of sluggish European demand for new cars. Ford's Spanish division says it wants the workers to stay home for 39 days between January and October of next year. The division has started talks with unions to negotiate terms of the temporary layoffs.

Ford Motor Co. workers in Britain will be among several hundred to lose jobs across Europe because of falling demand. The company said redundancies among permanent staff would be voluntary, although the exact number of job losses would 'not be known for a few months'.

Ford Motor Co. announced the closure of its last remaining UK vehicle production factory and another site, with the loss of 1,400 jobs. Production of Transit vans will end in Southampton next summer, with the loss of over 500 jobs, with the remainder being cut through the closure of a tooling plant in Dagenham. The company also unveiled plans to close its factory in Genk, Belgium, with the loss of 4,300 jobs, sparking violent protests. Ford announced that it will cut an additional 5,700 jobs at three facilities in the U.K. and Belgium, in an intensified restructuring meant to return the automaker's money-losing European operations to profitability by 2015. The plant closings became more urgent because Ford now expects to lose $1.5 billion in Europe this year, 50% more than its previous forecast. The deeper loss includes more than $400 million from reducing dealer supplies and $100 million in accelerated depreciation associated with plant closures.

Ford Motor Co. to stop making cars in Australia, nine decades after founder Henry Ford first began building Model Ts in the country, as a surge in the currency undermines the local industry's ability to compete with imports. Ford Australia faces costs double those in Europe and four times those of its Asian divisions. Bob Graziano announced the loss of 1,200 jobs from October 2016 at two plants.

Ford Motor Co. is planning to close two of its production plants by the end of July 2013. The company was planning to close both plants in late 2012. The company is closing its Southampton Assembly plant and Dagenham engine plant on July 26, 2013. It also plans to close its plant in Genk, Belgium, in the near future. The three plant closures will decrease the company's European production capacity by around 18% or 350,000 units. This move will save the automaker between USD 400 million and USD 450 million per annum.

Ford is laying off 197 temporary contract workers at an engine plant in Bridgend, South Wales, United Kingdom. The employees had been assigned to building 6-cylinder engines for Volvo products, and the loss was expected.

Ford Motor Co announced its laying off 700 workers at a Michigan assembly plant because of slow sales of the small cars and hybrids it makes. The Michigan Assembly Plant, in the Detroit suburb of Wayne, will move from three shifts to two starting June 22. The plant, which makes the Ford Focus and C-Max hybrid, has been operating on three shifts since 2012.

Ford Motor announced that it will close all operations in Japan and Indonesia in 2016 as it sees 'no reasonable path to profitability' in the two countries where it has struggled to gain market share. Ford will exit all areas of business, including closing dealerships and stopping sales and imports of Ford and Lincoln vehicles.

Ford Motor Co will close its Kansas City, Missouri pickup truck and van plant for a week in early January to match production and demand. The plant makes F-150 pickup trucks and Ford Transit vans. Ford also closed the Kansas City plant for a week a couple of months ago. The move comes a day after GM announced it was closing five U.S. plants, mainly ones that make light-selling sedans, in January from one to three weeks.

Ford Motor Co. announced that it is cutting jobs in Europe in a wide-ranging restructuring as it focuses on its most profitable models and shifts production towards electric cars. The company didn't reveal how many jobs would be cut and reductions would be achieved as far as possible through voluntary departures negotiated with unions and employee representatives. The move follows plans announced last year to reduce white-collar jobs across the company's global business.

Ford Motor Company is laying off around 200 employees in September at a Canadian manufacturing plant in Oakville, Ontario. The automaker plans to lay off more employees in January 2020. The company employs around 4,600 workers at the Oakville plant. The union president had originally estimated the number of layoffs at around 185. The automaker attributed the layoffs to decreasing sales of the Ford Flex and Lincoln MKT, both of which are produced at the Oakville plant.

Franklin Electric Co. Inc. has approved a plan to close its Tulsa Avenue, Oklahoma City, Oklahoma manufacturing facility. As part of this action, the company will transfer approximately 260,000 annual man hours of manufacturing activity primarily to the Linares, Mexico facility, with a small portion of the transfer going to another Oklahoma City-based facility. The transfers should be completed by the end of the first quarter 2012. The Company also expects to incur additional charges for the write-down of assets at its Siloam Springs, Arkansas facility, the closure of which has been previously announced. Additionally, the Company intends to complete other miscellaneous realignments and movements of manufacturing and distribution facilities in a variety of international locations, including the relocation to a new manufacturing facility in Joinville, Brazil. The Company has estimated the pretax charge for these actions to be between $2.6 million and $5.2 million, of which $1.2 million to $3.5 million is for the Tulsa Avenue facility. The charges will begin in the second quarter of 2011 and end in the fourth quarter of 2012 and include severance expenses, pension curtailments, asset write-offs, and equipment relocation costs. Approximately fifty to 60% of these charges will be non-cash.

G&K Services Inc. announced that, it reduced its North American workforce by approximately 340 positions and also eliminated approximately 120 currently open positions. These steps further adjust the company's cost structure in response to lower customer volumes and the expectation of continued weakness in near-term economic conditions. The company noted that, these actions will not impact the company's continued focus on providing excellent service to customers.

Gannett Co. Inc. has eliminated 120 full-and part-time jobs at its six daily newspapers in New Jersey. The cuts are part of a national reduction of 1,000 jobs, including 600 layoffs, across Gannett's newspaper operations around the nation. Gannett is the latest of several newspaper companies that announced staff reductions in recent months. Gannett, like the other media companies, blamed deteriorating business conditions for the cuts. The number of layoffs in Gannett's New Jersey operations was not announced in postings by the company. The layoffs took place at the Asbury Park Press of Neptune, the Courier-Post in Cherry Hill, the Home News Tribune in East Brunswick, the Courier News in Bridgewater, the Daily Record in Parsippany and the Daily Journal in Vineland.
Gannett Co. Inc. announced that it laid off about 2,000 workers, or 10% of its work force.
Gannett Co. Inc. announced it would cut 1,400 jobs nationally.

Gannett Co., Inc. laid off 700 of its 32,600 staffers. Twelve worked for The Des Moines Register. The layoffs got a little notice, but not much, given the sad state of the economy with millions unemployed.
Gannett will close its St. Louis printing plant by mid-March, affecting 19 employees.

Gap Inc. is closing the Forth & Towne chain that was supposed to help the struggling retailer sell more clothes to older women, aborting the 18-month expansion so management can concentrate on reviving the company's more established brands. The decision announced affects all 19 Forth & Towne stores opened since Gap unveiled the concept in West Nyack, N.Y., and north of New York City in August 2005. Forth & Towne's other stores are located in Atlanta, Chicago, Houston, Seattle, San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Diego, San Jose and Santa Barbara. The store closures are expected to be completed by the end of June, jettisoning about 550 jobs. Some of the affected employees may be transferred to one of the San Francisco-based company's other chains Gap, Old Navy and banana republic. Signaling that some layoffs are likely, Gap is budgeting $7 million to cover severance payments and other benefits for former Forth & Towne workers.

Gap Inc. announced plans to launch a real estate restructuring that will close some stores and relocate, remodel or downsize others. The move aims to better utilize the 40 million square feet of store space Gap leases, part of the company's effort to bolster profits while revamping the company's namesake and Old Navy chains.

Gap Inc. is closing nearly 200 stores and downsizing others in the U.S. as it focuses on international expansion. The company plans to reduce the number of Gap brand stores in North America to 700 by the end of 2013, a 21% decrease from the 889 that it operated at the end of July. This announcement was part of an ongoing company strategy to reduce the combined square footage of Gap's stores across all major brands in North America.The company provided a comprehensive business overview of the company that was heavily focused on overseas growth. Those plans include the opening of an Old Navy store in Japan within 18 months, the brand's first location outside of North America, and nearly tripling the number of Gap brand stores in greater China to about 45 by the end of 2012. The first Gap flagship in Hong Kong is set to open in a few weeks, and the company's first Banana Republic flagship in Paris is scheduled to open in 2011. The company would balance its Gap brand store closings by adding about 50 new Gap Outlet stores in North America.

Gap Inc. announced that the company plans to close all 13 of the bridal shopping platform's locations within its Banana Republic stores across the country by the end of May, including its in Union Square. Gap is guaranteeing orders made before June 11. The company will try to shift Weddington Way employees to positions within its other brands, which include Old Navy, Athleta, Intermix and its namesake label.
The Gap Inc. announced that it will close its massive three-level Gap store on New York's Fifth Avenue on January 20, 2019.

General Electric announced that the company layoff several employees after its acquisition of Honeywell. Business Week magazine reported that the layoffs may reach 75000, but a GE spokesperson said there was no definite target number.

General Electric Co. has told employees of its refrigerator operation in Louisville that it expects to eliminate its second shift and 360 jobs in June or July. Some of the affected workers will transfer to other jobs within GE's Appliance Park in Louisville, and some will take early retirement.

General Electric Co. announced April 15 that it will eliminate 7,000 jobs at GE Capital, its financial services division, in a cost-cutting move. That's slightly more than 2 percent of its work force of 310,000.
General Electric has announced that it will layoff about 90 workers from its switchgear West Burlington plant because of declines in orders.
General Electric will lay off 44 employees at its Shreveport plant by the end of the month due to economic slowdown that has led to a lower demand for their product.
General Electric is cutting up to 185 jobs at its Interlogix plant in North St.Paul that makes security products. GE decided to eliminate 185 of the 460 jobs at the North St. Paul plant.

Sluggish demand for refrigerators resulting from a weak economy is forcing a small layoff process at the Bloomington General Electric Company plant. Up to 29 workers will lose their jobs April 4. The Bloomington facility currently has about 1,850 workers. After the layoff, the total will be about 1,820.

General Electric Co.'s Silicones unit expects to conclude negotiations that will trim its work force within a week to 10 days. The company indicated in September that it wanted to pare its 1,100-worker payroll by about 80 hourly employees in a bid to remain cost-competitive. First, though, the cuts have to be negotiated with Local 359 of the International Union of Electronic Workers-Communications Workers of America.
General Electric Co. announced that it will lay off another 43 workers at its plant in Burlington, following a January layoff that put 85 workers off the job. About 550 workers remain.

General Electric Co.'s aircraft engine overhaul unit at Dallas Love Field is slated to close at the end of the year, eliminating 170 jobs, because carriers need less repair work. The company plans to let go 90 of the workers on April 1. Workers at the GE Engine Services facility can apply at other GE facilities, but there will not be automatic transfers. GE Engine Services plans to keep open its facility located near Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. About 20 employees work at the site located on FAA Boulevard.

General Electric Co. announced that this time the company is eliminating 18 hourly positions. The company expects to eliminate half of those jobs through early retirement and natural attrition. The plant on Industrial Drive on the Orange County side of Mebane opened in 1972. It makes high-tech switching equipment.
General Electric Co. announced that up to 150 workers at steam turbine and generator plant are facing a job loss, while another 75 to 200 may face temporary layoffs.

General Electric Co. announced that it is eliminating nearly 10% of the 1,000 jobs at its silicones plant in Waterford as part of a cost-cutting program. GE acknowledged that it plans to eliminate 95 jobs at the plant through layoffs, attrition, retirements and voluntary job eliminations. Of the 95 jobs, 50 will be union positions.

General Electric Co. will lay off 227 workers at its Nagykanizsa (SW Hungary) unit, with the first group of 193 employees to be dismissed on December 19, 2008. GE will lay off a further 34 workers on January 15.
General Electric Co. announced that it eliminated 20 positions at its Global Research Center in Niskayuna, where it employs more than 1,900 people.

General Electric Co. will cut the workforce at its Mebane plant by 55 jobs. Declining orders from customers forced the cuts. 34 employees will be laid off, with another 21 vacant jobs eliminated. As the economic recession continues, and as customer orders continue to drop, company have no choice but to reduce capacity because company manufacture custom electrical equipment to specific customer applications and orders.

General Electric Co. announced that it will axe 2,700 jobs in Hungary over the next two years after a decision to phase out traditional energy-guzzling light bulbs in Europe. The company said that the cuts, which were announced at meetings with employees and trade unions, would begin at the start of next year. The group is the US investor in Hungary, where it currently employs 14,000 people. A new EU regulation phasing out old-style light bulbs by 2012 came into effect in September. And this would inevitably hit GE's Hungarian operations. The factory in Nagykanizsa, southwest Hungary, would be hardest hit, with 1,300 jobs to go there. But six other sites would also be affected, and pointing out that the factory in Vac, near Budapest would be shut down entirely in 2011. GE would also close one of its five GE Energy plants in Hungary. Last year, GE laid off 500 employees and closed down a lighting factory and cut back output citing fierce global competition.

General Electric Co announced that it is closing its Palmetto manufacturing plant. The GE Digital Energy plant will close on Feb. 25, affecting about 100 employees. An undisclosed number of employees who work on the local plant's smart meter assembly line will be retained. Employees were notified Sept. 16 that the plant will close. The remainder of Digital Energy's operations, which includes making transformers for utility companies and large steel mills, will be moved to GE's six North American transformer repair facilities in an effort to cut costs.

General Electric Company is officially closing its thermal repairs and industrial repairs facility in Houston by January 2014. The company confirmed that after a 60-day bargaining period with unions, GE made the decision to close the facility, located at 8800 Wallisville Road. The facility closure will affect 206 employees.

Six months after announcing plans to move capacitor manufacturing work from upstate NY to Clearwater, Florida, General Electric is now delaying layoffs of up to 200 employees until early 2015. The company will begin layoffs of 177 manufacturing workers and 20 salaried employees at the Fort Edward, NY capacitor plant during the first three months of 2015.

General Electric (GE) has announced plans to shut down a foundry as well as cut more than 250 jobs at its Lufkin oil-field services unit in, Texas, US, amid dropping global oil prices. The decision to close the foundry and 262 axe jobs at the two Angelina County, Texas, sites is driven by the reduction in demand for drilling equipment made by GE's unit Lufkin Industries due to the plunging oil prices.

GE announced that it's planning to cut 100 jobs at its Jacintoport facility in East Houston as part of a broader move to shift some of its U.S.-based manufacturing of gas turbines and power generators to Europe and China.

General Electric confirmed that it will close its locomotive turbocharger manufacturing plant in Latham, New York within the next year. GE Transportation Engine Systems employs 48 people at the suburban Albany plant. Declining demand for remanufactured turbochargers for Electro-Motive Diesel Inc. locomotives led to the decision to shut down the factory near Albany International Airport. The Engine Systems plant is located on a 4.4-acre site just east of the airport. The 50,000-square-foot building also is used to manufacture locomotive heads, liners and pistons. Demand for that work remains strong.

General Electric announced that it will close its manufacturing facility in Rochester in 2018 and the work will be moved to China. The company announced that its plant in the Rochester Science Park will close by June. The workers losing their jobs will receive severance pay and tuition reimbursement.

General Electric (GE) has announced that it is axing 12,000 jobs at its global power business, as part of the industrial conglomerates latest effort to shrink itself into a more focused company. GE has announced that the cuts will save $1 billion in 2018, after admitting it expects dwindling demand for fossil fuel power plants to continue. GEs cuts follow a decision by rival Siemens AG to slash 6,900 jobs in the face of a global shift by electric utilities away from fossil fuels to renewable sources of energy such as wind and solar. GE did not give a breakdown of the job cuts, which represent about 4% of its overall workforce of 295,000, announcing only that they would be primarily outside the United States. The cuts represent about 18% of GEs Power business.
General Electric Company said a French plant that will see layoffs will remain open. The company is looking into alternatives there including building aeronautical parts.

General Mills Inc. said that it will close its frozen bakery goods plant in Eden Prairie within the next year and consolidate that production into other plants. The company in turned said some of the plant's 323 employees probably will be offered transfers to other facilities, making it too early to estimate the exact number of layoffs. However, none of the employees will be laid off before May 1.

General Mills Inc. plans to close a plant in Hazelwood by next fall, a move that would affect more than 400 jobs. The plant supplies frozen bakery goods and fresh-baked items to supermarkets. Pillsbury bought the facility, known as Hazelwood Farms, from Supervalu Inc. in 1999. General Mills also operates plants in Kansas City, Hannibal and Joplin, Mo.
General Mills Inc. will close a flour mill it has operated in Johnson City for 70 years, move the production to other facilities and leave 26 people without jobs.

General Mills Inc. has cut 38 jobs at a Pillsbury plant in Ontario. The company made the difficult decision to restructure its Midland facility. The plant, located on Pillsbury Drive, employed 155 people there two years ago. The company said that the decision aligns its workforce to better reflect business needs and enables the company's Midland facility to stay competitive in the current operating environment.

General Mills announced that it will close its manufacturing facility in Lodi, Calif., near the end of 2015. The company had announced a preliminary decision on September 18, 2014 subject to negotiation with union officials. Those discussions are now complete, and the company has begun a review of the necessary processes and transition steps to consolidate manufacturing at other facilities within the General Mills supply chain. The closure will impact approximately 430 employees. The company said it will provide severance and transition benefits to all affected employees.

General Mills announced plans to close its manufacturing facility in Midland, Ontario. The company expects the transition to be completed by mid-calendar year 2016. The decision will impact approximately 100 employees. General Mills said it will provide severance to all affected employees.

General Mills will indeed close its New Albany plant in mid-2016, after union workers voted for a compensation package that will reward them for staying at least until layoffs begin early 2016. Talks resulted in the union negotiation team signing an agreement that includes a $1-an-hour raise, a $4,000 retention bonus and a $1,000 signing bonus under a new contract. The new agreement also includes language that could allow some workers to more easily transfer to another General Mills location as jobs come open, though Miller said he's only heard from a few who are interested.

General Mills announced that it has completed a plan to eliminate about 800 positions. General Mills said that the previously announced job cuts, which were mostly in the U.S., were part of a restructuring plan called Project Catalyst that was approved during its fiscal second quarter. The company also has a restructuring plan called Project Century. As part of that plan, General Mills is reducing its refrigerated dough capacity and exiting its Canada and New Albany, Indiana, facilities. The plants support its U.S. retail, international and convenience stores and foodservice supply chains. Exiting the Canadian plant will impact about 100 jobs, while exiting the Indiana facility will affect approximately 400 positions. The actions are anticipated to be completed by the end of fiscal 2018. Project Century also includes the closing of a facility in Methuen, Massachusetts, that would eliminate about 250 positions, and exiting its Lodi, California facility, which would impact about 430 positions. All of those job cuts are expected to be completed by fiscal 2016 end.

General Mills, Inc. announced that the company is closing a snack manufacturing facility in Missouri and a snack, cereal and meals plant in suburban Chicago, resulting in the loss of 620 jobs. The company will wrap up operations at its snack manufacturing facility on Junge Boulevard in Joplin, Mo., by the end of 2015. The company has only been operating the location for about a year. The decision will affect 120 workers. The second closure is a plant in West Chicago that has been in operation since 1959. The closure will eliminate 500 jobs. The factory makes cereal, meals and snacks. If all goes according to plan, the plant will shut down by mid-2017, but the decision to close is subject to negotiations with union officials. The closures are a part of 'project century', the plan announced last fall to slim down the North American supply chain. Shortly after Project Century was unveiled, the company it would close two plants in California and Massachusetts. The company will have cut 1,694 manufacturing jobs after this latest round of closures.

General Mills Inc. announced that after several rounds of plant closings and layoffs at home, the company is cutting its international operations as well. The company reported that it closed the frozen dough manufacturing facility in Kaohsiung, Taiwan, that it has operated since 2006. It will offer severance to the plant's 78 laid-off employees. The company has also made what it called a 'preliminary decision' to wind down its South African foodservice business and shutter its manufacturing plant in the Linbro Park suburb of Johannesburg. Before finalizing the decision the company will consult with employees and employee representatives. The move would affect production staff and some salaried employees, but did not say how many.

General Mills announced a preliminary decision to close its manufacturing facility in East Tamaki, New Zealand. The preliminary decision is subject to consultation with union officials and employee representatives. If the decision becomes final, the company would expect the facility to close by the end of this calendar year. The closure, were the decision to become final, would impact 20 employees.

General Mills announced a preliminary decision to close its manufacturing facility in East Tamaki, New Zealand. The preliminary decision is subject to consultation with union officials and employee representatives. If the decision becomes final, the company would expect the facility to close by the end of this calendar year. The closure, were the decision to become final, would impact 20 employees.

General Mills announced it has completed collective consultation on the proposed closure of its manufacturing facility in Berwick, United Kingdom with employee representatives and union officials and has made a decision to close the facility by the autumn of 2016. The company had announced a proposal to close the Berwick facility on October 29, the proposal was subject to consultation with employee representatives and union officials. That consultation process has closed and a decision was made to proceed with the proposal. The company will now begin the necessary phases to close the plant. The closure will impact approximately 265 positions. General Mills said it will provide severance and transition benefits to all affected employees.

General Mills announced that the company plans to expand geographically in future quarters.The company plans to close their food and soup factory in Vineland, New Jersey in order to eliminate excess capacity in their U.S. Retail supply chain. The company expects this action will be completed by the end of fiscal 2019. Additionally, they are eliminating excess capacity and exiting unprofitable businesses in their International segment. In Brazil, they will close one of their snacks manufacturing facilities and will cease production operations on certain snacks and meals products at another facility. They are also restructuring their Snacks business in China and have plans to stop production on certain underperforming products in that market. They expects these actions to be completed by the end of fiscal 2017.

On December 5, 2016, General Mills, Inc. approved restructuring actions designed to better align its organizational structure with its strategic initiatives. In connection with these actions, the company expects to eliminate approximately 400 - 600 positions globally, subject to consultation with employees and employee representatives in locations as required. In the third quarter of fiscal 2017, the company expects to record total pre-tax restructuring charges of approximately $60 million to $90 million, reflecting primarily one-time, cash employee separation expenses. These restructuring actions are expected to be completed by the end of fiscal 2018.

General Mills officially closed Midland manufacturing plant in Canada. The plant which had manufactured refrigerated baked goods was in operation since 1952. In January 2015, General Mills had announced to close it while expecting the closure to be completed by mid 2016 which has been delayed. On the same date, the company had also announced to close its US manufacturing facility in New Albany, Indiana which affected 400 jobs. The two closures were part of General Mills?strategy to save about $100 million annually by the end of fiscal 2017.

General Motors Corp. announced that it will idle three of its North American factories and cut 2450 jobs next week to reduce production due to the slower demand for new cars and trucks. The facilities that will be shut down are located in Oshawa, Ontario
General Motors Corp. announced that it has reduced its workforce by another 600 contract workers in the Detroit area, adding to the 2,200 workers that were already laid off this year.
General Motors Corp. announced that it will be laying off 1,600 employees, representing 2.1 percent of its work force, as part of a restructuring program.
General Motors Corp. said it would cut up to 2,850 jobs by eliminating a shift at two plants in Michigan and New Jersey, citing low market demand for its automobiles.

General Motors Corp. ended production of Vauxhall cars at its factory in Luton, where 1,900 jobs have become casualties of restructuring in the auto industry and the strength of the British currency. After the final car, a silver V6 Vectra model, rolled off the production line, the last few hundred workers were sent home, many of them furious at losing long-term jobs. About 30,000 GM workers across Europe staged brief walkouts on Jan. 25, 2001 to denounce the plan.

In the midst of slumping sales, the Brazilian subsidiary of General Motors Corp. plans to cut 300 jobs, union leaders said. The jobs are among 8,500 workers employed at the automaker's plant in Sao Jose dos Campos, 50 miles northeast of Sao Paulo.

Operations at General Motors Corp.'s hot-weather testing center here will be phased out during the next 3 1/2 years and will stop completely in 2005. The auto giant originally planned to close the Desert Proving Ground by the end of this year but set the date back to late 2005 because of delays in getting a replacement center established in Mexico. About 370 people are working in Mesa, down from more than 1,000.
General Motors Corp.'s Saab unit announces plans to cut about 17% of its jobs, or 1,300 positions out of roughly 7,500.

General Motors Corp. will lay off some workers at a Saturn plant following a four-week shutdown that starts in May, company officials said. About 1,400 of the 2,100 workers at the Newport assembly plant will be temporarily laid off between May 12 and June 6. Some of those hourly workers will not return after June 6 because the plant is going to scale back production. GM officials declined to say how many workers would be affected by the longer-term layoffs.

Up to 1,400 hourly workers and 150 salaried employees could be affected when one of four production shifts is eliminated at General Motors Corp.'s assembly plant._x000D_
_x000D_
GM plans to open a new assembly plant in Eaton County's Delta Township in 2006 that is to employ between 2,500 and 2,700 workers, according to tax documents filed with the state.

General Motors, said it planned further job cuts in Europe as part of a radical overhaul of its business on the continent. GM vice chairman of product development, Bob Lutz, announced. He declined to say how many of GM's 60,000 jobs in Europe would be slashed, but company sources said the cuts would primarily affect administrative services. About half of its employees -some 32,000 - work for the German unit Opel. GM Europe, headquartered in Zurich, Switzerland but which largely comprises Opel, has been in the red since 1999.

General Motors will discontinue its ageing Chevy Astro and GMC Safari vans in 2005. As a consequence, the company's Baltimore, Md., assembly plant, which exclusively builds the Astro and Safari, will also close in 2005.

General Motors Corp. plans to slash 9,500 jobs at its German division as part of a drive to end a four-year stretch of losses in Europe. The U.S.-based auto giant's management in Detroit has approved a program to encourage workers to leave voluntarily by offering them buyouts or jobs in special new companies that will offer retraining and job placement help. The source attended a staff meeting at Adam Opel AG, GM's German arm, where latest details of the cost-cutting measures were announced. In October it plans to slash up to 12,000 jobs in the next two years in Europe, mostly in Germany, to cut excess capacity and return to profitability. The company expects the measures to save at least $665 million a year.

General Motors Corporation announced that it will lay off about 90 workers at its Powertrain plant. The layoffs will begin April 25, 2005. The company has not decided how long the layoffs will last. The cuts will affect every section of the plant.

General Motors Corporation's Argentine subsidiary announced that it was terminating the employment of 300 workers at its plant in General Alvear, Santa Fe. The company announced that it was reducing its workforce at the plant due to weak exports to Mexico, Brazil and Chile.

General Motors Corporation will closes its van factory near the city's industrial port. With only 1,100 workers remaining from a peak of nearly 7,000, closing the Baltimore factory is a small step toward fixing the vast company.

General Motors Corporation plans to eliminate 25,000 manufacturing jobs in the United States by 2008 and close plants as part of a strategy to revive North American business at the world's largest automaker.

General Motors Corporation's Doraville Plant expects an unspecified number of layoffs due to an assembly line slowdown beginning next month on four models of minivans. In addition to layoffs, reduction in staff will also be achieved by attrition, including retirements.

General Motors Corporation announced that it's Brazilian unit plans to cut 600 jobs at one of its local units. GM is cutting the jobs because of a decline in export revenue after the Brazilian real strengthened against the U.S. dollar. GM plans to reduce production at its unit in Sao Jose dos Campos city in Sao Paulo state.

General Motors could announce which plants are on the chopping block as early as next week as it details previously-announced plans to shave 25,000 hourly jobs by 2008. The Detroit News reports that the embattled auto manufacturer could detail up to four assembly plants that would be closed as well as well as shutting some stamping operations and eliminating shifts at other plants across the country. GM announced broad plans in June to trim 25,000 out of 111,000 union-represented jobs at its U.S. plants, although its contract with the United Auto Workers union includes pay guarantees that essentially stops it from cutting jobs until the current labor pact expires in September 2007.

General Motors Corp. announced that it will eliminate 30,000 jobs and close all or part of 12 facilities as the automaker confronts the biggest threat to its survival since the onslaught of Japanese rivals led to a vast overhaul in the early 1990s. As part of the latest overhaul, GM will reduce its annual North American manufacturing capacity to 4.2 million vehicles by 2008, down from 6 million vehicles in 2002, a 30% reduction. The announcement adds 5,000 job cuts to the 25,000 the company promised in June, lowering GM's workforce to about 100,000 by the time the reductions are completed in 2008.

General Motors Corp. is laying off about 500 contract employees, many of them engineers and designers at its Warren technical center. The layoffs planned are part of GM's effort to cut costs in its money-losing North American operations. The cuts are part of a previously announced plan to reduce GM's U.S. white collar work force by 7% in 2006. In November, GM announced plans to cut 30,000 hourly jobs and close 12 facilities by 2008 in an effort to restore profitability.
General Motors Corporation will close nine assembly plants and eliminate 30,000 manufacturing jobs by 2008 while getting about $1 billion in annual savings from union health care concessions.

General Motors Corporation has been prompted by lacklustre sales of the new Pontiac G6 sedan to cut production of the car beginning in April. The company announced that the Orion township, Michigan plant where the car is built will reduce Pontiac G6 output by more than 10% and lay off an unspecified number of workers.

General Motors Corporation announced it will cut the third shift at its Lordstown, Ohio, plant due to lower-than-expected sales of its Chevrolet Cobalt small car. The production line will be cut from 1,300 a day to 1,000 in an effort to bring capacity in line with sustainable market demand. The workers affected by the lay-offs will join those already in GM's 'Jobs Bank'. Closing a shift at Lordstown was not part of GM's turnaround plan and is a result of the lack of market penetration the Cobalt has achieved. Launched just a year ago, the Cobalt was intended to compete with Asian rivals, but has failed to attract consumers in sufficient numbers.

General Motors Corporation has decided to cut around 900 jobs at its U.K. plant in Ellesmere Port. Labor representatives failed to change the management's plan. The job cuts affect production of Opel GmbH's (AO.YY) Astra model, which is being produced at the Ellesmere Port, Antwerp and Bochum plants.

General Motors Corporation announced that it will cut production at its Fairfax Assembly Plant starting May 7 and lay off an undetermined number of workers. The reduction probably will include 200 to 300 layoffs and that the union won't know exactly how many workers will lose their jobs until mid-April. The plant will continue to run two shifts a day but will reduce output on each shift. The plant will shut down for a week starting April 30 in preparation for the reduced output.

General Motors Corporation plans to close up to 13 factories -- four more than it has previously announced -- over the next four years if United Auto Workers members approve a new contract. The plants employ around 2,500 workers, though many would be eligible to retire with full benefits and GM would offer more buyouts. The factories include an engine plant in Livonia, near Detroit, as well as another in Parma, Ohio and metal stamping plants in Indianapolis and Flint, Michigan.
General Motors Corporation is planning to restructure its European sites, a programme that will entail the cutting of 256 jobs at its French plant in Strasbourg in the second half of 2008.
General Motors Corporation announced plans to close its plant in Moraine, affecting about 2,500 workers.

General Motors Corporation is considering further job cuts among white-collar staff and the future of at least two of its brands. Separately, GM is also considering whether to bring the Chevrolet Beat concept model to the U.S. market when it becomes a production reality, in response to demand for smaller fuel-efficient models. The further job cuts are likely to be approved when GM's board of directors meets in early August.

General Motors Corporation announced that the Shreveport plant once employed more than 2,000 people. It will have fewer than 800 after, when the plant's entire second shift will be cut, affecting 798 employees, including 715 hourly and 83 salaried. The cut is part of GM's corporate plan to shift from trucks and sport utility vehicles to fuel-efficient cars in the wake of high gas prices. The plant's production lineup includes the Chevy Colorado, GMC Canyon, Hummer H3 and H3T.
General Motors Corporation will close a metal stamping plant in Wyoming, Mich., by the end of 2009. The closure will affect 1,340 hourly jobs.

General Motors Corporation announced that it plans to lay off another 1,900 factory workers at parts stamping, engine and transmission factories in North America as it cuts expenses to deal with a worsening cash crisis. The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that the layoffs are a result of declining sales. The 1,900 additional layoffs will come in the first quarter of next year. M also filed a notice with the state of Michigan saying it would lay off 650 factory workers and another 52 salaried employees at its Orion Township, Mich., assembly plant starting Jan. 23.

The United Auto Workers union announced that it is willing to renegotiate parts of its national contract with General Motors Corporation as it works to build support for a federal bailout package for the carmaker. The union also said it is willing to delay corporate payments into a retiree health care trust fund and modify the JOBS bank for laid-off workers to help GM cut costs. The moves came during an emergency meeting in Detroit called by UAW leaders. If adopted, the changes are expected to bolster GM's bottom line and help convince Congress to make billions of dollars in loans available as part of a bailout package for GM, Ford Motor Co. and Cerberus Capital Management LP's Chrysler LLC.The company announced that the company 's turnaround plan, submitted to Congress, the company announced it would close up to nine plants and eliminate up to 30,000 jobs.

General Motors Corporation slashed production plans to begin 2009, extending an already long layoff for Fairfax plant workers. GM announced most of its plants will be closed for all of January, cutting one-third of its first-quarter production schedule as it adjusts to the slowest automotive market in 26 years. Already slated to be closed for the first three weeks of the year, the GM Fairfax plant in Kansas City, Kan., also will be down the weeks of Jan. 26 and Feb. 2.

General Motors Corp. has laid off about 100 workers at its Parma parts plant located near Cleveland. The company says hundreds of other workers will face temporary furloughs in January. About half of the Parma Metals Center will remain shut down for another three weeks after the company's traditional two-week holiday shutdown period ends Jan. 5. About 600 people will be affected at any given time.

General Motors Company has closed its Willow Run manufacturing plant in Michigan. The automaker acquired the facility from Ford Motor Company in the 1950's and started producing cars and transmissions at the facility.
General Motors Company shutdown, which the company blamed on a shortage of parts from Japan following an earthquake and tsunami, affected about 800 workers.

General Motors Company has announced that it will close its Detroit-Hamtramck assembly plant, for four weeks beginning in June, for planned upgrades to prepare for a significant increase in the rate of Volt production, along with assembly of the 2013 Chevrolet Malibu midsize sedan. Already in tight supply, the number of Volts available for delivery to retail customers will be further restricted over the next three months before production resumes and the Volt and the Opel Ampera begin being exported to Europe and China. The 2011 Volt was launched in California, New York, Connecticut, Maryland, Michigan, New Jersey, New York, Texas, Virginia and Washington, D.C. The Volt will be available nationwide and in Europe, China and Canada by the end of this year. As a result of the plant upgrades, planned Volt and Ampera production capacity this year will increase to 16,000 units, including exports and a fleet of several hundred demonstration units sent to US dealers. In 2012, global production capacity is expected to be 60,000 vehicles with an estimated 45,000 to be delivered in the US. During the four-week shutdown the plant will complete some pre-scheduled upgrades, including the installation of new tools, equipment and overhead conveyor systems throughout the facility. This will prepare the plant for 2012 Volt and Ampera production and continue work on projects in preparation to launch the 2013 Malibu next year.
General Motors Company has cut about 4% of its hourly and salaried jobs in Brazil during the current quarter and more cuts will be made.

General Motors Company will eliminate 190 jobs at research facilities in India and the United States. Most of the positions affected are staff scientists, and workers will have the opportunity to apply for other jobs at GM. GM will eliminate roughly 100 jobs at its technical center in Warren, Michigan, and 90 positions in Bangalore, India.

General Motors Company announced it will close its fuel cell development office in Honeoye Falls, N.Y., and move operations to it global power train engineering headquarters in Pontiac by early 2013. GM said it notified about 220 affected salaried employees in Honeoye Falls on October 5. The majority of employees, who include engineers and technical experts, will have the option to relocate to Pontiac. GM will offer a severance package to those employees who choose not to transfer. The handful of employees not offered a move will have the chance to apply for other employment openings at GM. The Detroit automaker's lease expires in Honeoye Falls in early 2013 and fuel cell work will relocate into existing space in Pontiac.

General Motors Company announced that it has cut 2,300 jobs in Europe this year and wants to trim 300 more, part of a larger plan to reduce costs and raise revenue in the struggling region with new vehicles that are more appealing to buyers.
General Motors has announced that it will close a tooling systems plant in Grand Blanc by the end of June 2013.

General Motors Company announced it dismissed 598 workers at a struggling assembly line at his Brazilian unit on March 26, 2013 in line with an agreement reached with the union last January. The union said more workers could be fired, as GM had planned 1,600 job cuts.

General Motors Company announced that it is to close its specialist Performance Build engine plant in Wixom, Michigan, US. The plant, where owners were given the opportunity of involvement in the hand building of engines for certain GM performance models, is to close in January 2014. It has been operational since 2004, and a reduction in the range of engines that the company has to offer is believed to have precipitated the decision.

Holden announced that it needed long-term government support to remain in Australia, following a report that its parent General Motors had decided to close the unit's two plants in the country. However, while there remains uncertainty about the future of the firm's manufacturing in Australia. GM intended to shut down its two Australian factories, while also slashing output in South Korea, as part of a plan to weed out its unprofitable operations.

General Motors Corporation is laying off more than 1,000 employees from a factory in Sao Jose dos Campos, in Sao Paulo state. This move follows General Motors' decision last month to close its Australian manufacturing operation by 2017, at the cost of 2,900 jobs.
General Motors Co. will lay off up to 1,100 workers in South Korea due to rising costs.

General Motors has implemented the third unscheduled shutdown in 2014 at its plant in Russia. The company is also planning a fourth shutdown due to a car sales slump in the country that has been exacerbated by sanctions imposed on Russia by the international community due to its occupation of part of Ukraine. In the latest shutdown, production ceased on September 29, 2014 and is due to restart on October 3, 2014. The next shutdown is due to take place between October 10, 2014 and October 27, 2014.

General Motors Co. confirmed on December 8, 2014 it will lay off close to 450 hourly workers - about 100 more than originally announced - at its Lansing Grand River Assembly Plant as it moves to one shift early next year. The company said last month it would lay off 350 workers at the plant that builds the Cadillac ATS, ATS Coupe and CTS because of lagging sales of the cars. The company also said it would cut one of two shifts, and about 350 workers on the second shift would supplement the first shift. The Lansing Grand River plant will begin a shutdown on Dec.  15 that's expected to last until sometime in January.

General Motors Corporation is facing a labor strike at its Brazilian plant Sao Jose dos Campos, near Sao Paulo. The employees are staging a strike due to the automaker's decision to dismiss some of its workers and send others on unpaid leave. The company has requested help from a labor judge on this matter.The company is planning to lay off around 800 workers for a period of two months, only to finally dismiss them in April.

GM has confirmed it will cut 1,000 jobs at its Oshawa, Ont., assembly plant, even as it announces $5.4 billion in investment in its American operations. The end of production for the Chevrolet Camaro at the Oshawa Assembly plant will be Nov. 20, 2015. The plant is still waiting for the company to announce a model to be made after 2016.

General Motors announced that it will halt the third shift at two vehicle factories in Ohio and Michigan because of reduced demand for cars. The company will permanently idle shifts at Lordstown, Ohio, near Cleveland and in Lansing, Mich., in a move that will lay off 2,000 workers. The Lordstown plant makes the Chevrolet Cruze compact car, while the Lansing Grand River factory makes the Chevrolet Camaro muscle car and the Cadillac ATS and CTS luxury cars. The company also announced it would invest more than $900 million at a Toledo, Ohio, transmission plant, the Lansing Grand River factory and a casting plant in Bedford, Ind., to prepare for future new vehicles.

General Motors Co will cut 625 jobs. The job cut will be at the company's auto assembly plant in Ingersoll, Ontario, by the end of July. The company will cut the jobs as it moves some production work to Mexico.

General Motors is planning to lay off 3,000 or more salaried workers in the United States. Layoffs are reportedly likely at GM plants across North America after the deadline passed for workers to take company proposed buyouts.

GM said it plans to eliminate 15% of its salaried workforce in North America and stop production at five plants that employ 6,700 workers, including one in storied Lordstown, Ohio.The company plans to redeploy some $4.5 billion in annual savings to more profitable truck, electric-car and autonomous-vehicle manufacturing.

General Motors announced that it is fighting to retain a valuable tax credit for electric vehicles as the nation's large automaker tries to deal with the political fallout triggered by its plans to shutter several U.S. factories and shed thousands of workers. Preserving the $7,500 tax incentive for buyers is crucial for GM as the company pivots from internal combustion engines in favour of building cars powered by batteries or hydrogen fuel cells. Yet the layoffs and plant closings could imperil GM's push to keep the incentive. It helps make plug-ins such as the $36,000 Chevy Bolt more affordable at a time when competition from other electric vehicle makers is heating up. GM faces opposition from U.S. President Donald Trump and other Republicans who consider the credit a waste of taxpayer money and want it eliminated. Trump, who has pledged a manufacturing rebirth in the Midwest, reacted angrily to GM's 'transformation' announcement late last month, declaring that his administration was 'looking at cutting all GM subsidies, including for electric cars'.

General Motors Co.'s salaried job cuts will include the elimination of 1,298 jobs at the Warren Technical Center. It appears the layoffs in Warren will continue until Feb. 28, which the company announced last day employees will appear in the company's payroll system. The automaker's Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification is dated Feb. 4, 2019. GM declined to comment on the specifics of the cuts to its roughly 20,000-person workforce in Warren.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. said it has laid off 2,000 workers, or 1.4 percent of its work force, saying the cuts were needed to balance its employment levels with ongoing contracts. EDS, which has 140,000 employees worldwide, said most of the cuts were in North America. It said it periodically hires or fires workers to match them with available work.
According to unnamed sources, Electronic Data Systems may lay off an unspecified number of employees.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. would cut more jobs. EDS would shift more of its services staff overseas to countries such as India, with a goal of having 20,000 employees in so-called low cost countries by the end of 2004.
Electronic Data Systems Corp. announced it will cut 5,200 jobs nearly 4 percent of its work force by the end of 2004.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. has axed a number of jobs as part of a restructure, following the arrival of marketing and comms chief Malcolm George from Burson-Marseller. Redundancies are said to include UK regional director of EDS global marketing and communications Catherine Greenwood and UK-based PROs Kerry Denman and Catherine Sanders. The company currently uses Trimedia to operate an outsourced UK press office. 

EDS, whose projects include leading the group that operates London Underground's Oyster Card, was stripped of its 3 billion government contract to run the Inland Revenue's IT network.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. could cut 15,000 to 20,000 jobs - up to one-sixth of its work force - over about two years to help reduce costs by about $3 billion. The company has made most of the 5,200 job cuts it announced last year and has about 120,000 employees remaining including 55,000 in the United States.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. plans to lay off 110 of its 750 workers in Lansing by September after the systems-management company lost a portion of a client's help desk business. Workers will get a severance package equal to two to 20 weeks of base pay, and a sum equal to a month's worth of medical and dental benefits. The layoffs will happen in phases beginning in July at the company's call center in Lansing.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. is laying off about 50 mostly clerical workers at its facility at 725 Regional Road. Layoffs will happen Dec. 15. Some workers may be transferred to other locations. The employees were given 60 days' notice. A company spokesman was not available for comment about the reason for the layoffs.
EDS Corp. announced which employs 9,500 people in Michigan, will likely cut some jobs in the state as the company downsizes.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. plans to cut 220 jobs in Lansing as it closes a call center. The layoffs will take place in stages. The first cuts will come in April, and all 220 jobs will be gone by Aug. 1. The company said the affected workers might be able to find work within the company. Workers will receive severance packages equal to two to 20 weeks of base pay, depending on how long they have been with the company, the Lansing State Journal reported. Job counseling also will be available.

Electronic Data Systems Corp. announced that it plans to cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs in the second half of 2006. The cuts, intended to make the company more efficient, fall within the range of 2004 forecast for layoffs of 15,000 to 20,000. But the company had not anticipated the new cuts earlier this year. As of April, EDS had about 117,000 employees worldwide, including 7,100 in the Dallas area.
Electronic Data Systems Corp. announced that it's laying off 147 people at its Federal Way location effective August 24, 2007.

EDS is cutting 261 local jobs after a client transitioned contractual work back in-house. The affected employees at the Hoover operation were notified in October and the layoffs will be complete in April.
A unit of Hewlett-Packard Co. will lay off 76 employees in Rancho Cordova in early December. The layoffs will take place at HP Enterprise Services, LLC.
Genesco Inc. planned to open around 30 new stores, mostly Journeys and Journeys Kidz and to close around 40 stores.

Georgia-Pacific Corp. said 170 employees will be affected by its decision to close a particleboard production facility in Oxford, Miss. The paper company said customers that had previously been supplied by the Oxford plant will be serviced by other facilities. These decisions are always difficult to make, said Elliott Savage, president of GP's industrial wood products business.
Georgia-Pacific announced that it plans to discontinue panelboard production at Monticello, Atlanta, eliminating about 400 jobs.

Georgia-Pacific Corp. announced tht it is temporarily reducing tissue production at its Old Town mill because of a nationwide decline in retail sales. Five people may be laid off. Old Town temporarily will produce tissue five days a week instead of seven.

Downsizing continues at Georgia-Pacific's Dubuque plant. The hourly employees received pink slips, a decision effective immediately. The job cuts follow two separate rounds of layoffs earlier this year, displacing 93 employees. Since January, the Dubuque plant has trimmed its payroll by nearly 45%, shedding 115 of 265 jobs. The plant's hourly work force has been cut in half in the past two years. The company announced that the plant is shutting down a piece of converting equipment and a related furnishing machine in the plant's graphics department. The Georgia-Pacific Corp. announcement follows job cuts at Flexsteel Industries' Dubuque plant. The furniture maker confirmed it will layoff nearly 50 hourly employees, also represented by the United Steelworkers.

A small number of employees are expected to be laid off next month at the Georgia-Pacific LLC, mill when two tissue converting lines temporarily are shut down. About 15 employees are expected to be affected by the Oct. 1 change, but some will be transferred to the napkin line, which will be increased to full capacity next month. The mill's human resources department is looking at other areas within the mill where employees can be moved. G-P employs about 450 people.

Georgia-Pacific LLC's decision to shut down its Old Town tissue mill and lay off 400 workers could affect more than 1,000 additional jobs in the area. James McConnon, University of Maine Cooperative Extension business and economics specialist. That ripple effect already is being felt throughout the community and surrounding towns, and it isn't likely to disappear anytime soon. The effects on 1,000 other jobs stem from what economists call an employment multiplier -- a figure used to determine how closely various sectors of the economy are linked.

Georgia-Pacific LLC announced that it plans to cut 300 jobs at its Camas, Wash., plant and shut down production of tissue and some paper-towel products over the next year as it tries to make the aging mill more competitive. The shutdowns will begin shortly after the first of the year. The company also plans to close a pulp line at the site by the middle of next year. It will continue to operate production lines for premium paper-towel products and photocopying paper, which employ about 500.

Georgia-Pacific LLC is shutting down production at its plywood mill in Fordyce, Ark., as the new construction market remains slow. The company is laying off 300 people at the plant but will keep a small crew there to keep the plant functional. The shutdown is based on economic conditions, with continued slowness in the commercial and residential construction market.

Georgia-Pacific LLC plans for closing its box plant, which will result in loss of 45 jobs at the eastern Iowa city of Monticello. The workers were informed that the plant will fill orders over the next few weeks, and then would be shut down. The company has been in efforts since long for making the plant profitable. Shifting of the production will be done to units in Dubuque and in Oshkosh, Wis. State agencies will be requested by Monticello, for assisting the affected workers in getting a new job.
Georgia-Pacific announced that it will shutter in April its corrugated packaging facility in Doraville, Ga., cutting about 90 jobs.

Gerber Scientific Inc. has laid off 61 workers at its South Windsor headquarters and three manufacturing plants in Connecticut. Top company executives also accepted a 25 percent pay cut to help control costs. Overall, the maker of automated manufacturing equipment used in optical, apparel, sign making, graphics, apparel and materials processing industries laid off 100 workers. The company also operates plants in Massachusetts, Oklahoma and Texas.
Gerber Scientific plans to cut about 150 jobs due to a decline in sales.
Gillette Co. announced that it plans to close more factories and layoff an undisclosed number of employees.

Goodrich Corporation announced that it is going to cut 2,400 jobs (more than 10 percent of its workforce) and close 16 facilities in an attempt to counter the effect of a crisis in the airline industry. The cuts are occuring despite the fact Goodrich pos

Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co?s UK division plans to eliminate 455 jobs at its Wolverhampton plant in England?s West Midlands, citing overcapacity, adverse market conditions in Britain and the continent, high costs, and low productivity.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced plans to phase out hose production at its Lincoln plant over the next two years to save money - a move that could affect up to 480 jobs. Plant manager Todd Turner told union officials of the plan morning, followed by an announcement to the plant's 1,415 employees. They listened intently and were very concerned, he said.
Goodyear has announced that it may layoff an unspecified number of employees from its main UK factory, following weak demand in European markets.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it will end conveyor belt production at a Canadian plant. The phaseout of production will begin immediately, affecting 160 workers. Goodyear did not say how many would remain with the company. The plant will continue to mix rubber compounds for products produced at Goodyear's North American plants.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. laid off 350 white-collar workers at its Akron headquarters in a sweeping cost-cutting move. Some of the highly trained, older workers have landed on their feet, but not all. And the tire maker expects more cuts in 2004, although it is uncertain if Akron will be affected.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it would close its warehouse and distribution center at Lincoln Air Park between July and the close of this year, ending 160 jobs. Some of the workers - perhaps as few as 10 - may qualify for jobs at Goodyear's belt and hose manufacturing plant in Lincoln, but the others will lose their jobs. The company plans to open a new warehouse farther east. It declined to say where because final negotiations for the site are under way.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that another 250 jobs would be cut in Union City, Tenn., effective Nov. 1, 2004, amid continuing financial trouble by the auto industry nationwide. The 10% cutback at Union City will lower the work force to about 2,300, down from 3,800 just two years ago.
