Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. will lay off 330 hourly employees and reduce wire production at its Asheboro plant because of ongoing labor disputes with unionized workers at other facilities. The temporary layoffs, the first since the Asheboro plant opened in 1983, will begin Friday and could last until striking workers at 16 unionized plants in the U.S. and Canada return to work. More than 12,000 union members walked off the job Oct. 5. The United Steelworkers union and Goodyear had tried unsuccessfully since July to reach a labor deal. A prolonged strike also could affect 40 management employees at the Asheboro plant, which supplies wire to Goodyear tire-producing facilities.
Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. will close its plant in Collingwood, Ont., leaving 165 people without jobs. 138 hourly employees and 27 salaried staff will be affected.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it plans to exit 92 underperforming locations by the end of the year. The action will result in after-tax charges of approximately $30 million, of which $15 million will be recorded in the third quarter of 2008. In addition to the strategic benefits associated with it, the action is expected to eliminate losses related to these locations of approximately $9 million annually.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it has axed 34.5 full-time jobs as part of a plan to close a $13.9 million shortfall in its 2009-10 budget. With the cuts, 27 people lost their jobs, about 5% of Goodyear's workforce.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced a plan that would discontinue consumer tire production at a plant in Amiens, France, as part of its strategy to reduce high-cost manufacturing capacity globally. The action, which is expected to be complete by the third quarter of 2010, would result in a reduction of approximately 820 of the 1,200 total positions at the plant, which also produces farm tires. Production at a second tire plant in Amiens, employing about 1,000 people, would not be impacted by this action. The company currently employs approximately 3,500 people in France. The discontinuation of consumer tire production at the Amiens plant would result in the reduction of approximately 6 million units of production, which is part of Goodyear's strategy to remove 15 million to 25 million units of capacity over the next two years.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. and the Steelworkers union have agreed on a deal for buyouts to cut 120 technical center jobs in the company's Ohio hometown. The deal approved in a rank-and-file vote June 9 would protect another 256 tech center jobs in Akron through 2012. The deal offers buyout takers $2,000 for every year of service with a maximum of $40,000. About 130 workers eligible for buyouts have reached retirement age. If fewer than 120 sign up for the buyout, the company can reduce its staff through layoffs.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. announced that it will cut back on production at a Tennessee tire plant due to weak industry demand in a move that will cost 550 workers their jobs. The company said it will move to a five-day, three-shift operation from a continuous operating schedule on July 6. The company said also that it will record a $60 million charge in the second quarter relating to the reduction. Goodyear's Union City, Tenn. plant, which can produce about 12 million tires a year, currently employees about 2,300 workers.

Goodyear said its Union City, Tenn., tire plant-on the endangered list since September 2009 and the employer of 1,900-will close by the end of 2011. The shutdown is part of the company's plan to trim high-cost production capacity globally and improve its competitiveness. The factory produces passenger and light truck tires for the replacement and original equipment markets. Some salaried personnel might be offered positions at other Goodyear sites and production workers are eligible for preferential hiring if any of the firm's other plants need employees. The Union City unit was the only one of seven U.S. union-organized facilities not protected from closing when the United Steelworkers signed a four-year labor agreement with Goodyear. The tire manufacturer then put a three-year plan into place that included two phases of buyouts, with the third phase being possible closure of the plant. The company also moved tire-building equipment from Union City to its non-union factory in Lawton, Okla., during the last year. The closure announcement came despite an offer of $2 million from the state of Tennessee to help cover capital improvements at the factory to keep it operating.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. reported consolidated unaudited earnings results for the first quarter of 2011. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $103 million or $0.42 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $5,402 million compared to net loss of $47 million or $0.19 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $4,270 million a year ago. Income before income taxes were $186 million compared to $29 million a year ago. Tire unit volumes totaled 46.8 million, up almost 7% from 2010. First quarter sales reflect a $219 million increase in volume. Sales also benefited from strong price/mix improvements, which drove revenue per tire up 15% over the 2010 quarter, excluding the impact of foreign currency translation. The 2011 first quarter included total charges of $18 million (7 cents per share) due to rationalizations and accelerated depreciation and $6 million (2 cents per share) related to discrete tax charges. Net debt increased by $329 million.For 2011, the company now expects that its unit volumes will increase at the higher end of the previously announced range of 3% to 5%.For the year 2011, the company said its effective tax rate still expected to be about 25% of its foreign segment operating income. The company expects raw materials to increase 25% to 30% year-over-year, reflecting the recent moderation in natural rubber offset by higher costs in other key commodities. In 2011, the company expects to incur about $30 million to $40 million of additional costs in Asia Pacific versus 2010 as it starts up its new plant and wind down operations in its existing factory in China. For modeling purposes, the company now expects 2011 interest expense to be about $325 million to $350 million, which includes the benefits of the announced debt redemption. The company expects capital expenditures to be between $1.1 billion and $1.2 billion.Finally, the company remains on-track with plans for the shutdown of its Union City, Tennessee facility by year-end.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company announced that it has ceased production at its tire manufacturing facility in Union City, Tennessee. On February 10, 2011, the company had announced its intention to close the plant by the end of 2011. The company announced that the product transfers to the other Goodyear plants have been completed more quickly than expected. The company, now able to meet the needs of its consumer tire customers without further production in Union City.

More than 50 employees at Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. plant in Danville, will be laid off. The layoffs are part of those happening throughout the company. The 55 workers being laid off in Danville plant, just north of the Rockingham County line, are hourly employees.

Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. is laying off 41 workers at its plant in Danville. The layoffs are effective Feb. 4. The layoffs will reduce the plant's workforce to 2,150 employees. The plant makes medium radial commercial truck tires and airplane tires.

Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. Inc. confirmed the closings of three Food Basics stores in Detroit and one each in Harper Woods, Highland Park, Lincoln Park, Melvindale, Sterling Heights and Wayne. Montvale, N.J.-based A&P also announced that it would close three Food Basics stores in the Toledo, Ohio area and two Farmer Jack stores in Southfield and Waterford. One Food Basics store in Dearborn Heights will remain open. Approximately 60 employees at each Food Basics store and a total of 125 employees at the two Farmer Jack stores will lose their jobs when the stores close in late July. The closings will leave A&P with 86 Farmer Jack stores in Michigan and Ohio. The chain, which owns 650 grocery stores in North America, would not comment on whether it was trying to sell any of the stores slated for closing.

The A&P supermarket chain plans to close its Edison warehouse next month, cutting 230 union jobs. The Record has obtained a copy of a letter that a senior A&P executive wrote to the New Jersey Department of Labor outlining plans to permanently close the facility.
The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co. Inc. will close both of the local distribution centers servicing its 66 Detroit-area Farmer Jack stores by June 15, 2007.

A&P announced 25 separate store closings late last year. United Food and Commercial Workers Local 1262, Clifton, N.J., confirmed that Pathmark stores located in Gillette, Hillsboro, Livingston, Middletown, North Hackensack, South Plainfield and Whippany, N.J., would close. UFCW Local 1500 in New York conformed closures of Pathmark stores in Commack, Brooklyn and Hartsdale, N.Y. Additional stores set to close include Waldbaums locations in Greenburgh, Port Chester and Carmel, N.Y.; and A&P banner stores in Flanders, N.J., Barnegat, N.J., Manville, N.J., and New Rochelle, N.Y.
A&P has informed workers that it intends to close three Pathmark stores in Southern New Jersey. Pathmark stores in Edgewater Park, Camden and Cherry Hill will close on or around September 6, 2013.
Great Lakes Chemical Corp. has announced that it will close its Nitro plant in July 2002 and thereby lay off 52 workers to cut costs.

Great Lakes Chemical Corp. said it will cut about 400 jobs and consolidate operations, mainly at a unit that makes additives for plastics. Great Lakes said the layoffs are equivalent to about 9 percent of its staff. It added that the layoffs and facility consolidations target businesses facing the greatest economic challenge and are expected to reap $30 million in savings over the next 12 months.

Halliburton Company management began layoffs for 130 employees at the Duncan Manufacturing Center. The layoff process was expected to continue and an exclusive release from Halliburton to The Banner Sunday confirmed the downsizing. Duncan Halliburton employs 2,600 people, with about 1,200 of those in manufacturing. All positions affected were manufacturing and support. The layoffs were not considered a total surprise as management met with the employees in December 2012 and the rumors have been circulating since then.

Halliburton Co. announced that it will cut about 1,000 jobs in the Eastern Hemisphere, effective immediately. The cuts are unrelated to the company's pending $35 million acquisition of Hughes Inc. and so far no cuts have occurred or are currently planned due to the proposed transaction.
Halliburton announced that it expects to cut potentially more than 6,000 jobs across the globe because of a "challenging market environment" resulting from low oil prices.

Halliburton announced it will eliminate at least 5,000 jobs in response to falling oil prices. The Houston company announced it will lay off 6.5% to 8% of its staff, which represents 5,005 to 6,160 employees based on its total from the end of 2014. The company announced the cuts will come from all areas of its operations and that the moves are necessary because of the difficult market.

Halliburton Co. job cuts could amount to roughly 20,000 worldwide once finalized, and many will be in Houston. Halliburton has terminated almost 16,000 positions globally, or approximately 19% of its workforce, since its peak in 2014. The company has announced to its employees that it will make further workforce reductions, primarily in North America. The cuts now supersede the 16% global workforce reduction that Halliburton said it had implemented in its second-quarter earnings report.

Halliburton Co. announced that it will cut even more jobs companywide as 2016 looks worse than expected for the industry. The company will cut another 5,000 employees worldwide, or about 8% of its total workforce. The company declined to specify where exactly the cuts would be occurring.

Halliburton Co. has cut another 5,000 jobs in the second quarter as it positioned itself for a recovery in North America in the second half of the year. The company cut nearly 9% from its global headcount in the second quarter, leaving staff at 50,000.
Halliburton announced that it is laying off more than 800 employees in El Reno, Oklahoma, and says it expects to close its office in the Oklahoma City suburb.

Handleman Co. is abandoning its North American music distribution business in a move that will eliminate 260 jobs mainly in Michigan and Indiana. The company has agreed to sell its music inventory and other assets related to its Wal-Mart business to Anderson Merchandisers LP of Amarillo, Texas. Handleman says most of the 260 jobs to be cut are at company headquarters in Troy and at its distribution facility in Indianapolis.

Harland Clarke Corp. will shutter its Decatur, Ga., call center and cut 220 jobs. The company notified the labor department of the layoff Feb. 2. San Antonio, Texas-based Harland Clarke is publisher of checks and financial products. The company has made several rounds of job cuts and closures recently, including in Minnesota, Maryland and North Carolina.

John H Harland Co. announced that it will close five plants and eliminate about 500 jobs due to lower work volume and productivity improvements from digital printing technology. The Atlanta printing and software company said it will consolidate the U.S. manufacturing operations of its Harland Printed Products unit to 9 plants from 14, while cutting sales, general and administrative expenses. Company officials announced the specifics of only one closing. The plant in Decatur, Ga., near Atlanta, will be closed, with its production moved to another location. The work and employees from a second Atlanta-area plant, in Conyers, will be moved to the Decatur facility.
The Harris Corporation has announced that it plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs because of lower industry spending.

Hasbro Inc. laid off 55 employees in Rhode Island, as part of a larger downsizing. The company also announced that about 170 workers are being laid off worldwide because of the underperformance in Hasbro's U.S. and Canadian divisions, which are under new leadership. The layoffs will affect workers in Pawtucket and Providence.
H.J.Heinz announced that it is closing its tuna operations in Purerto Rico. It also is consolidating its operations in Bloomsburg, PA.

Heinz (HJ Heinz Co.)announced that it is moving production of the iconic British brand HP Sauce abroad with the loss of 125 jobs. Heinz said that the HP Foods plant at Aston, Birmingham, is likely to shut by March 2007. The Aston plant has housed a manufacturing facility since 1875.

HJ Heinz Co. putting that to the test with plans to shut the Birmingham steak-sauce factory that are creating an uproar. The mainstay of English cuisine was first sold in 1903 and is advertised with the jingle HP sauce is the great British sauce. Heinz, which acquired the plant last year, said it operates three days a week. Workers planto strike and Birmingham's MP Clare Short has joined calls for a boycott.

Heinz has dismissed 65 employees from its Pocatello facility, Idaho. The company, said: 'to ensure the number of employees are in line with the production needs at the Pocatello facility, it has made the difficult but necessary decision to layoff approximately 65 team members.

H. J. Heinz Company announced that the company it is cutting 90 management jobs across its North American business, including 55 jobs in Pittsburgh. The company is providing severance packages and outplacement help for employees who have been cut.

Eighty full-time workers at the H.J. Heinz Co.'s Pocatello factory will lose their jobs March 4. The company said the job cuts come as the company is ending its T.G.I. Friday's line of frozen meals. The Pocatello Heinz plant produces frozen meals and snacks. After the layoffs, it will have more than 400 workers, according to the company. The company also said in a prepared statement that it will 'adjust its production schedule to manage costs, maximize efficiency, and leverage the talent of its remaining workforce'. The state labor department will assist the workers facing layoffs and help them find new work or training.

Heinz announced plans to halt operations at its food production plant that produces Aunt Bessie's frozen potato products in Norfolk, UK. The move, which is subject to a 45-day consultation process, will slash around 200 jobs at the site. The company decided to close its plant as its license to manufacture Aunt Bessie's products will not be renewed when it expires in April 2015. Heinz explored extensive alternatives and options before announcing the plant closure.
The H.J. Heinz Co. confirmed a 'handful' of layoffs in its Pittsburgh operations as part of a 'slightly streamlined structure' for the company's North America division.

Hershey Co. is cutting 1,500 jobs over three years as part of a plan to scale back production lines and move some manufacturing to Mexico. When the plan is complete, Hershey's will make its chocolates and other candies at fewer facilities and have a lower overall cost structure. About 80% of Hershey's manufacturing will take place in the U.S. and Canada. The company said it will outsource production of low value-added items and also plans to construct a new plan in Monterrey, Mexico to meet growing demand in that country.

Hershey Co. plans to reduce its workforce by 1,500 jobs during the next three years and eliminate a third of its production lines. And when employees for a new plant to be built in Monterrey, Mexico, are factored in, the actual number of job losses at the company's U.S. and Canadian plants could total 3,000.

Hershey Co. announced that it will close a California plant with 575 workers, the fourth such closure announced in less than three months as it seeks to cut operating costs and expand overseas. Workers were told Monday they will lose their jobs when the plant is shut down by early next year. The chocolate factory will close in January 2008, with some lines shutting down as early as this fall. Hershey announced a restructuring plan on Feb. 15 that would cut its work force by 1,500 and production lines by one-third. It is shifting some work to contractors and a plant being built in Mexico, and has formed joint ventures to begin making its products in China and India.

Hershey Co. announced that it is closing its last Canadian factory, laying off 580 workers and moving part of the production to the United States and Mexico. The factory in Dartmouth, Nova Scotia, would close by December and that the company is negotiating severance packages for the workers. The Hershey, Pa.-based company closed the chocolate factory because it is operating at one-third of its capacity, Saville said. The company has to come up with ways to reduce costs to ensure the long-term competitiveness of the company.

Hershey Co. announced that it has ceased production at the plant. Peter Paul's 220 employees will either retire or find work elsewhere. Hershey is shifting production of Mounds and Almond Joy to a plant in Virginia. The shift is part of an overall realignment plan by Hershey. The company is eliminating 1,500 jobs nationwide and cutting a third of its production lines in the next three years.

Hershey Co. closed its online sweet store. The store has stopped taking orders effective July 31, 2009 and will officially close the store on August 28, 2009. The online store is reportedly offering 25% discount on all its products. The website sells a collection of the company's products including chocolate-covered macadamia nuts. The online store offers packaging for occasions, such as graduations, birthdays and weddings. The company said that 12 employees may lose their jobs because of the move and that the company will help them secure other jobs through the company's open job posting system.
Hershey slashed its sales and earnings outlook for the year and announced plans to cut 300 jobs amid an abrupt slowdown in chocolate sales in China.

Hewlett-Packard announced it intends to layoff 40 staff members in its Oregon location. On January 30, the company said that it would cut less than 2% (1,700 positions in the Marketing division) of its approximately 88,500 workers in a long-planned restr
The Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it is in the beginning phases of cutting up to 3,000 management positions due to slowed sales.
Hewlett Packard announced that the company has laid off 4100 employees in its printer division. This is a part of the company's aggressive cost cutting measures.

Hewlett-Packard Co. said that it plans more layoffs even if its proposed $22.4 billion acquisition of Compaq Computer doesn't go through. HP had previously warned that if the deal is completed, the combined company would lay off at least 15,000 employees as part of its effort to eliminate $2.5 billion in annual expenses. An HP representative declined to elaborate on the number of layoffs or the divisions from which those cuts will come.

Hewlett-Packard Co. finally began absorbing Compaq Computer Corp. and announced which of the companies products will live and die. HP and Compaq's Web sites had been meshed, and the 150,000 employees had gotten playbooks explaining the transition. HP expects to cut 15,000 jobs over the next two years, with many positions lost through attrition and voluntary severance programs. Layoffs will begin next Monday and will be mostly completed within six to nine months.
Hewlett-Packard Co. has announced that it may fire about 2000 employees, or 10 percent of its workforce, in Asia, in order to cut costs.
Hewlett-Packard has announced that it plans to cut 5,900 jobs in Europe as part of its earlier announced layoffs totaling 15,000, following the company's merger with Compaq Computer Corp.
Hewlett-Packard Co. has announced that it has closed most of its warehouse and distribution facility in Woodland and is expected to close the rest in about 18 months.
Hewlett-Packard announced that it has closed a manufacturing plant near Sacramento as it moves its server and storage facility from Roseville to Houston, affecting 300 employees.
Hewlett-Packard Co. announced 1,300 jobs in the third quarter on top of 3,500 jobs shed in the second quarter.
Hewlett-Packard cut 200 jobs from its enterprise systems group in Houston, Texas, as part of its effort to get back on track after reporting disappointing third-quarter results.

Hewlett-Packard Co. cutting jobs at its Vancouver printer division. An official at HP's corporate headquarters in Palo Alto, Calif., would not disclose the number of workers who would be affected or the areas where they work. An anonymous e-mail to The Columbian said as many as 100 HP Vancouver workers would lose their current jobs.

Hewlett-Packard Co. will make redundancies from its UK and Ireland operation. HP has confirmed that, as part of a realignment, some jobs will go, although CRN has learned that this figure could be as high as 330.

Hewlett-Packard plans to lay out. The details of a major revamping plan that is expected to include sweeping layoffs of more than 10,000 employees. The scope of the layoffs is excepted to be wide enough that it may drown out the subtleties of Hewlett's broader message.

Hewlett-Packard Co. announced a restructuring plan designed to save $1.9 billion annually and boost business performance. The company said it will lay off 10% of its regular full-time staff, or 14,500 employees, over the next six quarters. HP intends to simplify its structure by embedding sales and marketing efforts directly into business units, in a move to provide a tighter link with customers. The company said it will cut costs by restructuring support functions, eliminating redundancies and modifying HP's U.S. retirement programs, which will free funds for reinvestment in the business.
Hewlett-Packard Co. announced that it plans to drop 14,500 employees from the payrolls.

Hewlett-Packard Co. plans to cut 1,500 jobs in Germany by the end of 2006 out of a total workforce of 9,250 in the country. The job cuts are part of the company's global restructuring and cost-cutting programme which involves eliminating 14,500 jobs, including almost 6,000 in Europe.

Hewlett Packard Co. announced that its French unit reaffirmed its intention to maintain substantial ongoing operations in France despite plans to eliminate 1,240 jobs between now and 2008 as part of a Europe-wide reduction of 6,000 positions.

Hewlett-Packard Corp. laid off a number of employees in at least two units in Colorado Springs but did not say how many jobs were eliminated. Jobs were cut in a call center and in HP's small and medium business sales group. HP had cut call-center jobs in Colorado Springs in August and moved the positions to Guadalajara, Mexico.

Hewlett-Packard Co. announced that it was shutting down its global operations unit to cut costs and would assign functions like logistics and procurement to its three business groups. The reorganization is the latest effort, to lower costs and make business groups more accountable for sales and profit. As part of the changes, expected to be completed by November, operations will be integrated into Hewlett-Packard's main business units, the Imaging and Printing Group, the Personal Systems Group, responsible for PC's, and the Technology Solutions Group, which handles server computers, storage, services and software.

Hewlett-Packard Co. announced that economic development officials in Corvallis are girding for significant cutbacks, fearing that dozens or hundreds of HP employees may be about to lose their jobs. Through layoffs, buyouts and attrition, HP has sliced its Corvallis work force from 10,000 to 2,500 in the past 10 years.

Hewlett Packard plans to cut 26,000 workers from its global workforce. The global cuts are to take place over three years as part of its integration of Electronic Data Systems in its operations. Hewlett-Packard and EDS have about 320,000 employees between them globally.

Hewlett-Packard Co. plans to slash 9,330 jobs in Europe as part of a previously announced three-year plan to reduce its workforce by 24,600. About 90% of the cuts will be made at EDS, Electronic Data Systems, the computer services company HP has just acquired.

Hewlett-Packard Company's aggressive cost-cutting efforts will include laying off 69 employees at its Roseville campus. The high-tech giant, the county's largest employer with 3,600 people, will eliminate 23 credit analysts, plus software and electrical engineers, business consultants, project managers and others. H-P will begin the layoffs Oct. 31, with the final round ending Dec. 5, 2008.

Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it is to eliminate another 302 jobs in the Netherlands, above the 421 it announced previously. The extra job cuts are due to the fall in the hardware market, which will push HP to adjust its reorganization plans.

Hewlett-Packard Company announced that it would cut 9,000 jobs and take a charge of about $1 billion over several years, as it consolidates and automates its data centers. But during the same period, the company will hire 6,000 new workers in sales and service delivery positions.

Hewlett-Packard Company is considering cutting as many as 25,000 jobs, or 8% of its worldwide workforce, to reduce costs and help the company contend with ebbing demand for computers and services. The number of employees to be cut worldwide includes 10,000 to 15,000 from Hewlett-Packard's enterprise services group. Some of the cuts to Hewlett-Packard's workforce of 324,600 may come through early-retirement packages. The company to cut 4,000 Irish staff to cut costs.

Hewlett-Packard Company announced it will axe 520 jobs in France by 2014, as part of its European restructuring programme. The French unit of the group will launch a voluntary departure and early retirement plan. The company plans to cut 27,000 jobs worldwide within the next two years. The company plans to recruit 210 people over the next three years.

280 people are to lose their jobs at Hewlett Packard. 220 are employees, while a further 60 are contractors. All work at the company's offices in Sandyford in Dublin. The job cuts follow a decision by one of the company's clients, Barclaycard, to move services closer to its customers in Portugal and Italy.

Hewlett Packard Inc. is to shut one of its main operations in Ireland with the loss of 500 jobs. The multinational's facility in Leixlip, Co Kildare, focuses on products for the PC and printer market, which is under increasing pressure from the fall in traditional computer sales, the move away from printing documents and preference for tablet technology. It is likely that close to 500 HP employees will be impacted and leave the business over the next 12 months.

Hillenbrand Industries Inc. said that its Batesville Casket unit will close its plant in Nashua, New Hampshire and consolidate production into its Panola, Miss. plant. Hillenbrand said the consolidation of the two plants will result in charges of about $4.4 million, $2.4 million of which will be taken in the third quarter. The additional $2.4 million in costs will occur over the course of the plant closing.
Hill-Rom Holdings Inc. plans to trim 150 jobs, or about 3% of its salaried work force, as part of a cost-reduction effort.
Pinnacle Entertainment Inc. said that it plans to close the President Casino by July after gaming regulators moved to revoke the property's gaming license for declining revenue.

Home Depot Inc. announced that it is closing a 9-month-old call center that coordinated flooring installations and is shutting down its Floor Store concept as it shifts resources back into regular stores. The company notified 550 workers Tuesday that it would close the call center in Addison, Texas, on March 12, 2007. Affected employees will receive job-placement help and pay for 60 days after they leave. The company also said it has notified 80 workers in its Floor Store locations that those stores will close. Floor Store sells carpet, tile, wood flooring and installation services to professionals and consumers.

Home Depot Inc. announced about 750 people will lose their jobs when company closes a 6-year-old Brandon call center Jan. 28 that coordinates home installation services across the eastern seaboard. The move is part of the struggling home improvement giant's larger moves to save money and return more responsibility for the customer experience to people who work in its stores. The effort ranges from enhancing pay incentives to store performance to hiring more experienced tradespeople to staff plumbing and electrical departments. All that work now will be returned to the store departments that sold the job. Similar call centers in Dallas and Chicago that employ 100 people each will also be closed. A few call center functions for such items as water heater replacement will be outsourced to a third-party call center in Orlando. Home Depot plans to vacate the leased office building in Brandon.

The Home Depot Inc. announced that it is cutting 500 jobs at its headquarters in part because of market conditions caused by the slowing U.S. economy. The job cuts represent 10% of the 5,000 employees who work at Home Depot's headquarters. The company has more than 350,000 employees worldwide.

The Home Depot Inc. announced that it is throwing in the sponge on its Expo design and decor business, closing stores and laying off thousands of employees. The company said that Expo has not performed well financially and is not expected to anytime soon. Even during the recent housing boom, it was not a strong business. The business weakened significantly as the demand for big-ticket design and decor projects has declined in the current economic environment. Over the next two months, the company will close 34 Expo Design Center stores, five YardBIRDS stores, two Design Center stores and a bath remodeling business known as HD Bath, with seven locations. The company also said that all will result in the loss of about 5,000 jobs. Streamlining some support functions will cost another 2,000 positions for a total of about 2% of the company's workforce.

The Home Depot, Inc. is laying off 1,000 staffers as it cuts three pilot programs and cuts some support positions. As part of the restructuring, the company will create 200 jobs in Atlanta, where most human resources administration will be handled, although there will still be a field human resources team.

HON Industries Inc. announced that it expects to close three plants in a restructuring effort. The restructuring includes consolidating facilities, cutting jobs and discontinuing low-volume product lines.

HNI Corp. reported earnings results for the fourth quarter and year ended December 30, 2006. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $30,491,000 or $0.63 per diluted share on net sales of $682,215,000 compared to net income of $35,752,000 or $0.67 per diluted share on net sales of $657,237,000 reported for the same period last year. Net income per share was favorably impacted $0.06 per share as a result of the Corporation's share repurchase program. For the year, the company reported net income of $123,375,000 or $2.45 per diluted share on net sales of $2,679,803,000 compared to net income of $137,420,000 or $2.50 per diluted share on net sales of $2,433,316,000 reported for the same period last year.

The Corporation made decision to close its office furniture facility in Monterrey, Mexico and consolidate production into other locations which will be completed during the first half of 2007. During the fourth quarter $0.9 million of costs were recorded in connection with the shutdown as well as final costs associated with the shutdown of two facilities completed earlier in the year.

Household International Inc. announced that it is shutting down its automotive finance division in Jacksonville, laying off the 119 call center employees who work there. The shutdown will not affect the company's two other divisions, which handle private-label credit cards and tax-refund anticipation loans.

HSBC Finance Corp. will close its south Orlando call center by October, eliminating nearly 300 jobs. HSBC, based in suburban Chicago, will also close similar telephone-service operations in Duluth, Minn., and Scottsdale, Ariz., as part of a cost-cutting consolidation of company operations. The Orlando call center employed nearly 400 people at its peak three years ago, as Metris' main telemarketing arm for the Hispanic market. Metris had acquired the operation from Banco Popular, the Puerto Rico-based bank, in mid-2000. HSBC said it plans to reassign the work now done in Orlando to other HSBC operations.

HSBC North America Holdings Inc. has decided to close the Jacksonville office of its subsidiary operation HSBC Finance Corp. and eliminate nearly 240 employees. The move 'is a result of ongoing internal activities to improve efficiencies in the organization'. The company expects to complete the layoffs by the end of August 2008.

HSBC Finance Corp. announced the discontinuation of loan originations of all products by its Consumer Lending business. HSBC will continue to service and collect the existing receivable portfolio as it runs off, while continuing efforts to reach out and assist mortgage customers with their loan repayments and home preservation. The Consumer Lending branch offices, branded in the US as HFC and Beneficial, will cease taking new loan applications as soon as practical and substantially all branch offices will be closed as soon as commitments to customers are satisfied. HSBC remains committed to the US financial services market, including the remaining businesses in HSBC Finance, as well as its US banking operations under HSBC Bank.
Hubbell Inc. announced that the company has reduced its workforce by 19 percent since last year as sales fell amid the economic recession.

A northeast Missouri manufacturing plant will close in 2003, costing 41 employees their jobs. Workers at Louisiana Manufacturing learned of the plant closing. The plant, operated by Hubbell Inc., produces aluminum for electrical conduits.

The state Labor Department announced that at least 200 Hubbell Inc. workers in the region have lost or will lose their jobs primarily because of foreign competition. The affected workers will be eligible for U.S. Trade Assistance benefits, which can help with retraining and sometimes provide supplemental pay.

Huntington Bancshares plans to close 70 branches, 30 of them in Ohio, around the first of the year. Two of the branches are in central Ohio: Lincoln Village, 4975 W. Broad St., and Eastland, 2290 S. Hamilton Road.

Hutchinson Technology Inc. has announced a restructuring plan that includes a 20-25% reduction of its workforce, which totaled approximately 4,500 at the end of November. The workforce reductions are expected to be complete by the end of January 2009 and are part of the company's strategy to manage its cash and balance sheet and reduce its overall cost structure by approximately $65 million to $80 million on an annualized basis.

Hutchinson Technology Inc. announced that it is shedding 1,380 workers, or 30% of its workforce. Hutchinson said that it expected cuts of 20 to 25%, or 1,100, just a month ago. About 1,000 of the affected Hutchinson Technology workers are in Minnesota. Many received the bad news, noting that the rest will be notified throughout the week. The workforce reduction is higher due to the a lower demand outlook for 2009 and continued market and economic uncertainty.

Hutchinson Technology Inc. announced that it will lay off another 300 workers by the end of June as it struggles to cope with shrinking demand in the high-tech market for its disk-drive assemblies. The company plans to cut 200 jobs from its plant at its headquarters and manufacturing plant in Hutchinson. The main plant currently has 1,357 workers.

Hutchinson Technology Inc. is cutting yet another 600 local jobs, it marked the latest blow to a community that has seen its namesake employer wither in recent years. The company said it is scaling back its 2,275-person U.S. workforce by 30% to 40%, with manufacturing work the Hutchinson plant has done since the 1960 moving to Eau Claire, Wis., and overseas. Not long ago, Hutchinson Technology had a solid niche as the maker of a key component in computer disk drive storage units.

Hutchinson Technology Inc. is winding down its high-volume assembly manufacturing operation in Hutchinson by the end of July 2016 and expects to eliminate about 70 jobs. The Hutchinson-based maker of suspension assemblies for computer hard drives plans to start the layoffs around May 7, 2016. The plant might stay open past July "depending on disk drive market conditions and customer requirements". This action is expected to be permanent. Some employees have already been given notice but may find other jobs with the company.

ITT Industries has announced that it will close its Searcy plant by the second quarter of 2004 resulting in about 240 layoffs. In addition, the company plans to close its Rochester plant by the end of August 2002.
ITT Industries Inc. will close its fluid-handling systems plant next July because of a slowdown in the economy. The factory in the suburb of Gates employs 94 people.

Inco Ltd. announced it may close a copper refinery in Ontario because of high operating costs. Inco has been reviewing its Copper Cliff refinery at Sudbury for about a year as workers tried cutting costs, Inco spokesman Cory McPhee said. Inco will decide in the next month or so whether to shut the refinery, which produces 115,000 metric tons of copper cathode yearly, McPhee said. The company is negotiating to ship metal to another refiner if the plant is closed, he said. He declined to name the company. The United Steelworkers' union, which represents 150 refinery workers, said it wants Inco to upgrade the facility.

Vale Inco is defending its plan to cut the jobs of 423 Canadian workers, announcing the layoffs do not violate an agreement made in 2006 not to cut staff for three years. The company announced that it plans to cut 423 jobs permanently at its Canadian operations, with the contingent being 261 jobs in Sudbury. Plunging commodity prices led Vale to announce last December a worldwide job reduction of 1,300 and heavy production cuts.
Ingersoll-Rand has closed 25 plants and cut more than 5,900 workers due to a sluggish economy.

Ingersoll-Rand Co. Ltd. plans to cut several thousand jobs and close plants as sales in North America and Europe slow. The moves are part of a $110 million restructuring plan aimed at saving as much as $100 million in 2009. In an unrelated move, the company laid off 220 hourly workers this week from its Bridgeton plant. Excluding the 220 laid off-workers, the company employs about 1,270 hourly and salaried employees locally.
Insituform Technologies has announced that the company plans to eliminate about 75 salaried positions.

Griffon Corp. announced that it has decided to dispose of Clopay's remaining installation operations by the end of 2008, having already shuttered units in several markets. It expects to incur related costs of up to $40 million.

Integrated Device Technology Inc. reported after that it is cutting 240 positions in North America as part of a restructuring program. The company expects its restructuring program to eventually save between $5 million and $6 million a quarter.

Intel Corp. shed roughly 200 jobs in Colorado Springs during the past five months, mainly through layoffs and attrition. The job cuts shove the number of layoffs in the local semiconductor industry during the past two years to roughly 1,600. At the time, the company said it employed 1,050 workers here.

Intel Corp. may cut a significant portion of its work force following the completion of a broad business review. The chip maker could reduce its employee roster of about 100,000 by between 10,000 and 15,000.

Intel plans to cut costs by $5 billion over the next two years: $2 billion in 2007 and the rest in 2008. Most of the savings will come from changes in the company's global workforce. The company will cut its workforce to 95,000 by the end of 2006, and to 92,000 by mid-2007. According to its financial report for the second quarter, Intel has 102,500 employees worldwide. Most of the layoffs in 2006 will be among management, marketing, and information technology personnel. In 2007, streamlining-driven measures will include improving production procedures, better use of equipment, eliminating organizational redundancies, and improving product design methods and procedures. Intel did not disclose where the layoffs will take place, nor did it mention investment in development or the strengthening of existing facilities. The company said detailed plans would be released on October 17, when it will finalize its results for the third quarter.

Intel Corp. announced that workers in Oregon were informed that they no longer had a job. Company acknowledged the layoffs, but declined to say just how many employees got the news. The restructuring plan unveiled last month included the elimination of 10,500 jobs, or about 10% of Intel's worldwide work force. The company began cutting jobs in July after it lost market share in the microprocessor business to Advanced Micro Devices Inc. If applied evenly, more than 1,000 Intel workers in Oregon would lose their jobs.

Intel Corp. announced that it expects to cut more than 1,000 jobs at its Rio Rancho plant as the company ends production of an older silicon wafer technology. The company will stop making the 200-millimeter wafers at the plant by the end of August, and affected employees will be offered severance packages or can apply for other jobs within the company.

Intel Corp. will notify more than 1,000 employees that their jobs will be terminated beginning July 30, 2007. The previously announced work force reduction comes as Intel ramps down production next month in Fab 11, which makes older, simpler computer components using 200-millimeter silicon wafers. The job cuts will bring the total staff at Intel's Rio Rancho plant to below 4,000 employees.

Intel Corp. is cutting its IT staff by as much as 10% as part of an effort to make its internal operations more efficient. He confirmed the layoff plans after being asked about an anonymous blog posting that described the process being used to cut workers based on assessments of their skills.

Intel Corporation announced that it will stop production at five plants worldwide and up to 6,000 jobs will be cut. Two assembly test facilities in Malaysia and one in the Philippines will close. The company will also end production two US facilities, in Oregon and Santa Clara, California. The company also reportedly plans to close a development center in Yokne'am which employs 50 people.

Intel Corporation announced that it's proposed move to close two factories on Penang island is set to affect around 2,000 workers. However, they have been told that efforts will be taken to find alternative employment within Intel. It is not known when Intel is likely to cease operations of its PG6 and PG7 plants where manufacturing activities take place. Intel's Penang operations are currently home to an estimated 6,000 workers, while its Kedah site at the Kulim Hi-Tech Park employs around 4,000 people.

Intel Corporation has started to tell workers which of them will face the axe under a proposed redundancy scheme. The first of the 294 Intel employees to be made redundant by the company learned their fate through a series of individual meetings that are set to continue for a number of days.

Intel Corporation announced that up to 100 voluntary redundancies are to be sought by chip maker at its Lexlip operation due to the closure of one of is factories there. The Fab 10 factory is to close in March, having been operating below full capacity for several years.

Intel Corp. in Rio Rancho is reducing its 3,300 workforce by 400 people, but according to the company, its New Mexico facility remains critical to Intel's global operations and the plant here is still in the running for future investments. The decision to 'redeploy' 400 employees in New Mexico reflects the Santa Clara, Ca.-based chipmaker's efforts to restructure operations across the board to stay competitive as markets move away from personal computers, which Intel has long dominated, to mobile devices such as smart-phones and tablets. According to company no individual workers have yet been notified about changes in their employment status, because the 'deployment' process will begin with a company offer for workers in Rio Rancho to voluntarily seek positions at other Intel locations, opt for retirement if they qualify, or accept an 'attractive' separation package. Redeployment refers to an Intel program in which employees continue receiving a salary for two months while they look for jobs either inside or outside the company with Intel assistance. After that, their employment at Intel is terminated. On September 12, 2013, Intel announced it will shut down a chip making plant in Hudson, Mass., laying off 700 people by year-end. According to company, the circumstances at the Hudson and Rio Rancho plants are very different, because the Massachusetts facility was still making chips on 200 millimeter (8 inch) wafers, which is Intel's oldest technology. In contrast, Intel overhauled the Rio Rancho facility more than a decade ago to manufacture chips on 300 millimeter (12 inch) wafers, which remain the standard in the chipmaking industry now. On the other hand, Rio Rancho continues to make chips with 32-nanometer transistors. In that regard, the plant is two generations behind the curve, since Intel is already producing 22-nanometer chips at other factories, and the company is building manufacturing capacity for 14-nanometer chips at plants in Arizona and Ireland. The company continually strives to reduce transis

Intel to close its AppUp software distribution channel, originally created for Atom-powered netbooks, in March 2014, with refunds available for all customers. Intel has announced that its AppUp software distribution channel, launched in 2010, is to shut up shop in March 2014, with anyone who spent money through the service eligible for a refund. The AppUp service launched back in September 2010 as an off-shoot of Intel's Atom Developer Programme. After March 2014, users will no longer be able to download software from the service although packages already installed will mostly continue to operate as normal. Some, however, expect to be able to communicate with AppUp servers, and as a result will stop working when they are turned off altogether in March next year. All software, meanwhile, will no longer receive updates - including security updates - through AppUp.

Intel is preparing a significant round of job cuts across business units this spring. The cutbacks will reduce employment in some parts of the business by double-digit percentages amounting to thousands of job cuts across the company by the end of the year. The planned downsizing could begin soon after Intel reports its first-quarter financial results. The plans have not been officially announced inside the company and have not been publicly disclosed. Intel did not respond to repeated requests for comment this week.

Intel Corp. announced that it will cut 784 jobs at its facilities in Hillsboro and Aloha. The layoffs will take place by May 31, 2016. Workers will receive notices between April 26, 2016 and April 29, 2016. Intel said it will pay each laid-off worker six weeks of pay and provide three months of paid-premiums for COBRA benefits. The layoffs are permanent.

Intel has indicated that there will be job cuts here in Ireland. Staff at the company have been told its Irish operations will be impacted by its worldwide restructuring plans. Intel announced an 11% reduction of its global workforce last week saying the cuts will include voluntary and involuntary redundancies.

Intel announced that it will close a small production facility in Jerusalem and transfer most of the 170 people who work there to a factory 40 miles away in Kiryat Gat. Its the latest step in a broad restructuring Intel announced in April designed to prepare the company for long-term decline in its core business: making microprocessors for PCs and laptops. Intel is eliminating 12,000 jobs by the middle of the next year through a mix of layoffs, buyouts and early retirement offers. Intel operates a research and development facility in Jerusalem that wont be affected. Intel is closing a number of smaller outposts around the world, including a site in DuPont, Washington. The companys largest operations are in Oregon, and though Intel is cutting jobs locally it does not appear likely to shut down any of its facilities here.

Furniture Brands International Inc. announced that it is closing a manufacturing plant for the first time in High Point, N.C., as part of a long-term strategy for reducing domestic production. The company announced that it would shut down the Henredon Furniture Industries upholstery plant by the end of the year. 45 jobs would be cut as part of the closing.

Furniture Brands International Inc. announced that the company is reducing its workforce to reflect continuing soft retail market conditions. The staffing reduction will eliminate approximately 1,400 management, professional and hourly positions across all functions, a decrease of approximately 15% in Furniture Brands' domestic workforce.
Interface Inc. has announced that it will layoff about 300 employees combined from its US and international operations in an effort to reduce costs.

INTERMET Corporation announced that it intends to close its Radford Foundry in Radford, Virginia, before the end of 2003, with a target date of September 30, 2003. Around 374 people, including hourly and salaried staff, would be affected. The company cite
IBM has announced that the company will layoff 136 employees in computer software development at its Downtown office as the company consolidates operations.

International Business Machines Corp. plans to trim its payroll by roughly 9,000 workers by the middle of this year. The jobs to be lost make up fewer than 3 percent of International Business Machines' worldwide work force of 320,000, but most of the cutbacks will come among the company's 160,000 employees in the United States.

More than 700 employees at International Business Machines Corp. plants around the United States were told that their jobs would be eliminated. The cuts were announced at plants in Endicott and Poughkeepsie in New York; San Jose, Calif. and Rochester, Minn.

International Business Machines Corp. announced nearly 1,000 layoffs at its microprocessing site outside Burlington, Vt., in one of the biggest staff reductions at the company's Essex Junction plant thus far. Another 500 workers, including professional design engineers, technicians, and personnel support staff, will lose jobs at sites in Endicott and Fishkill, N.Y. Production workers will not be affected at any of the three sites. Instead, the company said it plans to add 200 to 300 skilled factory jobs to its payroll. The announced reductions, which represent close to 7.5 percent of the big computer maker's overall microelectronics work force.
According to unnamed sources, International Business Machines Corp. will cut about 4,000 jobs after its acquisition of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLC's consulting unit.

International Business Machines Corp. has announced that it will close its hard disk drive plant in Szekesfehervar, Hungary, cutting about 2,100 jobs there. In addition, it plans to cut 600 jobs in its services division and about 100 jobs from elsewhere i

International Business Machines Corp. will cut 260 local employees from its payroll by farming out more manufacturing operations to contractors, as the world's biggest computer services company continues efforts to cut costs and streamline its business. Those measures and layoffs shrank its local work force from 15,000 to about 13,500.
International Business Machines Corp. has sent layoff notices to nearly 1,000 employees, representing about 0.5 percent of its combined software and technology services work forces.

International Business Machines Corporation has sent layoff notices to 300 workers in various facilities around the United States in a job reduction action that it refers to as skills rebalancing. Among the layoffs are 50 people in a printer division based in Boulder, Colo. The Armonk-based computer giant has about 320,000 workers around the world. Last year it laid off 15,000 workers as the industry slump led to sales and earnings that were lower than expected.

The Swedish unit of International Business Machines Corp. said it will close an information technology support unit and lay off the 157 workers there because of a drop in demand for their services. The Armonk, N.Y.-based company employs about 320,000 people worldwide, including 4,000 in Sweden.

International Business Machines Corp. announced that it slashing 300 software jobs in a realignment of resources that has been happening periodically at the technology titan. The cuts affect fewer than 1 percent of IBM's 38,000 software employees and a tiny percentage of the company's 320,000 people overall. But they follow similar actions recently - IBM cut 400 software jobs in September and 200 in November.

International Business Machines Corp. plans to close three production units in the country. The three units to be closed are located in Milan, Ancona and Verona. According to the trade unions, the future of between 800 and 1, 000 IBM workers in Italy is a bit uncertain.

International Business Machines Corp. sold its personal computer unit and plans to cut 13,000 jobs, mostly in Europe, as it focuses on such high-growth countries as China and India and more profitable operations, including management services.

International Business Machines Corp. announced that nearly 400 employees, about one-fourth of them in Texas, are looking for new jobs within the company or facing layoffs by next month because of a realignment. The employees are from the company's hardware development division, which develops servers and microchips that go into IBM systems sold globally. Depending on how many workers find new positions at IBM, the company's plant in Austin could take the biggest hit with 100 layoffs. Other offices affected include Poughkeepsie, Endicott and Fishkill, N.Y. (99 employees); Rochester, Minn., (74); Tucson, Ariz. (43); Raleigh, N.C., (35); and Burlington, Vt. (16), plus about a dozen other locations with smaller reductions. Employees were notified of the change in early September 2006. They received a follow up notice and have until early November 2006 to find new positions.

International Business Machines Corp. announced that it would lay off 150 people in Boulder and metro Denver over the next 30 days as the company shifts resources to meet its customers' changing needs. The employees are part of the company's information technology delivery organization. The cuts in Colorado are part of 1,300 IBM cuts across the United States. Displaced workers will receive separation and severance packages based on their years of service with the company. They also will be eligible for additional health care and educational benefits.

International Business Machines Corp. laid off 1,570 people, primarily from an ongoing overhaul of operations in its giant technology services unit. The company carried out a similar level of job cuts at the beginning of the month, for a total of 3,023 in this quarter and 3,720 for the year. That amounts to roughly 1% of the company. But even these small numbers reflect a big project inside IBM to transform its business.

International Business Machines Corp. announced that about 300 employees in the Hudson Valley will be laid off. Most of the job cuts will be made at the company's East Fishkill semiconductor plant in Dutchess County, with some also coming from the Poughkeepsie facility. About 11,800 people are employed at the two plants. The layoffs are being made specifically within research and development, as part of the realignment of manufacturing and development. IBM is eliminating a total of 450 jobs nationwide, including 90 at the company's chip complex in Essex Junction, Vt. Severance packages will be given to all 450 employees.

International Business Machines Corp. has made its first filing under the new New York state Worker Adjustment, Retraining and Notification law, or WARN. But it was a partial one. The notice said 274 workers in software applications at the Hudson Valley Research Park here will be laid off for 'economic reasons' effective April 27. Those job cuts are part of a larger 'resource action' IBM launched in its Systems and Technology Group. Other cuts were in technical posts involved in semiconductor production, the chief role of the East Fishkill complex.

After having reportedly scuttled thousands of jobs already in 2009, International Business Machines Corp. is in the midst of another round of layoffs that is expected to affect hundreds of its employees. The company is cutting hundreds of jobs, primarily in the company's Global Business Services unit. At least 200 jobs will be cut as a result of this latest round of layoffs.

International Business Machines Corp. cut more than 1,500 jobs across a number of divisions. Documents submitted by laid-off workers to the Alliance(at)IBM, a labor union representing a small percentage of IBM employees, indicate that at least 1,518 jobs were cut. It's not known where the positions were located.

International Business Machines Corp. announced that it cut more than 1,500 jobs across a number of divisions, a sliver of the technology company's nearly 400,000 workers worldwide. Documents submitted by laid-off workers to the Alliance at the company, a labor union representing a small percentage of IBM employees, indicate that at least 1,518 jobs were cut. It's not known where the positions were located.
International Business Machines Corp. has issued layoff notices to more than 400 workers. Employees may be eventually be eligible for help under the Trade Act of 1974.

A restructure of International Business Machines Corp.'s client services is expected to affect more than 120 Ballarat jobs by the end of July. IBM provides IT support to large businesses from its service centre in Ballarat. The ABC has been shown emails that indicate IBM's help desk services for the Westpac Bank will be shifted to Adelaide by the end of the month. It is understood that 80 casual jobs will be lost from Ballarat and that those workers have been given the opportunity to move to South Australia. The emails indicate another 40 jobs will go in July, when the Ballarat centre will stop servicing the National Australia Bank. It is understood IBM will shift its NAB services to India.

International Business Machines Corp. is laying off some employees in the Triangle and in Charlotte. In addition to Charlotte and RTP, the layoffs are occurring at IBM facilities in New York, Georgia, California and Rochester, Minn.
IBM has announced plans to cut 233 jobs in Belgium. The company said it's suffering from a stagnating IT market and competition from low-wage countries.

International Flavors & Fragrances Inc. announced that it will eliminate around 300 manufacturing, selling, research and administration jobs, principally in its European and North American operations. The company announced that it expects to take charges of around $25 million to $30 million mainly in the fourth quarter in connection to these job eliminations.
Navistar International has announced it might layoff up to 400 workers, or half its work force at its truck factory in Canada.

Navistar International Corp. plans to idle its truck plant and lay off an undetermined number of workers next month because of declining orders. The layoffs will occur because of a production slowdown. The layoffs will come after the western Ohio plant is idled again, during the week of Aug. 11, 2008.

Layoff notices have gone out to all remaining employees at the Navistar International Corp. truck plant in Chatham. The notices would take effect June 27, just three days before the company's current contract with the workers expires. Navistar is required by law to issue the notices, however, Canadian Auto Workers national representative Joe McCabe says the truckmaker has gone an unexpected step further. Layoff notices were also circulated to management staff and those not covered under the collective agreement. In total, approximately 280 plant workers and 65 office employees are being let go. McCabe says the union still plans on trying to hammer out a new contract. Bargaining is expected to start in early May. The company has already had two rounds of layoffs 2009 year involving close to 700 employees.

Navistar International Corp. is planning to cut about 90% jobs in Canada and shift majority of its heavy-duty truck production to locations in the southwestern US and Mexico. Navistar will eliminate about 800 jobs out of the total 1,000 jobs at the Chatham plant. The labor agreement between Navistar and Canadian Auto Workers expired on July 1, 2009, which will allow the company to transfer majority of heavy-duty truck production.

Navistar International Corporation plans to cease production of motorized RVs at its Monaco RV manufacturing facility in Coburg, resulting in a loss of 255 jobs. According to a notice filed with the Department of Community Colleges & Workforce Development, Navistar will lay off the employees between March 16, 2012 and April 27, 2012.

Navistar International Corporation announced that it intends to close its Garland, Texas, truck manufacturing operation as part of its efforts to reduce costs and optimize its manufacturing footprint. Navistar intends to cease operations at the Garland facility by the first half of 2013. The Garland facility currently employs approximately 900 salaried, hourly and third party temporary workers. Truck volume now produced at Garland will transition to other North America operations that currently build similar models beginning in January 2013. Once completed, the Garland closure is expected to reduce Navistar's operating costs by $25 million to $35 million annually. The company will record a fourth quarter 2012 charge, primarily for employee separation benefits, which is not expected to exceed $10 million on a pre-tax basis. As the closure plan is implemented during the 2013 fiscal year, the company expects to record certain pre-tax charges, primarily related to accelerated depreciation and other related items, ranging from $30 million to $50 million dependent upon determination of fair value. Navistar projects this action will be cash flow positive in year one.

Navistar International Corporation announced that it will close its foundry operations in Indianapolis, Indiana, where it currently produces engine blocks and heads for its proprietary engines. Going forward, the company will source these components from the supply base. This transition will occur during the first half of next year, and the company expects to complete the foundry closure in the summer of 2015. Once completed, closing the Indianapolis foundry is expected to eliminate approximately 180 jobs and reduce Navistar's operating costs by about $13 million annually.

Navistar announced that it will cease all engine production at its plant in Melrose Park, Ill., by the second quarter of fiscal 2018. The company will continue the facility's transformation into Navistar's technical center, including truck and engine testing and validation as well as used truck sales and reconditioning, continuing the process that started in 2010. The majority of engines produced at Melrose Park are medium duty 9/10 liter engines used in International Class 6 and 7 vehicles, for which alternative engine options are currently offered in all applications. Once completed, the cessation of engine manufacturing at Melrose Park is expected to affect about 170 employees and reduce Navistar's operating costs by approximately $12 million annually. The company will take an approximate $43 million charge as a result of this action, including approximately $8 million of cash related charges. A significant portion of the hourly employees at Melrose Park are retirement-eligible. Assistance and opportunities for retraining will be offered.

International Game Technology announced it will lay off a yet-to-be determined number of employees by Jan. 5 due to the troubled economy. The company announced that the number of layoffs will be based on how many workers accept a voluntary separation program.

International Game Technology will close its Reno cabinet shop in 60 days and eliminate 25 jobs. Notices to cabinet shop employees were delivered, although the company had warned employees about the layoffs late last year.

International Game Technology officially closed the doors to their Reno based cabinet shop. Sheet metal work, wood working and lamination for the companies slot and gaming machines will be outsourced to other local businesses.

InterDigital Communications Corp. announced earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended June 30, 2005. For the quarter, the company reported revenues of $38.6 million, increased $9.2 million or 31%, over second quarter 2004 revenues of $29.4 million. The company's net income increased to $4.0 million or $0.07 per share diluted, from income of $0.9 million or $0.01 per share diluted in second quarter 2004. 

For first half 2005, the company reported revenues of $74.1 million, a 19 % increase over revenues of $62.4 million in first half 2004. Net income for first half 2005 was $3.1 million or $0.05 per share diluted against net income of $6.7 million or $0.11 per share diluted for the same period a year ago.

The company also announced it plans to close its Melbourne, Florida design facility in third quarter 2005 and relocate certain development efforts and personnel to other company locations. Currently, there are thirty-three full or part-time employees at this facility, of which sixteen have been offered continued employment elsewhere within the company.

InterDigital Inc. announced that it will lay off 100 employees, including some at its King of Prussia, as a result of a restructuring of its SlimChip business. The company expects the move will result in annualized pre-tax cost savings of approximately $33 million, of which 65% is cash-related.
International Paper Co. fired 65 employees at its Hudson River Mill in response to a decelerating economy this after the company shut down one of two paper machines for the second time this winter.
International Paper announced that it plans to cut 11 jobs at its Texarkana mill during the next few weeks. The company also announced job cuts at its Memphis, Augusta and Pine Bluff plants.
International Paper Company announced that it plans to indefinitely shut down three paper machines at the company's Savannah, Ga., mill and one at its Hudson River mill in Corinth, N.Y.
International Paper Co. announced that the company will end production at its Hammermill plant in Lock Haven on March 18, and subsequently shutdown the plant affecting about 265 employees.

International Paper Co. announced it will close its Hudson River mill at the end of the year, putting nearly 300 people out of work. The 103-year-old plant, where 290 workers produce 100,000 tons of coated paper annually.
International Paper Co. has announced that it plans to eliminate 80 jobs at its mill by the end of the year as part of the company's plan to eliminate 100 to 150 positions overall.
International Paper Co. will shut down its Corinth mill by the end of 2002.
International Paper Co. has announced that it will eliminate about 100 maintenance and operations jobs from its Androscoggin Mill, Maine.

International Paper Co. announced that it will close two of three container plants in Western Pennsylvania -- in Washington and in Sharpsburg -- resulting in the loss of 209 jobs. Closing date for the Sharpsburg plant will be April 6, and the Washington plant will close May 31. Some of the employees losing their jobs may transfer to open jobs at other plants.

International Paper Co. announced that another 60 jobs are being cut at the Bastrop paper mill. Approximately 41 additional hourly jobs and 19 salaried jobs will be eliminated due to changes in the processes and operating systems following the indefinite shutdown of the No. 3 paper machine. The latest announcement leaves about 660 jobs at the mill.

International Paper Co. announced that it will shut down its milk and cream carton manufacturing plant located in Longueuil on the South Shore of Montreal. The 36 members of Teamsters Local Union 555M will thus lose their jobs next July. In addition to the plant on the South Shore of Montreal, the company will also be shutting down plants in London (Ontario) and Boston (Massachusetts).

International Paper Co. announced that the No. 3 machine at container board mill in Valliant will cease operations November 1, 2008 impacting about 60 jobs. The plant employs 350 production workers, along with about 150 support personnel and contract workers. A department connected to the No. 3 machine will also be impacted. The company decided to shut down the machine to limit its exposure to high fiber and other input costs. The No. 3 machine produces about 430,000 tons of container board each year. Key grades produced on the machine will be transitioned to other mills.

International Paper Co. announced that it will indefinitely close its Louisiana Mill in Bastrop, Texas due to a continuing decline in pulp demand coupled with a weak economy. The closure will reduce the company's annual pulp production capacity by about 450,000 tons. About 550 employees will be affected.

International Paper Co. announced that it will close its Inverurie, Scotland, Mill by the end of March. A three-month employee consultation process failed to find a financially viable alternative future for the mill. The closure removes 250,000 tonnes of uncoated freesheet capacity from International Paper's European output.

International Paper Co. announced that it will close its Cedarburg plant in June, cutting 114 jobs. The plant can make 500 million square feet of corrugated containers each year. The company said it will also close a mill in Ticonderoga in May and a plant in Chesapeake, Va. in June.

International Paper Company announced it is laying off 1,100 people who work at an Alabama paper mill that it plans to permanently close because of waning demand for the paper the facility makes. The mill makes paper for forms, envelopes, labels, copiers, printers and magazines. Demand for such paper has steadily dropped as businesses shift to options such as online applications and electronic billing and filing. The mill is part of the company's printing and communications business. The company expects the closing to result in about $550 million in pretax asset write-off and accelerated depreciation charges. It expects about $125 million in pretax severance and other charges. The charges are expected to be recorded this year and in 2014. The mill will be closed in stages and is expected to be shut down by the end of first quarter of 2014.

International Paper (IP) plans to permanently close its Alabama Paper Mill in Courtland. The mill will shut down in stages with a full closure expected to be complete by the end of the first quarter of 2014. This mill closure will reduce IP's North American uncoated and coated free sheet paper production capacity by 950,000 tons, of which 765,000 is uncoated free sheet.

International Speedway Corp. has cut more than 40 corporate positions at its headquarters. The company's goal of reducing by 20% the size of its headquarters staff, which numbered 250 at the start of the year 2010, has been met. Whether there will be additional job cuts will depend on the state of the economy.
Interpublic Group of Cos. plans to reduce 10 percent of its workforce at its Mullen unit. The company will cut 56 workers at its headquarters in Wenham, Massachusetts.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. plans to close its Miami plant and streamline operations throughout Florida and Georgia, costing about 600 jobs. Closing the plant will cost 480 jobs. Consolidating routes, depots and thrift stores in the two states will eliminate another 120 positions.

For the quarter ending March 5, Interstate Bakeries reported a 1.7% decline in sales from a year ago to $1 billion and a cash balance of $95.4 million.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. announced that it will consolidate its southern California sales operations and cut about 350 jobs as part of the bankrupt company's continuing efforts to reduce costs. Interstate Bakeries previously has announced cuts elsewhere in the country that included closing some bakeries and involved about 3,650 jobs.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. announced that it is closing its Lakewood, Wash., bakery as it consolidates operations in the Northwest. The closure will eliminate around 200 jobs and be completed by Dec. 17. This is the seventh bakery the company has shuttered as it tries to eliminate low-performing operations and work its way out of bankruptcy.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. announced that it is laying off 450 workers as it consolidates operations in three regions across the country. The bankrupt baker of Wonder Bread and Hostess Twinkies said the closure will eliminate the positions of store clerks, salespeople and delivery people in nine states by the end of the year.

Interstate Bakeries Corp. announced that it will layoff around 230 employees in Indiana and Michigan as it consolidates routes, depots and retail outlets in the upper Midwest. The company said the moves, expected to be completed by March 13 if approved by bankruptcy officials, will require a $700,000 charge, including $400,000 in severance payments. In addition, the company said it expects to pay $300,000 in the future for capital expenditures tied to the consolidation.

Hostess Brands, Inc. has filed notices with the state of Florida regarding potential layoffs of 138 employees at outlet stores and manufacturing facilities in the Tampa Bay area. The layoffs at 11 different locations are part of statewide layoffs totaling 509 employees. The workers could be laid off from July 7 to July 21. Among the local layoffs, 30 Hostess employees at a Riverview facility could lose their jobs, and another 33 could be laid off from two Tampa facilities.
InterVoice Brite Inc. will eliminate 102 positions in the US and 23 in Europe, Asia and the Middle East.
Intervoice Inc. announced that it has eliminated 50 positions in March 2003. The cuts were part of the strategic cost-cutting action.

Invacare Corporation announced its decision to close its London, Canada manufacturing facility by mid-2014. The closure of this plant, which produces long-term care beds and case goods, is part of the company's long-term strategy to remain cost competitive by optimizing its global supply chain. Production of case goods currently manufactured in London will be transferred to the Invacare plant in Sanford, Florida. The long-term care beds production in London will be outsourced to a third-party with established FDA-registered manufacturing capabilities around the world. The third-party manufacturer has a significant focus on medical devices, including acute care bed production.

Invacare Corporation announced a restructuring initiative that includes a reduction to the company's workforce of approximately 150 associates and 40 temporary associates from the North America/Home Medical Equipment (HME), Institutional Products Group and Asia/Pacific segments.
The Iomega Corp. announced that it will shut down its Utah manufacturing plant in a consolidation plan resulting in the loss of 110 jobs.
Iomega Corp. announced that it plans on laying off approximately 1,100 employees, as a result of poor second-quarter results.

Iomega Corp. plans to lay off 125 workers, or about one-fourth of its work force, in Roy, Utah, by the end of the year as part of the 200 job cuts announced worldwide in July. Cuts will be across the board, with a focus on manufacturing operations and research and development positions.

Iomega Corp. announced a restructuring plan to reduce costs. The restructuring plan includes a workforce reduction of approximately 75 employees. Additionally, 13 positions have already been eliminated since the beginning of the year for a total workforce reduction of about 30%. The Company anticipates these actions along with other business changes will result in annual cost savings of $20 million to $25 million as compared to first quarter 2006 annualized run rates, when fully implemented by the end of the third quarter. Approximately 85% of the cost reductions are expected to be in operating expenses, with the remainder in fixed overhead. The cost reductions include the workforce reduction, consolidation of facilities and other spending reductions.
