The restructuring and other associated charges, expected to range between $3 million to $4 million, are anticipated to be recorded in the second and third quarters.

Ionics Incorporated announced that the program will result in the elimination of approximately 200 positions, or 10% of the Company's worldwide workforce. The Company believes that these actions, which it anticipates will be taken over the next six months, should result in an approximate annual savings of $15 million after they are fully implemented.

JLG Industries Inc. is cutting back its work force in response to a slowing construction market. The downsizing will affect both administrative positions and production positions at plants in McConnellsburg, Shippensburg and Bedford. The layoffs will occur between the beginning of August and end of September and will be combined with intermittent plant shutdowns. The layoffs also affect JLG facilities in North Dakota, Belgium and France.

JLG Corp. announced that it is cutting 600 employees worldwide, amounting to 13% of its work force. The jobs being eliminated are full- and part-time positions and range from hourly workers to administrators. The layoffs at the various JLG plants, will take place in phases from August 1-September 30. The layoffs will be considered permanent, adding the company is hopeful an eventual turnaround in the economic picture will generate some new business opportunities, perhaps allowing some workers eventually to be rehired.

JLG Industries Inc. announced additional layoffs affecting 325 production workers in this area, just one week after 100 administrative positions were cut. The company announced that 115 workers at the Shippensburg facility were notified on May 29, 2009 that they will be laid off on July 28. At McConnellsburg, a total of 210 workers will be laid off on June 5 or June 26. The layoffs affected other North American facilities, including one in Bedford. Forty-two production jobs there are being cut.
JLG Industries Inc. announced that it is closing its Orrville facility, laying off up to 279 employees. The facility will close by Sept. 30, and production will be sent to facilities in Pennsylvania.

Jefferies Group Inc. provided earnings guidance for the fourth quarter of 2008. The company expects to record a net operating loss for the fourth quarter of 2008 similar to that recorded in the first quarter of 2008 due to the extraordinary operating environment, before the impact of the severance costs, the office closing costs and the non-cash cost of writing off all unamortized stock-based compensation expense in respect of prior periods. The firm currently estimates that the aggregate impact of these costs will increase its fourth quarter loss by $340 million on an after tax basis, $320 million, or 95%, of this charge will be non-cash. The company announced that it has completed a strategic review and implemented changes designed to restore profitability in 2009. These changes include a substantial reduction in its headcount, changes in compensation plans, operating expense reductions, office closings, continuing risk reductions and other structural changes. The company expects to end 2008 with approximately 2,150 employees, as compared to 2,508 at the beginning of this year. The firm has now reduced its headcount by 18% year-over-year, not including approximately 85 new hires previously announced in mortgages and international equities. Jefferies is also closing its offices in Dubai, Singapore and Tokyo, and will restore its presence in these markets when appropriate.
Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. announced that it will lay off 100 or more workers starting April 1st. The container-board mill laid off approximately 25 workers in February.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. announced it will close a Canadian plant and reduce its U.S. operations in moves that will cut its work force by 1,400. Smurfit-Stone indicated in a statement the moves are needed because of slowing demand for packaging in the U.S. as manufacturing is being shifted overseas. The company plans to permanently close its corrugating medium mill in Thunder Bay, Ontario, and temporarily idle one paper machine in Jacksonville, Fla. The actions will reduce Smurfit-Stone's annual containerboard capacity by about 515,000 tons, or 6 percent. Smurfit-Stone also plans to permanently close a machine at its Philadelphia boxboard mill, which reduce the company's coated boxboard capacity by about 70,000 tons annually, or 12 percent.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. said it is closing four plants in Indiana, California, Texas and Kentucky in a cost-cutting move that eliminates 315 jobs or about 1 percent of its work force. The largest of the plants being shut down in the first quarter of 2004 is in Anderson Ind., where the closing and 143 job cuts were announced earlier this week. The company currently has about 37,500 employees worldwide.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. plans to lay off 1,400 employees contributed to a loss of $208 million last year. The paper-manufacturing company began laying off employees last year and will continue trimming jobs at plants and in corporate offices through the first half of this year.

Jefferson Smurfit Group(Smurfit-Stone Container Corp.) reported that it would close its Smurfit Paper Mill in Clonskeagh, Dublin, with the loss of 58 full-time and 12 part-time jobs. The company said the mill has been in operation for 51 years and it acknowledged the considerable efforts of a skilled and loyal workforce.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. is closing three containerboard mills, two of them in Canada, as part of restructuring efforts - eliminating about 565 jobs. The closures will result in the permanent layoff of about 295 employees at a linerboard mill in New Richmond, Que., and 270 at a mill in Bathurst, N.B. The company also said Thursday it will close its No.2 paper machine at its Fernandina Beach, Fla., linerboard mill, which has been idle since 2001.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. reported earnings results for the third quarter of 2005. For the quarter, the company reported net loss of $229 million. Quarterly net sales fell to $2.1 billion from $2.2 billion a year earlier.

The company announced that it will close up to 20% of its U.S. corrugated-container plants in three years, lay off as many as 3,000 workers and possibly sell part or all of its 7,000-person consumer-packaging operations. The company will close up to 40 corrugated-container plants under the new strategy; it didn't identify them.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. announced plans to permanently cease production at its Pontiac pulp mill in Portage-du-Fort, Quebec. The closure of the mill is targeted for October 31. The closure will result in a workforce reduction of 218 employees, with the company expecting to take restructuring charges in the fourth quarter 2008 totaling approximately $39 million, of which approximately $20 million is non-cash.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. is shutting down its cardboard manufacturing plant at 2525 S. Sunland Ave., in the Calwa neighborhood, as part of a consolidation of its regional operations. About 115 workers at a Fresno container plant are expected to lose their jobs over the next 12 months in a phased-down closure. The company is planning to close the Calwa plant in phases over the course of a year starting Nov. 23.

Smurfit-Stone Container Corp. announced that it intends to lay off 78 workers next month. Smurfit filed a worker adjustment and retraining notification notice Nov. 13 with the state's Agency for Workforce Innovation. The company plans to make the layoffs Dec. 13. The move comes about a year and a half after Smurfit Stone increased production at its Northside containerboard mill after closing mills in Los Angeles and Carthage, Ind.

Johnson & Johnson is cutting about 900 jobs, mainly from its Ortho-McNeil-Janssen Pharmaceuticals unit. The cuts include a mix of attrition and hiring freezes. They are part of the company's strategy to trim its U.S. sales force and refocus its approach in the market. The cuts amount to about 6% of J&J's overall pharmaceutical sales force.

133 jobs are to be lost in Cashel, Co Tipperary with the closure of the Johnson & Johnson facility there. The company has decided to close its factory and cease operations in the town. The company said it was closing the Cashel plant due to its decision to end development and manufacture of a coronary stent as a result of changing market conditions.

Johnson & Johnson is bailing out of the drug-coated heart stent business it pioneered, after seeing sales of its Cypher stent fall steadily since 2006 as rivals rolled out better ones and manufacturing problems vexed development of a successor. The company will lay off up to 1,000 people, close two factories and take a charge of $500 million to $600 million in the current quarter.
Johnson Controls has announced that it plans to layoff 44 employees at its damper manufacturing plant in Watertown by October 2002.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced that it will lay off 150 technical and administrative employees in Holland and Plymouth by the end of March. Milwaukee-based Johnson Controls eliminated 75 similar positions in Holland and Plymouth in October. Each location now has about 1,900 workers.

Automotive supplier, Johnson Controls Inc. plans to transfer sun visor production from its plants here and in Glasgow, Ky., to a Mexican factory, resulting in 885 job cuts. The layoffs will be at the Southview component plant in Holland. The affected workers will be a mix of salaried and hourly employees.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced that more layoffs at York to employees on February 28, 2006, as the company that bought York International continues to transition corporate positions to Milwaukee. The state Department of Labor and Industry announced that it received letters confirming Johnson Controls will terminate six employees at its corporate office and 11 at its York Americas Division office, both located on South Richland Avenue in Spring Garden Township. The positions include human resource specialists, administrative assistants and support technicians. The latest round of layoffs will begin by the end of April and continue through the end of June. The company eliminated 47 administrative and management positions after the purchase, announced another 127 cuts to corporate and supervisory positions last month, and eliminated 28 manufacturing positions associated with production of its big chillers.
Johnson Controls Inc. plans to close its Ossian operation on Nov. 3, 2006.

Johnson Controls Inc. is eliminating about 300 jobs at its operations in Holland. The company said that it is cutting administrative, managerial, engineering and technical personnel at its technical center and support staff at its manufacturing sites. Johnson Controls said the cuts will improve efficiency and lower costs within its interiors business.

Johnson Controls Inc. is to close its interiors facility in Montgomery, Alabama, resulting in the elimination of 170 jobs. Closure of the Montgomery plant is part of JCI s programme of cost reductions across its North American manufacturing operations, but is a little surprising given that the facility was only opened in early 2005 in order to supply Hyundai s nearby new assembly plant. The plant makes interior trim components and centre floor consoles for Hyundai, but in future these components will be supplied from alternative JCI plants in North America.

Johnson Controls Inc. plans to close the York Engineered Systems plant in this northwest Missouri town next spring, eliminating the city's largest employer. The plant, which makes commercial and industrial air handler units, employs 220 people in this city of 1,800.Johnson Controls plans to lay off employees in phases, beginning in the fall, through May 2007.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced plans to cut 2,200 jobs from its auto interiors unit and 5,000 jobs worldwide from throughout all operations as part of a restructuring plan. The company also plans to close 16 plants-10 of them in the North American interiors group. The restructuring plan also takes in three interiors plant closings in Europe, one interiors unit in Asia and two each in the Asian and European building-efficiencies group. It expects to complete the restructuring within 12 months. The company also announced that it planned to stop molding noncore plastics, instead concentrating in-house production on proprietary parts such as interior panels and door panels. That decision is expected to cut 500 jobs, with the work going to outside suppliers.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced that it is eliminating 250 positions at sites in Holland and Plymouth. This is due to declining vehicle-production volumes and increasing material costs in the North American market. The cuts will begin early next month. In Holland, on the other side of the state, the job cuts will be made at a technical center where Johnson Controls eliminated about 300 other positions in April. The facility now employs about 900 people.

Johnson Controls Inc. has announced plans to cut more than 9,000 jobs, consolidating or closing 21 plants.The company announced a new contract to supply batteries to more than 1,000 Checker Auto Parts, Kragen Auto Parts and Schuck's Auto Supply stores nationwide. Shipments begin in February.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced that at its facility in Botetourt County discharged 9 employees. The Botetourt facility is part of Johnson Controls' building efficiency division, which focuses on mechanical systems for heating, ventilating and air conditioning.

Johnson Controls Inc. plans to permanently close its factory in Hudson, in St. Croix County, leaving 51 employees without jobs. Layoffs are expected to begin on December 14, 2011 and continue through February 28, 2012.

Johnson Controls Inc. is cutting an unspecified number of jobs at its corporate headquarters in Glendale in an effort to control costs. The cuts are necessary after the company in January revamped its full fiscal year outlook.

Johnson Controls plans to lay off 310 of its New Jersey employees at five locations, including Bloomsbury in Hunterdon County, as the company weighs alternative options for its automotive division, according to workforce notices filed with the state. Its two Princeton offices along with those in Pennington, Plainsboro, New Brunswick and Bloomsbury will be affected by workforce reductions, all effective July 31, 2015. Layoffs at each location include 111 in New Brunswick, a total of 88 at both of Johnson Controls' Princeton buildings, 83 in Pennington, 17 in Plainsboro and 11 in Bloomsbury.

More than 30 Johnson Controls Inc. workers responsible for various maintenance work at Eastman Business Park will lose their jobs later in 2015. According to a filing with the state Department of Labor, 32 workers will be laid off by Sept. 2015 as the result of the company losing a contract with Eastman Kodak Co. to provide equipment and building maintenance services.

Johnson Controls Inc. announced that it plans to suspend work on a major information technology project, a move that could mean up to nearly 200 layoffs in its West Allis office. The Glendale company announced that its decision will result in up to 197 jobs being cut, beginning on Sept. 30. All positions will be eliminated by Oct. 14.

Johnson Controls announced that it is planning to reduce its global salaried workforce by as many as 3,000 people, or 2.5% of total employees, through comprehensive initiatives designed to ultimately deliver up to $250 million in annual cost savings. These actions will occur over the next two years.

Sears Holdings Corporation is liquidating the inventory of its Sears Grand store in American Fork with an eye toward closing the retail facility for good in late February. The company's American Fork store is being shuttered amid a sharp nationwide pullback in consumer spending, a result of the deepening recession that began in early 2008 and is expected to continue well into this year.

Sears Holdings Corporation intends to close stores in Perrysburg and Bryan in May, ending nearly 120 jobs. The company said that the workers at the two stores will be permanently laid off by May 8, 2009.

Sears Holdings Corporation is laying off about 200 workers at its Hoffman Estates, Ill. headquarters. The company announced the employees, who perform support jobs, represent about 4% of the total work force at the company's base.
Sears Holdings Corp. will close a West Side distribution center with 122 employees Aug. 25. The building at 4533 Fisher Rd., is one of five nationwide that handle apparel and other fashion goods.

Kmart Corp. is closing its Big K store in Gallup, causing about 80 people to lose their jobs, officials said. Tony Zigway, manager of the Big K store, confirmed the store is closing and said the store has 80 employees. Quinones said unemployment is above average in the Gallup area, so we're eliminating 80 jobs.

Sears Holdings Corporation announced plans to close Riverhead store. The store is scheduled to close its doors around the time when its lease expires, March 31, 2006. About 30 people work at the Riverhead store. The company is hosting an internal job fair later this month, and some employees may be offered jobs at nearby Kmart or Sears locations.

Kmart Corp. announced it will cut nearly 700 jobs, including approximately 400 positions at corporate headquarters in Troy, Mich., as the bankrupt discounter continues its turnaround efforts. Kmart has closed 283 stores and cut 22,000 jobs since filing for bankruptcy eight months ago.

Sears Holding Corp.'s Kmart chain will close more than a fifth of its in-store restaurant areas, citing a lack of profits. Kmart will close 188 of its 823 restaurants, including three in Northland Kmarts and one in a Liberty Kmart. The spaces may be used for general merchandise, according to Steven Pagnani, spokesman for Kmart. Kmart will continue to operate in-store restaurants at other locations, many of which are called K Cafe. Kmart doesn't sublet space to other restaurants as some of its competitors do.
The Big Kmart store at 3801 E. Washington Ave. closed ending the jobs of 73 employees.

About 35 accounting employees at the Kmart Corp.'s Troy headquarters were laid off as part of the company's cost-cutting and restructuring efforts, officials said. The layoffs were announced, The Oakland Press of Pontiac reported in a story. Kmart spokesman Jack Ferry said the layoffs were permanent and the employees were offered severance packages.

Sears Holdings Corp. will close an appliance repair facility in Upper Macungie Township in December, part of a companywide effort to bring customer repairs into its stores. Sears Holdings will close its Sears repair center on Snowdrift Road December 1.

Kmart Corp. is eliminating 660 more jobs as part of the bankrupt retailer's efforts to cut costs and reduce the size of its operations. Some 400 jobs will be cut at headquarters, 123 corporate positions will be cut around the country and another 137 vacant positions will be eliminated. Kmart closed 283 underperforming stores, or 13 percent of the total, in the second quarter of 2002.

Westar Energy announced that it will close two coal burning generating plants in Tecumseh and Lawrence and a gas burning plant in Hutchinson, eliminating 40 jobs. The company was forced to close the plants to comply with Environmental Protection Agency regulations for clean air.

Keithley Instruments Inc. has cut 5% of its global work force, including about 17 jobs in Northeast Ohio. The cuts would amount to about 35 people for the maker of measurement instruments, which previously employed close to 700 in the United States, Europe and Asia. The number of job cuts includes layoffs and vacated positions that will not be filled. Keithley employs 425 in Northeast Ohio, almost all at its headquarters in Solon. About half of the positions eliminated were local jobs, primarily in sales, marketing and support. Keithley said the work force reduction will drop operating expenses by about 7% and improve the company's bottom line.
Kellogg Company announced its plans to lay off 620 employees after it purchased the Keebler Foods Company. The majority of the lay offs will be Keebler employees.

Kellogg Co. announced that it is shutting down the Augusta Distribution Center at its Marvin Griffin Road bakery, possibly putting up to 121 warehouse workers and union truck drivers out of work. The move is part of a corporate reorganization of its Southeastern distribution network, which will result in about 300 layoffs. The distribution center will close at the end of September.

The nation's biggest manufacturing site for Kellogg Company's snacks began laying off employees in Cary this morning as part of a corporate reorganization. The company is moving ahead with plans to cut $1 billion in annual costs, but would not disclose the number of local jobs to be cut. The facility manufactures Keebler crakers, Cheez-It crackers, Zoo animal crackers, Austin cookies, among other products. Earlier this year the plant suspended production of all peanut butter products during an outbreak of salmonella that sickened hundreds of people.

The Kellogg's plant in London, Ont., will close by the end of 2014, resulting in the loss of more than 500 full-time jobs. Just last month, the company announced that it was laying off 110 workers by January 2014.

Kellogg Co. announced that it will begin laying off employees at its bakery east of uptown in November 2014 as it moves forward with previously disclosed plans to shut down the operation. A total of 161 employees will be laid off in four phases ending in January at the 933 Louise Ave. site. The company announced that more than 30 employees have already left the plant since February 2014 to pursue other opportunities, while 161 remain employed there. The plant will close in December 2014, but some maintenance employees are expected to remain until January 2015.

Kellogg Co. has upgraded part of the Rossville Eggo plant, allowing it to close less efficient production lines without sacrificing output. Kellogg informed state and Rossville officials that about 155 jobs will be eliminated between this fall and the end of 2017. The reduction would leave Rossville's main industry with about 250 workers. Watters said the job reduction might affect some small businesses, but she believes most employees come from outside the town.

Kellogg Co. plans to cut 250 jobs from its North American operations, the majority of which will affect employees at its headquarters in Battle Creek. The company confirmed it is slashing jobs as a part of Project K, a cost-cutting program by the company. In a statement, the company said it wants to become more efficient and effective to meet the needs of the people who buy foods,?which it hopes to do by eliminating work that doesn't drive the highest returns.

Kellogg announced that it could lay off more than 1,100 employees because of its decision to use grocers' warehouses rather than directly deliver many of its foods to store shelves. The company announced that it plans to begin exiting its direct store delivery network in favor of retailers' warehouses in the second quarter of 2017. As a result, the company will close 39 distribution centers. Closures are expected to be completed by the fourth quarter.

Kellogg Co. announced that it is closing its distribution center in west Charlotte this summer, a move that will result in the loss of over 230 jobs here. It is permanently closing its facility at 1816 West Point Drive Ste. A. The last day of work for most of the 233 affected Charlotte employees is expected to be between July 29 and August 11. Kellogg is also closing its facilities at 657 Brigham Road in Greensboro, and 250 employees will lose their jobs there, the company said in a separate filing.

Kellogg Co. is closing distribution operations and axing 180 jobs in Phoenix. The cuts are part of Kellogg's reconfiguring and reorganizing its distribution channels throughout the U.S. The company is closing distribution centers and nixing jobs in other states. The Phoenix cuts impact distribution, sales and merchandising workers impacted by Kellogg's restructuring.

Kellogg Co. announced that it is closing its Memphis distribution center and laying off 172 of its local employees. The company notified the Tennessee Department of Labor and Workforce Development of the layoffs on Tuesday, May 30, 2017 via a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN). The closure of the facility at 1751 Shelby Oaks Drive is set to take place July 29, according to the WARN. The Memphis closure is part of a larger cost-cutting initiative that is set to impact at least 2,000 Kellogg Co. jobs nationwide, including 500 employees in Pennsylvania, more than 500 in North Carolina, about 420 in Texas, more than 200 in Ohio and about 250 in Florida. With the move, the Michigan-based company is shifting its process to shipping product directly to its customers warehouses rather than to stores - a decision the company announced in February. At the time, Fortune reported the change would impact about 1,100 jobs.

The Kellogg Co. is laying off 230 employees in Roseville as part of a downsizing that includes 510 workers in California. The other 280 layoffs are in La Palma, a small city in Orange County. The layoffs are effective August 4, 2017 in Roseville, and July 29, 2017 in La Palma. The company said it is working to move those employees to new positions with its retail customers.
Kellogg Co. is closing its Union City distribution center, eliminating 181 jobs. The Union City distribution center is located at 3605 Royal South Parkway. The layoffs are effective July 29.

The industrial tool maker Kennametal Inc. will lay off 300 to 340 employees worldwide, or up to 2.4 percent of its work force, a company spokesman announced. The company, which has 14,000 employees, will make the layoffs, which have already begun.
Kennametal Inc. will close its Manchester Tool plant in Akron, Ohio, in March, affecting 87 employees, according to a notice filed with the state of Ohio.

Kennametal Inc. announced in September that it would close a plant in Bentonville, cutting 120 positions, by Dec. 31, 2008. The Bentonville plant will be eliminated in a company restructuring that moves the carbide drill and burr manufacturing currently done there to Asheboro, N.C.

Kennametal plant officials announced on March 25, 2014 that they would close the Lyndonville plant, which employs a total of about 80 people. The last day of production will be June 30, 2014. There are 10 management and 70 manufacturing positions. Labor is represented by the United Steelworkers of America. Lyndon is struggling to develop a fiscally sound water budget and the loss of a commercial water user will not help to stabilize the Towns water and sewer budget either.

Kennametal Inc. announced that it will close its Houston production facility, affecting 65 jobs. The closure process will begin around July 5 and is expected to be complete in October. The facility, at 4435 W. 12th St., is Kennametal's only location in Houston. The company decided to close its Houston operations and relocate production to other North American facilities as part of the companys continual review of its manufacturing operations.

Kennametal Inc. announced the closure of its manufacturing facility in Johnson City, Tennessee. The Johnson City operations will be consolidated into other newly modernized Kennametal facilities. The closure is expected to be completed by the end of fiscal year 2021 and is part of the Companys previously announced fiscal year 2021 Restructuring Actions.

Kerr-McGee Corporation. has decided to close four wood-treating plants Including one in Illinois, and leave the forest products business as it tries to reduce debt and focus on core assets. About 270 jobs will be eliminated when the plants close. Workers at the wood-preserving plants treat railroad cross ties.
The Kimberly Clark mill in Conway intends to fire 140 employees, or 20 percent of the mill's total workforce, within the next six to nine months, because the mill has become more efficient.

Kimberly-Clark will close a paper plant in East Ryegate, Vermont by the end of 2001 and four plants in Latin America over the next 18 months because of weak demand. Approximately 1,400 workers, representing 2 percent of its workforce will lose their jobs.

Kimberly-Clark Corp. announced that it would lay off about 6,000 employees. The company's moves, which will affect about 10% of its staff, are part of a cost-cutting plan that will result in the closure or sale of about 20 factories, mostly in North America and Europe.
Kimberly-Clark Corp. is closing its factory in Forchheim, Germany. The 350 workers at the plant will be informed of the decision.

Last July, Kimberly-Clark Corp. announced plans to close, sell or streamline about 24 facilities and cut about 10% of its worldwide work force. So far, 13 of the 24 plants already have been notified of their future. In the Fox Cities, the company will close its Neenah South plant later this year while expanding its Cold Spring facility in Neenah. About 30 jobs will be lost in that move locally. The initial phase of the cost-savings plan should be complete by mid-2007.

The first wave of layoffs at a Kimberly-Clark Corp. diaper plant left 105 people jobless. Some of the original 130 employees whose jobs at the Lakeview Diaper Plant were eliminated took other positions in the company, early retirement or severance. Kimberly-Clark announced in March it was shuttering the diaper plant and eliminating 510 jobs. The company is also selling or closing the Neenah Nonwovens Plant and cutting its 165 jobs by the end of the year. The cuts are part of a plan to trim 10% of the company's 62,000 workers worldwide.

Kimberly-Clark Corp. will eliminate 85 jobs in Waco and relocate them to India. The move is part of a worldwide restructuring by Kimberly-Clark that involves closing, selling or streamlining 24 facilities. The company will give employees a severance package but will not offer them work elsewhere within the company.

Kimberly-Clark Corporation is cutting 150 workers across its U.S. operations. The affected workers will be notified. This latest round of cuts is part of K-C's June 25 announcement, which noted the company would eliminate 3% or 1,600 positions from its total global work force of 53,000 before year's end in an effort to reduce operating costs during the global economic recession.

Kimberly-Clark Corporation decided to axe 170 full-time and 35 part-time jobs from May. The company announced the cuts were a result of a high Australian dollar and high energy prices which made it hard to compete against imports. Kimberly-Clark says 370 people will still be employed at the Millicent mill and the axed staff will be paid their full entitlements. There will also be 65 jobs lost at the company's Tantanoola pulp mill unless a buyer can be found.

50 jobs will be axed after it was announced a paper towel factory in Flint will shut down. Kimberly-Clark confirmed the redundancies after a four-month consultation with workers. The company is shutting its Delyn Mill plant - which opened in 1989 - this summer. A total of 330 workers, including contractors, are currently employed across the three plants on the site. The neighbouring Coleshill and Flint mills will be unaffected. The majority of job losses - 10 fewer than the original number proposed in October - have been achieved on a voluntary basis.

Kimberly-Clark is cutting 5,000 to 5,500 jobs, or 12% to 13% of its workforce, as the consumer products company tries to lower costs. It plans to close or sell about 10 manufacturing plants while expanding production elsewhere. It's also looking to exit or sell some low-margin businesses that make up approximately 1% of company sales.

The Kroger Co., the supermarket chain, announced that it would cut about 1,500 jobs after reporting that third-quarter earnings had fallen 33 percent because of the sluggish economy and one-time expenses. 

Kroger also lowered its earning forecast for the fourth quarter.
Kroger Co., says it is Eliminating 1,500 management and clerical positions as result of cost reduction process.

Kroger store in Crossroads Center on Dallas Street in Conroe, plans to shutter its windows at 5 p.m. on March 20, 2004. It's a management decision is based on lease agreements more than it is Kroger's reducing its presence in Conroe. There's really nothing more to the closing of the store (in Crossroads Center) other than lease renewal considerations. Kroger has made a significant investment in being the largest (grocery) supplier in Conroe.

Kroger Co. announced that it will close its grocery store at 1800 E. 10th St. and lease the space for $1 a year to Teachers' Treasures. The 16,425-square-foot Kroger store will close March 24. Located in the Woodruff Place neighborhood, it was built in 1958, replacing a sanitarium. Employees will be offered jobs at other stores.

Kroger Co.'s grocery stores on Warwick Boulevard in Newport News and on Lynnhaven Parkway in Virginia Beach are closing May 17. Kroger regularly reviews the performance of its stores and is closing the two stores because they were unprofitable. There are 75 employees at the Newport News store.

The Kroger Co. has announced it is going to close its Marietta, GA ice cream manufacturing facility at the end of January 2012. The facility, which operates under the subsidiary name Southern Ice Cream Specialties, has over 100 employees and is one of three ice cream plants owned by the giant supermarket chain. The company reports that the plant's production can be covered by its other facilities. The consolidation is described as a cost-saving effort that will benefit Kroger's customers. The workers from the Marietta plant will be given the opportunity to work at other Kroger production facilities or stores.

Kroger Co. announced that will close an underperforming Louisville store later in November 2016 that was on track to lose $900,000 in 2017. The 53,000-square-foot Southland Terrace store, at 3917 S. Seventh Street Road, is set to close permanently on November 29, 2016. The store, which opened in 1962, has 108 employees, all of whom have been informed of the company's decision. The company reported that those employees will be offered positions at other Louisville stores at the same wage and benefits.

Kroger Co. is planning to close 14 of its stores in Raleigh-Durham, N.C., as it exits the market. The company announced that the stores will close around Aug. 14. The stores that will close house about 1,500 associates, more than half of whom are employed part time. All of the 14 stores will be sold, including eight of them that will be purchased by Harris Teeter that Kroger acquired for $2.5 billion in 2014. Food Lion will purchase one of the other locations, while Crunch Fitness will purchase another.
Kulicke and Soffa Inds. announced that it has laid off 700 employees.
LSI Corp. announced that it will cut roughly 900 jobs, or 13% of its non-production work force, as part of a restructuring plan.
LTX Corp. announced that it would cut 153 jobs, or 25% of its work force.
La-Z-Boy Inc. announced that it will close its Canadian manufacturing facility in Waterloo, Ontario, on December 16, 2005. The closure will affect 413 people.

La-Z-Boy Inc. announced that it intends to close its four company-owned stores in the Pittsburgh region, as well as a distribution center in Freedom, because of poor sales. The stores in nearby Monroeville, McMurray, McCandless and North Fayette Township weren't meeting the profit expectations that the company have. The closings began with liquidation sales and should be completed in 60 days. La-Z-Boy's products still will be available in other area stores.
La-Z-Boy Inc. announced that it would shut down the plant in the town of Tremont and move some of the jobs to Mexico. It's the town's largest employer. 630 people will lose their jobs.

La-Z-Boy Inc. will move its U.S. cut-and-sew operations to Mexico over the next two years and also will close an upholstery assembly plant in Tremonton. The moves eventually will eliminate nearly 1,300 U.S. jobs and are expected to yield an annual cost savings of more $25 million. U.S. cut-and-sew operations will be transferred to facilities to Ramos Arizpe, Mexico, in the state of Coahuila. That move will result in the elimination of 1,050 U.S. jobs in five upholstery plants. Tremonton, the sixth plant, will be closed this summer and its production work will be shifted to the five other plants. The Utah facility employs 630 and represents 13% of La-Z-Boy's branded upholstery manufacturing capacity, producing recliners, motion and stationary seating.

La-Z-Boy Inc. announced that it was closing its Utah furniture factory. The closing has put 580 employees out of work. La-Z-Boy shifted production to five other facilities in the United States and sent 150 jobs to Mexico. The reluctance to part ways with La-Z-Boy is reflected by the presence of the company's logo on an interior wall. Workers opted against painting over it as they shut down the plant, stacking pallets and equipment neatly against the walls and turning scrap fabric materials into 140 quilts that were donated to a welfare program. La-Z-Boy said Utah workers this spring that the facility would be shuttered in July. But the closing date was moved up because of declining sales. More than 400 employees were laid off June 2. Another 200 worked until the end of June.

La-Z-Boy Inc. will lay off 850 workers as it reported a widening loss for its fiscal second quarter, hurt by a deteriorating economy and historically low customer confidence. The company will cut 850 workers, or about 10% of its work force, and expects between 15 and 20 dealer-owned stores to close in the next 90 to 120 days.

Lawson Products Inc. announced a strategic restructuring, which includes elimination of about 100 positions or 11% from its current workforce. The company expects to record pre-tax charges of around $40 million in the second quarter, of which $33 million will be non-cash. The restructuring actions are expected to generate net annualized savings of nearly $20 million. Lawson Products said it will eliminate several senior executive positions, including the open chief operating officer position. The workforce reduction, which does not include a reduction in its sales force, is expected to result in a one-time severance charge of about $7.0 million for the second quarter of 2012. The one-time non-cash charges of $33 million mainly consist of an impairment of goodwill of $28 million and additional inventory reserves of nearly $5.0 million. Lawson Products noted that the restructuring is aimed at reducing its cost structure, improve operating efficiency, enhance revenues and improve its liquidity position.

Lee Enterprises Inc. is shutting down the Suburban Journals of Greater St. Louis' Donnelly Printing Co. plant in Berkeley, Mo., and will outsource its printing operations to the St. Louis Post-Dispatch's press facility in Maryland Heights in a move that will cost 42 employees their jobs.

Leggett & Platt Inc. announced that it will close the Orthomatic adjustable bed factory at 500 South Falkenburg Road on April 1. All 153 workers will be laid off. Senior employee relations representative Mike Altman said Leggett intended to keep the facility running but decided recently to move the Orthomatic's production to plants in Kentucky and California, where it has excess capacity.

Leggett & Platt Inc. announced that it will lay off 259 workers at two of its plants in northeast Mississippi. The company says that the layoffs will begin in stages around Dec. 8 and are due to a consolidation of operations. The layoffs were announced for the Omega Motion facility in Saltillo and the Super Sagless facility in Tupelo.

Leggett & Platt, Incorporated has closed Whittier manufacturing plant and its entire 20-acre property, including its two buildings is up for sale. Manufacturing of beds and bed parts ceased May 14. The company also is looking to find another location for its operations and distribution site. The company moved its manufacturing to plants in Dallas, Texas and Linwood, N.C.

Leggett & Platt, Incorporated announced restructuring plan primarily associated with its Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses, both of which report within the Furniture Products Segment. The company plan to reduce workforce levels and narrow product offerings in company's Fashion Bed business. In company's Home Furniture business, company plan to downsize or consolidate certain facilities and reduce workforce levels. Company's Fashion Bed and Home Furniture businesses have underperformed expectations in recent quarters primarily from weaker demand and higher raw material costs.

Legg Mason Inc. will cut approximately 350 jobs, or close to 10% of its work force, as part of a companywide restructuring. As part of the job cutting, the company will move some shared services to its affiliates, and expects restructuring charges of $190 million to $210 million in the next 18 months.

Legg Mason Inc. announced that it is cutting roughly 30 jobs, or 3% of its corporate workforce, as part of ongoing changes in the asset management industry. The layoffs are across the Baltimore company's corporate offices and do not include affiliates.
Lennar Corp. announced that it would cut its workforce by 35%, reflecting a steep downturn in the housing market.
Eli Lilly & Co. is news for cutting pharmaceutical jobs as the company signed a new five-year agreement with Thermo Fisher Scientific. Lilly is expected to cut 115 jobs from its work force.

Eli Lilly & Co. planed to cut 200 sales and marketing support jobs in its US biomedicine group, with more than half of those cuts taking place in Indianapolis. The cuts are the latest wave of the drug maker's previously announced plans to chop 5,500 jobs worldwide by the end of 2011 in response to financial pressures. Lilly workers who lose their jobs will have an opportunity to apply for other openings within the company, although openings are limited.

Eli Lilly and Company announced that it is closing its Guayama facility because the patents on some of the drugs made there have expired. That means new competition reached the market and its sales and prices dropped. The company intends to sell the Guayama plant. Lilly said the 100 employees who work there will be offered jobs at another one of its facilities on the island, which are located in Carolina, Puerto Rico. Guayama is in the southeastern part of Puerto Rico, and Carolina is in the northeast.

Limited Brands, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the quarter, the company reported a comparable store sales increase of 7% compared to the fourth quarter ended January 29, 2011. Net sales were $3.515 billion compared to sales of $3.456 billion last year. Total sales were negatively impacted by the sale of third party apparel sourcing business in the beginning of November 2011. Operating income was $641.1 million compared to $713.5 million last year. Income before income taxes was $579,938,000 against $718,033,000 a year ago. Net income was $359.4 million compared to $452.3 million last year. Earnings per diluted share were $1.17 compared to $1.36 last year. Adjusted income before income taxes was $725,341,000 against $666,022,000 a year ago. Adjusted operating income was $786.5 million compared to $713.5 million last year. Adjusted net income was $459.2 million compared to $419.7 million last year. Adjusted earnings per diluted share, which exclude certain significant items as detailed below, increased 19% to $1.50 compared to $1.26 for the quarter ended January 29, 2011. For the year, the company reported a comparable store sales increase of 10% compared to the year ended January 29, 2011. Net sales were $10.364 billion compared to sales of $9.613 billion last year. Operating income was $1.238 billion compared to $1.284 billion in 2010. Income before income taxes was $1,226,476,000 against $1,250,460,000 a year ago. Net income was $850.1 million compared to $804.8 million in fiscal 2011. Earnings per diluted share were $2.70 compared to $2.42 in fiscal 2011. Adjusted operating income was $1.546 billion compared to $1.284 billion in fiscal 2011. Adjusted income before income taxes was $1,301,829,000 against $1,103,066,000 a year ago. Adjusted net income was $817.3 million compared to $684.5 million in fiscal 2011. Adjusted earnings per diluted share, which exclude certain significant items, increased 26% to $2.60 compared to

L Brands Co. plans to close around 250 Victoria's Secret stores in North America over the next several months. The company expects to close more stores in 2021 and beyond. Further, it plans to close 50 Bath Works stores in the U.S. and one in Canada. According to the company, the decision is to strengthen the foundation of Victoria's Secret, which is being separated as a standalone company, to manage through the current crisis of coronavirus pandemic.

L Brands, Inc. announced that it expects to deliver approximately $400 million in annualized cost reductions through its profit improvement plan for Victorias Secret and actions to decentralize and streamline shared corporate and other functions. The company expects to generate these annualized cost reductions through the following: A reduction of its home office headcount by approximately 15%, or about 850 associates, following completion of the previously announced review of its home office organizations in order to achieve meaningful reductions in overhead expenses and decentralize significant shared corporate and other functions and services in support of creating standalone companies. The company is providing a comprehensive benefits package for its departing associates, including severance, continuing access to health benefits and outplacement services, among other support. Reducing Victorias Secret store selling costs through changes in management structure and the labor model. Executing its previously announced plan to close 250 Victorias Secret stores in 2020 while also negotiating with landlords for ongoing rent relief. Actively working to reduce operating losses in the company-owned businesses in the U.K. and China. In the U.K., the company entered into Light Administration?in June in order to restructure lease agreements and explore the sale of the business to a joint venture or franchise partner. The company subsequently signed Heads of Terms with a major fashion retailer and is in an exclusive period of negotiation. In China, the company closed its unprofitable store in Hong Kong, is close to resolution to either close or restructure lease terms on other unprofitable stores and has implemented a significant overhead expense reduction plan.

Lincoln National Corp. has cut 5% of its workforce. About 550 of the financial services company's 10,870 workers lost their jobs because of the continued market volatility and the economic environment.

Lincoln National Corp. announced that it is considering further job eliminations as it moves to reduce costs, which, when added to earlier moves, are expected to save it about $250 million by the end of this year. The company initiated a company-wide restructuring effort at the end of last year, which at the time was expected to save it about $150 million by the end of 2009. The additional actions should increase savings to about $250 million, pretax.

Liz Claiborne Inc. will close its distribution center and outlet store here, eliminating about 340 jobs, company officials said Tuesday. The outlet and distribution center, located about seven miles south of Montgomery, will close in about 60 days. The company said the closings reflect a re-evaluation of strategies and customer service needs. Work from the 635,000 square-foot distribution center will shift to other facilities.

Liz Claiborne Inc. said that it planned to close its Mexx European catalog business and a distribution center in Secaucus, N.J. The company said that it would take a charge of as much as $11 million in the fourth quarter, mostly for employee severance. More than 100 jobs would be eliminated. Liz Claiborne also said that it had agreed to sell the 1.5 million shares that it owns in Kenneth Cole Productions, resulting in a pretax gain of about $12 million.

Liz Claiborne Inc. plans to cut 4% of its workforce and close 20 stores as part of a plan to streamline operations toward a more centralized sales approach. The apparel company will eliminate 500 jobs, with significant staff reductions at more senior levels of the organization.

Liz Claiborne Inc. announced that it plans to cut 600 to 800 jobs and is considering whether it should sell 16 brands in a bid to cut costs and focus on profitable lines. Under its restructuring plan, Claiborne expects to save $100 million in 2008 and an additional $90 million over the following two years. It plans to cut 600 to 800 jobs, or 7% to 9% of its non-retail based global work force, including cutting senior positions.

For fiscal 2007, the company expects adjusted earnings of between $1.90 and $2 per share, compared with a previous forecast of $1.90 to $2.05 per share, with adjusted net sales expected to be flat to down in the low-single digits from last year.The company provided earnings guidance for the full year of 2008. The company expects adjusted earnings between $2.35 and $2.50 per share on revenue of $4.2 billion to $4.3 billion. The company expects annual revenue growth in the high-single digits and earnings per share growth in the high teens over the long term.

Lockheed Martin Corporation will cut around 200 jobs from three space facilities in October as the space shuttle program winds down. The layoffs will occur at the NASA Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans, the Marshall Space Flight Center at Huntsville, Ala., and the Kennedy Space Center in Florida. In April, NASA announced that more than 8,000 contractor jobs in the nation's manned space program could be eliminated after the shuttle program ends in favor of the Constellation program, which is developing the next-generation vehicle and rockets to go to the moon and later to Mars.

Lockheed Martin Corp. announced that several hundred workers who assemble F-16 fighter jets could lose their jobs this year end as the company reverses course after a three-year hiring boom. Some of the workers could be assigned to other positions but Lockheed's F-35 joint strike fighter is behind schedule and unable to absorb a large number of jobs.
Lockheed Martin Corp. has announced may layoff an undisclosed number of employees as a result of losing the contract, to build NASA's Next Generation Space Telescope.
Lockheed Martin Corp. has announced that it will cut 400 jobs, or about 4.2 percent of its work force, at its Missiles & Space Operations by the end of 2002.

Lockheed Martin Corporation to lay off 51 employees at Naval Air Station Corpus Christi this summer once its defense contract expires. The company intends to cease operations and conduct layoffs on a periodic basis through July 31, when the government contract expires.

Longs Drug Stores Corp. announced that it will close 31 stores in four Western states in 2007 while opening or moving up to 30 other outlets and remodeling 40 more. The store closures will eliminate the drug store operator's presence in Colorado, Washington and Oregon, where the company has a total of 23 stores. California will lose eight locations.
 
 The company reported earnings results for the fourth quarter ended Jan. 25, 2007. For the quarter, the company reported profits slid to $26.94 million or 71 cents per share from $35.42 million, or 93 cents per share, during the same period last year. 
 The company announced that its profits were hurt by lower prescription drug payments from Medicare, but it improved store merchandise and distribution methods and increased revenues from its Rx America division.

Louisiana-Pacific Corp. announced that it will permanently close operations at its Woodland, Maine, OSB mill on April 15. The company said the closure is due to high long-term costs associated with significant capital investment required to keep the mill competitive and meet upcoming MACT requirements.

Lubrizol Corp. plans to cut 150 jobs, or 3 percent of its 5,200 work force, by the end of the year. The cuts will result in about $15 million in savings starting in 2004. Lubrizol will take a $13 million restructuring charge in the fourth quarter. Lubrizol will cut about 100 jobs at its Wickliffe headquarters, around 25 to 30 from its manufacturing plants in Deer Park and Bayport, Texas, and about 20 from its plant in Hazelwood, England.

The company changed its 2003 earnings expectation to $1.72 to $1.82 per share, including restructuring costs. Previously, Lubrizol had been expecting earnings of between $2 and $2.10 per share, excluding charges. Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call are expecting 2003 earnings of $2.09 per share.

Lubrizol Corp. announced its decision to close its Niagara Falls, Ontario facility, a Lubrizol Additives blending, packaging and warehouse site. After careful review of its operations and evaluation of different business strategies, the company determined that operation of the facility is not sustainable for the long term, under current and anticipated market conditions. Operations at the facility are expected to end by June 30, 2009. The Lubrizol Additives sales office in Oakville, Ontario and the Lubrizol Advanced Materials facility in Waterloo, Ontario will remain open. The Niagara Falls site, part of Lubrizol Canada Limited, has been in operation since 1953 and was established to serve the Canadian market as an additive blending, warehousing and bulk terminal operation. Since the early 1990s, the facility has undergone several restructuring activities as a result of capacity rationalization initiatives. The operation currently focuses on toll blending, packaging, bulk storage and warehousing of materials.

Luby's Inc. will close about 50 restaurants as part of a two year business plan designed to return the company to profitability, company officials announced Monday. The San Antonio based company will focus on its Texas markets and close underperforming stores Including two in Tulsa, one in Oklahoma City and a store in Fort Smith, Ark.

General Electric Co announced that it was cutting 262 more jobs at its Lufkin oil unit in Texas and closing a foundry as it grapples with the plunge in global oil prices. GE earlier this year said it planned to eliminate some 575 jobs from Lufkin, bringing the total cuts to more than 800. The jobs will be eliminated across two sites in Angelina County, Texas.

Lydall, Inc. announced the ramp-down of its manufacturing facilities in Hamptonville and Yadkinville, North Carolina; Meinerzhagen, Germany; and St. Nazaire, France in response to a number of Lydalls largest automotive OEM customers having temporarily ceased operations due to the impact of the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic on the global economy. As a result of these actions and a government-mandated shutdown in Pennsylvania, more than 500 U.S. employees will be laid off and nearly 500 employees in Europe have been asked to stay home.

MDU Resources Group Inc. has laid off 7 employees in its Bismarck corporate office after the sale of its oil company. In addition to the layoffs, two other Bismarck employees took voluntary retirement packages and 15 unfilled positions were eliminated from 160 total positions at the corporate office.

MTS Systems Corp. announced a workforce reduction as part of its efforts to align the business with current market and economic conditions while maintaining the ability to successfully execute its strategy. The company-wide workforce reduction will affect approximately 150 positions, about 6% of MTS' employee base, through a combination of attrition, cancellation of open positions and layoffs of current staff. As a result, the Company expects to take a pretax charge of $2.5 to $3.5 million related to severance and facilities in the second quarter of fiscal 2009, ending March 28, 2009.

Manitowoc Co. Inc. has cut deep into its workforce and plans to eliminate about 40% of the jobs in its largest division, which builds construction cranes. The company announced demand across businesses continues to be weak, especially in the cranes segment, which is causing it to operate at production levels well below its capacity.

The Manitowoc Co. Inc. informed state of Wisconsin officials that 50 employees in its food service division in Manitowoc will be laid off beginning August 1, 2014. The company filed a mass layoff notice related to its March announcement that it is cutting 150 jobs in Manitowoc by the end of 2015 because it is relocating production of its Indigo line of ice machines to a plant in Monterrey, Mexico. Employees are represented by the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Local No. 516.
Marathon Oil Co. plans to reduce its staff from 42 to 12 in Anchorage, Alaska, as part of a corporate restructuring.

Marsh & Mclennan Companies Inc. unveiled plans for another 2,500 job cuts worldwide as it battles to recover from last fall's scandal over alleged price-fixing. The latest layoffs will take total job cuts to 5,200 in four months.

Masco Corp., the owners of Heritage Ceramics, based at Armytage Road, said it was proposed to close the site following a review of company operations. The company said it is set to close with the loss of 43 jobs. If the proposal goes ahead, a potential consequence is that 18 positions may be redundant at the Heritage Ceramics site in Brighouse at the end of this month. The remaining positions would be redundant at the end of November, 2009, with the potential closure of the Brighouse Ceramics site.

Metaldyne Corp. announced that it has decreased its U.S. employment to 8,500 at the beginning of 2003 from about 11,000 in January 2001, partly as a result of the steel tariffs. Another 300 jobs will be cut in the coming months.

Metaldyne Corp. announced that it will close its Farmington Hills, Mich., plant by April 2008 to adjust for the excess capacity in its plants caused by production cuts from its North American customers.

Material Sciences Corporation announced the reorganization of three of its continuing operations into a single business unit resulting in a 13 percent reduction in its salaried employees. This is in order to cut costs.
Material Sciences Corp. has announced that the company will close its Pinole Point Steel plant following the sale of the plant. The closure will affect 220 employees.

Mattel Inc. announced that it will cut more than 200 jobs in the first quarter of this year, continuing a consolidation of its business that began last fall. The jobs will largely be cut from the company's headquarters in El Segundo, Calif. and represent about 1% of Mattel's worldwide staff. The cuts will be made through a combination of layoffs, attrition, retirements and elimination of open positions.

Mattel announced that it will cut more than 2,200 jobs as the maker of Barbie dolls and Hot Wheels cars seeks to save money. Like other toy companies, Mattel has lost sales as Toys R Us faltered. The toy retailer filed for bankruptcy protection last year, announced it was liquidating its business in March and then closed all its stores last month.
May Department Stores Company has announced that it plans to eliminate 100 jobs, approximately ten percent of its corporate headquarters staff, due to weak sales.

Nearly 500 former May Department Stores Co. workers collected a severance check and lost their jobs as the retailer's operations were folded into those of Federated Department Stores Inc. The job losses are the latest chapter in Federated's takeover of St. Louis-based May. The local employees, who worked for May's corporate offices in downtown St. Louis or in the May Merchandise Co., either did not receive or refused job offers from Cincinnati-based Federated, the St. Louis Post-Dispatch reported.

Maytag Corp. announced that it plans to sell its plant in Jefferson City, laying off 45 employees, approximately 64 percent of its work force, as transfer its refrigeration manufacturing operations to Iowa in order.

The appliance maker Maytag Corp. said that it would close a refrigeration-parts plant in Galesburg Ill., eliminating 1,600 jobs, or about 8 percent of its work force. The company said it planned to start closing the plant next year and complete the shutdown by late 2004. Some salaried workers from the factory will be offered jobs at other Maytag locations, a company spokesman said.

Maytag Corp. plans to phase out production of top freezer refrigerators at its Galesburg, Ill., plant this year, said Kevin Waetke, a company spokesman. The plant, which Maytag has operated since 1986, employs about 1,600 people. Layoffs and a decrease in production are planned to start in the second half of 2003 and the plant will close late next year, Waetke said.

Maytag Corp. plans to end all production at its western Illinois refrigerator plant in September, two months earlier than scheduled. Company spoksman said the decision to end production early was made because market demand for the top-mount units sagged. Although the facility will remain open until the end of the year, only a minimal number of workers will remain once production ends. Layoffs already have pared the plant's work force to about 1,000 employees.

Maytag Corp. announced a tentative plan to slash as many as 378 positions in North Canton and close an entire SteamVac production line there. Those cuts would be on top of the 500 salaried employees in North Canton who lost their jobs last year and the hundreds of production workers who were laid off before that. Many workers were shocked to learn that Maytag wants to move one SteamVac production line to Texas or Mexico. The SteamVac was one product they thought North Canton would always have and Hoover's nonunion plants would never get.

Maytag corp. plans layoffs in North canton. The company has already chopped hundreds of jobs across the country and reduced retiree health care benefits. More cuts are coming, particularly at plants in North Canton and Newton.

Maytag Corp. announced that it would close a laundry plant in South Carolina, affecting about 60 employees. The company expects to record charges of $40 million to $50 million as a result of the closure.

About 65 workers at the Maytag Corp. washer and dryer factory in Newton, Iowa, were laid off. It was the second round of layoffs in two months. About 50 workers were laid off Feb. 24. The reduction leaves a workforce of about 950 people, the lowest level at Newton in nearly 60 years. The plant's workforce was 2,600 in 2001. Whirlpool said the layoffs were the result of market demand for the machines made at Newton. United Auto Workers Local 997, said the layoffs had been planned before Whirlpool completed its purchase of Maytag in March.

McCormick & Co. Inc. will cut an unspecified number of jobs across its global spice operation, consolidate manufacturing facilities, revamp its struggling industrial business and cut administrative costs as part of a plan to rebound from a disappointing year. The world's largest spice maker is expected to take charges against earnings of between $130 million and $150 million, with about 60% coming from severance and other personnel costs. The cuts will take place in phases over three years and are expected to save $ 50 million annually beginning in 2008.

McDermott International announced it would close its fabrication yard in Morgan City, Louisiana and consolidate operations in Altamira, Mexico. The facility in St Mary Parish was a stalwart of offshore construction for decades, employing thousands at its peak and building many deepwater projects, including the pioneering deepwater platform Cognac, Shell's Auger tension-leg platform and topsides to UK supermajor BP's massive Thunder Horse production unit. The company has taken this move after business struggled deeply in recent years with competitive labour costs from abroad including Asia and Mexico.

McDonald's Corp. has announced that the company has cut 500 to 700 jobs, representing 10 percent of the company's US corporate employees. The job cut is a result of the company's effort to streamline its domestic organization by reducing the number of div

McDonald's Corp. has closed all 23 company-owned Donatos Pizza outlets in the Atlanta market. Penney said the units were closed earlier this week due to disappointing sales. McDonald's acquired the Columbus, Ohio, pizza business in 1999 and has expanded it to about 200 units in seven states. The chain focuses on the dining-out pizza market, which Penney noted has fallen upon hard times.

McDonald's Denmark said it will close 13 Danish restaurants and lay off 371 workers, part of the company's global restructuring plan. Last month, McDonald's Corp., based in Oak Brook, Ill., said it would close 175 restaurants in 10 countries, and restructure or cease operations in seven Middle Eastern and Latin American nations, eliminating 600 jobs. The company didn't say when the closings in Denmark would start. McDonald's Denmark chose to close restaurants that were too small to be profitable or were no longer strategically located because of changes in traffic patterns.
The Japanese unit of U.S. fast food chain McDonald's Corp. will cut 146 jobs, sell or close its Pret a manager sandwich restaurants here and focus on its core burger business.

McDonald's Korea began procedures to close down the first store it ever opened in the country due to leasing contract renewal issues. The local operation of the world's largest burger chain said Korea's first McDonald's shop, which opened in the swanky Rodeo Street of Apgujeong in southern Seoul in 1988, served customers for the last time. McDonald's Korea said demand for higher rent prompted it to shut its doors on Rodeo Street, despite its wish to be able to preserve the country's first store.

McDonald's Corp.'s Yorkshire Street restaurant will shut in three weeks time. No staff will be made redundant but bosses have decided to close after seeing trading patterns change. The restaurant will be closing on November 19, 2011.

Courts have suspended operations of two McDonald's restaurants in Moscow for 90 days. The Tverskoy Court closed the restaurant on the Manezhnaya Square near the Red Square for violating the sanitary requirements for public catering. Moreover, the Ostankinsky Court shut down the restaurant on the Prospekt Mira avenue in northeastern Moscow for three months, having upheld the motion filed by the Federal Service for Surveillance on Consumer Rights Protection and Human Wellbeing. On August 20, the consumer rights watchdog temporarily closed four McDonald's restaurants in Moscow, including the landmark restaurant on Pushkinskya Square that opened on January 31, 1990. After that McDonald's restaurants were inspected across Russia, with some of them having been shut down and others instructed to rectify violations. Specifically, McDonald's restaurants suspended operations in the cities of Kazan, Yekaterinburg, and Stavropol.

McDonald's has permanently closed a restaurant for the first time in its 25-year history in Russia. The restaurant, located south of Moscow, was closed after McDonald's and the property's owner failed to agree on rental payments.

McDonald's is laying off 70 people at its Columbus office. The layoffs are part of an overall restructuring of the company that was announced last year. The layoffs will take place in phases, 26 people in its accounting office on July 15, followed by 27 employees on Aug. 12, 6 on Sept. 16, and 10 on Oct. 14. The final layoff is expected to occur Dec. 16, 2016.
McDonald's announced that it plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs as part of a restructuring to save $500 million (SGD 668 million) and boost its US business.

McDonald's is permanently closing 200 of its 14,000 U.S. locations this year, with 'low-volume restaurants' in Walmart stores making up over half of the closures. During its quarterly earnings call, the fast food giant said the closings were previously planned for future years but are being accelerated. Officials also shared the continued impact the coronavirus pandemic is having on sales globally.

The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc. said that it would cut about 925 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, to reduce costs after ad sales slowed. McGraw-Hill said about 575 jobs would be cut in its education business and another 300 would come from the information and media operation.

Job cuts are coming at BusinessWeek and Forbes magazines. An unspecified number of employees at The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc. BusinessWeek were told this week they would be losing their jobs, Reuters reported.

McGraw-Hill Cos. has cut 500 jobs, mainly at BusinessWeek and its educational-testing unit. McGraw-Hill said it made the cuts to lower costs and reallocate resources. It closed some regional editions of BusinessWeek in Europe and Asia. It restructured its CTB/McGraw-Hill testing unit to move resources from its California operations to new regional offices, and consolidated technology and finance services.

The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc. is cutting more than 600 jobs, resulting in a fourth-quarter charge of $43.7 million. The 611 job cuts will come across the company's divisions and will reduce its after-tax earnings by 8 cents per share. About half of the job cuts will come in its education division. McGraw-Hill attributed the cuts in its financial services division to current business conditions, which were affecting both the credit ratings services and other businesses of Standard & Poor's.

The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc. announced that will cut 395 jobs, or 2% of its global workforce, in its financial services and education segments. The cuts reflect the current credit market environment as well as the consolidation of several support functions. 246 of the eliminated positions are in financial services and 149 in education.The company backs previously issued year 2008 EPS guidance of $2.65 to $2.75, which excludes the restructuring charge and associated benefits.

The McGraw-Hill Companies, Inc. will shut its office at Easton Town Center and combine it with its Polaris operation as part of a cost- and job-cutting consolidation. McGraw-Hill is splitting its education and financial businesses into separate public companies, and cutting 10% of its education work force, or about 550 positions. The 550 jobs include a 20% reduction in the education business executive ranks, but the New York-based company has not enumerated how many executive jobs will be eliminated. More than a year ago, McGraw-Hill was adding positions to its preschool-to-12th-grade School Education Group in Central Ohio as it combined offices from New York, Georgia and California in Columbus. The company was poised then to add jobs at Polaris and Easton through 2013, but it has not disclosed how the nationwide cuts will play out in Central Ohio. The company expects most of the job cuts to be complete by the end of the year, with some occurring early next year. The company also plans to freeze its pension plan and said it intends to focus its retirement program on market-competitive offerings. The retirement plan changes combined with job cuts should save the company about $50 million of the $100 million it expects to cut next year.
McKesson Corp. announced that it plans to lay off about 90 workers in its Rancho Cordova data center. Mainly the programmers and support staff will be affected by this move.

McKesson Corp. will phase out 79 jobs - all in the Information Technology area - from its Dubuque operation in a move that some local officials say is a brutal blow to the health of the area economy. The company announced that its plans to cut about 20% of jobs at the local facility and move the rest of the employees out of their current Dubuque Building location.

McKesson confirmed the dismissal of 174 employees. The jobs are of: software engineers, systems analysts, project managers. The layoffs result from a change in software systems provided to hospitals to streamline operations and reduce costs.
McKesson has laid off 60 workers at its Charlotte office. The company has confirmed the layoffs as part of an expense reduction move involving its information business.

Media General Inc. will lay off about 70 employees at the Tampa Tribune, its largest newspaper, as it cuts costs and focuses on additional local coverage to keep readers. The company has also decided not to fill some positions at the paper, and will cut 15 jobs at local Florida television station WFLA. The Tribune employs about 1,335 employees. No additional job cuts are planned for other Media General properties, which include the Richmond Times Dispatch and the Winston-Salem Journal in North Carolina. The Tribune will also shrink its page width by half an inch, combine several sections in its Friday and Sunday editions to lower costs and stop distributing the paper in Citrus, Manatee and Hardee counties.

Media General Inc. announced that it will cut its work force some 11% by October. The company reported that around 745 publishing positions would be eliminated, 60 in interactive media and 45 in the broadcast division. The planned cuts equate to annualized savings of $40 million.
Media General, Inc. laid-off 29 jobs. The layoff included 20 employees from back-office operations and nine from the newsroom, including members of the Tribune's feature staff.

Medtronic Inc. plans to cut 350 to 500 jobs within its cardiac rhythm disease management division. The company is attempting to achieve the cuts through voluntary measures. Employees will be given the option of transfers to other areas of the company, early retirements or voluntary buyout packages. Options on job sharing, part time work and alternative arrangements are also being explored for workers in affected positions.
Medtronic Inc. announced that as part of a restructuring plan it will lay off 450 employees. It is planning on consolidating certain manufacturing operations in Europe and U.S.

Medtronic announced that it had laid off 450 workers at its plant in Santa Rosa, California, representing about 1.7 percent of its 26,000 workers worldwide. This was announced after a court ruled that it could not sell an artery-clearing tool in the Unite

Mellon Financial Corp. said it would eliminate 650 jobs in the face of continuing economic weakness. The layoffs are in addition to the 1,500 or so positions eliminated as a result of a $300 million cost-cutting initiative announced by Chairman Marty McGuinn in 2001.

Drugstore giant CVS Corp. has announced it is pulling out of the Toledo and Canton markets and is closing scattered stores in the Cincinnati, Cleveland, Dayton, and Akron areas. A spokesman for the Woonsocket, R.I.-based chain said that it would shutter 16 stores in the Toledo area - 15 in Ohio and one in Monroe, Mich. The closings will cost between 240 and 320 jobs.

CVS Caremark Corp. to eliminate more than 400 jobs when it shutters a Phoenix mail-order prescription center early next week. The company cited changing business demands and the $27 billion merger of CVS and Caremark earlier this year. The center employs 423 employees, but about 100 of those workers will be reassigned to other positions within the company. Laid-off workers will receive a severance and health-benefits package plus outplacement support and counseling. The layoffs are expected to occur through March 31. A similar-sized center in Fort Worth, Texas, is also set to close.

Mentor Graphics Corp. has decided to reduce its workforce in India. The company has two research and development centres in Noida and Hyderabad employing 350 engineers. It also has a sales and service centre in Bangalore. It has asked 50-60 employees in Hyderabad to leave by the end of Apr. 2009. Some of the employees have been absorbed in other projects and a few have been given the option to move to the US.

Mentor Graphics Corp. announced that it will reduce its global workforce by 4% in a broad restructuring, partly through an early-retirement program for longtime employees. The company had 5,558 employees at the end of January, including more than 1,000 in Oregon. So a 4% cut would eliminate more than 220 jobs. It was at immediately clear how many of the cuts are in Oregon, where the company employs about 1,000. The job reductions include 110 workers in North America who took a previously announced early retirement offer from company. About 60 of them are in Oregon. These restructuring activities will enable Mentor to focus personnel and resources on priority opportunities and regions of the world, deliver long-term growth and build shareholder value. The company it will take a $37 million charge to cover the restructuring, including $34 million in the current quarter.

Mercantile Bankshares Corp. plans to consolidate most of the operations of its recent acquisition, F&M Bancorp into either its subsidiary, Mercantile Bank & Trust, or one of its other units. This will lead to the closure of 21 branches from the combined c

PNC Financial Services Group is laying off several hundred workers in the Maryland area at Mercantile Bankshares Corp. The Mercantile jobs being cut are redundant with ones at PNC and will be eliminated by the end of the year. The jobs include back-office operations, and corporate support and administration. A small number of jobs might relocate to Pittsburgh. The action is expected to save about $100 million a year in operating costs, after $40 million in merger-integration costs that include severance.

Merck & Co. Inc. announced the closing of five manufacturing plants out of 31 worldwide, trimming workforces at others and closing three research labs. In all, Merck will eliminate 11% of its 63,000 jobs.
Merck & Co. Inc. announced that it will cut 7,000 workers globally, or 11% of its workforce after a three-year decline in earnings.

Merck & Co. announced plans to cut an additional $1-billion (U.S.) in costs through 2010 and focus its research on medicines for the most common diseases. The struggling drug maker, which has been hammered by mounting lawsuits, falling revenue and profit, and sharply depressed stock as generic competition looms for its top drug, also reaffirmed its earnings forecasts for this year and next. The new cost cuts, to be achieved through redesigning business operations, were disclosed at Merck's annual business briefing with analysts at its New Jersey headquarters. They follow Merck's Nov. 28 announcement that it will eliminate 7,000 jobs and close or sell eight factories and research facilities to lower expenses by $3.5-billion to $4-billion through the decade's end.

Merck & Co. Inc. has revealed plans to trim its US sales representative workforce by around 15%. The move comes as part of the strategy of the company, which is based in Whitehouse, New Jersey, to cope with growing competition from the generic drug arena and low insurance compensations. The job cuts also follow regulatory rejection of an experimental medicine.
