Merck & Co. announced that it will contract out some of its sales work to deal with short-term vacancies in the U.S. sales force, months after it eliminated about 15% of that staff. Merck eliminated about 1,200 salespeople early this summer as revenue was hurt by questions about the effectiveness and price of Vytorin and Zetia, cholesterol drugs it jointly sells with partner Schering-Plough. In addition, an experimental cholesterol treatment they were hoping to launch was rejected by the Food and Drug Administration. The drugmaker has retained inVentiv Health to help it in its latest efforts. InVentiv provides sales, communications, market analysis, clinical trial management and other support to all top 20 global pharmaceutical manufacturers and dozens of other drugmakers and biotech companies.

Merck & Co. Inc. would close its Rosetta research site in Seattle by the end of next year and eliminate or transfer about 240 jobs. The South Lake Union facility houses 300 employees, most doing research at Rosetta Inpharmatics, and others at Rosetta Biosoftware developing software for biopharmaceutical companies. Merck bought Rosetta for about $630 million in 2001.

Merck & Co. Inc. announced that it has completed a restructuring begun in December 2005 and has slimmed down by 10%, from 61,500 employees then to 55,200 at the end of 2008. The company expects to lay off about 5,300 more workers under a new restructuring announced in October.

Merck & Co. Inc. announced that it is shutting down eight manufacturing plants and eight research sites around the world, including two domestic locations, in the latest phase in its strategic pruning of operations. The moves, which include consolidating some offices, are part of ongoing consolidation following Merck's acquisition of Schering-Plough Corp. in November 2009. That deal made Merck but the company said it would eliminate about 15% of the combined work force, or roughly 16,000 jobs. Those cuts are intended to save the Whitehouse Station, N.J., company about $3.5 billion a year, starting in 2012. Merck said that the restructuring plans announced so far will bring savings of about $2.7 billion to $3.1 billion in 2012, most of its target.

Merck announced it would transform the former Schering-Plough campus in Kenilworth into a research center and slowly wind down the manufacturing unit. The company confirmed it had sent layoff notices to the final 113 employees in a manufacturing division that once was many times that number. The facility will be shuttered by October.

Meredith Corp. has announced changes to the company's Books Division, most notably the elimination of 15 jobs. The Des Moines, Iowa-based company will keep approximately 100 employees. According to the AP, Meredith hopes to refocus its book publishing program, concentrating on areas including cooking, crafts, building, gardening and remodeling, where it has previously had success. Recently, the company expanded to publish children's books and single-author titles.

Meredith Corp. announced that, it will eliminate 250 jobs, or about 7% of its work force, as the recession cuts into advertising revenue at its magazines and television stations. About 100 of the eliminated jobs are in Des Moines, where the company's headquarters is located. The remaining 150 are elsewhere in the country. The company said, it will close Country Home magazine and relocate art and editorial jobs of ReadyMade magazine from Berkeley, Calif., to Des Moines. Creative positions at Parents.com in New York will also relocate to Des Moines. The company said, magazine has about 1.2 million subscribers. Closing it accounts for about 20 of the jobs cut in Des Moines. Another 20 positions in New York will be eliminated.
Meredith Corp. announced that it will cut about 45 jobs and take a charge during the second quarter as it retools its special interest media division.
Merrill Lynch & Co. has announced that the company will close as many as 25 trust centers throughout the United States and eliminate about 25 jobs.

Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. eliminated 9,000 jobs in the U.S. and overseas during the past year as part of a plan to reduce costs by $1.4 billion amid a slump on Wall Street. The company said half the job cuts are from divestitures and discontinued business and half are from voluntary separations and layoffs.
Merrill Lynch & Co. has announced that it plans to cut about 100 investment- banking jobs and 25 equity trading jobs. The firm might also cut about 80 equity sales jobs in Tokyo.
Merrill Lynch & Co. has announced that it will move all Nasdaq trading to its New York headquarters and shut down the office in Jersey City, laying off an unspecified number of employees.

Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. is cutting about 400 jobs in its private client group, citing the weak economic environment. The investment bank is laying off 250, or about 4 percent, of its 6,500 client associates, who assist financial advisers. About 150 of the support staff are also being cut. Merrill, which had 53,400 employees at the end of the third quarter, has reduced its staff by 18,600 since 2000. The New York company said it believed the bulk of its reductions were past.

According to unconfirmed reports, Merrill Lynch & Co. may cut 150 jobs, or 15 percent of its workforce, from its investment banking unit. The cuts are likely to affect all industry and product groups in the approximately 1,000-person division.

Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. plans to announce about 1,600 layoffs after disclosing fourth-quarter write-downs. The layoffs are likely to be in trading positions and related areas, and will not likely include investment banking or private client groups. The company had about 64,000 employees as of the end of September, so the potential for 1,600 layoffs would represent less than 3% of the company's workforce.
Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. has started implementing job cuts at its Australian investment lending unit. About 10 positions are reportedly earmarked for elimination in the unit.

Bank of America Corporation announced that as part of a plan to reduce its headcount by 35,000, it has cut roughly 1,900 staffers in London following its merger with Merrill Lynch. The layoffs affect both BofA and Merrill employees. The job cuts are across all business divisions. One-quarter of the combined BofA and Merrill leveraged loan team, around 40 people, was cut. Moreover, 120 people in fixed income sales and one-third of the equity sales staff were also let go. Earlier, the bank cut two top Merrill professionals from its Asia-Pacific debt capital markets team: Ajay Sawhney, head of Asian leveraged finance, and Jon Pratt, head of Asia debt capital markets outside Japan and Australia. Other top Merrill people to have left recently include former head of US leveraged finance Greg Margolies, former president and chief operating officer Greg Fleming, former wealth management chief Bob McCann and ex-chairman and CEO John Thain, who resigned after BofA reportedly lost confidence in him.

Bank of America Corporation announced that as part of a plan to reduce its headcount by 35,000, it has cut roughly 1,900 staffers in London following its merger with Merrill Lynch. The layoffs affect both BofA and Merrill employees. The job cuts are across all business divisions. One-quarter of the combined BofA and Merrill leveraged loan team, around 40 people, was cut. Moreover, 120 people in fixed income sales and one-third of the equity sales staff were also let go. Earlier, the bank cut two top Merrill professionals from its Asia-Pacific debt capital markets team: Ajay Sawhney, head of Asian leveraged finance, and Jon Pratt, head of Asia debt capital markets outside Japan and Australia. Other top Merrill people to have left recently include former head of US leveraged finance Greg Margolies, former president and chief operating officer Greg Fleming, former wealth management chief Bob McCann and ex-chairman and CEO John Thain, who resigned after BofA reportedly lost confidence in him.

Merrill Lynch & Co. Inc. has closed its private equity business in Japan. The firm announced that it has closed its private equity business in Japan and attributed the decision to the worsening economy.
BofA Merrill Lynch will cut roughly 20% of its 75 managing directors in Asia-Pacific region through layoffs, transfers and early retirements by end of March, 2012.

Merrill Lynch & Co., Inc. has asked more than two dozen employees at its wealth management unit to leave as the stock market slowdown worsens and the economy continues to be sluggish. About 32 people at the wealth management unit have been told to look for jobs. The retrenched employees include some advisors and support staff.

Micron Technology Inc. announced on Tuesday that it is laying off 10 percent of its worldwide labor force of over 18,000.
It is the first layoff the Boise based company has imposed since 1985, seven years after it was founded. Appleton said the layoffs will be proportional throughout the corporate system. Micron has about 11,000 employees in Boise, making it the states largest private employer.

Although it will be a blow to the 560 Micron Technologies Inc. workers in Manassas who were laid off last week. Micron said last week that the cuts at its Manassas plant were part of the company's effort to reduce its worldwide workforce by 10 percent. The job cuts represent more than half of the 1,000 Micron employees at the Manassas plant, between Godwin Drive and Nokesville Road. Micron said the laid-off employees would receive more than eight weeks of severance as well as job-hunting assistance.

Micron Technology Inc. announced that the officials hinted that more cuts and layoffs are to come at its Boise, Singapore and Xi'an, China, assembly and test facilities. While explaining that this round of layoffs has been much more targeted by function than the last round in 2003.

Micron Technology Inc. announced that it will phase out 200 millimeter wafer manufacturing operations at the company's Boise facility. This action will reduce employment at Micron's Idaho sites by approximately 500 employees in the near term and as many as 2,000 positions by the end of the company's fiscal year. The company has sufficient manufacturing capacity remaining and does not expect any disruption in product supply required for customer needs. The company will continue to operate its 300 millimeter research and development fabrication facility at the Boise site and perform a variety of other activities, including reticle manufacturing, product design and support, quality assurance, systems integration and related manufacturing, corporate and general services. These workforce changes were not anticipated or included in Micron's earlier 15% global workforce reduction announcement last October. Following these changes, Micron will employ more than 5,000 in the state.
Microsemi Corp. has announced that it will layoff an undisclosed number of employees and close plants as a part of its restructuring plan.

Microsemi Corp. announced consolidation plans that will result in the closure of its manufacturing facility in Scottsdale, Arizona by April 2011. The company announced that the action is part of its ongoing program to reduce inventory levels and improve its overall cost structure and business model as it grows in both new and existing markets.
Microsemi Corporation announced that it is closing its manufacturing facility in China. The devices manufactured at the facility are not aligned with its strategic direction.

Entergy Corp. is cutting 800 jobs companywide, including dozens in the Houston area. The company plans to cut about 115 jobs in Texas, including about 60 in the Woodlands. The rest will be in Beaumont - where Entergy Texas is based - and elsewhere in the state. Almost one-third of the 800 cuts are expected to be in Louisiana. Total savings from the reorganization are expected to be between $200 million and $250 million by 2016.

Entergy Corp. will lay off 800 people - 240 or nearly one-third of them in Louisiana - in an effort to improve the company's performance. The job cuts, about 5% of the power provider's workforce of nearly 15,000 employees companywide, were part of its second-quarter earnings report.

Entergy Corp.'s Vermont Yankee nuclear plant has officially notified the state that it will be laying off 165 employees starting in January. The plant's workforce already has shrunk from the 625 who were employed there in August of 2013, when it announced it would close at the end of this year. Currently there are 554 active employees.

Entergy Corporation announced that it will close its Pilgrim Nuclear Power Station in Plymouth, Mass., no later than June 1, 2019, because of poor market conditions, reduced revenues and increased operational costs. The company notified the independent system operator of the electric grid, the ISO New England Inc., that as of that date, Pilgrim would not participate as a capacity resource in the market. The exact timing of the shutdown depends on several factors, including further discussion with ISO-NE, and will be decided in the first half of 2016.

Entergy Corporation announced that aging Indian Point nuclear power plant just north of New York City will close within about four years under a deal with Gov. Under the arrangement, plant owner Entergy Corp. will shut both reactors at the Westchester County facility by April 2021.

Herman Miller Inc. revised earnings guidance for the second quarter of fiscal 2009. For the quarter, the company expects sales to be in the range of $475 million to $495 million with earnings per share estimated to be $0.57-$0.64. The current quarter's guidance is only modestly lower because of the strong backlog enjoyed coming into the quarter, and the existing strength of operating model and ongoing cost reduction efforts announced earlier. With these new actions, already strong balance sheet and ability to generate cash flow, Herman Miller remains a financially strong company. The company announced a series of actions intended to reduce the company's annual fixed overhead and operating expenses by approximately $60 million. Related charges are expected to total approximately $10 million, beginning in the third quarter. The actions come in response to a decline in orders during the current quarter and in anticipation of further global economic weakness through calendar 2009. The company noted that orders averaged $34 million per week in September and October, compared to $41 million per week in the first quarter. The company believes these actions will allow it to weather the current economic storm and enable it to sustain investments in key strategic growth areas. The actions include workforce reductions among both salaried and manufacturing staff, including temporary labor, through a combination of enhanced voluntary separation agreements, job eliminations, and manufacturing layoffs. These steps are expected to be implemented through January 2009. While many of the positions impacted are in Michigan, they also include other domestic and international locations.
3M has announced that it will cut 350 jobs worldwide including more than 100 jobs in Austin as the company trims its costs in the face of the continued deep slump in the telecommunications industry.
3M Corp. announced that it plans to cut 44 jobs at its Dynamic Message Systems plant in Spokane, Washington, when it closes its electronic sign-making operation by the end of the year.

3M will cut 130 workers nationwide from its Electro and Communications business, which continues to restructure amid weak demand for telecommunications and networking parts, during the next two months.

3M Co. is eliminating about 400 jobs at its Maplewood campus as part of a larger restructuring at the manufacturing giant. The company is outsourcing much of its administrative services and eliminating other jobs to get to the 400 figure, which is about 4%of its headquarters total. That includes eliminating 82 jobs at a tape-making plant and moving them to 3M plants in Iowa and Missouri. The 400 jobs are in addition to the 82.

3M Co. notified 50 Austin workers that their jobs will be cut as part of restructuring in its Electronics Solutions Division. The job cuts stem from the company's decision to scale back plans for its flexible circuit board product line. 3M will continue to make flexible circuit boards for computer printers and some medical electronics products but will discontinue making them for other types of products.

3M Co. plans to eliminate 141 jobs from its display and graphics unit. The company will lay off 63 workers in Maplewood and 78 from a facility in Cincinnati by February. The move is part of an effort to reduce expenses as the company cuts its LCD film prices to compete with manufacturers in Asia. Through a combination of layoffs and attrition, the company would shed 47 employees in its optical systems division in Maplewood, and its commercial graphics department would cut six positions. Its business lab plans to eliminate 10 positions and relocate another 10 to 12 positions either to the film lab or other units.

3M Co. has announced it will make 185 redundancies in the next 14 months at its plant in Gor-seinon, near Swansea. It comes after a 90-day consultation with the workforce. A further period of consultation will now start to discuss how best to achieve the necessary redundancies. A range of support services will be available for affected employees, including outplacement assistance, financial advice and training for alternative careers. The company announced that there would be no compulsory job losses before September, 2008. It anticipated that the redundancy programme would be completed by June 2009.

3M Co. announced that it is planning to cut several hundred jobs over the next few months. The cuts will begin in its industrial tapes and adhesives divisions. Workers in those businesses have already been informed by the company that it has plans for reorganization.

3M Co. announced it had cut more than 1,800 jobs across the country since the start of the fourth quarter and plans to cut another 500 in coming weeks. The company announced the job cuts were mainly in developed economies in the United States, Western Europe and Japan and would save the company $170 million in 2009. Roughly 700 jobs are coming from U.S. operations alone. The company also is closing 10 manufacturing, technical and office facilities around the world. The 2,300 jobs account for about 3% of 3M's global workforce of 75,000.

3M Co. announced that it had offered early retirement packages to about 3,600 U. S. employees, or 11% of its workforce, as the diversified manufacturer continues to respond to reduced demand for its products brought on by the economic downturn. The move is the latest effort by 3M to reduce head count and trim costs. Since December, it has eliminated 3,600 jobs in two rounds of cuts.

3M Co. cut 40 jobs in its engineering division, as part of continued cost-cutting moves by the company as it copes with the recession. Most of the jobs being cut are in Maplewood.The company also announced that it's closing a manufacturing plant in Southbridge, Mass., affecting about 200 employees.

3M Co. filed a notice with the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services that it will permanently close its Milford facility over the next several months. It will begin gradually eliminating jobs on Sept. 30, and job eliminations are expected to continue through Dec. 31. According to the filing, 115 of the employees at the medical manufacturing site are represented by the Workers United Union, Local 504. Affected workers will receive notice of the elimination of their position 60 days before the final date of employment, but workers will not be able to exercise bumping rights. Employees will be offered severance benefits and have the opportunity to pursue other employment with 3M.

3M Co. plans to cut nearly 100 jobs in Eagan, Minnesota, as it moves ahead with a planned shutdown of a filtration plant there. The closing of 3M's Eagan facility, which is less than 20 miles from 3M's headquarters in Maplewood, had been announced more than a year ago. Initially, the plant was supposed to close by the end of 2018, but 3M now announced it'll begin layoffs in late March. About 10 workers from the site will move to 3M's Maplewood campus, others may reapply for jobs elsewhere in the company.
3M Company announced plans to cut 2,000 jobs worldwide due to a slower-than-expected 2019.
3M Company announced that it plans to cut 2,000 jobs worldwide due to a slower-than-expected 2019.
Modine Manufacturing Co. is laying off 48 workers from its Emporia plant. Modine laid off 85 employees last March but 21 of the workers eventually returned to the company.
Modine Manufacturing Co. anticipates closing four plants after reporting a loss for the third quarter of fiscal 2008. The plant closures would affect three U.S factories and one in Tubingen, Germany.

Modine Manufacturing Co. announced that the company to close Harrodsburg plant. The manufacture of motor vehicle radiators and heat exchangers will be moved to other North American Modine plants. About 110 jobs will be lost in Mercer County over the next 6-9 months as the plant ceases operation. The company announced in January it would cut about 175 employees and contractors at its headquarters, or about 25% of the work force there.

Modine Manufacturing Company announced its intention to close its manufacturing facility in McHenry, Illinois. The closure is expected to impact approximately 135 full-time employees, who will receive a variety of support services. This action reflects Modine's proactive focus on operating scale production facilities across the globe in order to remain cost-competitive. Modine plans to transfer the McHenry production to other facilities in North America, including those in Nuevo Laredo, Mexico, Lawrenceburg, Tennessee and Jefferson City, Missouri. The McHenry plant makes parallel flow and serpentine condensers, oil coolers and radiators for the automotive, commercial vehicle, off-highway and building HVAC markets. Plans call for the plant to close over an approximate 18-month period. Modine will provide the affected employees severance benefits and work closely with the Illinois Department of Labor and other state and local agencies to offer employment assistance and other services.
Molex Inc. announced that it plans on eliminating 900 full-time jobs, cut 600 temporary workers, and shut down some plants, as a result of a declining demand for its product.

Ruby Tuesday, Inc. announced earnings results for the second quarter of fiscal 2010. For the quarter, the company reported fully diluted earnings per share of $0.01 compared to loss of $0.73 per diluted share last year. The revenue decrease of 5.6% during the quarter was primarily reflecting the 1.7% decline in same restaurant sales and the net decrease of 43 company-owned restaurants from the second quarter to prior year reflecting the full 43 restaurants, closed during the third quarter of fiscal 2009. The same restaurant sales were down 1.7% compared with a 3.1% decline in the first quarter of fiscal 2010 and a 10.8% drop in the second quarter of last year. The restaurant sales decline consisted of an increase in guest count of 1.8% and a 3.5% decline in net check.The company estimate same restaurant sales for company operated restaurants will be down 1-3% for the fiscal year 2010. The company expects the restaurant operating margin will be down 50-150 basis points primarily reflecting the impact of compelling value strategy for food costs. Diluted earnings per share for fiscal 2010 are estimated to be in a range of $0.50 to $0.60, unchanged from prior guidance. Capital expenditures are expected to be $18-20 million and estimate to pay down $50-60 million of additional debt this year bringing the total debt pay down for the fiscal year to $178-188 million.The company do not expect to open any new Ruby Tuesday company operated restaurants in fiscal 2010 and anticipate closing 12-13 in the second half of the year. These closings are consistent with previously announced plan to close 30 restaurants over the next several years when their leases expire. There are currently three franchise restaurants, one of which is international, that are expected to open in the second half of fiscal 2010.
Ruby Tuesday, Inc. confirmed it has closed its Vestavia Hills restaurant. The restaurant at 1041 Montgomery Highway.

Ruby Tuesday, Inc. reported unaudited earnings results for the first quarter ended September 04, 2012. For the quarter, the company reported total revenue of $332,921,000 against $330,345,000 a year ago. Earnings before interest and taxes were $7,061,000 against $8,054,000 a year ago. Pre-tax profit was $271,000 against $3,657,000 a year ago. Net income was $2,599,000 or $0.04 per basic and diluted share against $3,093,000 or $0.05 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Total capital expenditures were $6.4 million. The company planned to open 12 to 16 Lime Fresh restaurants, convert five to seven company-owned Ruby Tuesday restaurants to Marlin & Ray's. The company also estimated its franchisees will open 10 to 12 restaurants, up to 10 of which will be international.The company planned to close four to six company-owned Ruby Tuesday restaurants (excluding conversions). The company also estimated its franchisees will close two to four restaurants.The company estimated same-restaurant sales for company-owned restaurants will be in the range of flat to 2.0% for the fiscal year 2013. Operating margins will improve approximately 150-200 basis points due to cost savings initiatives coupled with fixed cost leverage on incremental sales. Interest expense estimated to be $25 to $27 million for the fiscal year 2013. Diluted earnings per share for the year are estimated to be in the $0.20 to $0.30 range including the CEO pension settlement expense and new CEO transition expenses. Excluding the impact of these items, diluted earnings per share for the year are estimated to be in the $0.24 to $0.34 range. Capital expenditures estimated to be $44 to $50 million for the year. Free cash flow estimated to be $20 to $30 million for the year. On an adjusted basis, free cash flow is estimated to be $31 to $41 million after excluding the impact of the CEO pension payout (approximately $8 million).

Ruby Tuesday announced it is cutting 50 jobs at its Restaurant Support Center in Maryville. The job cuts are the result of a cost review program. The cuts are expected to save $6 million annually starting in fiscal 2015 with an expected charge of approximately $2.2 million for transition-related costs in second quarter fiscal 2014 in conjunction with this action.
Ruby Tuesday, Inc. plan to open one restaurant during 2014 and rebuild one.The company plan to close 10 to 13 company-owned Ruby Tuesday restaurants.

Ruby Tuesday announced that it would close 95 of its underperforming locations by the end of the year 2016, in a move to help cut losses. The locations to be shut down were not immediately identified. The company said that employees displaced from the closed properties would be offered positions in nearby locations, when possible.

The Ruby Tuesday announced that the restaurant on 4600 Devine St. was abruptly shuttered. It is the second landmark restaurant to leave the Cross Hill area, as the neighborhood around Devine Street and Jackson Boulevard is known. The Ruby Tuesday closure continues a trend of downsizing for the fast casual restaurant chain.
It was announced that Motorola will cut up to 200 further jobs at Motorola sites across the UK.
Motorola Inc. has announced that the company has cut 7,000 jobs. This was announced along with Motorola's loss for the fourth quarter of 4 or 5 cents a share.

Motorola Inc. is slashing its work force - again - in a move the company says will usher in a return to profitability after a lengthy losing streak. The struggling technology giant announced that it is trimming 9,400 jobs, or more than 8 percent of its work force, in the latest of a series of sweeping cuts. The cell phone and computer chip maker said the move, combined with semiconductor plant closings and other restructuring measures, will result in about $1 billion in annual cost savings. Company executives said they expect to turn a profit next year. The latest cuts are to be made over the course of the next year. Motorola's semiconductor operations will see 4,000 jobs eliminated, while 1,300 jobs will be cut from its equipment manufacturing businesses. Another 4,100 cuts will be distributed companywide.

Motorola Inc. will close a semiconductor plant in Japan and lay off all 230 workers by December. Struggling to return to profitability, the U.S. mobile-phone and computer-chip maker has been reducing jobs, announcing the latest round of layoffs last month totaling 9,400, or more than 8 percent of its work force.
Motorola Inc. announced that it has laid off 2,000 employees as a part of its restructuring plan.

Motorola Inc. will eliminate 500 non-manufacturing jobs at its semiconductor operations. Motorola said 9,400 jobs would be cut worldwide as part of a plan to return the ailing technology giant to profitability. The latest cuts come on top of 500 jobs eliminated at Motorola's semiconductor operations in the Phoenix area last year. After the downsizing this month, the company will employ a little more than 10,000 people in the Phoenix area, including about 6,000 at semiconductor plants and offices in Mesa, Chandler, Tempe and Phoenix.
Motorola announced that it has laid offf 220 employees, approximately ten percent of its Fort Worth workforce, as the company refocuses its paging business strategy.

Motorola Inc. will end manufacturing at its Computer Group in Tempe, a move that will eliminate about 400 jobs as part of the cell phone and semiconductor maker's efforts to cut costs. The center specializes in design and production of computer circuit boards and other systems that go inside telecommunications, military, aerospace, medical and industrial automation equipment.

Motorola Inc. announced that it expects to eliminate about 7,000 employees worldwide. About 3,000 jobs were cut in the first quarter. Outsourcing and attrition will account for more than half the remaining 4,000 jobs to be eliminated in 2003.

Motorola Inc. has cut a few hundred jobs primarily in the United States in its wireless chip operation, as the company tries to trim losses. Layoffs occurred in a wide range of management and non-management jobs and affected workers in Austin, Fort Worth, Phoenix, Libertyville, Illinois; and Plantation, Florida.

Motorola Inc. announced that it had shut down its semiconductor chip-design operations in Singapore, Taiwan and Hong Kong and moved them to China and India. A total of 50 jobs will be lost at the old design centers. Half the lost jobs will be in Singapore, where Motorola employs about 2,000 workers.

Motorola Inc. is to reduce 4,000 more jobs to improve its operational and financial performance. With this the company hopes to save $600 million more in 2008. The company announced a 2-year cost reduction plan in Jan 2007 to remove 10% of its employees. The process of removing 3,500 jobs that commenced in Jan 2007 is likely to be completed soon, resulting in the saving of $400 million.

Motorola Inc. announced that it laid of an additional 1,600 employees during the fourth quarter in a company-wide restructuring effort. The company announced that it will take a pre-tax charge of about $90 million in the fourth quarter related to the layoffs. The company had already laid off about 5,100 workers during the first nine months of the year.

Motorola Inc. plans to cut 2,600 jobs, bringing the total number of employees laid off at the company to about 10,000 since the beginning of 2007. Motorola, which last week announced it would spin off its struggling mobile devices business in an attempt to create shareholder value, is doing so as part of an announced $500 million cost savings plan.
Motorola Inc. will lay off about 3,000 workers. Two-thirds of the layoffs will affect the company's cell-phone division.

Motorola Inc. announced that it is eliminating 400 more jobs, which will help add $25 million in pre-tax charges to the company's fourth-quarter results. The company in its regulatory filing announced that the 400 job cuts come in addition to the 1,500 announced in late October, which primarily were related to the company's Mobile Devices segment. Combined, the two batches of job cuts will result in total pre-tax charges of roughly $189 million in the company's fourth quarter.

Motorola Inc. announced that it would slash an additional 4,000 jobs as part of a stepped-up cost-saving move to remain competitive in a slumping global economy. The move is part of an overall plan to achieve annual cost savings of $1.5 billion in 2009. Of the latest job cuts, 3,000 will be in the Mobile Devices business and 1,000 positions in corporate functions and other business units. The latest moves are expected to save $700 million in 2009 costs.

Motorola Inc. has filed notices with the state of Illinois on the upcoming layoffs of nearly 550 local employees. The state's Department of Commerce and Economic Opportunity has received two notices from Motorola. The Illinois Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, or WARN, requires employers to give 60 days advance notice of mass layoffs. According to the filings, Motorola will be letting go of 49 employees at its downtown Chicago office on North Michigan Avenue. It will also be laying off 497 workers at two locations in Libertyville, where its mobile phone division is headquartered. Both sets of layoffs are expected to begin on March 27 or within 14 days of that date. These filings are part of earlier announced layoffs. Motorola said it is laying off about 4,000 employees, with roughly 3,000 of those jobs in its mobile phone business. Those cuts come after Motorola announced in late October that it was eliminating 3,000 jobs. Two-thirds of those workers were also in the cell-phone division. The mobile devices unit employed about 20,000 people before the two rounds of cuts.

Motorola Inc. announced that it did not find a buyer for its Research and Development (R&D) centre in Rennes, northwestern France. Thus, the facility, which has 138 on the payroll, will be closed as part of the company's restructuring plan to reduce activity in Europe and focus on North America, Latin America and parts of Asia. Apart from Rennes, Motorola plans to cut jobs at its site in Toulouse, southern France, and at the centre in the Saclay suburb of Paris.
Motorola Inc. announced that it is closing its music application store-Motomusic-in India.
Motorola Inc. announced that it plans to close its representative office in Russia on January 1, 2011. The company has already notified cell phone retailers of its plans.

Motorola Solutions, Inc. planned to cut 57 jobs at a Fort Worth facility in conjunction with a broader restructuring. Layoffs will begin around Aug. 31, 2012. The facility where the job cuts are taking place is at 5300 Westport Parkway in Fort Worth. Employees impacted by the layoffs will have access to postings of available jobs within the business, and Motorola Mobility will provide "career transition services" through Right Management Consultants.

Murphy Oil Corp. gas stations operated as Murphy USA in Waverly, Independence, Marshalltown, Anamosa, Grinnell and Le Mars are among 47 stations to be closed. Murphy Oil has just over 1,000 gas stations in 21 states including 27 stations in Iowa. Murphy reported in a statement that it entered an agreement on April 30 to buy stations it operates at Wal-Mart stores. The gas stations are currently leased from Wal-Mart. Murphy reported it plans to spend about $315 million in 2007 and 2008 to buy the properties.

Myers Industries Inc. announced that it is closing its Fostoria, OH manufacturing facility. The plant is one of three Ameri-Kart(TM) facilities in the Company's Automotive and Custom Segment producing custom plastic products for industrial, heavy truck and other markets. Current operations will be shifted to the Company's larger manufacturing facilities in that segment, and the closure is expected to be completed during the second quarter and the facility held for sale. Approximately 50 employees will be affected by the closure. The Company will make every effort to help employees through this transition. In addition to severance and benefit continuation, employees will be offered outplacement assistance.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) will lay off 110 Nashville employees by May as it moves technology operations to Atlanta. The layoffs announced affect employees with duties such as statement rendering, research and adjustments, and the proofing of checks. Some will be offered jobs in Georgia, and all will get outplacement help, extended benefits and severance pay.

Bank of America Corp. have notified California officials they plan eliminate more than 700 jobs in the state. In a filing with the state's Employment Development Department, Bank of America said it would lay off 235 employees from a big technology and operations center in Concord by Jan. 31 and 56 people from a Los Angeles location by March 31.

Bank of America Corp. announced that they were reducing their operations in the country. Bank of America, meanwhile, said it was cutting back its Brazilian operation sharply, eliminating at least three-fourths of its work force of 200. Bank employees in Sao Paulo said operations were practically shutting down, with investment banking activities and the trading desk being deactivated.

Bank of America announces that it was laying off half its staff in Tokyo because of the continued downturn in Japanese markets. The bank, which has operated in Japan for half a century, will keep 110 people in Tokyo and shift some jobs to Singapore.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) plans to cut 850 of the 1,500 jobs at the former Fleet Financial Corp. credit card center in suburban Philadelphia over the next year. The company plans to give Horsham workers priority in filling future vacancies and may eventually create new jobs there.

Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., expects to cut the jobs over the next two years. The actual number of layoffs is likely to be much higher than 500, but the job losses in Massachusetts will be partially offset by Bank of America's plans to move some of its divisions to Boston.
Bank of America Corp. (DE) is cutting about 90 full-time jobs at its consumer real estate fulfillment center in Wichita, citing a downturn in mortgage refinancing.

Bank of America has issued pink slips to 1,000 Fleet Boston employees across the Northeast and Rep. The layoffs are part of a Bank of America plan to reduce its work force by 12,500. The fired workers are being offered 14 to 48 weeks of severance, depending on length of service and health benefits if they take their severance in installments.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) officials announced that a check-processing center in Ridgefield Park that employs about 300 people may be among the former FleetBoston Financial back-office operations that will be shut down in whole or in part. A couple hundred other jobs, including jobs in bank branches, have been eliminated statewide as Bank of America integrates FleetBoston's operations into its own.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) will close a customer call center in downtown Bethlehem this summer, costing 80 employees their jobs. The center at 1 Bethlehem Plaza will close July 22. Other Bank of America operations in that building, including a branch and a private banking office, will stay open. The bank told workers of the closing March 16.

Bank of America Corp. has cut about 1,400 employees in Massachusetts in its merger with FleetBoston Financial Corp., about half of its total job loss in New England, the bank has told elected officials. The Massachusetts layoffs are double the number the bank had previously disclosed. Bank of America chief executive Kenneth D. Lewis and several other top executives told The Boston Globe in September the bank had cut 700 Massachusetts jobs in its merger with Fleet. But by December, those layoffs had increased to about 1,400, Bank of America said in response to a questionnaire from US Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Newton, and the House Financial Services Committee.

Bank of America Corp. (DE) announced that efficiency is the reason behind its elimination of 130 jobs in a Charlotte-based loan processing office during the next six months. The bank said the positions will be cut in Business Credit Services, which processes loans for corporate clients. Bank of America has said it will eliminate about 6,000 jobs as a result of its planned acquisition of MBNA Corp., a Delaware-based credit card firm, in a $35 billion transaction.

Bank of America Corp. (DE)will close four of the Maine call centers that it inherited through its merger with credit-card giant MBNA Corp. but will retain the Belfast facility and its 1,700 employees. About 350 full- and part-time employees will lose their jobs when the call centers in Farmington, Fort Kent, Portland and Presque Isle shut down March 10.

Bank of America Corp. is cutting 49 technology support jobs in Chicago as part of a nationwide restructuring. The company announced earlier that it will eliminate 550 U.S. jobs, including 250 in technology operations. Bank of America has about 3,700 workers in the Chicago area.

Bank of America Corporation expects to lay off 172 workers when the bank closes its wholesale mortgage division at the end of the year. The bank's wholesale sales and wholesale fulfillment operations at 1201 Main St. in Dallas will cease operations around Dec. 31. As a result of the closure, 172 associates will lose their jobs.

Bank of America Corp. will eliminate 650 jobs in its investment-banking division. And the Charlotte-based bank also will sell its equity prime brokerage business. The job cuts follow BofA's decision in October to eliminate 3,000 jobs, or nearly 2% of the company's total employment. The majority of those layoffs were in global corporate and investment banking.The bank made that move after reporting third-quarter earnings of 82 cents per share, a 32% decrease from the third quarter of 2006. Continued disruptions in the credit market hit BofA especially hard in its global corporate and investment banking unit, where third-quarter net income fell to $100 million, a 93% drop from $1.43 billion a year ago.

Bank of America Corporation has laid off about a quarter of its securities analysts. The bank announced it would cut 650 positions in the global investment banking and global markets units. It employed about 70 analysts last month. The analysts included Robert Morris, who followed the oil and gas industry, and John McDonald, who covered large-capitalization banks.

Bank of America Corporation has announced that it has made job cuts in Asia Pacific. The bank has cut jobs as part of its previously announced plans of 650 job reductions worldwide. The bank has however, not specified how many people have lost their jobs.

Bank of America Corporation announced that it will eliminate 165 customer service positions in Chandler next year as part of the bank's massive consolidation efforts following its January acquisition of collapsed mortgage firm Countrywide Financial Corp. The company announced that the layoffs, which will begin in September 2009, are part of the 7,500 job cuts the company announced in late June to result from the acquisition. The bank began notifying Chandler employees in late October. Those eligible will be offered a severance package and job support, placement and training.

Bank of America Corporation has confirmed in a filing with North Carolina officials that it is laying off nearly 140 workers from a local unit. The workers are in a financial-advising unit called Preferred Services, which is aimed at middle-class investors. The layoffs will be completed by March 10. The bank is laying off about 85 workers at a Preferred Services site in Dallas.

Bank of America Corporation has closed 259 ATM machines and shuttered 30 bank branches since the end of 2008. The closings buck BofA's longtime trend of expanding branch and ATM locations across the country through construction and acquisitions.

Bank of America Corp. is planning to retrench 50 employees in the Tampa area by the end of August 2010. These job cuts will translate into a cost reduction for BofA in the Tampa area.These 50 employees are primarily employed in an administrative office in Tampa. However, BofA will offer outplacement services and other assistance to the affected workers.Though the number of employees to be retrenched is almost negligible with respect to the size and total employee strength of BofA, the action demonstrates BofAs conscious attention on the cost of its operations following the downturn it experienced during the height of the financial crisis.

Bank of America Corporation plans to lay off about 3% of its staff in its investment-banking unit following a management review. The layoffs, numbering about 400 employees, are part of the bank's plan to sack under performing workers and also due to weak demand for business in the investment banking unit amid the uncertain economic environment. The layoffs are expected to affect several parts of the investment banking unit, including areas like equity and fixed-income trading.

Bank of America Corporation is laying off less than 5% of its investment banking staff and will tell employees about the cuts. The move would be the first significant organized reduction in the division's workforce. All units within the global banking and markets division, overseen by Tom Montag, will be affected. Even with the layoffs, the division is expected to have more employees at year's end than it did at the end of 2009. It was unclear how many people work in the division.

Bank of America Corporation announced that it is eliminating 1,500 mortgage positions nationwide, mostly in processing and underwriting roles. The Charlotte-based bank is also shifting 350 employees from its home loans unit to its legacy asset servicing division, which works with distressed borrowers. In the Carolinas, the company is eliminating 15 positions as it closes two centers where loans are processed. Another 50 workers are moving to servicing jobs. Nationwide, the company is closing about half of 200 smaller processing centers. Overall, it has thousands of facilities across the country. The move reflects a 25% drop in mortgage applications so far this year compared to last year. Also citing a decline in applications, Wells Fargo & Co. said it was slashing 1,900 jobs nationwide, including 310 in the Carolinas. Bank of America's reduction equals less than 1% of the company's nearly 28,700 employees. The 350 workers join a distressed-borrower staff that has more than doubled in the past two years. The area has been growing through new hires and through the transfer of employees from sales to servicing roles. In total, Bank of America's home loans and legacy asset servicing units have a little more than 60,000 employees. Displaced workers will be able to look for other positions in the company. Those who lose their jobs will receive severance.
Bank of America Corporation reports that it cut about 60 positions in its equity-sales and trading division in June 2011.

Bank of America Corporation announced that it has confirmed that it will be cutting some 30,000 employees over the next several years. The reduction in jobs will help the bank cut its costs by $5 billion per year by 2014. The bank's first phase of Project New BAC affects consumer businesses and support operations including retail and small-business banking, mortgages and wealth management. The job cuts are part of the first phase of a reorganization that started in early 2010. A second phase is scheduled to begin in October and continue through March 2012.

Bank of America Corporation has announced more local job cuts, including 140 positions in Thousand Oaks and 50 in Agoura Hills. Both cities have been notified of the cuts. The layoffs appear to be tied to the Charlotte, N.C., bank's Aug. 31 statement that it would either sell or wind down the correspondent lending side of its mortgage business.

Bank of America Corporation announced that a sign the significant staff cuts announced as part of a company-wide initiative have begun. The bank would not comment on how many or where the layoffs were occurring. The bank announced in September that 30,000 positions would be eliminated as part of the Project New BAC cost-cutting program. A bank employee who spoke only on condition of anonymity also told McClatchy Newspapers that layoff notices were given to employees in the global learning division, which trains new hires and existing workers. The bank would not confirm that. Project New BAC began in April, a bid to streamline the company and restore investor confidence.
Bank of America Corporation intended to close two branches in Massachusetts on June 1, 2012, as part of a broader plan to eliminate 750 of its 5,700 branches over the next few years.

Bank of America Corporation is planning to slash about 2,000 jobs in its investment banking, commercial banking and non-U.S. wealth-management divisions. The cuts target highly paid workers in units expanded when the Charlotte-based bank bought Merrill Lynch & Co. in 2009. The move is the latest in a continued effort to cut costs and streamline operations. The latest cuts come at a time when Bank of America has been building capital, trimming expenses and working to rebuild profits after the 2008 financial crisis.

Bank of America Corporation announced it plans to lay off 312 workers in its legacy asset servicing unit in Fort Lauderdale. The bank will cut those jobs through December 31, 2012. Employees were notified of the layoffs starting on October 30, 2012.

Bank of America Corporation will close a call center in Fresno, Calif. It's the latest in a string of layoffs for the company as it seeks to trim its payroll by 30,000 employees. The company's efficiency program, Project New BAC, seeks to cut as much as $8 billion in annual expenses and reduce the bank's work force to about 260,000 or less. When the program was announced, the company had 288,000 employees.

Bank of America Corporation planned to eliminate almost 200 positions next year when it closes operations at two facilities in the state. The bank will close a call center in Dorchester and a check-processing operation in Malden, though bank, that other administrative functions at both facilities will remain open. Bank of America will cut 86 positions in Malden, about three-quarters of which are part-time, in waves from the first to the third quarter of 2013. The bank will eliminate 107 positions, mostly full-time, in Dorchester in January.

Bank of America Corporation employees in Glendale will either be transferred or laid off in the wake of the company's decision to close its corporate offices on North Brand Boulevard by the end of the year. The 281 employees who work at 611 N. Brand Blvd. received the notices last month. The departure of the bank, which occupies four floors in the high-rise building, will only add to an abundance of Class A office space available in Glendale.

Bank of America Corp.'s plan to shutter its Getzville, N.Y., mortgage servicing center is expected to affect 1,320 employees. The bank has been slashing jobs as part of its cost-cutting plan, Project New BAC. At the end of 2012, the company had reduced its staff by about 15,000 from 282,000 when it initiated the New BAC plan.

Bank of America Corp. announced that it is slashing 1,200 jobs in its mortgage division as the company's refinancing business slows amid rising interest rates. The jobs are scattered around the country, including some in California. The company is planning to cut about 3,000 more jobs by the end of this year, but they are mostly contractors in its legacy asset servicing division.

Bank of America Corp. has filed notice with the commonwealth of Kentucky that it plans to lay off 55 employees at its Louisville Consumer Banking Legacy Asset Servicing Unit at 1231 Durrett Lane. The notice was filed October 30 with the Kentucky Office of Employment and Training.

Bank of America plans to lay off 13 employees in its finance and insurance department here in Jacksonville. The company's campus at 9000 Southside Boulevard offers back-office support in a number of areas, including mortgage services, the department that will be affected by the layoffs in September 2014. The layoffs were prompted by a decrease in the number of delinquent mortgage loans.

MBNA proposed to close its call centre and support operation at Carrick-on-Shannon at the end of November 2014, with the loss of 160 full time roles. This follows a comprehensive review of its customer contact centre operations in the UK and Ireland.

More Bank of America employees in North Texas are facing layoffs as the company plans to eliminate 50 positions at its Legacy Asset Servicing unit in Fort Worth. In a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act letter received by the Texas Workforce Commission on Sept. 25, 2014 began notifying affected employees on Sept.  18, 2014 and expects the layoffs to be complete by Nov. 17, 2014. About 29 of those workers are eligible for career transition resources, severance pay and benefits. As part of a nationwide initiative to reduce 30,000 jobs, 840 BofA workers will have lost their jobs in Dallas, Addison, Plano, Forth Worth and Richardson from mid-2013 to the end of this month.

Bank of America plans to lay off 69 employees at its Jacksonville offices. The workers, who are all in the finance and insurance departments, will be let go by mid-April. The downsizing has been prompted by a decrease in the number of delinquent mortgage loans.
Bank of America Corp. has announced a plan to close its office in Calexico. The branch is to be closed on June 16 and the bank that it was closing the branch because of new customer preferences.

Bank of America Corp. has announced a plan to close branches in north Olympic Peninsula of Washington State. The bank said that it would be selling its branches in Port Angeles, Sequim, Port Townsend and Port Hadlock to First Security Bank.

Bank of America Corp. has announced a plan to cut jobs in Charlotte, North Carolina. The bank said that it would cut about a 100 jobs in Charlotte and that it would continue to reduce staff that handles problem mortgage loans.

Bank of America announced the plans to cut about two dozen investment banking jobs in Asia, including some top dealmakers. Some bankers handling client coverage and deals will be made redundant, starting this week, with cuts expected in Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan, BofA's big centers in Asia. Bank of America's cuts will account for a small portion of its total Asia corporate and investment banking staff, and are part of an annual cost trimming.

Bank of America's retail network in Niagara County is set to shrink again this fall now that the financial giant has announced the pending closure of a branch and drive-up teller in Lewiston. The bank plans to close the office at 767 Cayuga St. and the nearby teller facility on Oct. 30. Customer accounts will be transferred nearly eight miles away to 1263. N. Military Roads in Niagara Falls.

NCR Corp. plans to close a Viroqua, Wis., manufacturing plant, eliminating 80 jobs as part of a factory consolidation. The company announced that it plans to dismiss a majority of the workers March 8, 2009 and that the 100,000-square-foot facility will close for good March 31, 2009. The factory, which makes printing labels for ATMs and cash registers, opened in 1968. NCR will transfer the plant's equipment to a factory in Morristown, Tenn. The company notified workers of the closing Jan. 8, and that they could apply for jobs at the Tennessee plant.

NCR Corp. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2009. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $17 million and net income attributable to company of $15 million or $0.09 per basic and diluted share on total revenue of $1,135 million against net income of $80 million and net income attributable to company of $80 million or $0.49 per basic share and $0.48 per diluted share on total revenue of $1,379 million for the same period a year ago. Income from operations of $29 million compared to $100 million for the same period a year ago. Income before income taxes and discontinued operations $5 million compared to $99 million for the same period a year ago. Income from continuing operations of $17 million and income from continuing operations attributable to common stockholders of $15 million or $0.09 per basic and diluted share compared to income from continuing operations of $82 million and income from continuing operations attributable to common stockholders of $82 million or $0.50 per basic share and $0.49 per diluted share for the same period a year ago. Non-GAAP income from operations of $70 million compared to $117 million for the same period a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities of $51 million compared to $157 million for the same period a year ago. Expenditures for property, plant and equipment of $39 million compared to $22 million for the same period a year ago.For the nine months, the company reported net income of $27 million and net income attributable to company of $23 million or $0.14 per basic and diluted share on total revenue of $3,267 million against net income of $171 million and net income attributable to company of $172 million or $1.03 per basic share and $1.01 per diluted share on total revenue of $3,894 million for the same period a year ago. Income from operations of $58 million compared to $227 million for the same period a year ago. Income before income taxes and discontinued operations $28 mill

NCR is axing up to 70 jobs at its research and development branch in Dundee. Staff were that between 50 and 70 jobs were being cut in the hardware operations side of the business and a 30-day consultation period had begun.

NCR Corp. is planning a large round of job cuts, which a source estimated at about 200. The is transforming into a technology and services company. It's a pivot many industrial giants, including IBM and GE are making, to stay relevant in the digital age. The NCR cuts, expected to occur in the next few weeks, affect sales and IT operations. The cuts involve the hospitality business, which include restaurants, cinema theaters and hotels, according to a source. The hospitality focused Radiant Systems business, which NCR acquired for $1.2 billion in 2011, is affected. The company is spending billions of dollars in developing high-margin software, applications and services as consumers change the way they shop, bank and travel. As the company's product lines pivot, so will its workforce. The company employs about 29,000, including about 2,000 in metro Atlanta.
Northwest Airlines Corporation will be laying off 10,000 employees, as a result of its reduction in the number of flights and its attempt to reduce company costs.

Northwest Airlines Corp. laid off 37 more skilled mechanics in Minneapolis-St. Paul late last week, according to Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association (AMFA) Local 33. This raises the number of Twin Cities-based Northwest mechanics laid off in the first months of 2002 to about 100. On January 15, 2002, the union reported that more than 60 skilled mechanics in Minneapolis-St. Paul received layoff notices, after Northwest transferred responsibility for repairing its DC-10 aircraft line to a private repair station in Singapore. At that time, union officials said another 150 skilled maintenance jobs at Northwest's Twin Cities hub were in danger of being lost by mid-2002. In 2001, nearly 300 mechanics in Minneapolis-St. Paul lost their jobs, according to Jim Atkinson, legislative liaison for AMFA Local 33.
According to unnamed sources, Northwest Airlines is planning layoffs and closures in Atlanta and Duluth.

Northwest Airlines has announced that it will shut down its maintenance center in Atlanta, Georgia resulting in the layoffs or transfers of 1,450 employees. The company also announced the closure of its reservations center in Long Beach, California and ci
Northwest announced that it will cut 1,600 flight attendants to put staffing in line with its reduced flying schedule.

As of last week, passengers have two less daily flights to travel on at Aberdeen Regional Airport. Northwest Airlines Corp. officials can't confirm exactly why the flights were permanently removed from the schedule, but they said the airline is focusing more on higher-demand markets. Northwest Airlines discontinued one arrival and one departure as of Jan. 7, said Mesaba Airlines Communications Director Dave Jackson.
Northwest Airlines might reduce 1,450 jobs, as part of a broader plan to lower annual labor costs by $950 million.

Northwest Airlines Corp. has proposed cutting 2, 031 jobs, or nearly half of its mechanics, in a bid to save $176 million a year, according to a statement issued on the Aircraft Mechanics Fraternal Association (AMFA) website. The airline is also asking the 2,381 mechanics who would remain to take a cut in their base pay of about 26%, the union said.
Northwest Airlines Corp. wants to lay off roughly two-thirds of its mechanics and is seeking concessions worth $203 million under its latest proposal to the striking mechanics union.

Northwest Airlines Corp. announced that the tentative agreement being considered by its flight attendants could lead to about 1,200 of them leaving the company early under a severance plan. The plan also includes pay cuts of 21%, and would save Northwest $195 million a year. The union's leadership has not recommended either acceptance or rejection. About 8,500 flight attendants now staff Northwest's flights, and another 1,200 are on furloughs. The contract includes raises of 1.5 percent in 2007, 1% in 2008, 2009 and 2010 and 2 percent in 2011.

Northwest Airlines Corp. to cut 85 ground jobs are being cut at North Dakota's four major airports by the end of the year as the bankrupt airline tries to reduce operating costs. Northwest is eliminating ground crews at about 70 smaller airports across the country, with plans to contract with private companies to fill those positions. The airline will retain its own staff at 40 airports that have 50 or more Northwest flights per week.

Thirty-five employees of Northwest Airlines Corp. will lose their jobs Nov. 29 when a union-negotiated contract takes effect, transferring those jobs to an outside contractor. Contract employees are taking over at all airports where Northwest has fewer than 50 flights per week. At Eppley, the 35 Northwest employees who will lose their jobs include 15 ticket and gate agents and 20 baggage handlers. All will receive a severance package with 20 weeks of pay, medical and travel benefits.

Nanometrics Inc. announced that the company will close its Milpitas machine shop and plating facility as part of the company's mission to reverse its vertical integration and lower its breakeven point. In conjunction with this closure, Nanometrics will record a restructuring charge in the third quarter of 2007 in an amount of up to $4 million associated with the write-off of these assets.

Nash Finch Co. announced that it will exit its Buy n Save(R) and Avanza(R) retail formats, closing its five Buy n Save outlets, and three Avanza outlets located in Chicago and Pueblo, Colorado. At this time, the Company intends to seek purchasers for its three Denver area Avanza stores. It will also close ten conventional outlets, primarily operating under the EconoFoods(R) banner. The 21 stores involved represent approximately 15% of the Company's annualized retail sales, and approximately 3% of its total annualized sales. The Company expects that the store closures will be completed by the end of its second fiscal quarter 2004.

Nash Finch Co. will close its Cedar Rapids, Iowa, distribution center by the end of 2012. The company announced fewer than 50 jobs will be lost and that the work will be consolidated at centers in St. Cloud and Omaha, Neb. The company announced combining the volume handled by Cedar Rapids into the other distribution centers will allow for increased efficiency and additional product selection for its Cedar Rapids customers.

National City Corporation. said it will shave expenses by $100 million to $200 million, possibly including job cuts, as it prepares for a mortgage origination slowdown after record volume last year. Executives with the $118 billion-asset Cleveland company were not specific about possible job cuts except to emphasize that tellers and other front-line personnel would not be fired.

National City, a bank branch in the Pittsburgh section of Mount Oliver, will close its doors. The building at Bausman Avenue and Brownsville Road has housed banks since 1931, including St. Clair Depository, Western Pennsylvania National Bank, Equibank and Integra. Employees were given the opportunity to relocate to other branches or apply for other National City positions.

National City Corporation announced that it is cutting more jobs. The cuts are nationwide, including some in Cleveland. The cutbacks are part of the Cleveland-based bank's annual budget review and aren't related to the mortgage crisis that forced 1,300 job cuts in recent months.

National City Corporation will cut 900 additional mortgage jobs as it closes its wholesale mortgage channel. National City has already cut 3,400 jobs companywide and restricted mortgage originations to almost only loans for traditional, prime borrowers.
Tenet Healthcare Corp. has announced that it is reorganizing its operations by closing its regional division in Northern California.
Tenet Healthcare Inc. announced that it plans to eliminate over 300 positions as part of a cost reduction initiatives.

Tenet Healthcare Corp. announced that it has provided notice to the Department of Health of its intent to close Medical College of Pennsylvania (MCP) Hospital on March 31, 2004. The 379-bed hospital has suffered sizable losses over the past 12 months, recently accelerating into losses of more than $5 million per month.

The Medical College of Pennsylvania is scheduled to close soon after 153 years. This hospital was the nation's first medical school for women and has been serving this community since the Civil War. Tenet Corp., a 100-hospital, for-profit corporation, owns MCP and announced that it would close on March 31. Such a closing has broad implications for American health care beyond the East Falls community MCP serves. For the operation of MCP represents the imperfect melding of for-profit, free-market capitalism with the economist's notion of a public good - a regional resource such as a city park, that everyone agrees is a wonderful thing to have but no one really wants to pay for.
National Presto Industries has announced the closure of its plant in Jackson, Mississippi as the company is moving production to China.

National Semiconductor Corp. said it will cut 500 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, and sell two divisions in an effort to become profitable. The job cuts mainly will hit manufacturing, sales and marketing operations, National Semiconductor announced. Santa Clara based National Semiconductor employs 10,000 people worldwide.

National Semiconductor Corp. announced that it now plans to close its assembly and testplant in Toa Payoh, Singapore and consolidate the operations into its plants in Melaka, Malaysia, and Suzhou, China. The closure will affect 950 employees. It expects to take a related charge in the first quarter of fiscal 2006 of $27 million to $30 million and achieve quarterly costs savings of $4 million to $6 million.

National Semiconductor Corp. will lay off about 130 workers and take a $10 million charge in the current quarter, as the company continues to refocus its product plans while confronting difficult business conditions. The affected jobs are primarily in the company's product line and support functions.

National Semiconductor Corporation announced plans to eliminate more than 1,600 jobs in an effort to cut expenses. Citing current economic conditions, the company set plans to cut 850 positions immediately in product lines, sales and marketing, manufacturing and support functions. It will also shutter an assembly and test plant in China and a wafer-fabrication plant in Texas, resulting in an additional 875 job cuts. These actions represent a 26% reduction in the company's workforce.

NBTY Inc. announced that the company will close its Amityville manufacturing operation in October 2015 and outsource the work to a California company, a move that will eliminate 214 jobs. The plant is housed in two buildings, at 5100 and 7000 New Horizons Blvd. Layoffs will occur between July 31, 2015 and October 2, 2015.

New York Times Co. plans to shut down its television production unit, resulting in the loss of about 24 jobs, as it focuses its efforts on the Discovery Times Channel, a 50-50 joint venture it formed with Discovery Communications Inc. a year and a half ago. The production unit had about $15 million in annual revenues and produced Times-branded shows as well as shows for other channels, including PBS, A&E and Showtime.

The Times-News of Hendersonville will lay off 35 employees by April 1, 2007 when it shifts its printing and mailroom operations to a sister paper in Spartanburg, S.C. Both newspapers are owned by The New York Times Co. Both full- and part-time workers will be laid off.

The New York Times Company is planning to cut about 12 newsroom jobs at its flagship newspaper. About a dozen support positions at the paper will be eliminated, including a number of clerical and secretarial jobs. Next year the paper will eliminate a few management jobs in administrative areas. The job cuts will not include any journalists.

The New York Times Company laying off 15 journalists after the company acknowledged it fell short of its goal of getting 100 people to take voluntary buyout packages. The company would not confirm the precise number of layoffs. As of the April 22 deadline to accept the voluntary buyout package, insiders estimated that only about 70 people had stepped forward.

The New York Times Company will cut up to 150 positions, including 100 in the newsroom, amid industry-wide declines in advertising revenue. The Times will offer voluntary buyouts at first but will resort to layoffs if it cannot meet the targets.

The New York Times Company has laid off at least 18 newsroom employees in the latest round of cutbacks driven by the newspaper's financial woes. In October, the newspaper said it would trim 100 jobs from its newsroom, leaving about 1,150 reporters and editors. Management hoped to avoid layoffs with buyout packages, but only 73 union and nonunion workers accepted. The company said that still expects to reach its goal of 100 newsroom job cuts by year's end.

The New York Times announced it plans to cut 100 newsroom jobs in the latest move by the prestigious daily to adapt to industry upheaval. The job cuts represent around 7.5% of the newsroom staff of 1,330. The Times will be offering buyouts to journalists and will resort to layoffs if it cannot get enough people to leave voluntarily.

The New York Times Co announced that it will close its editing and pre-press print production operations in Paris, resulting in the elimination or relocation of up to 70 jobs as it moves to cut costs at its international newspaper. The New York Times news bureau and advertising department will not be affected. The changes are part of an effort to simplify the editing and production processes of the International New York Times, and roles involved with those operations will be moved to New York and Hong Kong.
Newell Rubbermaid Inc. has announced that the company will close its Perry Township plant, in the next six to eight months, thereby affecting 430 employees.
Newell Rubbermaid is closing down the Madison headquarters of its division, Eldon Office Products, resulting in a layoff of 100 employees.

In another economic blow to a south-central Kansas community that has lost thousands of jobs in recent years, about 200 employees at the Winfield plant of Newell Rubbermaid Inc. are being laid off. The plant, which has employed between 550 and 600 employees, was shut down.

Newell Rubbermaid Inc. announced that it will exit several product lines, raise prices on others by as much as 22% and cut an unspecified number of jobs. For the full-year 2008, the company lowered its per share earnings forecast to $1.40 to $1.60 from prior guidance of $1.80 to $1.90. The new guidance assumes the per barrel price of oil stays around $140 in a best-case scenario.

Newell Rubbermaid Inc., owner of the plant since 2002, announced it would close the facility at the end of October. October 31, 2008 is the last day of work for most of its 330 employees, with only a handful of staff remaining to wrap up paperwork and prepare the facility for possible sale. Manufacture of the Vise Grip pliers will be moved to China. Unibit drill bits will be made at a Newell Rubbermaid plant in Gorham, Maine.

Newell Rubbermaid Inc. plans to cut 75 jobs from its manufacturing facility in the south-central Kansas town of Winfield as it copes with the global economic downturn. The company blamed the layoffs on a decline in consumer spending combined with the seasonality of many of the products produced at the plant.

Newell Rubbermaid Inc. will be laying off 135 employees beginning in August at its Macedonia plant, which makes Graco children's car seats. The injection molding work currently done at the Macedonia plant will be shifted to the company's plant in Mogadore, which makes plastic parts for Rubbermaid products. The Macedonia plant currently has 310 employees and will have 175 after the layoffs, which will continue until the end of the year. The Macedonia plant will continue to assemble car seats and the company will consolidate outside storage space back into the plant for product distribution.
Newell Rubbermaid Inc. announced that the company is shutting down its distribution centre in Wooster.

Newell Rubbermaid Inc. announced that it is plans to lay off 2,000 people worldwide, including an undetermined number in Atlanta. The company layoffs are an effort to reduce redundancies in a company that was long run as a group of separate operations and is trying to remake itself as a united business. The company is flattening and simplifying its management structure and reducing some layers. Instead of separating businesses by categories-Newell Consumer, Newell Professional and Baby and Parenting - Newell Rubbermaid will be organized by development and delivery in its new strategy.
Newmont Mining Corporation announced that it has laid off 3,000 employees worldwide which represents approximately 5% of its workforce.

Newmont Mining has cut 29 jobs at the Granites mine in the Tanami Desert of the Northern Territory since the start of June, 2013. Newmont Mining's total workforce at the Granites mine, located about 540 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs, is about 1,100 employees.

Newmont Mining says up to 80 jobs are expected to go by the end of September at its Boddington gold mine in Western Australia. Some staff will be made redundant and other jobs will not be filled. The company says 27 positions have been scrapped at the mine over the past few weeks after a review of costs. Newmont says the lower gold price and higher costs have affected operations. It says the current loss of jobs at the Boddington mine could lead to further layoffs. Newmont cut 29 jobs from its Tanami mine in the remote Tanami Desert in the Northern Territory in June because of rising costs and volatile gold prices.
Newport Corporation announced that it has laid off approximately 200 employees, representing 10% of its workforce.
Newport Corporation announced that it has reduced its workforce by over 50 percent, as part of a plan to reduce its break-even point.

Newport Corp. announced that it plans to cut up to 100 jobs, close two plants and take third-and-fourth charges as it assimilates an optical technology business it purchased last month. The moves will eliminate 75 to 100 jobs, about 4% to 5% of its workforce.

Nike Inc. announced this week it will close its flagship NikeTown store at the end of January, three years before the company's lease was due to expire. The NikeTown closure is more bad news for Triangle Square, which was envisioned as the new downtown for Costa Mesa when it opened in 1992.

NIKE Inc. announced the next stage of its category business model execution, which includes the restructuring of its business to further enhance its consumer focus and drive innovation more quickly to market. This realignment will drive greater efficiencies throughout the organization and may result in an overall reduction of up to 4% of the company's workforce. NIKE Inc. employs nearly 35,000 people worldwide.

Nike Inc. announced that it would lay off 17 employees at its Beaverton employee store. The company notified the state of the layoffs in compliance with the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, which requires that employers give 60 days advance notice ahead of a plant closing or mass layoff. The layoffs at the Beaverton store will start in mid-June and are not related to the corporate restructuring.

Nike wants to be more nimble on its feet and sell more shoes directly to customers online as part of a restructuring in which it plans to cut about 1,400 jobs and reduce the number of sneaker styles it offers by a quarter. The company announced several changes to its business structure, saying the moves will help it offer more products to customers faster. It also says a main focus will be the 12 key cities in 10 countries that it expects to represent more than 80% of its projected growth through 2020.
Nordson Corporation announced that it is eliminating 450 jobs, representing about 10% of its work force, due to a decline in orders.
Nordstrom Inc. announced that it had laid off 1,600 employees nationwide including about 250 at its headquarters in downtown Seattle.
Nordstrom announced that it will cut jobs across the company and reduce hours for some sales employees at its clothing stores.

Norfolk Southern Corp. has laid off 13 employees at its rail yard in Williamson. The workers will be indefinitely furloughed starting at the end of the month. The 13 employees work in the mechanical department at the Mingo County facility, repairing and maintaining railroad cars. There are now about 79 employees left in that department at the yard. Company hopes to be able to rehire the workers once the economy picks up.

Norfolk Southern Corp. announced that it has reduced the number of its train and engine service employees by 6% in the last eight months through furloughs and a hiring slowdown, and more job cuts are likely. The company has cut its train and engine service crew from a high of 12,380 in April to 11,622 as of last week. About 400 of those employees were furloughed and the rest of the reduction was the result of a hiring slowdown.
