Norfolk Southern expects to furlough more train and engine employees including 100 in the next month. Norfolk Southern has also reduced shifts at some terminals. It cut shifts at its Buckeye terminal in Columbus, Ohio, to one from three, and its Sheffield, Ala., terminal, now has two shifts instead of three. The company has also has fewer workers at its terminal in Reading, Pa.

Movado Group Inc. will permanently shut down all of its Movado brand watch store boutiques in the US. There are under 20 Movado boutiques in the US, each located in mostly high population areas or large cities. Movado watches will still be sold by independent third party retailers. The Movado boutiques, which sold watches as well as Movado jewelry were apparently not seeing sales nearly on par with corporate expectations. Movado seems to site a lack of overall profitability recently, and sees the closure of its boutique store division as a serious help in moving back towards profitability. Not all is lost though, Movado will retain one boutique store as its flagship retail location, the Movado boutique in Rockefeller Center in New York City. Most of the Movado outlet stores will remain in operation. Movado will place most of its efforts on its wholesale business, so consumers looking for Movado watches will simply go to one of their many authorized dealers.
Northeast Utilities announced that it will cut 200 jobs, most of them administrative jobs at its headquarters.

NiSource Inc. announced it would cut 445 jobs nationwide as part of a $1.6 billion deal with IBM for it to take over some business support services. About 530 other employees of the Merrillville-based utility company will be shifted to world's biggest provider of computer products and services as part of the 10-year agreement that will begin July 1. Among NiSource's Indiana workers, 84 will be laid off and 66 will have their jobs transferred to IBM or its subsidiaries. Those people work in areas such as information technology, human resources, accounting, purchasing, billing and collections.

Xcel Energy Inc. announced that two small Colorado coal-fired power plants will be shuttered by 2012 under companys plan to replace carbon-heavy electric power generation with renewable power sources. The Colorado Public Utilities Commission told company that it could proceed with plans to close the two plants--the 156-megawatt Arapahoe Station in Denver and the 73-megawatt Cameo Station in Grand Junction--and replace the lost generation with a 200-megawatt advanced solar plant.

Xcel Energy Inc. has received approval to shut down six aging coal-fired power units in Colorado and replace them with a $530 million gas-fired plant. The Colorado Public Utilities Commission also approved pollution controls for a coal-burning plant near Brush as Xcel tries to meet the state's Clean Air-Clean Jobs Act. The closures will occur between 2011 and 2017, and Xcel will be given accelerated cost recovery for the investments.

Xcel Energy proposed closing two coal-fired power generators in Colorado in the 2020s, and investing up to $2.5 billion there in new electricity production from renewable resources and natural gas. The proposal comes on the heels of Xcel's plans in Minnesota to shutter two large coal-fired generators in Becker, Minn., as the company sheds resources that can cost more to run and are the largest emitters of carbon dioxide. Coal plants kick out about twice as many greenhouse gases as natural gas generators. Xcel proposes retiring two coal generators at its Comanche Station in Pueblo, which together have a capacity of 660 megawatts. (A megawatt is 1 million watts). The generators would close by the end of 2022 and 2025, a decade ahead of their previously planned retirements. A third and much newer coal-fired generator in Pueblo - of which Xcel has majority ownership - would stay. Xcel plans to close its Becker coal generators - each with a capacity of 680 megawatts - in 2023 and 2026. The company will replace some of that lost power with a 786-megawatt natural gas plant in Becker. Xcel also plans to add 1,500 megawatts in new wind energy capacity in Minnesota and the Dakotas over the next few years.

Xcel Energy is planning to close its remaining two coal plants in Minnesota. The two plants that will close are the 511MW Allen S. King station by 2028 and the 939MW Sherco 3 generator by 2030. The company has worked on an agreement for the closure with a coalition of groups, including environmental and labour organizations such as the Minnesota Center for Environmental Advocacy, the Union of Concerned Scientists and the Sierra Club. The closure of the plants, which is a decade earlier than scheduled, is part of the proposed Upper Midwest Energy Plan which will be submitted in July. The plan is also subject to the approval from the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission and also outlines a path for the company to make a clean energy transition. Xcel Energy will focus on expanding solar and wind, as well as natural gas usage and continue to use its Monticello nuclear plant until at least 2040. By 2022, the company's wind expansion is expected to be completed, adding 1,850MW of wind. Xcel Energy also intends to add more than 3,000MW of new solar universal solar by 2030.
Nortel Networks Corp. announced that it will lay off an additional 5,000 jobs globally. It hasn't determined where these cuts will take place. These lay offs will be complete by midyear.
Nortel Networks Corp. announces plans to cut 3,500 more jobs, about 8% of its work force, and take charges of $600 million against earnings.

Nortel Networks Corp. provides earnings guidance for 2005. The company expects gross margins in the range of 40% to 44% of revenues through 2005.

The company plans to cut 10% of its workforce in a strategic plan expects to trim its operating expenses to 35% of revenues or lower in 2005.

Nortel Networks Corp. announced it will cut about 750 of its 6,000 workers in Ottawa -- 12.5% of its regional worforce -- taking it to the lowest level of employment in the region since 1990. By comparison, the company will cut 2,500 jobs around the world -- about eight % of the non-Ottawa workforce.

Nortel Networks Corp. said that the layoff of 3,250 employees, including 750 in Ottawa last year, that started a year ago will generate $360 million in savings this year -- down from the announced goal of $500 million.

Nortel Networks Corp. announced that, it will cut about 1,100 positions globally and change its pension program to improve operating margins and save money. As part of a previously announced restructuring plan, the company said it will cut 1,900 posts globally but add 800 new positions at new operations centers in Mexico and Turkey. About 1,200 of the job cuts will come from operations, as the company moves to consolidate its operations centers. Nortel also plans to eliminate 350 middle-management positions and cut 350 more positions in business units globally.
Nortel Networks Corp. could shed between 3,000 and 5,000 jobs when it details its latest restructuring plan.

Northern Trust Corp. said it would perform an intensive review of its operations. It also said it plans to sell certain banking assets and leasehold interests of its Higgins Road retail branch in Chicago to First Midwest Bancorp and shutter its downtown Wacker Drive facility there later this year, transferring the accounts to the main downtown bank location. It has already announced plans to outsource its mortgage processing operation.

Northern Trust Corporation said that it was eliminating 700 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, as part of an effort to cut annual operating expenses by up to $150 million. Most of the layoffs have already been made this month, the company said. Along with the elimination of 690 other jobs from the recent sale of assets of its retirement consulting branch, Northern Trust, which is based in Chicago, has reduced its work force by 15 percent this quarter. It now has fewer than 8,000 workers, down from 9,336 at the end of March.
Northern Trust Corporation is laying off about 700 workers worldwide and eliminating more jobs through attrition as part of a broad initiative to trim annual overhead by $250 million.
Northrop Grumman Corp. announced that it is laying off 490 employees. It said that all the layoffs will be complete by late june.

Northrop Grumman Corp. announced that it plans to cut about 500 jobs from its Navigation Systems business in California as it consolidates operations acquired from Litton Industries Inc. The job cuts represent 4.5 percent of Northrop's California workforc
Northrop Grumman Corp. announced that it has laid off 100 corporate employees following the merger with Newport News shipyard company.
Northrop Grumman Corp. has announced that it will lay off 250 to 275 workers from its Lake Charles operation next year.
Defense giant Nortrop Grumman Corp. will lay off 250 to 275 workers from its Lake Charles operation next year. Notices are expected to go out in January with the affected workers leaving on March 20.

Northrop Grumman Corp. has laid off 31 Hispanics and Middle Eastern workers from its Avondale shipyard because of regulations governing defense projects. Yount said that if certain foreign workers see restricted materials, the company can be fined $500,000 for each incident. The laid-off workers, who were legal immigrants Included men and women.

Northrop Grumman Corp. announced that it had to close two of its Southern California facilities because of wildfires. The facilities have not been damaged, and were closed only as a safety precaution. Firefighters in the Los Angeles area are fighting about 600 square miles of wildfires that have reportedly caused $1 billion in damages around San Diego alone. Almost a fifth of Northop Grumman's employees live in Southern California.

Northrop Grumman Corporation announced that it may layoff 330 employees in Fort Eustis, Va. The company provides a range of logistics services at Fort Eustis including maintenance, supply, transportation and food service. Its current service contract expires June 30, 2010. The government is looking for competing bids. The company notified the potentially affected employees on April 26. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act requires companies to provide notice to employees if large layoffs are possible.

Northrop Grumman Corporation announced that it will cut 74 jobs at its Amherst Systems division, following a drop in its engineering business and delays in some programs. The cuts announced to employees, include 54 positions in Amherst, representing 9% of the local work force of about 600. Another 20 will lose jobs in Bethpage, Long Island, where a small operation is being shut down. Remaining work in Bethpage will be moved to Amherst.

Northrop Grumman Corporation announced anticipation of a possible work stoppage at the Hagerstown Maintenance and Modification Center in Hagerstown, Md. The company has issued Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notifications (WARN) to 59 employees at the facility. The WARN Act requires companies to provide advance notice to employees in the event of potential large layoffs. Northrop Grumman is issuing the WARN notice as a result of an anticipated delay in the award of a government contract.

Northrop Grumman Corporation plans to close a New Orleans, Louisiana, shipbuilding operation in 2013 and consolidate its Gulf operations, affecting thousands of jobs. The roughly 5,000 direct jobs at the Avondale site support about 6,500 additional indirect jobs in the New Orleans region, meaning a total of roughly 11,500 jobs are at risk due to this change in the Navy's procurement program. The company said the decision was a necessity. The consolidation will reduce future costs, increase efficiency, and address shipbuilding overcapacity. This difficult, but necessary decision will ensure long-term improvement in Gulf Coast program performance, cost competitiveness and quality. As a result of the consolidation, the company said it will recognize an estimated pre-tax charge of $113 million in the second quarter. The company builds the LPD 17 San Antonio-class amphibious troop and cargo vessel for the U.S. military. Two other facilities that work on the LPD program also will be impacted. The LPD vessels will be built only in Pascagoula, Mississippi, after the Avondale closure. Shipbuilding will continue in Gulfport, Mississippi. The company also said it is considering options for its the shipbuilding business.

Northrop Grumman Corporation has notified the remaining employees at the Hagerstown Maintenance and Modification Center, Hagerstown, Md., that they will be laid off on August 26 and the facility will close later in 2010. The workload at the facility has decreased significantly since the beginning of 2010. This is the second layoff at the facility; 95 employees were laid off in May. Work at the facility will continue through September when Northrop Grumman will make its final delivery of P-3 aircraft to the U.S. Navy.

Northrop Grumman Corporation announced that the company will lay off 169 engineers and technicians that coordinate rocket launches at NASA's Wallops Island facility on the Eastern Shore. This comes after the company lost a bid to renew a five-year contract with NASA. The company confirmed the layoffs, which will occur Oct. 15, 2010.

Northrop Grumman Corporation said that it is cutting 380 salaried jobs at its Newport News shipbuilding facility, citing a need to control costs. The company that builds submarines and aircraft carriers for the Navy said the reduction of about 2% of its 20,000 workers at the shipyard was necessary to improve efficiency and costs.

Northrop Grumman Corporation shedding 150 high-paying, high-tech jobs at its Orlando-area laser-weaponry factory. The downsizing will affect more than 14% of the nearly 1,100 workers in the company's Laser Systems Division in Apopka. The company plans to issue pink slips to 90 workers by late February; with an expected termination date in mid-March. The jobs cuts are the largest locally so far to be tied to the Defense Department's budget squeeze. U.S. Defense Secretary Robert Gates has proposed cutting nearly $80 billion during the next few years. Lockheed Martin Missiles & Fire Control in Orlando laid off 90 workers last year -- that unit's first layoffs in a decade.

Northrop Grumman plans to lay off 224 employees - some at its operations at Fort George G. Meade in Anne Arundel County - starting in April. The cuts are the result of Northrop Grumman losing a Department of Defense contract after the work was put up for bids. Most of the employees are expected to be rehired by the new contract holder. The 224 employees are part of Northrop Grumman's Access Control Program, which is part of the defense contractor's technical services division at Fort Meade.

Northrop Grumman Corporation revealed plans to eliminate about 200 positions in Woodland Hills and Salt Lake City by March. Northrop confirmed that it has offered a voluntary separation program open to all employees working at its electronics division complexes in the two cities.
Terex Corp. announced that its division, Terex Cedarapids will be laying off 59 workers due to economic slowdown and weakening sales.
Unnamed sources have confirmed that Terex Corp. will layoff its 50 employees after it closes Standard Havens Inc, Terex's Asphalt Equipment Plant at Glasgow, Missouri.

Terex Corp. announced that about 60 jobs are likely to be axed following a slump in the industry. The Keresley End company, which employs 350 people at Prologis Park, had hoped to get back on track by starting its summer shutdown two weeks early but a further review has led to the shock announcement. The company is struggling as the sale of construction equipment continues its downward trend to record lows.

Terex Corp. recently announced plans to lay off workers from its aerial and crane divisions. Genie Industries, Terex's aerial division, is letting go of 184 workers at its Redmond, Wash., facility and 58 more in Moses Lake, Wash. Genie is shifting to a build-to-order model. The company hopes to cut an additional $100 million in costs by cutting work hours and managers' salaries. The cuts represent about 6% of Genie's workforce. Terex Cranes will lay off 114 workers from its Waverly, Iowa, manufacturing facility, and will shut down the plant from May 18 to June 19 and from August 3-7. The company will layoff 84 people from its 175-person production team and 30 people from its 135-person office staff.

The mortgage division ofWells Fargo & Co. announced that it plans to pull out of the increasingly risky business of issuing home loans through brokers to borrowers with blemished credit records. The move by Wells Fargo is the latest fallout from the decaying subprime mortgage industry which lends to people with spotty credit histories. As interest rates have risen and home values have moved sideways or even fallen in parts of the country, many of these borrowers have been defaulting. Wells Fargo announced that it will shutter its subprime wholesale offices in Baton Rouge, La., and Des Moines, Iowa. Wells Fargo announced that it will lay off 170 workers at the Louisiana office and try to help them find jobs at other companies. The bank said it will try to find jobs within the company for the 67 workers at the Iowa office.

Wells Fargo & Company plans to close 122 branches in California due to overlap with its newly acquired Wachovia division. The closures will occur in April. California is the only state where Wells and Wachovia had significant overlap. Most of the branches scheduled for elimination are smaller and less ideally situated than others nearby. Of the 187 Wachovia offices in California, 101 will be closed, along with 21 Wells Fargo branches, according to the report. Employees will be offered jobs at nearby locations. The closures don't necessarily represent a scaling back of the Wells franchise, but avoids unnecessary duplication and expenses.

Wells Fargo & Co. is eliminating 85 jobs in Wilkesboro as part of a corporate downsizing related to its purchase of Wachovia Corp. The size and complexity of the deal would mean that the elimination of positions, unfortunately, would take place across the company. The bank will begin cutting positions at the Brushy Mountain Road operations on June 29, 2010. It expects to be done by August 16, 2010. The bank filed a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act notice with the N.C. Department of Commerce. The WARN Act requires companies planning large layoffs to notify their state and local governments, and affected workers. Employees will be offered paid-leave benefits based on years of service and compensation levels.

Wells Fargo & Company is to cut 3,800 jobs over the next 12 months as it restructures its financial arm away from offering subprime mortgages and car loans. The bank - perhaps best known in the UK for wrestling control of Wachovia from Citigroup at the height of the financial crisis - is shedding the positions in its diversified financial services team. The bank is closing approximately 640 regional offices as part of the restructuring, which will account for 2,800 posts, with a further 1,000 coming from a regional centre in Des Moines, Iowa. The job losses are a direct result of the takeover of Wachovia, and the fact that many of the products offered by Wells Fargo Financial are available through its 6,600 US bank branches and its 2,200 mortgage offices.

Wells Fargo & Company announced that it is closing bank branches in several small North Dakota towns. The company said that the closings range from Crystal in northeastern North Dakota to Litchville and Tower City in the southeast and Scranton in the southwest.

Wells Fargo Wholesale Lending Operations will lay off 145 mortgage workers in Orange County, mostly in Irvine. Some jobs may also be eliminated in Costa Mesa. The workers, who handle third-party mortgages from brokers, were hired by the bank as interim team members for short-term assignments. The affected workers received a 60-day notice of layoff Jan. 30, 2011. The bank hopes some of the workers may be able to transfer into other positions within the company to avoid losing their jobs. The Orange County closures were part of a nationwide consolidation of the bank's financial services.

Wells Fargo & Company's Wholesale Lending Operations in Irvine will lay off 53 people by May. The layoffs come two months after the bank said it was cutting 145 jobs in Orange County, mostly in Irvine but also a few in Costa Mesa. The company also announced that it will consolidate its Northwood branch in Irvine with its Trabuco Grove store. All the Northwood workers will be transferred to the Trabuco branch.

Wells Fargo & Company and Edward D. Jones & Co., L.P. announced the closing of St. Louis Park Mortgage Subsidiary on March 7, 2013, with 214 Employees announced a Wells Fargo mortgage subsidiary with more than 200 employees in St. Louis Park is closing in March 2013. Edward Jones Mortgage, LLC notified the Minnesota Department of Employment and Economic Development that 214 Minnesota workers could lose their jobs. The St. Louis Park operation will close on March 7, 2013. About 210 employees are impacted by the closure, and the bank is helping them apply to job openings.

Wells Fargo & Company will terminate eight mortgage joint ventures including a partnership with HomeServices Lending, an affiliate of Berkshire Hathaway. Roughly 300 employees will be affected as the eight joint ventures are wound down over the next 12 to 18 months. The bank will work to retain as many employees as possible, though the unit itself will ultimately be eliminated. The eight ventures are Bankers Funding; Colorado Mortgage Alliance, DE Capital Mortgage; Home Services Lending; Military Family Home Loans; Prosperity Mortgage, a joint venture with the real estate firm Long & Foster; Premia Mortgage and Private Mortgage Advisors.

Wells Fargo & Co. announced that is laying off 48 workers in Raleigh as part of a nationwide purge that affects 2,323 employees. The nationwide round of layoffs is isolated to mortgage-lending jobs, which is the result of a slowdown in demand for mortgage refinancing.
Wells Fargo & Company announced that with demand for mortgage refinancing dwindling, the company is laying off nearly 100 employees from its Deerwood Park office in Jacksonville.

Wells Fargo & Co. cut more than 3,000 mortgage jobs this summer. The company said that Wells Fargo expects a 30% drop in mortgage volume in the third quarter. Wells estimates originations this period will dip to about $80 billion from $112 billion in the second quarter.

Wells Fargo & Co. is cutting another 332 jobs in the Twin Cities, citing further weakening in demand for home-mortgage refinancing. The bank's latest layoffs included 1,865 employees across the country. The cuts are "the result of lower mortgage refinancing volume than it experienced throughout 2012 and early 2013 and will better align and increase the efficiency of its organization.

Wells Fargo & Co. announced 5,300 full-time job cuts in mortgage production in the third quarter. That's about 8% of the 70,000 people in Wells Fargo's consumer lending business, which includes mortgages.

Wells Fargo will lay off 92 Portland employees. The job cuts will come from the Wells Fargo Home Mortgage Retail Distributed Fulfillment group, 9600 N.E. Cascades Parkway. The layoffs will begin on December 22, 2013. The bank will lay off 54 underwriters, four lending officers, three loan administration managers and 31 loan document specialists.

Wells Fargo & Co. is eliminating 28 jobs in North Carolina, mostly in Charlotte, as part of cutting at least 700 more mortgage jobs nationwide. The bank confirmed that 25 jobs will be cut in Charlotte and three in Wilmington. The bank announced there is no impact on its Triad West mortgage operations.

Wells Fargo announced that Home Mortgage office in Western New York is set to close in August, marking the continued decline of mortgage refinancing activity across the county. The closure stems from a nationwide slowdown in residential mortgage refinancing that's forcing several mortgage lenders and servicers to scale back their operations.
Wells Fargo has closed its commercial real estate office in Cleveland. Its commercial banking operation remains.

Wells Fargo will close its home lending servicing office in Milwaukee and eliminate 1,000 jobs, saying fewer homeowners are falling behind on payments and seeking help keeping their homes. Wells Fargo & Co. announced that as the economy has improved over the last two years, it has received fewer delinquent payments, and fewer customers have required assistance staying in their homes. The company says it will continue to offer assistance to borrowers facing financial hardship. Wells Fargo will close the office in late July. It says it will inform employees of other job opportunities within the company.

Wells Fargo has announced more Charlotte-area layoffs from its mortgage operation the company is cutting 91 jobs in Fort Mill, S.C. The company is reducing staff in response to ongoing declines in foreclosures and lower demand to refinance mortgages. The 91 layoffs are part of 125 layoffs the lender is making across the country.

Wells Fargo has laid off less than 10 employees in its investment-banking operation in Charlotte and New York. The employees worked in the bank's Wells Fargo Securities unit. The bank did not give a specific reason for the layoffs but said it is 'constantly evaluating its business model to better serve its clients. The company said the laid-off employees who worked in Charlotte were based in uptown's Duke Energy Center, where the bank has trading floors.

Wells Fargo confirmed 40 mortgage-related layoffs in Raleigh. Employees were notified on September 16, 2015. The local cuts are part of a companywide restructuring plan that impacts 182 employees across Wells Fargo, including a handful in Charlotte and Fort Mill, South Carolina. The layoffs are attributed to improvements in both delinquency and foreclosure rates. Impacted employees will receive pay and benefits through Nov. 14, 2015.

Wells Fargo is eliminating 121 technology jobs nationwide, including 39 in Charlotte, as part of an efficiency initiative. The layoffs are the latest effort by a big bank to reduce costs at a time when low interest rates have made it difficult to boost revenue.
Wells Fargo announced 16 layoffs in Fort Mill and Charlotte. Employees impacted by the announcement are eligible to receive pay and benefits through July 16, 2016.

Wells Fargo said it is adding jobs in Charlotte as it cuts some commercial mortgage positions in Oakland, Calif. The bank said it is laying off 55 employees who work in Oakland and shifting those roles to Charlotte. Wells Fargo said the move will consolidate similar functions being performed in both cities. The relocated jobs involve operations and loan administration functions in its commercial mortgage servicing operations. Plans call for Oakland to retain other commercial mortgage servicing functions.

Wells Fargo & Co. announced that it is making progress on its plans to close hundreds of branches. The bank, which has no branches in St. Louis, announced in January that it would close 400 branches through 2018. The bank is trying to cut $2 billion in expenses by the end of 2018 to free up money for investing elsewhere in the business and cut another $2 billion by the end of 2019 to boost profits. The U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau in September fined Wells Fargo $185 million after regulators found Wells Fargo employees created unauthorized deposit and credit card accounts for unsuspecting customers to collect financial bonuses.

Wells Fargo & Co. will close or consolidate four Minnesota branches as part of a nationwide cost-cutting plan. The locations affected are in Ely, Carlton, Fairbault and Owatonna, the San Francisco-based bank. The Ely location shuttering isn't a full-fledged branch and only has drive-up ATMs. Wells Fargo will keep its traditional branch in Ely open. The Owatonna and Fairbault locations will consolidate with other branches in those cities. Wells Fargo recently announced it would close 450 of its almost 6,000 branches across the country. It expects to shutter 200 of those by the end of the year and another 250 in 2018.
Wells Fargo & Co. confirmed that it is closing an automobile-focused service center in Winterville, affecting 600 employees. The center's operations will be phased out over a 12-month period.

Wells Fargo & Co. has laid off 130 Twin Cities employees who work in its home mortgage business. Continuing market changes as the reason behind the cuts in a press statement. In a layoff notification sent to the state, the financial institution said 115 workers who lost their jobs were based in the company's St. Louis Park office. Employees affected included those in customer-account management positions. The company said it will assist employees with finding other jobs within Wells Fargo. The round of Twin Cities cuts come about three months after Wells Fargo told the city of Minneapolis it wants to expand its home mortgage campus in south Minneapolis. The bank's plan calls for building a six-story parking ramp, allowing it to add about 1,250 more employees to the site.

Wells Fargo is laying off 101 employees in its Charlotte-area mortgage operation, part of a nationwide cut affecting 638 employees. In the Charlotte region, five of the layoffs are in Fort Mill, S.C., and the rest are in Charlotte. Affected employees are eligible to receive pay and benefits through October 21, 2018.

Wells Fargo is laying off 106 employees in its Charlotte-area mortgage operation, part of a nationwide cut affecting 638 employees, the company reported. In the Charlotte region, five of the layoffs are in Fort Mill, S.C., and the rest are in Charlotte, the bank said, citing a slowdown in its mortgage business. Affected employees are eligible to receive pay and benefits through Oct. 21, 2019.

Nucor Corporation announced two bar mills are scheduled for outages in October and November, while a third mill shut down. The company's mill in Kankakee, Illinois, is also planning to go down for maintenance from October 28 to November 3, 2012. The facility makes rebar and merchant rounds, flats and angles.

Nucor Corp. has decided to temporarily halt production at its St. James steel mill because of market conditions. Nucor said that its direct reduced iron plant has shut down for routine maintenance. Afterward, the company will continue to stop production at the facility until market conditions improve.

Nucor Corp. has closed its cold finished bar facility in Georgia, USA, less than a year and a half after it acquired the operation from rival steelmaker Gerdau Long Steel North America. Nucor ended production at the site around April 21. Nucor will assist the 14 employees at the operation in finding new positions at Nucor or 'within the community'.
FirstEnergy Corp. announced that it plans to layoff 1,250 employees, approximately eight percent of its combined work force following the merger with GPU Inc.

FirstEnergy Corp. said that it is eliminating 340 Berks County jobs or 22 percent of its local work force in a cost-cutting move following its $4.5 billion purchase of GPU Inc. in November. The Berks losses are about half of the 668 job cuts companywide that FirstEnergy announced as it streamlines the combined utilities serving 4.3 million customers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and New Jersey. The job cuts are expected to save $53 million. Of those, 131 employees at the local GPU Energy division in Muhlenberg Township and at GPU Services in Bern Township are being severed immediately, and another 134 have been given temporary assignments lasting from a few months up to 18 months. The remaining 75 jobs were cut through attrition over the past two months as workers voluntarily left the company.
FirstEnergy Corp. plans to eliminate 185 to 230 computer-related jobs.

FirstEnergy Corp. will cut as many as 220 jobs by mid-November. The job cuts are expected to save the company about $13 million a year starting in January, spokesman Ralph DiNicola said Wednesday. FirstEnergy has about 14,000 employees. FirstEnergy in September 2002 announced it would be cutting hundreds of jobs this year and in 2004 as part of a plan to save as much as $135 million a year.

FirstEnergy Corp. has notified 40 employees that they will be laid off on July 28, 2009. Another seven employees have been offered other positions within the company, but could be laid off if they don't accept those positions. The cuts at the Akron-based parent of Ohio Edison come on top of 335 management and support staff layoffs in March as part of a reorganization. The positions cut on July 28, 2009 are related to the company's previous reorganization. At the time of the March reorganization, several departments were combined and given more time to study their staffing needs before completing their reorganization. The 40 employees are nonunion and are part of a department that includes the finance group, information technology, controllers, corporate security and supply chain employees. The majority, 27 positions, are in the Akron area, including at the company's downtown Akron headquarters and West Akron campus. Another six layoffs came from Reading, Pa., and seven from power plants. Employees will be paid through August 27, 2009 and will receive a severance package of 11/2 weeks of pay for every year of service with a cap of 30 weeks.

FirstEnergy Corp. announced that it will cut its workforce by about 200 positions as part of an organizational restructuring to adapt to the current challenges of a weak economy. Results of an organizational study are due in November. FirstEnergy said affected employees may claim benefits from the company's severance plan. Staffing reductions may continue through 2013 due to normal attritions, company added. The action is due to slow customer load growth and dwindling prices for power in the face of greater supply. The review will include specifically corporate support departments and retail supply subsidiary FirstEnergy Solutions. FirstEnergy, according to its website, has about 17,000 employees. Last year, the company completed the acquisition of Allegheny Energy. The resulting company has 10 electric distribution utilities in six states. In January, the company said it would shut about 2,700 MW of coal-fired generating capacity, including a number of units dating from the 1950s, because of pending environmental regulations and capacity market prices in the PJM region.

FirstEnergy Corp. has every intention of closing its Hatfields Ferry and Mitchell power stations. The reasons for the closings haven't changed since the move was first announced in July. The plants are losing money and new environmental regulations and uncertainty around future regulations, will only add to that cost.

FirstEnergy announced that its three nuclear power plants in US states of Ohio and Pennsylvania will be closed by mid-2018 if there is no support from state legislation or any buyer. The three nuclear power plants - the Davis-Besse plant in Ottawa County, Ohio; the Perry plant east of Cleveland and the Beaver Valley plant northwest of Pittsburgh will be closed as power generation from natural gas and renewable energy sources in the two states is increasing. The same situation is being faced by the coal-fired power generating plants in US. At present the company is looking for a sponsor to develop a legislation that will make these power plants to continue their operations.
Olin Corp. has announced that it has laid off 900 employees as a result of the economic slowdown.
Olin Corp. has announced that it plans to shut down a manufacturing plant in Indianapolis, affecting 200 employees, due to shrinking demand for its brass products.

Olin announced that it will permanently close the portion of its Becancour, Quebec, Canada facility that has been shut down since late June 2014. This action reduces the facility's chlor alkali capacity by 185,000 tons.

Olin Corp. will open its new Technology and Administration Center in Lake Jackson later this year. The property, a former Randalls grocery store at 604 Highway 332, will become the main building for Olin's Texas operations. The 62,500-square-foot office building will be large enough to accommodate future growth. Consolidating employees in the new Lake Jackson TAC will increase local efficiencies and team collaboration. The building will feature an open floor plan and glass interior walls to create a collaborative work environment, large windows around the building to enhance visibility and natural light, and a industrial design training hall that can seat 130 people. Olin will relocate more than 200 employees from seven area offices to the new TAC when renovations are completed this summer. Meanwhile, the company is permanently closing two plants in Freeport: a 230,000-ton capacity chlor alkali plant and a vinylidene chloride plant. The closures are expected to be complete before the end of 2020.

Olin Corporation announced that it plans to permanently shut down approximately 20% of its diaphragm-grade chlor alkali capacity (approximately 225,000 ECU tons) at its Plaquemine, LA facility. The closure is expected to be completed by June 1, 2021 and is expected to be cash flow accretive.
Omnicare Inc. eliminated the jobs of about 50 people at the headquarters of NeighborCare, the Baltimore company it bought last month, a source confirmed.

Owens Corning announced plans to close its manufacturing plant in New Braunfels this summer, with a loss of 120 jobs. Glass fiber reinforcements, woven fabrics used in marine, military and industrial applications, are made at the plant.
Owens Corning is laying off about 50 workers at its glass composites plant in Guelph. The employees were notified of the layoffs earlier.

Owens-Illinois Inc. announced that as a result of the ongoing review of its global manufacturing footprint, the company will close its glass container plant in Lavington, British Columbia, on October 31, 2008. Existing production from the Lavington plant will be transferred to other O-I facilities. Approximately 300 employees will be affected.

Owens-Illinois Inc. to close its glass container plant in Castel Maggiore, Italy, after concluding a process of consultation with the local union representatives, which is anticipated prior to the end of 2008. Production will be transferred to other O-I facilities, including plants in Italy. Approximately 100 people will be affected and O-I will offer positions in other Italian plants to all affected employees.

Owens-Illinois, Inc. will close the jar and bowl making divisions of its unit Verreries Mecaniques Champenoises based in Reims, northern France, and in Karkula, Finland. The two divisions employ 252 in total, including 146 in France. The other European units will not be affected for the time being by the parent company's restructuring plan.

Owens-Illinois, Inc. announced that it will close all or portions of three U.S. plants as it adjusts to decreasing demand for beer bottles and other products. The company doesn't comment on contracts with individual customers, but stated that there has been no rupture in relations with Anheuser-Busch, which is the nation's No. 1 beer-maker and a major producer internationally. The plant closings affect about 800 of O-I's 23,000 employees worldwide. A plant in Charlotte, Mich., with 140 workers will close May 1, followed by closure July 1 of a Clarion, Pa., plant with 420 workers. Also, the firm will lay off about 200 of 400 workers at its Oakland plant as part of production cuts planned for the third quarter. O-I operates 19 bottle plants nationwide. Some work from the Michigan plant will move to plants in Auburn, N.Y., and Toano, Va., which have been closed since Christmas and likely won't reopen for to six months. Both plants rely heavily on orders from Anheuser-Busch, maker of Budweiser and Michelob beers.

Owens-Illinois, Inc. announced that it has laid off 25 workers from their world headquarters. There are more than 1,000 workers at the headquarters, and the layoffs amount to just shy of 3% of the workforce there.

Faced with losing almost a third of its mortgage subservicing portfolio, PHH Corp. said it would cut 91 of 294 employees in its Buffalo, New York facility by the end of the year. The company also told Buffalo Business First that it was 'evaluating (its) long-term need' to maintain a presence in western New York. The cuts stems from HSBC last month announcing that it has agreed to sell 139,000 mortgage loans currently serviced by PHH to a buyer that does not intend to retain PHH as subservicer. PHH also told Buffalo Business First that another reason for the job cuts in western New York is plans to relocate loan origination work from Buffalo to Jacksonville, Florida - most likely in the first quarter of 2017. That could lead to more job cuts in Buffalo.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. may eliminate as many as 3,000 jobs over the next six to 12 months to cut costs. The job cuts are part of the so-called One PNC Initiative unveiled by Chairman James Rohr at the company's stockholder meeting in April. The plan is designed to cuts costs and increase revenue for PNC, which operates 774 branches in six states. PNC employs about 24,500 employees in 36 states, including more than 7,000 in Western Pennsylvania.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. will eliminate 350 to 400 jobs at Sterling Financial Corp., which it bought earlier April 2008. The cuts will take effect by August in an effort to remove Sterling workers who duplicate tasks performed by PNC employees. The company said it would try to fill openings elsewhere in the company with the affected workers. The jobs to be eliminated include accounting, bookkeeping, transaction processing and legal positions in Lancaster-based Sterling's administrative offices and headquarters. PNC plans to keep branch managers and bank tellers at the banks, which will be converted to the PNC name in the coming months.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. downsized its original assessment of how many jobs would be lost due to the company's recent acquisition of Sterling Financial Corp. The company will cut fewer than 300 jobs, down from as many as 425 layoffs the company had projected last month. PNC informed the state Department of Labor and Industry that about 173 workers would be cut from the company's facility at 1097 Commercial Ave. East Petersburg effective June 20. PNC Financial also will cut jobs from Sterling's former headquarters at North Pointe Business Park. No cuts will be made at branches of Bank of Lancaster County, and cuts will come primarily from accounting-related positions that duplicate services of PNC employees.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. announced that it plans to trim 10% of its work force in the next two years. The company announced a move to cut 5,800 jobs from its nearly 60,000-employee work force by 2011.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. announced to close the National City mortgage processing center in Texas Township outside Kalamazoo. The company said it will move the call center's work to Pittsburgh and Downers Grove, Ill.
PNC Financial Services Group Inc. is closing one of its Dayton-area branches in the coming months. The company by May 2011 will shutter its Huber Heights branch at 6740 North Brandt Pike.
PNC Bank announced regulators that the branch at 3889 Military Trail is closed. That branch had $30 million in deposits on June 30, 2013. PNC Bank has five other branches in the city.

PNC Financial Services announced that they are stepping up cost-cutting in 2015 amid a slide in second-quarter profits as low interest rates crimp the bank's ability to make money on lending. The company did not provide details about where those cuts will be made, but much of it will be on the retail side, as PNC plans to close 100 branches in 2015. By the end of 2015, PNC will have closed more than 400 branches since 2012 as customers do more of their banking online and through mobile devices.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. plans to consolidate one branch in the Pittsburgh region within the next 90 days, its first local closure in 2016. The Bridgeville Trust branch, located at 456 Washington Ave. in Bridgeville, will be consolidated into the Great Southern Shopping Center office on Washington Pike, roughly a mile away, effective April 15.
PPG Industries announced that it has laid off about 400 employees at each facility due to the slumping demand in its marketplace.

PPG Industries Inc. announced that it would cut 1,000 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, after first-quarter earnings fell 39 percent. PPG has been cutting jobs and closing plants as orders have declined after the makers of automobiles, appliances and electronics sold fewer products.

PPG Industries Inc. said that it would lay off 60 employees at its fiberglass plant in Lexington on July 26, bringing the total reduction in its work force there since May 2001 to 650. The company said in 2001 that it planned to reduce its work force at the plant by 50 percent because of lower demand for its electronic products.

PPG Industries Inc. has laid off 27 employees at its Springdale plant. The workers, all salaried chemists and technicians, were notified on January 24, 2006 that their jobs were being eliminated immediately. About 500 work at the facility, which produces coatings and resins.

PPG Industries will lay off 110 employees from one of its North Carolina plants. The company announced that 420 employees at its Lexington fiberglass plant that the cuts are the result of a decline in the wind energy market. The cuts will take effect June 30.

PPG Industries Inc. declared force majeure on North American deliveries of the chemical used to make pulp, alumina and soap because of a factory shutdown. PPG announced that its Natrium plant near New Martinsville, W.Va., has a mechanical problem. The plant, which makes chlorine and caustic, known collectively as chlor-alkali, probably will be down for a "short" period.

PPG Industries will cut about 1,700 employees worldwide as part of a restructuring aimed at integrating recent acquisitions more efficiently. The company said the cuts represent less than 4% of its global workforce of approximately 46,000. The restructuring, which the company said should be completed in 2016, also includes adjusting production capacity, although PPG provided few specifics on which facilities might be affected. The company expects to record pretax charges of $135 million to $140 million in the second quarter related to the downsizing actions. It projects the restructuring will generate savings of $100 million to $105 million by 2017, including savings of $15 million to $20 million this year.

PacifiCorp announced faced with what appears to be out-of-reach emissions control requirements, the company is taking steps to close its Carbon coal-fired plant in Carbon County, Utah, in 2015. Idaho regulators announced that they have agreed to allow the company to establish an account to track expenses associated with the utility's plan to retire the 172-MW Carbon coal plant.

Paxar Corporation announced to its workforce in Hillsville, Virginia that, as a part of its continuing effort to create a more efficient woven label manufacturing operation, the Company plans to close the manufacturing operations at the woven label plant located there. As a part of this restructuring, the current manufacturing operations at the Hillsville plant will be consolidated into the Company's Weston, West Virginia facility. The Company anticipates that the closure of the Hillsville facility will be completed by December 31, 2005.
Pall Corp. will phase out either its headquarters building in East Hills or a technology center in Port Washington over the next several years.

Parker-Hannifin Corp. will close a plant that makes hydraulic hoses for trucks and other equipment, eliminating 200 jobs. The job cuts will begin in November at the 51 year old plant about 40 miles north of Columbus.
Parker Hannifin Corp. has announced that it has cut 72 jobs at its Parker Aerospace plant in the Weber Industrial Park.

Parker Hannifin plans to close a 150-worker factory near Fort Wayne in 2016. The company says it will transfer the New Haven factory's working making cooling system components to plants in Tennessee and Missouri.
Parker Hannifin Corporation announced that it laid off about 20 employees from its Cleveland headquarters.
J.C. Penney has announced that it has closed its store in Houston, thereby laying off 85 employees.

J.C. Penney Co. announced that it will cut about 2,000 jobs and close three facilities in its catalog business, whose sales have fallen sharply over the past year. Penney said it would close a catalog-fulfillment center in Atlanta and telemarketing centers in Atlanta and Lenexa, Kan., by the end of the second quarter. A Penney spokesman said about 800 jobs at the Atlanta fulfillment center were mostly full-time and most of the roughly 700 jobs at the two call centers were part time. The remaining job cuts would be spread across four other fulfillment centers and 10 call centers.

JC Penney Co. Inc. announced the first steps in its previously disclosed effort to reduce expenses in excess of $200 million annually in its department stores, catalog and Internet businesses. The steps described below are currently being implemented and are expected to produce annualized savings of $100 million, $50 million of which would occur in 2004. A charge of approximately $20 million, or $0.04 per share, will be recorded in the fourth quarter of 2003 in connection with the initial steps. The charges relate principally to contract cancellations, and severance and outplacement. Management continues to expect fourth quarter earnings of approximately $0.80 per share, including the effects of the above one-time charges. _x000D_
 _x000D_
Store Support Center (SSC) Network: Initial savings relate to the transfer of management responsibility to the Company in 2004 for the six SSC's currently outsourced to third parties. Corporate Organization: Restructuring efforts will be occurring in department store operations, catalog, and related corporate support functions. These efforts will include centralization of certain functions as well as elimination of resources devoted to certain activities. Marketing: The Company will be refining its investment in marketing by eliminating less productive expenditures and reducing overall production costs. Some of the savings will be reinvested in media that supports sales growth. The overall cost reduction effort will be phased in over several years, with additional savings opportunities occurring throughout 2004 and 2005._x000D_
 _x000D_
Catalog Telemarketing Centers: The Company will close its Austin, Texas telemarketing center in the second quarter of 2004 and reallocate the call volume to its remaining telemarketing centers. Approximately 475 positions will be affected.

J. C. Penney Company Inc. announced its call center in Moosic will close in March, eliminating 275 jobs. The last day for the center, which handles sales for the retailer's catalog, will be March 28. The company will provide severance packages to eligible employees. J.C. Penney's six other call centers -- in Pittsburgh; Grand Rapids, Mich.; Sacramento, Calif.; Albuquerque, N.M.; Richmond, Va., and Columbus, Ohio -- will remain open.

J. C. Penney Company Inc. announced that it would cut hundreds of jobs, as the mid-tier retailer tries to deal with the damage a weak economy has inflicted on its core customer base. The company was cutting up to 200 jobs and merging the chain store's buying and marketing operations.

J. C. Penney Company, Inc. is closing a call center in Chesterfield County that employs 252 workers. The call center will close on March 26. The center's call volume has declined as customers increasingly shop online. The facility primarily handles catalog orders.

J. C. Penney Company, Inc. is closing some stores, outlets and call center locations and continuing to work on an exit from its catalog business in an effort to streamline operations and boost profits. Penney plans to close six underperforming stores and two call center locations. It is also reorganizing its custom decorating business, which includes closing a custom decorating fabrication plant in Sacramento, Calif., and shifting to managing 300 decorating studios instead of 525 of its current in-store studios. The company's exit of its legacy catalog business includes shuttering 19 outlet stores that carry a large amount of catalog merchandise. Penney announced in November 2009 that it would stop publishing its twice-yearly 'big book' catalogs. The company will also close one furniture outlet store in Rancho Cucamonga, California, it will have two remaining such stores. The company did not disclose how many job cuts would be involved in the actions, which will take place during the course of the year.

J. C. Penney Company, Inc. has notified Connecticut it plans to lay off 442 workers at its Manchester distribution center. The company said that it is closing the facility's dot-com unit, and that employees' last day will be Sept 30, 2011.
J. C. Penney Company, Inc. is slashing an additional 2,200 positions from its payroll as the company scrambles to eliminate costs amid plummeting sales.
J.C.  Penney Co. Inc. announced it will whittle down the staff at its headquarters by around 9%. The company will cut 300 of its 3,400 home office jobs as part of cost-cutting measures.
J.C.  Penney announced that the company is planning to close some of its 1,014 stores soon.

J.C. Penney has announced that it has eliminated some positions at its corporate headquarters, following an announcement last month that it plans to shutter up to 140 stores. The job cuts come after J.C. Penney announced February 24 plans to shutter between 130 and 140 of its stores, or roughly 13% to 14% of its portfolio. Those locations contributed less than 5% in annual sales and no profit dollars to the company in 2016. Closing the stores is expected to generate annual savings of roughly $200 million, though the company expects to incur $225 million in pre-tax charges during the first half of 2017. A list of what stores will be closed is expected to be issued in mid-March after workers have been notified. Also being shuttered are two distribution centers in Lakeland, Florida, and Buena Park, California. The Florida facility is expected to close in early June, with operations transferring to a logistics facility in Atlanta. The company is already working on selling the California hub.

JC Penney Co. Inc. has announced that the locations of stores it plans to close, adding that it would buy out about 6,000 employees in the process. The J.C. Penney department store in Rockland Plaza is one of 138 locations that will be closed across the country by the end of 2017. Liquidation of the stores is expected to begin in April 2017.

JCPenney Co. announced that is closing its Richmond Heights store at Richmond Town Square, part of a plan to shutter 138 stores nationwide and a supply chain facility in Lake-land, Florida. The department store chain announced the decision, part of an aggressive strategy to return to profitability announced on February 24, would cut about 5,000 jobs nationally over the next few months. Most stores will begin liquidating on April 17 and most job cuts will take place in June. At Richmond Town Square, the former Macy's store remains empty nearly two years after it closed, and the Sears store is leaving on March 26.

JC Penney is laying off more than 100 workers in Ohio as it permanently closes one of its stores. The company sent a WARN notice to the Ohio Department of Job & Family Services alerting them that 117 workers will lose their jobs permanently by the end of July. The company intends to close its retail store located in the Richmond Town Square at 701 Richmond Road in Richmond Heights. The store will close July 31. The company anticipates that a few associates will be offered employment at other retail locations, though none of the employees are represented by a union and do not have bumping rights.

J.C. Penney Co. Inc. laying off 670 employees at its Wauwatosa, Wisconsin, distribution center, and plans to sell the massive building to a local real estate firm. It's also planning to shut down eight stores, though it did not give the locations for those closures. The distribution center will close July 1, and the call center Sept. 1.

J. C. Penney Company, Inc. provided sales guidance for the year 2020. For the year, the company expects comparable store sales to be in a range of negative of 3.5% to 4.5%.The Company expects to close at least six store locations in fiscal 2020.

Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust announced closure of the 118,000 square foot JCPenney store at its Exton Square Mall. PREIT looks forward to incorporating the JCPenney building into its planned redevelopment of the mall which is expected to follow the recapture of an existing Kmart location, ideally located with extensive frontage along heavily traveled Route 100 in Exton, Pennsylvania. Exton Square Mall is located in Chester County, whose exceptional demographics include the hige incomes in Pennsylvania. According to demographic data, 37.5% of households in the trade area exceed $100,000, which significantly exceeds the state average. Further demonstrating the strength of the market, average home values in the trade area are 75% higher than the state average.

PREIT planned closure of the 120,000 square foot Macy's store at Valley Mall in Hagerstown, MD. In the last five years, PREIT has successfully leased over 100,000 square feet of space at Valley Mall, upgrading its retail, dining and entertainment offerings to include featured national retailers like H&M, which will open later this year, along with eateries like Starbucks, Red Robin, Noodles and Company, Primanti Bros. and Tilted Kilt.
Pennsylvania Real Estate Investment Trust has permanently laid off 31 of its corporate and property management employees.
Pepsico, Inc. laid off 3,500 employees and closed six plants as part of an effort to cut $1.2 billion in costs by 2011.

PepsiCo Inc.'s Hampden bottling plant laid off 75 workers over cost concerns in part linked to Baltimore City's tax on bottled beverages. The facility's other 320 employees, who work in warehousing and sales to retailers, will not be affected. Manufacturing of the soft drink cans and two-liter bottles will be shifted to other facilities in Maryland and the mid-Atlantic.
Pepsico, Inc. is ending its bottling operation in Fargo, a move that will eliminate 16 jobs. The company's 302 warehouse and sales staff will not be affected.

PepsiCo Inc. shut down production at its Collierville bottling plant on March 13, 2014, idling about 60 workers as the soft drink giant grapples with a long national slump in cola sales. The employees were sent home after they arrived for work on March 13, 2014 morning at the plant at 150 S. Byhalia Road. About 100 employees on the distribution and sales side of the facility aren't affected.

Pepsico announced that up to 100 Philadelphia-area workers will be laid off from the company as the soda and snack giant deals with slumping sales following the institution of the sweetened beverage tax in the city. The Purchase, New York-based soda company directly connected the job cuts with the city's soda tax, rolled out at the start of 2017. Pepsi's job cuts and its reasoning behind them in a statement that insinuated the layoffs are just another tactic in the beverage industry's push to kill the soda tax in Philadelphia.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it would close job sites at four suburban Chicago locations as part of its reorganization since acquiring the former Pharmacia Corp. More than 2,000 people work at the five sites that will be shut down over the next 18 months at two locations in Skokie and one each in Mount Prospect and Elk Grove Village, Pfizer spokeswoman Mariann Caprino.
Pfizer Inc. announced that it plans to cut 615 jobs in Michigan by the end of the year.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it plans to eliminate jobs and make other spending cuts that will save $4 billion a year. Pfizer announced that manufacturing and sales positions would be likely targets but did not specify how many people would lose their jobs, or when.

Pfizer Inc. plans to shut down a factory that employs about 500 people in Stockholm by 2008, as part of a global cost-cutting plan. The shutdown of the factory, which makes syringes, will be phased out over the next three years, as the company has canceled plans to develop a new product.

Pfizer Inc. is planning to cut up to one-third of some 1,700 jobs in Germany. Pfizer has incurred sales losses as a result of Germany's health reform, under which pharmaceutical companies have had to lower prices on a number of patented drugs. The company is therefore under pressure to cut costs, and it has announced plans to cut costs by USD 4 billion worldwide.

Pfizer Inc. is eliminating about 40 positions, including data-management jobs, within its southeastern Connecticut operations as part of its continuing global restructuring. The local job reductions follow a downsizing of about 28 jobs last month within Pfizer's global manufacturing plant in Groton. Many of those affected by the job reductions are local, and longtime, Pfizer employees, and it's expected that the most recent job reductions would be completed around mid-April. The restructuring plan has already produced savings of about $800 million during 2005 -- ahead of initial projections -- and the company is forecasting savings of $2 billion this year and $3.5 billion in 2007, culminating in the anticipated annual savings of about $4 billion in 2008.

Pfizer Inc. it will phase out its manufacturing operations in Groton by the end of 2008, eliminating about 300 jobs. The move will allow the drug maker to expand its growing research and development operations near the 50-acre manufacturing site. The company announced that it will begin cutting its manufacturing operation next year. Pfizer officials said workers affected by the closure will be offered severance, early retirement, job placement assistance and other benefits.

Pfizer Inc. reported that it is likely to announce several thousand job cuts next week, as part of a strategy plan which could involve rethinking the way the drugs giant develops, makes and markets medicines. The company's emerging strategy appears to be to contain spending by keeping research and development costs flat, while cutting other costs, including marketing and manufacturing dramatically.

Pfizer Inc. laid off 50 employees earlier this month, and is cutting between 50 and 150 people in two-week cycles through the rest of the summer. The company has announced that it plans to transfer up to 70% of the Ann Arbor employees to other company locations.

Pfizer Inc. announced it expects to eliminate about 200 manufacturing positions in Portage and Kalamazoo during the next year. The company has about 3,000 factory workers in the area, so the cuts would represent about 6.6% of those jobs. Job cuts are needed because of ongoing changes in demand for Pfizer's products. Chambers also said the number of workers will be increased for some product lines and decreased for others. Some cuts will be achieved through job attrition. In January, Pfizer said it would eliminate about 250 drug-safety positions in downtown Kalamazoo next year as part of a larger restructuring effort.

Pfizer Inc. plans to close its Poce-sur-Cisse research centre near Amboise in France. According to management, 150 companies have been contacted in the course of a year with a view to finding a buyer, and three began negotiations, but the last of these is reported to have withdrawn at the beginning of February 2008. The number of employees at the laboratory is believed to have deterred potential bidders. Union representatives are demanding information regarding the content of negotiations, suspecting that the confidential nature of the talks may have indicated a lack of determination on the part of management to sell the laboratory, which currently counts 110 staff members following a restructuring programme. Cuts at Pfizer have been prompted by competition from generic drug manufacturers and a drop in sales.

Pfizer Inc. has announced that it intends to lay off 90 employees of its Italian subsidiary. The redundancies are based on a new structure which the company created in May 2009, which was part of its global reorganization plan. This reorganization plan will see the creation of smaller, more efficient units, and the centralization of certain roles within Europe. Moreover, in the next three years, Pfizer is going to make 43 of its Italian employees involved in clinical research redundant.

Pfizer Inc. is eliminating research-and-development operations in Sanford and Research Triangle Park that employ a total of 170 workers. The company announced the cutbacks as part of a worldwide restructuring of its R&D operations in the wake of last month's acquisition of Wyeth. The cutbacks at Sanford include only the research-and-development work done at the facility, which previously was part of Wyeth. Pfizer is closing a half-dozen R&D centers, a move that will leave it with 14 sites around the world. The closures also will eliminate the jobs of roughly 15% of the company's scientists and laboratory technicians. In addition to job cuts, some employees are being asked to move to other sites.

Pfizer Inc. is cutting 600 of its 1,000 St. Louis-area jobs and selling its Chesterfield research facility back to Monsanto Co. as part of a larger restructuring following its $68 billion acquisition of Wyeth. The company is narrowing its 20-plus research centers to five main research sites and nine specialized sites. The layoffs will occur through 2011. The companywide restructuring will cut Pfizer's global research and development square footage by 35%.

Pfizer Inc. announced it plans to close its research and development site in New London and move about 1,500 jobs to its Groton campus. The changes are part of a consolidation due to Pfizer's merger last month with Wyeth Pharmaceuticals.

Pfizer Inc. has filed notice with the state Department of Labor that it intends to lay off at least 200 people from its Rockland division by March. The Pfizer notice says 200 of 2,931 employees in pharmaceutical manufacturing will be laid off by March 12.

Pfizer Inc.'s drug manufacturing plant in Sanford has been spared from closure in a realignment of Pfizer's worldwide manufacturing plant network, but the plant's work force will be cut almost in half by the end of 2015. Staffing at the Lee County facility, roughly 25 miles southeast of the Triad, is facing a reduction of another 400 jobs by the end of 2015. The plant, which currently employs about 850 employees in manufacturing and support, was part of Pfizer's $68 billion acquisition of rival drug maker Wyeth in late 2009. The global manufacturing plant realignment plan includes the closure of eight manufacturing plants in Richmond, Va.; two plants in New York, two plants in Puerto Rico and three plants in Ireland. In addition to the reductions in Sanford the company will be trimming operations at plants in Puerto Rico and Ireland, as well as one plant each in Andover, Mass.; Havant, U.K., and Illertissen, Germany. The global realignment plan is expected to reduce the company's global headcount by 6,000 people over the next several years. Workers who will lose their jobs as a result of the changes will receive severance benefits and other assistance to help with the transition, the company states. The company announced in November that it would layoff off 100 people who worked in research and development at the Sanford plant, which had about 1,000 employees at the time. The May 18, 2010 announcement will affect workers in Sanford's manufacturing operations.

Pfizer Inc. unveiled plans to close its vaccine production site in Weesp, the Netherlands, as part of a global restructuring programme. In the coming 18 to 24 months, the company plans to move the production of poultry vaccines from Weesp to the United States and Brazil and that of other vaccines to Spain and other sites.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it will lay off more than 1,000 employees at its research and development site in Groton as the drug giant cuts costs. Pfizer's announcement was part of its strategy to focus on neuroscience, oncology and other areas and boost productivity. The eastern Connecticut work force of 4,500 will be cut to about 3,400 in the next 18 months, a reduction of about 25% as some operations are moved to Cambridge, Mass. Pfizer will shutter a research and development center in southern England in the next 18 months to two years.

Pfizer Inc. is to close its local base. More than 2,400 jobs are to go at the research site at Sandwich. The company said it is part of a global programmed of changes to accelerate Pfizer's long term research and development (R&D) strategy.

Pfizer Inc. has told 900 staff at its Kent plant that they are "at risk" of redundancy as the company prepares to pull out of the research and development site. During the consultation period, 900 employees, mostly involved in early-stage research received "at risk" notices, although these do not automatically lead to redundancy. Now that consultation has concluded, the first notices of redundancy are expected to be handed out over the summer. This will occur at different times according to the needs and priorities of each area of the business. The company begins a second consultation in May 2011 as part of the process of shutting down the site by the end of 2012. The company announced in April it will pay three-months base salary plus shift allowance as part of the redundancy package. The decision to close Sandwich came as the company took steps to streamline its research activities.

Pfizer Inc. is looking to cut $1 billion in costs. The company cut about 600 jobs from its once 1,000 members work force in Chesterfield, Mo., as part of the firm's larger plan to eliminate more than 19,000 jobs and reduce costs by $5 billion by the end of 2012, following its $68 billion Wyeth acquisition. About $500 million in annual expenses will be cut this year and another $500 million will be cut next year.

Pfizer Inc. announced pharmaceutical layoffs, and about a quarter of the 4,220 layoffs revealed by the company last year affected company employees in the region, as the New York-based pharmaceutical giant eased the last of its scientists out of the former worldwide research-and-development headquarters in New London now owned by the Electric Boat and released plans to reduce its local work force by 1,100 in a gradual process that will be completed by this summer.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it plans to cut an undisclosed number of U.S. sales positions. The job cuts which makes Viagra, Lipitor and the antidepreseent Pristiq, will come from segments of its sales force that promote drugs to primary-care physicians.
Pfizer Inc. to close the plant in Sydney in 2015 where about 140 workers manufacture both human and animal medications.

Pfizer Inc. announced that it will close one of its three manufacturing plants in Puerto Rico by 2017. The company announced the manufacturing of products at its plant in the north coastal city of Barceloneta will be moved elsewhere. The company announced the closure is linked to the loss of patent exclusivity and improved manufacturing efficiency. The company announced that it does not know yet how many people will be laid off.

Pfizer has decided to close its plant situated at Thane Belapur Road, K.U. Bazar P.O., Navi Mumbai - 400705 with effect from September 16, 2015. The decision to close the Plant is based on an assessment of its long term viability and its ability to achieve the needed production. There has practically been no production activity at this plant since 2013, and the closure will not impact the supply of any of Company medicines to patients. The decision to close the plant is based on an assessment of its long term viability and its ability to achieve the needed production.

Pfizer plans to slash 151 positions as it will discontinue the vaccine production at its site in Pearl River, USA. The site originally belonged to Wyeth, a company which Pfizer acquired in 2009, and had 4,000 employees. Pfizer already discontinued the consumer health production there and the new job cuts will reduce the number of employees to about 700. The remaining staff will be active in oncology drug production and research and development operations. The company then announced a plan to discontinue activities in eight sites.Pfizer is now focused on biologics manufacturing. It plans to invest between EUR 300 million (USD 336.2 million) and EUR 400 million to expand a biologics plant in Dublin, Ireland and further USD 200 million to build a new plant in Andover, US.

US drugs Pfizer will shut two of its three manufacturing plants in the UK in the next four years, putting 370 jobs at risk. The Park Royal site in London is earmarked for closure by May 2017, leaving 100 employees out of a job. Pfizer's global cold chain packaging and distribution site in Havant, in Portsmouth will shut by the end of 2020, with 270 job losses.

Exelon Power announced it will retire two suburban Philadelphia electric generating units earlier than previously announced, as a result of a new analysis by PJM Interconnection, the regional transmission organization. PJM will allow Exelon to close the Cromby Generating Station Unit 2 after Dec. 31, 2011, six months earlier than previously announced, and the Eddystone Generating Station Unit 2 after Dec. 31, 2012, a year earlier than previously announced.
Altria Group Inc. will cut its cigarette-related work force by about 15% as part of plan to reduce costs amid declining industry volume.
ConocoPhillips announced that it plans to restructure its operations in the Lower 48 states, the North Sea and parts of Europe to cut overhead costs. The restructuring will result in job layoffs.
ConocoPhillips announced it was shutting down its refinery in Sweeny, south of Houston.

ConocoPhillips is cutting 4% of its 32,000-member work force. The layoffs started and will continue through March. The job reductions will be based on the company's current business, skill-set needs and relative job performance. ConocoPhillips announced the layoff plan in January.

ConocoPhillips confirmed it will cut up to 230 jobs in its North Sea operations after completing a review of its business. Staff numbers in the UK would be cut from 1,649 staff and contractors to 1,419 by March of 2015. The cuts will fall predominantly on Aberdeen where the firm employs around 1,100, including 700 permanent staff and 400 contractors. All employees have been advised to re-apply for their current jobs.

ConocoPhillips announced that, the latest round of the company layoffs will affect approximately 90 workers in Bartlesville. That's about 6% of the 1,400 employees at the location, a number that is in step with the exploration and production. The global workforce is being reduced by approximately 6%, or about 1,000 employees, with the largest cuts coming in North America.
Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation announced that it will cut approximately 1,200 positions, or 12% of total workforce as part of restructuring initiatives.
Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. announced that it will close its last sewing plant in Ozark, Ala., by May 15, resulting in about 500 job cuts.

Phillips-Van Heusen Corp. announced that it will close 175 stores and lay off 400 employees due to the recession. About 250 of the layoffs will come from the company's salaried division, reducing that unit's work force by about 10%. The remaining 150 layoffs will come from the neckwear manufacturing division. The company will also stop domestic production of machine-made neckwear, reduce its warehouse capacity and cut travel, marketing and administrative expenses.

A Pier 1 Imports Inc. shareholder wants the company to close between 250 and 300 underperforming stores and add new directors. Last month that it had fired 175 workers to save the company about $17 million a year in costs. The company also hired former TJX Cos. executive Alex Smith as CEO, replacing longtime chief Marvin J. Girouard.

Pier 1 Imports Inc. will close 20 to 25 stores before the end of the year to cut costs.The company also will eliminate excess distribution center space. Costs from closing stores and terminating leases will be as much as $8 million.

Pier 1 Imports Inc. (PIR) announced that it is considering closing up to 45 locations in fiscal 2020 as leases expire. The store closure number could increase to up to 15% of stores if the company is unable to achieve performance goals, sales targets, and reductions in occupancy and other costs.
U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray will layoff about 55 employees, 10 percent of the workforce at its equity capital markets unit, because of the poor equity market conditions.

Pitney Bowes Inc. plans to lay off 96 employees in Danbury. The layoffs are part of a larger initiative through which the company is outsourcing its internal information technology work. These jobs support the company's internal voice and data networks, servers and other technology needs. In addition to the approximately 96 jobs in Danbury, about 24 workers in Shelton and 12 in Stamford are affected, as well as a smattering in Colonie, N.Y., and Lanham, Md., and one or two at various other locations. Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification act notices to give 60 days advance notice of a plant closing or mass layoff. According to the notice, the layoffs are effective September 20, 2007; the contract will take effect in a couple of months, or at about that time.

Pitney Bowes Inc. has laid off 128 employees in its software division, 12 coming from the North Greenbush operation. Pitney Bowes Software, based in the Rensselaer Technology Park, includes the Pitney Bowes MapInfo segment. The Pitney Bowes Software business has 1,600 employees.

Pitney Bowes Inc. plans to close the Bridgeton, Mo., warehouse it operates under contract with the U.S. Postal Service and lay off 59 workers. The closure, expected to occur by early March, is part of the Postal Service's larger plan to reduce costs and consolidate operations.
Pope & Talbot announced on January 17 that it would temporarily lay off 250 employees due to poor conditions in the lumber market and the increase of energy costs.

Another 800 mill workers in B.C. are about to lose their jobs as two more pulp mills-in Mackenzie in the Central Interior and Nanaimo on Vancouver Island-are shut down. Pope & Talbot Inc. said the closure will be effective immediately after creditors refused to extend financing for the company in bankruptcy court. The job losses add to the troubles already facing what was once the province's most important industry.
