Potlatch Corp. has shifted much of its shipping business to the Puget Sound, bypassing the Port of Lewiston and Snake and Columbia rivers and resulting in the layoff of a handful of port workers. The reduction in volume of the Port of Lewistons second largest shipper prompted the port to lay off four of 10 full-time container yard employees Friday, said David Doeringsfeld, Lewiston's port manager. Potlatch has about 775 workers in pulp and paperboard in Lewiston and another 650 in consumer products.
A division of Precision Castparts Corp. announced that it plans to cut 10% of its salaried workers.

Precision Castparts Corp. announced that its Special Metals alloy plant in Huntington is laying off about 100 workers. The company didn't specify in a statement whether the layoffs would be temporary or permanent. The company said it will evaluate its staffing in the future as business conditions warrant. The 130-acre plant manufactures high-performance nickel alloys for the aerospace, gas well and other industries and employs more than 500 hourly workers.
Procter & Gamble announced that its Industrial Area plant in Kenya would close down thereby laying off 80 employees.

The Procter & Gamble Co. announced that about 150 workers will lose their jobs when the company moves its paper production operations from one plant to another. About 1,250 employees involved in making facial tissues, toilet paper and paper towels at Procter & Gamble Paper Products' East River plant will move to the Fox River plant. The company will offer the rest, about 150 workers, a buyout through March 1.

The Procter & Gamble Co. is cutting 750 jobs in its Clairol division, or nearly half of the division's global manufacturing work force, and is closing three overseas manufacturing plants and a distribution center in New Jersey. The moves come as the company consolidates operations after its purchase of Clairol in November. Hair care manufacturing will be consolidated primarily at existing Procter & Gamble hair care plants. The company will close Clairol manufacturing sites in Lima, Peru, Maracay, Venezuela, and Cram lington, England, as well as a distribution center in Edison, N.J. There will be 260 jobs cut at P.& G.'s Stamford operation.

The Procter & Gamble Co. is closing its Hamilton-based Canadian distribution centre, putting 68 full-time employees out of work. But the company says the city is on a short list of southern Ontario locations for a new, much larger warehouse which will be run by another company. P&G says 16 of its workers could find jobs as a quality assurance workers at the new warehouse. Others will be eligible for retirement or severance packages. In addition to the 68 full-time workers who will lose their jobs next spring, Darby said, 30 temporary contracts with other workers will not be renewed.

Now P&G officials want all distribution operations under one roof and a new facility opened in the spring of 2005.

In an attempt to increase productivity and tackle rising commodity costs and declining consumer spending, Procter & Gamble Co. would be cutting 15% of its senior staff and restructuring international operations. The company announced that it is committed to flat or declining head count for the foreseeable future. It also aims to increase organic sales by the existing annual 4 to 6% target.

Procter & Gamble Co. announced that about 55 employees will be affected when the company closes a distribution center in eastern Henrico County in the first half of next year. The center on Carolina Avenue, which distributes professional hair-care products under brand names such as Sebastian, Wella and Graham Webb, is closing because the Cincinnati-based consumer products giant is reorganizing and reducing its hair-care products distribution sites from five to two. The local operations are being moved to a site in Joppa, Md., near Baltimore. Some employees might get jobs at other Procter & Gamble sites with full relocation support. Others will get severance packages of up to 12 months of pay and benefits, $5,000 retraining allowances and outplacement job assistance.

Procter & Gamble Co. will eliminate up to 2,000 jobs a year from 2014 to 2016, after it completes its current $10 billion restructuring. It's not clear how the cuts will impact P&G's local workforce of roughly 12,000. P&G already had targeted 5,700 nonmanufacturing jobs companywide to be eliminated by next June. The company announced plan to cut 10% of its non-manufacturing jobs, or 5,700 jobs, by the end of its fiscal year in June 2013.
P&G is cutting 3,000 office jobs over the next two years. It's selling its pet food business and may jettison other units. It's deep into cutting $10 billion from costs by 2016.
Publix Super Markets Inc. has decided to close PublixDirect, the online grocery shopping service it began testing in south Florida two years ago.
Pulte Homes Inc. announced a restructuring plan. The company plans to further trim its work force by 16%. The company reported it would also take a pretax charge between $40 million and $50 million.

Pulte Homes Inc. plan to cut 800 jobs will actually benefit Michigan. In a federal regulatory filing the company announced its August merger with Centex Corp. enabled the job reductions. At least half of those layoffs already have taken place, with the rest expected by the end of 2010.

Quaker Chemical Corporation declared a quarterly dividend of $0.23 per share, payable on January 30, 2009, to shareholders of record at the close of business on January 16, 2009. As part of its cost reduction efforts, the company has eliminated over 80 positions, primarily in North America and Europe, representing approximately 10% of the workforce in those regions. The company expects to take a restructuring charge of approximately $3 million in the fourth quarter.

The Quantum Corp. announced that it would cut an unspecified number of jobs by March, the end of its fiscal year, to reduce costs. Because of the action, Quantum will take charges of about $4 million to $5 million before the end of the fiscal year.
Raytheon announced that it is laying off 450 managerial and administartive positions in Kansas. The lay offs represent 10% reduction in the state workforce.
Raytheon Co. has laid off 61 workers in Rhode Island. All affected workers were assigned to development of research projects at the company's Portsmouth facility.

A delay in selling eight Patriot units to South Korea has contributed to the elimination of 490 Raytheon Co. jobs at five Massachusetts facilities, the company said. Lexington-based Raytheon announced that the layoffs would affect approximately 210 manufacturing employees and 280 support and engineering employees at its Andover, Bedford, Lexington, Sudbury and Tewksbury, Mass., facilities. All are associated with its Air/Missile Defense Systems business unit.
Raytheon Co. has announced that it will layoff 220 employees, approximately 0.25 percent of its workforce, in sites around Massachusetts.
Raytheon Co. announced that about 50 employees from its engineering and information-technology departments in Aurora that they will be laid off.

Raytheon Co. announced that it laid off 35 production workers at its Largo plant, effective July 20, 2007. The company said the cuts were triggered by production changes at the facility, which makes military communications equipment. Following the layoffs, Raytheon will have 710 employees in Largo and another 925 in St. Petersburg.

Raytheon Co. has confirmed that it will be joining State Farm Insurance in Richardson's new CityLine development. The company will occupy an almost 490,000-square-foot office campus to be constructed near the southwest corner of Wyndham Lane and Bush Turnpike. KDC will develop the three-building project, which will house 1,700 Raytheon workers now located in Garland. The Raytheon complex will be built along with apartments, shops and hotels in the 186-acre mixed-use CityLine project. Construction will start this summer. Architect HKS designed the building. The new office campus in Richardson will be ready late next year.The company will close its Garland office location on Jupiter Road, which has been in business since the 1950s.

Regal-Beloit Corporation will eliminate the jobs of about 200 workers in Saukville and Grafton as part of a restructuring of its motor manufacturing business. The cuts at one of Ozaukee County's top private employers come little more than two years after privately owned Leeson Electric, then based in Grafton, was sold to the Beloit-based manufacturer for $260 million.

Regal Beloit Corporation announced that 80 to 85 jobs at the company's plant in Springfield will be cut in mid-October. Most are full-time positions. The Springfield plant makes components for heating, ventilation and air condition systems. The company on September 27, 2012, reported that most of the products made in Springfield are in demand during the hot summer months. The company reported that it hopes to rehire workers in the spring, when demand picks up again. The second and third shifts at the Springfield plant are being eliminated for now.
AutoNation Inc. announced plans to cut 1,300 jobs and sell underperforming stores as part of a plan to reduce its costs by $100 million a year.

Reynolds & Reynolds Co. announced that it will cut 450 jobs. The company said that it will cut 170 jobs over the next days and will eliminate another 280 jobs over the next three years; the job cuts will help it save $25 million a year, with freezing of its defined benefit plan and other measures taking total annual savings to $40 million a year, with charges totalling up to $16 million.

Rite Aid Corp. at the corner of Main Street and Limestone is closing on April 19, 2008. And with its black metal facade, although it may not be the prettiest building on the block that is to become the site of a high-rise hotel, people who live and work downtown say the drug store's beauty is in its usefulness. The store's closing will mean downtown will be left without a pharmacy. Rite Aid is located on a block slated for redevelopment. Plans call for 14 buildings on the block to be razed to make way for the proposed $250 million CentrePointe project, a 35-story complex with hotel rooms, 77 condominiums, retail and office space and a parking garage.

Rite Aid Corp. will begin shutting down a central New York distribution center in 2011, affecting nearly 400 employees. The company said layoffs will begin in January and the Rome facility is expected to close by July. Union officials are negotiating severance pay based on seniority. The 388 workers will be offered the chance to apply for 60 jobs available at a distribution center in suburban Syracuse. Others could be transferred to warehouses elsewhere on the East Coast.

Rite Aid Corp. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended May 28, 2011. The company reported revenues for quarter were $6.4 billion, flat to $6.4 billion in last year's first quarter. Revenues were positively impacted by an increase in same store sales, which were offset by store closings. Same store sales for the quarter increased 0.8% over the prior-year period. Net loss was $63.1 million or $0.07 per basic and diluted share compared to last year's first quarter net loss of $73.7 million or $0.09 per basic and diluted share. Decreases in both SG&A and interest expense contributed to the decrease in net loss. This was partially offset by a decline in front-end margin, which was driven by investments in Rite Aid's wellness+ customer loyalty program, and a loss on debt modification related to the refinancing of the company's $343 million Tranche 3 term loan in March 2011. Adjusted EBITDA was $262.9 million or 4.1% of revenues for the first quarter compared to $249.8 million or 3.9% of revenues for the like period last year. Loss before income taxes was $60.81 million compared to $66.54 million last year. Net cash provided by operating activities was $385.33 million compared to $519.57 million last year. Loss attributable to common stockholders was $65.53 million compared to $76.00 million last year. Cash capital expenditures were $56.8 million. The company confirmed fiscal 2012 guidance with sales expected to be between $25.7 billion and $26.1 billion, same store sales to range from an increase of 0.5% to an increase of 2.0% over fiscal 2011 and Adjusted EBITDA to be between $800 million and $900 million. Net loss is expected to be between $370 million and $560 million or a loss per diluted share of $0.42 to $0.64. Capital expenditures are expected to be approximately $300 million. The company expects to be free cash flow positive for the year.The company plans to compete 20 relocations and remodel 500 stores. Remodels incorporate components of the various new formats. The comp

Rite Aid Corporation is planning to complete 13 relocations and remodel 500 Wellness stores in 2013. The company expects to close a total of 50 stores in 2013, of which the guidance includes a store lease closing provision to close 20 with the balance of the stores closing on a lease expiration.

Rite Aid Corporation announced a leadership transition plan and an organizational restructuring to better align its structure with the companys operations and to reduce costs. As part of the leadership transition, John Standley will step down as chief executive officer. The Board will promptly commence a search process for a new CEO, and Standley will remain CEO until the appointment of his successor. Rite Aid also announced additional management changes, each of which is effective immediately. Bryan Everett, chief operating officer of Rite Aid Stores has been promoted to chief operating officer of the company, succeeding Kermit Crawford who is leaving the company, effective immediately. Matthew Schroeder, chief accounting officer and treasurer, has been promoted to chief financial officer, effective immediately. Schroeder is succeeding Darren Karst who is leaving the company this spring after supporting a brief transition. Brian Hoover, group vice president and controller, has been promoted to chief accounting officer, effective immediately. Jocelyn Konrad, executive vice president, pharmacy, has been promoted to executive vice president, pharmacy and retail operations. Derek Griffith, executive vice president, store operations is leaving the company. Rite Aid also will consolidate additional senior leadership roles resulting in the elimination of certain positions. In addition, the company announced actions that will reduce managerial layers and consolidate roles across the organization, resulting in the elimination of approximately 400 full-time positions, or more than 20% of the corporate positions located at the companys headquarters and across the field organization. Approximately two-thirds of the reductions will take place immediately with the balance by the end of fiscal 2020. As a result of the restructuring, Rite Aid expects to achieve annual cost savings of approximately $55 million, of which approximately $42 million will be realized within fiscal year 2020. These cost savings will serve to

Rockwell Automation Inc. announced that Dublin plant will close in 2010, impacting 145 workers. The operation would face a phased closure beginning in October, 2009 and ending in July 2010. The company also plans to close its Sumner, Iowa, manufacturing center by December 2010, affecting 163 employees.
Rockwell International Corp. announced that it has released 119 Milwaukee-area workers as part of its cost-cutting strategy to eliminate 1,000 jobs.
Rohm and Haas Company announced its plans to reduce its workforce by 6-7% worldwide.
Rohm & Haas Co. is closing its plant in New Jersey, citing increased costs and overseas competition. The plant employs 90 workers.

Rohm & Haas Co. plans to cut about 80 jobs in North America after awarding a seven-year contract to Affiliated Computer Services Inc. for human-resources services. Most of the job cuts will be in the first quarter of 2005, Philadelphia-based Rohm & Haas said in a statement. Costs related to the cuts were deducted from fourth-quarter 2003 income, the company said.

Rohm & Haas Co. plans to reduce its workforce and cut its installed capacity in the company's emulsions network in North America by 30%, reflecting equally the impact of productivity improvement efforts and reduced market demand. The company also said it plans to adjust the infrastructure for its Electronic Materials group, reflecting the increased shift of the business to Asia.

Rohm & Haas Co. plans to cut 900 jobs, or 5.5% of its workforce, in an effort to cut costs as it sees weakening demand amid widespread market weakness. The chemical maker said the moves build on the restructuring actions the company announced in June 2008. At the time, Rohm and Haas said it would reduce production and cut about 925 jobs. The company is in the process of being acquired by Dow Chemical Co. The new round of restructuring and job cuts is expected to generate about $90 million in annualized savings. The actions will also result in $90 million in pre-tax restructuring and asset impairment charges in the fourth quarter of 2008.The company announced that the new round of restructuring and job cuts is expected to generate about $90 million in annualized savings. The actions will also result in $90 million in pre-tax restructuring and asset impairment charges in the fourth quarter of 2008.

Repsol E&P USA Inc. canceled a drillship contract with Rowan Companies PLC earlier in November. The cancelation will affect 80 to 110 Houston-based employees. Rowan is still finalizing its specific plans, but it expects to cut the jobs during the two weeks beginning January 14. Affected employees do not have bumping rights, meaning workers with more seniority cannot take jobs from those with less seniority. The affected employees work on the Rowan Renaissance, which is on standby mode in the Gulf of Mexico near Grand Isle Louisiana, according to the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act letter Rowan sent to the TWC. The company plans to retain some employees to work on the rig while it's idle, and it is possible that certain employees may be rehired if Rowan secures a new drilling contract.

Rowan Companies PLC plans to cut additional jobs on the Rowan Reliance drillship, which had been under contract with Cobalt International Energy Inc. Rowan said it plans to cut another 40 to 50 jobs assigned to the Reliance. The rig, which is managed from 2800 Post Oak Blvd. in Houston, will be idled once work for Cobalt is completed. Last month, Rowan said it expected to cut 100 to 150 jobs tied to the Reliance during the two-week period beginning July 21. The latest round of cuts is scheduled for the two-week period beginning Aug. 21. In both Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act letters, Rowan said it was still finalizing specific job cut plans. The company also plans to retain some employees to manage the rig while it's idle. Although Rowan might rehire some employees if it gets a new drilling contract for the rig, the job cuts are expected to be permanent. Affected employees do not have bumping rights, meaning workers with more seniority cannot take jobs from those with less seniority. The work for Cobalt was expected to be complete in mid-June, according to both letters.

Harris Teeter announced to close one of its Nashville stores next month, leaving a hole in the historic Belle Meade Theatre building. The two-story, 58,373-square-foot store in the Belle Meade Town Center will close Feb. 10, 2015.
Russell Corporation announced that it will be laying off 800 jobs from four Alabama factories, due to a declining demand for its athletic apparel.

Russell Corp. will eliminate 2,300 jobs about 15% of its worldwide work force and freeze its pension plan. The job cuts, most of which will come in the U.S., are part of a bid by Russell to reduce costs so it can continue selling men's fleece products to Wal-Mart Stores Inc. The company previously said it lost a contract to sell fleece products for boys to Wal-Mart, the world's largest retailer. The loss left Russell with too much manufacturing capacity, making cutbacks necessary. Russell said the company will eliminate about 2,300 jobs from its global work force of 15,000. About 1,700 of the jobs cuts will be in the United States, with about 1,250 in Alabama. Russell said it also would reduce an unspecified number of workers in Chantilly, Va., and cut about 90 office jobs in its former headquarters at Alexander City, Ala. and in Atlanta, where the company has been based since its last restructuring. Russell also plans to close a sewing plant that employs about 600 people in Jimenez, Mexico, and said it would move production of Huffy Sports backboards from Sussex, Wisc., to China, eliminating 85 U.S. jobs.

Russell Corp. announced that it is closing its last Cross Creek Apparel plant and cutting 300 jobs. The plant will be closed by Aug. 31. Cross Creek Apparel Inc. is a division of Russell, which has dual headquarters in Atlanta and Alexander City, Ala. Russell said it is closing the plant because of continuing pressure of imported textile and apparel products from China and the Far East.

Russell Corp. announced that it would be permanently closing the doors on its carpet yarn operations at the Coosa River plant. The plant's closure marks the second time Wetumpka has been hit with negative news from the company. Russell's textile dyeing and finishing operations were eliminated last year, resulting in the loss of 450 jobs for employees.

Ryan's Restaurant Group Inc. announced its Ryan's steakhouse on Miller Lane in Vandalia is the latest to shut down. The closure of Ryan's continues a flood of departing restaurants. The closing of Ryan's also marks the restaurant's exit from the Dayton market. The company closed the Ryan's steakhouse on Stroop Road in Kettering last November.
Ryder System Inc. announced to furlough 68 employees in Findlay and Bowling Green on Feb. 19 when it shutters two truck terminals in those cities that transport parts to Toyota plants in Canada.

SPS Technologies Inc. announced that the company plans to close two facilities in the Engineered Fasteners and Components segment: a marketing and distribution center in Singapore and a tool manufacturing facility in France.

Biovail Corporation announced that it has agreed to merge with Valeant in a USD 3.2 billion deal that will likely result in hundreds of job cuts over the next year as management works to refocus the business. The combined company will be called Valeant Pharmaceuticals International Inc. and have a "significantly expanded presence" in North America and operations in eight other countries. The merger will also mean deep job cuts between the two firms, with total head count reduction between 15 and 20% - or between 660 and 880 jobs.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals International plans to fire about 25% of its workers in the U.S. and Canada, after combining with Biovail Corp. in June. That's more than the 15% cuts initially estimated when the companies announced the merger June 21.

Safeco announced that it will eliminate hundreds of jobs throughout its organization. The layoffs will affect between 5 and 10 percent of Safeco's 12,400 employees and will occur across-the-board rather than concentrated in particular division or line of

Safeway Inc. reported that it is eliminating 940 of the approximately 7,000 positions in its administrative offices. About half of these positions will be eliminated from Corporate Offices in California and Arizona. The other half will come from Retail Division Administrative Offices across the U.S. and Canada. Of the company positions eliminated, 252 were open positions that will not be filled.

THE Safeway Stores Inc. supermarket in Market Square will close next year leaving only one grocery outlet in the central activities area. Umbrella company Woolworths will not renew its lease on the large ground floor site, which expires in November 2005, and has ruled out replacing the supermarket with a Big W store. Its property general manager Peter Thomas announced the company hoped to relocate employees to other Safeway supermarkets in Geelong. The move will leave the Coles store in Westfield Bay City as the only inner city supermarket. Market Square management has not indicated whether it has already signed a tenant to replace the Safeway store.

Safeway Inc. announced that it will close 26 underperforming stores by year's end, including nine Tom Thumb stores in Dallas-Fort Worth. It will also shutter 16 Randalls stores in Houston and one in Austin. That will leave Safeway with 62 stores in Dallas-Fort Worth, 36 in Houston and 14 in Austin. It plans to remodel many of the remaining Texas stores to create so-called lifestyle centers, with higher-end products.

Safeway Inc. decided to chop hundreds of jobs nationwide, including roughly 70 in its operations in Alameda County. The offices affected included the Pleasanton headquarters, operations in Northern and Southern California, and in locations that include Oregon, Washington, Arizona, Texas, Illinois, Maryland, and Virginia.
Safeway Inc. is to axe 69 jobs at its corporate headquarters in California and make similar cuts at regional headquarters.

Safeway announced that the Raleigh Hills Safeway store at 6745 S.W. Beaverton-Hillsdale Highway, near the Scholls Ferry intersection, will close by May 14. The grocers human resources department is working with the 53 affected employees and their labor unions to find them work in nearby Safeway stores.

St. Jude Medical Inc. is cutting 30 management employees in the Twin Cities as part of a move to combine its cardiac surgery and cardiology divisions. Most of the job cuts will come in finance, marketing and human resources because management infrastructure is needed for just one division.

St. Jude Medical Inc. announced the realignment of its product divisions into two new operating units: the Implantable Electronic Systems Division (IESD) and the Cardiovascular and Ablation Technologies Division (CATD). The company will also centralize several support functions including information technology, human resources, legal, business development, and many marketing functions. The company's United States and International Divisions, which are focused on product commercialization, will continue serving customers based on existing call points and specialties. As part of the reorganization, three additional executive officers have been named: Donald Zurbay, Rachel Ellingson and Kathleen Chester. Donald Zurbay is now vice president, finance and chief financial officer, reporting to John Heinmiller, who is taking on an expanded role as executive vice president, overseeing the centralization of the IT, HR, legal and business development functions. Rachel Ellingson has been named vice president, corporate relations, as Angela Craig assumes additional responsibilities as vice president, global human resources. Kathleen Chester has been named to a newly created role of vice president, global regulatory. The company is providing support to the approximately 300 employees whose jobs have been eliminated as a result of reorganization.

Sara Lee Corp. announced that it will reduce its manufacturing output at some offshore factories that will result in the elimination of as many as 1,400 jobs. The cut backs are parallel to the 7,000 layoffs that the company announced in January.
Sara Lee Corp. announced that it will be restructuring its Liberty Fabrics textile unit, including selling some assets and closing two plants.

Sara Lee Corp., said it plans to close a coffee food service plant in Oklahoma City. The plant employs 90. Sara Lee said it also intends to close three small bakery plants, resulting in a small restructuring charge for the current quarter.

Sara Lee Corp. announced that it plans to close more U.S. bakeries as it sheds slow-selling brands to reduce costs. The company plans to spend $1 billion (U.S.) to close factories, eliminate jobs and upgrade computer systems in the biggest restructuring in Sara Lee's 66-year history.

Sara Lee Corp. on February 13, 2006 announced that it is closing down operations at its Superior coffee roasting plant in Chicago, resulting in 80 jobs being eliminated. The company cited excess production capacity at its coffee plants nationwide and the costs that would be needed to upgrade the aging facility. The plant is expected to be closed on April 14. Twelve finance, sales and procurement employees will be relocated to other sites in the Chicago area.

Sara Lee Corp. will lay off nearly 1,700 employees, or about 3% of its overall work force of 54,000, as part of a reorganization plan to increase business performance. About 1,200 workers will be laid off when the company closes its pork processing and FlavoTech spice production plants in West Point, Miss., on March 30. The company also announced that another 489 workers will be laid off around the globe as part of the restructuring. Those layoffs will result in a $40 million pretax charge.

The company said it will take a $152 million noncash pretax charge in the quarter ended Dec. 30, 2006, mainly due to continued declines in its Brazilian coffee operation. That figure includes a $34 million charge to close the Mississippi factories.

Sara Lee Corp. announced that it will close its kosher hot dog and meat processing facility on or before Jan. 30, 2009. Sara Lee has decided to exit the kosher meat business, and discontinue processing and distributing products made under all of its kosher meat brands, including Best's Kosher, Sinai Kosher, Shofar and Wilno. The closure of the Chicago facility, located at 1000 W. Pershing Road, will result in a workforce reduction of approximately 185 employees. In addition, the company will also close the Sinai Kosher outlet store located on the premises. Following the discontinuation of operations at the Chicago facility, Sara Lee Corp. intends to decommission the plant's equipment and place the facility and property up for sale.

Sara Lee Corp. plans to close its massive Greenville County bread-making factory at 1916 Piedmont Highway by early next year in response to the loss of one of its major customers, putting about 200 people out of work. The company gave employees at the plant their Worker Adjustment and Retraining Act notices, a 60-day notification enforced by the U.S. Department of Labor. Some of the affected employees will be offered jobs at other company facilities, but most will be laid off. Those employees are being offered severance packages and transitional services.

Sara Lee Corp. announced that it will close a plant in Shannon, Miss., by March 30 putting 155 people out of work. The Shannon plant, which makes Bryan Smokies cocktail sausages, has been operating since 1997.

Schering-Plough Corporation announced that the global marketing department would be eliminated and its people would be folded into the Customer Groups, to accelerate the turnaround and drive the performance of the company's brands worldwide.

Schering-Plough Corp. announces that 170 jobs are to be cut within the next three months. Employees at Schering-Plough's plant in Brinny, Innishannon met with management to be told that the company is seeking to reduce its 930 strong workforce to 762. The company blamed the job cuts on a significant drop in the demand of its anti-cancer and anti-viral medicines which are used in the treatment of hepatitis-C, malignant melanoma and other cancers. It also follows upon the recent announcement by Schering-Plough Corporation of a 10 per cent reduction in payroll expenses worldwide.

Schering-Plough is phasing out manufacturing operations at its Manati, Puerto Rico site by the end of 2006. In addition, the company will lay off 1,000 workers at its facilities in Puerto Rico and New Jersey. The company will discontinue approximately 600 positions in Puerto Rico alone, including approximately 550 in Manati and 50 in Las Piedras. Five hundred full-time positions will also be eliminated in New Jersey at the companys Kenilworth and Union sites.
Schering-Plough Corp. announced 500 job cuts as part of restructuring. The company faces slumping sales for key drugs.

Schering-Plough Corp. has announced plans to cut 330 jobs in France, 206 of which are currently occupied. The management of the company says that it is working on plans for a voluntary redundancy scheme. The planned restructuring measures follow the takeover of Organon, the pharmaceuticals division of Dutch chemicals group Akzo Nobel, by Schering-Plough. The measures will involve the merger of the two head offices and the reorganisation of the sales activities. At the same time, 35 new jobs are to be created at the company.

Schlumberger Limited eliminated another 100 jobs in North America. Schlumberger also has reduced or eliminated overtime, adjusted recruiting targets and released some contractors to help manage the downturn.

Schlumberger Limited announced that it will cut 5,000 jobs worldwide during the first half of the year, more than previously disclosed. The company said the job reductions amount to about 5% of its global staffing, including contractors. Two weeks ago, Schlumberger announced 1,000 cuts in North America and said it was looking at reductions elsewhere. The North American cuts are part of the total reduction.

Scholastic Corp. announced plans to unload its Direct-to-Home Continuities business, which markets children's books directly to parents and caregivers. The company acquired the unit in 2000 as part of its $400 million purchase of Grolier Inc. and it was profitable for the first few years. But the business has not been profitable for the past three years, and the company determined that it would not meet its goals for fiscal year 2008, Investment bank Greenhill and Co. has been retained to handle the sale.

A. Schulman is saying it plans to discontinue manufacturing operations at its dispersion plant in Orange, Texas. The company expects to complete the shutdown in its fiscal fourth quarter, which ends August 31. The closing of the plant, which has 68 employees, will reduce the company's North American production capacity by roughly 12 percent to 440 million pounds from 500 million pounds.

A Schulman Inc. announced that it would close its plant at 3007 Burnet St. outside of West Orange by late summer, costing 68 people their jobs. The plastic resin plant has operated since at least the 1950s with Schulman in ownership since at least the mid-1960s. It suffered layoffs in 1998 because of a strike against a General Motors Corp. manufacturing plant in Flint, Mich. However, the plant worked four shifts a day, seven days a week from early 1995 up to that point.

A. Schulman Inc. announced that in November it cut 60 employees, or about 15% of its North American manufacturing workers, and reduced its North American manufacturing capacity by 6.4%. A. Schulman made the cuts at its plants in Orange, Texas, and Bellevue, Ohio. Separately, Schulman said it expects to begin producing its Invision plastic coloring product in the spring at a plant in Sharon Center, Ohio. The company's first full-scale Invision plant will begin operating in 2008 in Findlay, Ohio.

A. Schulman, Inc. announced that Nashville facility is expected to close no later than February 29, 2012, the end of the company's fiscal 2012 second quarter. As a result of the realignment, four production lines at the Nashville facility will be shut down and approximately 60 jobs will be eliminated, including jobs from the Nashville facility and support staff functions.The company also announced that construction in Akron is expected to begin next month, with operations to commence by early March 2012. As part of this effort, the company anticipates investing approximately $7 million to create technical compounding capabilities in the Akron facility. This move will add approximately 20 jobs in the Akron facility.

A. Schulman Inc. will eliminate approximately 60 positions, mainly from its middle management ranks. The company said the moves are part of Schulman's restructuring, following some recent losses and the August ouster of its former CEO, Bernard Rzepka. While Schulman did not put a date on when the cuts will take effect, it did say it expects to realize annual savings of between $5 million and $6 million per year, and to book partial-year savings from the cuts when its fiscal year ends next August 31. The company said most of the reductions will impact the company's operations in Europe. And that no more than three people at the company's Fairlawn operations will be affected by the cuts. Schulman said it will cut 42 positions from its Europe, Middle East and Africa businesses, another 15 from its U.S. and Canadian business lines, with three more cuts to the ranks working in its Asia-Pacific and Latin American businesses. The company said that there will be no position eliminations from the company's Engineered Composites segment.

Scientific-Atlanta Inc. announced that it would cut about 400 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, to reduce costs as demand from customers remains slack. The cuts will save about $40 million a year. Most of the reductions are effective immediately, although some will occur over the next several months, the company said. The positions being eliminated are from every part of the business.
It was announced that Sears Roebuck & Co. will likely lay off employees at its corporate headquarters.
Sears, Roebuck & Co. has laid off 180 department managers in metro Atlanta stores in a series of cuts that eliminated more people and at higher levels than anticipated.

Sears Roebuck & Co. it plans to close three underperforming stores in The Great Indoors chain of home decorating and remodeling centers.Sears, calling the announcement a refinement of its business strategy, said it will close three Great Indoors stores in Arlington and Willowbrook, Texas, and in Cincinnati by year's end. It also plans to convert a fourth Great Indoors store in Shelby, Mich., into an outlet store.

Sears Roebuck said that it will continue to look at cost-cutting measures this year that could lead to more pink slips as it shores up its balance sheet. The Company said that there will be some additional reduction in the number of employees.

Sears, Roebuck and Co. will close eight of its namesake stores in what it says are underperforming locations. Sears and Kmart stores together total 3,530 nationwide. The company has closed 98 locations since 2008. Sears said it would shutter stores in Georgia, Tennessee, North Carolina, Texas, New Jersey, Wisconsin and New Hampshire. The closings will be effective by May 9. Workers are being offered severance packages and the chance to apply for other open positions at nearby Kmart or Sears stores.

Semtech announced worldwide reduction in force to align operating expenses with business conditions and leverage recent infrastructure investments. The actions, primarily targeted at sales, general and administrative expenses, are expected to reduce the total number of employees by about 8%. As a result of the actions, the company expects to reduce its current annualized operating expenses by about $20.0 million once the reduction plan is fully executed. Semtech expects to record total charges related to the actions of about $3.5 million during second quarter and third quarter of fiscal year 2016. The charges consist primarily of termination benefits, including severance, which are expected to be settled in cash.

ServiceMaster Co. will lay off 250 people, including 50 from the corporate office here, starting Dec. 31. The cuts include about 90 call center jobs in California and 120 positions across all operating companies.
Servicemaster Co. plans to lay off as many as 200 information technology employees in Memphis 2008 in a move that could wipe out its entire IT department.

Sherwin-Williams Co. is closing nine of its 19 Flex Bon Paints stores in Southwest Florida and merging them into nearby Sherwin-Williams locations. These are the stores that will be closing over the next several weeks: north Cape Coral, Lehigh Acres, San Carlos Boulevard near Fort Myers Beach, Naples (north and south locations), Venice, Englewood, Bradenton and Port Charlotte.

Employees at the Sherwin-Williams Co. Deshler plant were announced that their paint roller and paint tray-making facility will be closed permanently due to lagging sales and deteriorating economic conditions. Closing date for the 126-employee Henry County facility, which opened in 1953, is not set and it will remain open for several months.
Sigma-Aldrich Corp. has announced that the company plans to eliminate more than 380 jobs including 90 in Saint Louis.

Symmetricom Inc. announced cost reductions as part of an ongoing effort to further streamline the business and enhance its operational business model. The company plans to eliminate approximately 30 positions or about 4% of the company's total workforce by the end of 2009 and incur associated restructuring charges in the range of $1.5 million to $2.0 million.

Symmetricom Inc. has announced cost reductions. Symmetricom said that it plans to eliminate approximately 30 positions or about 4% of its total workforce by the end of the calendar year and incur associated restructuring charges in the range of $1.5 to $2.0 million. Symmetricom expects to record the majority of the restructuring charges in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2009. Upon completion, Symmetricom expects the restructuring to reduce annual costs by approximately $3.5 million.The company reaffirmed earnings guidance for the fourth quarter and full year of 2009. For the quarter, the company expects net revenues to be in the range of $53 million to $58 million compared to previous guidance of $51 million to $58 million. As a result of the additional restructuring charges, the company now expects GAAP earnings to range from a loss of $0.01 to earnings of $0.04 per share compared to previous guidance of GAAP earnings in the range of $0.01 to $0.06 per share. Non-GAAP earnings projections remain unchanged. The company continues to expect non-GAAP earnings in the range of $0.05 to $0.10 per share.For the year, the company expects net revenues to be in the range of $214 million to $219 million compared to previous guidance of $212 million to $219 million. The company now expects a GAAP loss in the range of $1.00 to $0.95 per share compared to previous guidance of a GAAP loss in the range of $0.97 to $0.93 per share. Non-GAAP earnings projections remain unchanged. The company continues to expect non-GAAP earnings in the range of $0.35 to $0.40 per share.

AO Smith Corp. announced that it will lay off 79 workers in Upper Sandusky come fall. The layoff announcement, which appeared on the Web site of the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services, comes as A.O. Smith is in talks to purchase a Canadian firm and days before it releases its secondquarter earnings.
Smithfield Foods Inc. announces the lay off its 185 people said the money-losing operation would be closed as soon as possible.

Smithfield Foods Inc. plans to close its Plant City meatpacking facility and will lay off nearly 760 employees in September. The closing is part of an overall restructuring of the company's pork group. The company will close six plants and transfer production to facilities that are more efficient, reducing its pork group work force by 1,800.

Smithfield Foods Inc. plans to close its Smithfield Packing Co. South plant early next year. Of its 1,375 workers, the company said 745 will be transferred to the nearby Smithfield Packing North plant, 290 will be given transfers to North Carolina plants and 340 will be laid off.
Smithfield Foods Inc. plans to close a 413,000-square-foot meatpacking facility in its hometown early 2010.

Smithfield Foods, Inc. announced that it will begin its previously announced shutdown of a Virginia facility that makes hot dogs and deli meat. The company said layoffs will start at the Portsmouth plant in January and it will close at the end of March. The first layoffs at the Smithfield Packing Co. facility will involve about 120 workers, with more than 400 workers affected by the time plant is closed. The company announced plans last November to close the plant in 2013 and shift production to a facility in Kinston, N.C.

The JM Smucker Co. announced that it is closing three of its plants and eliminating 335 jobs, in part because it is processing less fruit. The company also plans to add 150 jobs at its new Scottsville, Ky., plant. The net reduction of 185 jobs amounts to 7 percent of the company's work force. Smucker is closing plants in Watsonville, Calif., Woodburn, Ore., and West Fargo, N.D. by September 2004.

Snap-On Incorporated. says it laid off 27 more hourly workers this week at its Kenosha manufacturing plant, bringing to 78 the number cut at the toolmaker this month. Twenty-five of the laid-off employees belong to the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers Lodge 34, which represents about 250 Snap on workers. Earlier this month, Snap on announced the layoff of 43 hourly employees, 35 from the Machinists union and the dismissal of eight hourly workers at the Kenosha facility.
Snap-on Inc. announced that it expects to reduce approximately 100 positions during the second quarter of 2003.

KeyCorp announced that it will eliminate about 200 jobs from its operations in downtown Dayton in the next six to eight months. The bank will close its call center and help desk operations and consolidate operations into other centers across the United States. The work that was handled there will be moved to centers in Cleveland; Tacoma, Wash.; and Buffalo and Albany, N.Y.
KeyCorp. will lay off 185 local workers because of the closing of its downtown Dayton call center and help desk.
KeyCorp confirmed that it will lay off 230 employees at its Cleveland headquarters in an effort to rein in expenses.

KeyCorp announced that it plans to cut expenses by closing some branches and cutting jobs by the end of 2013. Key plans to close up to 5% of its 1,062 branches, or about 50 locations. Of the first wave of 17 branches that will close, none is in Greater Cleveland, and this area isn't expected to be affected significantly by branch closings.

KeyCorp. announced that it is closing 160 KeyBank and First Niagara branches in upstate New York, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania as the bank moves toward its acquisition of First Niagara. The company has promised to limit job cuts in New York to 250 people following its merger with First Niagara Financial Group.

Sonoco Products Co. announced that it plans to permanently close a recycled paperboard mill in Downingtown, Pa., after it was ravaged by a fire last month. About $500,000 in damage was caused by a March 20 fire. The plant employs 71 workers and has an annual capacity of 73,000 tons.

Sonoco Products Co. will cease plastics packaging manufacturing at the 79-employee Paragon Plastics plant it recently acquired in Union County, and use the 160,000-square-foot facility as a warehouse. Sonoco will move some of the plastic extrusion machines and jobs from Paragon to its nearby Pinckney Plant in Union.

Sonoco Products Co. announced it would close its molded-plastics plant in Frankfort Ind., displacing about 90 employees. The company said it would consolidate its Indiana operations into existing facilities in Union, Detroit, Chatham N.Y., and Forest City, N.C. The closing will be phased in, with completion expected near the end of the first quarter 2004. In August, Sonoco said it would cut about 340 jobs - mostly salaried workers - and shut down 20 plants worldwide.

Sonoco Products Co. announced that it will close its flexible packaging printing plant in Charlotte, N.C., as a part of a previously announced plan to cut costs. Work will be consolidated into other Sonoco flexible packaging printing facilities in the region. The Charlotte plant printed mainly flexographic images on packaging film for confectionery, gum, beverages, cookies, crackers and salty snacks. In August, the company announced it would close a tube and core plant in Canandaigua, N.Y.

Sonoco Products Company will cut about 340 jobs and shut down 20 plants worldwide in hopes of saving $60 million annually. The cuts announced that it include 130 people at the packaging maker's Hartsville headquarters. The salaried payroll cuts, slated to start before the end of the year, are expected to generate about $31 million in savings before taxes. Sonoco said the pretax savings from closing the plants could be as much as $29 million. The company said it doesn't know how many of its 17,500 worldwide employees at 300 operations will lose jobs as plants are closed during the next 18 months.

SBC Communications Inc. has announced that it will be laying off thousands of employees and will curtail expansion of its high-speed Internet service after the company reported a profit decline in the third quarter.

SBC Communications Inc. will eliminate 5,000 jobs, or 2.6 percent of its work force, this quarter. Jobs will be cut in 13 states and include management and nonmanagement employees who do not directly serve customers.
SBC will be closing its Modesto call center and relocating the 40 employees to Stockton. The move is part of a companywide cost-cutting campaign in light of a $2.5 billion drop in revenue in 2002.

SBC Communications Inc. announces that it plans to close more call centers and reduce its work force amid continued efforts to save money and improve its financial strength. The company has eliminated 28,000 jobs in the past two years to offset an industrywide slump triggered by a global economic slowdown and intensified competition.

SBC Communications Inc. announced that it will cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs before the end of the year. The cuts, representing about 1.7 percent to 2.3 percent of its work force, are part of a continuing plan to cut staff and costs through employee buyouts and attrition.

SBC Communications Inc. could lay off as many as 1,000 Michigan workers over the next few years as the telecommunications giant consolidates its regional customer service operations. The San Antonio-based company plans to lay off 500 workers over the next two years and another 500 workers could lose their jobs after that.

AT&T Inc. may save $18 billion by 2008 after cutting jobs and stitching together operations from SBC Communications Inc. and AT&T Corp., more than executives first expected.The company is moving faster on a plan to shed 13,000 jobs. The forecast would mean $3 billion in annual savings.

AT&T Inc. is closing its Hartford and Meriden call centers, eliminating an estimated 200 jobs. The centers served land-line customers. The call center employees are guaranteed an offer of another AT&T job in Connecticut. Severance packages are being offered to the workers whose jobs have been eliminated and other employees who may want to leave the company, opening positions for the displaced workers. AT&T has about 8,000 employees in the state.
AT&T Inc. is cutting 57 jobs from its local work force to account for new technologies that have customers adopting more wireless products.

AT&T Inc. announced it will cut approximately 1.5% of its work force as its streamlines its operations. The move comes as part of the continuing integration between the former AT&T and SBC, and it will primarily affect management employees. AT&T announced it will take a $374 million pretax charge for what should amount to 4,600 job cuts.
AT&T Inc. announced that it is cutting just under 5,000 management level jobs from its payroll.
AT&T Inc. announced that it would lay off 178 employees from the National Passport Information Center, which it operates on behalf of the U.S. State Department.

AT&T Inc. Wisconsin workers in Milwaukee announced that about 180 people are scheduled to lose their jobs by the end of the year. 118 of the job cuts will come from the closing of a network support center on N. 26th St. The other reductions involve technicians who have been working on setting up AT&T's U-verse services, which include television and high-speed Internet.

AT&T Business Solutions Customer Service unit in Richardson could be laying off up to 78 employees in the new year. The unit says it will not know for sure how many reductions will be made until the Richardson division determines how many employees will enter into voluntary severance agreements, retire or move into other positions.

AT&T Inc. plans to eliminate 75 jobs in Connecticut as part of a larger nationwide layoff. The 75 Connecticut jobs being eliminated are part of a layoff of 2,500 employees nationwide. The cuts are expected to be completed by mid-November 2009.
AT&T, Inc. will lay off 160 of its Connecticut employees over the next two months, including 80 service technicians. The layoffs include 33 service representatives in the Network Services division.

AT&T, Inc. plans to eliminate 151 jobs in the state by early November. The jobs are slated to be cut by Nov. 5, and the bulk of them -- 137 positions -- are tied to AT&T's land-line service. The rest are part of AT&T Business Solutions. Company officials expect the impact of the cuts to be mitigated somewhat by workers who volunteer for enhanced severance packages.

AT&T, Inc. announced that its AT&T Ohio will lay off 96 employees at its Reynoldsburg customer-service center in November in a cost-cutting move. The center, at 8372 E. Broad St., provides customer support for small businesses. The work will be moving to facilities in other parts of Ohio and the Midwest. The Reynoldsburg facility will remain open and several other groups of AT&T employees who work in other parts of the business will continue to work there. AT&T will assist the 96 employees in finding other jobs -- either in AT&T or elsewhere -- before their expected final day, Nov. 19.
AT&T will eliminate 120 jobs in Wisconsin by mid-April, including nearly a dozen in the Madison-to-Janesville region in the landline and central office areas.

60 employees at the AT&T, Inc. facility in Saginaw Township learned June 16, their positions would be eliminated. As more customers ditch their landlines and depend solely on cellphones, companies like AT&T are forced to adapt. There are no plans to close the AT&T facility in Saginaw Township. Work from the Saginaw Township center is being consolidated into other AT&T locations, and some of Saginaw Township employees will have the opportunity to follow their work. Eligible union-represented employees have, as part of their contract, a job offer guarantee in another part of the business, those jobs will be in Michigan and not in other states.

AT&T, Inc. plans to close a customer service center that employs nearly 60 people in Saginaw County. AT&T said it would eliminate the center in Saginaw Township. A union official says the company will close the center in September and will ship the jobs to Wisconsin and Texas.

AT&T, Inc. is eliminating about 500 union jobs that support its landline business, a further reflection that people are shifting their loyalties to cellphones, Internet telephony and mobile devices. Workers may be able to find jobs with other parts of the company that are growing, such as the wireless business. About 70 of the job cuts will be in Georgia. The others are in Alabama, Florida, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi and North Carolina. The seven states were part of the former Atlanta-based BellSouth's nine-state territory.
AT&T is laying off around 80 employees at one of the telecommunications company's offices in Charlotte.

AT&T Inc. is cutting hundreds of jobs in its Southeast region. The Communications Workers of America (CWA) Local 3310, based in Louisville, shared in a Facebook post that AT&T will cut 917 employees in CWA District 3, which consists of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Kentucky, Louisiana, Mississippi, North Carolina, Puerto Rico, South Carolina and Tennessee. CWA confirmed that 25 of those job cuts will be in Louisville, with a total of 51 AT&T jobs lost in Kentucky. Nationwide, CWA said, the company is reducing its workforce by 1,800 employees.

AT&T is slimming down after grappling with COVID-19. The company plans to permanently shutter more than 250 AT&T Mobility and Cricket Wireless stores, affecting 1,300 retail jobs, the Communications Workers of America said in a statement on Tuesday. In addition, the company plans to cut over 3,400 technician and clerical jobs across the country over the next few weeks. The company confirmed there were store closures and job cuts without giving any numbers.

On October 28, 2014, Spartan Motors Inc. announced that it will close its Ocala, FL plant as part of its strategic plan to improve the performance of its Emergency Response Vehicles segment. Fire truck production will transition from Ocala to the company's Brandon SD and Charlotte, MI facilities.
Standard Microsystems Corp. announced a reduction in worldwide personnel of 5-10%, including a voluntary retirement incentive for most employees 55 years of age and older.

Standard Register Co. plans to eliminate about 500 jobs by closing one plant, consolidating four centers and making other cost-cutting moves, the company announced. The Dayton-based business-forms company is eliminating 235 jobs by closing its rotary printing plant in Kirksville, Mo. Another 150 jobs will be eliminated when the company consolidates four centers into one facility in Dallas.

Standard Register Co. announced that it will close a label printing plant in Terre Haute, Ind., and eliminate 60 jobs . The company is closing the 23-yearold plant to consolidate operations and better manage growth of its label business. These moves, combined with investments in new short-run roll label equipment and manufacturing computer systems, will create a label manufacturing 'center of excellence' in Radcliff where all key complex label products will be produced.

Standard Register Co. eliminated 250 jobs as part of a cost-cutting move. Seventy jobs were in the Dayton area, leaving 490. The rest of the cuts were at sites around the country. The cuts will save $22 a million and are part of a plan to save $40 million a year.
Standard Register Co. plans to close facilities and reduce its workforce as it struggles to deal with mounting losses and looming debt.

Standex International Corp. announced that its Cincinnati-based Standard Publishing division has tentatively decided to close its printing operation and cease its commercial printing business. The termination of operations is expected to be concluded by March 31, 2004. The commercial printing business has undergone massive consolidation in recent years in the face of weak demand, overcapacity and rising costs, said Randy L. Scott, president of Standard Publishing and group vice president of Standex's Consumer Group.
Enesco Group Inc. announced that it has laid off 120 employees, representing 14% of its United States workforce.

Enesco Group Inc. announced an additional corporate downsizing in its U.S. operations as part of the Company's operating improvement plan. The downsizing primarily affected the areas of administration, marketing and IT. The Company anticipates no material charges associated with the workforce reduction and expects annual pre-tax cost savings from the salary expense reduction to be approximately $300,000, which is included in the pre-tax cost savings of $34 million to $38 million in the U.S. as part of the Company's operational improvement plan.

Stanley Black & Decker, Inc. is closing a West Baltimore facility and cutting 142 jobs. Meanwhile, Adventist Behavioral Health is closing a Crownsville facility and laying off 100 people. Adventist is closing a treatment facility and school in Crownsville on March 31. The closure will impact 100 employees.
Nautica will close in the Great Mall of the Great Plains on July 5, 2009.

State Street Corp. announced that it planned to slash another 1,800 jobs, or 9 percent of its work force, in a clear sign that weak markets continue to dog the Boston financial services company. The company will then lay off workers to meet its target of 1,800 fewer positions. The cuts follow the elimination of at least 575 jobs at State Street last year, plus 1,000 dismissals in Nashville and Jersey City, N.J., related to its recent acquisition of Deutsche Banks securities servicing group.

State Street Corp. intends to continue cutting its way to profitability, and it is unlikely to stop at the 400 new layoffs. About 145 of the cuts taking place over the course of this year will be made in Massachusetts, representing about 1% of the company's roughly 12,000-personworkforce in the state. As a result of the cuts, the company expects to save $22 million in the second half of the year and another $18 million next year. If revenue growth continues to disappoint, the cutting will continue.

Storage Technology Corp. has eliminated 48 light-manufacturing jobs from its global supply chain. The work will be absorbed in the company's Puerto Rican operations, spokesman Joe Fuentes said Tuesday. StorageTek, with 7,600 employees worldwide and 3,000 in Colorado, makes tape and disk drives for data storage units and produces data storage systems.

Storage Technology Corp. plans to outsource certain development and manufacturing activities and expects to cut 200 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, by 2004. In a press release, the storage systems maker said it will outsource development activities and the manufacturing for the StorageNet 6000 product at its facilities in Minneapolis and Toulouse, France.
Stride Rite Corp. announced that it has laid off 120 employees, representing 20% of its workforce.

Stryker Corp. is shutting its area operations. The closings in Orchard Park and West Seneca will put approximately 160 people out of work. The privately-held Orchard Park medical manufacturer, which specializes in support surface, pressure ulcer management solutions for the health-care industry, was bought by medical devices giant Stryker of Michigan in a deal announced in late summer 2010. The company said the process of closing down production lines and relocating equipment to other Stryker sites or supply chain partners will take place in phases and will be completed by the end of 2012. The production facility in Guayama, Puerto Rico, is not impacted at this time by this change, and service and delivery to customers will not be affected.

Casco Products, a unit of Sequa Corporation plans to discontinue manufacturing operations at its facility at 380 Horace Street in Bridgeport, but will maintain its headquarters and administrative offices there.

Sunoco Inc. announced that the company permanently shut down its idled 145,000 b/d refinery in Eagle Point, New Jersey, as weak margins continue to batter the US refining sector. The company had idled the plant late last year due to weak demand for refined products. The refinery shutdown comes as US refining industry profits continue to suffer due to lower fuel demand.

Sunoco Inc. announced that it plans to trim an undisclosed number of employees at its Wayne County chemical plant, as profit margins have been less than expected. The lay offs will be across the board: supervisory, administrative, production and maintenan

Sunoco Inc. announced that it is closing its Bayport, Texas polypropylene plant. The decline in petrochemicals demand has made the 33-year-old facility 'no longer financially viable,'. The Bayport plant closure eliminates 400 million lbs of annual polypropylene capacity.

Sunoco Inc. announced that it will permanently close its polypropylene manufacturing facility located in Bayport, Texas, no later than April 30, 2009. The facility can produce approximately 400 million of polypropylene each year.
Sonoco has announced that it will close its machinery manufacturing operation in Fenton, Missouri, by the third quarter of 2002 thereby eliminating 15 positions.
SunTrust Banks Inc. announced that it eliminated 211 jobs in the first quarter of 2003 and more than 2,100 during 2002, mainly through attrition.

SunTrust Banks Inc. executives are exploring the possibility of outsourcing some or all of the banking company's 1,700 back-office positions related to check and other payment processing and statement generation. The decision is part of an overall cost-cutting plan the Atlanta-based financial institution is implementing. Executives project that plan, announced earlier this year and expanded this week, will cut $530 million in expenses by 2009. The affected back-office operations, known as the banking services area, include facilities in Atlanta, Baltimore, Memphis, Miami, Orlando, Durham, N.C., and Richmond. SunTrust will shutter its Durham call center when the lease expires. The Atlanta space will be used by other SunTrust units. Those changes are expected to be complete by October.

SunTrust Banks Inc. plans to sell about 473 properties that it will lease back and said it will eliminate about 300 jobs as part of a plan announced in January to lower costs. The company will market 48 office buildings and about 425 retail branches to developers, brokers, real estate investment trusts and other institutional investors. The bank won't close any branches as part of the move to reduce its occupancy expenses. A restructuring of the banking organization will lead to about 300 job cuts over the next six months.

SunTrust Banks Inc. laid off 20 staffers in its Wake County operations as part of a cost-cutting move unveiled in 2007. SunTrust continues to operate 32 branch offices in Wake County after the staffing cuts. The December staff reduction in Wake County was reported to the North Carolina Employment Security Commission in an early 2008 filing.

SunTrust Banks Inc. announced that it would close 13 Atlanta-area branches as part of its acquisition of GB&T Bancshares Inc. of Gainesville, Ga. The company would close five of its own branches and eight of GB&T's.

SunTrust Banks Inc. signed a 10-year deal that will reduce head count by 1,554 positions, or roughly 5% of its 32,323-member work force. The deal with Symcor Inc., which is headquartered in the Toronto suburb of Mississauga, calls for it to handle check and payment processing as well as statement generation. Starting Aug. 1, Symcor will take over those operations, and 1,500 of the affected employees will be transferred to its control.

SunTrust Banks announced that it will eliminate 800 jobs nationwide, including in Charlotte, the result of a slowdown in its home loan refinancing business. The company declined to disclose how many jobs would be eliminated in Charlotte or specific locations, such as its loan sales center near Charlotte Douglas International Airport. But with mortgage rates rising 2013, lenders have seen weakening demand for refinancings. That has led banks, including Charlotte-based Bank of America and San Francisco-based Wells Fargo, to trim the work force that processes those applications. The positions will be eliminated in the coming months, likely into the first quarter. Richmond, Va., is among the other SunTrust markets affected by the 800 cuts. The employees can apply for other positions in the company, and people who lose their jobs will receive severance pay and outplacement assistance.

SUPERVALU Inc. is planning to close all five of its Sunflower Market organic and natural foods stores by the middle of February 2008, since they have not delivered the expected returns. Supervalu has three Sunflower Markets in Columbus, Ohio and one each in Chicago and Indianapolis. The stores were opened to compete with supermarket operator, Whole Foods Market.

Superior Industries International, Inc. announced it will close its manufacturing facility in Rogers, Arkansas, as part of an initiative to reduce costs and enhance its global competitive position. The company announced it expects to cease operations at Rogers by the end of 2014. The closure will result in scheduled production being shifted to other Superior manufacturing facilities, including those in Fayetteville, Arkansas, and Chihuahua, Mexico, and is anticipated to generate a net $15 million labor cost savings year-over-year, resulting from a workforce reduction of approximately 500 employees.
Symbol Technologies Inc. announced that it would cut 700 jobs due to sluggishness in the global retail market.
Bombay Company Inc. will close its six Central Florida stores as part of the retailer's bankruptcy plan to shut down all of its approximately 385 U.S. locations.

RadioShack announced that it plans to close a facility in Arlington, Texas, cutting 31 jobs. The decision is part of the companys effort to boost efficiency, lower costs and focus on retail operations.

RadioShack Corporation says it will cut 195 manufacturing jobs in Fort Worth as part of a reduction in nonretail operations. The company plans to cut 176 jobs at its Tandy Wire and Cable Group and close a production facility by the end of November. It will cut another 19 jobs from a facility that makes store display racks. Combined with previous reductions in Arlington and North Carolina, the chain will have cut 373 manufacturing jobs.

RadioShack Corp. disclosed it plans to close 400 to 700 stores and two distribution centers as part of a plan to improve its financial performance. The company announced that tit could not project the number of job cuts until it identifies all the affected stores, but 88 employees will be affected from the distribution center closings in Charleston, S.C., and Southhaven, Miss. RadioShack the stores it plans to close are company-operated. There are nearly 7,000 RadioShack stores operated by the company or dealers, and more than 700 wireless kiosks. It also has more than 100 stores in Mexico.

RadioShack Corp. announced that the company plans to reduce its workforce by approximately 400 to 450 positions across its various support functions. This move will reduce the company's overhead expense and improve its long-term competitive position in the marketplace. Most of RadioShack's planned reductions will affect positions at its headquarters operation. The reduction will include employees at all levels. RadioShack will notify affected employees by early September.

RadioShack Corp. notified about 400 workers by e-mail that they were being dismissed immediately as part of planned job cuts. Employees at the Fort Worth headquarters got messages saying the work force reduction notification is currently in progress. Unfortunately your position is one that has been eliminated.

RadioShack Corp. laid off workers at its corporate headquarters on September 6, 2012 morning as the company continues to reduce costs following a second-quarter loss. Job cuts were mostly concentrated at the riverfront headquarters, where the company said earlier this year it had about 1,200 workers.

As part of the 2,400 locations RadioShack is shutting down across the country, nine nearby locations are getting the axe. The RadioShack locations are spread throughout malls, including the Regency Square Mall, the Avenues Mall and St. Johns Town Center, as well as in shopping plazas in Fleming Island and Orange Park. In all, 115 stores across Florida are closing down. The First Coast RadioShack locations shutting down include: Gateway Shopping Center at 5412 Norwood Ave. Suite 100, Jacksonville; St. Johns Town Center at 4668 Town Xing Dr. Suite 137, Jacksonville; Regency Square Mall at 9585 Regency Square Blvd. N., Jacksonville; The Avenues Mall at 10300 Southside Blvd., Jacksonville; Highland Square at 1140-2 Dunn Ave., Jacksonville; 6147 103rd St., Jacksonville; Orange Park Mall at 1910 Wells Rd., Orange Park; Orange Park Bolton Blaza at 661 Blanding Blvd. Suite 518, Orange Park; and 1489 County Rd. 220 Suite 100, Fleming Island.

RadioShack Corp. announced that two of Springfield's five RadioShack locations are on the company's list of those that could close as it restructures as part of its bankruptcy plans. RadioShack's potential store closure list includes the stores at 2601 N. Kansas Expressway #104 and 3530 W. Sunshine St. in Springfield. Locations at 1824 S. Glenstone Ave., 3303 S. Campbell Ave. and 1935 E. Independence St. are not listed. A store at 1077 Branson Hills Parkway in Branson is also listed among those that could close.

RadioShack has slated 13 stores for closure in Maine in the wake of filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The company posted a list of 1,784 stores nationwide that potentially could close, including the 13 in Maine. The company said it plans to close two locations in Augusta and Bangor, as well as locations in Auburn, Brunswick, Machias, Oxford, Portland, South Portland, Standish, Topsham and Wells. The retail chain lists 29 locations in Maine on its website, including standalone retail stores and affiliate stores where it shares space with other retailers.
Tecumseh Products Company laid off around 90 to 100 people and they will be temporarily shutting down their plant for 4 days.

Tecumseh Products Co. will cease engine assembly operations in Corinth, Miss. and consolidate activities at its facility in Dunlap, Tenn. 280 people will be affected by the shutdown. Layoffs are expected to begin by Dec. 31.

Tecumseh Products Co. announced that it is laying off about 390 people at its New Holstein, Wis., facility. The staff cuts, which are expected to include 315 production workers, 65 indirect production workers and 10 salaried workers, will eliminate more than half of the union work-force positions at the facility. The permanent layoffs are expected June 9.
Tektronix Inc. laid off an unspecified number of employees in addition to offering voluntary buyouts to others. The company announced that more than 100 people lost their jobs altogether.
Tektronix Inc. laid off 150 employees. The company has shed about 500 people, with an estimated 220 from its Beaverton headquarters.

Allegheny Technologies plans to cut up to 150 jobs by the third quarter of 2001. Roughly half of the lay offs have already occurred. For fiscal 2000, the company had a net income of $132.5 million on sales of $2.46 billion, compared with earnings of $30
Allegheny Technologies has announced that it plans to further reduce its by 90 employees in the High Performance Metals and Industrial Products segments, mostly in Europe.

Teleflex Incorporated will close its Lancaster manufacturing plant, idling all 88 employees. The shutdown of the local site stems from a corporate decision to save money by shifting its production to a sister plant in Kenosha, Wisc. The 300 Running Pump Road facility is part of the company's SMD (Specialized Medical Devices) brand of orthopedic fixation devices. It produces devices such as screws and plates used in surgery.
Tellabs Inc. announced that it will lay off approximately 1,000 workers and shut down 2 facilities, in an attempt to reduce company costs.

Tellabs Inc. announced that it would cut 800 jobs, or 14.5 percent of its work force. Tellabs will also close its manufacturing plant in Shannon, Ireland.

Tellabs Inc. announced that it expected to report a third-quarter loss. Third-quarter sales would be down about 15 to 25 percent, compared with its second-quarter sales of $345 million.

Tellabs announced that it will outsource manufacturing of its North American products to Sanmina-SCI Corporation resulting in the layoff of about 325 employees. The manufacturing transition begins immediately, and manufacturing operations in Bolingbrook are expected to cease by year-end. Tellabs plans to move remaining employees from its main building in Bolingbrook to its Naperville headquarters and sell the 545,000-square-foot Bolingbrook main building.

Tellabs Inc. announced it plans to reduce its workforce. The company is offering its U.S.-based employees the opportunity to express a preference to leave the company. Employees who volunteer for the preference procedure and are approved will receive severance benefits, which include severance pay, benefits and outplacement assistance. Tellabs offered the same voluntary preference procedure to its U.S.-based employees in April.

Tellabs Inc. announced plans to reduce its worldwide workforce by about 370 employees. The company also plans to close its development center in St. Laurent, Quebec, Canada, by mid-2004. Employees leaving the company will receive severance benefits, which include at least six weeks of severance pay, benefits and outplacement assistance.
Tellabs Inc. said 300 employees would be affected by its plans to outsource the manufacturing of its international products and to align its research and development spending to the industry average.

Tellabs Inc. announced that it will discontinue its gigabit passive optical network activities focused on Verizon Communications Inc., citing economic reasons. The company announced aid it is still working as a multi-product and services supplier to Verizon.
Temple-Inland Inc. has announced that it will eliminate a number of jobs and staff positions as a part of its plan to reduce costs and streamline corporate functions.
Temple-Inland Inc. has announced that it is eliminating approximately 200 jobs within staff and support functions to reduce costs.

Temple-Inland Inc. provided an update on the shutdown of its Bogalusa, Louisiana paper mill following an operational issue at the mill and its waste-water treatment facility. Predictive testing for Biochemical Oxygen Demand (BOD) indicated that the Bogalusa mill would exceed its maximum daily permit levels for discharge to the Pearl River from the mill's waste-water treatment facility. The company believes that this exceedance may have depleted the oxygen level in part of the river below that necessary to sustain a healthy fish population and resulted in a fish kill. On August 13, 2011, upon receiving the results of predictive testing, Temple-Inland immediately shut down the mill. The company promptly informed the Louisiana Department of Environmental Quality (DEQ) of the situation and began taking corrective actions to restore the water quality of the River.

Tennant Co. said that it will consolidate its North American distribution operations from the current seven centers into two new facilities, eliminating about 80 jobs. Tennant's distribution centers in Dallas and Pennsauken, N.J., will be converted into reconditioning centers for the company's used equipment business, said spokesman Chris Malecek. The distribution center within the company's headquarters plant will be closed, along with two centers in Anaheim, Calif., and facilities in Chicago and Holland, Mich., he said.The Golden-Valley based company reported a net profit of $400,000, or 4 cents a share, for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with $7.9 million, or 87 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales totaled $103.6 million, compared with $115.4 million a year earlier. For the full year, Tennant earned $4.8 million, or 52 cents a share, compared with $28.2 million, or $3.09 a share, in 2000. Sales dropped to $423.0 million, from $454.0 million.

Tenneco Automotive will let go of 405 of its salaried employees, part of the total 700 jobs the company announced it would eliminate in October 2000. The layoffs are part of cost-cutting initiatives. Tenneco expects yearly savings of about $45 million.
