Tenneco Automotive Inc. announced that it will layoff 1,100 employees mostly in North America, as part of its plan to cut costs.

Tenneco Inc. announced that it expected to spend as much as $15 million by mid-2007 to cut jobs, close facilities, and shift production. the reductions in the United States, Europe and Australia would result in annual savings of about $10 million when completed.

Tenneco Inc. announced its intention to close its Wissembourg, France manufacturing facility, which produces emission control products for original equipment manufacturers. The company will consult with work councils and local government authorities on the intended closure and potential impact of this announcement on the approximately 180 people employed at the facility. The company will implement any potential workforce reductions that may occur as a result of this plan in compliance with all applicable legal and contractual requirements including consulting with work councils and other employee representatives.
Tenneco Inc. announced it would lay off 200 workers at its exhaust systems plant in Cambridge.

Tenneco Inc. announced a major restructuring across its global operations designed to further reduce structural costs and capacity in response to the worsening industry downturn. The company intends to eliminate approximately 1,100 jobs worldwide, close five facilities and implement other cost reduction actions, which it expects will generate about $64 million in annual savings once fully implemented. The company intends to close four North America manufacturing facilities, restructure another manufacturing plant in North America, and close its Dunsborough, Australia engineering operation. The combination of these closures and other operational and administrative restructuring actions across its global operations will eliminate approximately 500 salaried positions and 600 hourly positions.

Tenneco Inc. has cut 82 jobs from its Hartwell, Ga., plant as U.S. automakers continue to struggle. The company has postponed a decision on whether to close any of its three original equipment ride control plants, including the Hartwell facility.

Tenneco Inc. announced that its intention to discontinue its Marzocchi motor bike fork suspension business and its mountain bike business, and liquidate its Marzocchi operations. These actions are subject to a consultation process with the employee representatives and in total would eliminate approximately 138 jobs. Tenneco intends to assist its motor bike customers with the transition of current production to an alternative supplier and expects to complete the closure by the end of 2015.
Teradyne Inc. announced that it laid off 650 employees in an effort to cut costs. The lay offs will affect its operations worldwide.
Teradyne will layoff 200 workers based at its San Diego branch, in January 2002.

Teradyne Inc. initiated actions to reduce its workforce by notifying approximately 400 employees from the Semiconductor Test Division that their employment is being terminated as part of the Company's ongoing effort to lower expenses. The terminations are expected to be completed by fiscal year end 2005.
Teradyne Inc. announced to cut about 14% of its worldwide staff. The job cuts are expected to help reduce its expenses by roughly $140 million on an annualized basis.

Tesoro Corporation reported that a fire occurred early this morning at the company's Wilmington, California refinery centered on the facility's coker unit. No injuries have been reported, the fire is contained and the affected units are in the process of being shut down.

Tesoro Corporation announced that at approximately 12:30 a.m. pacific time on April 02, 2010, a fire occurred at its Anacortes refinery. The incident was on a small section of the refinery following minor, routine maintenance. The fire was contained at around 2 a.m., has been extinguished and the unit has been shut down and isolated. Other major parts of the refinery remain in operation, but at reduced rates.

Andeavor will lay off 15 people in the Alamo City due to its merger with Western Refining. The layoff was listed in a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification, or WARN, Act. The merger between Andeavor - formerly known as Tesoro Corp. - and El Paso-based Western closed in June.

Texas Instruments Inc. is laying off 180 workers from its manufacturing plant here, lowering total employment to about 1,020. The cuts which are being blamed on an extended semiconductor industry slump, were effective immediately. The jobs lost were mostly manufacturing workers, who were paid an average of $12 to $15 an hour.

Texas Instruments Inc. cut its financial targets and announced a larger-than-expected number of job cuts for its current quarter, becoming the third major technology company in two days to warn that SARS has hit its Asian business. The Dallas, Texas-based company also announced that will cut 250 jobs from its chip operations in Japan, which will result in about $55 million in charges instead of the $40 million it previously predicted.

Texas Instruments Inc. has initiated measures to lay off employees in India as part of its global workforce restructuring plans. The company is planning to axe 1,700 jobs and reduce costs in OMAP processors and wireless connectivity solutions to focus on other embedded solutions with long life cycles. The company is likely to cut over 500 employees here and considerable number of staff could be 're-deployed'.
TXU Corp. has announced that it plans to cut an undisclosed number of jobs in the European operations.

Up to 200 former TXU Corp. employees who switched companies after a deal between the utility and a consulting firm will lose their jobs with the new company. The layoffs are part of a cost-cutting effort at Capgemini Energy LP, a partnership between Dallas-based TXU and consultants Capgemini America Inc. TXU and the consulting company announced a 10-year, $3.5 billion deal that included TXU's call centers and other operations. TXU owns less than 3% of the new partnership and created the partnership to cut costs by $175 million a year. About 2,700 employees, or one-fifth of TXU's work force, joined the partnership in July with guaranteed jobs for three months. Capgemini announced less than 200 employees will lose their jobs starting in mid-October. About 60 jobs will be moved to India and Poland.

TXU Corp. will mothball eight gas-fired power plants in Texas, leading, along with other moves, to 90 job cuts. Company moves would save it $14 million a year while other changes to its gas-fired operations would save it another $6 million.

Textron Inc. announced that it is planning to slow its production of the Osprey V-22 aircraft. Textron has stated that it plans to cut 4,000 employees during 2001 through layoffs, attrition and early retirement.
Textron Inc. will combine its industrial components and products segments that will result in the elimination of 40 to 50 jobs as the company seeks to trim costs and speed up decision-making.

The chairman of Textron Inc. said that nearly 20 percent of the company's top 150 executives didn't fare well in a recent performance review and could lose their jobs. Lewis Campbell said the review, which rated the 150 executives in color groups based on job performance, was completed as part of Textron's goal of managing its top executives much more aggressively. It was not clear whether the affected managers were concentrated in a specific division. A message left with a Textron spokeswoman was not immediately returned.

Textron Inc. is laying off more than 120 employees, primarily from its corporate offices in Rhode Island, Michigan and Texas. The company announced a cost-cutting effort in October, when it reported a drop in third-quarter profits. The firm's financing unit for business jet and other customers got hammered by the global credit crisis.

Textron Inc. announced plans to eliminate a total of about 6,200 positions, or nearly 15% of its global work force. The company said it will provide further details on the latest round of layoffs and production cuts on April 29 when it will release first-quarter results and an updated full-year outlook.

Textron Inc. is in the process of laying off 139 employees of its corporate offices worldwide, including 56 at the company's corporate headquarters in downtown Providence. The company announced the layoffs internally. They will take effect over the coming days and weeks.

The Textron Inc. division now headed by Scott Ernest is cutting around 400 jobs as part of a restructuring plan. The 400 cuts represent around 10% of Augusta, Ga.-based Textron Specialized Vehicles' total global workforce. The division, which makes products including E-Z-GO golf carts, has seen operating results "significantly below expectations," following its acquisition of Arctic Cat last year. That has resulted in the restructuring plan that also includes the closure of several factory-direct turf-care branch locations and a manufacturing facility, though the filing did not specify where those closures would occur.

Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc. announced that almost 50 workers are set to lose their jobs because production may be switched to Germany. Shocked employees at Thermo Fisher Scientific in Shepherd Road, Tuffley, were told the plans earlier this week. The company is currently in a 30-day consultation process.

Thermo Fisher Scientific, Inc. is shutting down a Rhode Island facility and putting more than 60 people out of work. The company's East Providence facility will close 2010 June, and its functions moved to other plants around the country. Some employees will be offered work elsewhere, but most will be laid off, with a severance package and career counseling.
3Com announced a reduction of its wrokforce by 170 employees. The reductions will be from its consumer Broadband Operation.
3Com Corp. announced that it will lay off approximately 3,000 workers over several quarters, in an attempt to reach profitability.

Six Flags Inc. is closing its Six Flags AstroWorld theme park at the end of the year and is looking for a buyer for the 109-acre site that sits near Reliant Park, Houston's entertainment district and Texas Medical Center. The closing will affect 119 permanent jobs, but Six Flags announced that a number of those people may be offered jobs at other Six Flags sites. The park also hires 1,500 people for seasonal jobs. Those will not be affected for the remainder of the 2005 season.
Timken Co. announced its plans to cut 700 jobs from its automotive group, or about 5% of that workforce.
Timken Co. announced layoffs of nearly 8% of the plant's 800 workers will begin March 1, 2009.

Timken Co. announced that low global demand for some products will result in at least 3,000 job cuts through the rest of 2009. In early 2008, Timken began trimming a fourth of its worldwide work force, and they have gotten 50% to 60% through that process. Of the 4,000 layoffs so far, 155 were at facilities in Northeast Ohio, principally among United Steelworkers Union members at Timken's Faircrest, Gambrinus, Canton and Harrison plants in Stark County. The company expects hard times for bearings and specialty steel sales to continue in 2009, with its steel group sales declining as much as 55% to 65%. The company hopes for some growth in its aerospace and defense sales.
The Toro Company has announced that it will close its Madera, California plant, which manufactures agricultural irrigation products, and consolidated that production into other existing facilities.

The Toro Co. announced that it will cut 100 salaried and office jobs, and make other cost-cutting moves, in response to the ongoing economic slump. The company is also cutting top management salaries by 10% for 2009, and suspending scheduled salary increases for all employees. The job cuts are taking place at Toro locations worldwide. Total employment is about 5,200.

Total System Services Inc. has laid off 237 employees, about 4% of its workforce, reducing it to about 5,500 as a result consolidation and improved efficiencies. The cuts came after a companywide review at the Columbus, Ga., card processor.

Toys R Us Inc. plans to eliminate 1,900 jobs, or about 3 percent of its permanent work force, close 64 U.S. stores and consolidate support services as part of a plan to cut costs and boost profits. The moves announced come as the Paramus-based company's earnings have slumped due to the economic slowdown and extensive remodeling costs.
Kids 'R' Us has announced that it will close its stores in the Milwaukee area as part of the nationwide restructuring by its parent company, Toys 'R' Us.

Toys R Us Inc. announced results for its third quarter ended November 1, 2003. Total sales for the third quarter of 2003 were $2.32 billion, up 2.2% from $2.27 billion for the third quarter of 2002. The company reported a net loss of ($38) million, or ($0.18) per share, for the third quarter of 2003, compared with a net loss of ($28) million, or ($0.13) per share, for the third quarter of 2002

For the nine months ended November 1, 2003, sales in U.S. dollars were $6.63 billion this year, up 3.0% (0.5% excluding currency) from last year's $6.44 billion. For the nine-month period ended November 1, 2003, the company reported a net loss of ($56) million or ($0.26) per share versus a net loss of ($49) million or ($0.24) per share for the comparable period in 2002.

The company plans to close the 146 freestanding Kids R Us and the 36 freestanding Imaginarium stores as well as 3 distribution centers that support these stores. The majority of these facilities are expected to close on or before January 31, 2004.
Toys R Us Inc. announced that it would lay off 100 people and would not seek to fill 200 vacant positions.

Toys R Us Inc. announced that it will shutter 87 locations in coming months as part of its reorganization after being taken private in 2005, but plans to convert 12 of those into Babies R Us stores. The closures will cause the company to record $155 million of restructuring charges, including $45 million for the cost of liquidating the inventory. Some $99 million will be recorded during the fourth quarter ended Jan. 28, and $56 million in the first quarter. The company did not specify which of its 674 U.S. Toys R Us stores are slated to close.

Toys "R" Us Inc. corporate office has confirmed that the local Express store in Santa Rosa Mall will close next month. The corporate office still is evaluating which of those outlets will be closed. The Toys "R" Us Express store in Santa Rosa Mall will have its last day of business on Jan. 8, 2012. The Toys "R" Us Express stores are designed to be additional shopping locations for customers during the busy holiday season. Most Toys "R" Us Express stores will close by mid-January.
Toys "R" Us Inc. to close its New Towne Square store in North Toledo by the end of July 2014. The company said the closure is not part of a larger store reduction.

The Toys R Us store in Ferguson will close at the end of March. The company do not have any plans for a new store in the Ferguson area. The store is at 10895 West Florissant Avenue, near Interstate 270. The 46,000-square-foot Ferguson store employs 36 people. The company said it will place as many as possible at its other stores.

Toys R Us to close one Houston-area location as the company goes through a restructuring. The company will close up to 182 locations in mid-April, according to USA Today. The only Houston-area location on USA Today's closure list is at 9730 Katy Freeway in Village Plaza at Bunker Hill, where the company has both a Toys R Us and a Babies R Us. Eight Texas locations will close in total.

Toys R Us Inc. is cutting nearly 1,200 Ohio jobs as it shutters stores across the state. This includes 79 employees at two Dayton-area locations: Miamisburg (37) and Beavercreek (42). The local stores are both set to permanently close on June 30, 2018. Their closures not only cost jobs, they leave two large retail spaces that will need to find new tenants. The struggling retail chain is closing its stores after facing the harsh headwinds of more competition in the toy sector from stores such as Walmart and Target, as well as online retailers such as Amazon.com.

Toys 'R' Us announced this week that it would be closing all 735 U.S. stores. Toys 'R' Us had announced they would be selling USD 2 Billion worth of merchandise at a discount, taking bids for its brand name, mascot and other intellectual property. In addition, they would be laying off all their employees, over 30,000 workers. The approximate 31,000 employees had received a 60-day notice, as required by law, and some were not paid severance.
Tribune Company announced that it has laid off about 1500 employees, representing 6% of its workforce.

Tribune Co. announced that it is cutting 300 positions and will shrink the number of daily sections to four from five. The expected savings from the move were not announced. The cuts will include a 70-position reduction across the editorial department, or 11%, in the coming weeks. The company said the paper will reduce the number of sections on March 2, folding the California section into the front section, which includes local, national and international news, while keeping Business, Sports and Calendar as daily fixtures. The feature section lineup, including Health, Food, Home, Image, Travel and Arts & Books, will remain unchanged. Other papers have also moved to trim sections in order to save money amid a rapidly worsening advertising market.
The Tribune Co. announced it was cutting 700 more jobs. Tribune Co. axed 800 jobs in the past year and emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy.
Tyco International announced that it has laid off 1,000 employees at its Tyco Telecommunications Inc. division.

Tyco International Ltd. announced that the company has laid off 27 employees at its TyCom laboratory in Eatontown as part of a larger restructuring to make the company more efficient. The reduction leaves 125 employees at the research and development office, down from about 400 a year ago.

Tyco International may consolidate headquarters operations, a decision that could mean a drop in status and loss of jobs for Boca Raton. While the company employs 1,600 people in Boca Raton, only 155 are in corporate jobs. The remainder work in Tyco's Fire and Security Division and home-alarm unit, ADT Ltd.

Tyco International Ltd. announced that it plans to lay off 248 of the 700 employees at the Shakopee site. The company will move most of its manufacturing operations to Juarez, Mexico, and Santa Teresa, N.M., with a small portion of manufacturing to continue in Shakopee. Once layoffs are complete in September, about 200 employees from the former ADC headquarters in Eden Prairie will be moved to the Shakopee site and the Eden Prairie property will be sold.
Tyson Foods Inc. announced an decision to close its pork-processing plant there, putting nearly 500 people out of work in town with almost no other major employers in 20-mile radius.

Tyson Foods Inc. has announced that it will lay off 187 more workers, a total of 737 employees by early 2003, after it closes its Jacksonville processing plant, a feed mill, and a hatchery near Fleming Island in Clay County.

Tyson Foods announced that it will cut its beef production because demand is lower after last year's mad-cow scare. Tyson Foods (TSN) will suspend operations at four beef plants and halt second-shift work at a fifth. Tyson said about 2,100 workers will be affected by the move, which it expects to last three to five weeks. The plants to be idled are in Boise, Idaho; Denison, Iowa; and Norfolk and West Point, Neb. The suspension of the second shift will be at the Pasco, Wash, plant.

Tyson Foods Inc. announced that it will close its chicken by-product rendering plant in Noel, Mo., by this summer, and area residents are breathing easier. Although the closure will reduce the company's payroll in Noel by 45 jobs, it will also do away with the stench from Tyson's River Valley Protein Plant, where byproducts are converted to pet food and livestock feed. Tyson decided to close the 42-year-old plant because it would cost too much to upgrade it, and it is more cost-effective to move the production to a similar rendering plant in Scranton.

Tyson Foods Inc. announced that it would close two Nebraska beef facilities with 1,665 workers and move the work to a plant being renovated in that state. Tyson said it will close its beef processing plant in Norfolk and beef slaughter plant in West Point, both in northeastern Nebraska. The company said it will pay workers at both plants and will provide benefits for 60 days. The company said it will try to retain some of the workers by having them move to Dakota City or Lexington, Neb., or Emporia, Kan.

Tyson Foods Inc. will close about a dozen beef and pork plants. Tyson chose to shut down production at 10 beef and pork plants because of factors such as market conditions that permit scheduling changes and the potential shortage of workers.

Tyson Foods Inc. plans to eliminate more than 400 jobs in North Carolina as the poultry. Tyson announced it plans to close the plant, one of three in Wilkesboro, N.C., by April. Tyson would continue to pay workers and offer benefits for the next 60 days.The company also moves forward with a $10 million expansion of a plant in its hometown that will add 370 jobs by next summer.

Tyson Foods Inc. announced that it was laying off about one-fourth of the workers at its Hanover County poultry processing plant. The permanent layoffs of 190 workers who debone and package chicken will occur June 13.

UAL Corp., the parent company of United Airlines, told employees in a phone message that it had pinpointed a total of $1.4 billion in annual nonlabor cuts that it intends to carry out. In addition, the company said in a separate announcement that it planned to save $100 million a year from a streamlining that includes the loss of about 1,250 jobs.

UAL Corp., parent of United Airlines, asked a bankruptcy court judge to approve an additional $2 billion in cuts from its operations. The airline is seeking to modify its existing labor contracts to slash $725 million annually in worker pay and benefits. It also wants to eliminate its four employee pension plans.Nearly $2 billion came from employees' pay and benefits.

United Continental Holdings, Inc. plans to cut 1,300 jobs and some service at Houston's main airport after the city backed Southwest Airlines's bid to start international flights from a secondary facility. The 10% reduction in seating capacity at George Bush Intercontinental Airport includes dropping a planned route to Auckland.

United Continental Holdings Inc. plans to cut 600 front-office jobs to reduce management and administrative staff by 6%. The cuts, which will be done through voluntary and involuntary reductions and will begin in February, are intended to control costs.

USG Corp. announced that it is eliminating 500 jobs, or 10% of its salaried work force worldwide, as demand for its products is reduced by the housing slump. The company's employees were told about the action last week. The company is offering voluntary severance benefits, including a lump sum payment based on salary and length of employment, an allowance to continue medical, dental and vision coverage and outplacement services. If enough employees don't volunteer to leave, it said it will begin cutting positions. The manufacturer expects the cuts to be completed by the end of June and to cost between $8 million and $12 million.
Unifi announced its plans to cut 750 jobs of its overall workforce, representing 12.5% of its workforce.
Ameren Corp. has announced that it will close most of its Venice generating plant near the McKinley Bridge in an effort to cut costs.

Union Pacific Corp. plans 2,000 job cuts by mid-2001. The cuts include about 1,200 that the railroad had intended to make through attrition over the next year as a result of its 1996 acquisition of Southern Pacific Rail Corp.

Union Pacific Corp. will cut 1,000 administrative jobs, with most people to lose their jobs in the first three months of 2003. The company said in a 10-K annual report that the 1,000 jobs will be eliminated through attrition and firings. Union Pacific executives had said the reductions would include layoffs but not how many. Some of the targeted jobs could include 139 crew management and timekeeping positions at the Harriman train dispatching center in Omaha.

Unitedhealth Group Inc. announced that will lay off more than three dozen workers in Louisville next month, according to a filing with the state of Kentucky. A notice of the layoffs said 38 employees of Ingenix were told Aug. 21 that the job cuts would be effective by Oct. 20. The employees are located at an office at 301 N. Hurstbourne Parkway.
Unitedhealth Group Inc. announced that the company would cut 4,000 jobs in an effort to curb costs.

UMB Financial Corporation announced reductions in employees, elimination of vacant jobs and cutbacks in overtime and hours worked as part of its effort to make the company more efficient. Severance costs from the job cuts at the company will total $8 million in 2015 and 2016.

United Parcel Service Inc. announced that a drop in package volume resulted in a decision to close its 'Next Day Air' night sort operations at Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport. The change will cause the reduction of 72 staff positions, all of which will take effect after Feb. 8, 2009.
United Parcel Service, Inc. will lay off 60 airline mechanics nationwide in an attempt to reduce costs in response to the economic slowdown.
US Airways announced that it will be reducing its staff by 11,000 employees, representing 24% of its workforce.

US Airways Group Inc. plans to lay off 471 more pilots by May to offset rising fuel costs and continued weakness in the airline industry. The planned cuts, 326 by Jan. 7 and 145 by May, would mark a 30 percent reduction in the number of pilots since the 2001 terrorist attacks, the Air Line Pilots Association union said. US Airways also plans to furlough 915 flight attendants by December, although most of the departures are expected to be voluntary. The airline has already laid off nearly 2,700 flight attendants of the 10,000 employed at the time of the terrorist attacks.

US Airways Group Inc. cut 2,500 jobs and said it is seeking additional concessions from labor to attain the cost cuts it needs to emerge from bankruptcy next year. The airline has already laid off nearly 15,000 workers out of more than 46,000 since the Sept. 11 attacks devastated the airline industry, and employees who were once the best paid in the industry have collectively agreed to $840 million in wage and benefit cuts to help the airline return to profitability. The latest cuts would mean US Airways has cut 38 percent of its work force since the attacks.

US Airways Group Inc. announced that it plans to transfer its revenue-accounting operations from Winston-Salem, eliminating 268 jobs, when its proposed sale to America West Holdings Corp. is completed. The local revenue-accounting operations are based in Madison Park in the northwest part of the city. The job cuts would shrink US Airways' work force of 1,122 in the Triad by nearly 25%. About 591 employees remain at the airline's reservations center off Hanes Mall Boulevard. The work force at the reservations and Dividend Miles centers was 1,600 as recently as August 2004.
United Technologies Corporation announced that it will be laying off approximately 5,000 employees, as part of a cost reduction plan.
United Technologies Corp. plans to cut about 5,000 jobs in the next few months.

United Technologies Corp. announced that more than 100 workers have been laid off from a northern Indiana plant that makes electronic components for heating and cooling control units. It cut the jobs of 112 hourly workers. But most of the layoffs at the plant about 20 miles southwest of Fort Wayne were voluntary.
United Technologies Corp. expects a headcount reduction of 13,400 this year.

United Technologies Corp. announced it is laying off 500 salaried and hourly employees worldwide - including some in the Charlotte area - between now and the end of 2012. The company announced that it is laying off three workers at its Monroe plant and one in its Charlotte aerospace division headquarters. The company will continue to notify affected workers through December. The cuts represent less than 2% of United Technologies' roughly 40,000 employees worldwide.

Sprint Nextel Corp. announced that it plans to cut roughly 2,400 jobs in 2006 to streamline operations, and it reported that costs from its merger dragged down fourth-quarter profit sharply. As part of its cost-cutting, the company for the first time disclosed how many jobs it plans to cut as a result of the merger, saying it expects to reduce its workforce of about 60,000 -- excluding the local phone unit that is being spun off -- by about 4% by the end of 2006. The workforce has already come down from roughly 63,500 at the start of 2005.

Sprint Nextel Corp. announced that it is cutting about 75 mainly sales and marketing jobs from a unit that provides network equipment to other telecommunications companies. The cuts come as the company seeks to serve some customers more with online services instead of direct sales. About two-thirds of the laid-off workers were from the North Supply unit in Gardner, which is south of Kansas City. The remainder of the workers are from other parts of the country.
As part of its plan to improve operations and cut costs, Sensient Technologies will layoff 200 employees from its staff.
Aquila Inc. has announced that the company is planning to eliminate some jobs at its Kansas City headquarters.

Aquila Inc. announced that it is eliminating approximately 200 positions from its Merchant Services and Corporate staffs. Aquila also will reduce 500 positions by early July with completion of the previously announced restructuring of its Networks business. Nearly 150 of reductions affect employees working in Aquila's two downtown Kansas City offices; the remaining positions are in locations throughout the United States, Canada and Europe.

Aquila Inc. said it is taking steps to strengthen its creditworthiness, including cutting jobs, even as it scales back its capital-intensive trading activities and focuses more on the regulated side of its business. Aquila did not specify how many employees would lose jobs. 

Aquila said it reduced its dividend by 42 percent to 70 cents per year. Details of the job cuts are expected to be firmed up within a few days.

Those moves, coupled with a shift away from the unregulated wholesale energy business, prompted Aquila to lower its predicted operating earnings for 2002 to the $1.30-$1.40 range. In mid-April Aquila reduced its forecast for operating earnings to $2.20 from $2.83. Aquila said it changed the focus of its wholesale energy services operations in response to the current high cost of capital for that business.
Valspar Corp. plans to close its plant at Fort Wayne, Indiana eliminating 30 hourly positions.

Valspar Corp. announced that it would lay off six of its local employees, with up to 24 more to go before the end of the year. The layoffs come a few months earlier than originally planned by the U. S.-based paints and coatings producer.

The Valspar Corp. has laid off about 25 employees in Minneapolis. The reduction is about 6% of the company's 400-person Minneapolis work force and 0.2% of its total worldwide workforce of 10,500. The layoffs were part of an ongoing review of personnel. They involved corporate and sales workers and happened in the past few weeks.

Valspar Corp. will shut down two subsidiary operations in Garland, cutting 54 jobs in the process. The Engineered Polymer Solutions Inc. subsidiary will close its consumer office located at 701 Shiloh Road in Garland, laying off all the workers there. The distribution center at 2750 Miller Park in Garland will also close. Layoffs for the consumer office go into effect March 17, 2015. The distribution warehouse closes May 22, 2015 but employees will be laid off starting March 27, 2015.

Valspar Corp. said it will stop manufacturing at the plant, which is on Lake Road just west of Interstate 71, almost exactly in the middle of Medina County. The 98 employees will be laid off without the possibility of recall or bumping rights. The notice is dated Jan. 30 but was released. Plasti-Kote specializes in automotive paint and scratch-repair products.

Veeco Instruments Inc. announced that it is shutting down most of its Camarillo operations as part of companywide reorganization. The economic downturn, tighter financing and slowdown in spending on equipment has hurt the company's end markets and consumers. In response, the company started a restructuring program during the last three months of 2008, including a 26% reduction in the work force. The company also is centralizing its supply chain and operations, consolidating business units, outsourcing more manufacturing and decreasing its number of manufacturing sites from eight to four. The company has three leased facilities in Camarillo. One, which designs and manufactures probes for atomic force microscopes, will continue to operate at that location. But the sites for Veeco's 'Slider Operations' business, which designs and manufactures components for the data storage industry, are being affected by the company's plans to outsource that manufacturing.
Vishay Intertechnology's Vishay-Sprague Inc., will lay off 320 employees in April.

Vulcan Materials Co. 's McCook lime plant closed and the Birmingham, Ala.-based company agreed to a court order with state and Cook County officials to keep it closed and pay a $120,000 fine. The order strips the plant's 1950s-era pollution permits.

Vulcan Materials Company announced that it is consolidating its eight divisions into four operating regions as part of ongoing efforts to reduce overhead costs and increase operating efficiency. This initiative is expected to generate an ongoing annualized pre-tax cost savings of approximately $30 million, in addition to approximately $25 million in annual pre-tax overhead reductions already implemented in 2011. The new organizational structure is consistent with Vulcan's longstanding commitment to decentralized management of its sales, marketing and operating functions, and will enable the Company to maintain close, local relationships with its customers. It also will allow the Company to leverage significant investments in technology that have replaced legacy IT and financial reporting systems. These new systems support improvement in administrative and operating efficiencies while also creating new opportunities for greater standardization and implementation of best practices throughout the organization. The Company expects that approximately 200 positions will be affected, with most coming from overhead and administrative staff. Staffing at plant facilities will be largely unaffected. Following the consolidation, Vulcan will have four regions: East, South, Central and West. The East Region, which will comprise the Company's former Southeast and Mideast Divisions, will be headquartered in Atlanta and led by Michael R. Mills, Senior Vice President, East. Mills, age 50, was President of Vulcan's Southeast Division. The South Region will comprise the Company's former Florida Rock and Southwest Divisions, and will include Vulcan's quarry and harbor on Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula and related shipping assets. The South Region will be headquartered in Jacksonville, Florida and led by James T. Hill, Senior Vice President, South. Hill, age 51, was President of the Company's Florida Rock Division. The Central Region will comprise the Company's former Midwest, Midsouth and Southern and Gulf Coast Divisions, excluding V
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that it has laid off 100 employees at its headquarters and eliminated 300 positions.
Wal-Mart in Macon laid off about 30 workers, in part because of customer shifts to the new Wal-Mart on Zebulon Road.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that it will close a Canadian store whose workers are on the verge of becoming the first ever to win a union contract from the world's biggest retailer. Wal-Mart said it was shuttering the store in Jonquiere, Quebec, in response to unreasonable demands from union negotiators, that would make it impossible for the store to sustain its business. The United Food and Commercial Workers of Canada asked Quebec labor officials to appoint a mediator, saying that negotiations had reached an impasse. The store will close in May.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that the Wal-Mart return center in south Bibb County will be closing by mid-September, affecting the jobs of 400 workers. The return operation here will be transferred to a third party and relocated near Spartanburg, S.C. The return center will cease operations on Sept. 13 of 2009.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that it plans to close seven smaller food supermarkets in Japan by the end of March 2009.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. will close 10 money-losing Sam's Club stores and cut 1,500 jobs to reduce costs. The stores will close Jan. 22, 2010. They are in Nampa, Idaho; La Quinta, Calif.; Louisville, Colo.; Vista, Calif.; Rolling Meadows, Ill.; Clay, N.Y.; and Irvine, Calif. The cities of Houston, Phoenix and Sacramento, Calif., will each lose one store. The company is trying to find jobs at other Sam's Club or Wal-Mart locations for workers who lost their jobs. Wal-Mart owns the Sam's Club warehouse stores chain.

Almost 40 employees at Sam's Club stores in Loveland and Fort Collins lost their jobs as part of Wal-Mart Stores Inc.'s decision to outsource its product demonstrations. The company said the cuts applied to every Sam's Club in the U.S. affecting about 18 demonstration product associates and two new business membership associates at each store. The move is an effort to improve sales at Sam's Club and comes on top of a decision to close 10 underperforming warehouse locations, which cost 1,500 jobs. All employees losing their jobs can apply to Shopper Events. The company said it was providing severance pay and benefits to eligible associates.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that to close its Moscow office.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. plans to close its mp3 download store at the end of the month after spending years as an also ran to Apple's iTunes. After eight years in business, the Walmart Music Downloads Store located at mp3.walmart.com will close on August 28, 2011. All content in the Store will be disabled and no longer available for download from the store. The sale of physical record music products on Walmart.com as well as in Walmart U.S retail stores will remain unaffected.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced Three Smart Choice?convenience stores (CVS) in Shenzhen that were run by the company were officially closed after a three years of operation. The company that such closure did not reveal failure of the CVS operation model, arguing that it is solely for testing in China and that the tests finish now. Wal-Mart opened three Smart Choice?convenience stores in Shenzhen at the end of April 2009 for trial operation. The company disclosed that with operation area being around 300 square meters, "Smart Choice" CVS focuses on food and daily necessities. Such operation model did not appear in the U.S. and was initiated in China.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that it is closing some stores in China and Brazil to boost productivity in those markets, while it's accelerating the expansion of small stores in the U.S. at a faster pace than that of its Supercenters. It aims to tether these small stores to Supercenters, which will act as mini warehouse hubs for their smaller cousins.For this fiscal year and next combined, it plans to add about 300 more smaller format stores, particularly its Neighborhood Markets. Those formats, which offer such items as fresh produce, meat, household supplies and beauty products, average about 38,000 square feet. In contrast, it plans to add 240 more Supercenters in that time period. Supercenters, which carry food and general merchandise, average about 182,000 square feet.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. said that it will open 110 new outlets in China in the future three years, including supermarkets and distribution centers.The company will also shut down some outlets that are having unsatisfactory performance, taking up nearly 9% of the total in China.

Wal-Mart Stores plans to shut down another underperforming store in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province in late April. The company decided to shut down more than 20 outlets in China in 2014 because those stores comprise about 9% of the total, but have contributed only 2% to 3% of the total sales volume from 2013 to date.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is moving ahead with plans to close an older store and build a new supercenter in Valrico's Bloomingdale neighborhood. The company official confirmed that the company will close its existing store at 949 E. Bloomingdale Ave., which is an older store that does not sell groceries. All associates at the existing store will transfer to the new one once it's completed. The new store is slated to be complete in 2016. It will be 152,000 square feet and combine a full grocery store with general merchandise and a garden center.

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that it plans to close 269 stores in the U.S. and globally. In total, the impacted stores represent less than 1% of both global square footage and revenue. As part of todays action, the company will close 154 locations in the U.S., including the companys 102 smallest format stores, Walmart Express, which had been in pilot since 2011. Walmart instead will focus on strengthening Supercenters, optimizing Neighborhood Markets, growing the e-commerce business and expanding Pickup services for customers. Also covered in the closures are 23 Neighborhood Markets, 12 Supercenters, seven stores in Puerto Rico, six discount centers, and four Sams Clubs. Internationally, the company is following a disciplined strategy of actively managing its portfolio. Consistent with this strategy, the company is closing 115 stores outside the United States. This includes 60 recently-closed, loss-making stores in Brazil, which represents only 5% of sales in that market. The company has already been able to relocate many affected associates in Brazil to other stores. The remaining 55 stores are primarily small, loss-making stores in other Latin American markets. Walmart will disclose more detail about those actions, including the number of stores per market, after completing local associate and community outreach. The financial impact of these closures is estimated to be approximately $0.20 to $0.22 of diluted earnings per share from continuing operations, with approximately $0.19 to $0.20 expected to impact the fourth quarter of fiscal 2016. The remainder of the impact will fall into the first half of fiscal 2017. Approximately 75% of the impact relates to U.S. closings and the remaining portion involves Walmart International, with a large majority of the international impact relating to the closures in Brazil. In total, approximately 16,000 associates will be impacted by the decision, about 10,000 of them in the U.S. More than 95% of the closed stores in the U.S. are within 10 miles on average of

Wal-Mart Stores Inc. announced that Wal-Mart Supercenter in McDowell County is one of the 154 locations nationwide that will be closed as part of a worldwide restructuring by the retail company. Wal-Mart Supercenter in Kimball will be shuttered at the end of the month. The store is one of only 12 supercenters nationwide that will be cut, and it is the only location in West Virginia that would be closed under the company's new plans. The decision to close the store in Kimball, is the result of a review of 11,600 stores worldwide, in which Wal-Mart officials scrutinized the locations' financial performance and alignment with the company's long-term plans.

DFW Walmart store closure to impact more than 100 workers. Another Walmart Neighborhood Market store is closing, impacting more than 100 jobs. The store at 6513 Meadowbrook Drive in Fort Worth will shutter on May 29 at 7 p.m. The closure is expected to be permanent as the store's lease is expiring. Wal-Mart Stores is working with the store's roughly 108 workers to find positions at other Walmart and Sam's Club stores in the area. There are 18 other stores within 10 miles of Fort Worth location. June 10 is the last day of work for the employees, according to the Morning News. They will be paid through July 1 if they do not find jobs at other Walmart stores, and will receive severance benefits after that date. In January, Wal-Mart announced plans to shutter 269 stores internationally, a move that impacted three Walmart Neighborhood Markets and three Walmart Express stores in North Texas. The Markets each employed roughly 95 workers, while the Express stores employed around 30.

Walmart announced that it is planning to cut 300 jobs at its Information Systems Division. The company will cut the jobs to make Walmart more agile and efficient, which will be crucial as it grows its e-commerce segment.

Wal-Mart Stores, Inc. announced its supermarkets in Hefei's Shengli Road and Ma'anshan will stop operation on April 12, 2017. The company, since entering Hefei City in 2008, has entered into a period of rapid development but started to close stores from 2013 and has closed seven stores in Hefei to leave only one. They are mainly optimizing the commercial layout in Hefei and will open more new stores while closing stores.

Walgreens announced that it plans to lay off 252 employees at its Central Pharmacy Operations facility in Orlando this spring. The company on February 2 filed a Worker Adjustment & Retraining Notification with the Florida Department of Economic Opportunity notifying the state that the layoffs would take place on April 2 at its facility at 8337 Southpark Circle in Orlando.

Walgreens announced that the Thruway pharmacy's last day will be May 17, 2018 but the store will remain open for about two more weeks for a final sale. The store's prescription records will be available at the Walgreens store at 2125 Cloverdale Ave. in Winston-Salem. The Walgreens-owned Rite Aid at 2012 N. Main St. in High Point will also close. Prescription files in that location will be available at 2019 N. Main St. in High Point. The pharmacy's last day of business will be May 24, 2018.

Washington Post Co. newspaper is reducing its newsroom staff by at least 80 people -- about 1-10th of its editorial staff -- through attrition and buyouts. The paper has more than 800 editorial employees, many represented by the Washington-Baltimore Newspaper Guild.

Wausau Paper Corp. reported earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2007. For the third quarter, the company reported net earnings of $6.1 million, or $0.12 per share, compared with $7.2 million, or $0.14 per share, the year before. Operating profit for the quarter was $11.9 million against the operating profit of $14.2 million for the same period a year ago. Net sales for the period increased 4% to $319.3 million against the net sales of $306.7 million for the same period a year ago. For the first nine months of 2007, Wausau Paper reported an operating profit of $29.8 million and net earnings of $25. 8 million, or $0.51 per share on the net sales of $935.9 million compared with operating profit of $25.4 million and net earnings of $10.3 million or $0.20 per share on the net sales of $887.6 million in the year before.
The company plans to cease manufacturing operations at its Groveton, New Hampshire mill effective December 31, 2007, reducing annual Printing & Writing production capacity by approximately 105,000 tons or 28%. The shutdown will affect approximately 300 permanent jobs.

Wausau Paper Corp. announced that it will permanently shut down paper machine number 10, one of the two paper machines at its Specialty Products mill in Jay, Maine on or prior to December 31, 2008 in response to dramatically increased input costs and difficult market conditions. Number 10 paper machine, with a capacity of 40,000 tons annually, presently serves the release liner market and a variety of smaller niche markets. The shutdown is expected to impact approximately 150 of the 235 employees currently at the facility.
Wendy's International Inc. announced that it will close 15 to 18 underperforming Baja Fresh stores, resulting in a charge of $17 to $18 million.

Wendy's International Inc. announced that it plans to slash as many as 375 jobs, with most of the cuts aimed at the company's Dublin headquarters, where 650 people work. The company offered voluntary retirement to 175 fulltime employees in May, and those who accept will make up a portion of the job reductions. The decision on jobs is part of the company's previously announced plan to improve its bottom line. Company has struggled for more than a year to boost sales, said the cuts are part of a plan to save the company $100 million annually.
It was announced that over the next three months, a 3% reduction in its salaried workforce is being made by West Pharmaceutical Services Inc.
Western Digital Corp. announced that it plans to layoff 51 employees in Rochester effective Feb. 15, 2003, when it will close its phone service center at Northbrook Shopping Center.

MeadWestvaco Corp. said it plans to reduce its corporate staff by about 435 jobs, or 21 percent, over the next 18 months as part of a restructuring.

The company outlined plans to cut 545 jobs at four sites in South Carolina, Virginia and Maryland, while adding 110 jobs at two sites in Ohio. The work force will be reduced from 410 jobs to 175 at the company's facility in Charleston, S.C., from 330 jobs to 150 in Richmond, Va., and from 160 to 80 in Laure.

MeadWestvaco Corporation announced plans to shut down permanently four coated paper machines and related equipment. These actions will take effect beginning April 1, 2002, and be completed by May 31, 2002. These actions reflect company determination to move rapidly to capture the benefits of this strategic merger.
MeadWestvaco Corp. has announced that it plans to layoff up to 110 hourly workers at its Rumford mill citing a sluggish paper market.

The MeadWestvaco Corp. plans to cut paper production this quarter, reducing profit by about $16 million, or 5 cents. because of competition from imports and falling magazine advertising. The company, which is based in Stamford, Conn., is closing plants and laying off workers to reduce expenses by $325 million a year. it would eliminate 3,000 jobs, or 10 percent of its work force, by 2004.

MeadWestvaco Corporation announced that it will close two manufacturing plants in Springfield, Mass., and consolidate its envelope operations in the Northeast by creating a single, high-powered manufacturing center in Enfield, Conn. The company expects to eliminate approximately 130 positions, offering restructuring benefits Including outplacement assistance, to all affected employees.

MeadWestvaco Corporation has announced that it plans to permanently shut down during 2003 eight sheeting machines at its Luke, Maryland paper manufacturing facility, eliminating approximately 150 positions.
MeadWestvaco is expected to layoff approximately 4,000 employees by the end of 2002 as part of its restructuring process.

Mead Westvaco Corporation announced that it will close its general consumer packaging operations in Newark, Delaware. The facility converts paper and paperboard into printed packages and is part of MeadWestvaco's packaging segment. The company expects to close the facility by late April 2003.

MeadWestvaco Corporation will close its folding carton plants in Richmond, Va., and Cleveland, Tenn., by the end of June, resulting in the loss of about 455 jobs, the company announced. The plants convert paperboard into printed packaging for consumer products and are part of MeadWestvaco's packaging business. The plants employed a printing process which is no longer heavily used in the United States, said Donna Owens Cox, a company spokeswoman.
The forestry division of MeadWestvaco will be cut 45 jobs in South Carolina, but company officials said they don't yet know exactly who will lose their job.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced it will close the KorPine particleboard plant here next week, putting 111 employees out of work. Jackie Lang, a Weyerhaeuser spokeswoman, said employees were told of the impending closure after arriving for the day shift.

Weyerhaeuser Co. plans to close its Woodburn lumber plant and lay off 57 workers as it continues to streamline operations following its merger with Willamette Industries. The plant will gradually reduce production and close by the end of the year.
Weyerhaeuser Co. has announced that it plans to close its glulam operation in a manufacturing complex thereby eliminating 66 jobs.
Weyerhaeuser Co. will cut 27 jobs by eliminating the engineering services department in its corporate office at Ruston.

Weyerhaeuser Co. said 75 jobs would be eliminated has it shuts down one of the two fine-paper machines in Rothschild, Wis. The paper company said the machine, which produced 32,000 tons per year, was shut down due to its age and small size. The remaining machine in Rothschild produces 130,000 tons per year, and employs 375 workers.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced it will close a fine paper machine in Longview, laying off 119 people the day before Thanksgiving. The machine can produce 90,000 tons a year. Weyerhaeuser had closed another fine paper machine in 2001 because of the poor market. Laid-off employees will receive severance pay, health care benefits and some job-transition services and counseling, the company said.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced another closure in a string of factory shutdowns and other changes in 2005 that include the sale of its composite paneling business. The Federal Way, Wash., integrated forest-products company (WY) will shut a Plymouth, N.C., containerboard machine it had already idled, eliminating 200 jobs. The 48-year-old idled containerboard machine in Plymouth has the capacity to make 350,000 tons a year of linerboard, the smooth outer surface of boxes, from recycled fiber. The closures are latest in a series of announcements by Weyerhaeuser since early October in an effort to cut capacity. The cuts include a box-finishing operation in California, a sawmill and pulp mill in Washington and a plywood mill in Oklahoma.

Weyerhaeuser Co. plans to close or sell plants in eight states and Canada, including a paper-bag plant in North Kansas City. Overall, 800 workers will lose their jobs in the cutbacks, including 58 in North Kansas City, although some could find work elsewhere in the company.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced that 260 people at the Big River sawmill and another 55 at the Wapawekka lumber mill near Prince Albert will be laid off April 19, 2006. The company's pulp mill in Prince Albert is scheduled to shut down in April 2006, and the other two operations depend on selling the chips and wood waste to the pulp mill to stay open.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced that it will shutter a British Columbia saw mill in December and boost production at a second plant. The company did not say how much it would cost to close the Okanagan Falls mill or how much it expected to save each year. Weyerhaeuser will boost investment at its plant in Princeton as part of a plan to 'modernize' the facility.

Weyerhaeuser Co. announced it will indefinitely curtail operations at its Structurwood(R) plant in Hudson Bay, Saskatchewan, by early July. There are 170 people directly employed at the Hudson Bay oriented strand board mill. The Hudson Bay plant is one of nine oriented strand board mills in the Weyerhaeuser system. It has annual production capacity of 550 million square feet. The Hudson Bay facility reduced its operations to five days per week of production in the spring of 2007.

Weyerhaeuser Co. eliminated 22 jobs at its Boise Technology Center. Most of the affected workers hold positions in fabrication, engineering, science, logistics, and administrative areas. Almost all of them will end their work by Jan. 3.

Weyerhaeuser Co. confirmed that it was cutting jobs in response to slowdowns at the ports of Seattle and Tacoma. The company will cut jobs at its Longview, Wash, pulp and paper mill at the end of the month. It was unclear exactly how many people would lose their jobs. Most of the company's exports move through the ports of Seattle and Tacoma. The ports have been experiencing a slowdown, which the union blames on industry changes and the PMA blames on the union.

Weyerhaeuser Company announced it will permanently close its lumber mill and plywood mill in Columbia Falls, Montana, in late August or earlySeptember. Weyerhaeuser will continue to operate three mills in Montana: a lumber mill in Kalispell, a plywood mill inKalispell, and a medium-density fiberboard mill in Columbia Falls. Approximately 100 positions will be eliminated as a result of the mill closures.
Whirlpool Corp. announced that it is laying off 79 employees at its dishwasher plant, due to slow sales.

Whirlpool Corp. announced it will create 200 Tulsa jobs in 2004 after a plant in Quebec closes as part of the corporation's global restructuring initiative. The closing of the kitchen range factory in Montmagny, Quebec, is part of a plan to cut 6,000 jobs, or about 10 percent of Whirlpool's worldwide work force. The company had shed 5,000 positions by the end of last year. About 500 jobs will be eliminated when the Canadian plant closes in 2004.

Whirlpool Corp. announced that it would dismiss about 730 workers at an Arkansas plant once a replacement factory in Mexico is operational. The Michigan-based company recently built a refrigerator plant in Ramos Arizpe, Mexico, to produce side-by-side refrigerator-freezer models, beginning in 2006. Once the Ramos Arizpe facility is operational, about 730 employees at Whirlpool's Fort Smith, Ark., plant will be part of a layoff, currently planned for October 2006.

Whirlpool Corp. announced that it will lay off 950 workers at its Fort Smith plant, 220 more than the amount of layoffs initially announced by the Michigan appliance-maker. The number of workers to be laid off Sept. 1 will account for nearly one-quarter of the 4,000 workers at the plant as the company decreases production of refrigerators and trash compactors here.
Whirlpool Corp. announced that it is planning to lay off up to one-quarter of the workers at its Vanderburgh County factory. The company announced that it expects to cut 300 to 500 jobs by November.

Whirlpool Corp. has decided to keep a small appliance parts manufacturing center in Iowa retaining up to 20 workers. The company planned to close the Maytag corporate headquarters and a washer and dryer factory in Newton, idling 1,800 workers by the end of this year. The parts center, a segment of the manufacturing operation in Newton, will continue after the main washer and dryer plant closes on Oct. 26, 2007.

Whirlpool Corp. is due to hold an extraordinary works council meeting in order to confirm plans to make 153 job cuts at its plant in Amiens, France, which specialises in the production of tumble dryers. The agreement will be accompanied by an increase in working hours from 32.5 hours to 35 hours per week in exchange for a bonus of EUR 1,200 in 2009 and a commitment to maintain production volumes at the site for five years. The proposals have been accepted by four of the factory's five unions and will enable the company to boost its output and to make further investments.

Whirlpool Corp. to close plants in Oxford, Miss., and Puebla, Mexico. The Oxford plant makes built-in ovens and cook-tops, and the Puebla plant makes semi-automatic washers. The closures will result in a shift of 500 jobs to the company's Cleveland plant, and 140 jobs to its plant in Celaya, Mexico.

Whirlpool Corp. has announced it is closing its Jackson, Tenn., facility as part of a plan to shed 5,000 workers by the end of 2009. The company had already closed or announced the closure of four other plants this year, including the company's La Vergne, Tenn., manufacturing facility that stopped production in August. The work handled by the Jackson plant will be moved to the Whirlpool's Ohio facility, cutting 500 jobs in Tennesee.
Whirlpool Corp. announced that it would close its F.E. Wright Drive plant by September, laying off 511.

Whirlpool Corp. is laying off about 170 workers at a plant that makes dishwashers in northwest Ohio. The company says the layoffs that begin November 10, 2008 in Findlay will be temporary and reflect falling demand. The company was cutting 250 jobs at its washing machine plant in Clyde, about 40 miles northeast of Findlay.

The Whirlpool Corp. has announced a new round of layoffs at refrigerator plant in Fort Smith, but the company won't say how many jobs will be lost. The company said that the layoff would begin in October, 2010 after production of counter-depth refrigerators ends. The company steadily laid off workers over the past few years after much of the work once done at the plant was moved to a factory in Mexico.
Whirlpool Corp. will no longer manufacturer appliances at its plant in Benton Harbor. A plan to close the hometown factory by mid-2011 is imminent.
Whirlpool Corp. is laying off about 350 workers from its refrigerator plant in Iowa. Workers were told of the layoffs on July 15, 2011.

Whirlpool Corp. announced that it plans to shut down the last of its operations in a southern Indiana city. Whirlpool would close its Refrigeration Product Development Center in Evansville by the end of 2014 and consolidate the center's work at facilities near the company's Benton Harbor, Mich., headquarters. Whirlpool expects to spend about $18 million on renovations and equipment. Some Evansville employees might be given the chance to relocate to Michigan.

Whirlpool Corp. will soon begin laying off workers as it prepares to close its Evansville product development center. The company announced that it would begin laying off workers 'on or about November 23, 2012'. Whirlpool announced last month it was closing its Evansville center and moving the work to Benton Harbor and St. Joseph, Mich. About 220 people, including engineers and product developers, work at the Evansville plant. The company would try to relocate as many of the workers as possible to Michigan, but added that 30% of them were eligible for retirement beginning in 2014.

Whirlpool announced that it would invest EUR 500 million over four years in Italy as part of a restructuring plan that would see 1,350 redundancies. A large part of the EUR 500 million earmarked for the next four years would be aimed at building up production in Italy through a specialized network of factories and extra investment in research and development.It would include the closure of some sites with 400 extra layoffs in addition to 950 redundancies already planned at the time it acquired Indesit in July last year. The company said that it would meet unions on April 20 for detailed discussion of the plans, which include the closure of the Carinaro site near Naples with the loss of 800 jobs in a region with one of the high unemployment in Italy.
Williams Cos. has announced that it will reduce its financial commitment to energy risk management services thereby laying off an unspecified number of employees.

Williams Companies Inc. said it will lay off 16 percent of the roughly 800 employees in its energy marketing and trading division because of the sector's slump. The company laid off 11 of its 86 London workers and cuts in Houston and at its Tulsa headquarters will come next week, spokeswoman Paula Hall-Collins said. The company employs about 50 energy trading workers in Houston and the remainder in Tulsa.

Williams Cos. stock soared after the company disclosed more of its continuing plan to cut its staggering debt, which will mean fewer jobs at energy giant. At the beginning of 2002, the company employed about 12,000 people. The work force, currently at about 9,300, is expected to be slashed to less than 6,000 by year's end as the company continues to sell pieces of its business.

Williams Cos. Inc. is through selling assets and cutting costs, its Tulsa work force will be down to 1,500 from about 3,000 at the start of 2002. So far, the number of Williams jobs in Tulsa has been cut to about 2,100. More layoffs are expected this week.

Williams Cos. plans to lay off about 660 employees, approximately 10% of its workforce. The cuts are the result of lower commodity prices, as the company plans to match its growth with the downturn in the energy industry. Employees in areas where the company is reducing investment will likely be affected more than others. The company will notify affected workers in late March 2016 and early April 2016. Severance and benefits packages will be provided to those who lose their jobs.

Williams-Sonoma, Inc. provided revenue guidance for the fiscal year 2019. For the fiscal year 2019, the companys total net revenues expected in the range of $5.670 billion to $5.840 billion. The company expects net 30 store closures for a total store count of 595 by the end of fiscal year 2019.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. announced that it will cease operations in four Southern states, close 326 of its 913 stores and cut 22,000 jobs under its proposed bankruptcy reorganization plan. The company announced that it will stop operating in Tennessee, Virginia and the Carolinas, and trim operations in its five remaining states, Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Louisiana. The cuts amount to 35% of its stores and 28% of its current work force of 78,000.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. filed notice Monday with the state to lay off 169 workers in South Florida. According to a report by The Business Journal, the layoffs will take effect Sept. 2 at two units the chain had earlier reports it plans to close: a store in Pembroke Pines, and one in New Port Richey. Winn-Dixie said it would lay off 92 workers at the Pembroke Pines location, and 77 in New Port Richey.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc., the Jacksonville-based grocer that has closed one-third of its stores and cut 22,000 jobs since 2005, got court approval for its creditors to vote on a plan to exit bankruptcy. Winn-Dixie must get unsecured creditors, vendors and landlords to approve the reorganization plan, which generally calls for them to be paid with common stock equal to 53% to 95% of their claims. Existing shareholders will be paid nothing under the plan.

Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. announced that it will close 30 non-remodeled, underperforming stores. The company will also consolidate its four operating regions into three and reduce its workforce at the field and corporate support levels. In addition to the staffing reductions that will take place as a direct result of the store closures, the company will eliminate approximately 120 positions in its corporate and field support staffs. The store closures and position eliminations are expected to be completed by the end of the first quarter of fiscal 2011, which ends on September 22, 2010. The company reaffirmed earnings guidance for the fiscal 2010. For the period, the company expects $3 million net loss or $0.05 per basic and diluted per share to $17 million net income or $0.31 per basic and diluted per share, EBITDA to be in the range of $117 million to $137 million. Adjusted EBITDA at the low end of its guidance range of $140 to $160 million, as previously announced. The company reaffirmed its guidance due to which the company believes it achieved through effective management of its promotional activity and cost control, despite a deteriorating sales environment in the fourth quarter.

Winn-Dixie is planning to close two Birmingham area grocery stores on or before Nov. 19, 2014. The company said Bi-Lo Holding has decided to close the doors to its Hueytown store at 104 River Square Plaza and the Center Point location at 2402 Old Springville Road. This brings the total of Winn-Dixie closings in Alabama to five. Winn-Dixie will also close locations at 4035 East Blvd. in Montgomery, 2055 Coliseum Blvd. in Montgomery and 1300 Gilmer Ave. in Tallassee.Winn-Dixie is closing the doors to some of its Alabama stores, it is currently remodeling its existing locations and plans to open more grocery stores before the end of the year. Trussville store at 465 Main Street, the 3925 Cross Haven Drive location in Vestavia Hills and the 3331 Rainbow Drive location in Rainbow City are all undergoing 'substantial remodels' Additionally, Winn-Dixie plans to open up to 25 new stores during the fourth quarter, including new Alabama sites. Winn-Dixie opened two new stores this year in Birmingham, one at 4476 Montevallo Road and the other at 500.

Winn-Dixie and its sister supermarkets are closing 20 stores across the chain and cutting low-level management positions at supermarkets as well. One store is closing in Orlando on South Orange Blossom Trail at the end of May. The company has also begun eliminating lower-level management positions in departments across its grocery store chain, which also includes brands such as Bi-Lo, Harvey's and Fresco y Mas. The closings are spread across the chain, with the biggest hit coming in South Carolina, where six Bi-Lo stores are closing. Winn-Dixie has been going through a flurry of strategic changes since changing leadership about two years ago.

Winnebago Industries Inc. is shutting down a factory in Charles City, Iowa and eliminating 270 jobs. The plant, which makes smaller units built on a van chassis, is expected to close in August, the news agency said. The company is blaming the weaker economy and fuel prices for the closure.

Winnebago Industries Inc. announced that it has been laying off more workers at its headquarters plant in Forest City as well as at facilities in Charles City and Hampton.Winnebago has battled a slump in the recreational vehicle industry that has cut sales nationally.
Winnebago Industries Inc. announced that it has cut about 300 jobs, or 9% of its work force.

Wisconsin Energy Corp. announced that it has laid off about 1,200 employees at the Tilden and Empire iron ore mines in Upper Michigan indefinitely, while the company attempts to restore electrical power to the two plants after flooding forced the shutdown.

Alliant Energy Corp. eliminated 228 jobs, including 141 positions in Madison, headquarters for the utility holding company. Of the local positions, 53 were already vacant, 18 involved employees who voluntarily accepted severance packages. Fourteen were union members who will go through bumping procedures, in which those union workers will get the chance to take other union jobs, putting less-senior employees out of work. The other 56 lost their jobs involuntarily. Employees affected by the reduction and the union were told that the cuts would take effect that day.

Alliant Energy Corp. plans to shut down one of three coal-fired generators at its Sheboygan power plant have been scrapped in the wake of rejection of the company's proposal to build a new facility in southwestern Wisconsin. Unit 3 at the Edgewater Generating Station in Sheboygan had been scheduled to be closed by 2013, but it will stay up now, according to Alliant spokesman Rob Crain.

Woodward Governor Co. announced that it will close its Woodward-HSC plant. Production will shift to plants in and near the company's headquarters in Rockford. Work will wind down over several months, with the doors closing for good by Sept. 30. Production will shift to plants in and near the company's headquarters in Rockford, Ill.

Foot Locker, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the quarter, the company reported sales of $1,502 million compared to $1,392 million a year ago. Income before income taxes was $123 million compared to $90 million a year ago. Net income was $81 million compared to $57 million a year ago. Diluted EPS was $0.53 compared to $0.36 a year ago. On non-GAAP basis, Income before income taxes was $128 million compared to $98 million a year ago. Net income was $84 million compared to $61 million a year ago. Diluted EPS was $0.55 compared to $0.39 a year ago. The net income included an after-tax charge of $3 million, or $0.02 per share, for the impairment of certain intangible assets. For the year, the company reported sales of $5,623 million compared to $5,049 million a year ago. Income before income taxes was $435 million compared to $257 million a year ago. Net income was $278 million compared to $169 million a year ago. Diluted EPS was $1.80 compared to $1.07 a year ago. On non-GAAP basis, Income before income taxes was $440 million compared to $265 million a year ago. Net income was $281 million compared to $173 million a year ago. Diluted EPS was $1.82 compared to $1.10 a year ago. The net income included the fourth quarter after-tax charge of $3 million. Capital spending was $152 million, slightly below the plan of $160 million.For the quarter, the company reported impairment of certain intangible assets of $5 million compared to $10 million a year ago.For 2012 the company expects to produce double-digit percentage profit growth for the full year and for each individual quarter compared to 2011. And expect to add about $0.10 per share to fourth quarter and full year 2012 results. The company planning 2012 comp gains in the mid single digit range. The company planning for a 30 to 40 basis point gross margin gains in 2012 based on a 52-week year. The capital program in 2012 is planned to be about $160 million. For 2012 tax rate is pl

Worthington Industries Inc. announced actions the company is taking to reduce the workforce by approximately 300 employees in the steel processing and metal framing business segments, approximately 4% of the total workforce. These actions are in addition to the previously announced (October 23) closings and job cuts. Dietrich Metal Framing continues to be heavily impacted by the steep drop off in construction that has resulted from the global financial crisis and, along with steel processing, has seen a dramatic decline in pricing and demand. To mitigate the negative impacts of the current business environment, Dietrich will close its Lunenburg, Mass., facility by February 28, 2009, and suspend operations at two facilities: Miami, Fla., by the end of February, and Phoenix, Ariz., by the end of January. Dietrich intends to re-open the Florida and Arizona facilities if business returns, but in the meantime, the McDonough, Ga., facility will service the Florida market and the Colton, Calif., facility will provide product to the Arizona market. Massachusetts customers will be served by the Boonton, N.J., operation. The total number of employees in the metal framing segment impacted by the closings is 125, approximately 9% of the workforce. The steel processing segment will reduce its workforce across all locations by approximately 12% or 186 employees. The job cuts include both hourly and salaried employees. The company is also reducing work schedules to better align with the lower market demand and employees are being asked to take unpaid time off. It is estimated that these workforce reductions and plant closings will result in annual savings of approximately $17 million, with restructuring charges of approximately $5 million primarily due to severance costs and asset write-downs.

Worthington Industries Inc. announced it plans to shutter three steel plants and cut its work force by 311 employees, including 18 laid off immediately at the company's processing plant near Delta in Fulton County. The company announced the cuts will save $17 million and are in addition to 300 layoffs announced in October. The latest layoffs include 186 workers at all 68 facilities worldwide. The permanent closing of the Lunenburg, Mass., metal framing plant and the indefinite shutdown of framing plants in Miami and Phoenix will idle 125 workers.

Worthington Industries Inc. announced that it will close plants and cut jobs over the next year in an effort to improve profitability. The announcement came as the same time the company reported a 36% decline in its fourth-quarter profit, compared with a year earlier, while its fiscal-year income shrunk as well. The company said it has undertaken a review of its business segments and plans to cut $35 million to $40 million in expenses through productivity improvement, facility closures and headcount reductions during fiscal 2008, which ends May 31, 2008. The firm did not identify any plants targeted for closure.
The Xerox Corp. announced that it will layoff 24 production workers at its Oklahoma City Xerox plant.
Xerox Corp. announced that it will cut 700 positions. The company stated that of the unit's 1,500 employees, approximately 700 would be let go by the end of 2001.
Xerox Corp. has cut some 750 jobs as part of its ongoing effort to trim costs.

Xerox Corp. announced that it will have a much smaller local presence after Jan. 1 after a companywide downsizing cuts the local work force by 100 employees. The company will cease its toner manufacturing operations in Oklahoma City by the end of December, laying off more than half of its 170-member work force. Operations will be consolidated from two buildings into a smaller, 340,000-square-foot space. The reason for the downsizing is two-fold. The reduction includes both union and nonunion employees. Xerox plans to keep its Oklahoma City operations and will try to lease or sell the 520,000-square-foot building it's vacating.

Xerox Corp. announced that on January 15, 2009, 50 people, or 3% of the company's Wilsonville plant employees were let go. The cuts affected all areas except sales and union manufacturing and included marketing, finance, human resources, product development and engineering.

Xerox Corp. is planning a big cut to its global workforce, and those cuts are going to impact Rochester. However, company officials didn't have specifics on how many of the approximately 3,000 earmarked job cuts would come from its 6,600-member workforce in Webster and Rochester. The company will cut jobs and pull back on its government health care strategy after it saw another decline in revenues and profits for the quarter ending June 30.
Xerox confirmed it was exploring "strategic options," the Connecticut-based technology giant has notified the state of North Carolina that it plans to lay off 178 employees at its Cary facility.

Xerox Corp. announced that it's laying off 350 employees from its call center in northwest Colorado Springs, the latest reduction in the company's local workforce. The affected employees will lose their jobs May 31, 2016. The layoffs result because of the "changing needs" of the company client.
YRC Worldwide Inc. will lay off about 3,750 drivers and dockworkers as it merges its Yellow Transportation and Roadway carriers, a 15% reduction in its 25,000 employees.

YRC Worldwide Inc. plans to eliminate 302 jobs at its Roadway Express and Yellow Transportation terminals here beginning March 1. Of the union workers affected, 150 will be laid off beginning March 1. Another 89 jobs will be transferred to other YRC sites, effective March 1; most of them will go to its Carlisle terminal.
