YRC Worldwide Inc. reported earnings results for the year 2008. For the year, the company reported that 7% drop in revenue compared with 2007.The company announced that is eliminating about 600 non-union jobs related to the integration of two subsidiaries and the harsh economy. The cuts result from efficiencies gained from combining Yellow Transportation and Roadway into YRC on March 1 and from ongoing cuts prompted by the economy. Eliminated positions include corporate staff and support positions throughout the company. YRC offered eligible workers an early retirement option, which includes subsidized medical coverage until age 65. Affected employees will get severance benefits. Integrating Yellow and Roadway has been expected to bring about 1,000 job cuts in the second and third quarters.

YRC Worldwide Inc. announced that it expects to pare its Yellow and Roadway networks, integrated earlier this year to become YRC, to about 400 facilities by the end of the month, rather than by the end of the year as previously planned. The move will result in a meaningful reduction in fixed and variable costs. YRC had 521 facilities, 37,000 employees and 16,700 trucks at the end of 2008. By the end of 2009, it had expected to have 400 facilities, 34,000 employees and 14,000 trucks. Those plans already marked a reduction from a target announced in March for 430 facilities by year end. Also announces it will close 'a small number of facilities' for which it had arranged sale-leaseback deals.

YRC Worldwide Inc. plans to close about 40 terminals across the country as it continues shrinking its operations to handle a smaller amount of customer freight. The company said that it planned to consolidate facilities between mid-December and mid-January and that employees at those facilities would be given the chance to relocate.

YRC Worldwide Inc. may cut 100 jobs at the end of March 2012 due to the selling the former Roadway headquarters. The company selling 270,000-square-foot building, which the company assumed as part of the huge 2003 merger of competitors Yellow Corp. and Roadway Corp. to form YRC, to the developer of the Goodyear headquarters. On top of the job cuts, 100 more YRC employees will transfer to some of its nearby truck terminals, and 50 more will get offers to take jobs in Kansas, South Dakota and Iowa, the report says. The job cuts could range from 50 to 100 depending on acceptance of relocation offers, ultimately leaving about 4,000 employees in Ohio.
Zale Corporation to close 115 under-performing stores to reduce costs during a sales slump. The store closings, to go into effect as leases expire, would save about $34 million in operating costs.

Zale Corporation closed 118 underperforming stores in the quarter ended July 31, 2009 and will record a $50 million pretax charge. The charge includes $23 million to cover lease guarantees on Bailey, Banks & Biddle stores. The closings bring Zale's total to 191 in 2009.
Zale Corporation has confirmed that 60 employees were laid off at its Irving, Texas-headquarters. The cuts leave Zale with about 800 corporate employees at the site.

Zions Bancorporation (UT) announced it will close, sell or scale back about 20 of its more than 400 branches. Targeted for closing are very small grocery store branches that are not profitable, primarily in Colorado and Utah.

Oshkosh Corporation announced that its Defense segment plans to reduce its workforce in Oshkosh by approximately 250 to 300 hourly positions in December 2014. In addition, approximately 70 salaried positions will be eliminated with the majority being temporary employees, elimination of open positions and those retiring. Oshkosh plans to reach out to the county and state workforce development agencies and local employers to help those affected in the layoff make the transition to other employment if they so desire. Provided Oshkosh receives interest from local and state-wide employers, the Company plans to hold a job fair to provide a venue for affected employees to meet prospective future employers.

In Winnebago County, Oshkosh Corp. has laid off hundreds of employees as military spending at the truck manufacturer fell by hundreds of millions of dollars - largely from the war in Afghanistan winding down.

Alliance Pharmaceutical Corp.'s flagship effort to develop a blood substitute suffered a severe setback when the company announced its development partnership for the product had collapsed and it would lay off 55 employees. The announced layoffs will affect employees involved in clinical trials of the blood substitute and leave the company with about 80 employees.

Buffets Holdings Inc. eliminated 25 jobs at its corporate headquarters late last year. The parent of the Old Country Buffet, HomeTown Buffet and Tahoe Joe's brands paid out $1.3 million in severance to the workers.
Bear Stearns Companies Inc. announced that it is set to cut about 240 jobs at its mortgage lending unit.
Bear Stearns Companies Inc. has laid off 240 employees at its residential home loans group, including 100 at Encore Credit, a California-based wholesale division.

Bear Stearns is slashing another 650 jobs in the firm's fourth round of cuts this year after getting burned on subprime mortgage bets that went up in smoke. The firm has announced the elimination of about 1,550 jobs this year amid the subprime lending crisis that has led to billions of dollars of losses across Wall Street. The cuts amount to nearly 10% of Bear Stearns' 15,500 employees at the end of the third quarter. Most of the cuts are coming from the firm's fixed income division, which underwrote billions in securities backed by home loans to borrowers with less-then-stellar credit ratings. The company reported earnings results for the third quarter of 2007. For the period, third-quarter profit fell 61% to $171 million as rising defaults on home loans sparked a fixed-income market decline in August.

The North Carolina board that oversees the state's 401 retirement plan picked Prudential, a giant insurance and financial services company based in Newark, N.J., to replace BB&T as the administrator of the state's $2.3 billion retirement plan. The decision will lower fees for 175,000 current and former state employees who participate in the state plan but will also prompt BB&T to eliminate about 40 jobs at its trust division in Raleigh.
BB & T Corp. announced that it will cut about 700 jobs through layoffs and attrition.

BB&T Corporation announced that it will close 21 branches as part of its merger of the two banks in South Florida. The shutdowns affect 21 branches that overlap, including 12 from BankAtlantic and nine from BB&T. BB&T plans to lay off 365 BankAtlantic employees by Feb. 1 as part of the merger, mostly back-office staff who do not deal directly with customers. It has offered those employees first dibs at BB&T jobs nationwide, severance, outplacement services and other benefits.

BB&T confirmed that it is laying off some employees, but it isn't releasing specific numbers or locations. Affected employees were given 60 days' notice period. The layoffs affected a small percentage of regional work force.

BB&T Corp. has decided to close a loan processing center in Hagerstown, Md., cutting 140 more jobs from the recently-acquired Susquehanna Bancshares. Most of the affected employees work in an administrative and support capacity and were notified on September 16, 2015. The bank will try to place affected employees into other positions at BB&T and that severance packages and outplacement services will be offered to those who are still working when the facility is closed during the fourth quarter. The company announced that it will be opening a career center within the facility on Oct. 1, 2015 to serve as a focal point for helping the affected employees prepare for the job search process - offering seasons on job search techniques, interview skills development, resume writing and use of virtual resources such as LinkedIn. The company announced last week that as part of its plan to consolidate back office operations after completing the acquisition last month, it will cut 89 jobs in Susquehanna's main office in Lititz, Lancaster County.

Valley National Bancorp is set to close its private aircraft lending business. The company stopped making new business more than a year ago and will completely close the business upon completion of the loans currently being paid. The company's private aviation business incurred losses since the 2008 financial crisis. Several lawsuits were filed by Valley National's lending unit, Valley Commercial Capital, in several states as it attempts to recover unpaid aircraft loans.

Wayne, N.J.-based Valley National Bancorp, the parent of Valley National Bank, plans to close and consolidate 13 branch locations during the second half of 2015. The branches - 12 in New Jersey and one in New York City - represent about 6% of the company's current branch network and are a mix of leased and owned properties.
Novell Inc. announced a workforce reduction of 10 percent, or approximately 600 positions, during the third quarter, as part of a cost cutting program.

Novell Inc. announced that it plans to eliminate 120 to 150 jobs in Europe, the Middle East and Africa in an effort to cut costs after results fell short of estimates. The cuts will cost about $10 million to $12 million, most of which will be recorded in the third quarter, the company said in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. The move will reduce quarterly operating expenses by about $3 million to $4 million.

Somber employees left the offices of Novell Inc. in Provo after the company's new owner laid off workers less than a week after completing the purchase. The Attachmate Group of Houston bought Novell for $2.2 billion and split the company in two.

Anadarko Petroleum Corp. could reduce its Houston-area payroll by an estimated 500 jobs about 10% of its global work force as the independent oil and gas producer restructures itself after two big acquisitions. The company has roughly 2,200 employees in the Houston area.

Anadarko Petroleum Corp. has confirmed it will cut 1,000 workers in response to the continuing oil slump. That amounts to about 17% of its total workforce, which stood at approximately 5,800 as of December 31, 2015.
EMC Corp. has announced that the company would lay off 1,600 workers.

EMC Corp. announced that it would cut an unspecified number of jobs as part of a restructuring plan approved the plan consists of cutting a certain number of jobs by the end of this year, resulting in a charge of between $130 million and $150 million. The restructuring is intended to enable EMC to rebalance and reorganize its workforce to best align with the opportunities ahead, continue to invest in key growth opportunities and prepare and evolve EMC for the future.

Dell EMC has announced that around 50 workers at the offices of technology company are to lose their jobs. The compulsory redundancies follow the merger of Dell and EMC, which was finalised in September.

Gottschalks Inc. reported sales results for the month of April 2006. The company reported that April total sales fell 0.4% to $43.3 million from $43.4 million in the year-earlier period. The company announced that in the third quarter it would close its 42,000-square-foot store in Danville, Calif.The company announced that it would open its fourth store in Oregon, at the Valley River Mall in Eugene.

Big Lots Inc. announced store opening and closing plans for fiscal 2013. For fiscal 2013, the company reported that it will open 55 new stores and close 57 stores, ending the year with 1,493 stores in the U.S.

Pacificare Health Systems Inc. of Colorado may eliminate up to 300 jobs in the Denver area or move them to Phoenix as part of a regional reorganization. The company announced Friday the changes would occur between March and September primarily in customer service, member services and claims processing. Parent company PacifiCare Health Systems is streamlining operations nationwide, and it will integrate some of its operations in Arapahoe County with a service center in Phoenix, said Amy Hudson, a PacifiCare spokeswoman. The company is based in Santa Ana, Calif.

Sun Microsystems Inc. is laying off 42 workers across three Hillsboro locations. The cuts are part of a restructuring announced Oct. 20 by the Santa Clara in which it will lay off up to 3,000 workers globally over the next year. In Hillsboro, Sun is shedding 26 positions from its facility at 3380 N.W. 215th Ave., 15 from 3295 N.W. 211th Terrace and one from 6220 N.W. Pinefarm Place. The layoffs are expected to occur between Jan. 3, 2010 and Jan. 17, 2010.
Sun Microsystems Inc. will cut 74 jobs at its Burlington offices next month as part of plan to shed 1,500 to 2,500 workers worldwide.

About 350 Sun Microsystems Inc. employees in Colorado are losing their jobs as part of layoffs announced last month. The Santa Clara, Calif. -based company began notifying employees and most of those being laid off will know by the end of the week, spokesman Prentiss Donohue said. The company, which makes computer servers that manage corporate networks, has 3,200 employees in Colorado. The majority work in Broomfield in consulting, training and support services but the company also has small offices in Denver and Colorado Springs.

Sun Microsystems Inc. posted a smaller than expected loss in its fiscal second quarter. For the three months ended December 28, Sun said it lost $125 million or 4 cents per share, on sales of $2.88 billion. The company lost $2.3 billion or 72 cents per share, on sales of $2.91 billion in the same period last year. Analysts, on average, were expecting a loss of 5 cents on sales of $2.7 billion, according to a survey by Thomson First Call. Sun saw its revenue from services grow from $902 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2003 to $944 million in the same period of fiscal 2004. But sales from products fell from $2.01 billion to $1.94 billion.
 
 
 
 Sun consolidating some of its manufacturing operations and will lay off 300 employees at a facility in Newark, California. The work once done in Northern California will be transferred to Oregon and Scotland.

Sun Microsystems Inc. which has had nine consecutive quarters of falling sales, said that it would eliminate as many as 1,080 jobs, or about 3 percent of its work force, to concentrate on products and services that are doing well. The company, a maker of server computers, will cut jobs in all regions, a spokeswoman, May Goh Petry, said in an interview. Sun had about 36,000 employees as of June, she said.
Sun Microsystems has announced that it plans to layoff 1,000 employees, approximately 2.5 percent of its workforce, as a part of its plan to return to profitability.

Sun Microsystems Inc. reaches its first deadline in a massive restructuring effort to reduce its global workforce by 11% to 13%. The company employs 4,700 workers in Colorado, most of them at its operations along the Boulder Turnpike. If across-the-board (percentage) cuts are made, that could mean Sun's Colorado operations would lose between 517 and 611 workers. The company would chop 800 jobs, 15% of the local workforce. Sun has 37,500 employees worldwide. 5,000 approximate planned layoffs throughout Sun Microsystems by the end of September.
Sun Microsystems Inc. has given layoff notifications to 1,300 employees, including 195 in Broomfield and Louisville. The company announced plans to reduce its global work force by 15% to 18%.
Sun Microsystems Inc. eliminated 2,000 workers since the end of June, and it expects to slash 1,000 to 2,000 more by the end of the current fiscal year 2007.
T. Rowe Price Group Inc. has cut about 180 jobs, representing 5 percent of its U.S. work force because of reduced profits and revenues due to stock market downturn.
Microsoft Corp. is shutting down one of its business software units, which employs 177 workers. Most of the jobs will be saved, though. Microsoft's Findlay office will close by the end of September.
Microsoft plans to lay off 2,850 more employees, mostly related to its struggling smartphone business, this fiscal year.

Microsoft has announced that it will be shutting down its $425 million purchased MSN TV, which it bought, backs in 1997. The company has announced that it will cease operations in September of 2013. Microsoft announced that WebTV started in 1996 with an aim to bring people 'online' and to give an easy, hassle-free means of accessing the internet that are already online. Then, MSN TV 2 was released with better power and features. The company added that it is advisable to save all data before the service will die on September 30, 2013.

Microsoft Corp. announced plans to restructure the company's phone hardware business to better focus and align resources. The company also announced the reduction of up to 7,800 positions, primarily in the phone business.
Microsoft has confirmed that it will close it's Finnish mobile phone unit and cut 1,350 jobs in the country.

Microsoft Corp. announced a restructuring plan to simplify its operations and align the recently acquired Nokia Devices and Services business with the company's overall strategy. These steps will result in the elimination of up to 18,000 positions over the next year. Of the total, about 12,500 professional and factory positions will be eliminated through synergies and strategic alignment of the Nokia Devices and Services business acquired by Microsoft on April 25, 2014. The actions associated with the plan are expected to be substantially complete by December 31, 2014, and fully completed by June 30, 2015. The company expects to incur pre-tax charges of $1.1 billion to $1.6 billion over the next four quarters, including $750 million to $800 million for severance and related benefit costs, and $350 million to $800 million of asset-related charges.

Microsoft Corporation has shut down its office in the funky Pioneer Square neighborhood of Seattle, where consumer electronics concepts like the "Metro" interface for Windows Phone 7 and the never-released Courier tablet were hatched.
Microsoft will axe its UK Skype office, resulting in redundancies for both Skype and Yammer employees.

Microsoft is laying off 62 test engineers in the second round of cuts hitting Windows testers in the past five months. The company has recently sent test work overseas, but a spokeswoman denied that's a factor. The company announced that the automation, not globalization, led to the cuts. The testers were given the option of staying, with pay, for six weeks while they look for other jobs in the company. But finding other test jobs in the company may be a challenge. The 62 work in the core operating system division, headed by Brian Valentine, a senior vice president. Microsoft is outsourcing some test work to overseas companies such as Wipro, Infosys and Tata Consultancy in India. The company initially told employees that 64 people were being laid off, but the number was later reduced to 62.

Microsoft Corporation reported earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended December 31, 2008. The company announced revenue of $16.63 billion for the second quarter, a 2% increase over the same period of the prior year. Operating income, net income and diluted earnings per share for the quarter were $5.94 billion, $4.17 billion and $0.47, declines of 8%, 11% and 6%, respectively, compared with the prior year. 

For the six months, the company reported net income of $8,547 million or $0.94 per share on revenue of $31,690 million compared to net income of $8,996 million or $0.95 per share on revenue of $30,129 million for the same period of last year.

Microsoft also announced additional steps to manage costs, including the reduction of headcount-related expenses, vendors and contingent staff, facilities, capital expenditures and marketing. As part of this plan, Microsoft will eliminate up to 5,000 jobs in R&D, marketing, sales, finance, legal, HR, and IT over the next 18 months, including 1,400 jobs. These initiatives will reduce the company's annual operating expense run rate by approximately $1.5 billion and reduce fiscal year 2009 capital expenditures by $700 million.
Microsoft Corporation announced it is axing 60 jobs, 2% of its 2,900 British workforce-after an 11% drop in income for the last quarter of 2008.
Microsoft Corp. laid off 61 people this week as it reshuffled its interactive television unit.
Microsoft Corporation announced the first significant layoffs in its 34-year history, affecting some 5% of its work force, after reporting a slump in profit for the quarter that ended Dec. 31.
Oracle Corporations has announced it laid off about 850 people, approximately two percent of its workforce, during the last quarter.

Oracle Corp. plans to lay off 108 employees at a North Austin office as the California-based information technology giant continues to shift its emphasis from hardware to cloud computing. The company does not plan to close the office at Riata Park, which spans two buildings and is just east of Apple Inc.'s Austin campus off Parmer Lane. Employees were notified on or before September 1, 2017 about the layoffs that are scheduled to occur October 31, wrote Victoria Thrasher, the corporation's Americas human resources group vice president. The affected employees don't have bumping rights, which refers to the right to replace less senior workers instead of cutting their jobs.

Coty Inc. announced that it has closed its site in Duesseldorf, western Germany, in early July 2006 in an effort to cut costs in Germany. After the plant closure, which will affect 62 employees, Coty plans to focus on its fragrance activities at its location in Mainz, also in western Germany. The company cost-cutting measures in Germany are due to the low growth rate of the sales in the country.

The Tech Data Corp. announced that it will immediately dismiss less than 2 percent of its 3,700-member work force. Tech Data also stated that the layoffs will affect its 2,500 employees in Clearwater.

OSI Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced a series of staffing adjustments, management realignment and business initiatives. The Company has reduced its overall headcount by approximately 40 people from approximately 490. The majority of these job reductions were concentrated in the discovery research area and primarily in biology sciences.

OSI also announced a series of senior management changes in research. Dr. Neil Gibson has been promoted to the position of Vice President, Research, reporting to the CEO and will assume responsibility for the Company's pre-clinical cancer research efforts. OSI also announced two senior research appointments at its Oxford, U.K. facility. Dr. Jim McCormack has joined the Company as Vice President, U.K. Research, reporting to Dr. Gibson.

X-Rite, Incorporated eliminated about 30 jobs, mainly from its Kentwood headquarters. The company announced the cuts were across several departments and represented a continuation of a profit-improvement plan announced in January.
Tekelec announced that it will implement a restructuring plan that will result in 60 layoffs.

Tekelec is expected to announce major layoffs as the Morrisville technology company deals with falling revenue and rising operating costs. The company is contending with slipping sales and declining confidence on Wall Street. The company could shed dozens of local workers as it shifts emphasis from underperforming divisions.

XOMA Corporation announced that it plans to reduce personnel by 84 positions, or 34%, including 50 positions to be eliminated immediately and the remainder by the end of the first quarter of 2012. The company said that the staff reductions result primarily from its decisions to utilize a contract manufacturing organization for Phase 3 and commercial production and to eliminate internal research functions that are non-differentiating or that can be obtained cost-effectively by contract service providers. The company said that it anticipates taking one-time charges for restructuring and related severance costs totaling approximately $6.0 million during 2012, of which $3.9 million will result in cash charges. In the first quarter of 2012, the Company expects to take a charge of approximately $3.6 million. As a result of the changes, the company expects to reduce ongoing net internal spending by approximately $14 million in 2012 compared to the 2011 level. This reduction in fixed costs allows investment of a similar amount into gevokizumab's clinical development during 2012.The company currently anticipates cash used in ongoing operating activities in 2012 to be approximately $35 million.

American Woodmark Corp. announced that the continuing housing slump has led to the decision to reduce production capacity. In a realignment of the company's manufacturing network, the facility in Berryville, Virginia and the oldest of the three facilities in Moorefield, West Virginia will be permanently closed. In addition, the company will suspend operations in Tahlequah, Oklahoma until market conditions improve and additional capacity is needed.

On June 1, 2020, American Woodmark Corporations Board of Directors approved the closure and eventual disposal of its manufacturing plant located in Humboldt, Tennessee. The closure is related to committed synergy capture from the acquisition of RSI Home Products Inc. and the subsequent realignment of its flatstock operations. A portion of the Humboldt facilitys capacity had been previously moved to Anaheim, California and the remaining capacity will be shifting to its Anaheim and Toccoa, Georgia facilities. The manufacturing plant is expected to cease operations in September 2020.

Harley-Davidson Inc. announced that it will cut 730 jobs, including hundreds at its Milwaukee headquarters and Wisconsin factories. Most of the job cuts, described as permanent, will take place over the next three months. The reductions will be accompanied by temporary plant shutdowns, possibly including a two-week closure in late June. Assembly line production also will be slowed, reducing the need for some plant workers. As a result of the slowdown, Harley plans to cut this year's motorcycle shipments by 23,000 to 27,000 bikes. For the full year, it means the company expects to ship between 303,500 and 307,500 motorcycles-at least 7% below last year.

Harley-Davidson, Inc. cutting production and reducing the work force by 730 jobs. The company's plan included cutting 300 positions from Harley's Springettsbury Township plant, which employs about 2,600 hourly and salaried workers. The company also reduced shipments of motorcycles through temporary plant shutdowns and adjustments to daily production rates.

Harley-Davidson, Inc. plans to close its Capitol Drive factory in Wauwatosa and its Franklin distribution center by September 25, 2009. The company also plans to lay off employees at its product development center in Wauwatosa on the same date. The company announced plans for the mass layoffs at the three facilities earlier this year. A notice filed with the Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development on Sept. 8 didn't indicate how many employees would be laid off, but the company stated earlier in 2009, that 645 employees would lose their jobs as a result of the closure of the Wauwatosa factory and the Franklin warehouse. The company announced in July that about 35 jobs at the product development center would be cut.

The store where Bruce Rossmeyer started his Harley-Davidson, Inc. empire will no longer sell motorcycles. The Original Bruce Rossmeyer Harley-Davidson, 290 N. Beach Street, closed and will reopen in the fall as a museum and souvenir/apparel store. The museum will feature private motorcycle collections from across Florida, as well as chronicle Harley-Davidson's growth in the state.

Harley-Davidson, Inc. announced it will cease operations at New Castalloy. The company expects the transition of supply from the New Castalloy to be complete by mid 2013. The decision to close New Castalloy comes as part of an overall strategy Harley-Davidson embarked on in 2009 to develop world-class manufacturing capability throughout the company by restructuring and consolidating operations for greater competitiveness, efficiency and flexibility. Under the strategy, the company is focusing its production operations on metal fabrication for motorcycle fuel tanks, fenders and frames, paint, final assembly and powertrain production, and has been transitioning to suppliers work that is outside these areas or cannot be performed competitively in house. The facility produces the majority of cast wheels for Harley-Davidson motorcycles and has a workforce of 212, including 183 employees and 29 contract workers. The sourcing of the New Castalloy production to other existing suppliers is expected to generate about $9 million in annual ongoing savings beginning in 2014. Harley-Davidson expects to incur about $30 million in restructuring charges related to the transition, including approximately $10 million in 2011 and $20 million in 2012. Approximately 35% of the $30 million will be non-cash charges. Including the closing of the New Castalloy operations, Harley-Davidson now expects all restructuring activities initiated since early 2009 to generate annual ongoing savings upon completion of approximately $315 million to $335 million, and to result in one-time overall costs of $505 million to $525 million, including costs of $75 million to $85 million in 2011 and $45 million to $55 million in 2012.

Harley-Davidson, Inc. announced that it will reduce the workforce at its Kansas City plant by 140 on June 30, 2013. The remaining 65 employees are being laid off. The move is all part of a new labor agreement signed in February 2011 that went into effect in August 2012. The agreement included reducing the overall full-time employment at the plant to about 540.
Harley-Davidson Inc. plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs and ship fewer motorcycles than it had planned for the year.

Harley-Davidson plans to cut more than 100 jobs at a plant in Pennsylvania. The company is eliminating 200 positions across the country, including about 115 jobs at its Springettsbury Township plant. Union officials said layoffs will begin in early October and will finish by the end of November. The company spokeswoman Bernadette Lauer said the company is continually evaluating the industry and making changes to right-size the company.

Toll Brothers Inc. announced that it will lay off about a quarter of its production staff in Knox. The plant employs about 80 people, and once the layoffs take effect, they will be left with 60. The company announced the cuts were due to continuing slow home sales in Illinois and Michigan, but announced that as soon as the housing market turns around he will be adding people to the plant.

Fred's announced that in the fourth quarter of 2015, the company plans to open 4 new stores and 10 to 15 pharmacy departments.For the full fiscal year of 2015, this brings the estimated net store closings to 44 and net new pharmacy departments to a range of 16 to 21 or a penetration rate of 58% to 59%. The 47 ongoing store closures will be completed during the fourth quarter along with the closure of 1 pharmacy department.

Freds, Inc. announced it will begin to close an additional 104 underperforming stores as part of an ongoing effort to rationalize its store footprint. Freds decision to close additional underperforming stores follows a continued evaluation of the Company's store portfolio, including historical and recent store performance and the timing of lease expirations, among other factors. Liquidation sales at the 104 stores designated for closure will begin May 16, 2019 while the Companys other stores will remain open. Freds intends to close all 104 impacted stores by the end of June 2019.
Watts Water Technologies, Inc. announced it will cut 330 jobs worldwide.
Cablevision Systems Corp. announced plans to close its Voom high-definition programming channels and cut jobs in the business, blaming a failed partnership with Dish Network Corp.

Cablevision Systems Corp. announced that it was cutting 600 jobs, or 4% of its full-time work force. The cuts would be made mainly in corporate, administrative and infrastructure functions. As a result of the cuts, Cablevision will take a charge of $55 million in the fourth quarter.
Adobe Systems Inc. announced that it plans to layoff 247 employees as a part of its plan to cut costs.

Adobe Systems Incorporated. said it is dismissing about 260 employees, or 7 percent of its work force, as the software maker revamps to combat sluggish sales. Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., had 3,557 employees at the end of August. The company cut 247 jobs in October 2001. Last week, Adobe said in a regulatory filing that it would take a restructuring charge of $10 million to $14 million for layoffs.
Adobe Systems Inc. has announced plans to slash its global workforce by 9%, eliminating some 680 full-time positions, in a bid to realign its costs in connection with its 2010 operating plan.

Adobe Systems is shutting down its R&D operations in China as U.S. tech firms face an increasingly hostile government. Although the company will maintain its sales offices, R&D operations will cease by the end of 2014, impacting 300 employees. Rampant software piracy as well as the Chinese government's recent probes, stemming from its 2008 anti-monopoly law, were also a factor in the decision.

St. Joe Co. will exit home building in the state and focus instead on its land holdings. St. Joe will cut about 10% of its work force and take a charge of about $10.7 million, of which $9 million will be taken in the third quarter.

Harte Hanks is closing its offices in Baltimore County and will lay off 112 people. The company confirmed the plant at 4545 Annapolis Road in Halethorpe was closing. Layoffs will start on November 18 and will continue through the end of the year. In all, the plant is home to more than 160 employees, but about 50 of them will be able to start telecommuting for the company or will be moved to one of Harte Hanks' other offices.
HealthSouth Corp. stated that it plans to lay off 62 of 86 workers at its office in Brentwood this summer.

HEALTHSOUTH Corp. announced that it will close its Metro West Hospital on Sept. 2, laying off about 500 workers. Company officials announced that the hospital, located in Fairfield in suburban Birmingham, has been losing more than $500,000 a month. The hospital's emergency department will close July 31.

HEALTHSOUTH Corp. announced it plans to shed its outpatient rehabilitation clinics, surgery centers and diagnostic division to focus on inpatient intensive care, an area where it is making the largest share of revenue. But it shelved the idea of coming up with a new name to replace the one that was marred during an accounting scandal that resulted in guilty pleas, layoffs and a sharply lower stock price.

Conseco Inc. announced it will eliminate its last major medical insurance unit, costing 445 employees their jobs and leaving 40,000 customers in 20 states looking for new coverage. So far this year, Conseco has cut more than 600 jobs.
A Fiserv In c. call center in Aurora, which employs more than 200 people, will close in the second quarter of 2010.
Due to economic conditions, Silicon Graphics Inc. announced its plans to cut about 1,000 regular, temporary and contractor positions, or about 15% of its global workforce, in June 2001.
Silicon Graphics Inc. announced that it is laying off about 250 workers, or 12% of its workforce.

On June 28, 2006, Silicon Graphics Inc. approved a restructuring plan that will include reductions in its workforce of approximately 90 positions or 5% of the Companys global workforce. On June 29, 2006, the Company began to implement these restructuring actions with notifications to affected employees in North America and certain other locations. The balance of the notifications will follow over a reasonable period, consistent with business and local legal requirements in other parts of the world. The Company expects the workforce reductions to be materially completed by the end of calendar year 2006.

On June 28, 2006, the Company and certain of its subsidiaries entered into a Post-Petition Loan and Security Agreement with certain lenders identified on the signature pages thereof, Morgan Stanley Senior Funding Inc., as administrative agent, sole lead arranger and sole bookrunner, and Wells Fargo Foothill Inc., as collateral agent, revolving agent and syndication agent. The Financing Agreement contemplates a $130 million financing facility, which consists of a $100 million term loan and a $30 million revolving line of credit comprising two types of advances ('Revolver A Advances' and 'Revolver B Advances', respectively). The interest rate under the Term Loan is the per annum rate equal to the sum of the rate of interest announced, from time to time, within Wells Fargo Bank, N.A., at its principal office in San Francisco as its prime rate plus 700 basis points.

KB Home announced that it has laid off nearly a tenth of its work force at its Inland Valley office. The company let go 25 of the 275 employees in its Pomona office. The move by the Los Angeles-based home builder comes amid difficult times for the residential construction industry.

Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. announced that it will axe 58 jobs at a bottling plant. Managers and shop floor staff in East Kilbride, Lanarkshire, face redundancy. Workers in the East Kilbride distribution operation face the sack as part of a drive to shed 170 jobs across the UK.

Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. announced the closure of its Malvern Water plant on the same day as the Government's comprehensive spending review. Around 17 workers will lose their jobs when the plant closes in two weeks' time.
Pilgrim's Pride Corp. will close a chicken processing plant in Alma, Virginia and move production to two other facilities. The plant employs 300 people.

Pilgrim's Pride Corp. terminated a total of 11 employees, including one superintendent, one supervisor, one foreman and eight hourly employees as a result of its continuing investigation into the violation of its animal welfare policies at the company's Moorefield, West Virginia, plant. All of the individuals terminated for cause earlier were employed at the Moorefield facility.

Pilgrim's Pride Corp. has announced it will lay off about 300 workers as it converts its Broadway chicken operation into a prepared-foods supply plant. The plant, which produces fresh traypack chicken products for retail sale, will begin supplying chicken wings and boneless chicken breast to the company's prepared-foods plants May 29.
Pilgrims Pride Corporation announced it will also close distribution centers in Oskaloosa, Iowa; Plant City and Pompano Beach, Fla.; Jackson, Miss.; Nashville, Tenn.; and Cincinnati.

Pilgrims Pride Corporation announced plans to idle a chicken processing plant in Clinton, Ark., and a further-processing facility in Bossier City, La. Both moves, which are expected to be completed within 60 days, are part of the company's ongoing effort to operate more efficiently and return to profitability amid high feed costs and an oversupply of chicken on the market. The idling of the two plants will eliminate a total of approximately 600 positions. Pilgrim's Pride will provide transition programs to employees whose positions are eliminated to assist them in securing new employment, filing for unemployment and obtaining other applicable benefits.

Pilgrim's Corp. announced that it will close its chicken-processing plant in Dallas, Texas, within 60 days as part of its continuing effort to reduce costs and operate more efficiently. The Dallas plant is scheduled to close by September 30. Approximately 1,000 hourly and salaried employees who work at the Dallas facility will be affected by the plant closing.

Pilgrim's Corp. announced to consolidate a pair of hatcheries and move jobs from De Queen to Nashville. The company has been operating beneath capacity at the two plants and decided to merge the operations. The move is expected to improve efficiency and make the Nashville hatchery more productive. All 21 workers at the De Queen plant will be offered jobs at other Pilgrim's Pride operations in southwest Arkansas. Operations at the De Queen facility are to be shut down by Sept. 16, 2011.

LoJack Corp. announced that it will lay off 46 employees, primarily at its Westwood corporate headquarters and from its field sales staff, as it undergoes a restructuring. The company said that job cuts were necessary to bring its operating costs in line with the changing dynamics of the automotive market. The company will incur an approximately $1.8 million charge for severance and other costs associated with the layoffs, which will be completed in the second quarter. The reductions will result in $3.5 million in savings for the rest of 2010 and $6.8 million annually beginning 2011.

CoreLogic announced that it will be closing its office in Charlotte, laying off 46 people. The division serves lenders and other companies who need property record retrieval or mortgage document processing, among other functions. The office closing will be complete by October. CoreLogic's Charlotte location is in an office complex on Forest Point Circle, off Arrowood Road.

Quiksilver Inc. plans to close 25 of its surfwear stores, primarily in the United States, because they 'are not generating sufficient cash flows and are unlikely to achieve desired profitability. The company plan to close nine of the 25 stores during fiscal 2009 and will be working to close the remaining 16 stores as soon as possible.
According to unnamed sources, Comverse Technology Inc. plans to layoff 1,000 employees as a result of the economic downturn.
Comverse Technology Inc. announced that it expects to implement an immediate action to reduce its workforce by approximately 6%.

Comverse Technology Inc. announced a round of layoffs which have been discussed since August, is set to get underway. Over the coming month of Feburary 2010, about 500 workers around the world, or 12% of its workforce, are set to be laid off. About 200 of the layoffs are expected to be employees in Israel.

Comverse Technology Inc. began the laying off of 200 more employees, less than six months after the previous wave of firings. Most of the layoffs are at the company's headquarters in Israel, as part of a restructuring. The company is expected to later cut hundreds more employees at its headquarters, in an effort to cut costs and swing to profit. The company's restructuring plan comes after the company announced in August 2010 that its cash reserves had shrunk to $327 million, and that it was liable to face liquidity problems in 2011. The company announced then a two-step restructuring plan, the first step of which was completed in October, and included 400 layoffs. The second step is now underway. In order to return to profitability, the company formulated a new business plan, which included restructuring. The company will now comprise four independent business units, with an emphasis on billing systems for mobile carriers. Based on the plan's progress and performance, management will decide which departments will see personnel cuts in the future.

News Corp. announced that its UK newspaper unit News International will cut its production staff by two thirds.

The company also announced to invest 600 million ( $1.07 billion) in four new plants.
News Corp. has flagged job cuts after reporting a $5.9 billion first half net loss amid a grim economic climate.

News Corp. may be preparing to layoff about half its 1,100 staff at MySpace, with termination notices to be distributed around mid-January as part of efforts to streamline the social-networking site ahead of a possible sale. Additional reductions in headcount will likely be necessary to lure a potential buyer, with News Corp. on track to complete a sale by mid-year.

Georgia Gulf Corp. announced that it will shutdown its Tiptonville, Tennessee, compound plant effective immediately as part of the Corporation's ongoing commitment to operational efficiency. Customers will see no change as a result of the plant closure due to increased efficiencies from the other Georgia Gulf compound manufacturing locations.

Georgia Gulf Corp. announced consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended March 31, 2008. The company reported net sales of $712.5 million for the first quarter of 2008 compared to net sales of $713.7 million for the first quarter of 2007. The reduction in sales is primarily due to difficult market conditions in the U.S., as well as extreme winter weather in Canada and the Northeastern United States. Sales benefited from higher prices for vinyl resin, caustic, and aromatic products, the weaker U.S. dollar, and increased exports. The company reported a net loss of $69.5 million or $2.02 loss per diluted share for the first quarter of 2008, compared to a net loss of $34.6 million or $1.01 loss per diluted share during the same quarter in the previous year. The net loss includes a write-down for the closing of the Oklahoma City, Oklahoma PVC resin plant, costs related to the sale of the outdoor storage buildings business, and other restructuring actions totaling $26.1 million or approximately $0.58 per share. Loss from continuing operations was $69,495,000 or $2.02 per diluted share against loss from continuing operations of $26,510,000 or $0.77 per diluted share for the same period a year ago.
The company provided earnings guidance for the full year 2008. Given the financial results of the first quarter and worsening projections for the Company's markets in 2008, the Company's operating plan now includes more significant sales of non-core assets compared to the beginning of the year. Including the anticipated gains from these additional asset sales, the Company expects to achieve a higher level of EBITDA in 2008 than it did in 2007.

The Company announced that it has closed its Oklahoma City, OK PVC resin plant, which has the capacity to produce 500 million pounds of PVC resin per year, in response to declining demand. The Company's Sarnia plant operated a portion of the first quarter but is presently temporarily idled and will act as a swing plant to match demand. The combination of these action

Georgia Gulf Corp. announced that it is permanently closing its Sarnia, Ontario (Canada) PVC resin plant. The plant had operated only periodically in 2008 due to decreased demand in the housing and construction markets. In response to continued weakening in the markets, Georgia Gulf has made the decision to permanently close the facility, which had the capacity to produce 450 million pounds of PVC resin annually. As a result of the Sarnia PVC resin plant closure, the Company expects to record a non-cash charge of about $50 million in the fourth quarter of 2008. The Company expects the cash costs related to the Sarnia plant closure and other cash restructuring costs incurred in the third and fourth quarters of 2008 to be approximately $12 million. Under the terms of the last credit facility amendment, these charges can be excluded from EBITDA for purposes of Georgia Gulf's covenant calculations.
OraSure has announced that it plans to close its research and manufacturing plant in Beaverton by 2003 and move operations to Pennsylvania.

The Plexus Corp. is cutting 300 jobs or 5 percent, of its work force by the end of its second quarter in March, the company said. Plexus would not disclose the number of jobs that had been cut already. The cuts are expected to save Plexus $1.5 million to $2 million a quarter.

Plexus Corp. decided to make some painful personnel cuts during the year, including the decision to close its San Diego manufacturing facility and consolidation of its Seattle holdings affecting about 400 employees. More than 100 workers in Neenah will be laid off with the closure this winter of the obsolete manufacturing plant at 2121 Harrison St.

Plexus Corp. announced that it plans to cut 400 jobs, or 8 percent of its workforce, and close its Kentucky manufacturing plant, as the soft economy continues to batter the electronics manufacturing industry. The job cuts would affect engineering and corp.

Plexus Corp. announced its intention to close its Ayer, MA manufacturing facility. The Company plans to transition products manufactured in this facility to other Plexus facilities, primarily in Neenah, WI. The closure of the facility is expected by March 2009. This decision will result in the separation of approximately 170 employees from the approximately 65,000 sq ft Ayer facility over the first and second fiscal quarters of 2009.

Plexus is planning to cut around 50 staff at its plant in West Lothian. More than 130 people are currently employed at the Pyramids Business Park near Bathgate. The company which also employs around 400 at a site in Kelso was making the move as a result of reduced demand from the oil and gas industry.

Impacts from the weak coal market are starting to be felt in the mine equipment sector, including at Joy Global, Inc., which is laying off 37 employees at its Lebanon, Ky., plant, the Lexington (Ky.) The workforce reduction is expected by July 20. The company is experiencing a temporary decrease in customer orders across the U.S.

Network Equipment Technologies Inc. provided revenue guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2009. For the quarter, the company expects its revenue to be flat to up 5% as compared to the second quarter of fiscal 2009.The company also announced a reduction in its workforce, leaving the company with approximately 255 employees as compared to 295 at the end of the second quarter of fiscal 2009.

Cash America International Inc. announced that it anticipates the closing of up to 139 locations in response to newly passed legislation which will change the pricing and parameters of its cash advance product offering in the state of Ohio. Because the new legislation significantly reduces the cash advance revenue available under current Ohio law, the new law will essentially eliminate the Company's ability to viably offer this important alternative form of short-term credit to customers in Ohio. Cash America expects that it will begin ceasing operations in virtually all of its locations in Ohio sometime between now and when the new law becomes effective, which could be as early as mid-August, 2008, depending on when the Ohio Governor signs the legislation. The Company is now revising management's expectations for anticipated earnings for fiscal year 2008 to $2.85 to $3.00 per share from the $3.00 to $3.15 per share issued in conjunction with its record breaking first quarter 2008 earnings release. The newly established range of 2008 full year earnings per share reflects the lost business economics of the Company's Ohio cash advance operations, but does not include the one-time expenses related to lease terminations, severance or asset write-downs and is based on the complete discontinuance of the product by the end of August, 2008.

Cash America International Inc. announced that it will close 43 Cashland shops in the coming months. It plans to close the 43 shops, it runs about 140 in the state, including more than a dozen in Greater Cincinnati, will cost 150 jobs.

Cash America International Inc. will proceed with its previously announced plans and intends to close approximately one-third of its Ohio lending locations over the next few months. The locations slated for closure are in various markets throughout the state and operate under the trade name, Cashland. This outcome will force the company to close about 43 of Cashland lending locations, leaving about 150 of hard-working coworkers without jobs. The Cashland locations that remain open will begin offering customers alternative services including short-term unsecured loans governed by a different statute and, in most shops, both gold-buying and/or pawn lending services.

Delta Woodside Industries Inc. announced that it would cut 400 jobs, or more than a quarter of its work force, to reduce costs amid oversupply and increased competition from imports. The company said it planned to close a cotton mill in Piedmont, S.C., affecting about 361 jobs. Salaries and positions at other plants will be cut, Delta said. Delta will have 1,100 employees, down from 2,000 three years ago, and four plants, down from seven, after the restructuring. The company has been streamlining operations in anticipation of the expiration of import quotas in January 2005.

Jack in the Box Inc. has announced 64 layoffs in a letter to the Texas Workforce Commission. The letter indicates that the company will cut 64 jobs most of them drivers at the company's 4721 Mountain Creek Parkway distribution center in Dallas. The layoffs will occur June 21, 2009. Jack in the Box is cutting the jobs due to the company's decision to outsource its transportation needs to a third party. Other jobs cut included four distribution supervisors and two customer-service representatives.

York International Corp. announced that it has planned a restructuring program to save the company $35 million a year starting in 2007. The restructuring program, scheduled to begin in the third quarter, entails consolidating operations within Europe, the Middle East and Africa. York plans to divest non-core operations, close one manufacturing facility and significantly downsize another factory. The company said the actions are expected to reduce the EMEA workforce by 1,300 employees, or 20%.

IndyMac Bancorp Inc. plans to eliminate as many as 1,000 jobs and slash its dividend by half amid challenging conditions in the mortgage and housing markets that have led to industrywide credit tightening. The company expects to cut 10% of its staff, or about 1,000 positions, as part of layoffs and a severance program.

The company plans to recommend that the company's board of directors to reduce the quarterly dividend payout to 25 cents per share for the time being.

C&D Technologies Inc. announced plans to reduce labor costs by approximately $4.5 million on an annualized basis. The actions to be taken include the elimination of approximately 90 positions, both salaried and hourly, over the next twelve months. The Company also announced that it would suspend annual salary increases at this time.

DMC Stratex Networks Inc. announced that it plans to relocate its Seattle operations to San Jose reducing its worldwide workforce by approximately 30%. The 30% staff cut includes prior reductions implemented since April.
Audiovox Corp. has said it has reduced its workforce by about 8%. It has 880 employees, including 600 on the Island. The company did not say how many jobs were cut locally.

General Communication Inc. is laying off 77 employees as part of a corporate restructuring. All but seven of the job cuts will be in Anchorage, and more than half are management and other salaried positions.
Retailer Saks Inc. announced plans to close its 104,000 square foot Bergner's department store located in the Lincoln Square Mall in Urbana, Illinois. The store will close in March 2002.
Saks Incorporated plans to consolidate its credit card operations in an effort to cut costs, resulting in the loss of 200 jobs at a facility in Elmhurst, Illinois.

The Saks Fifth Avenue department store at 1300 Franklin Avenue in Garden City is to close in January, as part of a plan to increase profits for its parent company, Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises. The plan calls for closing 10 stores, including 3 Off 5th outlets, throughout the country. Of the nearly 700 employees who will be affected, the company stated that it plans to offer them severance packages or the opportunity to work in another location.

Saks Inc. announced it will close its 69,000 square foot McRae's store at the Meadowbrook Mart in Jackson, Mississippi by the end of January 2005. The Company will continue to operate its three other McRae's stores in metropolitan Jackson located at the Dogwood Festival Mall, Northpark Mall, and Metrocenter Mall.
Saks Inc. announced it intends to close its 25,000 square foot Saks Off fifth store located in St. Louis Mills in St. Louis, Missouri by February 1, 2007.

Saks Inc. which operates the Libby Lu chain, announced that in November 2009 it planned to close the 98 stores nationwide, saying they were not profitable. The Arden Fair store will shut January 31, 2008.

Saks Incorporated is planning to close its Saks Fifth Avenue store located in the Fashion Valley Mall in San Diego, California by July 17, 2010. The planned closing of its San Diego store is consistent with its strategy of focusing its resources on its most productive stores.

As Saks Off Fifth prepares to open a store in the new Eagan outlet mall, its Nicollet Mall site in downtown Minneapolis is officially on its last legs.The outlet store, in the Gaviidae Common I building at 651 Nicollet Mall, will close January 2015.

Casual Male Retail Group Inc. announced that to further its previously stated goal of focusing primarily on its Casual Male Big and Tall business, it plans to accelerate the closing of its Levi's(R) and Dockers(R) Outlet stores and ultimately exit the business. In addition, the Company announced it has transferred the operations of its remaining seven Candie's(R) outlet stores to Candie's Inc.

Casual Male Retail Group, Inc. revised earnings guidance for the fourth quarter and fiscal year ending January 28, 2012. For the fourth quarter and fiscal year 2011, the company expects that comparable sales for the company increased 0.8% and 2.1%, respectively, as compared to the comparable prior year period. As a result, sales for fiscal 2011 will approximate $397.7 million, as compared to the companys previously reported sales range of $397.5 to $402.5 million. The company expects the gross margin rate for fiscal 2011 to range from 46.1% to 46.2%, a decrease from its previous guidance of 46.9% to 47.3%. For the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011, comparable sales from the companys 16 DestinationXL (DXL? stores increased 9.0% as compared to the prior years fourth quarter.The company expects earnings per share for fiscal 2011 to be $0.28 to $0.29 per diluted share compared to previous guidance of $0.35 to $0.38 per diluted share. For fiscal 2012, the company plans to open 35-40 additional DXL stores, resulting in approximately 51-56 DXL stores operating at the end of fiscal 2012, with at least one store located in most of the major metropolitan cities across the United States.  The company expects to close approximately 60 existing stores, most of which are in connection with opening these DXL stores, resulting in an estimated store count of approximately 425 stores at the end of fiscal 2012.

Destination XL Group, Inc. provided financial guidance for the full year 2019. The company expected to deliver comparable sales growth in omni-channel retail business and to generate free cash flow in fiscal 2019.In fiscal 2019, the company plan to open 2 new DXL retail stores, rebrand 12 Casual Male XL retail stores to DXL retail stores, and rebrand 1 Casual Male XL outlet to a DXL outlet store. The company also plan to close 5 Casual Male XL retail stores (two of which will be closed in connection with the opening of the two DXL stores), 1 DXL store and all 5 Rochester Clothing stores.

Destination XL Group, Inc. announced that in the fiscal year 2019, the company plans to open 2 new DXL retail stores, rebrand 12 Casual Male XL retail stores to DXL retail stores, and rebrand 1 Casual Male XL outlet to a DXL outlet store. The company also plan to close 5 Casual Male XL retail stores (two of which will be closed in connection with the opening of the two DXL stores), 1 DXL store and all 5 Rochester Clothing stores.

Cadence Design Systems Inc. announced the commencement of restructuring measures designed to further streamline operations and position the Company for its next phase of strategic growth. Upon completion, Cadence expects to achieve annual operating expense savings of approximately $30 million, through a combination of workforce and other expense reductions. The Company expects to eliminate approximately 225 full-time positions, representing 5% of its global employee base. The reductions come primarily from resizing the worldwide field organization to current business levels, decreasing the level of investment in the manufacturing side of DFM (Design-for-Manufacturability) and other infrastructure areas of the business. Because of varying regulations in the jurisdictions and countries in which Cadence operates, these workforce reductions will be realized over a period of time and are expected to be completed in the second half of fiscal 2009. Cadence expects to record a restructuring charge of approximately $20 million to $25 million pre-tax, approximately $18 million of which will be recorded in the second quarter of 2009.

Level 3 Communications Inc. plans to lay off 150 employees or 2.5 percent of its work force. the company has 6,000 employees Including 2,200 in Colorado. Woburn, Mass based Genuity employs 2,300 people.

Level 3 Communications Inc. announced that it would eliminate up to 12% of its overall work force by month's end. Between 500 and 600 jobs will be eliminated in the company's communications business, which sells wholesale services to Internet service providers. Nearly 3,700 of the company's 5,000 employees worldwide work in its communications business.

Level 3 Communications is cutting about 700 jobs as the company tries to trim costs and reach profitability for the first time in its 15 years as a publicly traded company. The reductions will include about 150 positions in Colorado, where Level 3 employs 2,700 people. The company employs 10,600 worldwide.
CNS Inc. announced that it has reduced its workforce by 25%, as part of its restructuring plan.

Carnival Corp. has announced the latest phase of its cost-cutting programme. The company is closing the Florida headquarters of Cunard, the transatlantic liner arm that operates the new Queen Mary 2 and the QE2. It is expecting to save $20 million a year by cutting 330 jobs at the Fort Lauderdale base and moving the operation to the Californian base of its Princess Cruises arm. The two brands will share administration, finance and IT and the company is hoping to relocate 70 of the Cunard staff to California. It also expects up to $20 million in one-off restructuring costs this year.
FileNET Corporation plans on laying off 170-180 workers due to lower spending in the information technology sector.

Hancock Fabrics Inc. reported that sales results for the five week period, fourth quarter and the year ended February 3, 2007. For the five-week period ended February 3, 2007, the company reported that sales totaled $35.1 million, compared to $31.9 million in the four-week period of the prior year ended January 28, 2006. The increase in total sales was due to having an extra week in 2006, partially offset by having 44 fewer stores this year and a decline in comparable store sales of 4.0% in January attributable, in part, to difficult weather conditions in the Southwest and Midwest. The comparable store sales change is based on sales during the four weeks of January that were comparable between both years.
For the fourth quarter, total sales were $111.7 million versus $118.3 million a year ago, and comparable store sales were down 4.9%. For the full year, total sales were $388.3 million versus $403.2 million in 2005. Comparable store sales in 2006 declined 1.9%, including a 2.7% benefit from 42 stores that were liquidated earlier in the year in connection with store closing sale events.

The Company also announced that it has made a decision to close 30 stores, representing approximately $18 million in annualized sales.

MBIA Inc. plans to cut 48 jobs as part of a corporate reshuffling. MBIA, whose stock has plunged more than 80% in the past year, is becoming pickier about which types of risks to insure. As part of the realignment of the company, MBIA is eliminating 48 positions in its insurance business. Some of the employees laid off will be reassigned to other jobs, mainly in asset management.

Aleris International Inc. announced that it will be permanently closing its Toronto, Ontario coil coating facility. Production will be phased-out during the first quarter of 2008 and the site will be permanently closed shortly thereafter. The facility, which was acquired by Aleris when it acquired the downstream aluminum business of Corus plc in 2006, employs 64 people and supplies coated aluminum coil for building and construction, transportation, distribution and consumer durables applications. Aleris expects to take a restructuring charge of approximately $5 million to $6 million related to severance, shutdown costs and asset impairment. Production will be transferred to other Aleris facilities in North America and Aleris will continue to provide the same high quality products and services that customers expect.

Aleris International Inc. announced that it will be permanently closing its Bedford, Ohio coil coating facility. Production will be phased-out, and the site is expected to be permanently closed by the end of the second quarter of 2008. The facility employs 40 people and supplies coated aluminum coil for building and construction, transportation, distribution and consumer durables applications. The closing of this facility results in restructuring charges of approximately $4.8 million related to severance, shutdown costs and asset impairment.

Aleris International Inc. announces reduction at Roxboro Coil Coating Facility. This action will affect 45 salaried and hourly employees at the facility and will reduce potential production by approximately 25 MM pounds per year.

Multi-Color Corp. announced plans to consolidate its Las Vegas, Nevada shrink sleeve label manufacturing facility into its other existing facility operations. Multi-Color expects to close the Las Vegas facility, which employs 17 associates, by mid-January 2004.
Fair, Isaac & Co. announced that the company plans to layoff 200 employees after its acquisition of HNC Software.

Fair Isaac Corp. will cut 250 jobs during the 2009 fiscal year as part of its earlier-announced cost-cutting initiative. The company it already eliminated 80 of those positions in its fiscal first quarter.
Charles Schwab Corp. announced that it has laid off 634 employees as part of a national cutback. The company stated that it plans to reduce its work force by up to 3,400 jobs nationwide.

Steadily shrinking stock brokerage Schwab Charles Corp. disclosed plans to fire 250 more workers and close about 20 more branches by year's end. The cutbacks will result in charges of $35 million to $50 million during the second half of the year, Schwab said in its quarterly report to shareholders. The San Francisco-based company absorbed restructuring charges of $24 million during the first half of the year, when it earned $126 million.

Charles Schwab Corp. has announced plans to close down its office in Singapore. The firm opened the office about two years ago. It added that it will no longer open new accounts. Charles Schwab had opened its office in Singapore to provide greater access for Asian investors to US markets.
Warnaco Inc. is closing down its Calvin Klein Jeans Outlet Store Retail Division.
Warnaco Group Inc. is closing its last two U.S. manufacturing plants, in Georgia and California.

Warnaco Group Inc. is cutting its corporate staff 7%, reducing capital expenditures 20% and will eliminate $40 million in selling, general and administrative spending in 2009.Despite the cuts, the company plans to add 100,000 square feet of retail selling space for its Calvin Klein businesses next year, after adding about the same amount this year.
Albany International will layoff 100 employees from a Greenville, South Carolina plant due to restructuring of its dryer fabric operations.

Albany International Corp. announced the intention to discontinue dryer fabric manufacturing operations at its facility in Cowansville, Quebec, Canada, and to shut down seaming capacity at its Menasha, Wisconsin, forming fabric operation. These actions are the result of shifting paper machine clothing demand in the Americas and the continuing closure of paper and paperboard machines in North America, especially Canada.

Albany International Corp. will cost the company more than $10 million to shut down manufacturing operations in East Greenbush and Menands. The company announced in August plans to eliminate 225 jobs in the Capital Region, including 137 at a factory in East Greenbush and 88 jobs at its headquarters building on Broadway. The paper industry has been consolidating in North America, squeezing demand for the company's products. As a result, it has had to shut down factories, and the two Capital Region locations lost out to larger facilities in South Carolina, Canada and Mexico.

Albany International Corp. will close its Montgomery fabric manufacturing facility August 31, a move that will cost the area about 90 jobs. The plant makes fabric used in manufacturing paper. Employees will receive severance pay and outplacement assistance.

Albany International Corp. will close a facility in Massachusetts and consolidate its technical and manufacturing operations located there into other facilities in Europe and North America. The closure will result in a loss of 80 jobs.

Albany International Corp. will spend $2.6 million closing down a Massachusetts plant later in 2008. The plant closing will impact about 80 people. More than half the employees will be offered relocation opportunities to other Albany International sites in the U.S. and Europe. About $2 million in cash will be spent on severance packages and other job termination benefits.

Albany International Corp. announced that it will cut 17 jobs in 2009, as it outsources the manufacturing of a signature bedding product. The cuts will start next month, and the company expects to stop manufacturing its synthetic bedding insulation, called PrimaLoft, by June. The cuts, impacting salaried and hourly workers, will take the company's Menands work force down to 200 workers. The job cuts will be bargained with the union representing the affected employees, Siegel said. The Menands headquarters will still perform some manufacturing after the PrimaLoft work is phased out.

Albany International Corp. announced plans by two if its European affiliates to reduce manufacturing capacity and personnel and also announced a plant closure in the US. Shares are trading near session highs. Albany will also discontinue operations at its process belt manufacturing facility in Tumwater, Washington. The company's process belt manufacturing will now be centered at its operations in Bury, England as of August 31.

FirstFed Financial Corp. announced a reduction in the staff of the Bank by 62 persons, or approximately 10% of the Bank's current workforce. The reductions will come primarily from the Bank's single family lending and commercial lending operations as well as some reduction in support areas of the Bank. The company currently expects to record approximately $553,000 in charges for salary and benefits to be paid in accordance with the California Relocations, Terminations and Mass Layoffs Act during the quarter ending March 31, 2009. The Company also currently expects this workforce reduction to result in estimated annualized compensation cost savings of approximately $4.2 million.

BancorpSouth, Inc. will only shutter one Alabama branch as part of its efforts to consolidate 23 bank branches in six states. A company announced that just one Alabama branch will be closed. The closings will affect branches in Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Missouri, Tennessee and Texas. The planned closings and consolidations result from limited business volume and not enough growth to support the normal and routine expenses required to continue operating. The consolidation plan is part of BancorpSouth's initiative to streamline its branch banking operations and improve production. BancorpSouth expects that it will reap about $4.4 million annually in expense savings, beginning with the fourth quarter of this year. The company announced that employees at branches designated for closure will be able to work at nearby BancorpSouth locations. The closings will start in August 2011.
NS Group Inc. announced that it is closing some facilities in Kentuckey and Pennsylvania. As a result, it is laying off 380 employees.
Borland Software reduced its total headcount by approximately 125 during the third quarter to realign its cost structure and strengthen its go-to-market efforts.

Polaris Industries Inc. announced that it will immediately stop making personal watercraft, saying the market has been shrinking with little prospect for improvement.
 
 Polaris expects to record a loss on disposal of discontinued operations in the third quarter of about $24 million after taxes, or 53 cents a share, related to discontinuing its marine division. 
 
 The division employs 35 full-time workers and 70 seasonal production workers in Medina and in Spirit Lake, Iowa. Fewer than 20 employees are expected to lose their jobs.

Pioneer Natural Resources Co. announced it will close the company's Denver office and cut the number of people working out of its Trinidad field office by nearly half. The company's headquarters staff in Irving, Texas, a suburb of Dallas, would oversee the company's operations in the Raton Basin, in southern Colorado, as well as in the West Panhandle field in Texas. Pioneer said that of its 70 employees in the Denver office, about one-third will be offered relocation opportunities to Dallas. The rest will be offered severance packages and access to outplacement services. In Trinidad, the company said it will cut 100 jobs - which is nearly half of the company's existing workforce in that office. There too, Pioneer said it will offer severance packages and access to outplacement services for the outgoing Trinidad employees.
IMC Global Inc. announced the elimination of approximately 100 positions company-wide, as part of an organizational restructuring program implemented in March 2003.

IMC Global Inc. plans to lay off 74 of the nearly 425 employees at its Carlsbad potash mining operation by the end of November. The layoffs are the result of the recent sale of the company's sulfate of potash mining operation to Great Salt Lakes Minerals Corp.

Manpower Inc. would shed around 5% of its Indian workforce as part of cost-cutting measures in the background of the global economic downturn. Manpower currently employs around 21,000 people in India and 35,000 globally.

Oregon Steel Mills Inc. announces that it will temporarily shut down its Portland, Oregon steel mill and rolling facility. The heat treat facility, which provides specialty plate, will continue to operate. The shutdown at Portland is scheduled to last approximately three weeks and will begin December 24 with startup expected to be January 13, 2003. The Portland shutdown is in response to a seasonal slowdown in demand for plate products, which appears to be more severe than in prior years.

Oregon Steel Mills Inc. announced that it would permanently close its large-diameter line pipe mill located in Napa, California and sell the pipe mill assets and real estate in separate transactions. The Company has contracted with Casey Equipment Corporation to market the pipe mill equipment and with Cushman & Wakefield to market the real estate.

Respironics Inc. planed to lay off 90 workers at its Wallingford, Conn., location throughout 2011. The company said that the affected workers are in the manufacturing division and the work will shift to other Philips locations as part of a company realignment. The company's remaining staff in Wallingford will number about 90 workers in research and development, marketing, sales and customer service department.

Sotheby's Holdings Inc. announced that it is undertaking restructuring initiatives which includes laying off its workforce by 8%, or about 165 employees. The company expects savings of $20 million per year in costs.
MGM Mirage Inc. announced that it has laid off 6,400 employees following the September 11 attacks that resulted in reduced demand for casinos.

Hundreds of managers at the MGM Mirage hotel and casino will be getting pink slips. The company is laying off more than 440 management employees at both the property and corporate levels. The layoffs are in response to the both the worsening national economy and a corporate belt tightening that began last year.

Wolverine Tube Inc. announced the planned closure of its manufacturing facilities located in Jackson, Tennessee and Montreal, Quebec. The closing of the Jackson, Tennessee operations and the consolidation of the U.S. wholesale distribution facility should be completed by the end of November 2006. The operations at the Montreal, Quebec facility will be phased out with completion of the closure occurring during the first quarter of 2007. The Company announced that it will consolidate its U.S. wholesale distribution facility into the Decatur, Alabama plant location. These actions constitute the first phase of the Company's restructuring and rationalization program, as a part of its strategic planning process and in conjunction with its Path to Profitability initiatives, which focus on reducing the Company's North American footprint while continuing to serve and support its customers globally. Wholesale and industrial copper tube manufactured in the Montreal operations will be transferred to the Company's other facilities, including its operations in London, Ontario and Decatur, Alabama. The closing of the Montreal plant will allow the Company to step away from its underperforming rod and bar product segment.

Playtex Products Inc. said that its moving to a consolidated operational structure in North America and restructuring its operations in Canada, as part of a previously announced strategy and realignment plan. The company plans to close its facility in Arnprior, Ontario and restructure its U.S. Banana Boat sales force. The moves affect 85 workers. The plant in Ontario, which packages tampons and infant feeding products, is expected to be shut down completely by the first quarter of 2006.

Playtex Products Inc. plans to cut 94 jobs at its Dover manufacturing plant, the company said Wednesday. The cuts represent 9 percent of the company's 1,045-member Dover work force, which produces tampons, gloves and infant-feeding products.

Waste Management Inc. said it is cutting 700 full-time jobs and 270 contract positions as it scales down North American operations. About 60 of the full-time job losses and all of the contract losses will come at the company's Houston headquarters. The other 640 jobs will be cut in the field, the company said in a news release.

Dell Inc. plans to shift manufacturing from Limerick to Poland are gathering pace, as it ramps up production at its plant in Lodz and scales back staffing for the Irish plant. The computer giant will rehire only one-fifth of nearly 1,000 contract staff it has laid off in Limerick.
Dell will cut back at least 3,000 or more jobs over the next two quarters. These cutbacks are said to be because of continued weakness in the technology sector.
