Dell Inc. has eliminated 260 jobs at its Forsyth County plant because of the downturn in the economy.
Dell Inc. announced the plans to close Dell plant in Limerick in 2009, and up to 2,000 job losses are expected at the company's operations in Limerick.

Dell Inc. will begin winding down manufacturing in Ireland, when 450 workers leave its factory at Raheen in Limerick. The workers are the first to depart under the US firm's restructuring plan, which was announced last January and will result in 1,900 layoffs in total. The 450 workers will leave the factory, as April 30 marks the end of Dell's financial quarter. A similar number will leave at the end of July, the end of the next quarter.

Dell Inc. will lay off roughly 1,200 workers in sales and call centers in Canada and Oklahoma. No jobs in the Austin area are affected. About 300 workers in Oklahoma City will lose their jobs, and 900 employees in Edmonton, Ottawa will be cut.

Dell Inc. planned to lay off about 8,000 employees over 2008 as part of an ongoing restructuring. The layoffs, which represent 10% of the company's global work force of 88,100, come as the company struggles to regain market share after Hewlett-Packard Co. ousted it from the top spot in worldwide computer shipments last year.

EW Scripps Co. announced that it will shut down its 126-year-old daily newspaper in Cincinnati, its headquarters city. The Cincinnati Post and its Kentucky Post edition will cease publication on Dec. 31. The decision follows word that the Gannett Co. owner of the dominant daily in the market, the Cincinnati Enquirer, plans to end its 30-year business partnership with Scripps under which the Enquirer delivers and sells advertising for the Post while they maintain separate, competitive newsrooms.

EW Scripps Co. announced that it would cut 400 jobs as the weak advertising market inflicted another blow on the struggling US newspaper industry. The company announced that 'approximately 400' job cuts would yield annual savings of $15 million and its newspaper division would employ less than 4,000 people at the end of 2008. Including the latest job cuts, the company has reduced its newspaper workforce by more than 1,000 employees since 2006.The company announced that it was suspending its quarterly dividend.

II-VI Inc. announced that it laid off around 70 local employees after the company encountered falling demand for its products that are geared to non-military markets. The company based in Clinton, Butler County, has cut around 10% of its U.S. workforce, which was around 1,300 employees before. The layoffs were completed through the end of December 2008, and overtime and other expenses also have been reduced. The overseas workforce, formerly around 1,200 people, also was trimmed. The company said the recent job cuts leave about 500 at the Clinton campus. About 40 were laid off at a Tampa facility.
American Power Conversion Corporation announced that it will lay off approximately 700 employees, representing 10% of its global workforce.

American Power Conversion Corp. announced that it laid off about 66 Rhode Island workers. In addition to the Rhode Island layoffs, the company unveiled plans at the end of June to cut 200 to 250 positions in Ireland. The company also announced that an interim CEO, Rob Johnson, formerly an APC vice president, has been appointed by the board of directors and will be paid $500,000 a year.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. laid off more than 600 people in New Mexico and Arizona. In the local region, the layoffs totaled 36 from Tyrone, 59 from Safford and the biggest hit was Morenci with 402. The latest layoffs came on the heels of 95 last week from Chino Mines.

Freeport-McMoRan Copper & Gold Inc. operations at PT Freeport Indonesia (PT-FI) continues to seek a mutually acceptable resolution to the ongoing labor strike which commenced on September 15, 2011. The company is following the established Indonesian legal process, including pursuit of a resolution through a labor court process, while continuing to seek to negotiate with the union in good faith.PT-FI is operating the Grasberg open pit mine and the DOZ underground mine at reduced rates using non-striking employees and contractors. Since October 22, 2011, milling operations have been temporarily suspended pending repairs to concentrate pipelines damaged as a result of civil unrest which has occurred during the course of the strike. The company has initiated repairs to the damaged pipelines but has not been able to gain full access to the affected areas of the pipelines because of road blockages by striking workers. PT-FI is working with local authorities to restore access to the road and the pipelines so that repairs can be completed and milling operations restarted.For the fourth quarter of 2011, the company estimated sales of 915 million pounds of copper and 305,000 ounces of gold included 185 million pounds of copper and 280,000 ounces of gold from PT-FI (average daily production from PT-FI of 2 million pounds of copper and 3,000 ounces of gold). These estimates were based on PT-FI achieving fourth quarter mill throughput averaging approximately 175,000 tonnes per day (approximately 75% of normal rates). The quarter-to-date average through October 31, 2011, including the currently on-going suspension of milling and concentrate delivery operations since October 22, 2011, has been approximately 120,000 tonnes per day.
Novellus Systems Inc. has laid off an undisclosed number of employees citing the economic slump. The company had 3,500 employees worldwide before the cuts.

Novellus Systems Inc. announced that its financial results for the fourth fiscal quarter ending December 31, 2008 are expected to be below the low end of the guidance ranges for bookings, shipments, revenues, and earnings per share. The company expects an incremental reduction of at least 10% in bookings, shipments and revenue for the fourth quarter, which is expected to result in a net loss per share of at least $0.15 before charges related to restructuring and/or goodwill impairment.The company reported it will expand its cost cutting and restructuring plans. This includes approximately a 10% reduction in its global workforce through a combination of attrition and layoffs which will generally be concluded by January 31, 2009. The company expects to incur approximately $12 million in related restructuring and asset impairment charges in the fourth quarter of 2008. As previously announced the company is also currently evaluating the $238 million of goodwill on the balance sheet for potential impairment which may result in additional non-cash charges.

Office Depot Inc. plans to cut 900 jobs as it consolidates operations at eight call centers and offices in six states, including Connecticut. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Office Depot -said three of the facilities will close. The cuts were estimated to generate $15 million in annual savings. Some operations will move to call centers located in Boca Raton and Norcross, Ga., the company said, affecting offices in California, Connecticut, Georgia, Kansas, Ohio and Texas.

Office Depot Inc. made a series of internal announcements on November 12, 2004, of its plans to rationalize staffing in several areas of the business, and to exit certain facilities that have become redundant. The Company will reduce staffing in its North American Retail Division, affecting the equivalent of approximately 550 full-time retail stores employees, or approximately 2% of the segments employees. The Company will reduce staffing at its Delray Beach, Florida, corporate headquarters, affecting a total of approximately 97 exempt and non-exempt employees. The Company will reduce staffing at its facility in Torrance, California over the next several months. This will result in job eliminations for approximately 24 employees.

Office Depot Inc. announced that it is firing 819 employees in the second round of job cuts since interim Chief Executive Officer Neil Austrian took over last month. The company will let go workers at its stores, headquarters and other facilities.

Office Depot Inc. will eliminate approximately 100 call center jobs in Boca Raton. Call center workers can apply for 100 jobs being created at Office Depot's Delray Beach headquarters. Another 100 new sales jobs are in the pipeline. Revamping call center operations, though, has been on the company's radar for two years, well before cost-cutting CEO Steve Odland came on board. The 100 call center jobs will be phased out by summer.

Office Depot Inc. announced it plans to close 112 underperforming retail stores in North America over the next three months, reducing the North American store base to 1,163. The stores to be closed are located in various geographic regions, including 45 in the Central U.S., 40 in the Northeast and Canada, 19 in the West and eight in the South. Additionally, 14 stores will be closed through 2009 as their leases expire or other lease arrangements are finalized. New store openings for 2009 now have been reduced to approximately 20, down from the previous estimate of 40 stores. This will facilitate a reduction in total company capital spending in 2009 to less than $200 million, significantly lower than projected depreciation and amortization of $275 million. Office Depot also plans to close six of its 33 distribution facilities in North America. This is consistent with the company's long term plan to reduce the total number of facilities and combine its separate supply chain systems. The company anticipates taking charges in the fourth quarter 2008 and in 2009 for these actions totaling in a range from $270 million to $300 million.

Office Depot Inc. plans to close all of its stores in Japan by the end of 2009 because of intense price competition. Office Depot's subsidiary in Japan has so far closed eight stores this year, with the other 20 expected to close by the end of 2009. The stated that the closures will cost about $13 million.

Office Depot, Inc. announced that more than 100 people will lose their jobs in February 2010 when the company closes its shipping facility in Mountaintop. The company filed a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act notice with local and state officials stating its intention to shutter the cross dock at 7 Elmwood Road. The 108 employees will be let go starting February 15, 2010. The Mountaintop facility will close by February 26, 2010 when it will relocate outside Harrisburg. The company will provide relocation assistance for eligible employees and severance and outplacement services to those unable to find a position within the company.

Office Depot, Inc. is laying off 132 people in May 2010 when it closes a distribution center in Odenton. The company is consolidating its supply chain system in the Northeast at a new 600,000 square-foot facility in Newvilla, Pa.

Office Depot Inc. announced that the company has reportedly laid off an undisclosed number of people at its headquarters in Boca Raton. The layoffs are part of the company's three-year restructuring plan. A Workers Adjustment and Retraining Notice was not filed, which would have given employees and the state formal 60 days notice of their termination.

Office Depot plans to close a total of 75 stores in the year 2017. Three hundred Office Depot stores are expected to close in 2018 as part of the company's strategy to decrease costs. That's in addition to the 400 stores the company announced it would close in mid-2014.
Phoenix Technologies Ltd. has laid off about 150 employees over time.
Phoenix Technologies Ltd. in an effort to further reduce expenses, the company has reduced its workforce by approximately 15% in first quarter of fiscal 2007.
Arch Coal Inc. announced plans to eliminate an undisclosed number of employees in order to cut costs.
Arch Coal Inc. has laid off 85 employees at its Cumberland River Coal operations in Letcher County, KY, idling the Parson No. 1 mine and reducing production at the Blue Ridge surface mine.

Arch Coal Inc. announced on June 21, 2012 it would lay off about 750 workers in the Kentucky, Virginia and West Virginia coalfields. The bulk of the cuts by Arch Coal Inc., almost 600, are in Kentucky. The disappearance of high-paying mining work heightened anxiety in hardscrabble Kentucky towns where officials worried declining demand for coal would result in leaner budgets and more people on unemployment rolls. The layoffs come amid forecasts that the share of U.S. electricity coming from coal will fall below 40% for the year the lowest level since the government began collecting data in 1949. Four years ago, it was 50%. By the end of this decade, it is likely to be near 30%. The job losses come as utilities increasingly switch from coal to natural gas, which has become cheaper as supplies grow. Natural gas' advantages over coal include producing fewer emissions of toxic chemicals and gases that contribute to climate change. From Kentucky courthouses to Congress, officials blamed tougher environmental rules for coal's woes and the resulting job losses.

Arch Coal Inc. reported that it will scale back operations at two coal mining complexes in Kentucky and Virginia, trimming the work force by more than 100. The company also reported that the cutbacks will affect the Cumberland River and Hazard mining complexes.
Concord Camera Corp. reported that it would cut 1,700 jobs, nearly half its work force and outsource camera design and development.

Concord Camera Corp. announced that a decision was made to implement a restructuring plan which involves significantly reducing its reliance on internally designed and manufactured digital cameras and increasing the design and co-development of digital cameras with contract manufacturers so as to continue to provide competitive products to the retail market. The Company's reliance on internally designed and manufactured digital cameras is expected to be significantly reduced by the end of the third quarter of Fiscal 2005. The Company believes that it will be more cost-effective and less capital intensive to increase its reliance on the design and co-development of digital cameras with contract manufacturers, due, in part, to the overcapacity in world-wide digital camera manufacturing.
 
 
 
 Due to the restructuring plan and other cost-reduction initiatives, approximately 1,700 positions will be eliminated throughout the world by the end of the third quarter of Fiscal 2005. The majority of these positions are expected to be eliminated in the Company's PRC manufacturing facilities and Hong Kong operations.

Lyondell Chemical Company announced that it will be shutting down its aliphatic diisocyanates (ADI) manufacturing units and it will be restructuring of its toluene diisocyanates (TDI) business. This will result in the reduction of 20% of its workforce.

Chemical Financial Corporation announced the resignation of Leonardo Amat, Chief Operating Officer-Business Operations, effective September 30, 2017.The company also announced approximately 7% net reduction in total employees, as well as certain branch consolidations.
Netegrity has laid off 90 employees, representing approximately 20 percent of its worldwide workforce, as part of its restructuring efforts.

Valero Energy Corp. has decided to shut its 325,000-barrel-a-day refinery in Port Arthur, 99 miles east of Houston. And Valero is concluding a shutdown of its 245,000-barrel-a-day plant in Texas City.

Valero Energy Corp. officials told plant workers in San Nicolas, Aruba that the company is halting production at the refinery indefinitely. The company originally shut down the refinery in July in the wake of poor economic conditions that made the refinery unprofitable to run. Executives hoped a temporary furlough of plant workers and a halt in production would allow the company to cut expenses until the petroleum industry improved. However, with margins still not improving over the past month, this prompted Valero's management to make a case for closing the refinery indefinitely. The refinery's contract workers at the plant will be laid off within the next two to three weeks. The company has not yet made a decision regarding the future of the 780 company employees at the refinery. The company is actively studying ways to keep the refinery open long-term, including a possible sale of the 235,000 barrel-per-day plant. However, those decisions will be made at a later date and much of that decision-making will depend upon future economic conditions.

Valero Energy Corp. plans to shut some of its East Coast and Caribbean refining operations and cut up to 950 jobs. The move, aimed at trimming 'underperforming' operations to cope with tight refining margins, will hit Valero's Delaware City refinery, where it will shut the plant's coker and gasifier units and cut a combined 250 staff and contract positions. The refinery saw extended downtime in the second quarter. The company said it is also letting 700 contract workers go this month at its Aruba refinery following its shutdown in July. Both facilities have been hurt by the shrinking price differential between typically cheaper heavy grades of crude oil and pricier light grades.
IDEX Corporation has announced that the company reduced its work force by 15 percent as part of its restructuring program in order to cut costs.

IDEX Corp. announced consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2008. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $24,806,000 or $0.31 diluted earnings per share on the net sales of $355,306,000 compared to net income of $38,436,000 or $0.47 diluted earnings per share on the net sales of $345,997,000 for the same period last year. Income from continuing operations of $25 million decreased 35% versus the fourth quarter of the previous year. Diluted earnings per share from continuing operations of 31 cents declined 16 cents, or 34%, from the fourth quarter of the previous year. For the year, the company reported net income of $131,314,000 or $1.60 diluted earnings per share on the net sales of $1,489,471,000 compared to net income of $155,145,000 or $1.89 diluted earnings per share on the net sales of $1,358,631,000 for the same period last year. Income from continuing operations was $131 million, or 16% lower than the prior year.The company expects organic revenue to decline at least 10% in the first quarter of 2009, with diluted EPS in the range of 32 to 38 cents. Given the current economic conditions, full year 2009 organic revenue is projected to decline 6 to 10%. The resulting diluted EPS is expected to range from $1.50 to $1.80.As previously announced, the company has commenced the closure of manufacturing operations in the Dispensing segment's Milan, Italy facility as well as an additional facility consolidation within the Fluid & Metering Technologies segment. IDEX has essentially completed Company-wide restructuring plans which include management and administrative workforce reductions of over 375 employees.

Enterasys Networks Inc. plans to lay off 300 employees at all levels of the computer networking company. Company officials said the layoffs, which will account for about 30% of the company's employees, are aimed at cutting expenses by as much as $13 million per quarter.

TCF Financial Corp. announced its decision to close its branch in the TCF Tower in downtown Minneapolis is not related to its ongoing search for office space to house more than 1,000 TCF employees now located in the same complex. The closure, along with TCF's plans to shed 37 branches in the Chicago area, was prompted by TCF's ongoing review of its branch portfolio and growth initiatives like online and mobile services.

TCF Financial Corp. said that it's closing eight bank branches in Minnesota by the end of March 2014. All are located at Cub supermarkets outside the core metro area, and most are near other TCF locations. The Minnesota branches being shuttered are in Hastings, Forest Lake, Northfield, Rogers, Chanhassen, Lakeville South, Elk River and west Mankato.

TCF Financial announced that it will close 33 branches inside Jewel-Osco stores in the Chicago area. The company did not identify the location of specific branches, which are set to close by May. The company will have a total of 148 branches in the Chicago area after the closings, including 85 inside Jewel-Osco stores. In the affected Jewel-Osco locations, the company will replace offices with enhanced ATMs. The company also plans to enhance other retail branches in the Chicago area, such as renovating in-store layouts. The company will also add ATMs in the parking lots of some Jewel-Osco stores.

TCF Financial Corporation announced that following the branch closures slated for the first half of 2016, TCF Bank will have 20% fewer branches than the 434 branches it had at the end of 2011. TCF ended 2015 with 375 branches in Minnesota, Wisconsin, South Dakota, Illinois, Michigan, Colorado, Arizona and Indiana. Most of the cost savings from branch closures will go toward digital banking. TCF Bank will have about 145 in-store branches after the closures.

TCF Financial Corp. announced that it will close 10 branches at Cub Foods stores in the Minneapolis-St. Paul market this spring, citing cost savings and a trend by bank customers away from physical visits.

TCF Bank has announced that its planned branch closure at Sioux Falls will affect 145 staff members. The layoffs are to start on November 9 and continue until March 31 next year. The bulk of the layoffs will include 54 call centre representatives and 43 operations specialists. The bank said that it would provide opportunities for some employees to relocate or work remotely.

Signet Jewelers Limited announced that the company plans to close more than 200 stores in Fiscal 2019.In fiscal 2019, the company plans to open 35-40 stores for a net selling square footage decline of approximately 4.0% to 5.0%.
Signet Jewelers Limited announced that the company plans to close more than 200 stores in Fiscal 2019 and open 35 - 40 stores for a net selling square footage decline of approximately 4.0% to 5.0%.

Staples Inc. has cut 326 jobs this week, including 115 at its headquarters here, but says it still plans to hire 1,200 people this year for 120 new stores. Staples is also planning to close 30 stores but still plans to open 120 others worldwide this year.
Staples Inc. announced it has begun laying off employees at its acquired Corporate Express unit as it combines the two companies' operations.
Staples Inc. is closing its distribution and warehouse building in Canton, Ga., eliminating 89 jobs. Staples is shutting down its operations at 168 Etowah Industrial Court by June 26.

Staples, Inc. will integrate its retail and online offering, increase investment in its online businesses, reorganize its operations, implement leadership changes, initiate a multi-year cost savings plan, and restructure its International Operations. This strategy builds on Staples' unique strengths, including its world-class supply chain capabilities, extensive retail store network, strong relationships with business customers of all sizes, and online presence. To achieve its vision, Staples is increasing investment in online and mobile capabilities to provide business customers with a differentiated multi-channel shopping experience. Building on its success in categories like facilities and breakroom supplies, copy and print, and technology products, Staples is significantly expanding its assortment beyond office supplies to better serve the needs of business customers. To support growth and better address the changing needs of its customers, the company announced the combination of its U.S. Retail and Staples.com businesses under the leadership of Demos Parneros. Joe Doody will continue to lead Staples' North American Contract and Quill.com businesses, and will assume leadership of supply chain and customer service operations in North America. The company plans to reduce retail square footage in North America by approximately 15% by the end of fiscal year 2015. As part of this plan, Staples is accelerating the closure of approximately 15 U.S. stores which will result in a pre-tax cash charge of approximately $35 million during the fourth quarter of 2012. Staples now expects a total of approximately 30 net store closures and 30 store downsizings and relocations in North America during fiscal year 2012. Staples announced key restructuring activities as part of an ongoing process to reduce the complexity and improve the profitability of its European operations. Staples plans to close 45 stores and several sub-scale delivery businesses in Europe by the end of fiscal year 2012, and also announced a leadership ch
Staples, Inc. reported that for the full year 2013 it remains on track to close 40 stores, and downsize and relocate about 45 [ph] of new 12,000 square-foot stores by the end of 2013.
Staples slashed 1,400 jobs in third quarter, including 15% of its vice presidents and directors.

Staples notified 68 workers at a Pembroke Park delivery facility that their positions would be eliminated after the location closes. The employees are expected to stay with the company until Nov. 17, 2014, but some will volunteer to stay beyond the closure date to close down the store. The deadline for them to leave the company is officially Dec. 19, 2014. Most of the positions being eliminated are delivery service-related, with two service delivery administrators and two delivery managers losing their jobs and 61 delivery shift workers being laid off. The location's senior human resources generalist is also being laid off. Staples said it plans to shut down as many as 225 stores by the end of 2015, which would save the company $500 million annually.

Staples Inc. is eliminating 60 jobs in Phoenix. The office superstore chain is cutting the jobs at a delivery operations center in Phoenix. The company has 23 stores in the Phoenix metro area. The company reported the layoffs to the state of Arizona under the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act.
Staples, Inc. plans to close approximately 50 stores in North America in 2016.
Staples, Inc. announced plans to close approximately 70 stores in North America in 2017.

A long-planned closure of Allergan Inc.'s Fremont collagen manufacturing facility is slated to be complete by Oct. 10, resulting in a loss of 59 mostly manufacturing jobs. It is part of the company's efforts to create a much more efficient and cost effective network of plants. The plan to close the Fremont facility came about because the company expects reduced future market demand for human and bovine collagen products.
Cirrus Logic has announced that the company is reducing its workforce by 155 employees, about 13 percent of the workforce, as a part of its cost reduction efforts.
Lattice Semiconductor Corp. is cutting another 30 jobs and selling off one of its subsidiaries.

Applebee's International Inc. franchisee in Memphis has shuttered its 12 Applebee's Neighborhood Grill & Bar restaurants and lost its franchise rights. Applebee's International said that all of the restaurants owned by the franchisee, Delta Bluff LLC, have closed but that Applebee's plans to re-enter the market. Applebee's International itself would open new stores in the area or whether new ones would be reopened by another franchisee. Applebee's has publicly said it plans to increase the number of Applebee's owned by the company.

Applebee's International Inc. plans to close its restaurant in the Myles Standish Plaza off Samoset Street in Plymouth as part of a corporate effort to boost profits. The company in March announced it was closing 24 corporate-owned restaurants, including five in Massachusetts. The Plymouth closing will bring that number to six. The company already decided to close restaurants in Braintree, the Prudential Center in Boston, Dedham, Westborough and Weymouth. Plymouth's closure leaves Massachusetts with 34 Applebee's restaurants. Only corporate-owned restaurants are being closed. Of the 1,940 restaurants in the Applebee's chain that were open before the recent round of closures, nearly 530 were corporate-owned and the rest are owned and run by franchisees. The standard Applebee's restaurant employs 60 to 70 full-time and part-time workers, although the Braintree location was larger than the typical Applebee's restaurant. The company is transferring about 80% of the affected restaurant managers to other corporate-owned locations and is offering some jobs to displaced hourly workers. The closings are part of a broader cost-cutting effort for the company.
Applebee's International Inc. announced that the company expects jobs will be cut as IHOP Corp. sells the majority of Applebee's 508 company owned restaurants.

Applebee's International, Inc. at Tuscany Village has closed its doors. The casual dining restaurant, which opened on McKenzie Avenue near Shelbourne Street in the summer of 2009, was to shutter for good Friday night after the last customer left. All three locations for the restaurant in B.C.-Victoria, Port Coquitlam and Courtenay-are closing. In a statement, the company informed that it came down to finances. Ongoing efforts to solve financial problems confronting Island Apple, the Applebee's franchisee in British Columbia, have proven unsuccessful and the company's franchise agreement has been terminated. Applebee's head office informed that it was not ruling out a return to the B.C. market. It gave no indication of how many staff is affected by the closings. Applebee's and its other six Canadian franchisees remain committed to the country, where 20 restaurants continue to operate in 17 cities. The company informed that it look forward to returning to British Columbia in the future.

BankUnited Financial Corporation filed a notice with the state on December 12, 2008 that it would lay off 10 employees. The employees, who work at 7765 N.W. 148th St., in Miami Lakes, are to be let go by Feb. 9, 2009.
Digi International Inc. announced that it has laid off 61 employees, representing 13% of its workforce. The layoffs are a proactive measure due to the current market conditions.
Digi International Inc. announced that it has eliminated 34 positions from its NetSilicon division.

On October 7, 2020, the Board of Directors of Digi International Inc. approved a reorganization of Digis IoT Products and Services business segment. The plan aligns the business segments organization around product lines. Under the plan, the Company expects to eliminate approximately 20 employment positions during the current fiscal quarter ending December 31, 2020. In connection with the plan, company expect to incur total restructuring charges in the range of $750,000-$850,000 relating to cash severance expenses during the quarter ending December 31, 2020.

Since 1998, Exabyte Corporation has taken several steps Including shaving nearly 900 jobs and merging with a crosstown rival, to try to regain market share and return to profitability. But the Boulder data storage company's 2002 results released show it's still languishing in the red. And once again, the 18-year-old firm plans to cut more workers and prioritize products, all in the hopes of making a profit.
Exabyte Corp. has announced that it has laid off 42 employees at its headquarters in Boulder, Colorado as part of a cost cutting initiative to bring itself back to profitability.

Community Bank System Inc.'s wealth management subsidiary has a new office now open in the North Country. The new office opened in August 3 in Plattsburgh. It offers investments, insurance and trust planning and management. The office has three employees with another three to five expected before the end of the year. More than 300 Oneida employees will keep their jobs and Community will employ more than 600 people in Central New York once the acquisition closes. The Oneida deal will give Community 12 new locations in Oneida and Madison counties and the fourth large deposit market share in the Syracuse metro area.Community is in the midst of acquiring Oneida Financial Corp., parent company of Oneida Savings Bank. The $142 million deal should close in October, according to Community. The acquisition has been delayed in part by a complaint over fair lending issues from a New York City-based advocacy group. The deal will lead to some layoffs. More than 60 jobs at Oneida will be cut.

First Indiana Corp. announced that it plans to eliminate 70 jobs and consolidate all its back-office operations into one department; the moves will result in a $1.1 million charge to third-quarter earnings. The company plans to lay off 30 employees and not fill 40 positions that are vacant or will become so soon because of retirements. Most of the charge will come through $900,000 of severance payments and $250,000 of contract termination expenses.
Fremont General Corporation confirmed it intends to jettison about 237 jobs in Concord. The affected employees for the company's subprime residential real estate operations.

Banknorth Group Inc. has announced that it plans to layoff an unspecified number of employees following its acquisition of American Financial Holdings Inc. as a part of the company's integration plan.
The Solectron Corp. announced that it is laying off the operation's entire workforce of 306 members.

Carolina Circuits of Greenville cut 140 employees because of a slowdown in the telecommunications industry. The layoffs are effective immediately. The company, which makes printed electronic circuit boards, said dwindling demand for its products and competition from foreign suppliers led to the layoffs. The job cuts affect about 35 percent of the company's employees. Eighty other employees were cut in August. After the layoffs, Carolina Circuits now has about 250 employees at its Greenville facility.

Shares of Solectron Corp., announcing mixed second-quarter results and plans to cut 12,000 jobs and consolidate facilities. Solectron has been struggling to get its costs in line with demand for its services. Over the past nine quarters, it has reduced its work force by 40,000. The company expects to have about 62,000 employees at the end of the latest job cuts. Solectron said it will reduce its manufacturing space by 3 million square feet, to 13 million square feet.

Solectron Corp. announced that it will close its manufacturing facility in Johor in May, 2005. The move will affect some 750 people on the company's payroll, and retrenchment benefits of RM5 million to RM6 million are expected to be paid out.

Solectron Corp. announced that Ottawa will lose close to 400 full-time and temporary positions by early 2007 as its manufacturing facility in Kanata. The closure of the Kanata manufacturing facility will eliminate 247 permanent positions and 147 temporary positions. The closure will be carried out between now and roughly the end of February, 2007. The company said it would reduce its workforce by approximately 1,400 employees from its global workforce of 53,000.
Solectron Corp. announced that it will lay off between 1,300 and 1,500 employees as part of a previously announced restructuring plan.

Sovereign Bancorp Inc. will cut 800 jobs, or about 7% of its work force, in a cost-cutting effort. The job cuts, to occur throughout 2007, will mainly be through attrition. Job cuts will be mostly in back office and corporate staff functions, and laid off workers will receive severance packages, according to Sovereign. Sovereign also will consolidate business, exit business lines performing below expectations and renegotiate contracts. The company expects the cost-cutting efforts to result in $100 million of savings, half of which is expected to come from the job cuts.

Sovereign Bancorp Inc. plans to close 11 Massachusetts branches this year as part of a $100 million cost-saving plan that the Philadelphia-based bank announced in December. The branches to close this spring and summer are locations in Quincy, Plymouth, Hanson, Brockton, and Cohasset south of Boston, along with branches in Newton, Marblehead, Amesbury and Haverhill. Sovereign also will close former Compass Bank branches in Harwich and Barnstable on Cape Cod.

Sovereign Bancorp Inc. announced that it is taking a $1.4 billion charge for goodwill impairments for the fourth quarter of 2007. The company also reported that it is shuttering its auto-lending business in the Southeast and Southwest.

Sovereign Bancorp Inc. plans to eliminate 830 full-time jobs.The company swung to a net loss of USD 817.3 million in the first-quarter ended March 31, 2009, from a profit of USD 100.1 million in the first quarter of 2008.

General Motors Financial Company, Inc. closed on Mexico, Chile and Colombia in Latin America, and the company closed on all of the European operations, including the U.K., Germany, Italy, Sweden, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, the Netherlands, Greece, Spain, France and Portugal. Brazil and China have yet to close. The company expects Brazil to close sometime later in 2013 and China, perhaps in the first part of 2014.

Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. is set to complete its purchase of Community Banks Inc. next month, triggering a small impact on branches but a larger impact on jobs. Only two of the combined companies' 39 branches here will close when the $860 million deal is completed on Nov. 16. They are a Susquehanna branch at 128 Toddy Drive, East Earl, near Shady Maple, and Community's Blue Ball division branch at 90 Willow Valley Lakes Drive in Willow Street. The local closings are among the 10 of 244 offices throughout the combined Susquehanna and Community branch networks to be shut, due to overlapping locations. The effect on jobs is harder to gauge. About 80 jobs here, mostly in the Community/Blue Ball operations center along Route 23, and about 350 jobs overall will be eliminated when the deal is completed.

United Fire & Casualty Co. is closing its 81-employee regional office in New Orleans and will leave a claims office that will employ up to 40, the company says. the company will lay off 18 support staff workers and offer transfers to its Galveston office to 23 underwriters. The consolidation will be complete by June 30.

First Commonwealth Financial Corp. expects to complete its $106 million purchase of DCB Financial Corp. on April 3. The company will add nine branches and increase First Commonwealth's presence in the Columbus region.The company plans to cut 58 jobs, including C-level posts, due to redundancies at DCB in two swaths. That's more than a third of DCB's staff. The first round is April 3-14 and the second between May 30 and June 2.

Twitter announced that it is cutting 8% of its workforce, or 336 jobs, in a restructuring of the troubled messaging platform under newly returned chief executive Jack Dorsey. The restructuring is part of an overall plan to organise around the company's top product priorities and drive efficiencies throughout the company. The company said the layoffs will result in USD 10 million (AUD 13.59 million) to USD 20 million in severance costs, and total restructuring expenses are estimated at USD 5 million to USD 15 million. The overall costs may be lower than severance due to recovery of unvested stock awards.

Advantica Restaurant Group announced that it has closed 61 stores and laid off approximately 90 out-of-restaurant support staff positions. The company also plans to close another 22 stores as a part of its cost cutting plan.

Denny's Corporation's restaurant that has stood near the Moline-East Moline border for decades has closed. The national chain confirmed that the store at 5304 Avenue of the Cities shut its doors, citing in part the weakened economy as a reason. The closed restaurant employed 35 workers, who will be offered positions at the other two locations. The company regularly evaluates each of restaurants and decided to close this unit in order to focus efforts on other nearby locations.
G-III Apparel Group Ltd. has announced that it has decided to close down its factory in Indonesia due to rising costs and the political and economic instability in the country.

PNC Financial Services Group Inc. expects to eliminate 325 to 425 positions at newly acquired Sterling Financial Corp. in 2008 summer. PNC announced the eliminated posts would be back-office and administrative positions. The number will be determined by attrition, retirements and potential redeployment.
Time Inc. is closing high-tech magazine Business 2.0, abandoning efforts to salvage a publication that survived the dot-com bust only to be doomed by the rise of Internet advertising.

Time Inc. announced that it will shut down Southern Accents magazine to close this year. The 32-year-old magazine, with a circulation of 400,000, was published six times a year. It focused on luxurious homes, entertaining, travel, fine arts and antiques. It was unclear how many of the magazine's 29 staff members would lose jobs because of the closing.

The New York Post reported that Time Inc. will lay off 540 employees, while The New York Times said the company was looking to cut $100 million in costs. It is only the latest in a series of cutbacks among the major U.S. magazine publishers. The recession has put a huge dent in advertising budgets, and the toll of closings and layoffs continued to rise this month.

Time Inc. is laying off 110 workers across all areas of company, or 1.5% of its workforce, and creating new teams to focus on specific advertising categories as it grapples with continued declines in print advertising.

The Scotts Miracle-Gro Co. announced that it has laid off more than 15% of its managers. This will result in a cash restructuring charge of approximately $5 million and will generate annualized savings of about $7.5 million.

A year after winning a major tax cut from the Legislature, Harrah's Entertainment Inc.'s New Orleans Casino has reduced its work force and payroll by 8 percent, but is still within its minimum employment obligation. For the two-week period ending March 28, the casino employed an operating work force of 2,460, which is 92 percent of the baseline established by state police.
Harrah's Entertainment Inc. announced that it has eliminated some 200 jobs in its Las Vegas corporate office.

SLM Corp. announced that it agrees to shut down its student call-center services at 19 colleges and stop paying for trips taken by university officials in settlement of New York state investigation into allegedly deceptive financial-aid practices (M).
Cisco Systems Inc. has laid off 5,300 employees following the economic downturn.

Cisco Systems Inc. announced that it has winding down an Australian technology company that it bought three years ago for $567 million at the peak of enthusiasm for the local high-tech industry. Cisco announced that the decision will affect a significant number of the 50 staff working at the old Radiata operation in Sydney's North Ryde.

Cisco Systems Inc. has filed a warn letter with the Texas Workforce Commission, advising the agency of 129 staff reductions at the company's Richardson facility on 2200 E. President George Bush Turnpike. Cisco Systems announced the staff reductions are part of the company's decision to cease operations within its Broadband Telephony Services unit at the facility. Staff reductions began on Oct. 8, and will run through Dec. 8, 2008.

Cisco Systems, Inc. notified about 170 employees in Research Triangle Park they will be laid off as part of the computer networking company's strategy to reduce global operating expenses by $1 billion next year. Additionally, the company said 2,100 employees agreed to take early retirements and 1,200 contractors are slated for elimination. Most of the affected workers will leave in the first quarter of 2012, suggesting that the head count at Cisco's RTP complex could go down by several hundred from a peak of 4,900 this summer.

Cisco Systems, Inc. is set to fire 300 employees in Israel as part of its streamlining of worldwide operations. Cisco has 1,800 employees in Israel after the acquisitions of NDS and Jungo in the past few years. the company will reportedly announce that it is laying off 20% of its global workforce. The layoffs are expected to begin in early October. Cisco already implemented a relatively small wave of layoffs at the end of 2013 when only dozens of employees were fired as part of a global cut of 5%. The company said it plans to slash some 6,000 jobs, or 8% of its global workforce in the coming year. The announcement came as Cisco announced a modest dip in quarterly profits at $2.2 billion in the quarter to the end of July. Cisco is expected to take charges up to $700 million for the restructuring, starting in its new fiscal year that began this month.

Cisco Systems Inc. confirmed that the company plans to lay off about 6,000 employees companywide, or about 8% of its workforce. The company expects to record charges of about $700 million to cover the restructuring costs. Those areas were identified as Data Center, Software, Security and Cloud, the Journal reported.

Cisco has confirmed 225 of its 6,000 reported global layoffs hit its Research Triangle Park campus. The number represents nearly 4% of company's 5,500 headcount in RTP. The company is in the process of expanding and adding 550 jobs to RTP - a plan that continues, in spite of layoffs.

Cisco Systems announced that it plans to eliminate several of its senior executive positions in China, as sales decline due to government fears about the security of foreign networking equipment. Several senior executives in China have been asked to step down, including Hahn Tu, Cisco China president, and Fredy Cheung, VP in Greater China. Cisco Greater China Chairman Owen Chan will maintain his position.

Cisco Systems Inc. is laying off 1,100 more workers, deepening job losses at the internet gear maker battling declining revenue. The new round of layoffs comes on top of the 5,500 jobs Cisco announced it was cutting in August. That amounted to about 7% of its workforce at the time.

Cisco confirmed that its restructuring plan announced in August 2016 will lead to the closure of CVTF (Cisco Video Technologies France), a subsidiary which specialises in video software. The closure puts around 200 jobs at risk in the Paris region. Cisco, which plans to scale back its video activities globally, acquired video software and content security provider NDS Group for approximately USD 5 billion in 2012, but has recently been forced to rethink its strategy following major changes in the industry.

The Reader's Digest Association Inc. New Choices magazine will cease publication after the May/June issue. The magazine was the recipient of numerous awards for editorial excellence but had struggled financially. Like many other small lifestyle publications, it suffered the effects of 9/11 and the economy on advertising and the demise of the stamp-sheet marketing channel for acquiring new subscribers. The bottom line was further eroded by the effects of recent postal increases.
Readers Digest Assn Inc. has announced that it is reducing approximately 200 jobs in Europe, Asia, Latin America and in U.S. based support functions.

NTN Communications Inc. announced that it has eliminated several management positions in an effort to lower its operating costs and consolidate operations through fewer managers. The positions that have been eliminated include the president of the NTN Hospitality Technologies division, the vice president of operations for the NTN Hospitality Network, and the director of information technology. The company announced the responsibilities for these positions have been assumed by other members of the NTN and Buzztime management teams.

The company also announced that John Boozer has been promoted to senior vice president of North American Sales. He will report directly to the CEO in his new role.
BE Aerospace Inc. has cut 200 jobs at its Litchfield plant, which it plans to shutdown in a few months.

BE Aerospace Inc. is shutting down its Dafen galley manufacturing facility due to poor performance. By mid-2003, the company expects to achieve its goal of closing five factories and eliminating about 1,400 positions.
Cone Mills Corp. announced that it has laid off 1,000 employees and consolidated some operations, as a part of its restructuring plan in response to the weak economy.

Ashworth Inc. announced that Gary I. Schneiderman resigned as president and he has been replaced by Edward J. Fadel, 51, who was most recently vice president of merchandising at Greg Norman/Reebok. He worked at Ashworth between 2001 and 2004, most recently as senior vice president of merchandising and design. Peter E. Holmberg, executive vice president of Green Grass sales and merchandising, also left the company to return to his home in Seattle.The company announced that it will cut 16 positions in a cost-saving move.

The Immune Response Corp.'s longtime chief executive resigned, and the company cut its local work force by more than half in an effort to conserve cash while pursuing approval for its controversial AIDS therapy. Dennis Carlo, Immune Response's chief executive since 1994 and a co-founder of the company with the late polio vaccine pioneer Jonas Salk, resigned. The company is searching for a new CEO. Immune Response will lay off 28 of 42 employees at its Carlsbad headquarters. The company estimates the reductions will save $7.2 million annually.

Merit Medical Systems, Inc. announced that it is eliminating 134 jobs at its Malvern manufacturing plant, which it is closing in 2020 as part of a previously announced consolidation plan. The closing of the Malvern plant will occur in four phases, according to the WARN notice, with 16 positions being eliminated as of May 1, followed by 40 on September 1, 26 on November 1, and 52 on December 31. The company also announced that it would be consolidating four manufacturing facilities over the next two years and moving production of 14 products to its facilities in Tijuana, Mexico, or Pearland, Texas.

Citizens Financial Group Inc. is laying off 900 employees. The company announced that the employees affected by the layoffs will be notified in the coming year. The cuts were being made across the commercial, retail and global transactions sectors.

Citizens Financial Group Inc. in Providence, R.I., is eliminating underutilized branches and laying off dozens of employees across its 12-state market area as part of a broader effort to trim overhead and improve efficiency. The company announced that is adjusting its branch structure to reflect the fact that more and more of its customers are doing their banking online or at automated teller machines.

AnnTaylor Stores Corp. will close its store in One Oxford Centre, Downtown, by the end of January. The women's clothing retailer is shutting 117 underperforming stores over a three-year period; an Ann Taylor Loft store at the SouthSide Works is closing this month. Ann Taylor still has three of its flagship brand stores and six Loft stores in the Pittsburgh region.
Ann Inc. announced about 100 job cuts.

ANN INC. expects to close approximately 40 stores in total in 2014. 15 stores have closed thus far in the first half of 2014, and it expects to close the remainder in the back half of the year with the majority of the remaining closures expected to occur at the very end of the fiscal year.

Ascena Retail Group, the parent company of Ann Taylor and several other retail brands, is filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and preparing to close stores. Locations in the Syracuse area and elsewhere in Upstate New York are on the list. Ascena plans to reorganize and emerge from bankruptcy and its remaining stores will keep operating as thebankruptcy proceeds. Its brands include Ann Taylor, Loft, Lane Bryant, Justice and Lou & Grey. The company plans to close 1,600 locations across all its brands, reducing its store count to 1,200 from 2,800, according to USA 24 July 2020. The firm said the coronavirus pandemic disrupted its recent progress and sparked the need for the bankruptcy and store closings. Ascena is closing all of its Catherines locations, including a store near the Home Depot in Clay and one in New Hartford.
Allied Waste Industries Inc. announced that it's planning to lay off 30 workers as part of a reorganization.
HCA Inc. began notifying 100 employees that they will lose their jobs because of a recent decision to abandon a new billing system for the nation's largest for-profit hospital company.

HCA Inc. announced that it will shut down Northlake Medical Center on December 15, burdened by several years of declining inpatient volumes, high employee turnover, difficulty recruiting employees and financial losses at the Tucker, Ga., hospital. Northlake Medical Center's emergency department will close at noon on December 8. The hospital's 350 employees will get their regularly scheduled pay and benefits for 60 days. Employees, both part-time and full-time, also will receive severance pay and access to outplacement services.

Hospital Corporation of America announced that it is closing one of its Florida hospitals, citing a sharp decline in in-patient volume. HCA will shut down the 162-bed Edward White Hospital in St. Petersburg by Nov. 24. Services at the hospitals will shift to three other HCA-affiliated hospitals in the area.

Xilinx Inc. announced that it will eliminate about 250 jobs as part of a company reorganization meant to improve operating performance. The job cuts, which are expected to be completed by the end of the next fiscal year, will adversely impact Xilinx's first-quarter operating expenses.

InPhase Technologies Inc., and Xilinx Inc., with about 350 employees in Longmont, is trimming their work forces. InPhase laid off 'fewer than 40' fulltime employees and an undisclosed number of contractors because of a delay in product production. Xilinx will eliminate approximately 250 positions, or about 7% of the company's global work force.

Xilinx Inc. has closed its research and development operation in Journal Center after more than a decade, eliminating most of the 50 jobs at San Jose, California. An aerospace and defense marketing group will remain in business here - about 10 or so employees. The R&D operation in Albuquerque is being consolidated with other Xilinx locations. The company reported that those losing their jobs will be offered severance packages and said it is possible some employees could be relocated to other Xilinx locations. The research and development operation moved into the former 45,135-square-foot Lovelace Park-Center in 2000, the year after Xilinx purchased the Albuquerque-based logic division of Philips Semiconductor, which had developed a line of programmable logic chips under the CoolRunner name. It is Xilinx's only New Mexico location.

Arctic Cat Inc. announced that it agreed to sell its plant in Madison, S.D., cutting 89 positions in an effort to streamline manufacturing. The plant does painting, welding and subassembly work which will be absorbed into Arctic Cat's plant in Thief River Falls, Minn. Workers at the Madison plant will be offered employment assistance and opportunities to work in the company's other plants.

Wet Seal Inc. announced that, as part of its strategic review of business operations, which includes various cost-cutting initiatives, the Company has implemented staff reductions affecting a total of 41 employees. The staff reductions are expected to result in annualized pre-tax savings of approximately $4.3 million beginning in fiscal 2008.

Wet Seal Inc. announced earnings results for the fiscal first quarter ended May 3, 2008. Net sales for the 13-week period ended May 3, 2008, were $142.4 million compared to net sales of $138.0 million for the 13-week period ended May 5, 2007. Net income was $8.9 million, or $0.09 per diluted share, as compared to net income of $7.6 million, or $0.07 per diluted share, in the prior year first quarter.  For the second quarter of fiscal 2008, based on current market conditions, earnings are estimated in the range of $0.08 to $0.10 per diluted share versus $0.07 earnings per diluted share in the prior year second quarter. Total net sales are expected between $149.3 million and $151.6 million.For all of fiscal 2008, the Company now expects a small increase in net new stores, with approximately 20 planned openings at Wet Seal. The number of net new store openings can fluctuate depending on the outcome of several store lease negotiations still in process. The Company forecasts fiscal 2008 capital expenditures, net of approximately $4 million in tenant improvement allowances, will be between $22 million and $23 million, of which between $15 million and $16 million will be for construction of new stores or remodeling of existing stores upon lease renewals and/or store relocations.  For all of fiscal 2008, the Company plans to close 4 stores at Wet Seal and approximately 9 Arden B closings as leases expire.

Wet Seal is winding down its Arden B retail store business, and will close 31 locations by the end of fiscal 2015. The company currently has 54 Arden B stores and 478 Wet Seal stores. The company announced that 31 Arden B locations will shift to Wet Seal Plus merchandise. The remaining 23 locations will transition from Arden B to regular Wet Seal merchandise. The company anticipates completing the conversion before the back-to-school season in late July. Stores slated for closing will do so when leases expire, or through early termination provisions. Wet Seal Inc. will close 15 Arden B stores in fiscal 2014 and 16 in fiscal 2015. For the interim period that the stores are open they will offer Wet Seal or Wet Seal Plus merchandise.
Wet Seal permanently closed its store at Rolling Oaks Mall last week. The company said that it closed more than 300 stores, resulting in the layoff of nearly 3,700 workers.

Lannett Company, Inc. approved a restructuring plan for its wholly owned unit Cody Laboratories. It has been unable to sell the Cody API business as an ongoing operation and now intends to sell the equipment and real estate used by the Cody API business and to have Cody Labs cease all operations. It will cut all remaining 70 positions at Cody Labs and expects all of this will be substantially completed by September 30.
Benchmark Electronics Inc. has reduced its workforce by 15 workers, and eliminated the third shift.

Benchmark Electronics Inc. is to shut its site at Meridian Business Park, near Braunstone. The company has made an announcement that it is going to close its operations in Leicester and all the people it employs here are going to be made redundant.

Alliant Techsystems announced that the Massachusetts leather-goods factory will shut down by July 31, 2009. The plant employs more than 300 people, mostly Latinos. Federal agents raided the plant and arrested more than 360 undocumented workers in 2007.

Alliant Techsystems Inc. announced that it has streamlined its process of making booster rockets, while also acknowledging that it will have to lay off more workers early 2013. The company will be reducing the number of its employees by an untold number in February in response to its anticipated workload. The company said that the layoffs would be companywide in the rocket propulsion teams at Utah's three ATK plants -- in Promontory near Brigham City, and in Magna and Clearfield. ATK not only makes rocket boosters for NASA, but has a weapons division for the U.S. military and a sporting division that produces ammunition and shooting accessories for sports shooting and law enforcement. Although the company would not say how many job losses there will be, insisted they are not part of the stream of layoffs that occurred in the past 3 years, which were largely related to the end of the space shuttle program and resulted in more than 2,000 employees being cut. ATK employees already know about the pending layoffs. With the help of NASA, ATK was able to identify areas where there were redundancies and made upgrades to its manufacturing and testing to improve the time and cost of making its boosters for its space launch system. NASA's SLS will launch future rockets into space for human exploration. It can be used to launch rockets for both crew and cargo missions. With the approximately 400 changes made to the process, which took a year to implement, the company can save as much as 46% of the assembly time, as well as millions of dollars in projected costs. Although the process is reducing costs and eliminating unnecessary steps in producing the boosters that does not mean the company is taking shortcuts. The steps have not affected the safety of the rockets or increased their risks.

Less than 50 employees at ESCO Technologies' plant in Glendale Heights, Ill., will lose their jobs when the plant closes. The company announced that it will close that facility, outside Chicago, as it consolidates its test segment's four domestic manufacturing facilities into three. The plant's closing is expected to be completed by January, and the majority of the employees will be transferred to the other three test segment facilities. The company expects about $3 million in restructuring costs, to be expensed over the next six to nine months. The consolidation is expected to yield partial-year cost savings in 2013 of about $1 million, excluding restructuring costs, and annual savings of $3 million starting in 2014, according the company. Despite the shortfall, the company expects its fourth-quarter pre-tax earnings to be more than 35% higher than the prior-year quarter. ESCO's pre-tax earnings were $19.9 million in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011.

Esco Technologies announced that it is closing facilities in its shielding and test division and cutting U.S. employees as part of a new restructuring plan. The company plans to close its Test business operating facilities in Taufkirchen, Germany, and Stevenage, England, and consolidate the operations into other existing facilities. Esco also plans to cut the number of employees in its Test division in the U.S. and eliminate some underperforming product lines. In its USG segment, ESCO plans to close its operating office in Doble-Brazil and consolidate Doble's South American sales and support activities into a lower cost operating structure. The cost to implement these actions, to be taken in 2016, is expected to be about $9 million. The moves are expected to save the company more than $6 million in 2016 and about $8 million annually in 2017 and beyond.
Ethan Allen announced the closure of its Cherry Hill plant in Union City, Pennsylvania, affecting 245 employees.

On December 2, 2008, Biolase Technology Inc. announced that it is currently completing an approximate 20% domestic work force reduction and is in the final stages of reviewing additional cost savings in its international subsidiaries.
Biolase Technology, Inc. has announced a global workforce reduction of approximately 20% as part of its operational restructuring.

InFocus Corp. announced a plan to restructure the company and reduce its global workforce by approximately 30%, commencing in January 2009 and spanning a twelve month period. The company currently expects to incur restructuring charges in the fourth quarter of 2008 ranging from $5.3 million to $6.1 million. Approximately $1.3 million to $1.6 million of the charge is related to the planned headcount reduction, and consists primarily of severance payments, to occur during the fourth quarter of 2008 and over the course of 2009. The charge associated with facilities is estimated to be approximately $4.0 million to $4.5 million and consists of costs to vacate excess leased facility space primarily located at the Company's headquarters in Wilsonville, Oregon. The charges related to facilities will be incurred in the fourth quarter of 2008 and the first half of 2009 as the space is vacated. The company provided earnings guidance for the fourth quarter 2008. For the period, the company expects results to be impacted by slower than expected growth in all segments and regions. The workforce reduction will begin immediately and continue throughout 2009, with the majority of the reductions completed in the first half of 2009. The company's 2009 business model will be built off a breakeven point of $50-55 million revenue per quarter, down 30% from previous assumptions. The company believes it will achieve profitable operations with an 18% gross margin target and operating expenses in the range of $10-11 million per quarter.
Sonic Corp. closed its drive-in fast food restaurant in Lafayette. The restaurant, at 50 Waneka Parkway, is being converted to a 'Karz' drive-in restaurant.

Zilog Inc. will close its last remaining manufacturing plant on June 23, putting 147 employees out of work. The closing of the Nampa plant was announced more than a year ago but no date was set at the time. Zilog once employed more than 500 people at two Nampa locations.

Zilog Inc. has announced that it will close its remaining Nampa manufacturing site and lay off 147 manufacturing and support workers. The move, set for June 23, is the final step in the company's strategy to outsource its manufacturing operations. The two plants once had a combined peak employment of nearly 700 in early 1998, Williams said. Zilog will retain about 30 Nampa employees in product design, engineering, product testing and quality assurance.

Atmel Corp. may soon cut its France-based manufacturing and design workforces. The company has made proposals to the French works council on the potential redundancies of approximately 210 employees from its Rousset and Nantes locations. The company reported earnings results for the second quarter ended June 2008. Revenues for company's second quarter were $420.9 million, a 2.4% sequential increase and a 4.1% increase year over year. Net loss for the June quarter was $4.9 million and compared to net income of $0.7 million for the year-ago quarter.

Atmel Corp. announced that it will sell or shut down its XSense product line in Colorado Springs, just 15 months after introducing it with great fanfare at its local manufacturing plant. XSense was the first product made at the local plant besides semiconductors.

Atmel Corp. announced that it plans to sell two European plants and cut 10% of its non-manufacturing work force as part of a restructuring aimed at boosting profitability. The company announced that it expects the plan to result in annual savings of between $70 million and $80 million next year and between $80 million and $95 million by 2008. The restructuring will mean a one-time charge of more than $200 million in this year's fourth quarter to cover fixed asset write-downs, severance and other expenses. One of the biggest chunks of anticipated savings, about $55 million annually, will come from the planned sale of Atmel's wafer fabrication facilities in Britain's North Tyneside and Heilbronn, Germany. Atmel also plans to cut about 300 of its non-manufacturing staff through a combination of voluntary resignations, attrition and other undisclosed actions. Among other facets of the restructuring, Atmel said it plans to cut manufacturing costs by expanding its foundry relationships.

Atmel Corporation has laid off 140 permanent employees in Colorado Springs in its latest round of cuts due to weak economic conditions. The company announced the cuts and the layoffs of 60 temporary workers in mid-December came because the company's Colorado Springs plant has been operating at about 70% capacity for more than a year. The plant has about 1,100 employees.

Atmel Corp. announced the closure of its manufacturing facility in Irving Texas, effective immediately. The facility, purchased in 2000 from Hitachi, had employed approximately 300 people at the time of its closure. The move allows Atmel to consolidate its manufacturing activity and reduce costs significantly.

Atmel Corp. has cut another 293 jobs in the company's second round of layoffs in five months. Atmel says 266 employees were laid off at its Colorado Springs plant, where 249 jobs were cut in December. The remaining 27 jobs were eliminated at Atmel's headquarters in San Jose, Calif.

Maverick Tube Corporation announced its plans to close its Youngstown, Ohio manufacturing facility during the second quarter of 2003. All of Youngstown's production will be moved to Maverick's manufacturing facilities in Hickman, Arkansas.
Gannett Co. plans to cut 2% of jobs and invest in more acquisitions to transform its business. The report indicated that the layoffs may affect about 380 employees across the company.

Exterran Corp. will close a facility about 70 miles west of Houston, affecting 241 jobs. The company will idle its Columbus production equipment manufacturing facility at 2207 FM 949 in Alleyton, Texas, by June 30. The job cuts will occur in six rounds, and the first group was let go on March 31. The other groups are scheduled to be cut on April 7, April 30, May 12, May 26 and June 30. Affected employees are not represented by a collective bargaining agreement and do not have bumping rights, meaning employees with more seniority cannot take the jobs of those with less seniority. Some employees might be able to apply for other positions within Exterran.

PMC-Sierra Inc. increased the number of jobs it expects to eliminate as part of a restructuring by 63 to 89. As a result, the communications semiconductor maker raised the expected cost of the restructuring by $5.9 million to $7.4 million.

PMC-Sierra Inc. announced that it plans to implement workforce reduction activities. The Company will close its Ottawa, Canada development site and plans to eliminate between 30 and 40 positions primarily from research and development, at a restructuring cost in the range of approximately $5.8 to $7.2 million, which includes a range of $2.3 to $3.2 million in one-time termination benefits and relocation costs, and $3.5 to $4.0 million for consolidation of facilities and adjustments of previously recorded provisions.

Cephalon Inc. will cut about 90 jobs as it closes a facility and consolidating other research and development activities. The costs of the restructuring plan will cost between $34 million and $47 million, before taxes.

United States Steel Corp. plan to indefinitely idle its mill in the St. Louis suburb along with the Keetac iron ore mining and pelletizing site in Keewatin, Minn., and its Great Lakes Works near Detroit because of the worsening economy, affecting a total of about 3,500 workers. Most of the 2,100 workers there will lose their jobs, though some will stay on to keep the plant functioning for a quick restart when production resumes.

U.S. Steel Corp. announced it's ceasing production at two steel mills in Ontario's manufacturing heartland. The shuttering of the two former Stelco plants, located in Hamilton and Nanticoke, will put roughly 1,500 employees out of work.

About 40 United States Steel Corp. workers were laid off, some permanently, because of problems with a blast furnace. The laid off workers had been transferred from the company's Midwest finishing plant to Gary Works in January after being put on layoff status at their home plant two months earlier. About one-third of the workers were on probationary status. During their stint at Gary Works, which ended when they were laid off March 26, the hourly employees drove trucks, worked as laborers and did other support services.

U.S. Steel Corp. is shutting down its iron and steel making plant in Hamilton, Ontario, by year's end as part of a bid to cut costs. The company employs approximately 2,200 people at the production complex. The company announced that it will take a non-cash charge in its fourth quarter of approximately $225 million related to the decision.

U.S. Steel is laying off nearly a quarter of the salaried staff of its Canadian operations as part of a companywide effort to reduce high administrative costs. The steel maker will lay off 175 of its 723 salaried workers at its Hamilton and Lake Erie plants as well as its corporate offices in Canada.

United States Steel Corp. has announced that it will adjust operations at three locations in Alabama and Texas. The company informed around 2,000 workers of the decision. The 1,918 union employees at the three locations were advised of the adjustment and have been issued notices under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act. The company said it is planning a temporary reduction in operating levels, not a complete shutdown of plants. The company also said it regularly adjusts production at certain facilities to reflect market fluctuations. Fairfield Works in Fairfield, Ala. Layoffs at the Fairfield Works could involve 1,214 employees, which could reportedly occur on or following March 30. Additionally, potential layoffs at Fairfield Tubular could affect up to 386 employees on or following March 29. At the Texas facility, the report said 381 employees could face potential layoffs occurring on or around Feb. 1.

U.S. Steel Corp. is laying off 2,080 workers at its Granite City Works in Metro East as part of a consolidation of its North American flat-rolled operations. The company is temporarily idling its Granite City Works operations in Granite City in the consolidation, which is "part of an on-going adjustment of steelmaking operations throughout North America to match customer demand". The affected workers in Granite City are being issued notices under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) Act. The notices are effective "on or after May 28" based on operations and maintenance needs.

US Steel has laid off 67 salaried employees at its Gary Works in northwest Indiana, USA. The May 15 layoffs were part of the Pittsburgh-based steelmaker's staff cuts in response to tough steel market conditions.

United States Steel Corp. announced the proposed intent to permanently close its blast furnace and associated steelmaking operations, along with most of the flat-rolled finishing operations at Fairfield Works in Fairfield, Ala. Under this action, the blast furnace and associated steelmaking operations will be idled. They and the finishing operations would be permanently closed on or after Nov. 17, 2015. The facilities that would permanently close include the blast furnace and steelmaking operations, the hot strip mill, the pickle line, cold mill, annealing facility and stretch and temper line. The decision affects about 1,100 workers at the roughly century-old plant.

U.S. Steel has it plans to lay off as many as 200 plant workers in Michigan by the end of next month. The layoffs are temporary, but the company said in a filing with the state they could last more than six months. The Aug. 1 filing came two months after U.S. Steel announced plans to idle two blast furnaces at its Great Lakes mill in southeastern Michigan and Gary Works plant in Indiana. The layoffs affect employees in nearly every area of the facility from blast furnace operations through finishing operations. Some layoffs began in July and others were expected to go into effect through September.

Apria Healthcare Group Inc. announced that it will eliminate 90 jobs at a suburban Rockford billing office as part of an effort to offset federal cuts in Medicare reimbursement rates. The company notified workers that it's consolidating billing for certain medical equipment businesses to Phoenix, Kansas City, Kan., and Jackson, Tenn. The company provides a range of home health care services, including respiratory therapy and infusion, and offers medications, diabetic supplies and other medical equipment.

Haemonetics Corp. reported that as a result of the reorganization, the Company reduced its worldwide workforce of 1,500 employees by approximately 4%. No facilities will be closed. The reductions will result in a charge for severance and related costs of approximately $2.7 million. Annualized cost savings of approximately $4 million are expected.

Jones Apparel Group, Inc. is looking to shut 166 underperforming specialty retail stores in 2010. The company has not disclosed the brand and location of the store which it intends to close. Most of the locations identified for closing will be mall-based specialty retail stores, as the company plans to lay more emphasis on its outlet stores.
Panera Bread Co. will close its Squirrel Hill location on August 31, with no plans to relocate within the Squirrel Hill area.
Panera Bread announced that it will be closing its store at 6981 S. Lewis Ave. by July 1, 2015.

Outback Steakhouse has closed after eight years in Kansas City. The restaurant, at 1851 Village West Parkway, was an original tenant of the shopping center now known as the Legends Outlets Kansas City. The restaurant had 57 employees and some had the opportunity to transfer to open positions at another area Outback location. Employees who did not transfer received a severance package.

Genesis ElderCare announced that it will close the 240-bed Pennsauken facility, which has been losing money for months. Wylie, a regional vice president, said Cooper River East would stay open until all 208 patients found a new place. Genesis ElderCare, a $2.6 billion company based in Chester County, filed for bankruptcy and closed 20 nursing homes because of Medicare cuts two years ago, Salamon said.
Genesis Health Ventures Inc. has announced that the company has laid off more than 130 positions in order to cut costs.

AES has decided to stop power production at its Tisza II gas-fuelled power plant in Tiszaujvaros, eastern Hungary, as of March 31, 2012. The company bought the plant in 1996 and now it wants to sell it. The facility has an installed capacity of 900MW and is Hungary's fourth biggest power plant, accounting for 5% of the domestic energy generation. AES will dismiss 101 workers at the plant and will keep only 30 employees in order to maintain machinery and equipment. AES closed down its 90MW coal-fired power station in Tiszapalkonya and its 71MW wood-fired power station Borsodi Hoeromu in March 2011, due to falling wholesale electricity prices.

AES Corp. has shut down its Beaver Valley coal plant in Potter two years ahead of schedule, having failed to secure a buyer for its electricity. The company flirted with the idea of converting the 125-megawatt plant to run on natural gas, but could find no takers for its energy. The small coal facility had been feeding neighboring industrial buildings since the mid-1980s, providing power to West Penn Power and steam to Nova Chemicals and BASF. When it lost its last electric customer in 2013, AES Beaver Valley told the regional grid operator, PJM Interconnection Inc., that it would wind down in the summer of 2017. But the company accelerated the process, taking a financial hit in the short term.

In quitting the aluminum-can business, Kaiser Aluminum Corp. plans to lay off as many as 150 employees at its Trentwood rolling mill by June. The cuts would affect both salaried and Steelworkers union workers.
MGIC Investment Corp. announced that it will close its Toronto office.The company also announced layoff of the staff of eight or nine including MGIC Canada chief executive officer Chuck Wilson.

Tti Floor Care North America Inc. plans to close its Euclid return center by the end of the year and move operations to Texas or Mexico. Fifty-seven full-time employees will lose their jobs.
