The center, in a former big-box store at Babbitt Road and St. Clair Avenue, began operations in 2004. Employees refurbish and remanufacture returned vacuum cleaners for resale. TTI plans to move these operations to a facility to be shared with TTI North America Power Tools. The company is considering locations in El Paso and Juarez, which is across the border in Mexico. The local employees have been offered severance packages, including one week of pay for every year of service and medical benefit subsidies for up to six months, along with career outplacement services.
Sybase has announced that it had cut 150 jobs during the second quarter.
Sybase Inc. announced that it plans to consolidate more facilities and reduce infrastructures, which will require reduction of people in some areas.

Building Materials Holding Corp. will shutter its Florida locations in four months. The company's subsidiary SelectBuild Florida, has offices in Jupiter and Fort Pierce. The company's other offices in Sunrise, Orlando, Fort Myers and Sarasota also will close. Statewide, the company said, 140 employees would lose their jobs.

On September 30, 2014, EZCORP, Inc.'s Board of Directors, on management's recommendation, approved a plan to exit the company's online lending businesses in the U.K. and the U.S. (plan). The plan includes: exiting the company's online lending business in the U.K. (conducted under the name Cash Genie) and terminating the employment of the employees related to that business; and discontinuing the company's online lending business in the U.S. (referred to as EZOnline) and terminating the employment of the employees related to that business. The company currently expects to have completed the Cash Genie exit activities, whether wind-down or sale, before the end of the second quarter of fiscal 2015. As part of exiting the Cash Genie business, the company will eliminate 115 positions (49 of which are currently held by independent contractors) and terminate the employment of 66 current employees. As part of discontinuing the EZOnline business, the company will eliminate 34 positions and terminate the employment of 34 current employees.
EZCORP, Inc. has decided to close the remaining 22 stores.

THQ Inc. announced that it was laying off 118 people at two game studios and it had reduced its aspirations for its Warhammer 40,000: Dark Millennium game. Previously, the licensed Warhammer 40K game was going to be a massively multiplayer online world. Now it will be an "immersive" single-play and online multiplayer game.

Biogen Idec Inc. will lay off about 28% of its San Diego work force, or 140 out of 500 jobs, as part of a larger reorganization. The Cambridge, Mass.-based biotechnology company, which suffered a major setback early this year when its new multiple sclerosis drug Tysabri was pulled from the market because of safety concerns, will eliminate 650 workers worldwide, or about 17% of its employees.
Technology Solutions Company plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs and offices in response to continued depressed market conditions.

LandAmerica Financial Group Inc. would terminate about 1,100 positions in the second half of this year, representing 13% of the company's residential and lender services workforce. Already, the company has let go some 300 workers since July 1. Those layoffs are in addition to about 700 layoffs that occurredearlier in the year. As a result, the company will take additional severance-related charges in the third and fourth quarters of this year. The company announced the layoffs are being made in response to lower mortgage origination volume and an attempt to improve efficiency.

LandAmerica Financial Group Inc. announced that it eliminated the equivalent of 300 full-time positions during the quarter, bringing to 3,600 the number of job cuts since January 2007, representing 25.4% of the work force.

Shopko Stores Operating Co. LLC planed to lay off 66 employees after deciding to close a store in Madison. The one affected is located at 2602 Shopko Drive on the city's east side. The layoffs are expected to begin on July 27 and continue through Aug. 30. The Department of Workforce Development will offer employment services to affected employees through the South Central Area Workforce Development Board.

Shopko Stores Operating Co. LLC will eliminate more than 100 jobs at the company's headquarters in Ashwaubenon. A mass layoff notice filed with the state showed that the company intended to terminate about 140 jobs at its store support center at 700 Pilgrim Way. It predates notices published last week by the state's Department of Workforce Development that reported that 578 employees would lose their jobs at 11 Shopko stores closing throughout the state. The February 6, 2019 letter addresses a total of 24 Shopko store closures including the 11 the Milwaukee Business Journal reported on previously where about 1,000 employees will be terminated. Those layoffs are expected to occur in May. The types of positions that will be eliminated at the company's headquarters had not been defined by the time the company filed the February 6, 2019 notice. The reductions, prompted by the store closures throughout the company's network, are expected to take place in April. The company filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection last month in Nebraska. Since then, the general merchandise department store chain announced plans to close more than 250 stores, including 42 in Wisconsin.
Shopko Stores announced that it will close all of its locations, including those in Dubuque and Dyersville, Iowa, and Lancaster, Wis. All stores are expected to close by June 16.

Shopko Stores' Dubuque location likely will close for good June 22 or 23. The date is contingent upon the store selling out of its merchandise. The company announced in March that it would close all of its locations because it could not find a buyer that would enable the stores to remain open.

Salton Inc. announced that it is laying off more than 200 employees as part of a $40 million cost-reduction plan. The layoffs, which equate to 27$of the company's U.S. workforce, are expected to lower annual costs by $11 million.

Goody's Family Clothing Inc. announced that in conjunction with its $65 million investor funding, it has reduced its home office workforce by 5% and realigned its field support staff to achieve improved operating efficiencies.
Goody's Family Clothing Inc. will close 18 underperforming stores in June. There are no plans to shutter any stores in East Tennessee, though two of the 18 locations are in Nashville.

Goody's Family Clothing Inc. is closing its Fayetteville store as it moves to emerge from bankruptcy protection. Over the summer, the company filed for Chapter 11 protection and that it would close 69 stores. Fayetteville was not on the list. But the company recently decided to close five more stores, including outlets in Fayetteville and Burlington.
Wabash National Corp. has cut 180 salaried positions, implemented a 10% pay cut for executives and remaining salaried workers and temporarily suspended stock dividends.

Wabash National Corp. announced that further salaried workforce headcount reductions of 25 associates, or 5%, bringing total salaried headcount reductions to over 25%, or approximately 170 associates, since the beginning of the industry downturn in early 2007.

Perrigo has reported plans to close two facilities located in Holland and Montague, Michigan. The company explained that since its acquisition of Agis, the firm has pursued opportunities to integrate both businesses and to make them as efficient as possible, whilst evaluating ways to improve under performing assets. Perrigo will transfer profitable product lines from the two locations to plants in Allegan, Michigan, and the Bronx, New York, whilst the unprofitable psyllium-based laxatives and effervescent tablets will be discontinued.
Qualcomm is laying off about 600 employees, which amounts to less than 2% of its global workforce. The company specified that about 300 of the laid off employees work in California.

Qualcomm Inc. announced that it is undergoing major downsizing that will impact dozens of employees at an office in Andover, Massachusetts. The company said that it plans to lay off 65 employees at its office at 100 Burtt Road in Andover beginning November 20, 2015 as part of a major restructuring. Similar notices have been issued in California and Colorado, but do not reflect all the reductions because they address only certain locations and relate only to full-time employees.
Vitesse Semiconductor Corp. announced a reduction of approximately 12% in its worldwide workforce. Severance and related charges will be incurred in the second fiscal quarter of 2009.

A $1.2 billion deal between Nextel Communications Inc. and I.B.M. will put at least 700 employees of Nextel in Rutherford, N.J., out of work. The companies announced the deal all workers at the Rutherford offices of Nextel, a wireless provider, will become employees of an I.B.M. partner, TeleTech Holdings, based in Englewood, Colo.

PDL BioPharma Inc. announced that it would lay off half its staff to save hundreds of millions of dollars. Four top executives are not part of those plans, however, and could earn nearly $1 million in retention bonuses the board approved last week. The firm reported that it would lay off 260 workers to help reduce annual expenses by $150 million.

Whole Foods Market Inc. announced that it plans to close 30 Wild Oats stores that compete with its own locations if it acquires the smaller rival. Whole Foods says it competes with larger supermarket chains that also sell organic food.

Whole Foods Market, Inc. announced that it is closing its Wild Oats location at Juan Tabo and Menaul Net on Feb. 15, and most of the 47 employees there are expected to get jobs at other store locations. With another Whole Foods in the Net heights, the company decided to close the Juan Tabo store. The majority of the 47 employees that work at the Juan Tabo store will get positions at the other Whole Foods locations, one at Academy and Wyoming and another on Carlisle and Indian School.

Whole Foods Market is closing a bakery facility in Dallas, a move that will eliminate 70 jobs. Whole Foods initially reported the plan to eliminate the jobs in a Jan. 5 letter to the Texas Workforce Commission. The facility will close by March 11, 2012. The company is attempting to place the 70 employees whose jobs are being eliminated into other Dallas-area stores or the Houston baking facility.

Whole Foods Market (WFM) announced it will cut about 1,500 jobs, or about 1.6% of its workforce, over the next eight weeks. The company announced that it had taken the decision to be able to maintain low costs for customers as it upgrades technology.

Whole Foods Market, Inc. will shut down its metro Atlanta food preparation facility by February 12, a move that will affect 149 workers. The closure of the facility at 1180 Hembree Road in Roswell, Ga., is part of Whole Foods ongoing plan to streamline operations. Whole Foods is also closing regional kitchen facilities in Everett, Mass., and Landover. The grocery chain will rely on outside suppliers for its in-store prepared foods.
Callaway Golf has announced that it has laid off 100 employees due to the sluggish economy.

SciClone Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced a corporate restructuring that will reduce its U.S. based workforce by approximately 17%, primarily in research and development.The company announced corporate restructuring that follows the discontinuation of company's RP101 phase 2 clinical trial announced on October 2, 2009. As a result of the restructuring, the company anticipates incurring a one-time severance-related charge of approximately $0.3 million, which includes severance and other expenses associated with the workforce reduction plan. The company expects to complete the restructuring in the fourth quarter of 2009.
AOL Time Warner Inc., set to lay off at least 12 staffers out of 250 as it looks to restructure following a miserable year in the music industry, Atlantic sources said.
AOL Time Warner Inc. is letting go 300 workers in its battered online unit, a source close to the company said. The positions being cut make up about 1.5 percent of AOL's 18,000-person staff.

AOL Time Warner Inc. is expected to make more layoffs in its America Online unit next week. The America Online unit of the company has had job reductions of about 2,000 people in the past 18 months. Last year, it pared 725 jobs and 1,200 two summers ago. About 15,000 work for America Online in the U.S.

AOL Time Warner Inc. for the second time in a month, is shutting down a money-losing magazine, Sports Illustrated Women. Last week, AOL's Time Inc. publishing division closed Mutual Funds, a personal finance magazine. Sports Illustrated for Women, which was published 10 times a year, has a circulation of about 400,000. The magazine was conceived as a way for Sports Illustrated, under pressure from ESPN's sports magazine, to extend its brand and reach out to women readers. The December issue will be the last one.

AOL Time Warner Inc. announced that it is planning to lay off more than 100 people at its Dulles-based online, the layoffs, the first this year, are slated to focus on the interactive marketing group and could involve nearly 140. The layoffs would represent less than 1% of the 15,000 employees of the online division, 4,800 of whom work in Northern Virginia. The parent company employs 90,000 people overall.
AOL Time Warner Inc.'s America Online division is expected to lay off 120 employees from its advertising-sales division on November 19.

AOL Time Warner Inc. is planning another round of layoffs at its struggling Internet division in Dulles, as shaken employees continue to react to AOL's falling stock price and the departure of a top executive, according to company sources. The layoffs, however, are expected to be more surgical than across the board could be limited to about 60 of the 1,000 employees under de Castro, the sources said. Overall, the online division employs about 18,000.

AOL, part of Time Warner Inc. announced that it's Tucson office has laid off 80 people, reducing presence in Tucson to one floor of one building after previously occupying three buildings. The cuts reduce AOL's staff of about 150 workers in half.

Christopher & Banks Corporation announced the store in the Lebanon Valley Mall will close in about a month Victoria Layser, marketing coordinator for the mall, said the women's apparel store will close by January 28, 2012. A new store, Leather & Lace, opened across from Schuylkill Valley Sports in the middle of the mall. It features special occasion lingerie and a belly dancing studio. Leather & Lace is signed through December 31, 2012.

ICU Medical disclosed that it will close its Vrable, Slovakia manufacturing facility and take a $3.4 million restructuring charge in fourth quarter 2015. The decision to close the Slovakian location will impact approximately 265 employees. Net cash outlays related to this action are expected to be approximately $3.3 million to $3.7 million, substantially all of which is expected to be paid for during fiscal 2016. The company will shift production from the Vrable facility to its facility in Ensenada, Mexico to take advantage of excess capacity there.

About 40 employees are expected to be laid off at Waynesboro's Mohawk Industries Inc. plant. The move from the carpet and flooring producer and distributor follows a workforce cut of 73 employees in January.

Mohawk Industries Inc. will shut down its Waynesboro plant. Due to this about 120 employees will lose their jobs by the end of the year. The plant will immediately begin the transition phase of terminating operations, which is expected to be completed by the end of the year. The company said some of the employees will be offered positions at other facilities in Virginia.

Mohawk Industries Inc. announced that it is closing its manufacturing plant. The plant, which opened about 50 years ago, will begin its closure April 26. At the end of July 2009, Mohawk announced it was laying off 400 workers from the East Dublin plant. At that time, the company was keeping about 190 workers, retaining its dyeing operation and customer service department.

Praxair Inc. revised earnings guidance for the fourth quarter of 2008. For the period the company reduced guidance for fully diluted earnings per share to a range of $0.95 to $1.00 excluding charges. This range is about even with the $0.98 earned in the 2007 fourth quarter. The company has seen a fall-off in demand in November and is expecting additional customer plant closings in December which will further reduce volumes for the quarter. For the fourth quarter, the company expects Diluted GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $0.58 to $0.63.

The company provided earnings guidance for the full year of 2008. For the period the company reported that excluding the fourth-quarter charge and the first-quarter pension settlement charge, diluted earnings per share are expected to be in the range of $4.13 to $4.18, an increase of 14% to 15% compared to $3.62 in 2007. For the full year, the company expects Diluted GAAP EPS guidance in the range of $3.73 to $3.78.The company announced that it has already initiated cost-reduction actions, including a reduction in workforce of about 1,600 and the closure of underperforming and non-core product lines and businesses.
First Data Corp. employees in Omaha lost their jobs in a cutback spread across technical, customer service and management areas. The 60 were all full-time employees, no contract workers were let go.

First Data Corp. announced that it has eliminated 110 Omaha jobs and immediately fired the people holding them. Twenty additional employees of First Data's card-issuing division in eight other U.S. cities also lost their jobs Wednesday. Card-issuing -- which prints and embosses credit cards and electronically processes credit card transactions -- is the company's major unit in Omaha. The cuts affected all areas and levels of employees. First Data also announced it was moving 300 employees, most of them in Omaha, to other jobs. The job shifts mostly affect systems and programming employees. The redeployment has been going on for a time and will continue.

First Data Corp.'s troubled Card Issuing Services unit will close a facility in Macon, GA, that prints and mails credit card statements and lay off the plant's 300 workers. By shutting the plant, Card Issuing Services is streamlining operations with a goal to reduce costs and increase profit. The Georgia Department of Labor, which has to be notified about major plant closings, said the layoffs will begin Feb. 15 and will be completed by May. First Data last month announced companywide layoffs of more than 1,000 workers. The job cuts, which mostly affected Card Issuing Services at its main facility in Omaha, NE, are designed to save the company $50 million to $60 million next year.

First Data Corp. has laid off 3% of its workforce, or about 1,000 people, as it seeks to cut costs. Most of the layoffs will be in the company's Card Issuing Services unit. The company expects to take additional actions aimed at further reducing overall operating costs prior to the end of 2005 that would result in additional charges during the quarter.
First Data Corp. announced that it has cut 6% of its global work force, including about 300 jobs in Omaha.

First Data Corp. eliminated 100 positions from its metro Denver workforce in a companywide consolidation on November 15, 2007. The Colorado cuts, about 5% of First Data's metro-area employees, were among about 1,700 jobs the company eliminated from its global workforce, including 300 positions in Omaha and 60 in Hagerstown, Md. The additional 1,200 jobs that were cut occurred in locations where First Data maintained a small concentration of employees. The job reductions in metro Denver, where First Data employs about 2,000 workers, covered a broad range of positions, including management.
First Data Corp. will lay off about 25% of the employees at its Corpus Christi, Texas, call center by September 1, 2010.The call center reportedly has 800 employees.

More than 300 employees at a Louisville credit-card transaction processing center will lose their jobs in the next few months. First Data notified the state June 13 that it plans to layoff 344 at the center at 1231 Durrett Lane. After the layoffs, First Data will have about 160 employees in Louisville.

About 40 employees of First Data Corp. in Omaha lost their jobs, among about 70 total positions eliminated by company. The layoffs were part of the same Financial Services segment restructuring effort that resulted in 60 Omaha jobs cut in April. That was the first sizable layoff since July 2010, when the company eliminated 50 jobs here.

Men's Wearhouse Inc. is eliminating 540 jobs as it closes its manufacturing plant in Montreal this July. The company announced the streamlining is the result of a high Canadian dollar and intense import competition in the specialty clothing business from overseas rivals in Asia and elsewhere. The cuts continue the wave of closures in Canada's manufacturing sector in recent months as companies try to cope with a loonie that remains above par with its weakening U.S. counterpart.

Tailored Brands is also moving to cut $50 million in distribution, organizational, employee and occupancy costs in 2016. Those cost-cutting measures and store closures will cost between $45 million and $60 million in 2016.

Tailored Brands has decided to cut approximately 20% of its corporate positions as it deals with coronavirus' impact on its operations. The move is part of the company's plan to strengthen its financial position and compete in a challenging retail environment. It is expected to be implemented by the end of the second quarter of this fiscal year. Additionally, the retailer has identified up to 500 retail stores for potential closure as it plans to reduce and realign its store organisation and supply chain infrastructure and organisation. The retailer, which closed all of its stores due to coronavirus, resumed operations at its e-commerce fulfilment centres amid the coronavirus (Covid-19) pandemic. Last month, US department store chain Macy's decided to reduce corporate and management headcount by around 3900, following the impact the coronavirus pandemic.

AGCO has announced that it will close down its track tractor factory in DeKalb, Illinois affecting 186 employees. The production at the DeKalb assembly plant is planned to cease by late May 2003 with production to be relocated and resumed in July 2003.

Stein Mart Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended July 30, 2011. For the quarter, the companys net sales were $270,167,000 against $275,955,000 a year ago. Income from operations was $2,247,000 against $13,477,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $2,250,000 against $13,493,000 a year ago. Net income was $1,316,000 or $0.03 diluted per share against $11,289,000 or $0.0.25 diluted per share a year ago. Comparable store sales decreased 1.1% for the second quarter, while total sales decreased 2.1% to $270.2 million. Adjusted 2010 net income and diluted earnings per share using the 2011 normalized ETR of 39.4% was $3.0 million or $0.07 per share for the second quarter.For the six months, the companys net sales were $573,713,000 against $576,953,000 a year ago. Income from operations was $28,458,000 against $34,655,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $28,465,000 against $34,679,000 a year ago. Net income was $17,216,000 or $0.38 diluted per share against $25,637,000 or $0.57 diluted per share a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $35,413,000 against $13,310,000 a year ago. Capital expenditures were $14,842,000 against $15,235,000 a year ago. Net income as adjusted was $16 million compared to $15.9 million in the first half of 2010. Earnings per share as adjusted were $0.35 in both periods. Operating income as adjusted was $26.4 million or 4.6% of sales compared to $26.2 million as adjusted or 4.5% of sales for the same period in 2010. For the first half, comparable store sales increased 0.3%, while total sales decreased 0.6% to $573.7 million.The company expects to open three new stores in the second half of 2011.The company expects to relocate two stores in the second half of 2011.The company expects to close one store in the second half of 2011.The company expects effective tax rate during 2011 to be about 39% and adjusted net income and earnings per share for 2010 use a 39.4% tax rate, which is rate for the f

Stein Mart Inc. reported consolidated unaudited earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the quarter, the company's net income was $5.7 million or $0.13 per diluted share compared to net income of $18.8 million or $0.42 per diluted share in 2010. Adjusted net income was $6.8 million or $0.15 per diluted share compared to adjusted net income of $11.3 million or $0.25 per diluted share in 2010. Net sales were $328.1 million, a decrease of 2.5% from $336.7 million in 2010. Comparable store sales decreased 2.2% for the fourth quarter 2011. Operating income was $9.0 million compared to $16.0 million in 2010. Adjusted operating income decreased to $10.6 million from $18.3 million in 2010. The decrease in operating income as adjusted is primarily the result of lower gross profit caused by lower sales and a lower gross profit rate. Income before income taxes was $8.23 million against $15.941 million a year ago. For the year, the company's net income was $19.8 million or $0.44 per diluted share compared to net income of $48.8 million or $1.08 per diluted share in 2010. Adjusted net income was $20.0 million or $0.44 per diluted share compared to adjusted net income of $29.6 million or $0.66 per diluted share in 2010. Net sales were $1,160.4 million, a decrease of 1.8% from $1,181.5 million in 2010. Comparable store sales decreased 1.1% for the fiscal year 2011. Operating income was $32.3 million compared to $53.5 million in 2010. Adjusted operating income decreased to $32.6 million from $48.1 million in 2010. Results for 2011 include a first quarter pretax gain of $2.0 million ($1.2 million after tax or $0.03 per diluted share) to correct an error in the company's credit card reward liability that is recorded as part of other income. Income before income taxes was $31.971 million against $53.192 million a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $64.507 million against $49.632 million a year ago. Capital expenditures were $33.449 million against $29.550 million a y
Boston Scientific Corp. has announced that up to 300 workers will lose their jobs as it cuts workforce.

Boston Scientific Corp. could cut between 2,000 to 3,400 jobs, which is about 7 to 12%of its work force. The company announced in February that it would lay off between 500 to 600 workers at its Arden Hills facility, which it acquired when it bought Guidant Corp. for $27 billion. The facility focuses on cardiac rhythm management devices implantable cardioverter defibrillators (ICDs) and related devices, which can be used to jolt an ailing heart back into proper rhythm. The cuts came as the market for ICDs slowed in the face of the recalls.

Boston Scientific Inc. is closing the operations of Rimon Medical Technologies Ltd., eight months after acquiring the company. Boston Scientific paid an initial $80 million, and will pay an additional $300 million subject to Rimon meeting certain milestones. Rimon's Israel activity is being closed down after its technology was installed at Boston Scientific's facilities in the US. The company develops and commercializes non-invasive smart, miniature implants which enable physicians to assess and treat a variety of medical conditions. The company's 40 Israeli employees have been let go.
Kohl's Corp. has closed its department store in Brooklyn Center, Minn. The company announced in an analyst call in February that it plans to close two stores in 2014 as their leases come up.

Kohl's Corp. will close its Brown Deer store - one of 18 under-performing department stores across the country that the company is shutting down. The company announced last month that it would be closing stores, but didn't disclose the locations until April 27, 2016. The Brown Deer store, 9060 N. Green Bay Rd., is the only Wisconsin property being shuttered. Nine of the 18 stores being targeted are in California. Three are in Georgia, two are in Florida, and one each are in Illinois, North Carolina and New Jersey. Except for a Georgia store that will remain open through October, the closings will be carried out by June 19. That will bring Kohl's nationwide department-store count to about 1,150.Meanwhile, the company this year is opening seven new small-format department stores, adding two Off/Aisle discount stores in Wisconsin, and opening 12 Fila shops in outlet malls.

Kohl's Corporation will close four 'lower performing' stores in 2019 - in Rego Park, New York; Valley Stream, New York; Lenexa, Kansas; and Houma, Louisiana. At the same time, the company said it plans to open four smaller-format stores at undisclosed locations, keeping its store count at 1,158.
Kohl's Corp. will expand to more than 200 the number of its stores offering Amazon products, but will close the Amazon "smart home" shops it opened in 30 locations since the fall of 2017.

Steris Corporation announced a targeted restructuring plan, which includes the closure of STERIS's Hopkins Production Facility in Mentor, Ohio, as well as other actions. Approximately 150 positions will be eliminated as a result of the restructuring plan, about 100 of which are in Ohio. The vast majority of the people who will be impacted have already been notified. The Hopkins Facility primarily produces STERIS's SYSTEM 1E(TM) Liquid Chemical Sterilant Processing System and related chemistry and accessories. Business operations at the Hopkins Facility are expected to cease by October 31, 2015. The Company will relocate the production of these products to existing North American manufacturing operations.

US Physical Therapy Inc. announced that it will close eight clinics, reducing its present total number of clinics from 260 to 252. The company reported 254 clinics in operation at June 30, 2004. Thus far in the current quarter ending September 30, 2004, the company has opened six facilities, bringing the current number of clinics to 260. The planned closings would reduce that total to 252. The company expects to open from 12 to 16 additional new clinics before year end. This would bring the total number of new clinic openings for the full year 2004 to 34 to 38 and the total projected facilities open at year end to an expected range of 264 to 268.
US Physical Therapy Inc. announced that it has decided to close 26 unprofitable clinics and has reduced its corporate staff by 19 positions. The 26 clinics to be closed are spread across 13 states.
Franklin Covey Co. has trimmed its work force in order to cut operating expenses. The company has reduced its workforce by 800 employees over the last two years.

Bed Bath & Beyond announced that an apparent shift in the soil closed a Washington County store. As a precautionary measure, the company closed this location while the full impact of the apparent settlement and related issues are evaluated.

Bed Bath & Beyond in Ward Village, which opened in 2013, will reportedly be closing sometime in early 2020, The company has been struggling in sales, reporting in October that second quarter net sales fell approximately 7.3% to $2.7 billion from $2.9 billion in the same quarter last year.

Express Scripts Holding Company announced that it is permanently closing its Tampa pharmacy. The closure will occur as the company lays off 216 workers at the site, on or about April 18, 2015. The Tampa layoffs make up the bulk of a nationwide workforce cutback by the company. The company is laying off 380 workers nationwide. The workforce reduction in Tampa and elsewhere is an effort to be more efficient and to serve clients better.

Express Scripts Holding Co. announced that the company eliminated 380 positions across the country, including 23 in St. Louis.The company also announced longtime board member John Parker retired from the board due to health reasons. Parker has been a board member since 2001.
The Finish Line Inc. said it will close just under 4% of its stores as part of a restructuring plan to speeding up inventory turnover.

Finish Line Inc. reported consolidated unaudited earnings results for the thirteen week and twenty six week ended August 27, 2011. For the thirteen week period, the company reported net sales of $331.514 million compared to $301.070 million a year ago. Operating income was $33.678 million compared to $26.991 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations before income taxes were $33.817 million compared to $27.146 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations were $20.920 million or $0.39 per diluted share compared to $16.804 million or $0.31 per diluted share a year ago. Net income was $20.920 million or $0.39 per diluted share compared to $16.814 million or $0.31 per diluted share a year ago. Capital expenditures totaled $5.5 million.For the twenty week period, the company reported net sales of $630.988 million compared to $583.468 million a year ago. Operating income was $60.249 million compared to $49.182 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations before income taxes were $60.530 million compared to $49.401 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations were $37.336 million or $0.69 per diluted share compared to $30.473 million or $0.56 per diluted share a year ago. Net income was $37.336 million or $0.69 per diluted share compared to $30.460 million or $0.56 per diluted share a year ago. Capital expenditures totaled $9.7 million.For the full year of 2012, the company expects capital expenditure to range between $35 million and $40 million. For the full year, the company expects depreciation to range between $27 million to $30 million. For the full year of 2012, the company expects to open 5 to 10 new Finish Line stores and close 20 to 30.

General Cable Corporation has confirmed the closure of its manufacturing and support operations in Auckland and Christchurch, with the loss of 170 jobs. The company had set out a proposal to wind down the local unit in November 2016, with consultation now complete. Manufacturing at Christchurch will continue until the end of March next year 2017, with sales of special products sourced from the international network of General Cable for special projects to continue after the closure. It had closed its Australian sales office early in 2016 and restructured its New Zealand operation to try to stem the losses. The North American company had been selling its Asia-Pacific operations, but in November the company announced that the remaining Chinese, Australian and NZ businesses would be presented as discontinued in the accounts. The New Zealand operations had provided copper, aluminium and fibre optic cabling for building and infrastructure in New Zealand and Australia.

Starbucks Corp. is laying off an undisclosed number of workers at its customer-service center in Seattle, which answers calls and correspondence to Starbucks from all over the world. The company said a small number of the center's roughly 120 employees will lose their jobs.

Starbucks Corp. announced that Woodbury Lakes shopping center is closing. The shop fell victim to a Starbucks plan to trim 600 stores nationwide. The store will close, but a previously reported deadline is March 31, 2009. The Woodbury Lakes shutdown is in addition to the shuttering of seven other Minnesota Starbucks sites, which was announced in August. Woodbury has two other Starbucks coffee shops, which are not closing. Woodbury Lakes is an open-air 'lifestyle center' that opened in 2005. The closing of Starbucks leaves it without a coffee shop or restaurant in the central mall area.

Starbucks Corp. announced that its two coffee stores will close as part of the company's efforts to rid itself of financial problems. Stores at 995 Nord Ave., near West Sacramento Avenue, and 1380 East Ave., near Mariposa Avenue, will be closing. Those two are among the newer shops opened by Starbucks in Chico, which has eight. The Starbucks inside the East Avenue Safeway will remain.

Starbucks Corp. is closing two more Denver-area outlets as part of its latest round of store closings. The local store stores to be closed are at 7777 E. Hampden Ave. in Denver and at 5350 S. Santa Fe Drive in Littleton. The move follows a around of store closures in 2008 that included several Denver-area outlets.

Starbucks Corp. announced that a shop in east Modesto's newest shopping center is among 300 the company is shutting in coming months as part of its latest round of cost-cutting efforts. The store is one of three that Starbucks plans to close in the Modesto area. Another is in Ripon on North Wilma Avenue at West Main Street. The third is in Turlock in the 2200 block of West Main Street. Some coffee shops will be closed by the end of April, with the remainder closing by the end of the fiscal year.

Starbucks Corp. is continuing its retrenchment in Dunkin' Donuts country by shutting down locations on Long Pond Road in Plymouth and on Cambridge Road in Woburn as part of a nationwide cost-cutting effort. The company that it can't provide specific details about when the shops would close or how many people would be affected. The company announced that it used several criteria to determine which locations it would close, including a store's prospects for profitability and local economic trends.

Starbucks Corp. announced that it expects to spend $170 million to close the 600 locations that it plans to shut down by next year, which is up from its summer projection of $120 million to $140 million.
Starbucks will close up to 17 Torrefazione Italia locations. Starbucks purchased TI along with Seattle's Best Coffee from AFC Enterprises in 2003.

Starbucks Corp. plans to close its store at 9615 Montana at McRae. The company announced on July 1, 2008 that it will close 600 U.S. stores. The Montana store is the only store in El Paso that was listed on what the company is billing as a complete list of its store closures. In Las Cruces, the store at 2800 N. Main at Temple is also slated for closure. Store closures will begin in July and will continue through the first half of 2009.

Starbucks Corp. released the list of stores it plans to close, and only one is in York County. The store at 189 Eisenhower Drive in Hanover will close as part of the company's cutback. The company announced July 1 that it will close 600 company-operated stores in the U.S. beginning July month and continuing through the first half of 2008.

Starbucks Corp. has cut 16 jobs at its Calhoun County roasting plant. The cuts were made 'to meet current business needs and continue to run plant in a better, more cost-effective way'. Starbucks announced the Sandy Run plant will transition from a 24-hour, seven days a week operation to a 24-hour, five days a week operation. The transition will also result in a change from two 12-hour shifts to three 8-hour shifts.

Starbucks Corp. closing three Lansing-area stores. It's part of a plan to perk up operations by slashing 600 underperforming U.S. coffeehouses. The company chain is shuttering stores in the Meridian Mall, Eastwood Towne Center and its newest area coffee shop near the Frandor Shopping Center at 3201 E. Grand River Ave. in Lansing. Cutting the Lansing-area market presence from venti to short-OK, maybe tall-means Jessica Rankin, 21, and Gina Flannigan, 19, will have to get their coffee fixes somewhere else. The two were leaving the Eastwood Starbucks on Friday with iced caramel macchiatos after a shopping trip.

Starbucks Corp. will shut down 27 of its Minnesota stores. Nearly 5% of the approximately 600 locations that are being closed by the company. The Minnesota stores on the chopping block include upscale locations such as the Woodbury Lakes location at 9000 Hudson Road and the Minnetonka outlet at 5101 County Road 101.
Starbucks Corp. has closed two of its thirteen stores in Austria. The closures in March and April completed its 'consolidation phase' in Austria.

Starbucks Corp. announced that it has laid off about 220 support staff who worked at the coffee retailer's headquarters and in field operations, and will leave about 380 open jobs unfilled. The company announced the 600 job cuts in an e-mail to Starbucks' more than 170,000 employees, calling it a difficult decision aimed at sharpening the company's focus on customers.

Starbucks Corp. announced that it will soon open its fifth outlet in Romania, on the premises of the Liberty Center shopping mall in Bucharest. The new Starbucks coffee shop has an area of 300 sq m (3,228 sq ft) and a capacity of 153 seats. Starbucks, which opened its first Romanian outlet in April 2007 in Bucharest, has a total of 16,000 coffee shops in 44 countries around the world. In Romania the chain is operated under a franchise system by Greek Marinopoulos.The group has recently announced its plan to close down 500 low-profit coffee shops globally and dismiss 12,000 employees, representing 7% of its global personnel. Starbucks said that 70% of the outlets scheduled to be closed down have been opened from 2006 to the present date.
Dynegy plans to layoff employees from its energy trading business and also from its Houston based headquarters.

Dynegy Inc. announced that it would close its energy trading operation and revamp its business as part of an effort to cope with declining prices, a junk credit rating and a stock price that has fallen more than 98 percent over the last year. 

The company also announced that its president and chief operating officer, Steve Bergstrom, who was a candidate to become chief executive, would resign. Dynegy's announcement warned of layoffs in the coming months but did not provide details.

Dynegy Inc. reported that it will mothball its plant in eastern Illinois in the first part of 2011. The company reported the Vermilion Power Generation Facility near Oakwood, Ill., will be closed for an undetermined amount of time because of fuel costs, its small size and fuel supply. The company reported the next step is suspending operations in a safe manner and a workforce reduction. The facility employs about 50 people. The company has eight power generation facilities and employs nearly 700 people in Illinois.

Dynegy officially closes the Morro Bay Power Plant. The company has made no formal plans about its future intentions for the site. But the corporation is seriously exploring the idea of building a wave energy farm that would transfer power from an offshore facility to existing transmission lines at the plant.

Dynegy's 1,488 MW coal-fired Brayton Point power plant in Somerset of US state Massachusetts will be closed on June 1, 2017. Dynegy is working with the town, its union partners and the community to complete the power plant shut down process smoothly. The decision to close the power plant was taken in 2013 before Dynegy acquired it from Equipower in April 2015. The four units of the power plant used to electrify about 1.5 million households when operated at full capacity. This is the last coal-fired power plant in US state Massachusetts.

Caraustar Industries Inc. announced the closure of the Charlotte, NC folding carton plant of the Custom Packaging Group and the Georgetown, KY plastics plant of the Industrial & Consumer Products Group. Customers of these facilities will be served by other Caraustar operations, with the Randleman, NC and Kingston Springs, TN carton plants handling Charlotte Carton Plant customers and the Paragon Plastics plant in Union, SC assuming Georgetown Plastics Plant customers. The closure of these two facilities is part of the previously announced initiative to right-size operations to better utilize capacity and achieve greater cost efficiencies. Associated with these closures, Caraustar will incur total costs of approximately $3.2 million. Of the total costs, $1.1 million will be a restructuring charge consisting of severance and other contractual obligations accrued as of June 30, 2004.
Caraustar Industries Inc. plans to close its folding carton plant in Mentor, eliminating 110 jobs.

On December 9, 2008, Caraustar Industries Inc. announced that it is finalizing and will complete a restructuring plan, including reductions among corporate staff. To date, the company has eliminated 49 positions, with projected annual pre-tax savings of $7.0 million. The Company will incur approximately $2.8 million in costs associated with this restructuring activity, which costs are comprised primarily of severance and other employee related items. The Company expects to complete its corporate reductions on or before the end of the first quarter of 2009.The company announced the resignations of Thomas C. Dawson, Jr., Vice President, Mill Group and John R. Foster, Vice President, Sales & Marketing. The Executives resignations will be effective December 31, 2008.
KEMET Corp. has announced more than 2,300 job cuts in response to the slowdown. Another leading parts maker, Pennsylvania- based Vishay, cut 6,000 of its 23,000 workers in 2001.

KEMET Corp. reduced its work force by another 300 employees during the second quarter ending Sept.30, according to the company's quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The total number of employees was reduced to 6,200 as of Sept. 30, compared with 6,500 shortly after the quarter ending June 30, according to the filing.

Kemet reiterated in the filing that it expects sales for the third quarter to be flat compared with second-quarter sales of $113.1 million. In the year-ago third quarter, Kemet posted sales of $117.3 million.

Kemet Corp. announced that it will cut another 10% from its work force worldwide. The electronic components company said it would cut 820 workers and take a $5.5 million charge against earnings. The company said the cuts will save it $11.1 million a year. The company in April said 7,000 of its 8,800 workers work in Mexico. It has 1,400 U.S. workers and 300 in China.

KEMET Corporation announced a reduction in force that will impact approximately 150 jobs worldwide, the majority of which are in the United States. The restructuring will result in annual savings of approximately $8 million.

KEMET Corp. announced a cost-reduction initiative in its Monterrey, Mexico, facilities that will reduce headcount by approximately 400 people. This will be accomplished through a combination of normal attrition, release of temporary employees, and a reduction-in-force affecting approximately 120 people. The cost associated with the reduction-in-force will be approximately $800,000, with a savings of over $4 million per year.
KEMET Corp. announced that it is cutting about 420 jobs to help it to return to profitability. The job cuts amount to about 4% of the company's workforce.

PeopleSoft Inc. said it will shed up to 1,000 employees or nearly 8 percent of its work force, during the next year as it tries to squeeze more profits from its $1.8 billion acquisition of Denver-based J.D. Edwards & Co. The streamlining will eliminate 750 to 1,000 jobs from a work force of about 13,000 employees. It layoffs will be concentrated in the administrative and marketing divisions.
Chart Industries Inc. has announced that it has closed its Denver-East plant as a part of its plan to cut costs.

Compuware Corp. has cut more than 1,500 employees as part of the software company's restructuring plan put into effect earlier this year, according to a filing Thursday with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The 1,528 job cuts through Oct. 31 represent more than 13 percent of the Farmington Hills-based company's global work force before its restructuring began. Over the summer, the company said that its job cuts had totaled 1,282 as of June 30.

Compuware Corp. announced that it is to cut 245 jobs, all outside its Detroit headquarters, will cost the technology company a one-time charge of $21 million. Going forward, eliminating positions at offices in San Diego, Merrimack, New Hampshire and Amsterdam -- more than 3% of the total workforce -- should save Compuware $25 million annually. Programming work in those three offices will be moved to Detroit and Poland. The realignment is part of Compuware's on-going efforts to reduce costs.

IAC/InterActiveCorp shutting down its native advertising unit nRelate, an online seller of content-recommendation ad inventory, effective Dec. 31, 2014. nRelate's assets will be incorporated into other IAC businesses. The company is aiming to transition nRelate's workers into its other content units.

HPE is planning to cut around 1,000 Enterprise Services jobs in the UK. The bulk of the cuts, around 780 jobs, will come at the Infrastructure Technology Outsourcing (ITO) unit. Staff in the UK were sent a memo on 04 March about the workforce reduction planned to take effect by the end of April, which marks the end of HPE's fiscal second quarter.

Four Corners Property Trust, Inc. announced to closed on the purchase of five restaurant properties from Washington Prime Group Inc. (WPG?. This is the second closing of the acquisition previously announced in September 2017. Closing of the remaining properties is expected to be completed throughout the remainder of 2018 based on the timing of parcelization of each respective property, subject to remaining due diligence and customary closing conditions. The purchase price for the five properties was approximately $9.5 million and represents a capitalization rate consistent with investment thresholds and past transactions. The leases have a current weighted average remaining term of approximately 8.6 years. Four of the five properties are ground leases (i.e., the tenant built its own building with ownership reverting to the landlord upon lease expiry).

Chesapeake Energy Corp. confirmed on September 19, 2013 that some laid-off employees have received worker adjustment and retraining notification act (WARN) notices. The notices are required when a company eliminates either one-third of its employee base in a community or at least 500 people. The company had more than 4,700 employees in Oklahoma City as of Jan. 31. The company has not yet filed a WARN notice with the Oklahoma department of commerce, indicating it has not yet reached the trigger amount. About 1,250 the company employees last year became access midstream partners employees following the company spin off. The company still reported 12,000 employees this spring. Since 2007, the company has received more than $28.8 million from the state quality jobs program. With $8.27 million in the most recent fiscal year, the company received more quality jobs money than any other company in the state. The company also has received more than $1.9 million over the past two years from Oklahoma City's General Obligation Limited Tax (GOLT) bond program. The company is due to receive up to another $1.5 million. If the companys annual average Oklahoma City employment drops below 3,984, the company would forgo the remaining GOLT money, said Brent Bryant, Oklahoma City's economic development program manager.

Chesapeake Energy Corp. announced that it was laying off 740 employees, most of them at its Oklahoma City headquarters, after the company reported a second-quarter loss of more than $4 billion in August. The company said the layoffs represent about 15% of its workforce, cuts that will hit hardest at the company's Oklahoma City office, where more than 560 people lost their jobs. Following the layoffs, the oil and natural gas producer will still employ about 4,000 people, including about 2,500 in Oklahoma City.

Cree Inc. will close an unprofitable silicon RF and microwave semiconductor plant in California to focus on silicon carbide and gallium nitride RF and microwave products. A subsidiary, Cree Microwave Inc., runs the Sunnyvale plant, which makes silicon microwave chips using laterally diffused metal oxide semiconductor(LDMOS) technology. Cree Microwave will accept last-time-buy orders for silicon LDMOS products through this month and close the facility in December. Cree reportedly plans to lay off 80 employees in Sunnyvale.

Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced that, the company is to close its Darlington distribution centre, with the loss of 160 jobs. The closure of the Faverdale depot, due in late summer, follows the relocation of Savers' head offices in Darlington to Croydon with the loss of 83 jobs in October last year. The company said at the time there were no plans to close the depot. All staff will be given the opportunity to relocate to distribution centres such as Dunstable or Pontefract, complete with relocation package, or redeploy to high street stores.

Actavis will shutter its manufacturing plant in Lincolnton, ending more than 300 jobs. The operation will wind down gradually, with the closure scheduled to be completed by mid-2015. The site's production of prescription medication will be shifted to an Actavis plant in Salt Lake City. The Lincolnton plant is in the Indian Creek Industrial Park.

Intuit Inc., has to cut staff and other costs to make its guidance through 2005. Intuit Canada reported that it had cut staff by a net 5% in Edmonton and Calgary to provide better execution for its customers. Some jobs were lost, mostly in the sales department, and others added in different areas for a net loss of 16 employees, leaving a total of 306.

Intuit Inc. has laid off about 32 workers from its Tucson call center, 2800 E. Commerce Center Place. The company previously laid off 80 workers in March 2006. The center has about 1,200 full-time-equivalent jobs.

Intuit told its employees that it will be laying off 249 employees as it transforms from a desktop software firm to a cloud-driven operation. The company detailed the plans to employees via internal communications. Eight Intuit employees will be affected in the Dallas-Fort Worth market. The layoffs will be focused on the company's small business group. They follow the June layoffs of 399 employees.

Shoe Carnival Inc. announced that sales for the 52-week 2004 fiscal year increased 5.8% to $590.2 million from sales of $557.9 million for the 2003 fiscal year. Comparable store sales decreased 0.8% for the 52-week period.

The Company also announced the closing of one store in Wyoming, MI during January 2005. 

In addition, the company announced that the first store opening of fiscal 2005 occurred in Chicago, Illinois.

Shoe Carnival, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended October 28, 2017. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $287,469,000 compared to $274,524,000 a year ago. Operating income was $17,880,000 compared to $15,452,000 a year ago. Net income was $10,697,000 or $0.66 per basic and diluted share compared to $9,672,000 or $0.54 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Income before income taxes was $17,824,000 compared to $15,410,000 a year ago. For the nine months, the company reported net sales of $775,922,000 compared to $766,901,000 a year ago. Operating income was $37,531,000 compared to $39,397,000 a year ago. Net income was $22,824,000 or $1.38 per basic and diluted share compared to $24,437,000 or $1.31 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $8,964,000 compared to $21,452,000 a year ago. Purchases of property and equipment was $16,708,000 compared to $17,426,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $37,286,000 compared to $39,276,000 a year ago. For the fiscal year 2017, the company expects net sales to be in the range of $1.020 billion to $1.025 billion, with comparable store sales flat to up low single digits. Fiscal 2016 earnings per diluted share were $1.28 and adjusted earnings per diluted share were $1.40. Capital expenditures for fiscal 2017, including the actual expenditures during the first nine months of the year, are expected to be $20 million to $21 million. The company expects its tax rate to be approximately 38.8%. The company raised its previous earnings guidance, and now expect earnings per diluted share of $1.42 to $1.49 compared to its previous expectation of $1.35 to $1.45.The company expects to open 19 stores and close 26 stores during fiscal 2017 compared to opening 19 stores and closing nine stores during fiscal 2016.
Microchip Technology Inc. has announced that it plans to cut approximately 140 jobs and close a factory, as concerns about the war in Iraq and the spread of a respiratory illness reduced demand.

Microchip Technology Inc. plans to cut about 400 employees, or 12% of its global work force to improve its operations. The company also announced it will reduce wafer capacity at two facilities in Arizona due to an economic slowdown.

Chico's plans to increase the rate of its domestic store closures in an effort 'to improve the overall productivity of its store fleet'. It expects to close approximately 120 stores starting in fiscal 2015 through 2017, a move expected to result in expense savings of approximately $55.2 million upon completion. In fiscal 2015, the company plans to close approximately 35 stores. The restructuring plan announced on February 26, 2015 also includes the elimination of approximately 240 existing jobs, expected to result in approximately $38 million of annualized savings.

Chico's FAS Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 30, 2016. For the year, the company reported total net sales of $2,642,309,000 against $2,675,211,000 a year ago. Loss from operations was $13,084,000 against income from operations of $116,343,000 a year ago. Loss before income taxes was $14,954,000 against income before income taxes of $116,441,000 a year ago. Net income was $1,946,000 against $64,641,000 a year ago. Diluted net income per common and common equivalent share was $0.01 against $0.42 a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was $196,991,000 against $282,483,000 a year ago. Purchases of property and equipment, net were $84,841,000 against $119,817,000 a year ago. Non-GAAP net income was $105,896,000 against $111,925,000 a year ago. Non-GAAP net income per diluted share was $0.75 against $0.73 a year ago. For the quarter, the company reported total net sales of $627,400,000 against $656,907,000 a year ago. Loss from operations was $14,442,000 against $36,453,000 a year ago. Loss before income taxes was $14,891,000 against $36,430,000 a year ago. Net loss was $21,091,000 against $31,830,000 a year ago. Diluted net loss per common and common equivalent share was $0.16 against $0.21 a year ago. Non-GAAP net income was $6,191,000 against $10,907,000 a year ago. Non-GAAP net income per diluted share was $0.05 against $0.07 a year ago. Capital expenditures totaled $18 million in the fourth quarter, mostly from a mix of investments in the stores and technology.The company provided earnings guidance for the year 2016. For the year, the company anticipates flat to slightly negative comparable sales, with more opportunity for positive growth in the back half of the year. The company estimates capital expenditures will be between $75 million to $80 million.The company also expects to open approximately 25 stores, while closing an additional 50 stores in a move to reduce costs.For the quarter, the company announced goodwill and i

Gymboree Corp. reported sales results for the month of September 2006. The company said its September sales at stores open at least one year rose 20%. Total net sales for the five-weeks ended September 30 rose 25% to $84.1 million.The company also said it plans to close its Janeville division, including all of the division's 17 store locations, by the end of the current fiscal year. As a result, the company said it expects to take a third-quarter pre-tax charge of approximately $8 million, or 16 cents a share. In addition, the company expects to take an additional pre-tax charge of $6 million and reduced gross margin, or 11 cents a share, due to the closure.The company reaffirmed earnings guidance for the third quarter and full year 2006. Excluding the charges and lost gross margin, the company said it still expects earnings of 53 to 55 cents a share for the third quarter.
For the full year, the company still expects earnings of $1.67 to $1.70 a share.

During fiscal 2015, The Gymboree Corporation continues to plan to open approximately 12 stores.During fiscal 2015, the company expects to close approximately 30 to 40 stores.The company reported consolidated unaudited earnings results for the first quarter ended May 2, 2015. For the period, the company reported net sales were $276.1 million, compared to $272.0 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2014. Adjusted EBITDA was $15.6 million compared to $22.0 million for the first quarter of fiscal 2014. Adjusted EBITDA is estimated to be negatively impacted by approximately $6 million in the first quarter as a result of the west coast port slowdown and net loss attributable to the company for the quarter was $23 million compared to $13.4 million for the same quarter of fiscal 2014. Capital expenditures were $3.1 million compared with $9.353 million for the same period last year. Loss before income taxes was $20.520 million compared with $14.627 million for the same period last year. Operating income was $0.647 million compared with $6.068 million for the same period last year. Net cash used in operating activities was $2.639 million compared with $14.683 million for the same period last year.For the full year, the company continues to expect adjusted EBITDA to be in the range of $95 million to $105 million, which includes the net impact to adjusted EBITDA of approximately $10 million to $12 million resulting from the west coast port slowdown in the first half of the year. Based on this guidance, the company expects to have sufficient liquidity during fiscal 2015 to service its debt and invest in the business to drive long-term growth. During fiscal 2015, the company continues to anticipate spending approximately $25 million to $30 million for capital expenditures.

Gymboree Corp. plans to close 350 of its children's clothing stores across the U.S. as it continues to restructure. The closings will be mainly in its Gymboree and Crazy 8 brands. The company also operates the Janie and Jack brand. Local stores that will close include the Gymboree stores at the Chesterfield Mall, the Meadows at Lake St. Louis, Mid Rivers Mall in Missouri and the Gymboree store in St. Clair Square in Fairview Heights in Illinois. The Crazy 8 store in the Chesterfield Mall will also be closing. Closing sales at the affected stores are slated to start on July 18, 2017.

Gymboree Corp. will close four stores in Central Florida, including three Gymboree stores at malls in Altamonte Springs, Oviedo and Sanford and a Crazy 8 store at Millenia Crossing. The closings are among 350 nationwide.

Gymboree Corp. plans to close 350 of its children's clothing stores across the U.S. as it continues to restructure. The closings will be mainly in its Gymboree and Crazy 8 brands, the retailer announced Tuesday. Gymboree Corp. also operates the Janie and Jack brand. According to the Boston Globe, the local stores that will close include: Crazy 8 at Tower Shops at 1976 South University Drive in Davie; Gymboree at 801 North Congress Ave. in Boynton Beach; Gymboree at Delray Marketplace at 9173 Atlantic Ave. in Delray Beach; Gymboree at Galleria at 2318 E. Sunrise Blvd. in Fort Lauderdale; and Gymboree at CityPlace at 700 South Rosemary Ave. in West Palm Beach.

Fossil Group announced that it is cutting staff at its Richardson headquarters. The company declined to say how many jobs were being eliminated, but did say the affected workers are receiving severance benefits. The layoffs affected employees across Fossil's global organization.
Sanmina Corporation plans several facilities, putting 265 employees out of work. The closings will take place at two of the company's circuit board facilities in New Hampshire.
Sanmina-SCI announced that the company plans to lay off about 125 employees, or 25 percent of its workforce, at its plant on Civic Center Drive.

A California based electronics manufacturer has delayed plans to shut down its local plant until late May, a company official said Tuesday. Sanmina-SCI Corp. plans to shut down its Augusta facility gradually, with 320 workers remaining on the job through mid-March, said Dana Berry, the firm's human resources director. By the end of March, 200 employees should still be on the job, and by the end of April only 50 should be left, the Kennebec Journal reported.

Sanmina-SCI Corporation a major electronics contract manufacturer and serves larger manufacturers in the automotive, communications, computing, defense and aerospace markets announced that it will shut its Lynchburg operation, leaving 330 employees jobless.
Sanmina-SCI has laid off 99 employees, or 9 percent of its workforce, at its electronics plant 80 miles south of Denver.
Sanmina-SCI Corp. has laid off about 90 workers at its printed circuit board plant in Owego. Affected workers can receive partial unemployment insurance benefits to supplement their lost wages.
Sanmina-SCI Corp. has told local labour authorities of plans to lay off 550 staff at its plant in the Hungarian city of Tatabanya.
On February 25, Sanmina-SCI Corp. announced it was laying off 130 employees at its factory in the north Cork town.

Royal Caribbean will lay off about 100 employees at its Miami offices, include the head of global sales and marketing and other spread across different levels and departments within the company.The company also reported that head of global sales and marketing, Lisa Bauer role is being eliminated. Since the company will not replace Bauer, Royal Caribbean International president and CEO Adam Goldstein will resume all of her responsibilities.
PolyOne announced that it will cut 135 jobs.

Polyone Corp. announced that it is realigning certain of its manufacturing assets, primarily in North America. Over the next nine months, the Company will close certain production facilities, including seven in North America, and one in the United Kingdom, resulting in a net reduction of approximately 150 positions. Production at the affected facilities, as well as several manufacturing lines, will be moved to a limited number of the Company's more than 30 remaining plants. PolyOne expects no disruption of service, due to the Company's focus on improved product delivery systems and inventory management. As a result of these actions, PolyOne expects to incur one-time charges of approximately $31 million, of which approximately $18 million are expected to be non-cash. These one-time charges will include costs related to severance and asset write-downs, which will be included in the Company's financial results over the next three quarters. The Company also expects to invest approximately $12 million in additional capital expenditures at its remaining locations to support these changes.

Polyone Corp. will close its Macedonia engineered-materials plant, which employs about 45. The closing is part of a manufacturing realignment. The Avon Lake company had said about 240 positions are being eliminated in connection with eight plant closings, six in the United States and one each in Canada and England. Also to be closed is an operation in Avon Lake called Building 452 that is part of the company's vinyl compound complex. It will displace 30 to 40 workers. All closings are expected to be completed by March 31.

PolyOne Corp. announced plans to close six of the plants it recently acquired as part of its purchase of Spartech Corp. The plants to be closed are in Warsaw, Ind.; Evanston, Ill.; Portage, Wis.; Cape Girardeau, Mo.; Donora, Pa.; and Lake Charles, La. The closings will eliminate about 250 jobs and produce $25 million in annual savings for PolyOne. The closings are expected to be completed by the end of 2014. The Warsaw and Evanston plants make sheet, while the Portage plant makes packaging, primarily film. The Cape Girardeau and Donora plants make color and engineered materials. The Lake Charles plant does contract manufacturing, although the firm declined to specify what products are made there.

PolyOne plans to close its engineered thermoplastic materials facility in Wichita, Kansas. The Wichita facility is a former Spartech plant. The latest plant closure is part of PolyOne's effort to 'right-size manufacturing footprint'.

Jabil Circuit Inc. is cutting jobs in Michigan as part of a company-wide effort to reduce costs. Jabil announced in December layoffs that were planned as it restructured in the face of the recession and it was company policy not to disclose the scope of any layoffs.

For the first quarter of fiscal year 2002, Jabil reported its revenues dropped 22 percent to $885 million. Its net income dropped 82 percent to 4 cents per share from 24 cents per share in the same quarter in fiscal year 2001.

Jabil Circuits Inc. announced that it could lay off more than 1,000 workers in Hungary if it decides to consolidate its operations in the country, moving production at its base in Szombathely, near the border with Austria, to Tiszaujvaros, in the East of Hungary. The company announced that it had already started talks with workers on offering them work at other Jabil Circuits plants. It noted that the plant's closure was made as a matter of business necessity.
Jabil Circuit Inc. will close its plant in the southwestern Hungarian city of Szombathely, and will lay off 1,070 employees.

Jabil Circuit Inc. announced 120 local job cuts. That's about 6.5% of the local work force. In making the cuts, the company has cited a downturn in business among customers that hire Jabil to assemble their electronic goods. The cuts come at a delicate time locally for Jabil.

More than 300 employees will lose their jobs when Jabil Circuit Inc. shut its Billerica manufacturing plant later this year. Layoff are expected to occur in waves during the next six months. The company announced in late January that it would be cutting 3,000 jobs, or nearly 4% of its work force, because of a weak global economy.

Jabil Circuit Inc. announced that it expects to have to lay off 2,500 employees as part of its restructuring plan that will have a $64 million impact to its bottom line. That's 500 workers less than what it expected to cut at the beginning of the year when it planned to pay $65 million in restructuring and impairment costs.

Jabil Circuit Inc. announced that it would reduce its employee head count by 4,500 as part of the restructuring plan unveiled last January with a cash expenditure of $57.4 million. The original plan was to cut 3,000 positions in order to reduce operating expenses. The revised plan calls for $64 million of restructuring and impairment charges through the fiscal year. That includes $47.3 million in exit or disposal activity costs and $6.4 million in fixed asset impairment costs.
Jabil Circuit announced that the company has laid off about 400 employees worldwide, close to 100 of them in St. Petersburg. The layoffs began last week.

Jabil is cutting its workforce to trim about $50 million in expenses as the coronavirus pandemic pushes up its costs by up to $170 million. Nor did he say whether the reductions would be temporary or where they would take place.Jabil went into the pandemic with 225,000 employees at 100 sites in about 30 different countries, with more than 100,000 workers in China alone.Those factories turn out a huge range of iPhone components, cameras, appliances, medical devices, 3D printers, data centers, product packaging, and other products for customers such as Amazon, Apple, Cisco Systems, GoPro, Hewlett-Packard, LM Ericsson and Nokia Networks.After the virus exploded early this year, Jabil shifted production at its 36 health care plants to make everything from hand sanitizer and ventilators to reusable N95 masks and testing kits. The St. Petersburg-based company had $6.3 billion in revenues during March, April and May, up more than 3 percent from the same three months in 2019.Revenue generated by manufacturing electronics, which accounts for two-thirds of Jabil's revenues, dropped 2 percent.Meanwhile, revenue for manufacturing other consumer and industrial products, including health care equipment and supplies, rose 13%. Along with health care, Jabil saw strong demand for packaging, cloud computing equipment, routers and mobile devices.

Titan International Inc. announced that it experienced a loss in Australia. The Australian iron ore markets are halved and are continuing to remain weak. But the bottom line is it needs to do better there and it will be better with this business and how its manage it through this downturn. The company is in the midst of a restructuring plan that will reduce headcount by 25% there.
Allstate Corp. announced that it closing its insurance claims office in Lincoln due to the financial crisis.

Papa John's International Inc. will cut 70 jobs in the fourth quarter, partly due to the pizza industry's sluggish growth and higher costs for ingredients, fuel and other expenses.

The company now expects to earn 65 cents to 69 cents in the fourth quarter, down from its previous forecast of 68 cents to 72 cents. 

For the year, the new guidance is for a profit of $2.17 to $2.21 per share, down from $2.20 to $2.24 per share.

Papa John's International Inc. has laid off 30 people from its corporate headquarters in Louisville. The company said that 15 people were laid off in corporate support and 15 in the company's printing and promotions subsidiary.

Libbey Inc. announced additional layoffs of salaried workers, changes to the retirement benefits of U.S. salaried workers, and changes in some retirees' health-care benefits. In July, the company announced that it would cut about 5% of its global managerial, professional, and administrative work force. On September 13, 2012, it changed that to 9%, including the reduction announced in July. The exact number of people affected was unavailable. As of Jan. 1, 2013, the company will freeze company contributions to its cash balance pension plan for U.S. salaried workers. Pension plan participants will retain their accrued pension benefits. The company announced it would offer salaried associates an improved 401(k) benefit that includes an increased company match. Effective Dec. 31, the company also will end its health-care benefit for salaried retirees who are 65 and older and instead provide a Retiree Health Reimbursement Arrangement that supports retirees in purchasing a Medicare plan. The staffing and benefits changes would reduce annual expenses by more than $10 million a year.

On July 8, 2020, Libbey Inc. announcing a tentative plan to close its manufacturing facility in Shreveport, Louisiana. Whether and the extent to which the tentative plan is finalized and implemented will depend on the outcome of negotiations with the unions representing the companys employees.
Simon Worldwide Inc. has laid off 380 employees, about 95 percent of its workforce, because of the controversy over some game contests.

The Brink's Company announced that planed to restructure its Netherlands operations in response to a loss of business with Rabobank. The restructuring plan includes the potential closure of three branches and a workforce reduction of approximately 600 employees.

Flyi Inc. announced it completed a financial restructuring plan under which it will cut its fleet of regional jets and reduce its workforce in return for tens of millions of dollars in concessions from creditors. After almost four months of negotiations, Flyi said it will be allowed to terminate leases on 24 of its regional jets -- about one-third of its fleet. Those concessions will help cut its aircraft lease payments by $94.5 million over the next two years. Flyi's workforce is also being cut -- from 4,300 full-time equivalent positions last fall to 3,350 this spring. 

Flyi also said it was given a five-year, $16.1 million loan from GE Capital Aviation Services Inc. In exchange for the concessions from its creditors, which Flyi did not name, the airline agreed to issue them about 8.3 million shares of stock. The company said that under an agreement with GE Capital Aviation Services it may have to turn in eight more regional aircraft if certain financial milestones are not met this year and in the first quarter of 2006.
Flyi Inc., parent of Independence Air announced that it will discontinue flights because of its continued financial challenges.
About 116 jobs are expected to be cut when Borg-Warner Inc. closes its Hall County plant June 14, the Georgia Department of Labor reported.

BorgWarner Inc. announced that it is in the process of reducing its North American workforce by approximately 850 people, or 13%, spread across its 19 operations in the U.S., Canada and Mexico. The reductions are driven by recent customer volume decreases and restructurings, and are expected to be substantially completed by the end of October.

The company also revised its full-year 2006 earnings guidance down to $3.95 to $4.10 per share due to the significant recent customer volume declines and a greater-than-expected impact from higher commodity prices. The range excludes a one-time cost of approximately $0.15 per share related to the restructuring. Previous guidance was $4.35-$4.60 per share for the full year.

The company still expects to grow company-wide 2006 sales at the low end of its original guidance of 5% to 7% and be back on track for 7% to 9% growth in 2007.

BorgWarner Inc. announced that 90 employees were laid off. The layoffs are part of the company's nationwide restructuring plan. The cause for the additional layoffs is part of the larger economic picture.

BorgWarner Inc. plans to eliminate 1,250 jobs. This total represents nearly 20% of BorgWarner's North American workforce, and is 250 jobs higher than the figure previously announced by the company in July.

BorgWarner Inc. announced to incur a $34 million charge in cash expenditure towards the already-announced closure of its Muncie, Indiana plant in the United States. The company had issued a final notice to its employees at its Muncie plant about the closure of the plant in the next couple of months.

BorgWarner Inc. announced that it is looking to shut down two technical hubs in central Indiana and merge them into a newly built $15 million facility in Noblesville that will house over 300 high-wage workers. Company reported its plans to start transferring operations from facilities in Anderson and Pendleton after the 100,000-square-foot, two-story facility in Noblesville is concluded in early 2018. Building work is expected to start in June. To be sited on the southeast corner of 141st Street and Olio Road, the building, will be used for research, development and testing, and for the generation of propulsion-system products for combustion, hybrid and electric vehicles. Product lines include starters, alternators and electrification technologies.
