The firm said it will invest a further $13 million to buy machinery and equipment that will be installed in the center over the next five years.
Spartan Stores Inc. announced that it will close its only Toledo area distribution warehouse for the groceries, eliminating 150 jobs within 60 days. The warehouse is at 1020 Ford St. in Maumee.

Spartan Stores Inc. will close three Food Town stores in Ohio next week as part of its ongoing efforts to dispose of the supermarket chain, but it is unclear whether the stores will stay shuttered or be sold and reopened under a new name. An official at the Food Town at 1415 Byrne Rd. in Toledo's Southland Shopping Center confirmed that the store will close, but no other information was available on the store's future.

Spartan Stores Inc. announced plans to save up to $3 million a year by consolidating warehouse operations and shedding 25 office jobs. Spartan announced it eliminated about 25 administrative support staff positions at its headquarters. Some employees could be offered other positions. The company revised earnings guidance for the third quarter of fiscal 2010. The company warned third-quarter results would be weaker than expected. The company predicts third-quarter earnings of 21 cents to 25 cents per share.
ARRIS announced that it took several actions to reduce its breakeven point, including a reduction in workforce by approximately 70 employees.

Arris Group Inc. has reduced its head count by 500 to 6,500, but the company said that few of the people let go worked in Horsham, Pa. The job cuts had been expected since Arris bought Motorola Home from Google Inc. for $2.35 billion in April. Arris began notifying employees of the cuts two weeks ago. Employees being let go are receiving severance packages and outplacement services.

ARRIS Group Inc. has reported 195 layoffs to the state of Arizona. The company is closing customer service centers in Phoenix and Tempe. ARRIS will no longer provide customer care services to AT&T and plans to transition support through November 30, 2016.

Meta Financial Group, Inc. announced the layoff of 40 employees in its Meta Payment Systems division as part of new cost-cutting program and more than half of those jobs are in Sioux Falls. Meta Financial Group said this plan demanded the cuts to curb costs. The company said the reduction would affect 40 employees in the product development and research division of Meta Payment Services. Of those jobs, 25 are in Sioux Falls and the rest are in other locations throughout the company.

Keurig Green Mountain, Inc. announced that it will lay off more than 300 employees companywide after sales of coffee brewers and accessories plunged. The company plans to cut $300 million in costs over the next three years, with about $100 million in savings in fiscal 2016.

Keurig Green Mountain will cut 108 jobs in Vermont as a result of discontinuing the Keurig Kold system, which failed to fully deliver on consumer expectations.The company announced it had hired a new chief executive officer, promoting then-CEO Brian Kelley to vice chairman of the board. The new CEO is Bob Gamgort, formerly CEO of Pinnacle Foods, Inc. in Parsippany, New Jersey.
Keurig Green Mountain laid off approximately 130 employees in the week. Of those laid off, 40 were in Vermont and were primarily salaried and administrative workers.

Monaco Coach Corp. to cut 600 jobs in Oregon and Indiana. The layoffs represent about 12% of its workforce and the cuts are roughly equal in both states. The job cuts affect administrative and production employees and are effective immediately.

Monaco Coach Corp. has provided termination notices to the majority of its remaining workforce while it continues to seek additional financing or capital or a corporate transaction. Most of the separated employees had already been on furlough since mid-December 2008. In its notice to employees, the company noted that absent consummation of a sale or obtaining additional financing or capital, it may ultimately be forced to shut down operations.

Barnes & Noble Inc. will close its Montgomery store at the end of June. The store is in the Montgomery Towne Center shopping center at the intersection of the Eastern Boulevard and Troy Highway. The center has been declining for years, and the company said that is one of the main reasons it decided to leave.
Barnes & Noble, Inc. announced that the last book store in Laredo would close.
Barnes & Noble, Inc. is cutting back in New York. The company will close its store at Broadway and 66th Street near Lincoln Center in January 2011.
Barnes & Noble, Inc. announced that it will close its stores in Calabasas and Encino at year's end as re-evaluates its business model.

Barnes & Noble will close its doors this week and another anchor store, DSW Shoe Warehouse, is set to close in January. Store officials indicated that the foreclosure figured into the decision, but declined to elaborate. DSW Shoe Warehouse, the center's remaining anchor store, is set to close by Jan. 15, 2011. Barnes & Noble and DSW Shoe Warehouse will likely have the option of moving to the Westfield Eastland shopping center just north of the 10 Freeway.
Barnes & Noble, Inc. has three stores in the Albany, N.Y., region. The Saratoga Springs store is scheduled to be closed.

Barnes & Noble has closed its store at the Pruneyard Shopping Center. This follows news that another Barnes & Noble at Westgate Center was also slated to close in January. The company has been shuttering stores around the country as it focuses more on its Nook tablet business.

Barnes & Noble, Inc. announced that it will be closing 30% of their brick-and-mortar stores over the next ten years. They will be putting a greater emphasis on e-books and online sales. Barnes & Noble's announcement represents a trend in the book world, readers are buying books online leading to the decline of brick-and-mortar bookstores and more readers are purchasing e-books.

Barnes & Noble is closing its store at Mohawk Commons in Niskayuna, NY. Niskayuna's building department was told the bookstore will be closing and the 24,000-square-foot store divided into three retail spaces.
Barnes & Noble plan to close 13 consumer stores this fiscal year instead of 20.
Ultratech Stepper Inc. announced that it will be reducing its workforce by about 100 positions, representing 20% of its staff. It will also be consolidating and exiting certain operations.
Ultratech Stepper Inc. has announced that it plans to reduce its global workforce by about 50 positions, approximately 15 percent of its workforce, as a part of its cost-reduction plan.

Ultratech Stepper Inc. announced it has implemented a cost-reduction plan in response to the continuing weakness in the semiconductor industry. The company plans to reduce its global workforce by about 50 positions, or approximately 15 percent.
Ultratech Inc. announced that it plans to cut 10% of its employees and closed some sales offices as it lowered its outlook.

Belden Inc. announced that it will close its telecommunications cable plant in Kingston, Ontario, by September 2003 and will take several additional actions to adjust the Company's product lines and capacity. The products currently manufactured in the Kingston plant will be transferred to other Belden facilities, principally Belden's communications plant in Phoenix, Arizona.

Belden Inc. will lay off more than 400 employees as it closes a plant in Kingston, Ontario, and quits some unprofitable product lines because of weakness in telecommunications and technology changes, the wire and cable company said. The plant closing and other changes will result in the layoff of about 200 people in Kingston and another 225 in Europe and Australia. In Kingston, about 140 workers were eligible for early retirement.
Belden Incorporated has announced that it will close its electronic cable plants in Australia and Germany.

Belden Inc. announced plans to cease production activities at one of its manufacturing plants located in Leominster, Massachusetts by July 2010. The facility manufactures wire and cable products for enterprise applications throughout the United States. The production will be moved to other existing Belden manufacturing facilities located in Leominster, Massachusetts, Monticello, Kentucky, and Nogales, Mexico. There will be approximately 170 associates affected by these actions who will be eligible for severance benefits from the Company.
OM Group Inc. announced that the planned maintenance shutdown of its Big Hill smelter, located in Lubumbashi, Democratic Republic of the Congo, is underway.

Ultimate Electronics Inc. announced that it will close its Highlands Ranch store, February 20, 2005, just prior to the natural expiration of the store's current lease. The Highlands Ranch store opened in 1992 and is located at 8262 South University Boulevard, in Highlands Ranch, Colorado. All employees at the Highlands Ranch store will be offered positions at nearby SoundTrack stores, such as the Park Meadows store located at 9657 East County Line Road in Englewood, Colorado.

Ultimate Electronics Inc. will close its consumer electronics stores in Des Moines, Davenport and Cedar Rapids this spring as part of its bankruptcy reorganization plan. Twenty-seven other retail stores in Kansas City, South Dakota, Texas and Utah also will close, according to documents filed last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission. About 900 employees, along with 65 corporate workers, will lose their jobs as a result of the closings.

Costco Wholesale Corp. announced plans to close on July 3 its two Costco Home stores, located in Kirkland, Washington, and Tempe, Arizona. Employees at the Costco Home locations will be offered the opportunity to transfer to other local Costco warehouses. Costco Home employees at the Issaquah home offices will also be offered other opportunities within the Company.

The Credence Systems Corporation. has cut 225 jobs and reported a wider fourth-quarter loss. Credence also closed operations in Switzerland and Germany as part of a reorganization. The company said in August that it would cut 150 jobs, or 11 percent of its work force, to lower costs.

Credence Systems Corporation announced additional headcount reductions and the adoption of other cost-cutting measures as part of a continuing effort to reduce expenses and appropriately size the Company for prevailing market conditions. The reduction of force includes the elimination of approximately 173 positions or 14 percent of the Company's global employee base. Approximately 160 positions in the United States will be affected, with the remaining reductions in other locations worldwide.
Urban Outfitters, Inc. announced that it will be opening approximately 39 new stores and closing approximately 9 stores during fiscal year 2021.

Universal Forest Products Inc. announced that a Sanford facility is among six being closed across North America, which sells wood and other building products. The company also is closing a plant in Stanfield, a town about 30 miles east of Charlotte. Other affected facilities include two plants in Indiana, one in Mississippi and one in Ontario, Canada.
It was announced that JDS Uniphase Corp. will eliminate another 7,000 jobs by the end of 2001 making the total number reductions 16,000 for this year.
JDS Uniphase to close its Roanoke County office because of efforts to streamline the operations of the international public company. The company canceled its lease a couple of months ago.

Martek Biosciences Corp. announced it will suspend the manufacturing of omega fatty acids for infant formula at its plant in Winchester and reduce the company's workforce there by 100 employees. The decision was spurred by a need to reduce manufacturing costs and operating expenses.
Gateway Inc. reported larger-than-expected second-quarter loss. As a result, Gateway Inc. announced that it plans on reducing its staff, as part of the company's restructuring plan to reduce costs.
More than 900 Gateway staff members will lose their jobs in a Gateway cost cutting effort.

The layoff of 400 workers by Gateway Inc. brings to 600 the number of high-tech jobs lost in El Paso County since Jan. 1. Gateway's departure is a blow to the city's base of technical support centers, which has grown significantly in recent years after being spawned by the need for specialists at the area's military bases.
Gateway is shutting down unprofitable retail stores as part of its restructuring and cost-cutting plan.

Personal computer maker Gateway Inc. has announced plans to eliminate some 1,300 jobs to streamline manufacturing and service operations. CNET News.com reports the Poway, Calif., company notified about 850 customer service and technical support employees it would be eliminating their positions. The 850 job cuts come on top of an additional 450 layoffs announced last week, when Gateway made public a plan to close its PC manufacturing plant in Hampton, Va., and to outsource some PC manufacturing.
Gateway Inc. announced in September that it was laying off 1,800 workers nationwide.
Gateway Inc. will reduce its workforce to mid-5,000 from the current 7,400 employees.

Gateway Inc. is laying off manufacturing and technical support employees. As of July 1, Gateway had 3,400 employees nationwide. Gateway plans to end 2004 with fewer than 2,000 employees. Gateway has no plans to close its Kansas City operations but the company is putting the facility up for sale later this year. Remaining employees will be consolidated and the company hopes to lease back office space from a new owner.

Gateway Inc. announced that it has eliminated nearly 100 jobs as part of a cost-cutting effort designed to save it between $30 million and $35 million a year. The company, which also makes plasma TV sets and other electronic devices, it will take a charge in the fourth quarter for severance costs. The jobs were corporate positions, including some in the marketing, accounting and legal departments.
Macromedia Inc. announced its plans to lay off 200 employees. It also announced that it has closed some facilities.

TriQuint Semiconductor Inc. announced a reduction of 7% of its worldwide workforce. This affected about 15% of the 465 employees in Hillsboro, Oregon, where the company recently upgraded from 4-inch to 6-inch wafers. This also affected about 10% of the 425 employees in Richardson, Texas, where the company recently consolidated its Texas manufacturing facilities. TriQuint has approximately 1,600 employees worldwide. The Company expects to take a charge of approximately $0.01 per diluted share for severance related benefits for these workers in the 3rd quarter of 2002.

Eastman Chemical Co. announced that it will close its Altovar Ltd. varnish products facility in Banbury, England, and move production to Kallo, Belgium, as part of continuing efforts to consolidate manufacturing operations. 
In a press release, Eastman said it doesn't expect any material charges related to the closing, which will affect 18 employees.

Eastman Chemical Company has announced that it plans to consolidate its coatings technology organization at its Carpentersville, Ill., facility with its coatings technology organization at its headquarters site in Kingsport, cutting 50 jobs.

Eastman Chemical Co. announced it is closing its vitamin producing Peboc plant on Llangefni Industrial Estate - with the loss of 65 jobs. The closure decision follows a consultation period with employees at the Peboc site that began earlier this year. Peboc will cease production of Vitamin E immediately and them anufacture of active pharmaceutical ingredients for a major customer will finish later this year at the end of an existing contract. The company reported that it was not the case that work was being transferred overseas.

Eastman Chemical Co. announced that, it is eliminating about 40 headquarters jobs by the end of the year as it restructures and keeps its budget at current levels. The company said that, about 40 positions in non-operation departments will be cut. Some jobs will be consolidated while some others will be eliminated through attrition. The company is adjusting to changing business conditions with rising costs and global economic uncertainties.

Eastman Chemical Co. announced that, it will slash costs by more than $100 million in 2009, mostly by cutting jobs, in response to the current economic turmoil. The company said, at least $80 million of cost reductions would come from labor, including a reduction in contractors, part-time labor, management and the maximum vacation carry-over amount. The company also plans to eliminate planned wage and salary increases as well as overtime when possible.

Eastman Chemical Co. announced that it will take a $30 million charge as it cuts up to 300 jobs and reduces salaries, in an effort to trim costs and keep its dividend and lowered capital spending plans intact. This marks the second round of cost cutting in the last four months for the Kingsport, Tenn.-based maker of chemicals, coatings, adhesives and specialty plastics products. In December, it said it was reducing contractors, part-time labor, management and its maximum vacation carry-over amount. The company expects to lay off 200 to 300 employees, nearly 3% of its global work force, over the next six weeks, with most cuts coming at the company's Kingsport headquarters.
GreenPoint Financial Corp. plans to lay off 400 people and post a loss for 2001 as it shuts the unit, bought three years ago for $703 million.
Spherion Corp. announced that it is closing about 108 more field offices as a result of the economic downturn.

Spherion Corp. announced that it is cutting about 95 jobs after a client said it wouldn't renew managed services contracts that produced $75 million in revenue in 2004. Severance and restructuring costs will be about $2 million in the first quarter.
MapInfo Corp. laid off 67 employees worldwide in October due to recession.
MapInfo Corp. has announced that it has laid off 16 employees at its North Greenbush office as a part of the company's restructuring plan.
MapInfo Corp. has laid off 20 employees and eliminated another 10 vacant positions, in an attempt to return back to profitability.

As part of a restructuring, Sonic Solutions will reduce its employee and contractor workforce by approximately 100 positions, generating annual cost and operating expense savings of $14 million. The company expects to incur one-time severance and other related costs of $2.5 million.
Amvescap plc has announced that it plans to layoff about 100 employees as a part of its plan to cut costs.

Denver-based Invesco Funds Group will get a new leader and new spot on its parent company's organizational chart next year. But the name sponsor of the Denver Bronco's new football stadium should be spared the fate of the Berger Funds, another medium-sized Denver fund family that is closing its doors. AMVESCAP plc parent of Invesco Funds Group, said it will fold five divisions into two in an effort to simplify its structure and create synergies. Invesco Funds Group is one of the smallest pieces of the Amvescap empire, with $19.6 billion in assets under management. Its sister mutual fund group, Atlanta-based AIM, is nearly seven times as large with $138.4 billion.

Amvescap plc eliminated 26 jobs at the office campus at the Denver Tech Center, according to an announcement. On top of the portfolio managers who are packing their bags, 10 Invesco traders and analysts lost their jobs, according to the company.
Rock-Tenn Co. announced that it has closed plants and cut jobs because of weak demand.

Rock-Tenn Co. will close its box-folding plant and lay off about 130 employees. The company plans to close its plant on Madera Avenue later this year, saving the company about $2 million a year. Much of the business will be absorbed into its Greenville, Texas, plant.

Rock-Tenn Co. announced it will close its Knoxville box-making plant. Thirteen salaried and 75 hourly workers will lose their jobs. The company plans to end all production, sales and shipments at the Knoxville plant by the end of August.

Rock-Tenn Company will shutter its Milwaukee container facility in July, leaving 69 people without jobs. There are no bumping rights since the facility is being permanently closed. The Wisconsin Department of Workforce Development will work with the Milwaukee Area Workforce Investment Board to provide dislocated worker services.

WestRock Company announced that it is laying off 170 employees in Charlotte as it permanently closes a facility later in 2018. In a notice to the N.C. Department of Commerce, the company stated that it will begin dismissing employees Oct. 19, or within two weeks after that. WestRock listed anticipated dates for the firing of employees in specific positions at the facility, all of which fell before the end of 2018. Many of the employees who work in labor-intensive positions, including baler operators and finishing specialists, are expected to be let go in mid-October and early November. Operations-focused positions, including managers and plant supervisors, are expected to have more time, with those layoffs occurring later in November and at the start of December. Employees at the Charlotte facility will not be able to use seniority to bump employees at other WestRock facilities out of their positions. This is because they are not represented by a union. North Carolina has seen 7,852 employees laid off through WARN notices in 2018.
Ciber Inc. announced that it will be laying off 200 employees, in an effort to reduce company costs.

Shurgard Storage Centers Inc. announced that it will close two of its five Shurgard Storage To Go warehouses and restructure its management to cut overhead costs. The Company announced that it is discontinuing Storage To Go operations at its Atlanta and Orange County locations. The Company will continue to operate Storage To Go in three markets: Seattle, Portland, and Oakland.

AK Steel Holding Corp. reported a third-quarter loss of $89 million, or 82 cents a share, on an adjusted basis. This was slightly narrower than the Wall Street consensus calling for a quarterly loss of 85 cents. AK Steel's third-quarter net loss came to $277.5 million, or $2.56 per share, reflecting two noncash charges totaling $188.5 million, significantly wider than the year-earlier net loss of $3.3 million, or 3 cents. Sales slipped to $1.06 billion from the prior year's $1.12 billion.

For the nine months ended sales were $3,088.3 million and net loss was $396.5 million or $3.66 per share as compared to the sales of $3,226.8 million and net loss of $12.7 million or $0.12 per share for the same period of last year. 

The company also announced that it was eliminating the jobs of about 20% of its steel operations salaried workforce, affecting approximately 475 employees.

AK Steel Holding Corp. announced that it is implementing a salaried workforce layoff plan due to the continuing economic downturn, which has significantly impacted AK Steel's customers, resulting in fewer orders for the company's steel products. AK Steel currently employs about 1,500 salaried employees. The layoffs will likely affect salaried employees in all of the company's plants and offices. While the company announced that it hopes the layoffs are temporary, a continuation of the economic downturn could result in some or all of the layoffs becoming permanent job reductions.

AK Steel Holding Corp. announced that about 1,000 of the company's 6,500 workers have been laid off, and that number 'will probably double before things get better,'. About 106 workers are currently laid off at AK Steel's Middletown Works, and Wainscott told the Journal-News that it will take advantage of the downturn to do a multimillion-dollar maintenance job on the mill's blast furnace. That will likely idle more workers from March into April.

AK Steel Holding Corp. will likely idle most of its Ashland (KY) Works beginning late in July or early August. The idling will affect about 750 hourly and salaried employees, and is the result of recent announcements by GM and Chrysler of significant production curtailments, along with the continuing global recession. The company announced the plant is likely to remain idled at least through the balance of 2009.

Centex Construction Products Inc. announced the closing of its aggregates quarry and crushing plant in Georgetown, Texas, north of Austin. The operation is owned by CXP subsidiary Centex Materials, LP. Centex Materials, which also operates a large crushed stone operation south of Austin in Buda, is a major producer of readymix concrete and aggregates products in the Austin area.

American Eagle Outfitters, Inc. announced that it would close the 500,000-square-foot Warrendale distribution center in 2015 to get closer to its customers and serve them more quickly. The location is close to the major population centers of the East Coast and allows trucks to reach all the way up to New England in a day's drive.The company also announced that it will open a new 1-million-square-foot center in Hazleton, situated in Luzerne County in the northeastern Pennsylvania. The company expects the new Hazleton center will eventually provide more than 600 jobs, an amount said to be triple the headcount in Warrendale. Employees at the Warrendale facility will be offered jobs at the new facility or others in what's expected to be an 18 month transition process.

American Eagle Outfitters Inc. to close 150 stores as the teen retailer attempts to boost profit and evolve to respond more quickly to fashion trends.The closings are part of a strategy to cut costs at brick-and-mortar locations, shift focus toward online and mobile sales, reduce inventory and roll out fashions on a shorter turnaround.

American Eagle Outfitters, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 31, 2015. For the quarter, the company reported total net revenue was $1,071,853,000 against $1,041,707,000 a year ago. Operating income was $112,210,000 against $23,977,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $113,762,000 against $24,012,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $70,074,000 against $10,510,000 a year ago. Net income was $61,609,000 against $10,510,000 a year ago. Net income per diluted share was $0.32 against $0.05 a year ago. Adjusted EPS was $0.27 for the comparable quarter last year, an increase of 33%. Net revenue increased 3%, EPS of $0.36 increased 33%, driven by a significant reduction in markdowns.For the year, the company reported total net revenue was $3,282,867,000 against $3,305,802,000 a year ago. Operating income was $155,765,000 against $141,055,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $159,502,000 against $142,077,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $88,787,000 against $82,983,000 a year ago. Net income was $80,322,000 against $82,983,000 a year ago. Net income per diluted share was $0.42 against $0.43 a year ago. Non-GAAP basis operating income from continuing operations was $206,985,000 or $0.63 diluted income per share. Adjusted EPS from continuing operations was $0.63 for the year ended January 31, 2015, compared to adjusted EPS of $0.74 for the year ended February 1, 2014, a 15% decrease. In 2014, capital expenditures totaled $245 million. The company ended the year with no debt.The company expects first quarter 2015 EPS to be approximately $0.09 to $0.12, which includes the expected negative impact of $0.02 per share due to the West Coast port slowdown. The company expects capital expenditures to be approximately $150 million in 2015. The tax rate for 2015 is assumed around 40%.In 2015, the company plans 20 to 25 targeted openings. In 2015, the company plans close another 70 stores.

American Eagle Outfitters, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 30, 2016. For the quarter, total net revenue was $1,105,828,000 against $1,071,853,000 a year ago. Operating income was $115,636,000 against $112,210,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $113,374,000 against $113,762,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $81,706,000 or $0.42 per diluted share against $70,074,000 or $0.36 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Net income was $81,706,000 or $0.42 per diluted share against $61,609,000 or $0.32 per basic and diluted share a year ago. For the year, total net revenue was $3,521,848,000 against $3,282,867,000 a year ago. Operating income was $319,878,000 against $155,765,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $321,871,000 against $159,502,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $213,291,000 or $1.09 per diluted share against $88,787,000 or $0.45 per diluted share a year ago. Net income was $218,138,000 or $1.11 per diluted share against $80,322,000 or $0.42 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Capital expenditures were $153 million. Based on an anticipated mid-single digit increase in comparable sales, management expects first quarter 2016 EPS to be approximately $0.17 to $0.19. This guidance excludes potential asset impairment and restructuring charges, and compares to EPS of $0.15 last year.For fiscal 2016, the company expects capital expenditures to be in the range of $160 million to $170 million.The company continues to expect to meet its goal of closing 150 stores by the end of fiscal 2016.

Quintiles Transnational announced that its restructuring will cost an additional 316 jobs - bringing the number of announced layoffs since November to 546. But the pharmaceutical services company, which employs 1,100 people at its Durham headquarters and about 17,000 worldwide, said that hiring will outpace job reductions by the end of the year.

Gardner Denver Inc. announced it is laying off 41 more workers in connection with its plans to close the Thomas Products Division plant in Sheboygan, increasing the number of layoffs to about 100 and reducing employment at the plant by a third. Gardner Denver informed the state Department of Workforce Development that the latest phase of layoffs will begin Oct. 28 and continue to Nov. 11. Prior layoffs affected a total of 58 employees.

Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. cut its ranks by 500 employees including its chief investment strategist Jeffrey Applegate, a person familiar with the matter said. The companywide cuts at the New York-based investment bank, one of Wall Street's biggest, amounted to 4 percent of its total work force of 12,980 as of Sept. 30.

Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. is poised to cut a further 1,200 jobs as the struggling Wall Street brokerage tries to bolster its balance sheet by reducing costs and selling assets. The redundancies, expected to be finalised and announced possibly before the group reports its third-quarter results in two weeks' time, would mark Lehman's fourth round of job cuts in the past 12 months. They would represent about 5% of its remaining workforce and bring total redundancies to about 6,400 since June last year. Although details have yet to be finalised, the job losses are expected to be felt right across Lehman's operations, including those in the City. Most of the recent cutbacks have fallen in Lehman's mortgage-related businesses, but more jobs are expected to go this time from the investment banking and trading division as the group's efforts to cut costs spread further through the business. Lehman is not alone among financial services companies to cut jobs. Banks and securities firms have eliminated 101,250 posts across the world since the credit crunch took hold, according to Bloomberg. Many of these losses have stemmed from efforts to cut costs as the institutions have taken a collective credit crunch-related write-down of more than $510 billion (281 billion).

Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. announced that more than 4,000 City workers were clearing their desks in an unprecedented jobs cut. Staff at Lehman Brothers, one of the biggest and most respected names in investment banking, were told that the firm is shutting down. Another 1,000 jobs at a Lehman office in High Wycombe will also go. Senior staff were told late last night that efforts to save the US bank had failed.

Administrators at Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc.' British operations announced 750 job cuts. The jobs lost are in Britain, but a handful of European jobs have also been cut. The losses are in the bank's fixed income and personal investment management sections.
Nektar Therapeutics will lay off about 110 people, about 20% of its regular full-time staff -- eliminate 40 open positions and cut some temporary, contract positions.

Nektar Therapeutics announced the closing of the Nektar UK site in Bradford, UK as part of its ongoing strategy to realign business operations with a focus on product development using its leading drug delivery technologies.

The Jos. A. Bank men's clothing store in River Ranch will close as part of parent company Tailored Brands' Chapter 11 bankruptcy plans to close 500 stores. The company which also owns the Men's Wearhouse chain, filed on Sunday and plans to eliminate 20% of its corporate positions by the end of the second quarter. The store at 1900 Kaliste Saloom Road Suite 200 has been removed from its website. It's the only Louisiana store the company plans to close, reports indicate.

PSS World Medical Inc. will close 13 of its 46 distribution centers in its physician supply business and close 19 of 26 distribution centers in its imaging supply division. The company also plans to centralize its service call dispatch and service billing operations for the imaging division to one location in Jacksonville over the next year. In addition to cost-cutting measures, PSS also plans to continue new sales initiatives, including the hiring of 70 to 90 new sales representatives for its physician supply business. Because of its new initiatives, PSS expects to incur $8 million to $9 million in restructuring charges for the fourth quarter ending March 31, and another $7 million to $8 million in charges in the fiscal year ending March 31, 2003. PSS also said the new programs will add $4 million to $5 million in general and administrative costs next year that will not be classified as restructuring costs.
PSS World Medical Inc. will lay off 124 employees, include 66 in Jacksonville. The layoffs will take place Oct. 15 through Feb. 15.

Frontier Airlines Holdings, Inc. will cut a total of 220 jobs at its airport hubs in Denver and Milwaukee and ground nearly one-third of its 67 flights from the Wisconsin center. Layoffs affecting about 4% of the Frontier workforce come as Republic Airways Holdings tries to reduce costs while battling rising fuel prices and heavy competition from other low-fare air carriers.

Fresh Del Monte Produce Inc. announced that it plans to cease its pineapple operations in Hawaii in 2008, saying the fruit can be grown for less in other parts of the world. It would be cheaper for Del Monte to buy pineapples on the open market than for the company to grow, market and distribute Hawaiian pineapple. Del Monte also cited difficulty in obtaining a long-term lease extension with landowner Campbell Estate.
The Greenbrier Cos. Inc. announced that it plans to lay off 160 workers in the Portland area during July and may close one of its two factories in North America.

Movie Gallery Inc.'s announced that it plans to close its remaining namesake and Hollywood Video stores brings a bittersweet win for Dallas-based Blockbuster Inc. It leaves Blockbuster as the only national movie-rental store chain - but in a fast-changing industry combating new technologies and new competitors. While Movie Gallery stores are mostly in rural locations, Hollywood Video stores compete head to head with Blockbuster. Employees in five of the company's 16 stores in small North Texas towns said May 07, 2010 would be their last day. The other stores said they've been told remaining stores will also close soon.

Affiliated Computer Services Inc. announced that in a filing with the Texas Workforce Commission that it will close a facility and eliminate about 450 jobs. The company announced that the terminations would occur around September 1, 2008.

Affiliated Computer Services, Inc. has laid off 181 employees at its Houston call center, but the move won't affect the company's growth plans in the Raleigh-Durham area. The layoffs in Houston resulted from the restructuring of a single client, whose troubles scuttled one ACS project but won't have any impact on the company's operations in Raleigh and Cary. The company has been adding positions at a rapid clip at its Raleigh call center, where more than 1,100 employees have been hired since March, bringing the company's head count in the Triangle to 2,400. The Texas layoffs raised an eyebrow because ACS also had been growing in Houston. The company would eliminate 181 jobs "due to lack of work." The positions impacted were mainly in telesales and customer care. The layoffs took place Dec. 21, but the affected employees will receive wages and benefits for the next 60 days as well as job placement assistance within the company.

Stratasys Ltd. announced that it is reducing its global workforce as part of a strategic plan to accelerate growth with a leaner operating model. This resizing, advanced sooner due to the impact of COVID-19, will affect approximately 10% of employees, and is designed to reduce operating expenses as part of a cost realignment program to focus on profitable growth. The company expects the vast majority of the reduction to take place in the second quarter and to complete the reduction during the third quarter of this year.
Aspen Technology Inc. has announced that it will cut about 195 jobs, or 10 percent of its workforce.

Officemax Inc. announced that it opened a store in a new East College Avenue strip mall five years ago will close the store at the end of February because of weak sales. The OfficeMax store next to the Giant supermarket at 2252 East College Ave. is one of 45 stores in the company's 1,000-store chain marked that will close. The State College store has about 15 employees.
OfficeMax Inc. will close its store at 4310 Coldwater Road, among 45 stores the company is shutting.
Technip is to lay off a total of 640 employees at its shipyard in Pori, Finland, as of March. The group said the redundancies are necessary due to a drop in activity at the site.

Technip SA announced on July 6, 2015 it plans to cut approximately 6,000 jobs globally as part of restructuring efforts. The company did not give a specific timeline or details about where the job cuts would occur. Some of the trends impacting company, which focuses on offshore engineering and construction, in the wake of low oil prices have not improved or have worsened over the past two months Therefore, the company is accelerating its cost reduction and efficiency efforts, which are expected to save EUR 830 million, or approximately $917.86 million, by the end of 2017. In company's subsea segment, which is outperforming initial expectations, there will be some cost reductions in markets where new project awards are under pressure, such as the North Sea. The company will also reduce its subsea fleet by two more vessels, in addition to the two vessels it had already planned to take out this year 2015. More of the restructuring plan will focus on company's onshore/offshore segment, which has had unsatisfactory performance. The company will reduce its presence, through sales or closures, in some markets that are not expected to be profitable even in the medium term. Such markets could include selected countries in Europe, Asia and Latin America, including Brazil. The company also has put aside some projects where it will take time to resolve disputes with clients on changes and variations. The company will incur one-off charges of EUR 650 million, or approximately $718.81 million, to cover all aspects of the restructuring and workforce reductions.

Northwest Bancshares, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2010. For the quarter, the company has reported net income of $12.7 million, or $0.12 per diluted share. This represents an increase of $11.7 million over the same quarter last year when net income was $1.0 million, or $0.01 per diluted share. Net interest income increased $9.2 million, or 15.8%, to $67.2 million for the quarter ended December 31, 2010, from $58.0 million for the quarter ended December 31, 2009, which was primarily attributable to an increase in interest income from loans receivable and a decrease in the cost of deposits. Income before income taxes was $17.8 million against loss before income taxes of $3.4 million reported last year. The annualized returns on average shareholders' equity and average assets for the current quarter were 3.90% and 0.63% compared to 0.46% and 0.05% for the same quarter last year. Total interest income was $93.0 million against $90.9 million reported last year.Net income for the year ended December 31, 2010 of $57.5 million, or $0.53 per diluted share represents an increase of $24.8 million, or 76.2% compared to net income of $32.7 million, or $0.30 per diluted share, for the year ended December 31, 2009. Income before income taxes was $81.0 million against $39.7 million, total interest income was $370.6 million against $364.5 million and net interest income was $257.6 million against $228.7 million reported last year. The annualized returns on average shareholders' equity and average assets were 4.40% and 0.71%, respectively, for the current year compared to 4.71% and 0.46%, respectively, in the prior year. Book value per share at the end of the year was $11.85 against $11.90 reported last year.The company also announced that its Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.10 per share payable on February 17, 2011, to shareholders of record as of February 4, 2011. This represents the 65th consecutive quarter in which
Pinnacle Systems Inc. announced that it has reduced its workforce by 5%.

Capital One Financial Corp. announced plans to close its Fredericksburg operations on December 1, 2003 in an effort to consolidate the company's resources in Virginia. The closure will affect approximately 650 associates all of whom will be offered positions at other Virginia locations -- primarily at Capital One's sites in Henrico and Chesterfield counties. The closing of operations in Fredericksburg is viewed as a prudent business decision that will allow Capital One to reduce operating expenses as it consolidates its resources in Central Virginia.

Capital One Financial Corp. announced plans to consolidate its operations work by eliminating 220 positions at its call center facility located in Irving, Texas and transition the vast majority of the work to its Richmond, Virginia facility. The move is part of the company's ongoing drive to achieve cost efficiencies. The company intends to close the Irving, Texas site by the end of the second quarter 2005. All impacted Capital One associates will receive a minimum of 90 days notice along with extensive career transition support including career training, job fairs, one-on-one counseling, and access to an on-site career services center. All full-time associates will be eligible for severance packages including retraining assistance and outplacement services. In addition, as the work is transitioned to Richmond, the company will provide assistance to those associates currently working at the Irving facility who are interested in relocating and continuing their work for Capital One.

Capital One is cutting 750 jobs and will outsource much of the work performed by those employees to another company. The company said most of the job cuts will come from Capital One's offices in Federal Way and Richmond, Va. About 260 jobs at Federal Way will be eliminated by March 2005; the site will be closed.The company said it would transfer the work to a U.S.-based supplier.

Capital One Financial Corp. plans to lay off 281 workers at its Tampa operation between Feb. 5 and March 6, according to a recent filing with the state. Capital One said in July it was closing its Tampa credit card call center, eliminating 1,100 jobs in stages. The first batch of 363 workers were let go in October, followed by 362 this month. A Capital One spokeswoman could not be reached for comment Monday afternoon.
Capital One Financial Corp. announced that it is cutting 2,000 jobs, or about 6% of its work force, amid mounting loan losses and a slowdown in the mortgage industry.

Capital One Financial Corp. has told about 60 employees their jobs are being cut. The layoffs affect the company's U.S. Card division, which manages credit card acquisitions, services and accounts. About 40 of the layoffs will be in the Richmond area and the rest will be at Capital One headquarters in McLean. Affected employees will receive career-transition assistance and be eligible for severance packages.

Capital One Financial Corp. is eliminating 66 jobs in its U.S. credit-card customer operations at its offices in Goochland County. The cuts mark the third round of layoffs this year for the company, for a total of 143 local job reductions this year.

Capital One Financial Corp. is eliminating 79 positions at the former HSBC card and retail business facility in Portland, Ore. The cuts, which will be made beginning in the third quarter and continue into the second quarter of 2013, will be permanent. The cuts, to begin at the outset of the third quarter and extend into the second quarter of 2013, will include the permanent elimination of the marketing department. The cuts will come from 32 titles, including the elimination of the marketing department.

The closure of Capital One Financial Corp.'s local credit-card office will be complete by early January, taking with it 61 jobs and further reducing the number of employees at One HSBC Center in downtown Buffalo. The company announced the final tally of job cuts in an updated WARN notice filed September 27, 2012 with the state Labor Department. The company originally planned to lay off 78 workers, but 17 of those employees have already found new jobs. The layoffs are scheduled to take effect January 2, 2012. To date, none of the positions have been eliminated.

Capital One Financial Corp. planed to eliminate approximately 111 jobs at one of its Houston locations. The Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act letter states the jobs will be eliminated at Capital One's 5718 Westheimer Road location. The eliminated jobs include 20 different job titles. The cuts are expected to occur in phases, with the earliest beginning around - but no earlier than - Jan. 2, 2015. The last of the cuts is expected on or about - but no earlier than - April 3, 2015. All affected employees will receive at least 60 days written notice and outplacement assistance. For those full-time employees who are eligible, their severance pay and benefits will begin upon the termination of their employment. Capital One also is providing affected employees with the opportunity to seek roles at its other facilities. Affected employees are not represented by a union, and they will not have bumping rights, meaning higher-ranked workers whose positions are eliminated cannot take lower-ranked jobs.

Capital One Financial Corp. is planning to lay off another 286 employees from its Plano, Texas, campus. The move is in addition to the 950 employees the bank said in November it would let go from the North Texas campus as it exits the mortgage lending and home equity business. Rising interest rates have forced banks to focus their mortgage departments on writing new loans for homebuyers rather relying on refinances. The latest round of cuts stem from a deal Capital One made in May to sell a portfolio of $17 billion in existing home loans to DLJ Mortgage Capital, a subsidiary of Credit Suisse.

RSA Security Inc. has approved a plan to reorganize its structure which includes cutting 17 percent of its work force, or 200 workers and taking a related second quarter charge of $8 million to $10 million. 

The company also said it is forming three new product divisions comprised of engineering and product management teams focused on authentication, developer solutions/encryption and Web access management. The company's sales, marketing and general and administrative functions will continue to operate as separate groups serving the entire corporation.

Hanmi Financial Corporation announced the planned closure and consolidation of three branch offices in Harvey, Naperville (South) and Roselle, Illinois and one branch office in Springfield, Virginia. The closing of these branches is scheduled for August 28, 2015 after regulatory notice requirements are met. The closures will result in an estimated annual pre-tax cost savings of $2.7 million. Non-recurring charges associated with the branch closings are estimated to be approximately $0.9 million. After these closures, Hanmi will operate 42 full-service branches and 6 loan production offices in California, Texas, Illinois, Virginia, New Jersey, New York, Colorado, Washington and Georgia.

Cox Communications will cut 240 jobs in Oklahoma City and another 84 jobs in Tulsa as part of a plan to consolidate its services at regional offices around the country. However, the company is also expanding its sales force in Oklahoma City by about 300 positions. Layoff notices filed with the Oklahoma Commerce Department this week show that Cox plans to eliminate all customer service and technical support jobs in Oklahoma City and all customer care accounts service jobs in Tulsa. Cox will eliminate the positions between May and September, according to the notices. The notices were filed with the Commerce Department under the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, which requires most large employers to give workers and local governments at least 60 days notice of a mass layoff.Cox sent the layoff notice because it is legally required to do so when shifting jobs to another location, but many of the affected employees will relocate to other positions within the company or chose to move to Cox call centers in other states to keep their jobs.

Insight Enterprises Inc. announced actions to reduce its expense structure, based on the company's expectation of continued softness in the market's technology sector. The actions include a workforce reduction in its North America operations of approximately 270 employees or roughly 8% of its North America workforce.

Rent-A-Center Inc. announced plans to close 280 U.S. stores over the next three months. The company will book pre-tax restructuring charges between $36 million to $43 million for its quarter ending December 31. The 280 stores generated revenues of $140 million year-to-date through October 31.

Rent-A-Center Inc. announced that it will shutter its 2915 Linden Ave. store within three months and merge its operations with local stores. The closure is part of the rent-to-own chain's plan to close 280 stores nationwide. The company will close 13 stores in Ohio, leaving it with 190 statewide.

Brooks Automation Inc. unveiled plans to cut 100 jobs from its payroll. The company said the job cuts, representing about 6% of its total workforce, would eventually save the company $10 million a year in expenses. The company said its plan involves eliminating redundant positions throughout the company, as well as the consolidation of offices in California, Germany, Korea, Singapore, Taiwan and China. The job cuts will take place through mid-2013.

P-Com Inc. will close four facilities in the U.S. and United Kingdom as it is consolidating its R&D and manufacturing operations. The company will also cut about 42 jobs by the end of the first quarter to cut costs.

Dollar Tree on March 6, 2019 announced plans to close nearly 400 Family Dollar stores and rebrand 200 others amid ongoing attempts to turn around the Family Dollar brand. The company said it will re-banner 200 Family Dollar stores under the Dollar Tree name in 2019 and that as many as 390 Family Dollar stores will be closed. The company also plans to renovate at least 1,000 stores.

Amerisourcebergen Corp. announced 180 more workers learned that they are about to lose their jobs. A wholesale prescription drug distribution center in West Toledo operated by AmerisourceBergen Corporation will close.

AmerisourceBergen Corp. is shutting down its compounding pharmacy business, Illinois-based PharMEDium, by the end of 2020 in a move that will impact about 1,000 employees in four states. Valley Forge-based AmerisourceBergen, a wholesale pharmaceutical distribution and services company with annual revenues of just under $180 billion, acquired PharMEDium - a maker of ready-to-use compounded sterile preparations - in 2015 for $2.6 billion. PharMEDium has compounding facilities in Dayton, New Jersey; Cleveland; Mississippi; Sugar Land, Texas; and Memphis, Tennessee. Compounding pharmacies make drug formulas that are specially tailored to patients when commercially available drugs do not meet their needs. In May 2019, a federal judge issued a permanent injunction blocking the Memphis plant, PharMEDium's most active, from manufacturing activities after the Food and Drug Administration had issued numerous warnings for safety violations that were not addressed by PharMEDium. At that time, the company ceased operations at its Mississippi facility. Under the injunction, its Texas and New Jersey facilities were required to hire an independent expert to ensure compliance with the law. Production at PharMEDium's North Jersey plant was stopped last month. The status of its Texas plant could not immediately be determined.

Darden Restaurants, Inc. announced the elimination of 85 jobs at its Orlando headquarters and the retirement of its second-in-command on September 20, 2013 as it struggles with performance issues at its key chains, Olive Garden and Red Lobster. The job cuts were a combination of layoffs and the elimination of vacant positions. The company cut across department lines and affected both lower-level and senior employees. The company plans to save $50 million a year through spending cuts, including the layoffs at headquarters, where it employs about 1,300 people.
Borders Group Inc. announced that it will layoff all 70 workers at its Borders.com operations as a result of its agreement with Amazon.com Inc.

Borders Group Inc. announced that it will close its Crossroads Plaza store effective July 21, a move it attributed to the LDS Church's planned downtown redevelopment project. The Borders closure is the latest in a slow tenant procession away from the two downtown malls, started when The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (Mormon) announced nearly three years ago its plans for a massive mixed-use development.

Borders Group plans to close two of its three area Waldenbooks stores. The Ward Parkway Center store and the Metro North Shopping Center store are scheduled to close January 2007. Both stores are having a closing sale.

Borders Group Inc. announced that it will close its Mill Avenue store in downtown Tempe, probably in late January, because sales have not met expectations. Thirty-nine employees will be affected by the closing.

Borders Group Inc. announced that it plans to close its store on Michigan Avenue in Chicago in January 2010. The company continues to have a strong commitment to Chicagoland with 19 stores throughout the area, including nearby locations on State Street, West North Avenue, North Clark Street in Lincoln Park and in the Citigroup Center-all of which are located within five miles of the Michigan Avenue store-plus others that are just minutes away.
MCR announced that 36 employees based at the London head office of Borders Group, Inc. had been made redundant.

Borders Group, Inc. announced that it has closed for good, leaving writers worried and readers saddened. Borders, which went into administration last month, ceased trading across the whole of Britain, with the loss of about 1,550 jobs.

Borders Group, Inc. announced the closing of some stores, including one at the Carousel Center in Syracuse, but the company has no plans at this time to close any of its three stores in the Albany, New York, region. The chain has struggled with declining sales for years because of competition from online retailers and, more recently, growing interest in electronic books. Borders has a store at Crossgates Mall as well as stores in Clifton Park and downtown Saratoga Springs.

Borders Group, Inc. announced that it was eliminated 45 jobs at its corporate headquarters as the bookseller works to cut costs. The job cuts came in several areas of operations, including human resources, finance, merchandising and distribution centers. The company was facing stiff competition from online retailers, discount stores and the growing electronic book industry.

Borders Group, Inc. announced that it would close four of five of its book superstores in the Tampa Bay area, including all three in Hillsborough County. The stores are expected to close within a few weeks and are among 200 of the chain's 624 Borders and Waldenbooks stores nationwide shutting down as part of the Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings filed Wednesday by the chain, based in Ann Arbor, Mich. The Waldenbooks in International Plaza, which is having a store closing clearance sale, was already in the process of closing by Feb. 22. On the list to close are superstores at 2020 Brandon Town Center Blvd., 2683 Gulf-to-Bay Blvd. in Clearwater, and 909 N Dale Mabry and 12500 N Dale Mabry in Tampa.

Borders Group, Inc. is closing two more Hawaii stores on Maui and Oahu as part of its bankruptcy reorganization plan. The Kahului and Waikele stores are among 28 locations Borders Group Inc. plans to close by the end of May. After the closures, Hawaii will be left with three full-size Borders stores at Pearlridge Center, Ward Centre and Windward Mall. Two Borders Express stores in Mililani and Waikiki will remain open. All the surviving stores are on Oahu.

Borders Group Inc. plans to close a store in Sandusky as it restructures under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, court filings show. The location at Sandusky Mall is one of 45 Borders stores scheduled to close, according to a list submitted this week in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York. Ann Arbor-based Borders originally planned to close 51 stores, but later reached agreements with landlords to keep six stores operating.

Borders Group, Inc. is looking for approval to conduct going-out-of-business sales at up to 45 more stores. Judge Martin Glenn of the U.S. Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York in Manhattan will consider the store-closing request at a June 20, 2011 hearing. Borders has been working to get an extension from its landlords for a Sept. 14, 2011 deadline to assume or reject leases. It has obtained an extension for nearly 371, or 90%, of the leases, but not at a remaining 45 locations. According to court documents, Borders doesn't wish to liquidate the 45 stores because they are among the most profitable in its portfolio. But the debtor is unable to assume the leases because, according to court papers, 'various creditor constituencies have indicated that they would oppose any such assumption outside of the context of a sale of the business as a going concern or confirmation of a plan of reorganization'. Borders is 'actively negotiating a going concern sale with multiple potential buyers'. However, if it doesn't commence the store-closing sales before the Sept. 14, 2011 deadline, Borders will be in default on its $505 million debtor-in-possession loan from a group of lenders including GE Capital Corp., GA Capital LLC, Tennenbaum Capital Partners LLC, Stone Tower Credit Funding I Ltd. and GB Merchant Partners LLC. This leaves the Debtors with a Hobson's choice: the debtors can proceed with store closing sales at these stores under these unfortunate circumstances or, if they refuse to do so, risk being placed into default by DIP lenders. Borders is hoping to waive the requirements under the DIP loan, a request that the DIP lenders are currently considering, and hopes to remove many of the 45 stores from the GOB sales list as it continues to negotiate with its lenders. Indeed, Borders sought the right to proceed with GOB sales at 51 stores in its May 8, 2011 motion, but by May 10, 2011 the total had been reduced to 45 after a deal was reached with landlords for six of the stores. If the company is force

FEI Co. said deteriorating business conditions would force it to lay off 160 workers or 10 percent of its worldwide work force. The jobs cuts at FEI, including 20 at its Hillsboro headquarters, come after a similar announcement by its prospective merger partner, Veeco Instruments of Woodbury, N.Y., which plans to lay off 20 percent of its staff.

On March 30, 2020, Wyndham Hotels & Resorts, Inc. announced workforce reductions approved on March 26, 2020, as part of the Companys cost cutting measures implemented in response to the negative financial and operational impacts resulting from the rapidly evolving novel coronavirus (COVID-19? pandemic. Nearly half of the Company's 2,500 corporate payroll staff worldwide are impacted either through workforce reductions, salary reductions or reduced-hour work weeks. Under this plan, the Company will eliminate approximately 270 positions. The Company expects this initiative to be substantially complete in the second quarter of 2020 and that annual savings realized will be approximately $30 million.On March 30, 2020, the Company announced that Tom H. Barber will leave his role as Global Chief Development Officer, effective April 1, 2020. The Chief Development Officer for North America will now report directly to the President and Chief Executive Officer, and the development leaders for the Company's international regions will report to their respective regional presidents.
KLX Energy Services Holdings, Inc. announcing an additional reduction in its workforce of approximately 170 employees, which it expects to complete by April 10, 2020.

Concentrix expected to lay off as many as 150 staff from its call centre in Belfast. The jobs blow follows the loss of a lucrative contract to investigate UK tax credit fraud. HMRC said it would not renew the contract following a slew of complaints. Tax credit investigations were dealt with by staff in Belfast But dozens of mistakes were made leave families out of pocket. The anticipated redundancies represent around almost a tenth of Concentrix' 1,800 workforce in the city.

Concentrix is laying off up to 258 employees in Northern Kentucky. Concentrix CVG Corp. plans to permanently close one of its client programs in its Erlanger Contact Center, located at 1101 Pacific Ave. The closure of the client program is planned to occur on Dec. 28 and could impact up to 258 employees.

Concentrix is laying off as many as 245 of its employees in Tampa, though the company said it is not leaving the city. Rather, the company said it will close one of its client programs doing business out of the Interstate Corporate Center on E Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard near Interstate 4.

Dish Network Corp. reported that it plans to shutter 500 Blockbuster stores across the United States within the six months. The move would leave approximately 1,000 Blockbuster stores, with about 150 of those selling Dish services, said Lumpkin, adding that the number of Blockbuster stores offering Dish services will expand.

Dish Network Corp. plans to close an additional 300 locations over the next few weeks on top of hundreds closed previously. The further closures will leave some 500 Blockbuster locations open nationwide. That's the number of Blockbuster stores that Dish said in 2011 bankruptcy-court filings that it planned to leave open after taking over the troubled home-movie chain. Locations of the latest stores to close were not announced. Some 3,000 jobs nationwide will be lost as a result.

DISH Network is letting go of 90 workers from its El Paso, Texas, manufacturing facility following a decrease in demand for equipment-refurbishing services. The El Paso facility, which receives DISH equipment from customer refurbishes, is consolidating its manufacturing operations into the first and second shifts, thus eliminating the third shift operations. Employees affected were given two months to prepare for the layoff.

Dendrite International Inc. will close its Bethlehem Township facility and lay off about 25 workers in October. Dendrite of Morristown, N.J., expects to close the facility by Oct. 28, 2005. The company makes computer software for the pharmaceutical industry. The Bethlehem Township facility, which opened in 2001, provides inventory management, repair/replacement processing and configuration management for a variety of personal computers and hand-held computing devices used by pharmaceutical salespeople and others. The company moved employees to the Emrick Boulevard plant from an East Stroudsburg facility it had closed.
MEMC Electronic Materials Inc. announced that it'll reduce its global work force by 20%, or 1,300 people, as it idles a plant in Italy and takes other actions to cut costs.

SunEdison announced it is laying off 100 employees in St. Peters, saying it needed to make the move to remain competitive. As part of a plan to consolidate its semiconductor crystal operations, the company, formerly called MEMC Electronic Materials, will move its small diameter crystal activities from its St. Peters facility to its other facilities in Korea, Taiwan and Italy. The change will be implemented over the next 12 months. Indefinitely close its polysilicon manufacturing facility in Merano, Italy, which was shuttered in December 2011. Company officials said the move came after having studied how to improve the facility's cost effectiveness for two years and the identified cost reductions were not enough to sustain the economic viability of the plant in the current market environment. About 200 employees at the Merano polysilicon plant are affected by the indefinite closure. The company's related electronic grade TCS (trichlorosilane) operation, which employs about 35 people, also will be closed over the next 12 months.
SunEdison announced that it would lay off 15% of its workforce. The company said it would incur charges of approximately $30 million to $40 million connected with the move.

GrafTech International Ltd. announced organizational changes and workforce reductions and a restructuring charge as part of its cost savings programs. In conjunction with this realignment and as part of GTI's previously announced $80 million major cost savings plan, GTI has announced voluntary and selective severance programs. These programs are designed to compliment GTI's global work process and organizational redesign. Since 1998, GTI has reduced its global workforce by approximately 1,600 employees or 30 percent. The voluntary and selective severance programs are expected to result in the reduction of up to an additional 200 employees, representing 5 percent of the global workforce.

Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings said it cut about 30 percent of its ground staff. Atlas Air has eliminated 170 ground-staff positions 65 in Purchase, N.Y. 32 in Miami and 28 at other locations, 45 open positions will not be filled for a savings of $14 million a year.
Midwest Express Airlines has announced that it will layoff 200 to 250 jobs, by January 2003, to cut costs. The layoffs include 63 employees or 15 percent of the airline's flight attendants.

The Midwest Express Holdings Inc., that operates Midwest Express Airlines said that it expected third-quarter earnings to be lower than analysts' projections and that it planned to cut its work force by as much as 250 jobs and adjust flight schedules.

Midwest Express Holdings Inc. will cut 13 percent of its employees while reducing pay for those who remain and launch a low-fare airline to attract leisure travelers, the company said. The furloughs will affect about 430 employees at Midwest Express Airlines.

Cray Inc. is laying off about 90 employees -- or 10% of its worldwide work force -- in an effort to cut costs and make a profit. The company also announced that it was forcing its U.S. employees who make more than $50,000 a year to take a temporary pay cut from July 1 to the end of the year. The pay cut is voluntary for international employees. Finally, Cray said it plans to cut its travel spending and reduce some other benefits. The layoffs, expected to save $5.5 million a year, would take place mainly in the operations, sales and marketing divisions.
Checkfree Corp. has laid off about 40 of its 850 Dublin office employees as part of a 5% cut in its work force.
Central Parking Corporation announced that it plans to eliminate certain positions in order to deal with the current economic environment and strengthen its competitive position.
RadiSys Corporation has announced that the company plans to layoff approximately 80 employees as it consolidates its Houston design center to other sites and some of its sales and service offices.

RadiSys Corp. determined that it would eliminate approximately 15 engineering and marketing positions in its Birmingham, UK office during the fourth quarter of 2004. RadiSys is planning on moving the work currently done by these employees to other RadiSys offices in Hillsboro, OR, Boca Raton, FL and Shanghai, China. This action aligns with the Company's focus on providing more integrated hardware/software platform solutions to its customers. The Company believes the workforce reduction will result in approximately $400 - $500 thousand in cash severance expenses and $50 thousand in non-cash asset write-off expenses in the third and fourth quarters of 2004, and is expected to be complete by December 31, 2004.

Qwest Communications International Inc. closed 17 wireless retail stores in six states, including four stores in Colorado. The closings affected about 90 employees. The stores were not profitable and the company hopes to avoid layoffs by placing the employees in other jobs.

Qwest Communications International Inc. has decided to end Qwest Digital Media, its venture with the Anschutz Corp. The shutdown affects 50 employees, including 43 in Denver. Thirty-four of the employees will lose their jobs this week, Qwest said. Others will keep their jobs while the unit is being closed.
Qwest Communications International laid off 135 employees in its Qwest Wireless division, with a majority of the cuts coming in Denver.

Qwest Communications International Inc. has notified union officials it plans to cut 320 jobs in five states, including 150 positions in Colorado, in the next three months. The phone company's management said the cuts in Colorado, Wyoming, Nebraska, Iowa and Utah are in response to weak demand for phone service. The company said it hopes to achieve the cuts through attrition and other voluntary measures, but might have to resort to layoffs to reach the targeted number. Qwest employs 53,000 people, including 14,500 in Colorado. Some analysts said the company will need to make additional cuts in 2003 unless the economy dramatically improves soon.

The pending restructuring at SanDisk Corp. will reportedly involve extensive layoffs. The company will reportedly lay off 30-40 of its 700 employees in Israel. The company has 3,000 employees worldwide, and layoffs are expected everywhere. The layoffs are part of the company's decision to change its global cost structure and consolidate activities as a cost-cutting measure. The sources added that most of the layoffs will be in administration and marketing. The company declined to comment on the report.

Increased materials costs, higher employee benefits and greater energy expenses are the driving factor behind the pending layoff of four employees at the Schweitzer-Mauduit International Inc. paper plant in February. A representative for the paper company confirmed that the layoffs are planned for next month. This comes on the heels of a work force reduction of seven employees at the end of last year.

Profits at Lexmark International Inc. fell sharply in the fourth quarter of 2001, causing the Lexington-based company's bottom line to sink for the second year in a row. For the fourth quarter of 2001, Lexmark said net income fell by 33 percent to $36.8 million, or 27 cents a share, compared with $55 million, or 42 cents a share, a year earlier. But without a one-time tax gain of $40 million, the company would have posted a net loss for the quarter. Revenues were $1.15 billion, up 5 percent over the year-earlier period. Excluding the one-time gain and one-time charges of $58.4 million for restructuring and $29.3 million for outdated printers, earnings were 46 cents a share. Financial analysts were expecting earnings of 44 cents, according to Thomson Financial/First Call.

For the year, Lexmark had net income of $273.6 million, down 4 percent from $285.4 million in 2000.

The company predicted earnings per share for the first quarter to be in the range of 43 to 53 cents, well below the 60 cents a share Lexmark earned in the first quarter of 2001.

About 625 positions will be cut by early next year in the United States largely in Lexington, where the company has 4,000 employees. The cutbacks are expected to save Lexmark about $40 million this year.

Lexmark International Inc. is to cut 1,650 jobs from its 14,900 strong workforce in a move it announced will cut costs by $20 million this year and $70 million in 2008. The cutbacks will include the closure of one of its inkjet supplies manufacturing facilities in Mexico.

Lexmark International Inc. announced that it's going to cut approximately 550 positions - 4% of its workforce - in the next 12 months worldwide as part of a restructuring program, with a portion of these positions being shifted to low-cost countries. The program is expected to generate approximately $67 million in savings for 2016 and ongoing savings of approximately $100 million beginning in 2017.

Lexmark announced that it is running a worldwide restructuring program that will result in 700 of its 10,000 worldwide employees being laid off over the 2018. The company said that the action will work to align company talent with its strategy to ensure future success.

Advent Software announced that it has determined to restructure or eliminate certain roles as part of an internal reorganization of responsibilities. As a result, the employment of company's executive vice president, Todd Gottula, and executive vice president, Sales and Solution Management, Chris Momsen, will terminate effective September 1, 2015. The employment of company's executive vice president, Global Customer Experience, Anthony Sperling, will terminate effective October 1, 2015.In addition, the company expects to eliminate approximately 40 roles in the third quarter of 2015, and may eliminate an additional 15 roles over the next 12 months upon the completion of the pending transaction with SS&C Technologies Holdings, Inc.

Photon Dynamics Inc. announced that its board approved a cost-cutting plan designed to help the company achieve consistent profitability. The company said it is instituting a number of initiatives, including job cuts, which will better align its costs with its core business strategy and lower its break-even point. Photon Dynamics announced that it now employs about 330 workers, down from about 420 at the end of December 2006.

Advanced Energy Industries Inc. announced that in response to the deteriorating economic conditions and weakening demand from the company's end markets, the company is reducing its global workforce by approximately 330 people or 22% of total headcount across all functional areas and geographies and lowering the salaries of management and executive officers by an additional 5%, totaling 15% overall, effective April 1, 2009.

Advanced Energy Industries Inc. announced that it will cut 200 jobs over the next nine months when it moves some of its manufacturing to China. The job cuts amount to 23% of the company's local work force and 12% of its staff worldwide.
NetApp Inc. is set to close its Israeli development center in Haifa, which has 60 employees.
NetApp is laying off an undisclosed number of workers from its Wichita facility.
Buckeye Technologies Inc. is closing a plant in Glueckstadt, Germany, and cutting 100 jobs to move production to Memphis, Tennessee.
Buckeye Technologies Inc. is reducing shifts and laying off 20-25 employees at its Canadian plant. Buckeye will reduce the number of shifts at the Delta, British Columbia facility from seven to five.

Parexel announced that it plans to lay off 850 employees globally, but did not specify where the cuts would be focused. The company says it now has 17,440 employees in 51 countries. The company calls a Margin Acceleration Program?designed to increase profits. It coincided with a slight lowering of what the company previously said it would generate in revenues for the quarter and full year ending.

Parexel International Corp. is planning a potentially massive new round of layoffs as it reportedly explores a sale. The company previously announced in January that it would lay off an unspecified number of employees as part of a restructuring initiative aimed at streamlining operations and reducing costs. The filing states that "approximately 1,100 to 1,200 jobs in the company will be impacted" by layoffs and a related effort to consolidate some facilities, up from around 400 jobs under the initial plan. The restructuring is expected to be completed by the end of 2018 and could save the company up to $95 million annually.

Tollgrade Communications Inc. announced that it laid off 30 people about 10% of its workforce blaming weak demand for its telecommunications testing equipment. The staff cuts, primarily research and development posts, included 26 at its Cheswick facility. That reduced Tollgrade's work force to 162 locally and 285 corporatewide. The company expects to record a charge of $200,000 in the third quarter to account for the layoffs.
Tollgrade Communications announced its plans to reduce its staff by 80%, streamline its operations and cut costs. The company stated that it expects to employ 296 people after the cuts.
Tollgrade Communications Inc. announced that the company has reduced its staff by two to three percent.

The Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. will lay off 850 Connecticut employees by next month, and the jobs of 100 others could be in jeopardy, company officials said. The layoffs, part of the company's plan to eliminate 1,500 jobs this quarter came as the insurance giant announced it would write off $1.7 billion in earnings to fund reserves against asbestos claims and exit the property-casualty reinsurance business.

The Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. is overhauling its claims operation in a project that will mean up to 400 layoffs nationwide, but none are expected in the Lehigh Valley. Offices are not closing, but some will shrink.

The Hartford laid off 50 employees on June 30, after at least some were accidentally tipped off the previous day, and the company said another 50 or fewer workers will be cut later this year from a different information technology area. The IT employees laid off worked in the Investment Products Technology group of Hartford Life mostly in Windsor, but some in Woodbury, Minn.
