The layoffs are part of a reorganization of the technology unit that will also move some people into different jobs. At least some of the 50 employees found out that they were about to be laid off because the company mailed them pay statements, knowing they would be gone by the usual payday.

Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. announced that it will cut 500 jobs, or about 2%, of its total work force, citing losses in its investment portfolios and declining revenue. The company would slash jobs and other expenses to save $250 million in annual costs by the end of 2009.

Hartford Financial Services Group Inc. reported it is planning to cut at least 500 jobs over the next 18 months from its customer service and back-office administration, continuing a consolidation that began in late 2008. The company would not say how many jobs are affected or how many are in Connecticut, where The Hartford has 10,400 employees. But some employees who spoke anonymously put the total figure at between 500 and 600, and said customer service jobs would be heavily targeted.
Core Laboratories has decided to close its Reservoir Management office in London.

Pharmaceutical Product Development Inc. is laying off 270 people across the country due to lower than expected demand for its services. The company is confining layoffs to its North American operations. The company has a strong backlog of work throughout the world, business in North America has not picked up. The reduction of 270 positions will bring the size of the company's North American work force in line with the demand for services in the region.

LCA-Vision Inc. will close 10 of its 71 U.S. centers and reduce its work force by 15%. The job cuts, about 70 in all, will come from the closed centers, along with call center, corporate and regional office layoffs. LCA didn't identify the centers it plans to close, but described them as 'underperforming.' The closings and layoffs will take place by year end, and result in an annual savings of more than $4 million.

LCA-Vision Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter of 2009. The company posted a third- quarter net loss of $19.9 million or $1.07 per share, compared to a net loss of $4.7 million or 25 cents per share, in the third- quarter 2008. The company also announced that it would close 10 of its 71 U.S. centers and reduce its work force by 15%.

EarthLink Inc. has informed the state Department of Labor that it will cut 65 jobs at its Amherst operation beginning in late September. The WARN notice said the job cuts will take place starting Sept. 30 at the office on Northpointe Parkway. After the Amherst office shuts down, a limited number of employees will remain in a work-at-home model.

Century Aluminum Co. announced it is shutting down one of the five potlines at its smelter in Hawesville because of the global collapse of prices and demand for aluminum. The company will lay off 120 of its 750 employees at the Hancock County smelter. It's because of the economic crisis and the fact that the price of aluminum has fallen from $3,000 per metric ton to under $1,300 per metric ton.

Cost Plus Inc. announced that it will exit eight media markets during fiscal 2008 while closing 18 of its existing stores. The elimination of these media markets will allow the Company to increase its brand presence in outperforming markets. The Company plans to open 17 new stores over the next 12 months in existing states, confirming its previously announced intent not to increase store count in fiscal 2008. Additionally, the Company will reduce its corporate workforce by approximately 10% through the consolidation of functions and the automation of certain activities. The Company anticipates these cost reductions will result in annual savings of approximately $8 million beginning in fiscal year 2008.The company provided earnings guidance for the fiscal 2008. During fiscal 2008, the company expects to record a pre-tax charge of approximately $9 million for costs related to the store closures.

Lucent Technologies announced that it will slash up to 16,000 jobs, about 15% of its workforce, as part of efforts to reduce costs and achieve profitability. The company intends make 10,000 of the layoffs in the next six weeks.
Lucent Technologies announced that it is laying off 400 employees from its Columbus Plant. The layoffs are part of a company wide restructuring plan that was announced in January.

About 650 Lucent Technologies Inc. who received extra unemployment benefits when the company misreported their salaries will not have to repay the money, state officials said. Division of Employment and Training Director Jack King said some of the workers who were asked to repay the money were unable to do so because of financial difficulties. These individuals should not be penalized now because of incorrect wage information given by the company, King said in a statement. Lucent, which cut half the 5,000 employees at its North Andover plant last year, said it had mistakenly overreported workers' salaries, which boosted their unemployment benefits.

Lucent Technologies Inc. announced its Merrimack Valley work force by half in the past year, has notified workers that another 800 jobs will be cut by the end of March. Lucent, a telecommunications equipment maker, currently has 2,700 employees in its North Andover facility. It plans to trim down to 1,550 workers in preparation for a sale of some of its manufacturing lines.

Lucent Technologies Inc. posted a net loss of $495 million or 16 cents per share. Excluding one-time charges, the loss amounted to 14 cents per share, or 3 cents better than the 17 cents-per-share loss forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Those results excluded a 6-cent charge for a tax law change. 
In the second quarter of 2001, Lucent posted a net loss of $3.7 billion or $1.09 per share. Revenues fell 40 percent, to $3.52 billion from $5.9 billion in 2001's January-March quarter, with U.S. revenues up 12 percent but international sales down 16 percent.

For the first six months, Lucent had a net loss of $918 million, or 29 cents per share, a strong improvement over the net loss of $4.2 billion, or $1.23 per share, in the first six months of its 2001 fiscal year. First half revenues fell 31 percent, to $7.1 billion from $10.3 billion a year earlier.

The company's worldwide work force has been cut from 123,000 in January 2001 to 56,000 at the end of March. The 56,000-person figure also excludes about 17,000 Agere employees. Lucent expects to trim the work force to about 50,000 by the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30, and further cuts are still possible.
Lucent Technologies Inc. said that it planned to cut 6,000 more jobs reducing the company to less than half its peak size and might need to take additional steps to return to profitability.

Between 125 and 130 local employees Lucent Technologies Inc. were given their layoff notices, according to one of the laid-off workers. The employee, who spoke to the Times on the condition of anonymity, said workers from all sectors of the telecommunications equipment manufacturer's Hyannis office were let go. The employee said the cuts represented about half the office's current work force.

Lucent Technologies Inc. revised earnings guidance for the full year ending September 30, 2006. For the period the company expects revenue to be flat or in the low-single-digit % (percentage)range, down from its forecast of a %(percentage) increase in the mid-single digits.The company also provided earnings guidance for the first fiscal quarter ended December 31, 2005. For the period the company expects revenue of about $2.05 billion down from the $2.43 billion it reported in the fourth quarter.The company has announced that it will cut 1,000 jobs this year after reducing its workforce to 30,500 employees from 106,500 four years ago.

Yahoo! Inc. will close before the end of the year 2008 its office in the Netherlands, with six employees. The activities, mainly search marketing, will be handled from London and Dublin. The closure is part of the company's global restructuring plan.

Sources close to the company said that Yahoo! Plans to close 36 of operating business units and layoff 385 employees, approximately 15 percent of its total work force following the losses in its third quarter and decline in revenue.

Yahoo! said it plans to close down its research centre in Grenoble, southeastern France, thus cutting 78 jobs. The group will reorganise its research teams at four major centres, in the USA, London, Taiwan and India. According to the plan presented to the works council, all the employees will be offered a transfer to sites in the UK, Switzerland, Spain or the USA. At the beginning of the year, Yahoo axed 40 jobs in Paris.
Yahoo! Inc. has announced that it will close auction sites in the U.K., Ireland, France, Germany, Italy, and Spain in the next 6 weeks in order to return to profitability.

Dean Foods Company announced that it is exploring the sale of its wholly-owned subsidiary, DFC Transportation Company, located in Huntley, Illinois. This business provides transportation services for some of Dean Foods' product lines and

Dean Foods Co., makers of Stroh's brand ice cream, will shut down its Detroit factory and lay off 29 people by April. The company is also closing the Melody Farms due to excess ice cream production capacity. Affected employees will be offered a limited number of positions within the company. But most will receive severance packages that include health care benefits and job placement assistance.

Dean Foods Co. announced that production at a Lincoln dairy plant is ending, but workers can stay on the payroll another week to help close the doors. Nearly 100 people are losing their jobs as the Meadow Gold dairy plant stops producing milk and other dairy products on August 21, 2009. The company said that all of them can stay through August 28, 2009 to help with cleanup and other closing tasks. The company had planned to close the plant next month as part of a consolidation. Employees are getting severance. The company says about 70 people in sales and distribution will continue to work in Lincoln.

Dean Foods Company is set to shutdown up to 15% of manufacturing facilities by mid-2014 as part of its cost reduction initiative. The company's share of US fluid milk sales volume declined to 36.4% during the second quarter from 37.8% in the first quarter of 2013.

Dean Foods plans to continue implementing cost-saving measures by closing eight to 12 manufacturing facilities, representing 10% to 15% of total facilities, by the middle of the year 2014. It already has closed eight plants and announced a ninth since it began the initiative at the end of 2012. The company announced the closure of its Waco plant, at which it expected to lay off 150 workers. It alsoclosed a Shreveport, La., facility.

Payless ShoeSource Inc. has laid off 60 to 70 workers in the most recent phase of job cuts designed to make the shoe company more efficient. Payless is North America's largest shoe retailer with 4,974 stores. It has laid off almost 200 employees in three phases since November. The restructuring will cost between $18 million and $20 million, but is expected to generate $18 million in savings, Reid said.

Payless Shoesource Inc. announced that it will close its Topeka warehouse and eliminate up to 550 jobs there after opening a new distribution plant east of the Mississippi by the summer of 2008. The company announced that it has not determined where it will locate a new 600,000-square-foot distribution center sometime in the summer of 2008. It will be in addition to a 400,000-square-foot distribution center it will open in Redlands, Calif., this summer. Currently, Payless has only its distribution center in Topeka. When the two new distribution centers are opened in the summer of 2008, the company will close the Topeka warehouse, which will mean the loss of about 450 to 550 jobs.

Collective Brands, Inc. has closed three local Payless ShoeSource locations: O'Neal Lane, pictured, and Perkins Road in Baton Rouge and Sullivan Road in Central. The company could not be reached for comment. Its locations on Florida Boulevard, Airline Highway, Siegen Lane and both malls, among others, remain open.

Payless announced that it is preparing for additional store closures in San Diego County. Payless ShoeSource, which announced in April that it filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection and the closure of nearly 400 stores, will close additional stores in San Diego County. Also in late May, Payless listed these two local locations that may be subject to closure pending ongoing negotiations.

The St. Paul Companies Inc. announced that it lost $736 million in the fourth quarter, largely due to its decisions to stop writing medical malpractice insurance and restructure other operations. The loss, $3.57 a share, compared with a profit of $193.5 million, or 83 cents a share, in the final quarter of 2000. The St. Paul-based insurer's operating loss, excluding one-time items, totaled $646.7 million, or $3.14 per share, compared with an operating profit of $128.6 million, or 55 cents a share, a year earlier. The loss was significantly worse than the $2.35 per share consensus estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. The brokers' individual estimates had ranged from $2.10 to $2.71 per share.

The company, which cut 750 jobs last year, also said it will cut an additional 400 jobs-mostly in the first half of 2002-as it continues to shut down most of its international insurance operations.
Travelers Property Casualty Corp. (The Travelers Companies Inc.) said it expects to close an insurance claims office here by June 1, eliminating 107 jobs.
The St. Paul Cos. announced that 40 to 50 people will lose their jobs as it closes 11 offices and consolidates nine others in its surety bond business to cut costs.

St. Paul Travelers Companies Inc. plans to cut 3,000 jobs so it can deliver the savings executives promised investors when The St. Paul Cos. merged with the Travelers Property Casualty Corp. Layoffs had been expected since The St. Paul and Hartford, Conn.-based Travelers agreed to the $17.9 billion merger, which closed in April.

Travelers CEO Brian McLean announced the company will cut $140 million from its consumer insurance operations by 2015 in an effort to make the auto insurance division more competitive. The cuts include cutting 450 jobs as early as this week.
Sykes Enterprises will layoff about 73 employees at its Bismarck, North Dakota call center.

Customer service center operator Sykes Enterprises Inc. announced that it is closing two U.S. centers and a European operation, resulting in the loss of 230 jobs. Sykes, which operates service centers for computer companies such as Microsoft and Apple Computer, blamed the cuts on the slow economy. Sykes employs about 15,000 people in 41 centers worldwide. Sykes is closing its Greeley, Colo., call center and one in Bismarck, N.D. A second Bismarck call center will remain open and employees are being consolidated at that location. One of the company's five European centers is also being closed, but company officials declined to disclose its location. The cuts are expected to cost the company $15 million to $16.5 million.

Sykes Enterprises Inc. said it will cut more than 1,000 jobs as demand for its help desk services mirrors the slump in demand for technology products. Sykes will close call centers in Greeley, Colo. and Bismark, N.D. eliminating 800 vacant seats. One of five European distribution centers will close, as will U.S. consulting offices in Seattle and Merrimack, N.H.

Sykes Enterprises announced several restructuring initiatives, including the shut-down of its US-based fulfillment and distribution operations, the consolidation of technical support centers in Florida and North Carolina, and the lay off of 460 employees.

Sykes Enterprises, Incorporated is closing its Minot call center May 10, 2009, putting about 200 people out of work. The company said that the Minot jobs will be dividend among other Sykes centers around the country.

Sykes Enterprises Inc. is laying off 393 employees at a Kentucky call center as the company shifts its operations from rural America to cheaper operations overseas. The Hazard call center will be shuttered Aug. 29 and Sykes spokeswoman Andrea Burnett said the center will close permanently unless it can land a new customer.

Biotech company Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. said it would lay off 103 workers, including 54 full-timers, as it adjusts its focus from research to product development. The layoffs will come at Millennium's Cambridge, Mass. headquarters and at facilities in South San Francisco, Calif., and Cambridge, England.

Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced that it expects to cut about 200 jobs as a result of the restructuring of the company's collaboration agreement with Schering-Plough Corp. The company said that the modified agreement, under which Schering-Plough acquires exclusive development and marketing rights for the cardiovascular drug Integrilin, will lead to a 15% decrease in research-and-development costs and selling, general and administrative expenses for Millennium Pharmaceuticals. Millennium said the job cuts will affect its sales force, medical science liaisons and other positions, and that Schering-Plough 'is inviting the majority of affected staff to apply for positions.' The company said it will support affected employees by providing severance and outplacement services, and said it expects to incur undetermined restructuring charges related to the amended agreement.

FTI Consulting, Inc. plans to close three offices and cut about 150 jobs this quarter, taking a $25 million charge as a result. FTI Consulting did not disclose which offices would close. The company said the affected locations will be disclosed as they are consolidated in coming weeks. These actions are intended to eliminate certain redundancies resulting from acquisitions completed over the last two years, to better align capacity with expected demand and to provide for appropriate levels of administrative support, but in a more efficient manner. It expects the job cuts and office closings to be the only reductions made this year.

FTI Consulting, Inc. announced that it will lay off 115 employees, or 3% of its total 3,800 employees. The company reported that the cutbacks allow consolidation of leased office space in six locations, but did not name them. The majority of affected employees were employed by two business segments most impacted by current economic conditions. The company estimated the impact of the layoffs would result in a pretax income charge of about $28 million in the second quarter, including $23 million in cash and the remainder in noncash costs related to loan forgiveness programs and other factors. The cutbacks and other actions will result in operational savings of about $14 million for the remainder of 2012. The company reported that more cutbacks would come in the third quarter of fiscal 2012 related to real estate consolidation activities.
Tupperware Corp. has laid off 45 workers whose jobs were moved to the Philippines.
Tupperware Corp. announced that it would cut about 250 jobs at its plant in Hemingway, S.C., because it had decided to increase imports of its products from outside the United States.

99 Cents Only Stores announced that after a thorough evaluation of its Texas business, it will exit the Texas market where it has 48 stores to focus on its core markets of California, Arizona, and Nevada, where it has 230 stores which contribute approximately 90% of the Company's sales. Despite years of positive same-store sales, the Company's Texas stores were only generating slightly more than half of the average sales of its non-Texas stores. Additionally, the Company's Texas operation remains unprofitable. Based on its recently completed strategic review, the Company now believes that even if it continued to invest in its Texas operations over the next few years and was successful in achieving substantial sales increases, and closed its most unprofitable stores and right-sized its distribution center, the result would still likely be only a minimal profit providing an unacceptable return on investment to justify the substantial cost and effort. As a result, the Company's management team and its Board of Directors made the decision that it is in the best interests of the Company to exit this very challenging market and focus its resources where they can better contribute to making the Company stronger and more profitable. To this end, the Company plans to wind down its Texas operations in an orderly and prompt fashion.

Imation Corp. announced that it will cut 200 jobs worldwide. The company has not determined how many jobs will be lost at its headquarters in Oakdale, but most of the cuts will be in sales, administration and general staff. The vast majority of the jobs will be gone by the end of 2009, but some jobs in foreign countries may require more time to eliminate. The company employed 1,760 people worldwide at the end of September. The company revised down its earnings guidance for the fourth quarter and full year 2008. The company expects a quarterly loss of $11 million to $18 million, or 21 cents to 34 cents per share, which includes restructuring charges of about $25 million, or 44 cents per share. Previously, the company had forecast a fourth quarter profit of $7 million to $14 million, or 11 cents to 23 cents per share.

For the full year, the company is expecting a profit of $5 million to $12 million, or zero to 12 cents per share. That includes restructuring and other charges of $46 million, or 83 cents per share. The company previously had expected to see a full year profit of $30 million to $37 million, or 44 cents to 56 cents per share, including charges.

Imation Corp. announced that it will close its Camarillo, Calif., plant by year's end and consolidate all its magnetic-tape coating operations in Weatherford, Okla. The closure means laying off 140 employees in California. The company also closing a floppy-disk plant in Wahpeton, N.D., by the end of the year, a move announced last year that affects 390 workers. Although Imation had not mentioned closing the Camarillo plant before, officials said last year that magnetic tape, which once accounted for the bulk of the company's sales, would be a flat business with little growth opportunity.

Imation Corp. has shuttered its floppy diskette plant in Wahpeton and will transfer ownership of its buildings to the city. Imation will keep a few workers in place to help a group of former employees who have taken over some of the company's contracts.

Aviation Sales Company has laid-off 400 employees, or 9% of its staff. In addition, it has temporarily closed its airframe maintenance facility in Oscoda, Michigan and has consolidated two of its component repair operations. The move is expected to cut d
TIMCO Aviation Services Inc. announced that the company has laid off more than 100 employees since September 2001.

Siebel Systems Inc. predicted a third-quarter loss due to restructuring charges and the ninth consecutive period of declining sales. Siebel Systems said it expects to report a third-quarter loss of about 12 cents a share, or roughly $60 million, including $118 million in pre-tax charges. A year ago, it had a net loss of $92.1 million, or 19 cents, including restructuring and other charges of $164.3 million. Third-quarter sales are expected to be $320 million to $322 million, down from $352.7 million a year ago. Sales were at the low end of the company's forecast, which called for revenue between $320 million and $340 million, and below the consensus analysts forecast of $328.4 million, according to Thomson First Call.
 
 
 
 The company said in July it would slash about 10% of its staff and close offices to offset a prolonged decline in demand for its customer relationship management software. Siebel dismissed 605 people in the third quarter, ending September with 4,984 workers.

Siebel Systems Inc. announced that it would cut close to 1,200 jobs and take a third-quarter charge of between $200 million and $250 million as the software maker weathers the effects of a weak information technology economy.
Siebel Systems Inc. announced that it was cutting its 7,310-person work force by 18 percent.

An agreement under which TeleTech Holdings Inc. will take over customer service operations for Nextel Communications Inc. is expected to eliminate 1,000 jobs in Arapahoe County. Officials say that means the companies will close two of Nextel's six U.S. centers this year, including one in the Denver Tech Center. TeleTech spokeswoman Karen Breen said the facility employs 1,000 people. The Rutherford N.J., facility also will be closed, Breen said. Some jobs will be created at the other four Nextel facilities.

A $1.2 billion deal between wireless provider Nextel and IBM that will close a call center in Colorado will put at least 700 Nextel employees in New Jersey out of work. The companies announced the deal On Feb. 1, all workers at Nextel's Rutherford, N.J. offices will become employees of IBM partner TeleTech Holdings Inc., based in Englewood, Colo. TeleTech did not say when the job cuts would take effect. Workers in Rutherford said they were told that their jobs would end by April.

TeleTech Holdings announced that it will close its Thornton customer-care center, laying off 235 employees, and consolidating the operation at another under-used facility in North Hollywood, California as a result of the slowdown in demand.
TeleTech Holdings Inc. will shutter its Topeka, Kan., office and lay off 790 workers when a contract ends April 2. Large-scale layoffs are becoming commonplace among call centers.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. informed workers this week at its Melbourne center that the company was shutting the customer-service facility as part of a consolidation, putting 148 people out of work. The company said the layoffs will take effect Aug. 4.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. will close its Hampton call center by the end of September, eliminating 535 jobs. The office will lay off 200 people by Aug. 31. The center will close by September 30, eliminating the remaining 325 jobs.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. presented a downsizing plan, which envisages dismissing 133 employees, out of the total 2,576 in Spain. The plan will affect the personnel at the company's plants in Barcelona, Madrid and Oviedo. The employees in Toledo and Valencia are not in jeopardy of losing their jobs.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. has left its doors open a crack after suspending operations and laying off about 200 employees current week. The company said workers hung up their phones at the call centre Thursday, although a handful of key staff members will stay on at the site to complete administrative duties and prepare for new prospective clients.

TeleTech Holdings Inc. plans to close its operation in Moundsville and lay off about 260 workers in September 2013. The company decided to close the center effective September 20, 2013 because of a decline in call volume, streamlined processes and the changing business needs of its clients.
TeleTech Holdings, Inc. plans to close its facility in Charlotte, North Carolina. That will result in job losses for 171 workers - consisting mostly of customer service representatives.

E*TRADE Financial Corporation announced that it has decided to exit the retail mortgage origination business, its last remaining loan origination channel. The company reported it will partner with a third party company to provide customers with access to real estate loans after it exits the business.

E*TRADE Financial Corporation announced that it planned to exit the wholesale-mortgage business and also lowered its profit expectations more than 25% for the year. The moves include setting aside $245 million and are expected to result in charge-offs of $95 million. The company expects exit charges, which will primarily be recorded during the fourth quarter, to be about $32 million, including severance pay.

Metro One Telecommunications Inc. announced that it will exit the wholesale directory assistance business by May 5, resulting in the closing of call centers and the elimination of about 600 positions. The company reported that it will close or sell call centers, where it handled incoming information calls for telecommunications companies, in Minneapolis; Charlotte, N.C.; Orlando, Fla.; and Honolulu in addition to its recently closed call centers in Long Island, N.Y., and Portland. It also will reduce corporate staff at its Portland headquarters. About 600 call center and related positions will be eliminated, and staff will be provided severance packages. The company expects costs of about $3.6 million for the closings and staff reductions, and future cash expenditures associated with the actions of about $2.3 million. After the transition, the company expects to employ about 70 at its headquarters, where it will provide inbound and outbound contact services and leverage its databases and proprietary information systems to provide services to consumer and business marketers. The company reported that it plans to help its telecommunications customers find alternative solutions.

Metro One Telecommunications Inc. shut down its main business after losing most of its customers. Metro One laid off 600 people nationwide, but retained a staff of about 70 at its Beaverton headquarters.
Cymer Inc. announced its plans to trim its workforce by 80 employees, representing approximately 8% of its workforce.

Calpine Corp. announced that it will jettison about 20 power plants and lay off another 775 workers, continuing to retreat from a rapid expansion that buried the company in debt and drove it into bankrutpcy. The projected job cuts will affect about one-fourth of Calpine's remaining work force of 2,900 employees. About 100 employees lost their jobs and the remaining pink slips will be handed out as Calpine's fleet of power plants shrinks.

Hot Topic Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended October 30, 2010. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $183,219,000 against $189,568,000 a year ago. Income from operations was $321,000 against $9,634,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $435,000 against $9,727,000 a year ago. Net income was $390,000 or $0.01 per basic and diluted share against $5,849,000 or $0.13 per basic and diluted share a year ago.For the nine months, the company reported net sales of $495,873,000 against $522,485,000 a year ago. Loss from operations was $13,031,000 against income from operations of $6,060,000 a year ago. Loss before income taxes was $12,785,000 against income before income taxes of $6,506,000 a year ago. Net loss was $7,657,000 or $0.17 per basic and diluted share against net income of $3,897,000 or $0.09 per basic and diluted share a year ago. Capital expenditures were $23,739,000 against $19,518,000 a year ago.The company announced that it has developed and is in the process of implementing a cost reduction plan to meet the challenges of the current environment. Beginning in 2011, these efforts are expected to result in an estimated annual pre-tax income improvement of approximately $13 million. The key elements of this plan are as follows: Closure of approximately 40 to 50 underperforming store locations by the end of the first quarter of 2011. These closures will occur as a result of natural lease expirations, exercising lease kick out clauses and other negotiations. The company expects to incur costs of approximately $6 million, primarily in the fourth quarter of 2010. These costs are associated with the write down of store assets, early lease terminations and store management severance; and reduction of approximately 14% of the home office and field management positions plus planned savings in other non-payroll overhead expenses. The company expects to incur approximately $2 million in expenses in the fourth quarter of 2010 primarily

Abercrombie & Fitch Co. announced that it will cut 170 jobs at its Columbus, Ohio, headquarters as its reviews all expenses. The cut represents about 9% of the Abercrombie & Fitch's home-base staff and is the second round of layoffs for the company this year.

Abercrombie & Fitch Co. will close its Tupelo store in January 2011, as part of a corporate initiative to rid the chain of underperforming stores. The store inside The Mall at Barnes Crossing will close Jan. 15. The store will not be replaced with Abercrombie's Hollister brand.

Abercrombie & Fitch Co. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended July 30, 2011. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $32,031,000 or $0.35 per diluted share on net sales of $916,763,000 compared to net income of $19,479,000 or $0.22 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $745,798,000 a year ago. Operating income was $47,174,000 compared to $27,560,000 a year ago. Income before taxes was $46,189,000 compared to $26,753,000 a year ago. The second quarter net income rose 64%, boosted by higher demand for its preppy fashions in the U.S. and Europe. Results were better than expected and the company's shares rose about 83 cents, or 1%, to $71.85. For the six months period, the company reported net income of $57,172,000 or $0.63 per diluted share on net sales of $1,753,437,000 compared to net income of $7,651,000 or $0.09 per basic and diluted share on net sales of $1,433,602,000 a year ago. Operating income was $85,919,000 compared to $8,848,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations before taxes was $83,984,000 compared to $7,216,000 a year ago. Net income from continuing operations was $56,376,000 or $0.62 per diluted share compared to $7,651,000 or $0.09 per basic and diluted share a year ago. The company continues to anticipate opening five company's flagship locations during fiscal 2011, including the flagship opened in Paris in May. After losing market share to cheaper competitors during the recession, the company has rebounded as it focuses on international expansion and closing underperforming stores. The company expects to open up to 40 international mall-based Hollister stores, of which six had opened in the first half of 2011. The company expects to open two domestic stores in fiscal 2011 and now expects to close approximately 60 to 65 domestic stores, primarily at the end of the year through natural lease expirations.Based on current new store plans and other planned expenditures, the company continues to expect total capital e

Abercrombie & Fitch announced for the year 2014, the company plans to open 4 additional stores in China, including a mall-based A&F store in Chengdu and preparing for an accelerated rollout for both brands in 2015. For 2014, the company plans to open 2 additional Hollister stores in Japan, 1 at LaLaport Tokyo Bay and the other in Kobe, and it sees significant growth opportunity, given iearly success. During 2014, the company expects to open 15 full-priced international stores, including a small number of A&F mall-based stores. The company also now plan to open 8 to 10 international and U.S. outlet stores during the year. The company expects to close between 60 and 70 stores in the U.S. during the fiscal year through natural lease expirations.

Abercrombie & Fitch Co. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the thirteen weeks ended April 30, 2016. For the period, the company reported net sales of $685.483 million against $709.422 million a year ago. Operating loss was $54.911 million against $90.197 million a year ago. Loss before taxes was $59.417 million against $94.836 million a year ago. Net loss attributable to the company $39.587 million against $63.246 million a year ago. Net loss per diluted share attributable to the company was $0.59 against $0.91 a year ago. Non-GAAP operating loss was $52.343 million. Non-GAAP loss before taxes was $56.982 million. Non-GAAP net loss attributable to the company was $37.174 million or $0.53 per diluted share.For fiscal 2016, the company now expects: comparable sales to remain challenging in the second quarter, but to improve in the second half of the year; operating income of approximately $15 million, including the year-over-year impact from hedging; a gross margin rate up slightly to last year's rate of 61.9%, but down modestly in the second quarter; and an effective tax rate in the mid-to-upper 30s. The company continues to expect capital expenditures in the range of $150 million to $175 million for the full year.The company plans to open approximately 15 new stores in fiscal 2016, including approximately 10 in international markets, primarily China, and approximately five in the U.S. The company now plans to open six new outlet stores, primarily in the U.S. The company anticipates closing up to 60 stores in the U.S. during the fiscal year 2016 through natural lease expirations.

Abercrombie & Fitch announced that in 2017, it expects to complete approximately 40 Hollister remodels, about 10 of which will include a downsizing of an existing location and 7 new A&F prototype stores, 4 of which included downsizing of an existing location.The company also announced that in total, it expects to open 7 full-price stores and 2 outlet stores in 2017.In 2017, the company expects to close approximately 60 stores in the U.S. through natural lease expirations.

Abercrombie & Fitch will close up to 40 stores this year. The company that includes Abercrombie & Fitch and Hollister brands has 850 stores globally. Most of the 40 closures will be in the United States, the company said in a press releases. There are Abercrombie & Fitch stores at the Mall at Fairfield Commons and Kenwood Towne Center, along with Hollister stores at the Mall at Fairfield Commons, Dayton Mall, Liberty Center and Kenwood Towne Centre. The brands also plan to leverage new store prototypes to add 85 "new store experiences" in 2019.

Lightbridge Inc. announced that it will close its Broomfield, Colorado Call Center on Jan. 28 and distribute the business to its other call centres. 40 employees, or 8% of the total call center workforce, will be cut.

Univision that it planned to slash its workforce by 5.9% in order to reduce overhead. The elimination of about 260 staffers will take place primarily in the Miami-based television business and focus on eliminating job redundancies and inefficiencies.
Univision Communications will cut between 200 to 250 jobs, with many layoffs expected at Fusion in Doral. As part of the restructuring, other office and editorial employees will likely be laid off.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the thirteen weeks and twenty-six weeks ended July 31, 2010. For the thirteen weeks, the company reported net sales increased 13.6% to $139.8 million compared with $123.1 million for the 13-week period ended August 1, 2009. Comparable store sales increased 11.9%, making it the second straight quarter the company has produced double digit comparable store sales growth. Net income increased 261.9% to $4.0 million compared with $1.1 million for the second quarter of Fiscal 2010. Earnings per diluted share increased 257% to $0.14 compared with $0.04 for the second quarter of fiscal 2010. Income before provision for income taxes was $6.43 million against $1.9 million for the same period a year ago. Operating income was $6.5 million compared to $1.9 million for the same period of last year.For the twenty-six weeks, the company reported net sales increased 15.5% to $324.3 million compared with $280.8 million for the 26-week period ended August 1, 2009. Comparable store sales increased 13.4%. Net income was $21.4 million compared with $12.0 million for the 26-week period ended August 1, 2009. Earnings per diluted share increased 75% to $0.73 compared with $0.41 for the 26-week period ended August 1, 2009. Income before provision for income taxes was $34.10 million against $19.46 million for the same period a year ago. Operating income was $34.2 million compared to $19.5 million for the same period of last year.The company increased its earnings guidance for fiscal 2011 to a range of $1.45 per diluted share to $1.55 per diluted share based on a mid- to high-single-digit increase in comparable store sales in the second half of fiscal 2011.For fiscal 2011, the company expects to open approximately 30 new stores and expand approximately 20 high performing locations.For fiscal 2011, in its efforts to increase operating margins, the company intends to close 10 to 15 underperforming stores, which is permitted by the terms of the leases for these stores

Hibbett Sports, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended July 30, 2011. For the quarter, the companys net sales were $153,127,000 compared to $139,819,000 for the same period in 2010. Operating income was $9,368,000 compared to $6,481,000 for the same period in 2010. Income before provision for income taxes was $9,308,000 compared to $6,437,000 for the same period in 2010. Net income was $5,940,000 or $0.21 per diluted share compared to $4,013,000 or $0.14 per basic and diluted share for the same period in 2010.For the six months, the companys net sales were $356,783,000 compared to $324,325,000 for the same period in 2010. Operating income was $43,508,000 compared to $34,157,000 for the same period in 2010. Income before provision for income taxes was $43,392,000 compared to $34,106,000 for the same period in 2010. Net income was $27,277,000 or $0.98 per diluted share compared to $21,354,000 or $0.73 per diluted share for the same period in 2010. The company spent $6.1 million in CapEx year-to-date. For the fiscal year 2012, the company expects to open approximately 50 to 55 new stores, expand 15 high performing stores. The company expects to close 10 to 15 stores in 2012. The company increased its earnings guidance for Fiscal 2012 to a range of $1.90 to $2.00 per diluted share with a comparable store sales increase in the mid-single digit range. The companys fiscal year 2012 plan for CapEx will be $14 million.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2012. For the quarter, the company's net sales were $190,681,000 against $173,209,000 a year ago. Operating income was $25,052,000 against $19,302,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $25,002,000 against $19,261,000 a year ago. Net income was $15,824,000 or $0.59 diluted per share against $12,457,000 or $0.44 diluted per share a year ago. For the full year, the company's net sales were $732,645,000 against $664,954,000 a year ago. Operating income was $93,531,000 against $73,547,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $93,314,000 against $73,442,000 a year ago. Net income was $59,060,000 or $2.15 diluted per share against $46,400,000 or $1.60 diluted per share a year ago. The company spent $13 million in capital expenditure for the year versus a $13 million budget.For Fiscal 2013, the company expects to open 55 to 60 new stores, expand approximately 15 high performing stores. For fiscal year 2013, the company expects to close up to 18 stores. For the full year 2013, the company expects earnings with a range of $2.35 to $2.55 per diluted share (which includes an expected contribution of $0.07 to $0.09 per diluted share from the 53rd week) and comparable store sales to increase in the low to mid single digit range.Capital expenditure for 2012 will be a little more than $15 million.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended April 28, 2012. For the quarter, net sales were $232.914 million, increased by 14.4% against $203.656 million a year ago. Comparable store sales increased 11.1%. Operating income was $42.399 million against $34.141 million a year ago. Net income was $26.363 million or $0.98 diluted per share, increased by 23.5% against $21.337 million or $0.76 diluted per share a year ago.For the fiscal year of 2013, the company increased its earnings guidance to a range of $2.50 to $2.65 per diluted share (which includes an expected contribution of $0.07 to $0.09 per diluted share from the 53(rd) week) and an increase in comparable store sales in the mid single digit range. For Fiscal 2013, the company expects to open 55 to 60 new stores and expand approximately 15 high performing stores.For Fiscal 2013, the company also expects to close up to 18 stores.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended February 02, 2013. For the quarter, the company's net sales were $217,407,000 against $190,681,000 a year ago. Operating income was $30,906,000 against $25,052,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $30,865,000 against $25,002,000 a year ago. Net income was $19,359,000 or $0.73 diluted per share against $15,824,000 or $0.59 diluted per share a year ago. For the full year, the company's net sales were $818,700,000 against $732,645,000 a year ago. Operating income was $115,981,000 against $93,531,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $115,813,000 against $93,314,000 a year ago. Net income was $72,582,000 or $2.72 diluted per share against $59,060,000 or $2.15 diluted per share a year ago. Capital expenditure was $22.9 million.For fiscal 2014, the company expects to report diluted earnings per share in the range of $2.85 to $3.05 and an increase in comparable store sales in the low to mid-single digit range. For fiscal 2014, the company expects to open 65 to 70 new stores, expand approximately 18 high performing stores and close 15 to 20 stores.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended August 3, 2013. For the quarter, the company has posted net sales of $186,235,000 against $165,445,000 a year ago. Operating income was $16,966,000 against $12,377,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income tax was $16,924,000 against $12,336,000 a year ago. Net income was $10,542,000 or $0.40 diluted per share against $7,895,000 or $0.30 diluted and basic per share a year ago. The company spent $12.1 million in CapEx for the quarter, including approximately $9.2 million for new office and wholesaling and logistics facility. For the six months, the company has posted net sales of $426,228,000 against $398,359,000 a year ago. Operating income was $59,406,000 against $54,776,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income tax was $59,318,000 against $54,687,000 a year ago. Net income was $36,756,000 or $1.40 diluted per share against $34,258,000 or $1.28 diluted per share a year ago.For the fiscal 2014, the company expects to open 70-75 new stores, expand approximately 18 high performing stores and close 15 to 20 stores. The company is revising its guidance for the 52 weeks ending February 1, 2014, to earnings per diluted share in the range of $2.65 to $2.77, and an increase in comparable store sales in the low single-digit range. This compares to previous guidance of earnings per diluted share in the range of $2.85 to $3.05, and an increase in comparable store sales in the low to mid single-digit range.

Hibbett Sports, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended February 3, 2018. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $266,738,000 against $246,929,000 a year ago. Operating income was $15,884,000 against $19,132,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $15,830,000 against $19,050,000 a year ago. Net income was $9,733,000 or $0.51 per basic and diluted share against $12,055,000 or $0.54 per diluted share a year ago. For the year, the company reported net sales of $968,219,000 against $972,960,000 a year ago. Operating income was $56,678,000 against $96,764,000 a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was $56,447,000 against $96,496,000 a year ago. Net income was $35,030,000 or $1.71 per diluted share against $61,075,000 or $2.72 per diluted share a year ago.The company provided earnings guidance for fiscal 2019. Earnings per diluted share is expected to be in the range of $1.65 to $1.95, comparable store sales in the range of negative 1.0% to positive 2.0%, improvement in gross margin rate in the range of 70 to 100 basis points, and capital expenditures of approximately $20.0 million to $25.0 million.For fiscal 2019, the company expects approximately 30 to 35 new store openings with approximately 55 to 60 store closures.

Sabre Holdings Corp. plans to cut as many as 150 jobs in a reorganization of its technology group. The layoffs will cost the firm as much as $5 million in severance charges this year, with as much as $4 million incurred during the second quarter.Sabre Holdings Corp. revised earnings guidance for second-quarter 2005. The company now expects EPS to be between 39 cents and 42 cents, on an adjusted basis which is as much as 12.5% lower than it's previous forecast.

ArQule Inc. has announced that it has closed down its facilities in Redwood City, California and Cambridge, United Kingdom, laying off around 128 employees, approximately 31 percent of its entire workforce.
Metris Companies Inc. plans to close its Champaign operations by March 2 eliminating 50 jobs.
A month after Metris Cos. abruptly fired long-time CEO Ron Zebeck, the company has slashed its top management ranks and cut 180 jobs overall as part of its strategy for returning to profitability.

Stage Stores Inc. reported comparable store sales and total sales for the month, quarter to date and year to date ended June 2006. For the month, the company reported total sales of $133.4 million compared to the total sales of $100.0 million for the prior year period, while comparable store sales grew 3.5% versus an increase of 11.0% for the prior year period.For the quarter to date, the company reported total sales of $249.5 million compared to the total sales of $215.0 million for the prior year period, while comparable store sales grew 3.7% versus an increase of 9.1% for the prior year period.For the year to date, the company reported total sales of $593.0 million compared to the total sales of $525.1 million for the prior year period, while comparable store sales grew 3.4% versus an increase of 6.6% for the prior year period.As planned, during June, the Company closed its Peebles store in Harrisonburg, Virginia, and on July 4th, the Company closed its Peebles store in Cullman, Alabama.
Stage Stores Inc. announced that as part of its initiative to shut its underperforming stores, they closed 23 stores in 2015 and expect to close approximately 30 more in 2016.

National Oilwell Varco Inc. is shutting down its local operations by the end of 2015, affecting at least 150 employees. The company will close its Springfield site by the end of 2015, but declined to provide other details. The company filed a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification notice with the city of Springfield and state officials Tuesday, showing the move will affect about 150 workers. The notice filed with the city showed the company will permanently close its facility at 1895 W. Jefferson St., affecting all employees. It shows layoffs are expected to begin on Sept. 18 this year. All the layoffs will be complete by Dec. 18.

National Oilwell Varco Inc. announced more job cuts on Dec. 7, 2015. The company will cut 900 more jobs in Norway due to fewer orders amid low oil prices. That's in addition to the 900 permanent jobs and 600 contractor workers the company already announced it would cut in Norway. Altogether, the cuts amount to about half of the company's Norwegian staff. Closer to home, the company has notified the Texas Workforce Commission of several job cuts due to facility closures throughout the year. Those notifications have included 120 job cuts in San Angelo, in West Texas; 85 in Houston; 150 in Willis, north of Houston; and 110 in Mineral Wells, in North Texas. To weather the extended oil slump, NOV has been taking steps to cut costs as it also acquires new technologies and businesses to expand and strengthen its portfolio. The company's cost-cutting measures include closing facilities.

National Oilwell Varco Inc. plans to cut more Houston jobs as it consolidates locations.The oil field equipment and services company will relocate work from its SHP facility at 1530 W. Sam Houston Parkway in west Houston to its FM 529 facility in northwest Houston. The entire SHP facility will be consolidated with the 529 facility. Some SHP employees will be transferred to the 529 facility, but the company told 54 jobs will be cut. The company said it would excuse the affected employees on Sept. 1, 2016, but they would receive pay and benefits for at least 60 days. Separations are expected to begin Nov. 1, 2016, and be complete by Nov. 14, 2016. Affected workers are not represented by a union, and they do not have bumping rights, meaning workers with more seniority cannot take the jobs of those with less seniority.

Education Management Corp. has laid off 225 people, both faculty and staff. The cuts were spread among the company's 53 Art Institute campuses. Fewer than 10 people were laid off at the school's Boulevard of the Allies campus.

Education Management Corp. made another round of cuts, this time impacting dozens of employees at the art Institutes online division in both Pittsburgh and Phoenix. The exact number of layoffs weren't disclosed but it was reportedly more than 40 in Pittsburgh and a couple of dozen in Phoenix. The jobs were mostly support and administrative, not in instructors.

Education Management Corporation has laid off 3% of its workforce, including 41 Pittsburgh-based workers. Some of the Pittsburgh staff worked at the corporate level, while others worked at The Art Institute of Pittsburgh.
Ingram Inc. announced that it laid off 470 employees, representing 2.8 % of its workforce.
Ingram Micro laid off 100 people last week from its sales, marketing and purchasing departments.
Ingram Micro Inc. has announced that it has cut 265 jobs in the quarter ending June 2003, as part of its ongoing reorganization.
United Natural Foods, Inc. announced that it also plans to close four other Shoppers stores, with those locations slated to close their doors by the end of January.

NCO Group Inc. laid off around 40% of its staff this week at a Canadian office focused on customer relationship management work, that the workers were engaged in customer relationship management services.

Gold Banc Corp. Inc. will eliminate more than a quarter of its work force, or about 190 positions, in connection with its merger with Marshall & Ilsley Corp. of Milwaukee. About 80% of the positions are in the Kansas City area and the rest are in Florida.

ViroPharma Inc.,announced that it was cutting its workforce by 70 percent, or about 100 jobs, to focus on commercializing later-stage products. 
 
 It announced the departure of ViroPharma's original founders, scientists Mark McKinlay and Marc Collett.

Steel Dynamics Inc. announced plans to idle its Minnesota ironmaking operations located in Chisholm and Hoyt Lakes, MN, effective immediately. Management and the company's board of directors have elected to idle the operations for an initial twenty-four month period given the continued significant decline in pig iron pricing, which has resulted in the cost of iron nugget production being meaningfully higher than product selling values. In total, approximately 200 positions will be reduced in Minnesota. A small group of individuals will be retained in Minnesota to maintain the site and facilities.
Linens'n Things Inc. announced that the company plans to close four metro Atlanta stores, at Perimeter Mall in Atlanta and in Fayetteville, Lithonia and Morrow.

Linens Holding Co. announced that as part of its ongoing financial restructuring, the Company plans to close fewer than the previously disclosed 87 underperforming stores. The actual number of store closings is now 57.

Linens Holding Co., owner of Linens'n Things Inc. announced that it will close five of its nine Central Florida locations as part of a previously announced plan to shutter poor-performing stores. The move will impact about 100 employees, according to a company spokeswoman. The company previously announced that it would close 120 stores nationwide. Since then, the company announced that it may need to close an additional 87 stores. That number was pared down to 57, bringing the total number of closings to 177.
Linens'n Things Inc. will close 17 stores, put more sales help on the floor, and concentrate on keeping shelves better stocked. The closings will begin in February and take up to 12 months.
Forrester Research Inc. has announced that the company has eliminated 21 positions, approximately 5 percent of the workforce, as part of its cost reduction measures.

Powerwave Technologies Inc. to discontinue high volume filter production at its kempele, Finland facility. The move expected to result in the elimination of about 190 jobs. The restructuring will result in charges of $3 million to $5 million.
TMP Worldwide Inc. has announced that the company plans to layoff an additional 475 employees.

Monster Worldwide Inc. provided sales outlook for the third quarter and fourth quarter of 2007 and revised earnings outlook for the full year. For the third quarter, the company expects sales to grow at a similar pace as the second quarter. 

The company expects sales growth rate for the fourth quarter to increase.

The company lowered its full-year sales outlook to a range of $1.34 billion (?.98 billion) to $1.37 billion (? billion), down from an April forecast for $1.36 billion (? billion) to $1.4 billion (?.02 billion).

The company plans to slash 800 jobs in the wake of swelling legal expenses.
Broadway Ford Inc. announced that it will close its doors March 31 as part of Ford Motor Co.'s nationwide cutbacks.

Lithia Motors Inc. announced that it will divest at least 9% of its stores, cut jobs and consolidate its offices over the next 90 days. Falling consumer confidence, declining home values and domestic automakers' loss of market share have also contributed to it having to cut 10 to 15 of its 110 stores. The company is looking to save $1 million a month during the next year with the plan's implementation.
Administaff has announced that it plans to eliminate more jobs as a part of its plans to cut costs.
SCPIE Holdings Inc. has announced that it has laid off 41 employees, approximately 17 percent of its workforce, as a part of its costs cutting plan.
Ciena Corp. announced that it will layoff 400 employees, the company said it was cutting 12 percent of its work force and closing its Marlborough, Mass.
CIENA Corp. has cut 2.5% of its workforce as telephone companies chop equipment orders and bathe company results in red. The company announced that it cut 56 jobs company-wide.

CIENA Corp. is slashing Ottawa operations and it will cut 80 jobs from the former Catena Networks access products division in a bid to generate profits. Some of the founders of Catena, Ottawa's richest startup, were hit by the top-to-bottom shakeup. CIENA also plans to shift some future research work offshore to get closer to customers and improve profitability.

CIENA Corp. is preparing a deep round of job cuts for the second time in a month. The networking shop is cutting 300 jobs from across its operations, say people familiar with the plan. The 25% cutback after Ciena closed its San Jose facility. The 300 new cuts come on top of the 425 jobs Ciena slashed with last month's closing of its ONI unit. The back-to-back cuts suggest that Ciena is seeing few bright sales prospects ahead, and show that the company's bold invest-through-the-gloom strategy has backfired.

Silgan Holdings Inc. closed a plastics plant it has owned in Port Clinton for 20 years. The company said that it was not the fault of its 150 local workers, who will be offered assistance when the plant closes sometime in late summer.
Ameritrade Holding Corp. announced that it will lay off 170 customer-service workers, representing approximately 7% of its workforce.

Ameritrade Holding Corporation posted record profits of $9 million for the three-month period ending Dec. 31. Ameritrade had profits of 4 cents a share, compared with a loss of 13 cents a share -- or about $23 million -- a year ago. Analysts had expected the firm to earn 1 cent a share for the fiscal first quarter, according to the Nelson Information/Thomson Financial survey. The 26-year-old firm reported fiscal first quarter revenues of $111.3 million compared to $148.5 million for the same period in fiscal 2001. 


Finally, Ameritrade reduced its payroll by cutting its work force from 2,700 to 1,735.

Ameritrade Holding Corp. notified some technology workers in Omaha and five other locations that they will lose their jobs over the coming months as the company integrates Datek Online Holdings Corp., which it acquired last year. Ameritrade will cut 300 jobs company wide by September. The cuts will come in several areas of the company and not all from technology. The company plans to reduce employment to 1,700 as it combines the Datek and Ameritrade staffs, said Donna Kush, Ameritrades director of communications.

TD AMERITRADE Holding Corporation closed one of its two financial-service operations in Orlando and dismissed the staff as part of a nationwide consolidation. The company expects to eliminate 45 jobs in shutting its downtown office at 301 E. Pine St.

TD Ameritrade Holding Corp. is laying off another 38 employees, bringing the number of St. Louis-area workers it has cut to 1,208 since its $4 billion buyout of Scottrade Financial Services. That's according to an updated notice, required under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, that TD Ameritrade filed Aug. 9, 2018 with the state's Division of Workforce Development. The 38 newly affected employees do not have so-called bumping rights and are not represented by a union. TD Ameritrade completed its purchase of Scottrade in September last year 2017. The sale of the discount brokerage was expected to cost the St. Louis area as many as 1,300 jobs of the estimated 1,800 employed by Scottrade here. The company began reporting in October that employees would be laid off in St. Louis beginning Nov. 21, 2018. Kim Hillyer, director of communications and public affairs at TD Ameritrade, told the Business Journal in October that the company had added over 250 full-time employees since the prior summer to staff a client center in St. Louis, and the company had projected hiring another 365 over the following 12 months.

Nationwide Financial Services Inc. will eliminate 71 information technology positions during the next 12 months at its office in Stanton. An unspecified number of these jobs will be moved to Nationwide's headquarters in Columbus, Ohio, as the company consolidates information technology positions that support brokers who sell life insurance and annuities as part of the Nationwide Financial Network.

Amazon announced that it plans to shut down its Amazon Webstore business, which helps small and midsize retailers create and run their own online shop. Amazon is giving its Webstore customers more than a year to find a new vendor before the company shuts down the service.

Amazon plans to layoff 36 employees at its Jersey City office, while transferring another 41 workers to Newark and New York City effective May 31. The company plans to work with the employees whose roles were eliminated to find other jobs within Amazon.
Amazon.com has laid off several dozen employees in its Amazon Game Studios after failing to make inroads in videogame sector it hoped would provide more customers for its cloud services.

RF Micro Devices Inc. announced that it will eliminate 120 manufacturing positions, although some employees have been identified as candidates for other positions. The employee reduction due to changes in technology and consumer demand for the Greensboro company's products.

Ralph Lauren Corp. plans to shut its Polo store on New York's Fifth Avenue and cut some staff as it shifts more resources to e-commerce. The company will shutter other retail locations and upgrade its e-commerce system. Goods from the Fifth Avenue store will be sold at other Ralph Lauren stores in New York. The moves will result in $370 million in one-time expenses.

Ralph Lauren Corporation announced steps to accelerate its Next Great Chapter plan to deliver sustainable long-term growth and value creation, which include establishing a simplified global organizational structure and rolling out enhanced technology platforms to support the Company's global operations. In connection with the first initiative, Ralph Lauren announced plans (the Fiscal 2021 Strategic Realignment Plan? to reduce its global workforce by the end of the Company's Fiscal 2021, which is expected to result in gross annualized pre-tax expense savings of approximately $180 million to $200 million, with savings realization primarily beginning in the Company's Fiscal 2022. In connection with the reduction in workforce, the Company expects to incur total estimated pre-tax charges of approximately $120 million to $160 million.

Maximus Inc. has announced a round of layoffs. The company has announced that it will lay off 52 workers at its facility at 3750 Monroe Ave., in Pittsford. Maximus opened the site on Monroe Avenue nearly three years ago by consolidating some regional operations in the hopes of bumping its local workforce to more than 300 to handle Medicare health appeals. Despite telling investors on Feb. 5 that revenue in its first quarter, ending on December 31, grew 15% to $467 million, the loss of a key Medicaid and Medicare services contract account resulted in the local layoffs.

StarTek Inc. will close its call center in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada, in the first quarter. The company would pay $200,000 in one-time employee termination benefits in connection with the Regina closing.
Pacific Premier Bancorp Inc. announced intention to close 3 branches during third quarter of 2016 in the cities of Seal Beach, Point Loma and Palm Springs pro forma16 branches.

Outerwall quietly closed the doors on several of its new ventures. Outerwall will discontinue three new venture concepts, Rubi, Crisp Market and Star Studio. The wind-down process is expected to be substantially complete by the end of the first quarter of 2014. Outerwall will continue to invest in the rollout of ecoATM, as well as a limited investment in its SAMPLEit concept. The three failed ventures join Orango, which was discontinued earlier 2013.

Corrections Corp. of America (CCA) has entered into a contractual agreement with Mississippi's Delta Correctional Authority to resume operations of the state-owned Delta Correctional Facility located in Greenwood, Mississippi. Under the new contract, CCA will manage an estimated 950 State of Mississippi medium security male inmates. The contract term is one (1) year, with two (2) one-year extension options. CCA formerly managed the 1,016-bed medium security correctional facility for the Delta Correctional Authority since its opening in 1996, until the State closed the facility in 2002, due to excess capacity in the State's corrections system. 
 
 CCA has indicated its intent to cease operations at the CCA-owned and operated T. Don Hutto Correctional Center located in Taylor, Texas on May 14, 2004, due to low inmate population demands in the facility's region. CCA expects to be able to transfer the majority of the approximate 60 federal offenders currently housed in the 480-bed facility to other CCA-operated facilities.

Choicepoint Inc. announced that the company will discontinue the sale of information products that contain sensitive consumer data, including social security and driver's license numbers, except where there is a specific consumer driven transaction or benefit, or where the products support federal, state or local government and criminal justice purposes. ChoicePoint will continue to serve most of its core markets and customers, but these actions will have an impact on the scope of products offered to some customers and the availability of information products in certain market segments, particularly small businesses. The transition will begin immediately and is expected to be substantially completed within 90 days.

Umpqua Holdings will close 27 branches by the end of 2014 as part of its integration of Sterling Financial in Spokane, Wash. The closures will begin in September 2014. Customer accounts will be automatically transferred to the nearest branch location. The closures include 13 Umpqua and 14 Sterling branches, located across the $11.8 billion-asset company's operations. The list includes 13 branches in Washington, seven in Oregon and seven in California.

Kendle International Inc. plans to close an office in the Netherlands by March 1. The company announced that the employees were notified of the closure, but the company did not disclose how many workers are affected. The expects to see severance-related costs of $3 million from the closure and real estate costs of $1.3 million.

American Capital Ltd., has closed its Chicago buyout operation as part of a cost-cutting effort. Of the more than 20 people who worked in American's office at 111 S. Wacker Drive, only a handful remain. Last month, American announced it was cutting 110 positions, or 19% of its combined U.S. and European workforces.

Solutia Inc. announced that it will shutter its Queeny plant in south St. Louis, which employs about 60 people. Three operations at the Queeny site will be closed. These include a joint chemical-processing operation between Solutia and Huntsman Petrochemical Corp.; Solutia's Skydrol hydraulic aviation fluid manufacturing; and a portion of Flexsys, a joint venture between Solutia and Akzo Nobel.

Solutia Inc. plans to shut down its acrylic fibers business in April as part of its effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection. The move will trim the workforce of its Decatur, Ala., plant by half, to 250.

Solutia Inc. is laying off 300 workers. The decision to idle the plant in Greenwood came because of the poor economy. The company has seen an unprecedented drop in demand for nylon in the past six weeks. The layoffs began in August, but many of them occurred last weekend. Some of the workers laid off worked directly for Solutia, while others worked at the plant through a contract company.

Solutia Inc. announced that it would lay off 101 additional employees and 23 contractors. Earlier, the company said a sharp drop in demand for nylon forced the layoff of more than 300 workers, or about one-third of the workforce at its Greenwood plant.

Solutia Inc. plans to discontinue manufacturing at its plant in Cologne, Germany because cheaper chemicals from rivals have made it "no longer competitive on a global scale." Taminco N.V. will acquire certain assets and assume contracts and commercial obligations relating to the Solutia's tetramethylthiuram disulfide and tetraethylthiuram disulfide products, two chemicals used in rubber production that are manufactured at the plant. As a part of that transaction, the company will continue to produce TMTD and TETD at Cologne for Taminco during a transition period until the end of the first quarter 2010. Due to the emergence of lower cost competition, the TMTD and TETD products manufactured by Solutia at Cologne are no longer competitive on a global scale. The company said it would continue to manufacture another rubber chemical, Perkacit DPTT.

Solutia Inc. announced that it will exit the Primary Accelerators business and discontinue Primary Accelerators production at its facility at the Monsanto Antwerp site in Belgium. Production of Primary Accelerators is scheduled to stop in the second half of 2010. This decision does not affect the Santoflex PPD manufacturing operations at Antwerp, including production of 4-ADPA, the key intermediate for Solutia's Santoflex(R) line of antidegradants. This action regarding Primary Accelerators is a necessary and strategic step in positioning Solutia's Flexsys portfolio to remain the global leader in the manufacture and supply of high-quality rubber chemicals that have a competitive advantage in the market. Over the coming months, Solutia will work closely with customers, suppliers, and Monsanto to provide a smooth transition out of the Primary Accelerators business.

ArvinMeritor Inc. announced that it has taken cost-cutting actions since October, including workforce reductions, plant closings and suspending dividend payments that will save the company approximately $430 million on an annual basis. The company announced that its expense-reduction measures have included cutting more than 1,800 positions globally, shutting two plants in Canada, pay reductions for salaried employees and the suspension of merit increases for 2009, the elimination of matching 401(k) contributions, reduced capital spending, suspending its quarterly dividend payment, reducing compensation for its board of directors by 10%, and the elimination of company-paid education and training programs. In February and March, the company lay off nearly 250 employees and implemented other cost-reduction actions that will result in annual savings of $95 million or $64 million in fiscal year 2009. During its first-quarter earnings report on February 5, 2009, the company announced $335 million in savings.

ArvinMeritor Inc. is winding down employment at its plant in Carroll County, and officials plan to stop production at the plant by the end of the year. The company filed a notice with the state of Kentucky announced that it will lay off 83 workers. The company announced that work from the plant will be moved to other facilities in Kentucky and Ohio, and the Troy, Mich.-based company will outsource machining and casting work.

Meritor, Inc. announced that it will close its European trailer axle business on July 31, 2011. The company currently estimates that charges in the range of $17 million to $23 million will be incurred over 2012 in connection with these actions. Of these charges, an estimated $12 million to $18 million are expected to result in cash expenditures.

Yum! Brands Inc. announced that it will eliminate several hundred jobs and shift a couple hundred more as part of a restructuring of its U.S. business. Several hundred jobs will be eliminated in Louisville as well as at Taco Bell's headquarters in Irvine, Calif., and at Pizza Hut's headquarters in Dallas. Blum said a couple hundred more positions are being shifted from Yum's corporate headquarters in Louisville to the company's brands as part of the restructuring. The restructuring is part of Yum's strategy to sell more company-owned stores to franchisees.

FARO Technologies Inc. announced a global reduction in force. This reduction is in addition to previously announced reductions of approximately 21% which occurred during the first quarter of 2009. The reduction, effective immediately, impacts approximately 8% of FARO's current workforce. The company expects to save approximately $4.1 million on an annual basis and will incur a third quarter charge of approximately $0.6 million related to severance costs. In total, the actions taken this year should provide an annualized benefit of approximately $17 million.
The Children's Place, Inc. plan to open 5 stores and close approximately 30 stores in 2016.

The Childrens Place, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated financial results for the fourth quarter and full year ended January 28, 2017. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of USD 520.772 million against USD 498.544 million a year ago. Operating income was USD 48.658 million against USD 29.347 million a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was USD 48.671 million against USD 29.284 million a year ago. Net income was USD 34.196 million against USD 17.477 million a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share were USD 1.86 against USD 0.87 a year ago. Adjusted net income was USD 34.628 million against USD 24.074 million a year ago. Adjusted net income per common share was USD 1.88 against USD 1.19 a year ago. Adjusted operating income was USD 49.953 million against USD 33.468 million a year ago.For the year, the company reported net sales of USD 1,785.316 million against USD 1,725.777 million a year ago. Operating income was USD 147.408 million against USD 90.080 million a year ago. Income before provision for income taxes was USD 147.013 million against USD 89.382 million a year ago. Net income was USD 102.336 million against USD 57.884 million a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share were USD 5.40 against USD 2.80 a year ago. Adjusted net income was USD 103.015 million against USD 74.588 million a year ago. Adjusted net income per common share was USD 5.43 against USD 3.60 a year ago. Adjusted operating income was USD 151.682 million against USD 110.826 million a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities was USD 199.292 million against USD 182.650 million a year ago. For the quarter, the company reported asset impairment charges of USD 0.808 million. On March 8, 2017, the company is extending its fleet optimization initiative from a target of 200 closures by the end of 2017 to a minimum of 300 closures by 2020.The company expects to open 2 stores and close approximately 40 stores in 2017. The company expects net income per diluted share in the first quarter of 2017 wi

Spectrum Brands Inc. announced that it will lay off about 100 people as part of consolidating operations into three product-based areas. The company's new structure will enable Spectrum to operate more efficiently and profitably by eliminating duplicative staff functions and overhead in each business units, and downsizing their corporate infrastructure. The restructing will realign the company's four geographically based operating areas into three product-focused units global batteries and personal care, home and garden and global pet supplies. Beginning Jan. 1, the start of the fiscal 2007 second quarter, Spectrum's earnings statements will reflect segment results under the new structure.

Spectrum Brands, Inc. announced that it will cut about 100 jobs from its plant here in the southwest corner of Wisconsin. Officials the cuts will be made in January and the jobs will move to China. The cuts represent nearly one-third of the 275 workers at the plant in Fennimore.
Rayovac Corp. plans to eliminate 630 jobs, or 14% of its world-wide work force, as its closes three plants and opens $20 million facility in Illinois as part of restructuring plan.
Spectrum Brands Inc. announced that it will divide its pesticide and lawn fertilizer division among Atlanta, St. Louis and Birmingham, Ala., and will eliminate 70 jobs here over the next 12 months.
Power-One Inc. has announced that it will cut 636 jobs, or about 24 percent of the company's workforce, and close plants in California and abroad as part of its cost cutting initiatives.

Power-One Inc. has slashed 1,000 jobs, or 22% of its global work force, in an aggressive move to curb operating costs and become more efficient. The majority of the reductions occurred in January.
