The bulk of the layoffs were offshore manufacturing jobs. The current economic situation necessitated staffing reductions, a portion resulted from changes in operation.
American Italian Pasta Co. announced it would eliminate 100 jobs and shutter one factory as it struggles to weather the low-carb climate.

American Italian Pasta Co. announced that it would cut its work force by 14% and slow production at several plants, part of its answer to the desire of Americans for a low-carb diet that does not include pasta. The nearly 200 workers in Columbia will be off the job for seven to 10 days in July. The company plans to close a plant in Kenosha, Wis.

American Italian Pasta Co. disclosed plans to close its Kenosha, Wis., pasta plant and stop selling two brands of its pasta. The company will incur $36.8 million to $41.3 million in new charges for the plant closure, discontinuation of its Mrs. Leeper's and Eddie's brands, the disposition of previously manufactured products and the sale of other unneeded manufacturing equipment.
Choice Hotels International Inc. announced that it would close down its offices in Charlotte and Golden. This is part of its corporate reorganization program.

An estimated 100 employees will lose their jobs as Fairchild Semiconductor invests $15 million to shift computer chip production to larger silicon wafers, company officials announced Thursday. The layoffs and the closing of an older 6 inch silicon wafer facility at the plant will occur during the first and second quarters of 2003, said Fran Harrison, director of corporate communications and government relations. The projected layoffs represent at least 20 percent of the company's current work force of almost 500.
UNOVA Inc. has announced that it is implementing industrial automation systems, which would result in reduction of 800 to 900 employees over time.
Group 1 Automotive Inc. announced that it is seeking to reduce its work force by 16%, or 1,450 jobs, by the end of 2009.
Pericom Semiconductor Corp. announced its plans to cut 25 employees and take a restructuring charge up of to $250,000 in the fiscal third quarter.

Applied Micro Circuits Corp. announced that on August 21, 2007, its board of directors approved a restructuring plan to reorganize the Companys operations and reduce its workforce. The plan, which was effective September 27, 2007, includes eliminating job redundancies and reducing the Companys current workforce by approximately 4%. The Company expects to incur a charge of approximately $0.6 million to $0.9 million over the remainder of fiscal 2008 for employee severances. The effective dates of the terminations vary by employee and extend into the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008, therefore the anticipated reductions in operating expenses will be phased in gradually over the next two quarters. The Company anticipates that the restructuring plan will reduce ongoing operating expenses by approximately $2.8 million annually.

Career Education Corp. will close its Beaverton facility, eliminating 124 positions. The operator notified the Oregon Department of Community Colleges and Workforce Development it will permanently close its American InterContinental University Online facility in Beaverton. Layoffs are slated to begin approximately March 23.
Broadcom Corp. announced that it will be cutting jobs in order to reduce company costs.

Broadcom Corp. announced that it will lay off an undisclosed number of workers and lose money again in the fourth quarter because sales of its silicon chips for high-tech electronic products are stagnating. Company declined to say how many of the company's 3,067 employees would lose their jobs, though company said the cuts would affect all types of spending - from travel budgets to capital expenditures.

Broadcom Corporation said that its previously announced cost reduction program is on track, and that as part of the program slightly more than 500 positions are being cut from the company's worldwide workforce. Last month, the company announced a program to reduce overall operating expenses, through workforce and facility reductions, cost controls and improvements in operating efficiencies, by approximately 10 to 12% below the level reported for the third quarter, with the overall reduction to be implemented within the quarter ending December 31, 2002. At September 30, 2002, Broadcom's worldwide workforce numbered 3,067 Including contract and temporary personnel.

Amcor Ltd. to shed almost one-eighth of its European workforce in an aggressive restructure aimed at cutting costs. The company said it hoped to cut about 900 jobs from its workforce of 7,600. The anticipated benefits are robust and supported by headcount reductions and substantial operational improvements.

Amcor Tobacco Packaging has determined that there is an overcapacity in gravure printing across Western Europe. In order to rebalance its own supply and demand, Amcor has announced plans to close its operation in Neumunster, Germany. Amcor expects the closure process to take place over the course of four months with final closure anticipated on or before December 31, 2014. Production will be transferred to other Amcor Tobacco Packaging sites across Western Europe. As operations are scaled down, the first priority is, as always, the safety of those on site. Throughout the closure process, Amcor will continue to provide the best quality and service to customers.
VNU Group B.V. announced it will cut 4,000 jobs, or around 10% of its work force, as part of a major reorganization.

Nielsen Co. announced plans to lay off 117 workers in July 2008 at its global technology centre in Oldsmar, Florida. The company employs 1,700 employees at this facility. The company will have to forgo the tax incentives it received to build the centre if it decides to lay off the workers. Nielsen also plans to reduce another 170 jobs.

Columbia Sportswear Company announced that it has cut an undisclosed number of jobs at its Beaverton headquarters. The reductions came through layoffs and voluntary buyouts. The company wouldn't say how many people were affected but classified the number of layoffs as small. The company made the cuts because of increased investment in marketing to help the company grow globally and because of concerns about a continued weak domestic economy.

First Niagara Financial Group Inc. will close its Hudson call center by May. But the nine employees there have landed other positions at the 120-branch bank. First Niagara is shifting the work to its call center in western New York in a move that would increase efficiency. The old center, in the Hudson City Centre, will remain as a backup.

First Niagara Financial Group Inc. will shed more than 100 jobs and close an unspecified number of branches, including locations in Bethlehem and Latham. A first phase of cuts will eliminate 100 positions statewide by the start of June, including 24 in eastern New York. A second phase of job cuts will come through branch closings.

Manhattan Associates Inc. also eliminated 150 jobs, about 7% of its 2,300-strong workforce, mostly in the United States, in an attempt to align capacity with demand. 'Due to downward pressure on economies worldwide, the company saw a significant number of software license deals expected to close in the third quarter slip to the fourth quarter, and possibly later.

Amkor Technology, Inc. announced that its manufacturing facility in Kitakami, Japan has suffered relatively minor damage in earthquake. The Kitakami facility only provides services to a few Japan-based customers. The Kitakami facility is currently closed due to power supply interruptions and plans are underway to restore production capabilities at the site when power, gas and water supplies, and transportation systems are stabilized. The company analyze the situation and evaluate alternative sources of supply where appropriate.

AXT Inc. announced that on March 11, 2005, it is reducing the workforce at its Beijing, China manufacturing facility by approximately 100 positions or approximately 15%. This measure is being taken as part of the company's previously announced and ongoing effort to reduce its cost structure and bring capacity in line with current market demand.
Microstrategy Inc. announced that it will lay off 600 employees as part of a restruturing plan to become profitable.

Restoration Hardware, Inc. is planning to close its store at Taubman Centers Inc.'s MacArthur Center in Norfolk., on January 21, 2011. The company did not receive any notice of lease termination. Its lease agents are in talks with Restoration Hardware, the publication noted.

King Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced restructuring and workforce reduction initiatives it is taking to decrease the company's operating expenses. These actions, when combined with the reduction in headcount arising from King's recent acquisition of Alpharma Inc., result in a total workforce reduction of approximately 22% or approximately 760 positions. Approximately 240 of these reductions are corporate positions associated with synergies from the Alpharma acquisition. Approximately 520 of these reductions are associated with the restructuring announced of which approximately 380 are field sales positions and approximately 140 are corporate positions.
MIPS Technologies Inc. announced that it plans to terminate 60 employees and contractors, or approximately one-third of the company's workforce, as part of a restructuring plan.

MIPS Technologies Inc. reported earnings results for the fourth quarter and year ended June 30, 2008. For the quarter, the company losing $108.5 million and had revenue of $28.9 million. A year ago in the same quarter it had $23.7 million in revenue and earned a profit of $2.4 million.For the year, the company loses $131.8 million and had revenue of $104.8 million. In the previous year it had revenue of $83.3 million and earned a profit of $8.5 million.The company also plans to restructure and cut jobs to save money.

MIPS Technologies Inc. announced $103.1 million write-down charges for the fourth quarter of 2008.

The company will cut some 75 employees, mostly from analog business and corporate positions.
Electronics Boutique Holdings Corp. announced it discontinuing another 29-store division that sells computer-oriented educational childrens toys.

Catapult Communications Corp. announced that it is reducing its global workforce by up to 25 employees through layoffs and early retirements. This restructuring represents a reduction in the number of employees of up to 11%. Included in the restructuring is the closing of the Company's Australian research and development office. The Company expects that this restructuring will reduce annualized pre-tax expenses by up to approximately $4.8 million, including up to approximately$465,000 in non-cash stock option expenses. The Company expects to record total restructuring costs of up to approximately $1.9 million in the current fiscal quarter ending March 31, 2008.

Convergys Corp. announced it will close a customer service center here early next year, putting 570 people out of work. The center will close by Feb. 29. Cincinnati-based Convergys provides billing and customer-care services for companies. It has 48,000 employees at 50 call centers and other offices worldwide.
CONVERGYS Corp. trimmed its Brandon workforce by 100 people.

About 1,080 call centre jobs are leaving Alberta following downsizing by Convergys Corporation, which will close its Edmonton call centre June 30. The Edmonton closure affects 400 people. The company is also closing its 280-employee Red Deer centre on June 30, and its Lethbridge operation, with 400 workers, at the end of August.

Convergys Corp. plans to eliminate 275 jobs at its call center in Winnipeg, Manitoba, while opening three new call centers in the Philippines. The Canadian jobs were eliminated because the company lost a customer service contract that the Winnepeg center had been handling. In the Philippines, Convergys will open 3 new call centers April 1, creating 2,900 jobs. The centers are located in Cebu, Quezon City and Laguna. The company had announced last May that it planned to add five new call centers in the Philippines.

Convergys call centre announced that the 130 staff at call centre that set up in Halifax with $28.6 million in government assistance will lose their jobs by the end of the year. The company's call centre in Dartmouth will close on Dec. 31. The rebates are provided after the company creates the jobs, and the investments are often regained through income tax revenues the government receives from the new employees. The agency also announced payroll rebates to help the company open call centres in Truro and Cornwallis in 2004, but both facilities were closed by 2010. Convergys provides assistance to customers of major telecommunications firms. Most of those employees had worked in well-paid positions as technical support representatives. The province offered $14 million in payroll rebates and $5 million for training and recruitment to BlackBerry.

Convergys will close its Moore call center on March 10, laying off up to 375 workers. Call center employees received layoff notices, to comply with federal law that requires some large employers give workers at least 60 days notice of an impending mass layoff. The call center, housed in a leased former Walmart off Interstate 35 north of Southwest 19th Street in Moore, is scheduled to be torn down to make way for a new Sam's Club.

Convergys Corporation announced that it is cutting 20% of its Jacksonville workforce. The company is eliminating 250 positions from its center at 8000 Baymeadows Way. The job cuts come a day after the firm canceled a job fair at the last minute. The company was expected to hire 80 employees at the fair. As of July, the company had about 1,200 workers in Jacksonville.
Convergys Corp. intended to lay off up to 375 employees this fall. The layoff, scheduled for September 23, was disclosed in a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification notice.

Global Crossing Ltd. is implementing measures designed to improve its cost structure in a tough economic environment. These actions include: A previously announced voluntary staff reduction of approximately 800 employees, effective immediately. A further staff reduction of up to 1,600 employees, the majority of whom will come from administration and sales. Salary reductions among senior leadership and selected managers. Real estate consolidations rendering expected annual savings of approximately $150 million through the closure of 71 offices totaling more than 1.2 million square feet. 
 
The Company also said that Anthony Christie, senior vice president of product management, will take on the additional responsibility for developing Global Crossing's conferencing offerings as a self-sufficient business, preparing the business to make a greater ongoing revenue contribution or for a potential sale. Mr. Christie will continue to report to Carl Grivner, COO. Chris Nash, senior vice president of corporate development, will continue to work with the growing number of potential investors interested in acquiring Global Crossing, as well as managing the potential sale of portions of Global Crossing's businesses. Jose Antonio Rios, currently the president of Latin America and the Caribbean operations, will also now manage all European operations. Joe Perrone, executive vice president of finance, will continue to focus on restructuring efforts. To enable him to do so, administrative responsibilities including administration of offices, travel, real estate and vendor management will be distributed to other executives. John Comparin, executive vice president of human resources, will add to his present duties office administration and travel. Dan Wagner, the former head of Global Crossing's European operations, will become senior vice president of information technology, real estate, procurement and vendor management. Mr. Wagner will report to Carl Grivner, COO.
Global Crossing has announced that it has closed 181 offices and plans to close 217 offices by the end of the year as a part of its plan to cut costs.

eBay Inc. announced plans to reduce its global workforce by approximately 10%, affecting about 1,000 employees in addition to several hundred temporary workers and the reduction of open positions. The global reduction is intended to simplify and streamline eBay's organization, improve the company's cost structure and strengthen the overall competitiveness of the company's existing businesses. The company revised its earnings guidance for the third quarter 2008. The company expects to hit the low end of its third quarter 2008 revenue guidance and exceed GAAP and non-GAAP earnings per share guidance as issued in conjunction with its second quarter earnings release on July 16.
eBay Inc. has announced that it will shut down its Polish office, as part of the major cuts it announced recently to its global operations.

eBay Inc. announced that it would cut 400 jobs out of the 1,000 at its single German site in Dreilinden, near Berlin. The company will transfer part of its Customer Care unit to Dublin, Ireland. The whole process is supposed to be completed by mid-2010.

eBay Inc. is mulling the elimination of thousands of jobs in early 2015 as part of the spin-off of its PayPal unit. Ebay could reportedly be looking to attract potential bidders for the company by slimming down through the spin-off and job cuts. The company to be targeting the elimination of about 3,000 positions or 10% of its workforce, with most to the cuts happening at its core marketplace division.

EBay plans to cut 2,400 jobs, or 7% of its staff, in the first quarter to simplify its structure and boost profit ahead of a planned separation of its business. The company announced that the jobs fall across its marketplaces, PayPal and enterprise businesses.
Unnamed sources said that Goldman Sachs Group Inc. plans to layoff at least 2,000 investment-banking employees.

The Goldman Sachs Group Inc. plans to cut its work force by up to 1,000 positions, with a substantial number coming from the firm's research department, according to David Trone, an analyst at Prudential Securities. Mr. Trone said in an interview that Goldman would fire between 500 and 1,000 people, or 2% to 4% of its staff. The firm has been rumored to be considering a plan similar to that of Merrill Lynch & Co., which cut its head count by just over 20% last year.
Goldman Sachs has announced that the company will layoff 1,360 employees, approximately five percent of its workforce, in 2002.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. has announced that the company will cut 12 of 14 investment banking jobs in Singapore to cut costs.
Goldman Sachs has announced that it has cut 991 jobs, or 4.4 percent of its workforce.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. has announced that it will layoff 42 employees, about 5 percent of the traders at its European equities unit, to lower costs.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is dismissing close to 100 stock traders, salespeople and related staff, citing the dearth of business that followed a big buildup during the bull market for stocks.
Goldman Sachs Group Inc. announced that it may fire as much as 5% of its employees, or 1,500 people, over the next few weeks to weed out underperformers.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. has said that it would cut more jobs. The company is planning to eliminate posts in its mortgage and investment banking units because of the credit crisis. The bank is expected to start eliminating jobs in April 2008. It is not known how many jobs are to be cut. The bank had said in January that it was to dismiss about 5% of its employees, which translates to about 1,500 people.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is to cut jobs in the Cayman Islands. The company will be cutting its operations in the Cayman Islands over the next 12 to 18 months. The bank is planning to move its fund accounting business from the island. It will, however continue to run its investor services and corporate services businesses on the island. The bank is planning to retain as many staff as possible by offering relocation packages.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. will lay off as many as 250 workers in Europe, with most cuts coming in London. The job cuts are part of the company's plan to trim its global work force by 10%. The round of cuts is expected to be across several divisions.

The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. announced that it plans to close its principal-strategies unit, which does proprietary trading, following Dodd-Frank financial-regulation overhaul law that restricts such operations.

The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. announced that it will cut 230 jobs in New York City between September and March in 2011. While the cuts represent less than 1% of Goldman's global workforce of 35,700, they come on the heels of reports that the bank is hiring thousands of employees in Singapore, Brazil and India.
Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. announced late June that it will lay off 230 employees due to economic reasons.

The Goldman Sachs Group, Inc. (GS) is shutting down its Canadian 'dark pool' trading operation less than a year after it was launched. Goldman launched its 'Sigma X' dark pool operation last August. Dark pools platforms allow big players to place and match buy-and-sell orders anonymously to avoid tipping off rivals and moving share prices. The Investment Industry Regulatory Organization of Canada said that the service would cease accepting orders as of the close of trading on April 27, 2012.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. is reducing its workforce in Russia by more than 10% due to the company's weak first-quarter results. Having already cut jobs in Russia over the last few months, the U.S. bank is likely to further reduce the number of staff in the country this summer.
Goldman Sachs (GS) will start its third round of job cuts this year from next month, with 98 positions set to be lost. The layoffs with start July 21 and continue until the end of October.

Goldman Sachs Group Inc. plans to lay off 98 employees in New York between July and October. The dismissals, which will happen between July 17 and October 29, are part of a third round of layoffs at the bank.

J Crew Group Inc. laid off about 30 employees from its distribution center and call center in Lynchburg VA, according to the Lynchburg News and Advance. According to the report, the layoffs follow a decline in mail order returns, now that J. Crew accepts returns in its stores.

Sprint said it will cut another 2,100 jobs as part of a move to combine the billings, support and other parts of its operations. Shares of Sprint fell 56 cents to $13.60, a 4 percent decline. Sprint Corp. PCS Group lost 25 cents to $4.80. Last month, Sprint announced plans to eliminate 1,600 jobs in its wireless and other divisions to reduce costs. Under the latest overhaul, Sprint plans to combine some operations to save money and to provide customers with easier ways to sign up for a variety of services.

The company also announced in the third quarter, it's sales edged 3 percent higher to $6.79 billion from $6.57 billion.

Sprint Corp. PCS Group will close its Fort Walton Beach call center and lay off nearly half of its area workforce as part of the telecommunication giant's latest restructuring effort. The company announced that it plans to shut down its call center on Hollywood Boulevard on March 28 and let go 90 of its 200 employees in the Fort Walton Beach market, said Sprint spokesman Jason Duff. Sprint notified the affected employees, mainly call center representatives, on Wednesday that their jobs were being eliminated upon the closure of the call center in March, Duff said.

Select Comfort Corporation confirmed that it is laying off workers. The company confirmed the new layoffs are company wide. The company, which recently laid off 20 of its 3,000 workers, has been pressured by shareholders to close money-losing stores and stop opening stores.

Conexant Systems Inc. announced plans to reduce its worldwide workforce by approximately 300 employees by the end of the calendar year. The headcount reduction is a result of further merger-related synergies and the company's revenue outlook for the September quarter, which was communicated in the company's quarterly earnings call on July 29, 2004, and is lower than the company expected one quarter ago. The reduction will affect employees in Conexant's research and development, technical marketing, and sales, general and administrative groups. This headcount reduction is in addition to the actions announced last April that will affect approximately 200 people by the end of the calendar year.

Conexant Systems Inc. plans to continue improving its capital structure through the early retirement of up to $80 million of its floating rate senior secured notes due in November 2010. The company is commencing a tender offer for $73 million of the notes and intends to purchase an additional $7 million of the notes. If the company decreases the outstanding notes by $80 million, it estimates that interest payments will be reduced by more than $5 million per year. The $80 million used in debt-reduction activities will be a combination of proceeds from the Broadband Access sale and other completed transactions, and cash from the balance sheet. Prior to the completion of the sale of its Broadband Access product lines to Ikanos Communications, the company initiated actions that will reduce core operating expenses by approximately $3 million per quarter exiting the calendar year. The actions consist of non-headcount and headcount-related cost-reductions. Approximately 100 Conexant employees worldwide will be affected by the reduction in force.

InfoSpace Inc. announced that it will lay off 250 of its approximately 620 employees. The layoffs have begun and will continue through the middle of 2007. The cuts will cost InfoSpace about $6.5 million in severance costs and between $6 million and $7 million for other charges.The company also announced that board member Ed Belsheim, who is also chief administrative officer, will leave the company on January 1, 2007.
According to unnamed sources, American Axle and Manufacturing has begun weekly layoffs of 60 to 70 people because of lighter demand from automakers.

American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc. is considering trimming salaried workers while it moves forward with plant closings, including the Tonawanda Forge Plant in 2009. Talk of cuts in the salaried workforce comes four weeks after American Axle reached a new labor agreement with the United Auto Workers union that ended a nearly three-month-long strike. The agreement allows the company to close two plants in New York in Buffalo, where production at the gear and axle plant ended in December 2007, and Tonawanda forge and a forge plant in Detroit. The company earlier announced that it expects to reduce its hourly workforce of 3,650 UAW-represented hourly employees by about 2,000 over the next year through plant closings, buyouts and retirements.

Arch Chemicals Inc. announced that it will discontinue the manufacturing of its BIT molecule and begin sourcing from third-party suppliers to reduce the overall cost of certain of its products in the industrial biocides business. Also announced that it will close its Seal Sands, U.K. production plant and downsize manufacturing at its Huddersfield, U.K. site. This will result in about 50 job cuts, as well as several service agreements. The company expects a pre-tax charge of $20 million-$25 million, the majority of which will be incurred in the second quarter. Arch says it expects to realize projected annualized pre-tax cost savings of about $8 million beginning in 2008. It will continue to produce formulations containing BIT in both the U.S. and England for global end- market uses.

Albany Molecular Research Inc. reaffirmed revenue guidance for the full year 2010. The company reaffirms its full year 2010 non-GAAP financial guidance, expecting an increase in contract revenue of up to 13% versus 2009, which was previously provided on May 5, 2010.As part of cost reduction efforts, the company is reducing its US workforce by approximately 10%, or an estimated 80 jobs. This includes currently open positions that the company is not filling at this time. The company expects that actions to reduce 2010 workforce related costs will result in an estimated $4 million in savings.The company continued shift in demand from customers for services in Asia and Europe. Overall for 2009 and 2010, the company anticipates investing in excess of $30 million on international facility and capability expansions and estimates its non-US workforce will increase by approximately 180 positions in order to meet known and anticipated customer demand.

Albany Molecular Research Inc. announced that it has decided to close its Holywell, U.K. facility following a consultation process with employee representatives. The Holywell site provides chemical development services and small- and large scale-manufacturing services of active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) and intermediates. AMRI will transition activities at the Holywell site to other facilities within the AMRI network and plans to cease operations at the site by the end of 2015. Closure of the site is expected to affect approximately 62 positions.

Corinthian Colleges Inc. has closed all operations and discontinued instruction at its remaining 28 campuses, including the Honolulu campus of Heald College, leaving roughly 16,000 students without a school to attend. The beleaguered Santa Ana was closing 13 remaining Everest and WyoTech campuses in California, Everest College Phoenix and Everest Online Tempe in Arizona, the Everest Institute in New York, and 150-year-old Heald College - including its 10 locations in California, one in Hawaii and one in Oregon.

Delphi Automotive Systems Corp. the world's largest auto-parts maker, lost $131 million the last three months of 2001 due to the price of an ongoing cost-cutting plan and plunging sales from its largest customer, former parent General Motors Corp. Delphi would have made $55 million for the fourth quarter, if not for a onetime charge against earnings of $186 million to account for the pending sale of the company's generator business and losses from investments in Brazil and Argentina. A year ago, Delphi made $200 million for the quarter. The supplier still gets 68 percent of its sales from GM. The loss in the fourth quarter equaled 23 cents per share. Excluding the onetime charges, Delphi made 10 cents per share, matching the estimate from auto analysts. A year ago, it made 36 cents per share. Delphi reported fourth-quarter sales of $6.38 billion, down 7.7 percent from sales of $6.91 billion a year ago. Sales to GM fell by 11 percent, or $525 million, compared to a year ago.
Coming the same day as Ford's fourth-quarter announcement of a loss of $5.07 billion, Dawes said his company was a bit overlooked by Wall Street auto analysts.

For the year, Delphi reported a net loss of $370 million, or 66 cents per share, compared to a profit of $1.06 billion or $1.88 per share a year ago. Excluding various onetime charges -- mostly related to Delphi's cost-cutting plan -- Delphi earned $220 million, or 39 cents a share, in 2001.

Delphi is still working through a cost-cutting plan it announced last March that would close nine of 196 plants worldwide and eliminate 11,500 jobs worldwide from a global workforce of 195,000. So far, Delphi has closed seven plants and cut 10,100 jobs.

Delphi projects first-quarter earnings in 2002, excluding any more onetime charges, of $110 million to $130 million. For the year, it expects earnings of around $275 million. Sales of new cars and trucks are expected to decline by 10 percent or more in 2002, after dipping by 1.4 percent in 2001.

Delphi Automotive Systems Corp. announced it was closing its production facility in Bochum, Germany. The plan calls for reducing its worldwide work force by 11,500 employees, closing nine facilities and consolidating activities at 40 others.
Delphi Automotive Systems announced that the company has closed its Bochum, Germany production facility thereby laying off 329 employees as part of its restructuring plan.
Delphi Automotive Systems Corp. announced that it will layoff 800 employees at its brake plants in order to consolidates its operations by the end of March.
Delphi Corp. announced plans to immediately start the wind down of its global generator product line.
According to unnamed sources, Delphi Automotive Systems may eliminate another 835 jobs at the company's plants in Kettering and suburban Moraine.
Delphi Automotive Systems Inc. may lay off as many as 550 workers in January at its two air-conditioning compressor plants in an effort reduce costs.

Delphi corp. provides the revised fourth quarter and full year 2004 earnings guidance. The company expects to report fourth quarter revenues between $6.9 billion and $7.0 billion, approximately $200 million lower than its prior guidance on a constant exchange basis. fourth quarter net loss was $123 million - $143 million; Excluding the impact of $45 million in restructuring charges in fourth qurter, as well as a $8 million reduction in tax benefits on the first three quarters of restructuring charges due to a reduction of the tax rate, pro forma net loss of $70 million - $90 million.

Full year revenues were $28.5 billion - $28.6 billion.full year net loss of $57 million - $77 million, Excluding the impact of $207 million in restructuring charges in 2004, offset by a $12 million reduction in tax reserves associated with thesubstantial completion of the 1999/2000 U.S. federal tax audit, Current year proforma earnings of $118 million - $138 million.

The company reports outlook for 2005. The company expects to report revenue of approximately $28.5 billion - $29.0 billion, and expects to incur a net loss of $350 million for the 2005.

Delphi is aggressively planning to further reduce its workforce by 8,500 positions in 2005 through GM flowbacks, normal attrition and incentivized retirements. Of the total reductions, 3,000 are expected to be U.S. hourly employees and 5,500 are planned to be non-U.S. employees.
Delphi Corp. said it wants to shed 25 plants as part of its restructuring. That's on top of the 23 former Visteon Corp. parts facilities already on the market.
Delphi Corp. announced to shut its Puerto Real factory in Cadiz, which employs 1,600 people. The shutdown had been announced to union officials. The closure is imminent and irrevocable.

Delphi Corp. announced that it had filed for bankruptcy protection for a Spanish unit as part of a plan to close a money-losing plant in Cadiz, Spain. The parts maker will spend about $70 million this quarter for severance costs for the 1,570 workers at the plant, which makes steering mechanisms.

Delphi Corp. announced that production at the Wichita Falls Delphi plant will grind to a halt late next week. There currently are about 100 full-time employees working at the plant as production winds down. In light of the impending layoffs, Workforce Resource has made resources available to those affected by the closing.

Delphi Corp. announced that it expects to close its powertrain-systems plant in Oak Creek by the end of the year, laying off about 200 employees. The layoffs include mostly manufacturing positions and are expected to be permanent. The auto-parts supplier is based in Troy, Michigan. It used to be part of General Motors Corporation before it was spun off as a separate company in 1999.

Delphi Corp. announced that hourly workers at brake plant on Needmore Road have begun switching over to jobs at General Motors Corp.-related operations as the Delphi plant faces closure. The Delphi plant will close June 29, 2008. Most of the plant's employees have been transferred to jobs at a GM parts warehouse in West Chester Twp., Butler County, or to a similar facility in Trotwood owned by the Jones Group, or they are waiting to be placed elsewhere. The facility, along with a second brake components plant on Wisconsin Boulevard, was part of GM's Delco Chassis operation.

Delphi Corp. has announced that it will lay off workers at its safety component plant in Vandalia (Ohio, United States), in the wake of ongoing bankruptcy reorganization. Kevin Clancey, human resources director for Delphi Electronics and Safety, confirmed in his letter to the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services that the 116 workers at the Vandalia plant will be permanently laid off between August 2009 and January 2010. Delphi has not revealed whether about 200 thermal auto component workers at the plant will be retained in future.
Life Technologies Corporation confirmed that it is closing its Camarillo facility and laying off an undisclosed number of workers.
MKS Instruments Inc. has laid off about 120 employees as part of a previously announced strategy to reduce costs.
The Pepsi bottling plant on Merrow Road will lay off 23 workers and shut down its production of carbonated beverages in mid- November.
Extreme Networks Inc. announced that it will be laying off about 12% of its workforce due to missed sales and earnings expectations.

Extreme Networks announced that it has reduced 8 percent of its full time work force, as part of its plant to reduce cost structure. There have also been cuts in the companys temporary and contract work force.

Extreme Networks Inc. announced the next step in its strategic transformation with a restructuring plan that will lower operating costs in fiscal 2012 by approximately $20 million with the goal of enabling the company to achieve consistent double digit operating income. As part of the organizational changes, the company will be consolidating most of its software engineering resources into its current facilities in lower cost venues, and expects the consolidation to be complete by the end of the calendar year. Transitioning these resources to lower cost areas will enable the company to enhance its R&D investment in new product development and innovation by increasing headcount over the course of the year. The company is reducing headcount in all functional areas outside of R&D, to better align its cost structure with it stated operating model. The restructuring plan will affect approximately 110 people or 16% of its worldwide workforce, and the company will take a pretax restructuring charge of approximately $3.5 million in its fiscal fourth quarter which ended July 3, 2011. The company revised earnings guidance for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2011. The company anticipated revenue will be above prior guidance of $80-$85 million, and will be in the range of $88 - $90 million. Non-GAAP EPS for the quarter should be $0.01 to $0.02 per share, compared to prior guidance of $0.03 - $0.05 per share. EPS on a GAAP basis is anticipated to be a loss in the range of $0.02 - $0.04 per share, and includes estimated charges of approximately $1.5 million for stock-based compensation expense and $3.1 million for restructuring charges, net of reversals.
Heidrick & Struggles has reduced its workforce by about 166 positions, during the first quarter of 2002, to cut costs.
Consol Energy Inc.'s announced that it will lay off 110 miners representing about half of its workforce at its Loveridge No. 22 mine near Fairview, Virginia.

Consol has announced that it is shutting four mines in Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania including the Dilworth mine in Greene County. The company's shutdowns combined with reduction in the number of operating shifts at mines that will eliminate approx

CONSOL Energy Inc. has issued notice under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) of a layoff at Mine 84, near Washington, Pa., that may occur during a 14-day period beginning November 7, 2007. Up to 111 workers at Mine 84 may be affected by the layoff. The mine has a total workforce of 482.

Consol Energy Inc. will eliminate about 100 coal mining jobs from its 84 Mine in Washington County, by the end of the year because there is a substantial amount of rock where mining activity is occurring. Consol Energy's Eighty-Four Mining Co. subsidiary notified the state Department of Labor and Industry on Oct. 17 that the layoffs will begin Dec. 18 and continue for the remainder of the year.

CONSOL Energy Inc. has issued notice under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) of a lay off at its Fola Operations near Bickmore, W. Va. It is expected that the layoffs will occur during a 14-day period beginning at 12:01 a.m., on Sunday, February 7, 2010. Approximately 104 workers at the Little Eagle Coal Company and 378 at the Fola Coal Company may be affected by the layoff. The company attributed the idling at Fola Operations to the appeal of its approved permits to mine brought by the Ohio Valley Environmental Coalition (OVEC). Subsequent to that appeal, Judge Robert C. Chambers, of the United States District Court for the Southern District of West Virginia, Huntington Division, recently issued an order suspending Fola Coal Company's Clean Water Act Section 404 permit for the Ike Fork portions of Fola Operations effective January 23, 2009. Without this permit, neither Fola Coal Company nor Little Eagle Coal Company can satisfy the required specifications of its coal sales contracts.

CONSOL Energy Inc. announced that it will temporarily idle its Buchanan Mine in southwestern Virginia. The longwall mine produces metallurgical grade coal used in steelmaking. CONSOL Energy will also idle at least a portion of the Amonate Mining Complex in southern West Virginia. A determination of whether to partially or fully idle is expected soon, along with an effective idling date. Amonate also produces metallurgical grade coal used in steelmaking. Global steel demand is under pressure and as a consequence, raw materials used to make steel are in less demand. Through these idlings, CONSOL Energy is responding to weak market conditions throughout its export markets in Asia, Europe, and South America. The idlings are expected to last for 30 to 60 days.

CONSOL Energy Inc. announced that it intends to complete the idling of its Fola mining complex in West Virginia, resulting in 147 layoffs at two mines in mid-to late February 2013. CONSOL had announced in June that it was idling the mine in August and laying off 318 employees and reassigning the remaining 147 employees from mining to reclamation work. The 147 employees who had been performing reclamation work will be laid off during a two-week period beginning Feb. 14, 2013. CONSOL attributed its decision to idle Fola to a combination of weak market conditions and increasing regulatory pressures from the U.S. EPA.

Logan Regional Medical Center said Wednesday that it will lay off 16 workers but raise wages for many of its remaining employees. Interim CEO Ron Tyrer said the cuts were made after comparing staffing levels with industry measures and similar sized hospitals owned by LifePoint Hospitals Inc. . The layoffs are in ten different areas of the hospital and are the first since the purchase.

Brocade has announced it plans to cut 110 jobs, or 9% of its total workforce. The workforce reduction was planned after an analysis of all company operations conducted by internal teams in each department.
U.S. Concrete Inc. has announced that it has restructured its Dallas/Ft. Worth operations by exiting certain non-core businesses and, thereby, reduced its operating and administrative staff.
RJ Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc. are reportedly bracing for a round of layoffs as the No. 2 cigarette company readies cost cuts in an attempt to turn around a profit slump.
RJ Reynolds Tobacco Holdings Inc. announced that it will reduce its work force by 40%. The work force reduction is done to reduce its costs and its combats competition from low cost brands.

On May 28, 2010, Reynolds American Inc. announced a consolidation and upgrading of manufacturing facilities at multiple operating companies. A cigarette factory in Winston-Salem, North Carolina and one in Yabucoa, Puerto Rico will close, and production from those facilities will transfer to RJRTCs facility in Tobaccoville, North Carolina. As a result of the consolidation, approximately 60 manufacturing positions in Puerto Rico will be eliminated, and affected employees will receive severance benefits. American Snuff Company, LLC is expanding its manufacturing operations inMemphis, Tennessee, expecting the new facilities to be fully operational in early 2012, and increasing its tobacco-processing capacity in Clarksville, Tennessee, expecting the new facilities to be fully operational in early 2012.

F5 Networks, a Seattle-based Internet traffic equipment firm, has fired 100 employees or 17% of its staff following an $8.9 million loss, or 41 cents per share, for the fiscal quarter that ended December 31.
Skechers USA Inc. has announced that it has laid off five percent of its workforce and closed its catalog operation as a part of its plan to cut costs.
Openwave Systems Inc. has announced plans to cut about 475 of its roughly 1,900 workers as part of a restructuring plan.

Openwave Systems Inc. announced a reduction of approximately 18% to 20% of the workforce. As part of the restructuring, the company intends to reduce its spending on legacy products and solutions that have been underperforming. The company said it expects to reduce annual Non-GAAP operating expenses by about 30%, or $30 - $32 million, on a year-over-year basis.
SBA Communications has announced that it has laid off 250 employees, approximately 18 percent of its workforce, as a part of its plan to cut costs.

The SBA Communications Corp. plans to cut an unspecified number of jobs, close offices and build fewer towers this year. The company expects to build or buy 250 to 350 towers this year, instead of 400 to 600, it said in a statement.
Ariba Inc. announced that in an effort to reduce spending, it will lay off 700 employees which represents approximately one third of its workforce.

CyberSource Corporation which announced Nov. 27 that it would close its 30-employee software development group office in St. Louis, said last week that it would eliminate roughly 70 more jobs. The two cuts, to be completed by March 31, would amount to 36% of the work force at the Mountain View, Calif., company, which provides payment and fraud management services to Web merchants.

IAC Search & Media, Inc. is laying off about 130 engineers as it abandons its own technology for indexing and recommending websites. The retreat announced is aimed at cutting Ask.com's costs while sharpening its focus on finding answers to search requests posed in the form of a question. As part of that shift, Ask.com is closing its offices in Edison, N.J., and Hangzhou, China. That will reduce Ask.com's work force of about 400 employees by nearly one-third and concentrate its remaining offices in the San Francisco Bay area. Ask.com will rely on formulas developed by another search engine to process general-purpose requests that aren't posed as questions. It didn't disclose the identity of its new search provider, citing a confidentiality agreement.

Lennox International Inc. announced that 270 hourly workers in Danville, Illinois will lose their jobs when the company closes its refrigeration operations due to increased domestic and foreign competition. The company plans to consolidate Danville's manufacturing, support and warehouse functions in its Tifton and Stone Mountain locations in Georgia over the next 18 months. The company attributed the action to weakness in the residential new construction market.

Blockbuster Inc. plans to lay off up to 20% of its headquarters staff in Dallas and the suburb of McKinney. Between 200 and 300 jobs will be eliminated, including open positions that won't be filled. The cuts are designed to help offset an incremental $70 million that the company said it would spend this year on Blockbuster Online. Blockbuster earlier said it would have to cut costs and reduce its corporate staff to help build its growing online DVD rental business.

Blockbuster Inc. plans to cut 300 jobs as part of a $75 million cost-cutting campaign, the second round of layoffs in less than a year for the nation's largest chain of video stores. Blockbuster announced that it would lay off 200 corporate employees over the next two weeks and won't fill 100 vacant jobs. Less than a year ago, the Dallas-based chain had 1,500 corporate jobs, divided between offices in downtown Dallas and suburban McKinney. Blockbuster eliminated 200 jobs last spring, mostly through layoffs, as the company came under pressure from financier Carl Icahn to cut costs.

Blockbuster Inc. has taken over the operations of four Blockbuster Video outlets in Lexington, and six other Blockbuster locations across the city have closed, all as a result of unspecified difficulties faced by the company's Lexington franchisee. The company had assumed control of Blockbuster stores at 2925 Richmond Road, 4222 Saron Drive, 921 Beaumont Centre Parkway and 551 Euclid Avenue. Six other Lexington Blockbuster locations have closed at 2467 Nicholasville Road, 1650 Bryan Station Road, 3090 Helmsdale Place, 450 Southland Drive, 3735 Palomar Centre Drive and 4101 Tates Creek Pike.
Blockbuster Inc. announced that it may close all of its 7,400 retail locations globally.

Blockbuster Video announced that it is closing some of its stores locally as part of a nationwide retrenching of its troubled business. The company will not disclose a list of all locations to be closed. But stores at N. 124th St. and W. Capitol Drive in Brookfield, W. National Ave. at S. Moorland Road in New Berlin, and N. Farwell Ave. in Milwaukee and S. Chicago Ave. in South Milwaukee have posted closing signs.
Blockbuster Inc. is closing two local stores as part of a plan to reduce its number of locations by about 20%.

Nineteen Blockbuster locations across Central Virginia operated by Bay Management, a Franchisee of Blockbuster Inc. will be closing January 3, 2010. These stores are located in Blacksburg, Charlottesville, Christiansburg, Daleville, Harrisonburg, Lexington, Lynchburg, Madison Heights, Martinsville, Roanoke, Salem, Staunton, Waynesboro, Winchester and Vinton. Any product out for rental will need to return to any of these Blockbuster locations by the due date.

Blockbuster Inc. plans to close 182 stores by the end of the first quarter of next year as it tries to find a way back on its feet. The company plans to close 72 stores by Jan. 1 and 110 more in the first quarter of 2011.

Blockbuster Inc. will close three more Hawaii stores on April 10. On Oahu, the Blockbuster store at 848 Ala Lilikoi St. in Honolulu and the store at 86-120 Farrington Highway in Waianae are scheduled to close. On the Big Island, the Blockbuster location at 74-5586 Palani Road in Kailua-Kona will be shut down.

Blockbuster Inc. announced that it will close more than half of its Tulsa-area stores by April 10 as the movie rental chain tries to reposition and reorganize after a bankruptcy filing last year. The chain has closed or is closing 11 of its 21 stores in the metro area. The closings will leave some communities, such as Sand Springs, Sapulpa and Claremore, without the presence of a national video rental chain after Hollywood Video shuttered all of its stores in February 2010. The company has been closing stores since September when it filed for bankruptcy with $900 million in debt. It now has about 3,000 stores, down from more than 9,100 in 2004.

BB Liquidating Inc. is closing both its remaining area DVD and video game rental stores, one on 5063 W. Main St. and the other at 4308 S. Westnedge Ave. The final day of business at both locations will be February 19, 2012. These closures are based on store performance and lease agreements. Unfortunately, these stores are being closed for one of these reasons.
Blockbuster Video is set to shut its doors September 2, 2012. The company announced to close Middletown store, look for new location.

Tween Brands Inc. laid off about two dozen workers at its New Albany headquarters. The layoffs, which represent less than 5% of the company's New Albany work force of more than 500, came as a result of a recent study on cost-savings opportunities and does not reflect the company's recent performance. Unlike many retailers, Tween posted good results for the holiday season, with average same-store sales up 9% compared with the same period a year earlier.

SpectraSite Holdings Inc. said that it plans to lay off as much as 10 percent of its work force, or about 200 employees, and scale back expansion plans to reassure investors amid a continuing telecommunications industry slowdown.

KANA Software Inc. has terminated the employment of Alan Hubbard, Executive Vice President Products and Technology, effective as of January 15, 2006.

Kana Software has acted to terminate the employment of approximately 18 employees based in New Hampshire. This reduction in force is expected to be completed by the end of January 2006.

As a result of this consolidation, KANA will incur restructuring charges of approximately $1.0 million to $1.5 million, primarily related to excess leased facilities and severance costs. This charge will be recorded in KANA's fourth quarter of 2005 ended December 31, 2005.
OMNOVA Solutions Inc. has announced that the company has eliminated an unspecified number of positions in its wallcovering business in United Kingdom, in order to cut costs.
InterNap Network Services announced that it has laid off 118 workers representing 15% of its workforce. This is in part to the declined demand for Internet connections.

Internap Network Services Corporation reiterated its fourth quarter 2001 guidance for revenue growth and EBITDA losses, as well as announced additional cost-cutting measures including the elimination of 70 full-time equivalents or approximately 13 percent of its staff. 

Internap also stated that it is satisfied with First Call consensus revenue estimates of $30.33 million for the fourth quarter 2001. The company previously projected a sequential increase in revenue growth for the fourth quarter, a drop in quarterly EBITDA losses to $15 - $17 million resulting in annual EBITDA losses of approximately $99- $101 million.

BlackRock, Inc. announced that starting at the end of next month, the company would cut 59 jobs in San Francisco in order to eliminate expenses. The asset manager added that it would focus on key priorities, and at the same time the firm would identify ways to update processes, adding that some recent procedures included shifting some personnel, employing select key talent, and in some cases reducing positions.

BlackRock, Inc. is planning to cut around 15 staff in its European iShares business, at a time when its US operation is also making redundancies, Wealth Manager understands. The move is part of the firm's response to the 'challenging' economic conditions which has seen BlackRock streamline both its US and European iShares businesses.

BlackRock Inc. plans to lay off 500 of its workers, or 3% of its worldwide headcount, in the coming weeks.This follows news that BlackRock has promoted Mark Wiedman to head the company's international operations and corporate strategy.
Williams Communications announced that it has laid off 700 employees, approximately 25 percent of its workforce at Tulsa, as a result of the economic downturn.

Williams Communications Group Inc. announced layoffs of about 800 employees Including nearly 500 Tulsa workers. The cuts will be spread throughout the company, which is trying to cut expenses by 25 percent. After the layoffs, Wil-Com will have some 2,300 employees in Tulsa and about 3,200 worldwide.
World Wrestling Federal Entertainment Inc. announced that it has laid off 39 employees, approximately nine percent of its work force following the decrease in the demand.

Akamai Technologies Inc. announced that it will take a restructuring action in the fourth quarter to reduce certain operating costs. The Company expects to use the ongoing savings generated by this action and its continuing cash from operations to support investments in key growth opportunities for content delivery, application acceleration, and its advertising industry solutions, as well as for further international expansion. As a result of these cost cutting measures, Akamai expects to take a restructuring charge of approximately $4 million this quarter for severance and related expenses. These costs are anticipated to be partially offset by a net reduction in non-cash stock-based compensation of $0.8 million, reflecting a modification to certain stock-based awards previously granted to the affected employees. Approximately 110 employees, or 7% of Akamai's worldwide employee population, will be affected. Additionally, the Company expects to recognize a loss on sublease income of approximately $2.5 million related to certain leased facilities.

Charter Communications Inc. announced that it would cut about 300 jobs, citing an expected 20 percent decline in sales during the final quarter of the year. Singapore-based chip Chartered, the world's third-largest semiconductor foundry operator, said the layoffs amount to about a 7 percent reduction in its staff. The company intends to save $8 million a year and it will take a charge of $5 million during the fourth quarter as a result of the job cuts, most of them in Singapore.

Charter Communications Inc. Reports second quarter that ended in September, reported a loss of $89.4 million, or 56 cents a share, on sales of $129.5 million. During the same quarter last year, Chartered reported a loss of $118.3 million, or 74 cents a share, on revenue of $79.2 million.

Expedia Inc. announced that it will close its Tacoma call center by the end of the year. The company plans to transfer some of the work from the Tacoma office to Las Vegas. An unspecified number of workers in Tacoma will be offered jobs at the Las Vegas center or Expedia's Bellevue headquarters.
Rudolph Technologies Inc. has announced that it is laying off about 10 percent of its employees because of weakness in the semiconductor industry.

On November 14, 2014, Rudolph Technologies Inc. approved a restructuring plan designed to reduce the company's cost structure. Under the Plan, the company expects the global headcount to decrease by approximately 4%. In conjunction with this reduction in headcount, the company will close its facility in Mainz, Germany.The company also announced that it will relocate the operations to its facilities in Snoqualmie, Washington and Bloomington, Minnesota with a target completion by the end of March 2015.Effective November 14, 2014, D. Mayson Brooks, Senior Vice President, Worldwide Sales & Field Operations, is no longer employed by the company.

Test-and-measurement equipment maker Agilent Technologies Inc. will cut another 4,000 jobs despite meeting Wall Street's expectations in its fiscal fourth quarter. The reductions are in addition to the 4,000 announced in August and are part of a continuing effort to cut costs amid the economic slump. The combined total represents 19 percent of the company's work force.

For the three months ended Oct. 31, Agilent earned $197 million, or 43 cents a share, compared with $305 million, or 66 cents a share, in the same period a year ago. The net earnings were boosted by a $1.1 billion pretax gain from the sale of Agilent's health care business to Philips. For the year, Agilent earned $174 million, or 38 cents per share, compared with $757 million, or $1.68 per share last year. Fiscal 2001 revenue was $6.4 billion, compared with $10.6 billion last year.

Agilent Technologies Inc. announced that it will sell off some of its parts and return to its roots as the test-and-measurement business. The company agreed to sell its semiconductor chip division to an investor group for $2.66 billion and take a series of other actions -- including laying off 1,300 of its 28,000 employees -- as part of a restructuring aimed at transforming the conglomerate into a more focused company.Agilent is also selling its stake in Lumileds Lighting, which makes light-emitting diodes aimed at replacing light bulbs, to its partner Philips Electronics for $950 million plus repayment of $50 million in debt held by Lumileds. And it plans to spin off its chip-testing equipment business in 2006 as a separate company.

Agilent Technologies announced that it will lay off 450 workers around the world after profits fell 34% in the second quarter. The job cuts will affect 2% of Agilent's global workforce. The timing and scope of the reductions will vary based on local legal requirements. There was no information immediately available on layoff implications for the company's Sonoma County operations. The company employs 1,150 people in the county.

Retek Inc. said that it is cutting about 130 jobs, or 15 percent of its work force, and reducing discretionary spending to bring expenses in line with lower revenue expectations. Retek, which provides software and services to retailers, said third quarter revenue fell 15 percent to $40.5 million from $47.5million in the third quarter of 2001 and 33 percent from $60.8 million in the second quarter of this year. For the fourth quarter, Retek said it expects revenue of $35 million to $37 million. Retek shares fell 22 percent, or 58 cents, to $1.99 on the Nasdaq Stock Market.
John Hancock Financial Services will close its call center in Albuquerque, thereby laying off 130 employees, as part of the company's ongoing expense reduction program.

Gentiva Health Services Inc. will lay off 75 Connecticut workers by February. The move stems from a change in a contract between health insurer CIGNA HealthCare and CareCentrix, a Gentiva unit that provides administrative services and coordinates home health services for managed care organizations and commercial health plans.
Palm Inc., in a continuing effort to reduce company costs, is continuing with its March plan to reduce its employee headcount.

Palm Inc. reached a point of no return when it announced plans to close all but one of its retail stores. The news follows an extensive period of troubles for the Sunnyvale, Calif., company, which explored various turnaround plans for more than a year and last June sold a 25% stake to the private equity firm Elevation Partners.
UTStarcom Inc. announced that it plans to cut 17% of its workforce to offset a sharp drop in revenue from a unique wireless service it offers in China.

UTStarcom Inc. announced it plans to cut 700 jobs, or about 11% of its work force, as part of a restructuring plan to reduce operating costs. The cuts will be mainly in the United States and China. As a result, the company expects to record a restructuring charge of about $10 million in the fourth quarter, for severance costs. The company said it should realize annual cost savings in salary and compensation-related expenses of about $21 million.

Edwards Lifesciences Corp. announced that it plans to lay off 130 people, or 2.5 percent of its work force worldwide. About 80 of the lay offs are in Orange County. The cuts are in corporate, administrative- support and operations.

Energizer Holdings Inc. has announced that high operating costs in the country and excess global manufacturing capacity led top executives to order the closure of its 40-year-old Eveready carbon zinc battery plant in Jagobiao, Mandaue City in May. The company said following the closure of the plant, all battery requirements in the country will be imported from affiliate plants in Asia. The Eveready carbon zinc batteries that have been produced at the plant in Jagobiao, Mandaue City will soon be sourced from Indonesia. The company said 100 plant workers will be affected by the closure. The company assured that the employees affected by the closure will be provided with a very reasonable severance package, as well as an outplacement program including skills and livelihood training, transition management and counseling.
Energizer Holdings Inc. announced that they anticipate more layoffs due to likely decreases in sales volume, and that they will detail those changes by early June.

HealthStream Inc. is closing its Laurel office and laying off 134 people who work there. HealthStream's Maryland Patient Interview Center housed a patient experience research team that is being consolidated with other patient experience research operations in Tennessee. The layoffs are expected to occur between April 30, 2017 and June 30, 2017.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. is closing a northeast Ohio doughnut plant citing oversupply. The Winston-Salem-based company announced that it will shutter its $4.6 million plant in Ravenna on Oct. 16 because too many doughnuts are being made and not sold.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. announced that it has planned to close three stores in Ontario. The stores, in Toronto, Oakville and Windsor, will shut after an extensive analysis of the business showed there was excess production capacity in Ontario. After the closures, the company's Ontario store count will drop to six from nine.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. closed two of its four First Coast stores on Sunday. Stores on Cassat Avenue and in Orange Park closed. The Cassat Avenue store opened in 1970; the Orange Park store, 1995. The company closed 30 underperforming stores, reduced overhead costs and strengthened its senior management team.

Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc. is scrapping its test of bakery stores in Wal-Mart stores. The beleaguered Winston-Salem, N.C., doughnut maker will close five outlets in Wal-Mart stores around the United States.

MetLife Inc. plans to lay off 35 employees in the Independent Agent Underwriting department of the MetLife Auto & Home unit, effective September 19, 2003. It involves administrative and management employees.

MetLife Inc. will cut its U.S. work force by 600 employees as a part of its acquisition of Travelers Life and Annuity. MetLife announced that it will offer ongoing employment to 1,400 of Travelers' 2,000 workers. About 1,100 of the positions will remain in Hartford, Conn.
MetLife Inc. is laying off 118 workers in Irvine as part of the company's plan to shut down its nationwide mortgage operation.

Exelixis, Inc. announced that the Board of Directors of the company approved a restructuring plan that is expected to result in a reduction of the companys workforce by approximately 65% over a two-year period. The company had approximately 400 employees as of December 1, 2010. The restructuring plan is a consequence of the companys decision to focus its investments and proprietary activities on the late-stage development and commercialization of its lead compound XL184. The company expects to complete an initial reduction of approximately 40% of its personnel, consisting of a reduction of approximately 144 employees and the elimination of an additional 16 currently open positions, by the end of 2010. Personnel reductions will be made across the companys entire organization, including discovery, development and general & administrative departments. Further personnel reductions are expected to be made through the end of 2012 as the company completes its obligations under collaboration agreements and withdraws resources from completed projects.
Exelixis, Inc. announced that the company will reduce its workforce by 70%, or approximately 160 employees, resulting in approximately 70 remaining employees.
Bookham has announced that the company is laying off 17 percent of its workforce after Nortel Networks Corp. stopped buying some of its products.

Bookham Technology plc U.K. posted a net loss for the fourth quarter of 46 million pounds, including exceptional charges of 26.3 million. Revenue 14.3 million pounds up 88 sequentially.

Bookham Technology plc said it plans to significantly downsize the manufacturing and R&D of its ASOC product line at its Milton facility as it seeks to reduce its overall cash burn. The move will result in the loss off about 200 jobs.

Bookham Inc. announced layoffs as part of a cost-cutting drive and replaced its chief executive. The company launched a cost-cutting plan to save between $6 million to $7 million per quarter in the September 2007 quarter. The company said that the savings will come mainly from layoffs, consolidation at Bookham's British semiconductor operation and shifting more development activities to China.

About 180 employees have been laid off by eFunds Corporation, a software development and electronic payment services business spun off in 2000 from Shoreview-based Deluxe Corp. Spokeswoman Drea Garrison said the layoffs, which affect operations at its Shoreview and Woodbury locations in Minnesota and in Glendale, Wis., New Berlin, Wis., and Phoenix, were effective immediately.
AT&T Wireless Services Inc. records $47 million charge in second quarter 2003 related to restructuring costs Including reduction of 1500 employees.
NRG Energy has announced that it plans to layoff 55 employees, about 78 percent of the workforce based at its Devon station, on August 1, 2002.

More than a dozen jobs will be eliminated this spring in the Houston office of NRG Energy Inc. as a result of the company's merger with GenOn Energy Inc. In a Jan. 16 Worker Adjustment and Retraining Act notice to the Texas Workforce Commission, NRG said a round of 13 job losses are expected between March 21 and April 3, bringing the total so far to 107 jobs lost in the Houston market. Between the two companies, about 500 positions are expected to be eliminated. The company said still, it has 45 job openings in other Houston departments. Eleven other positions have been filled since November.

NRG Energy announced that it notified about 100 area employees and contract workers that it was eliminating their jobs as part of a cost-cutting move. The company said that the job cuts affect workers at company's subsidiaries Reliant Energy and Green Mountain.

NRG Energy has notified the PJM Interconnection that its 510-MW coal plant in northern Illinois will not be bidding into PJM's 2019-2020 capacity auction and will be shut down by mid-2018 unless market conditions change. The company confirmed that it notified PJM Interconnection LLC on Dec. 1, 2015 that its remaining unit at the Will County coal plant in Romeoville, Ill., will not be bidding into PJM's 2019-2020 base residual auction.

NRG Energy Inc. has filed a notice with the state Department of Labor of plans to lay off 72 workers at the Huntley Generating Station in Tonawanda. The company has previously said it would shut the plant in 2016, likely around March 1, 2016. The labor notice, filed under the state's WARN procedure, said the layoffs are to occur between March 31, 2016 and June 30, 2016. NRG's plant in Dunkirk is also expected to be mothballed in 2016. The closings follow studies done by energy regulators that determined the plants are no longer needed.
Visteon Corp. announced that the company has eliminated 150 engineering jobs in Michiganin as part of its program to reduce the research and development spending by 10 percent.

Visteon Corp. laid off 80 salaried employees in late January to cut costs. Most of those cut were quality engineers and managers, according to a person familiar with the company who didn't want to be named. Visteon confirmed the layoffs but wouldn't say in which areas the employees worked.
Visteon Corp. is expected to shed up to 80 jobs after relocating part of its manufacturing operations overseas.

Visteon Corp. plans deep cuts to retirement health coverage and life insurance benefits for thousands of salaried workers. The cutbacks could impact about 6,700 white-collar workers. The salaried workers who retire on or after June 1, 2007 will no longer receive company-subsidized health insurance. As many as 4,300 employees will be forced to pay 100% of their health care premiums after retirement.

Visteon Corp. plans to close three plants and put another six up for sale under a restructuring plan that could affect up to 23 of its facilities worldwide. Under the new restructuring plan, Visteon plans to close plants in Monterrey, Mexico, and Rio Grande, Puerto Rico, in the first quarter of this year. It plans to close a third plant in Buffalo, N.Y., in the third quarter, although around 70 customer service and engineering employees at the Buffalo plant are expected to keep their jobs. It also plans to transfer 100 jobs from its plant in Swansea, Wales, to Ford. Visteon didn't release the total number of employees who could be affected. Visteon has around 15,800 employees in North America, including 11,000 hourly workers at 35 plants. The company has a total of 50,000 hourly and salaried employees at 170 facilities worldwide. In addition to the closures, Visteon trying to sell six plants and would give more details as talks progress. The company said it's working with 12 plants to transfer work to other facilities or close out product lines.

Visteon Corp. announced that the company plans to lay off 74 hourly workers at its Bedford plant. The layoffs are indefinite and take effect on April 2, 2006. Workers also were given the option to leave immediately with pay. The plant in Bedford, about 65 miles southwest of Indianapolis, currently employs about 975 hourly and salaried workers.
Visteon Corp. has announced that the company plans to close two other Indiana factories, a 900-worker plant in Connersville and a 695-employee facility in Bedford.

Visteon Corp. has announced a three-month delay in closing its Connersville (Indiana) plant, citing continuing demand for the plant's parts from customers. Instead of closing in September, as was announced back in February, the plant will continue operating for three additional months as Visteon instead conducts two job cuts between now and then. Originally the plant was to close when the United Auto Workers (UAW) union contract ended on 14 September, but a contract extension will allow the plant to continue operating. As part of its massive restructuring efforts, the company aims to fix, sell, or close nearly 30 facilities by 2009, several of them in the Indianapolis (Indiana) area.

Visteon Corp. plans to close its one-year-old Eureka plant by the end of the year 2009, affecting 94 workers. The plant, which made door panels, cockpits and consoles for Chrysler, lost its biggest customer when Chrysler stopped making Dodge Ram trucks at its Fenton facility in July.
Janus Capital Group Inc. announced that it has eliminated 60 positions in the second quarter.

Axcelis Technologies Inc. announced a two-pronged restructuring plan that allows the company to reduce operating costs and improve liquidity while continuing to penetrate new markets with its Optima and Integra product lines. As part of the first component of the restructuring plan, the company is reducing its workforce by approximately 200 positions, or roughly 14% of its employees worldwide.

Axcelis Technologies Inc. announced a global workforce reduction of approximately 235, or 20% of its employees, since year end 2008. The company had previously implemented a series of cost saving activities including furloughs, plant shutdowns and layoffs. Given the severity of this downturn, these additional actions were required to better align operating costs with near term revenue expectations. The reductions are estimated to yield savings of $25 million annually.

McDATA Corp. announced a workforce reduction of 92 employees, or approximately 9 percent. Following the workforce reduction, the company's worldwide workforce totals approximately 982 employees. McDATA has implemented these cost-improvement actions to optimize its operating efficiency and to better align its business model.

McDATA Corp. announced that about 150 workers are being laid off as a result of McDATA Corp.'s $973 million acquisition by Brocade Communication Systems. The jobs were being eliminated after Brocade, a network equipment manufacturer, completed its purchase of the storage-equipment manufacturer.
Avaya announced that it will lay off 220 workers, representing 6% of its workforce.
Avaya Inc. announced that it will cut 11 pct of its staff or representing 3,000 jobs.

Avaya Inc. announced that it plans to eliminate 400 to 500 management positions and has offered early retirement packages to about 1,700 union workers. The two moves would reduce the companys worldwide work force by nearly 13 percent.
Avaya Inc. announced in August 2002 it would cut 407 jobs in Omaha because of a decline in demand for its products.
Avaya announced that it plans to cut some 60 jobs from a total 145 in Austria due to the rationalisation of distribution.
Avaya Inc. announced that it will close offices in the U.S. and cut 40 jobs in Europe, the Middle East and Africa as part of a broader restructuring.

More than 60 jobs are to be lost at Avaya. Workers at the firm's Sandyford base were in shock after learning that they were to be paid basic statutory redundancy, which entails two weeks' pay per year of service plus an extra week. A further 34 workers will transfer to the western base as part of the plan.
TTM Technologies Inc. has announced that it plans to layoff 130 employees at its Burlington plant as a result of the decline in sale.

TTM Technologies Inc. announced that weak demand is forcing it to close two California plants that together employ 347 workers. The layoffs represent about 11% of TTM's work force. The closures are expected to result in about $14 million in annual savings.The company reported that production at the Los Angeles facility will be transferred to other sites in California, Utah and Wisconsin. Backplane assembly services provided by the Hayward plant will be transferred to the plants in Shanghai, China and Stafford Springs, Conn.Excluding impairment charges and closure costs, the company announced that it is on track to achieve its guidance for the third quarter of 2009. The company has forecast earnings of 9 cents to 15 cents per share and revenue in a range of $134 million to $142 million.`

TTM Technologies Inc. announced that it will close its Cuyahoga Falls plant and lay off more than 70 people starting later the year 2015 as it consolidates operations following a major acquisition. At least some Falls employees will be relocated to a newly acquired plant in North Jackson Township in Mahoning County. The first layoffs are expected no sooner than December 21, 2015 with final layoffs taking place in April 2016. Employees who are not transferred to North Jackson will be eligible for separation and other benefits. It will also close a plant in Mexico. The company said the moves will result in 550 job cuts about $16.5 million in annual cost savings. The company said it will record one-time closing-related charges of $15 million to $20 million.
Oplink Communications Inc. is cutting about 50 percent of its worldwide workforce as part of its ongoing restructuring efforts.
Mirant has announced that the company is closing its Berlin office.
Mirant Corp. announced a new round of unspecified job cuts in October 2003, in order to reduce costs.

Mirant's 482-MW Potomac coal-fired power plant -- a critical asset to the Washington, D.C., electric grid reliability -- was shut down as the company grappled to find an environmental solution to emissions concerns.
Last week, Mirant said the findings of an environmental computer modeling study of air quality led to immediately reduced output of all five units at the plant -- to their lowest feasible levels.
