The computer model was designed to analyze local air quality levels using a worst-case set of assumptions, so further study of the results may yield additional insight.

Mirant Corp. announced that it plans to mothball two major Bay Area power plants because it has been unable to negotiate long-term contracts with any power purchasers. The plants have a generating capacity totaling a little more than 1,000 megawatts, enough power for 750,000 homes. The shutdown of plants in Antioch and Pittsburg would cut into California's margin for error this summer, but wouldn't seriously deplete supplies.

Mirant Corporation and RRI Energy, Inc. announced that they are combining in a $1.61 billion stock-swap deal, renaming the company and creating a utility powerhouse that will become one of the nation's largest independent power producers. The combined company, which will have a market capitalization of about $3.1 billion, will be called GenOn Energy. There likely will be job cuts among the two companies' 3,600 employees, but how many has not been decided.

Mirant Corporation and RRI Energy, Inc. announced that they are combining in a $1.61 billion stock-swap deal, renaming the company and creating a utility powerhouse that will become one of the nation's largest independent power producers. The combined company, which will have a market capitalization of about $3.1 billion, will be called GenOn Energy. There likely will be job cuts among the two companies' 3,600 employees, but how many has not been decided.

Mirant Corporation and RRI Energy, Inc. announced that they are combining in a $1.61 billion stock-swap deal, renaming the company and creating a utility powerhouse that will become one of the nation's largest independent power producers. The combined company, which will have a market capitalization of about $3.1 billion, will be called GenOn Energy. There likely will be job cuts among the two companies' 3,600 employees, but how many has not been decided.

Mirant Corporation and RRI Energy, Inc. announced that they are combining in a $1.61 billion stock-swap deal, renaming the company and creating a utility powerhouse that will become one of the nation's largest independent power producers. The combined company, which will have a market capitalization of about $3.1 billion, will be called GenOn Energy. There likely will be job cuts among the two companies' 3,600 employees, but how many has not been decided.

GenOn Energy, Inc. announced that the Potrero Hill plant, one of the dirtiest in California, will cease operations on Jan. 1, 2011. The plant, operated by the company could be fired up in the event of a dramatic power emergency before being decommissioned permanently on Feb. 28, 2011. The impending closure comes after bruising political infighting at City Hall and is a clear victory for residents of the oft-neglected southeast corner of the city. Many residents there suffer from disproportionately high rates of cancer, asthma and other health problems. Some have fought for more than a decade to shut down the plant, which sits between the waterfront and a residential neighborhood. The central sticking point to shutting down the plant was a state requirement that the city have adequate power sources during a major disaster, like an earthquake. The proposed plant would have consisted of three 'peakers' and only used during peak energy demand. The natural-gas turbines would have reduced, but not eliminated, the pollution generated. The plant would also have given the city a reliable generation source if it wanted to embark on a public power plan to provide residents an alternative to utility monopoly Pacific Gas and Electric Co.

GenOn Energy, Inc. has put power plants in Elrama, Washington County, and in New Castle on its list of eight plants to shut down by May 2015 because of environmental regulations. Elrama, a 460-megawatt plant, will be deactivated in June. The 330-megawatt New Castle plant is expected to close in April 2015. According to the company, the eight plants in Pennsylvania, Ohio and New Jersey represent about 13% of its generating capacity, or 3,140 megawatts in the wholesale market. One megawatt can power about 800 homes. But the plants, seven of which burn coal, don't generate enough profit to cover costs of complying with new air pollution rules.

Greatbatch Inc. plans to close three plants as part of its push to consolidate its production facilities and eliminate excess capacity. The consolidation will close plants in Minnesota, New Jersey and Pennsylvania and shift that work to other Greatbatch facilities. The shifts are expected to result in a few jobs being added at the company's headquarters and research and development center in Clarence. The consolidations will eliminate some duplicate positions. The consolidation plan will cost Greatbatch between $5.7 million and $7 million, mostly in severance and other personnel expenses, along with write-offs of some assets. The company has been trying to reduce its costs by consolidating operations and cut overhead in the wake of the seven acquisitions the company has made since the start of last year. The company is closing its plant in Blaine, Minn., and shifting the research and development and production work for its catheter and micro components product lines to its 98,000 square foot factory in Plymouth, Minn. That shift is expected to be completed by September 2009. The company also is closing its commercial battery factory in Teterboro, N.J., and shifting that work to the company's new facility in Raynham, Mass. The company also is shutting its orthopedic products facility in Exton, Pa. and shifting that work to other sites that are closer to Greatbatch's customers, factories or its Clarence R&D center.

Integer Holdings Corp. is shifting operations from the plant - which manufactures machined components - to a site in Brooklyn Park, Minnesota, run by another Integer subsidiary, Lake Region Medical. The company is closing a Clarence factory that employs 120 people. Integer said it would assist the affected employees with placement assistance and career counseling. The Clarence factory represents 12% of the Greatbatch Medical workforce in Western New York. The company also has a corporate office in Clarence that employs, and factories in Alden (355 employees) and Orchard Park (270 employees).

SFBC International Inc. plans to shut its Florida operations after being told to demolish its 350-bed unit in Miami. SFBC's Florida operations have more than 500 employees. The company's decision to pull out of Florida is going to send a signal through the entire drug industry that human-subject protection is not a nicety or a courtesy, but a bold-faced moral and legal requirement.

Monsanto Co. announced that it's doubling its work force reductions and cutting another 900 jobs. In June 2009, the company said it was eliminating about 4% of its staff, or about 900 jobs, but announced a new target of 8%, or about 1,800 jobs. Of this total, about 600 jobs will be cut in the United States, including 300 in St. Louis. Most U.S. workers have been notified.
Monsanto Co. announced to cut 900 jobs, or 4% of its work force.

Monsanto Co. recently announced internally that it plans to eliminate between 70 and 90 jobs across the nation through layoffs and attrition by the end of the month. The job cuts are part of restructuring announced last year that is reducing the company's workforce by 1,800 positions, or 8%. The company announced plans to 'drastically narrow' its Roundup herbicide portfolio and slash prices to better compete with generic Chinese weed-killers.

NII Holdings is cutting back. The company is eliminating 1,400 market operations jobs and reducing its headquarters staff by 25%. NII Holdings did not provide numbers for its headquarters staff reduction in its statement announcing the cuts. NII Holdings said it expects to realize annualized cost savings of $50 million to $55 million as a result of the cuts.

Bank Mutual Corporation announced that it plans to close seven retail branch offices as part of an efficiency and expense reduction effort. Management anticipates that this action will result in annual net cost savings of approximately $1.5 million and that the closures will be completed during the second quarter of 2015. Bank Mutual will continue to provide products and services to affected customers through its other nearby locations, as well as its electronic and mobile banking channels.

Bank Mutual is planning to close 10% of its branch network on May 16, 2015. The strategic cost-cutting move, which has been announced in February 2015, will involve the closure of branches in Barron, Brillion, Cornell, Eau Claire, Green Bay, Menomonie and Peshtigo. The closures will bring Bank Mutual's total banking locations to 68 in Wisconsin and one in Minnesota, incurring one-time costs of $352,000, and will result in annual net cost savings of about $1.5 million, which the bank intends to invest in technology. The bank will sell the branch properties following the closures.

Align Technology Inc. has announced that it will layoff 385 employees, approximately 35 percent of its workforce. The company also plans to close plants and call centers in Pakistan and the United Arab Emirates and shift those operations to the United Sta

Garmin Ltd. is laying off 141 people as the economy stalls its record growth. The company told workers of the layoffs on March 9, 2009 morning. Employees are being let go in the company's human resources, marketing administration and product support divisions. The layoffs which represent 5.6% of the company's local workforce will be in Olathe or at two area service centers. For the full year of 2009, the company expects slower sales. For 2008, the company reported sales of $3.5 billion.

Agere Systems Inc. announced plans to close two plants in Pennsylvania and sell a third in Florida. The moves will result in about 300 job cuts in addition to reductions of about 7,000 announced in the last year.
Agere Systems has announced that it is considering further layoffs in order to cut costs.
Agere Systems has announced that it plans to layoff about 150 employees, approximately 15 percent of its workforce at the Orlando semiconductor plant, in response to a slumping microchip market.

Agere Systems Inc.'s giant semiconductor plant on South John Young Parkway ceased operations on September 30, its remaining workers driving away one by one from what was once Central Florida's greatest hope for a high-tech future. The shopping-mall-sized factory stopped production a week ago, giving its remaining 400 production workers a few extra days to prepare for the shutdown.

Agere Systems Inc. will cut 110 jobs between now and the middle of the year 2006. It's unclear whether the jobs are at its headquarters and research facilities in the Lehigh Valley or at the company's other offices in California, Colorado and overseas. The job cuts are part of a plan that the company announced in October to consolidate operations and improve profitability.

Odyssey Healthcare Inc. is closing its Wichita and Hutchinson offices. Kansas offices likely will shut down by the end of January, once patients and their families have been transferred to other area hospice providers. While Wichita officials declined to elaborate on why they were closing and it was a market-based business decision.

Global Payments Inc. of Atlanta will lay off 218 workers in Maryland Heights when it closes a technical support center later this year. The company said that the Maryland Heights center will close in late September. The company notified employees of its plans March 12. Employees will receive severance pay based on their length of service, and some will have the option to move to another Global Payments location.

Peabody Energy announced that it plans to shut down its Seneca Coal Co. mine in northern Colorado by the end of the year, affecting 100 employees. The mine, which opened in 1964, provides the Hayden Power Station with some 1.6 million tons of coal every year. St. Louis-based Peabody has a contract to provide Hayden with coal through 2011. Peabody is renegotiating its contact with Xcel Energy, the power station's operator, Sutton said. Xcel intends to continue operating the Hayden plant.
Peabody Energy Corp. planed to cut 450 contractor jobs, as a global glut in supply pushes down prices.

Peabody Energy Group plans to eliminate 170 jobs in Australia or about 5.7% of its workforce in the country in an effort to cut costs. The company announced that it does not plan to fill 230 vacancies in the country, bringing the total of permanent positions being cut in Australia to 400. In June, the company announced plans to cut 450 contractor jobs in the country.
Peabody Energy will cut up to 70 jobs at its coal mine on Queensland's western Darling Downs.

FMC Technologies Inc. announced that it will close its western Pa. plant next year. All 70 employees at plant were told that their jobs will end by March 1. The light-industry product line in Homer City will be consolidated into FMC plants in Tupelo, Miss., and Changshu, China.

Kraft Foods Inc. announced that it would eliminate 7,500 jobs, or 6.4 percent of its work force, as it integrated Nabisco Holdings. The company is spending $373 million to close or reconfigure plants, including some Nabisco plants in Guatemala City and San Jose, Costa Rica, announced in November. The job cuts include more than 1,000 positions that were eliminated last year as part of Kraft's effort to save $100 million by reducing overlap between itself and Nabisco.

Kraft Foods Inc. announced that it is eliminating 330 jobs at Kraft Foods Inc.'s pizza production plant in Sussex. The facility, at W227-N6088 Sussex Road, will close March 2007, with production being transferred to Kraft's two other Wisconsin frozen pizza plants, in Little Chute and Medford. The closing is part of a larger restructuring that Kraft announced this year to help reduce the company's costs and streamline its worldwide operations.

Workers at a Kraft Foods plant that produces cottage cheese and sour cream learned that half of them will be losing their jobs over the course of the coming year. Kraft announced it will close its plant in Visalia that employs 160 people and consolidate production into the company's newer, larger plant in Tulare.

Kraft Foods Inc. is planning to cut around 100 jobs at its site in Bad Fallingbostel, Germany, by the end of 2007. The site currently employs 850 staff. Management is said to have reached an agreement with the works council, as part of which the jobs will be cut by transferring some staff to other sites and introducing part-time working for older employees. The company says that about 50 other jobs that were originally to be cut will now be maintained.

Kraft Foods Inc. announced that as many as 8,000 jobs could be cut as part of a continued effort to help the compsny revive its slumping sales. Kraft announced that it may eliminate up to 8,000 jobs about 9% of its work force and exit up to 20 production facilities, according to a document outlining the plan. Since 2004, Kraft has eliminated 5,500 jobs. Kraft says the restructuring program will include a one-time pretax costs of $2.5 billion and expects the cuts to save about $700 million.

Kraft Foods Inc. signalled the loss of up to 400 jobs by announcing the closure of a Cadbury factory - despite promises to keep it open. It was 'unrealistic' to reverse Cadbury's plans to shut the site at Somerdale near Bristol and announced that it would shut by 2011. Kraft had pledged to retain the plant. Kraft has not made any formal announcement of job losses at Cadbury but redundancies are expected at both firms in 2010 as the businesses merge.

Mondelez International, Inc. announced plans to invest more than $130 million in new biscuit manufacturing technology and capabilities in its current U.S. network. The investment will focus on bakeries in Fair Lawn, N.J., and Richmond, Va., supporting priority cookie and cracker brands and product platforms. To enable this investment, the company will consolidate its current U.S. biscuit manufacturing footprint on the East Coast, resulting in the closure of its Philadelphia bakery by early 2015. The role of the Philadelphia bakery within the company's biscuit manufacturing network footprint has changed over time. The site currently produces a limited number of core products. Other facilities are better positioned to support the company's future business needs. The closure of the Philadelphia bakery will affect approximately 350 employees, who were informed of the company's decision earlier today.

Mondelez announced that it would be closing its Montreal manufacturing facility on Viau Street by the end of 2017. Earlier in the day, 454 employees were informed of the company's decision, which will happen in phases. The company said the move is part of a global strategy to increase efficiency.

Mondelez International confirmed the closure of Dunedin factory next year, leaving about 350 people facing an uncertain future. The company announced that its staff 200 people would be made redundant by the end of the 2016. About 100 people would remain with the business until early next year when the factory would close. More than 70% of the products manufactured at the site were exported, most to Australia.

Omnicell Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2008. For the quarter, the company reported net income of USD 3,323,000 or USD 0.10 per share on total revenue of USD 62,055,000 against net income of USD 14,297,000 or USD 0.39 per share on total revenue of USD 57,946,000 for the same period a year ago. The company also announced the non-GAAP net income of USD 5,473,000 or USD 0.17 against non-GAAP net income of USD 10,229,000 or USD 0.17 for the same period a year ago.For the full year, the company reported net income of USD 12,724,000 or USD 0.38 per share on total revenue of USD 251,865,000 against net income of USD 43,295,000 or USD 1.28 per share on total revenue of USD 213,081,000 for the same period a year ago. The company also announced the non-GAAP net income of USD 23,643,000 or USD 0.71 against non-GAAP net income of USD 34,452,000 or USD 1.02 for the same period a year ago.The company also announced the reorganization, on January 20, 2009, announced it has taken steps to reduce its regular full-time employee headcount to 744 positions. The company expects approximately USD 2.5 million of pre-tax restructuring charges associated with the reduction in force to be recorded in the first quarter of fiscal year 2009.

Accenture Ltd. notified 24 employees in Wichita that they would be laid off March 15. It's the second time in a year that Accenture BPO has announced layoffs at the company's Wichita office, which employs more than 340 in the former Thorn Americas building at 37th North and Rock Road. Despite the layoff notices. The company plans to add more workers in Wichita. In other words, Accenture BPO has clients who no longer need certain outsourced services or need different ones. Finlaw would not identify specific services no longer needed. Those clients may have also requested those services be provided by a different Accenture BPO location that may have workers with different skill sets. The Wichita office provides outsourced finance and accounting, payroll, human resources and tax services for companies.

Accenture Ltd. announced that it will cut some 336 senior-level executive positions as part of a broad-based restructuring effort. The layoffs total about 7% of Accenture Ltd.'s 4,800 senior executives.

Alliance Data Systems Corporation plans to cut up to 251 jobs at a Dallas call center. The layoffs could be fewer in number and were not related to the failed takeover. The company notified the Texas Workforce Commission last week that it planned to make the job cuts by March 31.

Willis Group Holdings Ltd. announced about 400 employees would be affected by job cuts through a corporatewide initiative to trim costs and drive up revenue. The initiative involves consolidating data-center operations, overhauling operations and technology in London and overseas, and streamlining real estate assets.

Willis Group Holdings Plc will cut 350 jobs in the U.K. as part of its global cost-cutting measures. The layoffs, which the company revealed to staff April 13, are mainly due to relocating London-based roles to lower-cost locations in the U.K. and in Mumbai, India. In 2014, Willis cut 200 jobs in the U.K. as part of its plan to reduce costs.

Rockwell Collins Inc. announced laying off approximately 300 employees across the company, primarily in Operations, and reducing the number of contract laborers by approximately 100, primarily in engineering functions. This layoff represents an estimated 1.5% of the current workforce.

Rockwell Collins Inc. announced that it is cutting 600 jobs and freezing salaries for all executives and managers at 2008 levels. The cuts include 500 salaried employees and 100 contract workers. About 200 are in Iowa. The layoffs are in addition to the reduction of 300 employees, or 1.5% of the work force, announced in November. Another 100 contractors were laid off then as well, bringing the total layoffs to 1,000. The cuts reduce the company's work force by about 5%.

Rockwell Collins Inc. announced that it will close its San Jose facility and lay off about 600 people who work there on aircraft displays for the military market. The closure is related in part to the cancellation of the F-22 Raptor fighter aircraft program and the loss of a bid to make the displays for the F-35 Lightning II aircraft.
Rockwell Collins Inc. plans to eliminate 90 positions as a string of work force reductions continued at the company. The company said 55 of those jobs are being cut in Cedar Rapids.

Rockwell Collins Inc.'s downsizing of former B/E Aerospace Inc. operations accelerated with plans to close a Tucson, Ariz., plant by Sept. 30, affecting 413 job positions. The local salaried jobs will be terminated between June and December, while the hourly jobs will be terminated between May 1 and the end of the year.
Aramark Services has announced that it will layoff 436 employees in Seattle as Boeing has switched its food services business to the Compass Group.

Big 5 Sporting Goods Corp. announced that in 2016, the company plans to continue to maintain a cautious approach towards selecting the right new store opportunities for the company's business in the current retail environment. While the company is still in the process of evaluating and finalizing its store openings strategy for the year, at this time, the company's plans would suggest approximately 5 to 8 store openings and approximately 10 closures.

Big 5 Sporting Goods Corp. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the second quarter and six months ended July 2, 2017. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $243,671,000 compared with $241,409,000 a year ago. Operating income was $5,120,000 against $3,998,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $4,740,000 against $3,569,000 a year ago. Net income was $2,778,000, or $0.13 per diluted share, compared with $2,124,000 or 0.10 per diluted share a year ago. Same store sales increased 0.8% for the second quarter of fiscal 2017, reflecting continued market share gains resulting from the closure of certain major competitors last year. For six months, the company reported net sales of $496,275,000 compared with $475,937,000 a year ago. Same store sales increased 4.3% in the first 26 weeks of fiscal 2017 versus the comparable period last year. Operating income was $14,098,000 against $3,744,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $13,450,000 against $2,863,000 a year ago. Net income was $8,104,000, or $0.37 per diluted share, compared with $1,005,000 or 0.05 per diluted share a year ago. The companys CapEx, excluding noncash acquisitions, totaled $7.2 million for the first half of fiscal 2017, primarily reflecting investment in IT systems, existing store upgrades and remodeling and new stores. From a cash flow perspective, operating cash flow was a negative $19.4 million for the first half of fiscal 2017 compared to a positive $16.4 million last year, largely due to increased funding of merchandise inventory purchases and the timing of payments.For the fiscal 2017 third quarter, the company expects same store sales to be in the negative low single-digit range and earnings per diluted share to be in the range of $0.22 to $0.32, compared to a same store sales increase of 6.8% and earnings per diluted share of $0.38, including $0.03 per diluted share for store closing costs, in the third quarter of fiscal 2016. Fiscal 2017 third quarter guidance reflects a small benefit as a resu

WellPoint Inc. is eliminating approximately 1,500 positions. This includes the elimination of more than 900 open positions. The approximately 600 associates affected by the layoff will receive both severance pay and outplacement assistance in accordance with WellPoint's policies.

WellPoint Inc. announced that it will outsource its internal information technology help-desk functions, cutting about 100 positions. About 50 of the jobs are in the Richmond area, where the insurer operates Anthem Blue Cross and Blue Shield. Most of the other job cuts are in Indianapolis, where the company operates another computer help desk. A few workers scattered throughout the country also are affected.

WellPoint Inc. announced that it may trim some more jobs as part of a push to become more efficient next year. The company reviews the size and skill of its workforce as the economic environment changes 'and makes adjustment as necessary.' The insurer also noted that many of its customers have reduced their labor force during the current downturn, and that has lowered WellPoint's membership totals. The company has no total for the number of cuts or when they may happen. Other ways to trim costs may include technology upgrades or reductions in administrative expenses.
For 2013, GameStop Corp. announced it will open about 50 stores in the U.S. The company will close about 200 stores in 2013.

GameStop Corp. is planning to close up to 130 GameStop stores. The closures of its GameStop stores represent 2% or less of its current collection of 6,457 stores. The company planning to add 300 to 400 of its technology branded stores as part of a partnership with AT&T Inc.within fiscal 2014. The company's technology brands Spring Mobile, Simply Mac and Cricket Wireless together will almost double their footprint in 2014. The company said the move to bolster its technology brands is simply to continue diversifying the company's offerings, but that its pre-used and digital sales have only been on the rise, something it expects to continue into fiscal 2014.

AMERIGROUP Corp. announced that it laid off 80 employees, including 20 in Virginia Beach, to improve the efficiency of its information technology and marketing departments. The 20 in Virginia Beach worked in the company's information technology department, and three held posts of vice president or higher. The cutbacks were prompted by efforts to make specific operations more effective and weren't driven by economic concerns. Employees who were let go were eligible for a severance program that takes into account an employee's position and length of service. The company continues to hire new employees.

Principal Financial Group Inc. announces it would cut 204 jobs in retirement services. Company said 96 workers lost their jobs in Des Moines, 41 in Mason City, 36 in Waterloo and 31 in Spokane, Wash. The company which currently posts about 300 job openings, hopes to absorb many of the workers in other areas of the company. Those who do not find jobs internally will be offered a severance package and outplacement help. The cuts came as the company authorized the repurchase of up to $450 million in common stock.

Principal Financial Group Inc. announced that it is cutting 300 jobs at its headquarters and around 250 in 45 other locations. The insurance, banking, retirement and asset management company blamed the cuts on continued deterioration of U.S. and global markets. The cuts represents about 3.5% of Principal's work force. The company announced that most affected employees will leave December 31, 2008. All affected employees will receive severance and career assistance.
Principal Financial Group Inc. announced that it will layoff 140, workers at its corporate headquarters in Iowa. About 80 workers in 40 other locations also were fired.

Principal Financial Group Inc. says it's getting out of the health insurance business. It says the move will eliminate 150 jobs initially and more later. Principal's health insurance division employs 1,500 workers but some will be considered for other jobs in the company, which employs 14,000 workers. It says it has agreed to have UnitedHealthcare renew medical insurance coverage for its customers as they come up over the next 36 months.
Advance Auto Parts Inc. has laid off 19 full-time hourly employees at its distribution center at the Centre for Industry and Technology.

Advance Auto Parts Inc. is planning to cut 100 corporate jobs from its headquarters in Roanoke, as well as from the company's corporate campus in Raleigh. The company will be notifying the employees who will be impacted by the end of the month.

Acuity Brands, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended November 30, 2012. For the fiscal 2013 first quarter net sales were $481.1 million, an increase of $6.8 million, or 1.4%, compared with the year-ago period. Operating profit for the first quarter of fiscal 2013 was $48.2 million, or 10.0% of net sales, compared with $50.6 million, or 10.7% of net sales, for the prior-year period. Excluding expenses associated with the closing of the Cochran facility as discussed below, adjusted operating profit for the first quarter of fiscal 2013 was $53.7 million, a 1% increase over the prior-year period's adjusted operating profit of $53.3 million. Income before provision for income taxes was $40.4 million against $45.8 million reported last year. Net income for the first quarter of fiscal 2013 was $26.1 million, or $0.61 diluted earnings per share compared with $29.9 million, or $0.70 diluted earnings per share for the year-ago period. Excluding special charges and related temporary expenses in both periods, fiscal 2013 first quarter adjusted net income was $29.6 million compared with adjusted net income of $31.6 million for the prior-year period. Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the first quarter of fiscal 2013 were $0.69 compared with adjusted diluted EPS of $0.74 for the year-ago period. Net cash used for operating activities was $14.5 million against net cash provided by operating activities of $27.7 million reported last year. Purchases of property, plant, and equipment were $11.2 million against $4.2 million reported last year. The year-over-year growth in fiscal 2013 first quarter Net Sales were due primarily to an increase in volume, partially offset by a slightly net unfavorable change in product prices and the mix of products sold. Fiscal 2013 first quarter results included $0.1 million of net miscellaneous expense compared with $2.9 million, or $0.04 per diluted share, of net miscellaneous income in the prior-year period. The company expects that the closure
Altiris Inc. plans to cut approximately 10% of its 850 employees worldwide this quarter.

Republic Airways Holdings Inc. announced that it will shut down Lynx Aviation Inc. Republic said it will begin phasing them out on April 6, and they'll all be gone by mid-September. The changes will mean 175 people will lose their jobs initially, with more cuts expected. Most flying done by Lynx will be replaced by regional jets operated by Republic crews. However, the company will drop flights to Fargo, N.D., and Tulsa, Okla., on April 5. Republic is also terminating leases on seven CRJ200 aircraft operated by its Chautauqua unit for Continental Airlines.

Aropostale, Inc. now announced that it is planning to open approximately seven Aeropostale stores and remodel, either partial or full, approximately ten Aeropostale stores, and expects to open one new P.S. store. The company expects to invest approximately $22 million in fiscal 2014 primarily related to store openings, store remodels and certain infrastructure investments. Currently, the company planed to close approximately 50 Aeropostale stores and two P.S. stores, and has retained a real estate consulting firm to investigate the opportunity to accelerate the pace of closures, as well as to identify other potential rent reduction savings.
Aropostale, Inc. plans for one store opening in the year of 2016.The company plans approximately 20 to 40 store closures.
FairPoint Communications decided to close its regional operations center in Irving, Texas and laid off 140 workers consisting mostly of sales, systems support, and administrative staff.

FormFactor Inc. announced a global reorganization and cost reduction plan. As part of the plan the company will reduce its workforce by 22%. The company expects to incur approximately $8 million in charges related to the plan, which will be recorded in the first quarter of fiscal 2009.

Red Robin Gourmet Burgers after suffering through another disappointing quarter to begin 2019, will close 10 under-performing stores, just one step the Greenwood Village-based chain will take in the near future to attempt to return to sustainable, profitable growth after recording its fifth straight quarter of declining same-store sales. Chief Financial Officer Lynn Schweinfurth did not specify which of the full-service restaurant chain's locations will shutter but noted that seven of them are based within enclosed malls - a segment of the company's business that is hurting even more than other locations. The company did not specify which of the full-service restaurant chain's locations will shutter but noted that seven of them are based within enclosed malls - a segment of the company's business that is hurting even more than other locations. The 10 restaurants targeted for closure lost a combined $900,000 through roughly the first four months of this year.

Wynn Resorts Ltd. to lay off more workers after reporting a third-quarter loss of nearly $14.2 million. After trimming 1,400 jobs from its opening day work force of 9,600, more cuts will be made Monday at the $2.7 billion Strip hotel-casino. The reduction in full-time workers will be another major adjustment, since the megaresort debuted April 28, The job reduction process historically requires six to 12 months to complete.

Carters Inc. announced earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended October 1, 2005. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $10,578,000 or $0.35 per diluted share on net sales $372,158,000 compared to net income of $18,412,000 or $0.62 per diluted share on net sales $251,357,000 for the same period a year ago.

For the nine months, the company reported net income of $29,877,000 or $0.98 per diluted share on net sales $770,865,000 of compared to net income of $34,642,000 or $1.16 per diluted share on net sales 590,384,000 for the same period a year ago.

The company provides earnings guidance for the fourth quarter and full year 2005. For the fourth quarter, the company expects to report $0.63 per adjusted diluted share on net sales of $340 million.

For the full year, the company expects to report $2.40 per adjusted diluted share on net sales of $1,111 million.
 
The company plans to close 38 under-performing OshKosh retail stores, or 22% of the 171 stores acquired. The company plans to close all but five of the 38 stores by the end of 2005. The company plans to close the remaining five stores by June 2006.
Carters Inc. announced plans to close a Tennessee distribution center for its OshKosh B'Gosh products, and book about $6 million in severance costs and other charges over two fiscal years.

Carters Inc. announced that in the third quarter of fiscal 2008, the company opened three Carter's retail stores and as of September 2008 had 234 Carter's and 163 OshKosh stores. It plans to open 19 Carter's and three OshKosh stores during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008.The company will close one Carter's store during the fourth quarter of fiscal 2008.

Seagate Technology announced it plans lay off 10% of its U.S. work force, or about 800 people, in response to economic turmoil. Layoffs will affect a broad range of departments, including research and development.

Seagate Technology announced it will cut 6% of its global workforce and reduce some employees' salaries by as much as 25%, as it struggles in a woeful business climate. The announcement by the company expanded on plans announced Jan. 9 to trim 800 jobs, or 10% of U.S.-based workers. The reduction in force and salary cuts are expected to save Seagate $210 million a year.
Seagate Technology has announced plans to close its Singapore harddisk drive manufacturing plant by the end of 2010 and lay off 2,000 workers.

Seagate Technology disclosed that it would eliminate 1,050 jobs or 2% of its global workforce as part of its restructuring plan. The company recently stated its commitment to realign its cost structure with the current macroeconomic business environment. Last month, International Data Corp. (IDC) forecasted a bigger drop in PC shipments this year due to a large inventory of notebooks and a strong dollar. Seagate Technology estimated to achieve approximately $113 million in saving annually after implementing its restructuring plan. Seagate Technology indicated its expectation to complete a large part of its restructuring plan by the end of December 2015 quarter. Seagate Technology estimated that its restructuring plan could result in total pretax charges of approximately $53 million.

Sagate Technology will cut 6,500 jobs worldwide over the year 2017. The 14% workforce reduction was part of a restructuring and "footprint consolidation" that would help the bottom line. The jobs to be eliminated are in the Americas, Asia, Europe, the Middle East and Africa. The cuts will cost the Seagate $164 million during the fiscal year, including $82 million in employee termination expenses.

On March 9, 2017, Seagate Technology plc committed to an additional restructuring plan in connection with the continued consolidation of its global footprint across Asia, EMEA, and the Americas. Pursuant to the plan, the company intends to close its design center in Korea, which will result in the reduction of the company's headcount by approximately 300 employees. This action, which the company expects to be substantially completed by the end of fiscal year 2017, is expected to result in total pre-tax charges of approximately $50 million, primarily in fiscal year 2017. The majority of the charges will be comprised of cash expenditures on severance and employee-related costs. The balance of the charges will include other cash expenditures on exit-related costs, as well as other non-cash charges.

Conns Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended April 30, 2011. For the quarter, the company reported operating income of $14,160,000, income before income taxes of $6,552,000 and net income of $3,993,000, or $0.13 per diluted share on total revenues of $189,309,000 compared to operating income of $15,351,000, income before income taxes of $9,397,000 and net income of $5,793,000, or $0.26 per diluted share on total revenues of $197,909,000 for the same period last year. The decrease in sales during the quarter was driven largely by declines in the consumer electronics, appliance and home office categories and was partially offset by a 24.9% increase in furniture and mattresses sales. The following key drivers accounted for $0.11 of the difference in earnings per share. Severance charges reduced earnings per share by $0.02, increased interest expense accounted for $0.04 and the 9.3 million shares issued in last year's rights offering reduced earnings per share by $0.05.The company expects second quarter same store sales to decline mid to high single digits. But the company expects to maintain retail gross margins of between 27% and 28%.The company also announced its plans to close 5 stores. The company also allowing two leases to expire. One location closed in the first quarter.

Conn's will close 10 locations in 2014, completing review of its stores that will put the chain solidly behind its Home Plus format. Conn's shut two of the outlets in fiscal fourth quarter ended Jan. 31 and will close the remaining eight over the balance of the year, finishing up with all but five locations featuring Home Plus. The stores being closed didn't "justify the investment" needed for Home Plus, including one location that at 16,000 square feet was too small for it.

Conns Inc. reported unaudited consolidated financial results for the first quarter ended April 30, 2015. For the quarter, the company reported total net sales of $298,479,000 against $277,629,000 a year ago. Total revenues were $365,076,000 against $335,448,000 a year ago. Operating income was $34,106,000 against $49,031,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $24,678,000 against $44,307,000 a year ago. Net income was $15,677,000 or $0.43 per diluted share against $28,469,000 or $0.77 per diluted share a year ago. Consolidated revenues increased 8.8% to $365.1 million due to new store openings, partially offset by a decrease in same store sales of 4.3%, as well as an increase in credit revenue from growth in the average balance of the customer receivable portfolio, partially offset by a 100 basis point decrease in portfolio yield. Retail gross margin decreased 10 basis points to 41.3%. Adjusted retail segment operating income increased 9.3% to $43.2 million. The retail revenue growth reflects the impact of the net addition of 12 stores over the past 12 months partially offset by a decrease in same store sales of 4.3%.For the second quarter of fiscal 2015, the company expects interest income and fee yield between 16.5% and 17.0% (as a point of reference, generally for every 100 basis point change in the provision rate, yield is impacted by approximately 15 basis points). For the fiscal year 2016, bad debt charge-offs (net of recoveries) to average outstanding balance between 11.5% and 12.0%; and interest income and fee yield between 16.5% and 17.0% (as a point of reference, generally for every 100 basis point change in the provision rate, yield is impacted by approximately 15 basis points). The company change in same stores sales to range from flat to up low single digits; retail gross margin between 40% and 41%. For fiscal year 2016, the company plans to open 15 to 18 new stores. For fiscal year 2016, the company plans to close 2 stores.

New Alliance Bancshares Inc. announced that it would close 10 branches acquired in the year 2004 in the purchases of Alliance Bancorp of New England, in Vernon, and Connecticut Bancshares Inc. of Manchester. The closings, scheduled for September 2004, would leave New Alliance with 65 branches in five counties.

Universal Technical Institute Inc. announced a reduction in force of approximately 225 employees nationwide, effective September 16, 2007. The nationwide headcount of the Company following these terminations is approximately 2,080 employees, compared to 2,368 employees as of September 30, 2006. Severance and outplacement charges relating to the reduction in force, as well as the previously reported campus sales management restructuring, of approximately $3.6 million and $0.8 million, respectively, will be included in the results of the fourth quarter ending September 30, 2007. The reduction in force is expected to provide a cost savings in fiscal 2008 of approximately $10.7 million to $11.4 million.

Assurant is closing its Dayton office. The insurer will close its service center at 4646 Needmore Road, about two years after that office came online. The company confirmed they planned to move those functions back to the Springfield office and transfer the employees there back to Springfield. The move affects 150 employees, several of whom will have the option to work from home.

Compass Minerals International Inc. is cutting 150 jobs. A mild winter and other factors in the ag market cut into profits and sales at Overland Park-based Compass Minerals International Inc. As a result, it will whittle down its workforce throughout the year, which will lead to a $4 million restructuring charge in the first quarter.

Wild Wings in Middletown and Hamilton have closed, but corporate officials say the Hamilton site will reopen later. Buffalo Wild Wings corporate officials confirmed Monday the franchise agreement between the former franchise owners and the company has been terminated, saying the franchise owners did not meet contractual requirements.
Buffalo Wild Wings, which has seven restaurants along the Wasatch Front, is laying off workers, due to amid higher labor and chicken-wing costs.

Motorola Inc. will close its chip-packaging plants in Sendai, Japan and in Austin, eliminating 1,200 jobs, as part of the ongoing restructuring of its semiconductor operations. The plant closings will take effect in the next 15 months.

Freescale Semiconductor Inc. reported earnings results for the third quarter ended October 2, 2004. For the quarter, the company reported net income of $57 million or $0.15 per share on net sales of $1.43 billion against loss of $106 million on net sales of $1.23 billion for the same period a year ago. 

The company provides earnings guidance for the fourth quarter of 2004. For the quarter, the company expects revenues of $1.40 to $1.45 billion and gross margins of 38% to 39%.

Freescale also announced plans to continue streamlining its operations and reducing SG&A expenses. The company plans to eliminate approximately 1,000 positions worldwide and record total restructuring charges in the fourth quarter of 2004 of approximately $65 million associated with these actions.

Freescale Semiconductor Inc. announced it is cutting jobs companywide. Some of the cuts involve projects that management deemed less profitable. The company also has reduced its spending on equipment and shifted more production to its own factories rather than using contract manufacturers.

Freescale Semiconductor Inc. has decided to close its smallest chip factory, located in Tempe, Ariz. The factory makes wireless chips from a specialized material, gallium arsenide, rather than silicon, which is the most common base material for semiconductor devices. Workers can apply for other jobs at Freescale. The factory closing leaves Freescale with six chip factories: two in Austin; one in Chandler, Ariz.; one in Scotland; one in France; and one in Japan.

Freescale Semiconductor, Inc. confirmed the closure of its Scots plant and the loss of 800 jobs, is now poised to axe 27 posts at its research and development unit. The technology giant had insisted its 200-strong R&D team at East Kilbride would remain unscathed.

Freescale Semiconductor Inc. plans to close its plant in Toulouse, southwestern France, in the framework of a programmed envisaging the closure of its least modern sites. The plant in Toulouse employs 1,900, of whom 700 engineers and executives. At the presentation of its quarterly financial results, the company announced its plans to close its plants in Toulouse and Sendai, Japan. The decision will be implemented by the end of 2011.

Freescale Semiconductor Inc. will not reopen its 600-person factory in Japan, citing irreparable earthquake damage. The company evacuated the wafer fabrication plant in Sendai, Japan after the country incurred widespread damage from quakes and a massive tsunami on March 11. The area continues to experience major aftershocks and trouble reaching basic services that pose continuing safety risks. The company is now in the process of transitioning that work to other factories worldwide. Help was also extended to employees and their families recovering from the event. The plant was built in 1987 through a Toshiba Corp. and Motorola Inc. joint venture. The company said workers were already building buffer inventory to prepare for the closure, so supply will not be interrupted. Work is also being ramped up in Texas and Arizona.

Genworth Financial Inc. announced that with a global recession gathering, the company is preparing to make up to $150 million in expense cuts, most of them by the end of the year. That could mean layoffs for a work force that includes more than 3,100 people in Virginia, including about 1,700 in the Richmond area.

Genworth Financial Inc. announced actions being taken to advance the company's strategic goals in response to the current economic downturn. The actions include the elimination of approximately 1,000 jobs globally.The company expects to record a pretax non-operating charge of approximately $45 million in the fourth quarter of 2008 for severance, outplacement and other costs associated with the plan for workforce reduction and other restructuring actions.

Genworth Financial revealed plans to cut approximately 80 jobs including 35 operation jobs in Lynchburg and 21 job cuts at its corporate headquarters in Henrico County. The rest of the Genworth Financial job cuts involve remote workers. The company has decided to briefly halt the sales of individual long-term care insurance and income Assurance Annuity products via brokerage general agencies. Subsequently, Genworth will distribute these products directly to consumers. These plans will also be made available through affinity and association programs as well as other distribution channels.

Cytokinetics, Incorporated has announced plans to restructure the company's workforce and operations in connection with its commitment to focus resources primarily on the development of its later-stage development programs, CK-2017357 and omecamtiv mecarbil. As its first priority, the company intends to focus its resources on the partnering and advancement of CK-2017357, including the planning and initiation of a clinical trial in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients that may potentially serve as a registration trial. Additionally, Cytokinetics plans to retain a smaller, but fully integrated, R&D organization focused to the advancement of its follow-on skeletal muscle troponin activator program and certain other R&D programs also directed to muscle biology. Following the implementation of this restructuring program, Cytokinetics will have reduced its workforce to 83 people.

B&G Foods, Inc. announced that it has reached an agreement to sell its Portland, Maine manufacturing facility and 13.5 acre waterfront property to the Institute for Digital Engineering and Life Sciences. B&G Foods plans to move manufacturing operations of B&M, Underwood and certain other brands to third-party co-manufacturing facilities and existing B&G Foods manufacturing facilities. The decision to close the Portland manufacturing facility, which is more than 100 years old, is consistent with B&G Foods?ongoing efforts to improve productivity and reduce overall costs. The Portland property will become the future home of The Roux Institute at Northeastern University, on a campus that will include partner companies, housing and other amenities. The B&M manufacturing building will become the anchor of The Roux Campus, providing an incubator lab and office space for start-up companies. The campus will be built in phases over a decade or more, and will include coastal restoration to open waterfront areas to the public. There are approximately 86 employees at the Portland manufacturing facility. B&G Foods has put in place a plan to offer all eligible employees severance and career transition support. B&G Foods does not anticipate any disruption in production or the delivery of customer orders relating to the transition of manufacturing operations, which is expected to be completed during the fourth quarter of 2021 or the first quarter of 2022. The sale, which is subject to customary closing conditions, is expected to close by year-end.

Procera Networks Inc. announced they have entered into an agreement with a global organization to substantially outsource Procera's operations and logistics functions, formerly handled in Procera's Los Gatos, California facility. By leveraging this new business model, Procera reduced its workforce by 25% effective April 20, 2009. Procera does not expect to incur material costs in connection with this workforce reduction.

Dominos Pizza, Inc. has closed eight of its 25 company-owned pizza outlets in Phoenix and laid off about 90 full- and part-time employees. The recession and burst housing bubble have dramatically curtailed the Valley's once-robust growth rate. McIntyre said that about 15 management-level employees will be offered jobs at other stores and the 90 employees who are losing their jobs can apply at other locations. Approximately 25 franchised Domino's locations outside Phoenix proper are not affected by the move.

Hospira Inc. announced plans to close its medical device manufacturing plant in Donegal, Ireland, within the next 18 months. In connection with the plant closure, Hospira estimates that it will incur total expenses in the range of $30 million to $40 million over the 2005 to 2007 time period for the impairment of assets, employee-related costs and other expenses.

Hospira Inc. announced details regarding Project Fuel, a multi-phased initiative to improve the company's margins and fuel its growth. Project Fuel will capitalize on the company's potential to increase shareholder value and improve operational efficiency by optimizing its product line, evaluating non-strategic assets and streamlining its organizational structure. In conjunction with these actions, which are slated to occur over the next 24 months, Hospira expects to reduce its global workforce by approximately 10% and deliver annual cost savings of approximately $110 million to $140 million. The net projected reduction associated with these collective actions represents approximately 10% of the company's global workforce, with the majority of reductions occurring in the next 12 months. In connection with these actions, Hospira estimates it will incur total pre-tax charges in the range of $140 million to $160 million, of which approximately $90 million to $100 million will be incurred during 2009. For the year 2009, the company estimates approximately $30 million of non-cash costs is related to various potential asset write-downs.
Google Inc. will be closing its Denver office. The company will keep open its offices in Thornton and Boulder. The office in suburban Denver, at 4600 S. Syracuse St., is slated to close.

Google Inc. is closing three engineering offices and cutting 100 recruiters from its work force as the recession dampens hiring at the company. Separately Google said it would close its engineering offices in Austin, Texas; Trondheim, Norway and Lulea, Sweden, a step the company said would affect 70 workers.
Google Inc. is planning a significant reduction of its contract workers.
Google Inc. plans to cut nearly 200 marketing and sales jobs from its international operations.

Las Vegas Sands Corp. announced that up to 11,000 workers will lose their jobs in Macau after the company halted building projects in the Chinese gambling city. Aabout 2,000 of the workers are from Macau, and the remainder are from Hong Kong, mainland China and other countries. The company has been forced to fire workers after announcing earlier this week it would suspend construction on two sites in Macau. The company is trying to arrange financing to finish projects, but he couldn't say how long that would take or when the construction would resume.

Las Vegas Sands Corp. plans to slash the equivalent of 3,000 to 4,000 more full-time jobs in Macau and Hong Kong by September. The owner of the Venetian and Sands casinos in Macau aimed to cut payroll via a combination of layoffs, pay cuts, attrition and transfers of staff to the company's soon-to-open Singapore resort. The staff reductions are part of a $270 million annual Macau cost-cutting exercise. Las Vegas Sands revealed the measures last week after reporting a net loss of $87.68 million for the first three months of the year. The cuts are deeper than the $125 million in reduced Macau expenses that the company had announced in February. The measures are part of a campaign to maintain compliance with leverage requirements built into agreements on a total of $10.27 billion in long-term debt as of March.

Las Vegas Sands Corp. announced that it has laid off nearly 200 people in Las Vegas. The layoffs came this week and are an attempt to adjust staffing levels to meet the current economic environment. The 194 layoffs affect various departments.

Consolidated Communications Holdings Inc. announced that about 11 positions were eliminated in mid-June, with some of those not being filled after people -- including a senior vice president -- took jobs elsewhere. Altogether, about 2% of Consolidated's workforce is affected by the reductions.

Mosaic Co. announced that it plans to shutter three Florida phosphate fertilizer operations by the end of the month. The company announced its intent to close plants in South Pierce and Green Bay and its Fort Green mine.

Mosaic Co. has issued layoff notices to 1,000 workers at two locations in Canada because of slowing demand. The layoffs affect 700 people in Esterhazy, Saskatchewan, and 300 at its Colonsay, Saskatchewan, operation. Layoffs represent 80% of their operations in Canada. The indefinite layoffs are effective Feb. 15 in Esterhazy and March 8 in Colonsay.

On November 23, 2009, Mosaic Co. determined that it would not reopen, and approved the permanent closure of, its Green Bay, Florida concentrated phosphates plant and South Pierce, Florida, phosphoric acid plant, both of which had been indefinitely closed as part of a restructuring of the companys Phosphates segment at the end of May 2006. In addition, the company determined that it would no longer use certain idled machinery and equipment. The company currently estimates that it will incur non-cash charges in the fiscal 2010 second quarter ending November 30, 2009 associated with the permanent closures of the two plants and the idled machinery and equipment in an aggregate amount of approximately $50 million pretax.

Mosaic Co. announced it will temporarily shut down its ammonia and phosphate plants near Donaldsonville because flooding from the Mississippi River is expected to affect the flow of electricity to the plants. The temporary closures are not expected to affect company's earnings.
Mosaic Co. announced that it plans to close its potash mine in Colonsay, Saskatchewan, for the rest of the year. About 330 workers have received temporary layoff notices.

The Mosaic Co. is cutting 350 workers at its Colonsay potash mine in Saskatchewan as it ramps up production at a lower-cost operation. The fertilizer giant says it has issued 395 layoff notices to hourly workers as it indefinitely idles the Colonsay mine, but expects 52 of those workers to stay on to keep the operation on standby in case market conditions improve. The move comes after unprecedented wet spring weather in North America disrupted the planting season and affected fertilizer demand, though potash prices still rose.
Celanese AG has announced that it will cut 1,600 jobs, or 13.5 percent of its workforce, this year as a part of the cost cutting measures.
Celanese Corp. has confirmed it will shed 385 jobs when it stops manufacturing acetate flake and tow - used to make cigarette filters - in Spondon at the end of next year.

Neenah Paper Inc. announced that a 150-year-old paper mill is set to close in June 2007, a move that will mean the loss of about 140 jobs in this Berkshire County town. The Great Barrington mill was one of four plants owned by Fox River Paper and purchased by Neenah Paper Inc.
Bill Barrett Corp. announced that it will halt drilling new oil and gas wells in order to conserve money. The company announced that it had laid off "less than 20%" of its staff.
VeriFone Holdings Inc. announced that it laid off approximately 100 employees in December in response to weakened demand for the San Jose, Calif.-based company's products.

Dexcom said that it will cut 350 full-time jobs in San Diego and Arizona as its shifts some customer support and other functions overseas. The layoffs are occurring in customer support, sales, tech support and administrative functions. The job cuts, which amount to 13% of Dexcom's workforce, will occur over the next 60 to 180 days. The company will take a $25 million charge as a result of the move.
NeuStar has laid off about 10 percent of its workforce as part of an effort to refocus its business strategy.

Cooper-Standard Holdings Inc. announced that it will close its Archbold plant and idle 215 workers by the summer of 2008. Workers in Archbold will have the opportunity to apply for jobs in other Cooper-Standard plants, including the one in New Lexington, which employees more than 200, and two closer plants in Bowling Green. One plant in Bowling Green, employing nearly 500, makes automotive seals, and the other, employing nearly 400, makes hoses and other automotive products.

Dresser-Rand Group Inc. has laid off 39 employees at its Olean plant as the company grapples with the fallout from a 34% drop in its new order bookings in 2009. The layoffs amount to about 5% of the company's work force in Olean, which numbers around 800. The layoffs will begin next week and will run indefinitely.

Cbeyond, Inc. announced earnings results for the year 2011. For the period, the company reported net income of $80 million in fiscal 2011, on revenues of $485 million.The company announced that it plans to cut about 200 jobs company wide, as the telecom provider shifts its business focus. Cbeyond offers a suite of communication services, including broadband calling (or voice over Internet protocol), Internet access, e-mail, Web hosting and secure backup to small businesses, with five to 250 employees. The majority of the cuts will be in sales and sales support outside metro Atlanta.
Cbeyond Inc. axed 100 jobs and could be prepping for a sale. The cuts are related to the company's transition from bundled telephony to managed cloud services.

Ameriprise Financial Inc. announced that 300 employees in its Minneapolis headquarters will be out of a job by week's end. An undisclosed number of workers in its field leadership and branch offices also are being let go. The move largely does not affect financial advisers or client services employees. Job cuts in the field organization are due to the acquisition of H&R Block Financial Advisors, which gave Ameriprise an opportunity to remake its entire employee adviser force.

CROCS Inc. plans to close its Quebec City plant in July and shift production to its site in Mexico to improve the company's cost structure. Crocs has been expanding and upgrading its manufacturing capabilities in Mexico to include molding, sewing and compounding. The Quebec City facility was not fully used and its shutdown will take out $5 million in annual costs and lead to a $16 million one-time charge on earnings. The closure will eliminate 670 jobs. Some 262 people already have been laid off.

CROCS Inc. has notified the 37 employees at its Aurora warehouse that it plans to close the facility this summer. The company says the move is part of the company's ongoing strategy to consolidate warehouse space. The Aurora warehouse is expected to close July 8, 2009.
Crocs, Inc. announced that it is expecting to close another 65 stores, while only opening 35 new ones in 2015.

Crocs, Inc. planed to close another net 12 stores in fourth quarter of 2017, which will result in a total of net 96 fewer stores at the end of 2017. This will bring total store count down to 462 from 558 at the beginning of the year.

Under Armour Inc. still plans to open a store on Fifth Avenue in New York but has significantly pushed back the timeline. Under Armour plans to take possession of the 53,000-square-foot space on the first floor of the General Motors building in the first half of 2020. Under Armour expects to open its store in the first half of 2021. The pinnacle brand expression store,?as Bergman described it, will be located in the space that used to be occupied by the iconic FAO Schwarz toy store and put Under Armour's logo in a prime Manhattan shopping destination for tourists. The company is also laying off 400 employees as part of its restructuring plan.
Science Applications International Corporation has reduced its workforce by 700 people to remain competitive in a challenging market.

Western Refining Inc. plans to shutter its Bloomfield, N.M., refinery and consolidate the operations of its two New Mexico plants in a move the company said it will save $25 million per year. Together, the company's Bloomfield and Gallup plants could process 40,000 barrels of crude oil a day at peak capacity. Recently, each has produced 12,000 to 14,000 barrels a day, and the company said it can process the same volume of oil about 26,000 barrels per day at the Gallup refinery alone.About 100 employees will be laid off. The job cuts are set to begin within two weeks and should be completed by mid-December.

Western Refining Inc. has completed the safe and orderly shutdown of its refining process units at its Yorktown, Virginia refinery. The suspension of refining operations at Yorktown was announced on August 5, 2010. The decision was based on the continued outlook for weak refining margins on the East Coast. The Company will continue to operate the products terminal and storage facility and supply the region with finished products. The Company is continuing to evaluate all strategic alternatives for the facility. As previously announced, the Yorktown decision will result in the Company recording a one-time cash charge totaling approximately $13 million during the second half of 2010. Additionally, the Company expects to generate approximately $50 million in cash from the reduction of working capital at Yorktown in the third quarter of 2010.

Viacom Inc. is to axe around 250 jobs from its MTV Networks International business, which operates channels including MTV, Nickelodeon and VH1 in the UK. This represents around 8% of MTVNI's total workforce of 3,257. The job cuts form part of a restructuring designed to improve MTVNI's operating margins and focus the outfit on high growth markets and business. In London, MTVNI will be merging some of its international operations with its UK business, which is the cable and satellite broadcaster's biggest money spinner outside the US. The company is also planning to relocate some of its emerging markets Europe/Middle East group from London to Budapest and Warsaw.

Live Nation cut about 100 people last week, mostly in "back office" personnel, including accounting, business operations, and other functions. The layoffs were part of efforts to find efficiencies and are said to be unrelated to the Ticketmaster/Live Nation merger. It is expected that Live Nation will promote fewer shows than the 20,000 it promoted last year worldwide, but much of that reduction will come from low margin shows and venues that Live Nation does not own.

Chipotle said it temporarily shut down a restaurant in Virginia following reports of customers becoming ill. The company said it shut down a location in Sterling, Virginia, on July 17, 2017 after becoming aware of a "small number" of reported illnesses. It said it is working with health authorities to understand the cause, but the reported symptoms are consistent with norovirus. Chipotle plans to reopen the restaurant after a "complete sanitization".

Chipotle has temporarily closed a Dallas location where a diner posted video of rodents inside the restaurant. The restaurant will remain closed while the company thoroughly checks out the 100-year-old building in Dallas' West End neighbourhood. Last month, a diner posted video online that showed three small rodents near a door, including one climbing a wall. Chipotle said at the time that a few mice got inside through a small gap in the building, and that the gap was repaired.

Fidelity National Information Services Inc. will close its Middleton office and lay off 53 employees. The company provides payment and processing services for the financial industry. The work being done at the Middleton office at 1800 Deming Way will be moved to other locations. The layoffs are expected to occur in March.

Fidelity National Information Services Inc. announced it plans to close a facility in Madison that will result in the permanent layoff of 157 employees. The company said the first wave of firings will begin July 15, 2010 and will continue through March 31, 2011.

Vanda Pharmaceuticals Inc. announced that it is cutting 15% of its work force and suspending all commercial and development activities. To reduce expenses, Vanda also let go of eight employees. In addition, Vanda has eliminated four full-time contract commercial positions. The company now has 44 employees.

NYSE Euronext Inc. announced it plans to cut 109 jobs of its 359 staff on the bourse in Paris. The job cuts will be carried out within a restructuring plan, announced at an extraordinary works council meeting on November 12, 2008. Out of the total number, 85 employees will be laid off and the rest will be relocated to other units.

Embarq Corp. announced that it will lay off 65 workers when it closes a Tarboro call center in January. The closing is aimed at making the telecommunications company more efficient and eliminating redundancy. The company announced that the call center is part of a larger Embarq operation in Tarboro, and the closing won't impact the other workers. The company says the laid-off workers are encouraged to apply for other jobs within the company.

Embarq Corp. will lay off about 100 workers when it closes its call center in November. Workers learned on September 3, 2009 about the closing, which is the result of Embarq's recent merger with CenturyTel Inc. The company said the New Bern employees can apply for jobs in the new company, Century Link, or relocate to available positions. Workers who stay with Embarq until early November get a severance package.

Halliburton Co. is cutting jobs and slashing employee benefits at its Kellogg Brown & Root arm as a possible precursor to a sale. The cutbacks come as the subsidiary admitted in a letter to staff that KBR had lost several major bids in the Europe/Africa region worth more than Dollars 1bn in the past two years and that competitors are significantly outperforming KBR. However, KBR could face legal problems in its efforts to cut costs at its UK division, which employs 3,000 people.

Windstream Corporation will close a customer service call center in Lincoln November 9, 2007 and shift the work to Ohio. The 100 employees whose jobs will be cut will be eligible to apply for jobs in a Twinsburg, Ohio, center or for severance pay. Jobs will be added at Twinsburg. The Lincoln call center provides technical support for Windstream's broadband service customers. Windstream employs 646 people in Nebraska, 500 of them in Lincoln. The call-center closing and the soon-to-be-completed sale of Windstream's telephone directory business, announced in December, will reduce employment by 151, all in Lincoln.

Windstream Communications (Windstream Corporation) announced 120 layoffs for Concord employees, the second set of cuts since the company's purchase of Concord-based CT Communication in August. The announcement comes as Windstream prepares to complete the systems conversion with CTC in mid-February, at which time about 120 call center jobs will be eliminated.

Windstream Corporation will lay off about 35 people in Newton after buying Iowa Telecommunications Inc. The restructuring affects about 60 positions at operations in Iowa and Minnesota and takes effect August 2. The positions being cut are mostly in accounting, finance and marketing. The affected employees may apply for other jobs with the company or receive severance benefits.

Windstream Corp. is reportedly set to cut 40 jobs in Lexington, N.C., effective September 3, 2010, as the company completes the conversion of Lexcom Communications' billing system to its own platform. Most of the cuts are set to come from customer service, The (Lexington) Dispatch reported July 7, citing David Avery, Windstream director of corporate communications.

Windstream Corporation has eliminated five management positions in Lexington as part of a recently completed restructuring. Looking to reduce expenses, the company announced the move during the second quarter 2012 and eliminated about 350 positions overall, roughly 3% of its work force. The restructuring is expected to save $30 million to $40 million annually.

Western Union Co. announced that it would eliminate 200 jobs, including 60 in metro Denver. The job cuts represent about 2.5% of Western Union's global workforce of 6,000 and 4.6% of its metro Denver workforce of 1,300. This decision is difficult but necessary to position the company for continued success in this challenging economic environment.

Western Union Co. plans to lay off 88 workers in St. Charles, according to a notice filed last week with the state of Missouri. The job cuts will occur by June 30. Additional details about the job cuts were not immediately known.

Western Union is laying off 10% of its staff and will be consolidating its corporate and business offices. As of December 31, 2018, Western Union employed approximately 12,000 employees, of which approximately 2,400 employees are based in the U.S. The layoffs are part of a new cost-cutting global strategy program that Western Union will reveal at its investor day event on Sept. 24 in Denver. The cost-cutting program is expected to cut $100 million from Western Union's annual costs starting in 2021. Additionally, Western Union predicted that the program will result in $50 million in savings in 2020.

Western Union announced that it is laying off a 'significant portion' of its employees based out of a New Jersey office. The impacted employees of the office at 100 Summit Ave. in Montvale, New Jersey, will be laid off by Oct. 13, according to the Worker Readjustment and Retraining Notification Act (WARN) notice that the company filed with the state on Aug. 7. The letter, however, indicated that not all of the 192 'terminated' employees will leave the company.

Hanesbrands Inc. announced that it will close a high-cost distribution center in Florida and consolidate two other distribution centers in Winston-Salem, N.C., into a nearby third facility. The company will reduce the amount of space it leases for distribution of mens panties and sleepwear by more than 400,000 square feet. The consolidation also will better align the companys product flow within its overall global supply chain by moving distribution of some products from Florida to the companys new distribution center in California. The closing of the Weston, Fla., distribution center will result in a reduction of 79 jobs.

Hanesbrands Inc. announced that it will lay off 83 workers as it closes its underwear distribution plant in Weston. Under the federal Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification, or WARN Act of 1988, companies that employ at least 100 people, or 50 people at one location, must notify the state's Agency for Workforce Innovation every time they plan to lay off more than 50 people in one month. Company expects to take restructuring and related charges for the Weston distribution center closure of about $8 million, including severance, lease exit and asset write-off costs. Operations at the 267,000-square-foot distribution center, at 2935 West Corporate Lake Blvd., are expected to cease by March. The company also plans to close three manufacturing facilities: a sewing facility in Mexico employing 1,700 employees, a North Carolina textile manufacturing facility with about 260 employees and a South Carolina hosiery knitting facility employing 145 workers.

Hanesbrands Inc. announced that it would cut 5,300 jobs, or 11% of its work force, close nine sewing and assembly operations and move production to lower-cost sites in Asia and Central America. The company will close plants in Mexico and the Dominican Republic and cut other positions in the U.S. and Puerto Rico. The news followed an announcement in May that the company would cut 1,400 jobs and close three sewing and assembly operations in the Dominican Republic.
Hanesbrands Inc. announced that 46 workers are being laid off from its Virginia Service Center. The company announced the cutbacks on March 20, 2009.

Hanesbrands Inc. is eliminating jobs at its headquarters in North Carolina and closing a distribution center, moves that affect 440 workers. The company reported that the 200 layoffs at the headquarters affect workers in finance, human resources, sales and marketing and supply chain management. Shutting down the distribution center affects 240 workers, including 40 third-shift workers immediately.

Shutterfly Inc. discloses it is closing its Hayward factory next spring, a move that eliminates 100-plus East Bay jobs. The manufacturing operations will move to Arizona. Shutterfly also has a factory in North Carolina. The decision will idle 106 employees.
Shutterfly Inc. announced that it plans in July to close its manufacturing plant in Hayward, Calif., by early 2009 and lay off the plant's 100-plus employees.

Shutterfly, Inc. announced that as part of the company's plan to consolidate the company's team to its Redwood City headquarters, and closure of its offices in New York, 260 jobs equal to approximately 13% of its workforce will be terminated. Additionally, the company will shut down its pro gallery service, review its Borrow Lenses business, and re-invest in Tiny Prints as its premium card and stationary brand.

Shutterfly Inc. has decided not to fill 14 open positions at its Shakopee manufacturing plant, which opened in 2014, as part of a national restructuring plan. The company announced that it will reduce its nationwide staffing by 13% - or 260 employees - following a nearly 31% decline in profits for the last quarter of 2016. The digital photo company will also close its offices in New York and Santa Clara, Calif. The Santa Clara workers will move to corporate headquarters in nearby Redwood City, Calif.

Shutterfly, Inc. provided earnings guidance for the first quarter and full year 2019. For the quarter, the company expects net revenue to range from $317 million to $328 million. Operating loss to range from $102 million to $107 million. Net loss per share to range from $2.49 to $2.59. For the full year, the company expects net revenue to range from $2,130 million to $2,210 million. Operating income to range from $76 million to $101 million.
