Net income per share to range from $0.55 to $1.06.The company announced that Christopher North, President and CEO, will be stepping down at the end of August 2019, and that the Board of Directors has engaged an executive search firm to identify candidates to succeed him.The company will also open a new 237,000 square foot facility in Texas, in the first half of 2020, which will serve both Lifetouch and Shutterfly.In the first phase of Project Aspen, the company will close four legacy Lifetouch facilities, including the two sites previously announced, and two additional facility closures announced on February 5, 2019: Chico, California and Chattanooga, Tennessee, both of which will close in the second half of 2019.
First Solar, Inc. cut profit goals and will cut 100 jobs in its second restructuring in six weeks as it shifts its focus to large utilities.

First Solar, Inc. announced that it would slash 2,000 jobs, or 30% of its work force, to keep pace with steep declines in panel prices. First Solar will cut output of its thin-film solar panels and shift its focus away from Europe, where governments have been changing subsidy policies that had boosted demand for First Solar's panels. Solar panel manufacturers have struggled amid a steep decline in selling prices for solar equipment over the past year that has sent share prices in the sector plummeting. Several companies have gone into bankruptcy. Solar makers, particularly in China, have rushed to build new manufacturing capacity in recent years as demand for the renewable energy systems grew. That expansion left the industry struggling with output capacity nearly double customer demand. The resulting inventory glut sent prices for panels down by more than half over the last year.

Time Warner Cable Inc. will close its customer call center in Fayetteville on Oct. 29, 2009. Those 80 jobs will move to Raleigh and Wilmington. Employees will be able to reapply for their positions in the new locations.

Time Warner Cable Inc. announced that it is eliminating hundreds of jobs from its national network management center in the south Denver metro area as part of a national realignment. The cuts affect employees a network operations site in unincorporated Douglas County and a call center in Centennial. The company notified 350 people to begin winding down their services in 90 days.The company is restructuring its management of national network operations and consolidating some of those functions out of Colorado.

HFF Inc. announced that it carried out a complete review of its business lines and support functions during the fourth quarter of 2008 and has reduced its operating costs and expenses. As part of measures to reduce costs the company cut 57 jobs, or approximately 12% of its workforce. HFF now has 433 employees, including 163 producers.

Domtar Corporation has confirmed the elimination of a shift at the sawmill in Timmins will result in the layoff of between 30 and 35 people. This is something that has already been announced to employees and the public. The layoff is for an undetermined amount of time and is a result of the problems facing the forestry industry. The company announced that the Domtar-Chesney Sawmill will go from two shifts to one, due to deterioration in demand for lumber products.

Domtar Corporation announced that it will close its Port Edwards, Wisconsin mill as well as reorganize production at its Dryden, Ontario facility. These measures will result in a permanent reduction of Domtar's annual production capacity by approximately 342,000 tons. The Port Edwards, Wisconsin mill, which produces uncoated freesheet paper, has an annual production capacity of 165,000 tons. Operations are expected to cease in the second quarter of 2008. Approximately 500 employees will be affected by this closure. Most product lines will be gradually transferred to more efficient facilities. The Dryden, Ontario mill, which produces uncoated freesheet paper, will undergo a reorganization of its operations. Paper machine #2, which has a production capacity of 332,000 tons, as well as two cutsize sheeters, will close on December 22, 2007. Paper machine #1, which has a production capacity of 155,000 tons, will be restarted in mid-January 2008. This will result in a net permanent reduction of annual production capacity by 177,000 tons. Approximately 125 employees will be affected by this reorganization. In total, approximately 625 employees at these facilities will be affected by these decisions. In accordance with its values and policies, Domtar will take appropriate measures to assist affected employees.

Domtar Corporation has announced indefinite layoffs at its sawmill in Ear Falls. The company said 55 of the mill's 131 employees will be impacted, as will another 58 contract employees in harvesting and hauling operations.

Domtar Corporation announced the permanent closing of its Lebel-sur-Quevillon, Quebec pulp mill. Operations were halted on November 24, 2005 due to unfavorable economic conditions. The Lebel-sur-Quevillon mill employed approximately 425 employees. The permanent closing of the mill comes after all other solutions have been considered in the last three years and as the global pulp market now faces deteriorating conditions, therefore putting an end to any expectation to re-launch a profitable operation at Lebel-sur-Quevillon.

Domtar Corporation announced that it will permanently lay off 185 workers at its Plymouth mill in Washington County. The layoffs go into effect March 1. The company will offer severance packages to affected employees. There will be 500 workers at the site after the cutbacks.

Domtar Corporation employees ready to return to work in Timmins, Ont., now have to wait until May to go back on the job. The company's vice-president Michel Rathier blames the six-week extension on the continuing downtown in the economy. The forestry giant announced the initial six-week shutdown earlier this year and said the mill would re-open on March 20. That has now been extended to May 4, affecting about 100 employees.

Monotype Imaging Holdings Inc. announced a restructuring of the Olapic business designed to accelerate its integration into the core Monotype business, thereby helping Monotype to drive improved growth and customer value for the Olapic offerings, and to calibrate investments to better support the Olapic business over time. As a result, Monotype has reduced its headcount by 80 positions, primarily Olapic employees.

Cinemark Holdings Inc. announced that it has closed the previously announced divestiture to Carmike Cinemas of three theatres and 52 screens required by the Department of Justice final judgment in the Rave Cinemas acquisition.

TechTarget Inc. plans to cut 76 positions, or about 12% of its staff by the end of the year. The reductions, which include the elimination of its two print publications and a reduction of office space it leases, is meant to reduce expenses in the midst of a recession.

Covidien Ltd. confirmed that it will cut 40 full-time positions from its Watertown plant by January. The announcement comes as the company moves four product lines from Faichney Drive to a Covidien manufacturing facility in China.

Covidien Ltd. will close its Faichney Drive facility and cut all 247 local jobs by January 2011. The company will start transferring production to other Covidien locations or discontinuing lines in June. Its service and repair group also will be moved to an unspecified facility elsewhere in the United States. Employees who lose their jobs will receive severance benefits. The closing is due to the overall economic decline.
Tyco Electronics Ltd. announced that it is laying off 2,500 workers worldwide. Those affected by the layoffs are being offered severance packages.

A round of 500 job cuts for Discover Financial Services has cost about 50 jobs at the company's New Albany call center. The cuts at the area call center took place over the last few weeks. The center, in New Albany's Research and Information District, had about 1,200 full-time and 500 part-time workers at the end of 2008, making it one of Central Ohio's largest employers The company last month announced plans for company-wide job cuts, most of which took place at its headquarters. The company employed about 12,000 before cutting about 4% of its work force.

On August 20, 2019, comScore, Inc. announced that it is implementing a reduction in force plan that is expected to result in the termination of approximately 8% of the Companys workforce. The reduction in force is being implemented following a determination to reorganize the Company's technology, product and sales organizations to optimize its focus on core areas of growth. The majority of the employees impacted by the reduction in force will exit the Company in the third quarter of 2019. In connection with this reduction in force, the Company will incur certain exit-related costs, which are expected to range between $1.5 million and $2.5 million, consisting primarily of one-time termination benefits and associated costs, to be settled in cash. Together with recent attrition, the reduction in force is expected to decrease the company's annualized operating costs by more than $20.0 million, a portion of which will be realized beginning in the third quarter of 2019.

Genpact announced that the company will cut 65 jobs in the mortgage services business in Richardson. The employees were notified and will be offered severance packages. The jobs will be officially cut on Feb. 17. The global company, which offers information technology services and software services in addition to mortgage assistance, has its headquarters in Bermuda but most of the key executives are based in New York City. The Richardson office, which opened in April, 2012, had more than 150 employees in September, including vice presidents and assistant vice presidents. The company also announced the hiring of Michael Moore, a former Bank of America executive, as the vice president and COO of the mortgage services unit.

MiMedx announced it is cutting 240 jobs about one-quarter of the embattled firm's workforce ?as it struggles to survive. The company has been fighting to right itself as it copes with leadership upheaval and apparent problems with the accuracy of its financial disclosures. The company plans to cut costs to match revenues.

Vitamin Shoppe, Inc. provided guidance for 2019. The company expects the Full year comparable sales of negative low single digits to flat and also For the fourth quarter ended December 29, 2018, the company reported goodwill, trade name and store fixed-assets impairment charges of $1,466,000 against $786,000 a year ago.The company expect closing of approximately 60 to 80 stores over next three years.

Vitamin Shoppe, Inc. provided earnings guidance for the year 2019. Based on first quarter performance, the company is updating total comparable sales guidance for 2019. All other guidance for the key levers that drive the business are unchanged. The company expected full year comparable sales of negative mid to low single digits.The company expects to close approximately 60 to 80 stores over next three years.
Patriot Coal Corporation plans to eliminate 400 jobs by idling more West Virginia mines. Patriot blamed high costs for idling its three-mine Remington complex in Kanawha County.

Patriot Coal Corporation announced that it will close three local mining operations in Kanawha and Boone counties between March 24 and April 6, 2009. Remington LLC, Highway Mining and Weatherby Processing have 220 employees who will lose their jobs. With other recent closures, 400 Patriot Coal employees in West Virginia will have lost their jobs. The operations being closed will include: The Deskins Mine in Kanawha County and Stockburg No. 2 in Boone County, as well as a Kanawha County mine office, which employ 143 hourly and salaried individuals. The Wildcat Surface and Highway Mining operations in Kanawha County, which employs 45. Weatherby's coal preparation plant, which employs 45. Patriot Coal explained it is shutting down its less productive operations, including the recent closure of the Jupiter mining complex in Boone County.

Patriot Coal plans to cut production at two mining complexes in southern West Virginia and potentially lay off workers. The company announced that it has issued 60-day layoff notices to workers at its Wells mining complex near Wharton and its Corridor G complex near Danville. Patriot employs 450 workers at the Wells complex and 397 workers at the Corridor G complex. The company needs to align its production with expected sales. The company says pricing for both metallurgical and thermal coal is well below production costs at many mines in Central Appalachia.

Patriot Coal Corp. is halting operations at its Highland No. 9 mine and Dodge Hill No. 1 mine in Union County. The mines employ about 670 workers and produced about 3.9 million tons of thermal coal last year. Patriot announced that these actions are a result of the difficult coal markets. Sales volumes were lower last year at the Highland mine. The company's Heritage preparation plant near Waverly and the barge loading terminal on the Ohio River at Uniontown are expected to continue processing and shipping coal from on-site stockpiles.

Patriot Coal sent notices of potential layoffs to employees, in advance of a potential sale. The total number of employees who the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification, or WARN, notices wasn't known. Layoffs included 500 jobs at Remington Coal in Cabin Creek, 252 jobs at Toms Fork Road in Eskdale, 164 jobs at Midland Trail Energy in Charleston, 118 jobs at Remington in Eskdale and 47 jobs at Wildcat Energy in Wharton.
Patriot Coal expects to lay off more than 2,000 employees at its operations in West Virginia. The company issued layoff warning notices in Boone and Kanawha counties.

A. H. Belo Corporation will cut about 5% of the newspaper s jobs. The company plans to cut $50 million in expenses over the next eight months, partly by reducing the work force at its newspapers. The job cuts are the result of a broad restructuring that A.H. Belo announced it is implementing as it faces an unprecedentedly adverse business environment in the newspaper industry. As part of the plan, A.H. Belo announced it will eliminate the equivalent of about 500 full-time jobs company wide, representing about 14% of its overall work force of about 3,570 employees. The company announced that it has already eliminated the equivalent of 170 full-time jobs so far 2008 through attrition and disciplined hiring practices. The company also announced that it plans to sell some real estate in each of its three principal markets. The company also plans to reduce its overall marketing and promotional expense, travel expense and other discretionary expenses.
A. H. Belo Corporation announced to lay off 500 workers, or about 14% of its work force, and implement other cash-saving measures to cope with declining advertising revenue.
A. H. Belo Corporation announced that it would lay off 500 workers.

Visa plans to cut another 58 positions at its Foster City campus, after laying off 213 employees at its former headquarters earlier this month. The company's latest round of layoffs will be effective March 20, 2017. The company announced that it was eliminating positions around the globe as it digests its $23 billion purchase of Visa Europe and adjusts to the rapidly shifting payments landscape. Visa declined to discuss how many jobs in total it plans to cut this year.

Colfax Corporation announced that it will close its plant in Sanford, N.C. Production for its Zenith gear pumps will move to the company's facilities in Monroe, N.C. and Columbia, Ky. This consolidation is expected to reduce the company's cost structure by approximately $2.3 million annually ($1.4 million after taxes or 3 cents per share). The Sanford plant, which employs 68 people, is scheduled to close by the end of the year.
By the end of 2016, Colfax Corp. now expects to eliminate in excess of $100 million from cost structure and reduce the workforce by approximately 1,500 compared to where it started 2015.

Philip Morris International has announced a restructuring programme which may lead to 170 job cuts out of 3,000 in Switzerland. The reorganisation aims to simplify the structure and reallocate resources, in order to support the group's international growth in the long term. The job cuts or transfers will take place in Lausanne and Neuchatel. The management will launch negotiations with the staff and is ready to offer financial support and advice in finding another job.

HSN Inc. announced that it was closing a facility near Bonsack, HSN Inc. formerly known as Home Shopping Network, will begin the gradual process of laying off 257 workers starting Aug. 10, 2016 according to a layoff notice filed with the state June 10, 2016. HSN spokesman Brad Bohnert said the company will begin layoffs based on "specific roles and business needs" as early as Aug. 10 and the downsizing will continue through April 2017, when HSN expects to fully close the facility.
Tree.Com, Inc. is closing operations at its Indianapolis mortgage center by Aug. 16, with the loss of 64 jobs. Some affected employees may be offered positions at other Tree.com operations.

Roadrunner Transportation Systems, Inc. announced it will downsize its unprofitable dry van business, which is part of the companys Truckload segment. The downsizing includes reducing dry van company tractor and trailer fleets by over 50%, closing five terminal locations and eliminating approximately 450 positions. Employees subject to the workforce reduction will receive either severance or a 60-day notice. In conjunction with the downsizing activities, the company expects to incur one-time pretax operations restructuring costs of between $12 million and $16 million, excluding the gain or loss on the sale of equipment and the write-down of assets. The downsizing activities are expected to reduce lease obligations and debt and be substantially complete by year-end 2019, with workforce reductions effective over the next 60 to 90 days. The reduction in force represents approximately 10% of the companys total workforce.
Avago Technologies plans to cut more than 1,100 jobs and realize various operating efficiencies of more than $200 million in cost synergies.

Broadcom Inc. is laying off 262 former CA employees from its Islandia facility in the aftermath of its acquisition of the software company. The filing said 45 additional employees would be discharged from CA's most recent headquarters on Madison Avenue in Manhattan. CA listed about 1,000 employees at Islandia as of May, the same month the board of directors approved a restructuring plan to cut about 800 jobs worldwide. Broadcom is providing severance packages to employees who were laid off.

Allscripts announced that it is laying off employees at its Raleigh office. The company said the restructuring move will impact 250 jobs companywide, including 60 in Raleigh where it employs 1,200. The cuts are across the company's services, support, solutions management and selling, general and administrative functions.
Pennsylvania Fashions announced that the company would close down some of its 247 stores.

Rue21 announced widespread store closures. Catoosa Hills, Bartlesville and Miami locations will be among the area stores that are closing. Twelve of the 31 Oklahoma stores are scheduled to shut their doors. The Tulsa Promenade mall, Shops at Broken Arrow and Owasso locations will remain open. The company announced over the weekend that it was closing 400 stores nationwide, is among a slew of retailers that have announced cost-cutting measures to compete in a changing retail landscape.

Rue21 announced it was closing about 400 stores. That includes its Bellis Fair space, which is in the Macy's wing, as well as a location in Everett. The clothing company is currently having a closing-store sale. Hundreds of its stores, including 11 in Washington, will remain open.

AOL Holdings, LLC plans to shed up to 2,500 jobs - more than a third of its workforce - as it prepares to separate from Time Warner and finally sever their ill-fated marriage. AOL, which has already got rid of thousands of workers in recent years and employs about 6,900, is asking for volunteers to accept buyouts. If it falls short of the 2,500 target, it plans layoffs to reach a payroll cut of up to 2,300 positions. The cuts will leave AOL at less than a quarter the size it was at its peak in 2004, when it had more than 20,000 employees. The reductions show the company is trying to become lean as it leaves Time Warner's side in three weeks, but it is still unclear how they will help the internet company, which has been trying to reinvent itself as a content and advertising company amid an ongoing decline in its legacy dial-up internet access business.

AOL, Inc. agreed to buy the Huffington Post in February, laid off about 20% of its work force, with the bulk of the job cuts taking place in India. The company eliminated 950 jobs - 750 in India and the rest in the US - as it integrates the news website and restructures to try to return to revenue growth.

AOL, Inc. announced that the company cut 700 jobs in India, but is outsourcing 300. So effectively, it's about 400 to 600 job cuts between India and the US. The company currently has about 5,000 employees, which includes employees from the recently acquired Huffington Post.

AOL has laid off around 100 employees, mainly in its dial-up business, as it looks to eliminate overlap with parent Verizon Communications Inc. The company was re-aligning and a portion of its workforce has been impacted.

For the third quarter of 2014, Express Inc. expects to open 13 new stores and expects to close 3 stores.For the full year 2014, the company expects to open 27 new stores and expects to close 20 stores.

Express, Inc. announced an additional measure as part of its continued strategic approach to improving profitability and managing and optimizing its store footprint. As part of this plan, the company intends to close all 17 Canadian stores and discontinue its Canadian operations through its Canadian subsidiary, Express Fashion Apparel Canada Inc.

NXP B.V. announced that it plans to close its manufacturing facility in Boeblingen, Germany by the end of 2007. Approximately 550 employees are affected by the closure. The majority of the production load will be transferred to NXP's factories in Nijmegen and Hamburg. The move reflects the company's Business Renewal strategy which focuses on enhancing the company's competitiveness, operational effectiveness and profitability. The decision was taken against the backdrop of a low production load which was reduced by an additional 30% as a result of the recent withdrawal of the company from two underperforming businesses. The move of production to Nijmegen and Hamburg will assure continuity of supply to customers, reduce the European cost base and raise the overall productivity and efficiency by further improving the economy of scale within these two sites.
Tesla Motors Inc. announced that to cut jobs and delay a second model because of the global financial crisis. The company also will close its vehicle engineering facility in Rochester.
Tesla Inc. will lay off 63 employees in its SolarCity division's Roseville offices, according to a disclosure filed with the California Employment Development Department.

Tesla announced the laying off more than 3,000 employees, Model 3 production positions won't be affected. The memo didn't say specifically how many jobs would be cut, only that 9% of the workforce would be laid off. In a Securities and Exchange Commission report filed at the end of December 2017, the company announced it had 37,543 full-time employees, meaning at least 3,000 will be impacted.

Tesla is cutting more than 3,000 jobs, or 7% of its workforce, after experiencing a year its founder, Elon Musk, said was both its most challenging and most successful. The road ahead is very difficult" because its products were not yet affordable for most people and it was up against a big incumbent industry. The company has not published its precise headcount but Musk gave a figure of 45,000 in October, implying 3,150 job losses.

Tesla Inc. plans to shutter most of its retail stores and shift the bulk of its global sales to online-only. The sudden about-face came days after it's annual report said the company would be expanding its retail locations. The company also plans to sell its standard Model 3 vehicle at $35,000.

BankUnited filed plans with federal regulators to close its branch in North Miami Beach's Keystone Plaza. BankUnited said it's closing that office because it has a branch just one mile south, at 12290 Biscayne Blvd.

Motorola Mobility Holdings, Inc. announced that it would lay off 20% of its work force and close a third of its 94 offices worldwide. The cuts are the first step in Google's plan to reinvent Motorola, which has fallen far behind its biggest competitors, Apple and Samsung, and to shore up its Android mobile business and expand beyond search and software into the manufacture of hardware. One-third of the 4,000 jobs lost will be in the United States. The company plans to leave unprofitable markets, stop making low-end devices and focus on a few cellphones instead of dozens.

Motorola Mobility announced that it will make a further cut of around 1,200 employees, or 10% of its total headcount, in the US, China, and India. The layoffs follow a previous round of 4,000 job reduction announced in August 2012. An executive of Motorola Mobility said that the cuts are a continuation of the reductions made in last summer and it's very hard for the employees concerned.

Motorola Mobility's handset unit will close its factory in Fort Worth by the end of 2014, putting 700 assemblers of Moto X phones out of work. Moto X, Google Inc.'s initiative to build smartphones in the United States fell victim to weak sales and high costs. Motorola said it will continue to manufacture the Moto X in other plants, including in Brazil and China. Motorola opened the Fort Worth factory in May 2013.

Northrop Grumman has announced a reduction in force of about 380 salaried employees at Northrop Grumman Shipbuilding, Inc., effective November 12, 2010. All impacted employees will receive information on eligibility for severance benefits and other career and other transition services to assist them in finding employment. Of the approximately 380 affected employees, over 100 have been identified as having prior trades experience and have been offered hourly positions, such as welders, electricians, for example.

Francesca's Holdings Corporation plans to open 3 additional boutiques, 1 in third quarter and 2 in fourth quarter.The company also plans to close 14 additional boutiques in the back half of the year, mostly in the fourth quarter.

WPX Energy plans to close its Oklahoma City office by mid-year and it will relocate up to about one-third of those workers to Tulsa. Of the 95 employees at the Oklahoma City office, 33 employees from land, operations, finance and accounting have been offered the option to relocate to Tulsa; and two employees were offered the opportunity to relocate to Carlsbad, New Mexico. Sixty Oklahoma City-based employees are receiving notice that their positions will be eliminated. WPX said the decision was based on finding the best way to control costs and create the structure that the company needs to drive efficiencies going forward. Benefits of having the teams in one office include helping to eliminate costs, increased efficiency and collaboration, increased bench strength and building a greater multibasin skill set among technical talent.

WPX Energy Inc. has laid off 42 employees, including 38 at its headquarters in Tulsa. The company also cut three positions in North Dakota and one position in New Mexico. The layoffs account for 4% of the company's entire workforce.

HomeStreet announced that it will eliminate 86 positions, including 37 jobs in its mortgage business. The other cuts will involve personnel in its commercial and consumer business lines and corporate support. The moves, which represent about 4% of the workforce, should save HomeStreet $12.4 million annually.

Renewable Energy Group, Inc. announced the closing of its 35 million gallon per year nameplate capacity facility located near Houston, Texas. The company acquired and commissioned the plant in 2008 and has been operating it since. The company is currently working with plant employees on relocation opportunities within the production network. The company will completely shut down the Houston plant in November 2021.

Bonanza Creek Energy, Inc. announced that it has performed a corporate reorganization, which resulted in a total workforce reduction of 26 employees and 17 contractors. The reorganization aligns its employee base and general and administrative cost structure with the current commodity price environment and resulting anticipated activity level.Moreover, each of William J. Cassidy, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, and Christopher I. Humber, Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary, will separate from their positions with the Company. Mr. Cassidy joined the Company in 2013 and served as its Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Mr. Humber joined the Company in 2012 as its Executive Vice President, General Counsel and Secretary immediately following its initial public offering.

Laredo Petroleum Inc. is closing its Dallas office and laying off about 20% of its workforce because of plummeting oil and natural gas prices. Laredo announced its commitment to a companywide reorganization effort that will move some Dallas workers to offices in Tulsa or Midland, Texas. It also is cutting about 75 employees.
Exelis, Inc. cuts 21 jobs because of falling demand for defense-related products. The workers, mostly engineers, were given two weeks' notice and will receive severance pay and transition assistance.

Exelis, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2012. The company reported 2012 financial results for the fourth quarter and full year of 2012. Fourth quarter revenue was $1.4 billion, an 8% decrease from the fourth quarter of 2011. Earnings were $0.45 per share, a 32% increase from the fourth quarter of 2011. Net income was $86 million or $0.45 per fully diluted share against $64 million or $0.34 per fully diluted share a year ago. Adjusted net income was $90 million or $0.47 per fully diluted share against $94 million or $0.50 per fully diluted share a year ago. Cash flow from operating activities was $288 million. Capital expenditures were $33 million. Free cash flow was $255 million. Adjusted free cash flow was $259 million.For the full year 2012, the companys total revenue was reduced 5% to $5,522 million against $5,839 million a year ago. Operating income was $561 million against $535 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations before income tax expense was $521 million against $537 million a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $330 million or $1.75 per fully diluted share against $326 million or $1.75 per basic and fully diluted share a year ago. Net income was $330 million or $1.75 per fully diluted share against $326 million or $1.75 per basic and fully diluted share a year ago. Adjusted earnings were $1.85 per share, down 7% from 2011. Full year revenue was impacted by slowing global acquisition cycles due to budget and economic challenges, while the continued sales mix shift away from high volume, surge-related products also drove revenue lower year over year. Net cash provided by operating activities was $385 million against $334 million a year ago. Capital expenditures were $119 million against $95 million a year ago. Free cash flow for the year was $285 million, which reflects $266 million in contributions made by the company to its pension fund. Adjusted free cash flow was $285 million against $508 mil

Yelp announced that it will cut 175 jobs as it abandons its plan to expand into international markets. The international job cuts amount to 4% of Yelp's total workforce of 4,350 employees. The company will stop selling international accounts and focus on its business in the U.S.  and Canada.
Yelp is laying off 1,000 workers and furloughing 1,100 as it imposes "severe cost reductions" to survive amid the coronavirus pandemic.

TRI Pointe Homes, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2015. For the quarter, the company's total revenues were $879,715,000 against $635,001,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations before taxes was $131,344,000 against $68,841,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $85,353,000 or $0.52 diluted per share against $41,426,000 or $0.26 diluted per share a year ago. Net income available to common stockholders was $85,072,000 or $0.52 diluted per share against $41,426,000 or $0.26 diluted per share a year ago. EBITDA was $154,416,000 against $84,554,000 a year ago. Adjusted EBITDA was $155,196,000 against $88,030,000 a year ago.For the year, the company's total revenues were $2,400,149,000 against $1,703,616,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations before taxes was $319,260,000 against $127,964,000 a year ago. Income from continuing operations was $207,181,000 or $1.27 basic and diluted per share against $84,197,000 or $0.58 basic and diluted per share a year ago. Net income available to common stockholders was $205,461,000 or $1.27 basic and diluted per share against $84,197,000 or $0.58 basic and diluted per share a year ago. EBITDA was $382,862,000 against $202,544,000 a year ago. Adjusted EBITDA was $388,121,000 against $233,562,000 a year ago. Net debt as at December 31, 2015 was $956,020,000 against $967,864,000 as at December 31, 2015.The company expects to open 25 new communities, and close out of 11, resulting in 118 active selling communities as of March 31, 2016.For the full year 2016, the company expects to grow communities by 20% and deliver between 4,200 and 4,400 homes at an average sales price of $550,000. The company expects its homebuilding gross margin for the full year of 2016 will be in a range of 20% to 21%, with quarterly fluctuations based on the mix of California deliveries and expects SG&A expense will be in the range of 10.3% to 10.5%. In addition, the company anticipates gross prof

WellCare Health Plans announced that the lay off 100 Tampa Bay area employees. The layoffs, which translate to about 3% of WellCare's workforce, involve streamlining several departments in order to adapt to the changing conditions and requirements of federal and state government programs. About 115 of the affected jobs are in Florida. But that loss will be more than offset as the company expects to add nearly 500 jobs statewide based on potential contract awards with Florida's Agency for Health Care Administration as part of the state's Managed Medical Assistance program. And as WellCare continues to expand other businesses across the country, it anticipates it will continue to add jobs at its Tampa base.

Cabela's Inc. announced a reduction in workforce of approximately 10% at its corporate headquarters in Sidney, Nebraska. After completing a review of its organizational structure, the Company determined to reduce staffing levels in selected areas. The Company expects approximately two-thirds of the reduction to come from not filling open positions and one-third of the reduction to come from job eliminations.

LyondellBasell Industries AF S.C.A. revised earnings guidance for the first quarter ended March 31, 2009. For the quarter, earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, amortisation and reorganisation (EBITDAR) are now projected at $350 million (?62.5 million), up 18.6% from the previous projection of $295 million. The company projected better first-quarter earnings due to better-than-expected showing within the chemicals and polymers markets.The company anticipates improvement in the second quarter but cautioned that it is currently lagging behind its planned second-quarter EBITDAR of $637 million.The company plans to cut 4,800 employees and contractors and close 14 plants and facilities.

LyondellBasell announced that it will shut down a high density polyethylene (HDPE) unit in Wesseling, Germany in the third quarter of 2013. The 100 KT per year unit is among the smallest and least efficient of the LyondellBasell HDPE units in Europe.

LyondellBasell plans to shut down its cracker in Corpus Christi, Texas, as part of the plant's expansion project. The turnaround and expansion project could last 90 days. The project will add 800m lb/year (363,000 tonnes/year) of capacity to the plant. In preparation for the shutdown, LyondellBasell is building up inventory. The inventory build should lower fourth quarter results by $30 million.

Aetna Inc. intends to reduce its workforce in Connecticut by 80 employees as part of a larger reduction of 160 workers. The job cuts started in August and will be spread out for the rest of 2012 and into early 2013.

New Albertsons, Inc. will soon be closing two underperforming stores in Southern California, including one location in Coachella and another in Covina. Both stores are scheduled to close by the end of May. Workers at the 42,433-square-foot Albertsons/Sav-On Pharmacy store in Covina have union representation and "bumping rights" based upon seniority, which will help them secure positions at other company stores.
Albertsons is closing its location on Evangeline Thruway in north Lafayette. The closure is tentatively set for Feb. 18.

Albertsons announced that it will close its three Salt Lake Valley stores on Feb. 22. The company said the action affects stores at 3871 W. 5400 South, Taylorsville; 1653 W. 9000 South; and 6950 S. Redwood Road, West Jordan. Displaced workers will be aided in finding future employment, and customers' pharmacy prescriptions have been sold and relocated to other local drug stores.

Avon announced that it plans to eliminate about 650 jobs as part of its ongoing plan cut costs by $400 million. The cuts are expected to be largely completed by before the end of 2014. The company expects the moves to save it about $40 million to $45 million per year on a pre-tax basis.

Avon Products Inc. announced that it is cutting 2,500 jobs. The company said it expects to save $50 million this year from payroll cuts and the closure of open positions. Starting in 2017, it expects to save around $65 million to $70 million a year.

Avon Products Inc. will close its Springdale manufacturing plant and 590 workers will lose their jobs by mid-2012. A returned-goods facility at the plant also will close. As part of the plan, work will be outsourced to countries with cheaper labor costs. Production at the Springdale plant will move to sites in Morton Grove, Ill., and Celaya, Mexico. Trade Adjustment Assistance funds are for workers who lose their jobs or have hours or wages reduced as the result of foreign trade.

Avon Products, Inc. announced plans to reduce its global workforce by approximately 10% to align with ongoing operating model changes and to create a leaner organization that is better aligned with Avon's current and future business focus.

The Bank of New York Mellon Corporation will move its operation from Pawtucket to another of its locations about 40 miles away, in Westboro, Mass. BNY Mellon offered jobs in Westboro to all the Pawtucket staff. About two-thirds of them accepted the offer, opting to relocate. About 103 people will be laid off. The winding down of the Pawtucket operation, and its consolidation with the Westboro operation, are part of the transition related to acquisition last year. The transfer of workers will start late this month, when some of the Pawtucket employees begin working in Westboro. The process will continue until the fall. Workers who opted not to relocate will be laid off in stages, from the end of June until the fall.

Bank of New York Mellon announced that it is laying off staff and considering whether to sell its corporate trust arm, which includes 135 employees in Pittsburgh, as it faces pressure to control expenses and retreat from a business that has become less profitable since the financial crisis.

The Bank of New York Mellon Corp. is laying off 280 employees at its offices in Philadelphia, effective Oct. 9, according to a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act notice filed with the commonwealth. Some of the Philadelphia employees will be relocated to BNY Mellon offices in King of Prussia and Wilmington.

Bemis Company, Inc. announced to close two Twin Cities plants this year, resulting in layoffs for more than 160 employees. The company will close a St. Louis Park plant by late September and a Minneapolis plant by the end of the year. The move will result in the loss of 162 jobs. Bemis told MPR that the closings -- as well as a handful of others domestically and internationally -- are aimed at increasing the company's efficiency. About 500 employees will lose their jobs companywide. Operations at the closed Twin Cities plants will be moved to other Bemis facilities. Laid-off employees will get transition assistance.

Bemis Company, Inc. said it is implementing a restructuring and cost savings program to improve efficiency and profitability, which includes closing facilities and reduction of its global workforce. The company said the initiatives will result in annual savings run rate of $55 million - $60 million, with targeted timing of 5% - 10% in 2017, 50% - 60% in 2018, and the remainder in 2019. Under the program, the company will close two manufacturing facilities; work performed at these facilities will be transferred to other Bemis locations. The company will initiate the closing of one of these facilities in 2017 and the other in 2018. Benefits from these two plant closures will be $10 million when fully implemented. The company continues to evaluate opportunities to consolidate additional facilities. Bemis also said it will reduce its administrative support cost structure to align with the current business environment. These activities will result in a reduction of 300 positions, or 5% of the global administrative workforce, over the next three years. Impacted employees will receive job placement assistance and severance benefits to assist in their transition. The cost savings from these changes will be approximately $20 million over the next three years.

Brown Shoe Co. Inc. provided earnings guidance for the second quarter 2012. The company expects sales being between $2.6 billion and $2.6 billion and delivering adjusted earnings per share between $83 and $95 is going to be a very solid year for the company. Over the next 3 years, 2012, 2013 and 2014, the companys plan is to open 165 stores. Basically, the company took the numbers it saw of course, in that third year maturity for those stores, the company expects them to do about $230 million in total. That would be a $240 a square foot on that 165 stores. If they hit operating return that it put down, that's $13 million worth of operating profit that 165 stores will deliver. In the meantime, between this year and the next year, the company is closing 90 stores this year and 50 stores, as planned, for the next 2 years.
Caterpillar Inc. announced that it will shut its Aurora, Illinois, plant, costing about 800 employees their jobs, shifts production to other U.S. facilities.

Caterpillar Inc. revised earnings guidance for the fiscal 2016. The company has revised its 2016's income forecast reduce by USD 1 billion. The company announced that there's a strong possibility for it to lay off up to 10,000 employees through the next three years, all driven by the slump in energy and mining industries, let alone China's own industrial slowdown. Revenue is highly projected to deteriorate for the fourth straight year in 2016, to USD 48 billion, plus plunging more 5% over the next, adding the expectancy to cut 5,000 jobs by year end.

The Canadian Auto Workers announced Caterpillar Inc. would close its Electro-Motive plant in London, Ont., a month after it locked out about 450 workers. The closure was a "callous" move, but not unexpected because Caterpillar had no intention of keeping the London plant open, whose union estimates the move will impact about 2,100 jobs.

As many as 150 jobs could go at Leicestershire's Caterpillar factory because of a downturn in sales. The job cuts will hit permanent staff in the mechanical excavator - or backhoe loader division - at the plant in Peckleton Lane, Desford. Caterpillar has about 1,200 workers in the village and a consultation over the voluntary redundancies is now under way.

Caterpillar Inc. has announced the layoff of about 200 full-time production employees at its East Peoria and Decatur facilities. In addition, the company will also end the assignments of 40 agency employees.
Caterpillar is shedding 100 jobs in the North. The company said economic weaknesses in some key markets were impacting on global demand for a number of its products.
Caterpillar Inc. abruptly shuttered its locomotive plant in London, Ont. Kelly Gordon, a welder and single mother, was one of about 700 workers who lost their jobs that day.

Caterpillar will pursue strategic alternatives, including a possible divestiture, for its room and pillar products, which serve a segment of underground soft rock mining customers. It will also discontinue production of track drills within its resource industries portfolio. Up to 155 jobs are expected to be cut associated with the room and pillar business, including some immediately. In Denison, Texas, where track drills are produced, 40 jobs will be cut. The company will also repurpose its Winston-Salem, North Carolina facility from a mining to a rail facility. The company announced that it will repurpose its Winston-Salem, North Carolina, facility, transitioning it from a mining to a rail facility beginning later in 2016. Operations will transfer to Progress Rail, a wholly owned Caterpillar subsidiary. As a result, the company will relocate the manufacturing of some components used in large mining trucks from its facility in Winston-Salem to its existing facility in Decatur, Illinois.

Caterpillar Inc. announced that it will move two production lines from its Joliet plant to Mexico in a plan that will result in the loss of 230 jobs at the Illinois site. The company announced that it was pushing ahead with the plan in order to "remain cost competitive." Under the plan, the company will move production of gear and engine oil pumps and valves to a sister plant in Monterrey, Mexico. The transition is expected to begin in late 2016 and be completed by the middle of 2018.

Caterpillar Inc. announced that it will lay off another 50 workers at its East Peoria, Illinois campus on June 22, 2015 because of a downturn in demand for mining equipment. The latest action brings to 270 the number of workers Caterpillar has said it will lay off in 2015 at its East Peoria campus. The company employs about 3,900 workers at the site, which is its main manufacturing hub.

Caterpillar announced a major cost-cutting program that could shutter more than 20 facilities and eliminate more than 10,000 jobs. The company said it will cut 4,000 to 5,000 jobs by the end of 2016 and could eliminate more than 10,000 positions. The moves are a response to weakness in the mining and energy sectors, two of Caterpillar's core areas.

Caterpillar Inc. announced another round of layoffs in Illinois as it deals with slowing demand for its mining equipment. Nearly 60 employees at Caterpillar's plant in Mapleton, Ill., will be placed on indefinite layoff. That announcement comes a few weeks after Caterpillar said it would eliminate about 460 jobs at its Decatur, Ill., plant, or about 11% of the work force there. Caterpillar has also been enacting temporary layoffs at various company locations, including up to 300 jobs at its South Milwaukee factory.

Caterpillar announced that it plans a new round of layoffs to cut costs as declining revenues from global mining and construction activities erodes its bottom line. The company notified workers it will reduce staff in its customer services support division by cutting 475 jobs. The move comes after the company previously announced about 270 layoffs for Illinois employees.

Caterpillar plans to slash 1,400 jobs at its Gosselies site in Belgium. The plant, which employs around 4,000 workers and has been open since 1965, is located on the outskirts of Charleroi in southern Belgium, a region that was once a thriving industrial belt. the job cuts involving 1,100 workers and 300 office staff were aiming at keeping the plant open and operational beyond 2015.

Caterpillar Inc. has confirmed that it is eliminating 80 jobs at its Winston-Salem plant by December 31 and reducing the workforce-at least temporarily-to 140 employees. The planned reduction was announced by Caterpillar this summer as part of a global operations restructuring. Caterpillar is shifting primary operations at the $426 million plant from axle manufacturing for mining trucks to railroad equipment for its Progress Rail Services Co. subsidiary. The transition is underway and is scheduled to be completed by early 2018. Progress Rail officially takes over the plant January 1.

Caterpillar Inc. announced that it will close five plants in the US and cut around 820 jobs, to cut costs due to falling demand. The company said that so far it has cut around 5,300 jobs from a global workforce of around 11,400. Caterpillar will shutter its plants at Jacksonville - Florida, Morganton - North Carolina, Oxford - Mississippi, and two in South Carolina. Operations of these plants will be merged into other company plants or will be given to parts suppliers outside Caterpillar during the next 12 months to 18 months. The company will also demolish a near vacant engine manufacturing building in Mossville, Illinois, to save money.

Caterpillar announced that it plans to close five plants and trim about 670 jobs in Illinois and several other states, in the latest phase of a larger cost-cutting campaign announced in 2015. The company will cut about 230 jobs for office and production workers at a major manufacturing campus in East Peoria, Illinois, where Caterpillar says it's consolidating some manufacturing and transferring some work to outside contractors. Another 120 employees there will be placed on indefinite layoff.

Cintas Corporation announced plans to gradually close its distribution center and centralized stockroom in Atlanta, GA over the course of the next 12 months. Cintas acquired these facilities as part of its merger with G&K Services earlier this year. The facilities closure will impact about 200 employee-partners. Cintas has 10 other facilities in the Atlanta market and affected employee-partners are encouraged to apply for open positions at those facilities. If the company is unable to offer continuing employment, severance pay, optional continued healthcare coverage and job placement help and resources will be provided. It is a top priority for the company to assist these employee-partners and their families throughout this transition.

Cintas Corporation announced that it will close its Menomonee Falls facility. Cintas regularly examines its operations to determine the optimal structure for continued customer service and future growth, and as such has recently analyzed the Milwaukee market. Based upon this study, and unforeseeable business circumstances related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the company has made the decision to close its Menomonee Falls location at N51 W139915, Northpark Drive as of August 31, 2020 and transition servicing its customers and processing products to other local operations. Cintas remains committed to providing great service with no disruptions to customers during this transition. The company also remains committed to continuing to be a good corporate citizen to the Milwaukee community. Affected employee-partners are encouraged to apply for open positions at other area Cintas facilities. If the company is unable to offer continuing employment, severance pay, and optional continued healthcare coverage will be provided.
Coca-Cola announced that it plans to eliminate 1,200 jobs later this year from a pool of 5,500 corporate positions. The cuts are part of a plan to save about $800 million through 2019.
Coca-Cola says it's cutting between 1,600 and 1,800 jobs globally as part of an ongoing push to trim costs.

Coca-Cola filed a notice with the state saying it will close its 190,000-square-foot production facility off state Route 94 at 47th Street, laying off 92 employees on Nov. 8. The company announced that it will keep the 110,000-square-foot distribution center next to the bottling plant, and its 430 employees. It will handle products from larger bottling facilities in Downey and Los Angeles.

Coca-Cola announced plans to lay off around 750 people in the coming months across the country. About one-fourth of those cuts -180 or so people-will be in Atlanta. These changes are the next step in evolving the organization so that we're focused on the company's highest-value opportunities to grow the business and make it easier for the company people to get work done. The company added that the cuts represent 1% of Coca-Cola's 75,000 employees in North America, which consists of the United States and Canada.

Cullen/Frost Bankers, Inc. will close four branches in the Rio Grande Valley. The company gained the branches after it bought the parent company of the $401 million asset Alamo Bank of Texas in 2006. The closures are the company's first in more than five years and will result in 27 layoffs.The company will have 111 branches in Texas. It has plans to open two more branches in the Dallas area next year 2013.

Walt Disney Co. announced that it is laying off 700 people from the interactive unit that makes video games and operates websites, about a quarter of the workforce in the division. The move narrows the company's focus on mobile and social games that use key Disney characters.
Nearly 130 employees who work for a third-party food-services operation at Walt Disney Co. offices in Burbank and Glendale are slated to be laid off in early November.

Walt Disney Co. announced that it will be shutting down its SOAPnet channel at the end of the year. The channel, which launched in January 2000, will be taken off the air on Dec. 31, 2013. Disney announced plans to drop the channel three years ago in order to make room for Disney Junior, a channel for toddlers. However, at that time cable and satellite TV operators were ready to give up SOAPnet, which played reruns of daytime soap operas, including 'General Hospital', 'All My Children', 'The Young and the Restless', at night.

Walt Disney Co. announced that it is shutting down its Disney Infinity line of video games. The company booked a $147 million charge, mostly for unsold inventory. It also laid off about 300 employees, most of them based in Salt Lake City at Avalanche Software, a game studio Disney bought in 2005.

Walt Disney Co. announced that it will close its 500,000-square-foot distribution center off Highway 176 near Jonesville. The company said it will consolidate the center, which employs about 150 people, into another Disney distribution center in Memphis, Tenn. Some employees will be offered the opportunity to relocate to the Memphis facility, which will serve Disney stores and Disneystores.com.

Ecolab Inc. announced that it will cut 500 jobs from its workforce, mostly corporate staff, as it streamlines operations following its $8.3 billion merger with Nalco Holding Co. of Illinois. People whose jobs are eliminated will be offered severance and outplacement.

General Dynamics Corp. plans to lay off 20 people in October 2010 at its armored vehicle plant in Eynon. The Oct. 22 layoff follows the dismissal of about 30 people in September. Workers at the facility manufacture parts for Abrams tanks, armored personnel vehicles and amphibious transport units. The layoff will bring employment at the facility to about 270.

General Dynamics announced it will lay off about 170 employees at its plant in Ladson, South Carolina by the end of 2014. The company said it will stop making mine-resistance vehicles at the plant by December 2014. The company said it will keep about 50 workers in Ladson to supply spare parts and supplies and offer field service support to its customers. The company said about 140 workers will lose their jobs in June when production of the Buffalo mine-resistant vehicle is halted.
General Dynamics announced that it is temporarily cutting 30 jobs at its plant in Edmonton that does overhaul work on the army's fleet of light armoured vehicles.

Caught off guard by labor unrest at a factory in Turkey, Greif Inc. is dealing with the financial consequences and plans to close the factory. The company announced that the plant has recorded 110 days of downtime 2014 because of an occupation that began in February by labor activists and some employees. As a result of the unrest, the company has decided to close the plant, with a final shutdown to occur by the end of the year.

Grief announced plans to shut down its burlap sack facility located in Hadimkoy of Istanbul, which recorded 110 days of downtime in 2014. The company has decided to close the facility, as it was hit by a workers strike, which resulted in $13 million loss for the company. Final closure of the plant is expected to take place by the end 2014.

Haverty Furniture Companies Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the fourth quarter and full year ended December 31, 2012. For the quarter, the company reported net sales of $182,307,000 compared to $168,259,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes were $10,093,000 compared to $6,061,000 a year ago. Net income was $6,779,000 or $0.30 basic and diluted per share compared to $16,958,000 or $0.76 basic and diluted per share a year ago.For the full year, the company reported net sales of $670,073,000 compared to $620,903,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes were $23,516,000 compared to $4,603,000 a year ago. Net income was $14,911,000 or $0.67 basic and diluted per share compared to $15,463,000 or $0.70 basic and diluted per share a year ago. Net cash provided by operating activities were $52,168,000 compared to $19,072,000 a year ago. Capital expenditures were $25,014,000 compared to $17,566,000 a year ago. Book value at the end of 2012 is approximately $259.4 million or $11.66 a share.For the year 2013, the company expects effective tax rate to be in the 38.5% to 38.8% range and capital expenditures of $20.0 million.Following the year 2013, the company will close 3 underperforming stores, which are at the end of their terms -of their lease terms. The company announced that it expand 3 stores with major remodeling projects and complete another 18 of Bright Inspirations store upgrades. By the end of 2013, 93 stores or 80% of its company will either be new or updated.

Sears Holdings announced the Kmart store in South Burlington will close to the public in mid-January 2016. The store's closure is part of a cost-cutting measure. The company hopes to migrate the shopping activity of people who previously shopped in the Shelburne Road store to alternative channels, including other Kmart and Sears stores and online. The Shelburne Road location is the only local store impacted. Another Kmart store is located in Rutland. The store's 66 employees will receive severance packages and have the opportunity to apply for open positions at area Sears or Kmart stores. The store will begin a liquidation sale on Oct. 25 and will remain open until mid-January.

Dozens of Sears and Kmart stores have been added to the list of closures set for early this year 2017. The stores' parent company, Sears Holdings, has decided to close an additional 42 Sears stores and 108 Kmart stores by April. The new closures are in addition to 46 others that were disclosed last week. The Kmart closures will be made at stores in 36 states -- Alabama, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Hawaii, Iowa, Illinois, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, New Jersey, New York, Nevada, North Carolina, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming. The Sears closures will happen in 27 states -- Alabama, Arkansas, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Louisiana, New York, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, North Dakota, New Mexico, Ohio, Oklahoma, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia, Washington and West Virginia. The closures will bring Sears' total to more than 200 for fiscal 2017.

Sears Holding Corp. is shutting down its parts distribution facility on Bellview Street in Dallas, resulting in 77 employee layoffs. In a letter filed under the Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act, the company said the job cuts and facility closing are expected to be permanent. All terminations will occur on or around February 17, 2015.

Sears Holdings Corp. to close108 Kmart stores and 42 Sears stores this spring, including the last Kmart in the Louisville. area. That Kmart is located at 191 Outer Loop. The announcement came in two rounds, with 30 Kmart and 16 Sears closures announced Dec. 27 and an additional 78 Kmart and 26 Sears closures announced in a company statement.

Sears recently learned that it would survive at a fraction of the footprint it once was when a bankruptcy judge approved CEO Eddie Lampert's bid to buy the company. But that wasn't before every Miami Valley Sears got the ax. Stores at the Dayton Mall and Mall at Fairfield Commons closed late last year, the Piqua store closed last month and the Springfield location is set to shutter later this month.

Sears Holdings Corporation's Kmart store in Parkway Plaza off University Drive in Durham will close in late January and begin liquidation sales this weekend. The closing will result in 79 layoffs. Eligible employees will receive severance and have the opportunity to apply for open positions at area Sears or Kmart stores.

Sears Holdings Corp. announced that a near 40-year-old Kmart in Boca Raton is expected to close its doors in October. The location at 1401 Palmetto Park Road is the next step in Kmart's parent company Sears Holdings Corp.' plan to close down low-performing locations.

Sears Holdings Corp. announced that it is closing Kmart stores in Hales Corners, Greenfield and Portage as it continues to shrink its footprint amid net losses and declining sales. The stores will close in mid-April 2014, eliminating 314 positions. Most of the affected employees are part-time or hourly, and those who are eligible will receive severance and the chance to apply for other open positions. The Milwaukee-area stores are at 5600 S. 108th St., Hales Corners, and 4601 S. 27th St., Greenfield. The company recently closed its Brookfield Kmart at 18200 W. Blue Mound Road. The Sears store at Regency Mall in Racine is scheduled to close in January 2014.

Sears Holdings Corp. continued to announce closings of Sears department store and Kmart locations. Sears will close its department store at 7630 Pershing Blvd. Among the casualties is the large Sears department store at Southridge Mall in Greendale, which will close in mid-September. Also being shuttered are the Kmart department store at 6900 W. Greenfield Ave. in West Allis, and Kmarts in La Crosse and Medford.

Sears Holdings will shut 29 Sears and 11 Kmart locations by February. The number of Sears and Kmart stores will dwindle further as the company plans to close an additional 40 locations by early next year. The latest closure list does not include any New Jersey stores, though two are just over the border in Pennsylvania a Kmart on Roosevelt Boulevard in Philadelphia and a Sears at the Stroud Mall in Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania will soon be gone. Three of those stores are in New Jersey Sears locations on Route 35 in Middletown and at the Deptford Mall in Gloucester County will go out of business along with a Kmart on Delsea Drive in Glassboro.

Kmart Store in Sand Springs will close in mid-October. The store at 1200 E. Charles Page Blvd. will remain open until then, but is beginning its liquidation sale on July 27. The Kmart has 52 employees, most of them part-time and hourly. Those associates who are eligible will receive severance and have the opportunity to apply for open positions at area Sears or Kmart stores.

The Kmart in Collinsville will close its doors within the next three months. According to the city's Community Development Office, the retailer has declined to renew its lease at 1101 Belt Line Road and will close its store after business on Sept. 7, 2014.
Sears Holdings announced it will be closing 46 more Sears and Kmart department stores in November, including Sears in Florence and Colerain Township.
Sears Holdings Corp. to close a handful of Kmart stores across the country by mid-April, 2016 as it continues to trim its ailing fleet.

Sears Holdings will begin laying off 325 workers at its call center facility at the Oak Hollow Mall in High Point in January 2017. Sears had announced in October that it would close its services contract support call center, located at Oak Hollow Mall at 921 Eastchester Drive, by late February, but it had not specified how many people would be affected. Now a notice from the N.C. Commerce Department reveals the number of layoffs and that they will begin Jan. 2. The facility will permanently close in February. The company will fire 89 telephone sales advisors, 142 total protection agreement advisors, 21 resolution specialists, 16 customer advocates, 13 data entry clerks and many other positions.

Sears announced it would be closing 72 more Sears and Kmart stores across the country after a $424 million net loss during the first fiscal quarter. With sales down 30%, the company identified 100 under-performing stores (15 Kmart and 48 Sears) that it plans to close in early September. That list includes three locations in Georgia- Northlake Mall, 2201 Henderson Mill Road, Atlanta; Southlake Mall, 1300 Southlake Mall, Morrow; and Gwinnett Place Mall, 2100 Pleasant Hill Road Duluth. The auto centers at these locations will close in late July. The latest closures follow the loss of two other Georgia locations which shuttered earlier this year at Stonecrest Mall in Lithonia and in Valdosta.

Sears Holdings Corporation has received commitments for $300 million in senior priming debtor-in-possession ("DIP") financing from its senior secured asset-based revolving lenders and is negotiating a $300 million subordinated DIP financing with ESL Investments Inc. ("ESL"). ESL is the Company's stockholder and creditor, and Edward S. Lampert is ESL's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer. Subject to Court approval, the DIP financing is expected to improve the Company's financial position immediately and support its operations during the financial restructuring process. Holdings will also close 142 unprofitable stores near the end of the year. Liquidation sales at these stores are expected to begin shortly. This is in addition to the previously announced closure of 46 unprofitable stores that is expected to be completed by November 2018.Holdings has enacted a series of leadership and Board changes in support of the continued transformation and restructuring process: CEO Transition: Edward S. Lampert has stepped down from his role as Chief Executive Officer of the Company, effective immediately. He will remain Chairman of the Board. The Company's Board has created an Office of the CEO, which will be responsible for managing the Company's day-to-day operations during this process. The Office of the CEO will be composed of Robert A. Riecker, Chief Financial Officer; Leena Munjal, Chief Digital Officer, Customer Experience and Integrated Retail; and Gregory Ladley, President of Apparel and Footwear. Formation of Restructuring Committee: The Board has formed a special committee (the "Restructuring Committee") that will oversee the restructuring process and have decision making authority with respect to transactions involving affiliated parties. The Restructuring Committee consists solely of independent directors and includes Alan J. Carr, Paul G. DePodesta, Ann N. Reese and William L. Transier. Appointment of Chief Restructuring Officer: Mohsin Y. Meghji, Managing Partner of M-III Partners, has been appointed Chief

Sears announced it is closing its Sears Grand store at a mall near Pittsburgh, idling 97 workers there. The stories located at the Galleria at Pittsburgh Mills in Frazer Township. That's about 20 miles northeast of Pittsburgh along Route 28. The mall has struggled with vacancies and minuscule foot traffic. The store will begin a liquidation sale October 31, 2014.

Sears Holdings announced that it was closing 64 Kmart stores. Of the 64 closures, 17 are part of Seritage Growth Properties, a real-estate investment trust that currently owns 235 Sears and Kmart stores. The latest closures are in addition to a decision in April to shutter about 68 Kmart stores, which account for 14% of all existing Kmart stores.

Sears Holdings announced that the company will close 68 Kmart and 10 Sears stores this summer. All of the Sears stores and nearly all of the Kmart stores will close in late July 2016; two Kmart stores will close in mid-September 2016. Sears Holdings expects the store closures to generate a meaningful level of cash from the liquidation of store inventory and from the sale or sublease of some of the related real estate. The closing Kmart and Sears stores will start their liquidation sales on May 12, 2016 and April 29, 2016, respectively.

Sears Holdings Corporation continue to reduce unprofitable stores as leases expire and in some cases will accelerate closings when appropriate. The company have announced the closure of approximately 80 underperforming stores in fiscal 2014 and may close additional stores during the remainder of the 2014.

Sears Holding Corp. will close its Kmart store in the Manahawkin section of Stafford. A liquidation sale at the store, located on Route 72, will begin on June 15. The store will close to the public in early September.

Sears Holdings announced that it will close its Eden Prairie Center anchor store in a cost-cutting move. The Hoffman Estates, Ill.-based department store chain has sold its 130,800-square-foot store and the connected parking lot to Eden Prairie Center owner Cypress Equities for $16 million. Dallas-based Cypress has begun marketing the 18.3-acre site for lease, but hasn't decided if it will tear down the store and rebuild or lease the existing space to smaller retailers, according to sources who have seen plans but requested anonymity to protect business relationships. The company confirmed it will begin a liquidation sale Sept. 9 and close the store in late November.

Sears Holdings Corporation announced plans to close five stores in Illinois, two months after the company got a hefty tax credit for dropping a threat to move its headquarters out of state. The stores include a Sears in Alton, a Sears Grand/Essentials in McHenry, and Kmarts in Oak Lawn, Zion and Peru. The Illinois Legislature and Gov. Pat Quinn approved a $150 million tax credit for the Hoffman Estates-based retailer in December after the company threatened to move its headquarters. Less than two weeks later, the company announced plans to shutter up to 120 Sears and Kmart stores, but no Illinois outlets were on the list at the time. The company laid off 100 workers at its headquarters outside of Chicago earlier this month.

Sears Holdings Corporation announced that Kmart department store in San Leandro is shutting its doors in early December 2014. An estimated 102 employees, mostly part-time workers, will lose their jobs when the store closes. The company is closing at least 110 Sears, Kmart and Sears Auto Center locations. More than 6,000 workers will be laid off.

A Sears department store in El Monte is among the first 79 Sears and Kmart stores earmarked for closure by Sears Holdings Corporation as a result of weak holiday sales. The company identified 41 Sears locations and 38 Kmarts that will be closing. Sears Holdings announced earlier this week that it plans to close a total of 100 to 120 underperforming locations. The El Monte store is located at 3610 Peck Road. The list identifies the 110,000-square-foot El Monte location as a Sears Grand/Essentials store, although the storefront simply says Sears Essentials. The other sites are on Arden Drive and at Santa Anita Avenue and Valley Boulevard.

Sears Holding Corp. announced Florida will be hit the hardest by the closing of Sears and Kmart stores, losing 11, according to a preliminary list of 79 planned closures released. Ohio, Michigan and Georgia are not far behind with six store closures planned in their states. Tennessee, North Carolina and Minnesota are set to lose four stores each. The company said that it would close up to 120 stores to raise cash. The list of closures announced so far: Alabama (3): Sears in Mobile Kmart in Auburn and Gadsden. California (3): Sears in El Monte and San Diego (2).Colorado (3): Sears in Longmont Kmart in Broomfield and Glenwood Springs. Florida (11): Sears in Crystal River, Deland, Port St. Lucie, Stuart, West Palm Beach Kmart in Callaway, Fernandina Beach, New Smyrna Beach, Orange City, Pompano Beach and St. Augustine. Georgia (6): Sears in Macon Kmart in Atlanta, Buford, Columbus, Douglasville and Jonesboro. Idaho (1): Sears in Lewiston. Indiana (3): Sears in Anderson Kmart in Indianapolis and St. John. Iowa (2): Kmart in Cedar Rapids and Davenport. Kansas (1): Sears in Lawrence. Kentucky (3): Sears in Middleboro Kmart in Hazard and Winchester. Maryland (1): Sears in Ellicott City. Michigan (6): Sears in Adrian, Brighton, Chesterfield Township, Harper Woods, Monroe and Washington Township. Minnesota (4): Kmart in Duluth, New Hope, White Bear Lake and Willmar. Mississippi (3): Sears in Columbus, Jackson and McComb. Missouri (2): Sears in Lee's Summit and St. Louis. New Hampshire (2): Sears in Keene and Nashua. North Carolina (4): Sears in High Point, Morehead City, Rocky Mount and Statesville. Ohio (6): Kmart in Chagrin Falls, Columbus, Medina, Springfield and Toledo (2). Oregon (1): Sears in Roseburg. Pennsylvania (2): Sears in Pottstown and Upper Darby. South Carolina (1): Sears in Sumter. Tennessee (4): Sears in Antioch, Cleveland, Oak Ridge Kmart in Hendersonville. Virginia (3): Sears in Norfolk Kmart in Midlothian and Richmond. Washington (2): Sears in Walla Walla Kmart in Lacey. Wisconsin (2): Sears in West

Sears Holdings Corporation announced four Sears stores in North Carolina are closing as part of the company's move to shut down more than 100 stores nationwide. The company would close 100 to 120 Sears and Kmart stores across the country after holiday sales were weaker than the company expected. The company listed 79 of the stores it plans to close. The four Sears that will close in the state are in Statesville, High Point, Rocky Mount and Morehead City. No Kmarts were on the list. The company did not say how many employees would be affected, but a typical store employs between 40 and 80.

Sears Holdings Corporation announced that two Kmart stores in Toledo and two Sears stores in southeastern will be closed. The Kmart locations to be closed are on South Reynolds Road, near the former Southwyck Mall site, and on East Manhattan Blvd. The Sears stores are in Adrian and Monroe.

Sears Holdings Corp. plans to close two dozen more K-Mart stores in nine states between March and April following liquidation sales, including eight in Florida, according to Business Insider. A Kmart at 2211 W. Irlo Bronson Memorial Highway in Kissimmee will be shuttered. Others on the chopping block in the Sunshine State are in Crystal River, Sarasota, Port Charlotte, Fort Pierce, Jacksonville, Naples and Palatka, according to the report.

Sears Holdings Corporation will close Houston's The Great Indoors location on Old Katy Road on June 16, eliminating approximately 74 positions. The company will lay off employees during a two-week period starting June 16, a notice filed with the Texas Workforce Commission said. Employees affected by the closing will not have bumping rights, meaning that higher-ranked workers whose positions are eliminated cannot take lower-ranked jobs. It planned to close its nine remaining Great Indoors locations in Arizona, Illinois, Maryland, Michigan, Ohio and Texas. Another notice filed with the Texas Workforce Commission indicated The Great Indoors would lay off 80 people at the Dallas-area Farmers Branch location as of June 1.

Sears Holdings Corporation announced it will close its Kmart stores in Medina and Bainbridge Township in the first wave of what could eventually be 120 store closings nationwide. The company said that it would be closing Sears and Kmart stores in the wake of disappointing sales during the holiday shopping season, when some of its stores offered round-the-clock shopping. The company posted a list of 79 stores that included its Kmart stores at 1105 N. Court St. in Medina and at 17625 Chillicothe Road in Bainbridge Township, outside Chagrin Falls. Four other Ohio Kmarts are closing: one each in Columbus and Springfield and two in Toledo. Sears did not say how many people work at any of those stores. Sears Holdings of Hoffman Estates, Ill. could announce up to 41 more stores that will close in addition to those released.

Sears Holdings Corp. announced two Wisconsin locations are included on a partial list of stores that the company intends to close in the face of declining sales. A Sears Grand/Essentials store in West Baraboo is set to close, as is a Kmart store in Rice Lake. The company said that it would close 100 to 120 underperforming stores. Florida will be hit the hardest by the closing of Sears and Kmart stores, losing 11. Ohio, Michigan and Georgia have six store closures planned in their states. Tennessee, North Carolina and Minnesota are set to lose four stores each. The company said that each store employs 40 to 80 people. None of the closures announced so far are in Sears' home state of Illinois. The projected closings represent about 3% of the companys U.S. stores.

Sears is axing 115 jobs at its headquarters and other corporate support locations across the US in a bid to reduce expenses as the struggling retailer continues to post losses. Sears has confirmed 100 job cuts at its Hoffman Estates headquarters and 15 other positions at corporate support locations around the country. These job cuts will be spread across most of Sears 30 business units, from tools and appliances to the legal department. Eligible employees will receive outplacement services and severance.

Lockheed Martin announced it would put 3,000 workers on unpaid leave due to the government shutdown. The company said the number of employees furloughed was expected to increase weekly in the event of a prolonged shutdown.
