The furloughs include employees who are unable to work because the government facility where they perform their work is closed, or their work requires a government inspection that cannot be completed, or the company has received a stop-work order, the Bethesda, Maryland-based defense contractor said in a statement.

Lockheed Martin Corp. is laying off 145 workers in two upstate New York plants. The company notified 80 employees on November 6, 2013 at its Electronics Park plant in suburban Syracuse and another 65 at its facility in Owego. The layoffs are part of a nationwide cutback of 587 people. Most of the layoffs will be effective in two weeks. Affected employees will be offered undisclosed severance benefits and outplacement services. The company announced that in both instances the cuts were necessary to address unclear program funding, delays in contract awards and a competitive marketplace.

Lockheed Martin Corp. will announce plans to lay off about 500 people across its information systems and government services division, which it plans to sell or spin off later this year. The job cuts would be both voluntary and involuntary and should be completed by mid-November.
Lockheed Martin Corporation announced that its space-systems unit will lay off about 1,200 workers, or 7.5% of its work force, by end of year, citing pending closure of some major projects.

Lockheed Martin announced that it plans to close operations in Newtown, Pa.; Akron, Ohio; Goodyear, Ariz.; and Horizon City, Texas; and four buildings on its Sunnyvale, Calif., campus. The facility closures will result in the elimination of 2,000 positions. Current cost cutting measures should eliminate an additional 2,000 positions in the company's Information Systems & Global Solutions, Mission System and Training and Space Systems divisions by the end of 2014.

Lockheed Martin Corporation will offer voluntary buyouts to 6,500 corporate and enterprise business services employees in its latest move to reduce expenses. The buyouts are being offered to about 2,000 Lockheed employees in the Washington area, including 1,500 at the company's Bethesda headquarters. Eligible employees have until Aug. 1 to take the buyouts. Lockheed does not currently have a target number for layoffs, though based on past experience, it expects about 2% of eligible employees to take the buyouts. The voluntary layoff package includes two weeks pay, plus one week of pay per year of service, up to a maximum of 26 weeks. The latest round of cuts comes after Lockheed's aeronautics division announced a workforce reduction of up to 1,500 employees and its space systems division cut 1,200 jobs.

Lockheed Martin Corp. has warned the North Carolina Department of Commerce that it will lay off 74 people in Cumberland County. This is the third Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification for the county in the month.

Two Lowe's stores in the Inland Empire closed their doors permanently on November 7, 2010, leaving 181 people jobless. The two locations were at 4060 N. Hallmark Parkway in San Bernardino and 15000 Dale Evans Parkway in north Apple Valley. Ninety-one employees at the San Bernardino store and 90 in Apple Valley received notice of the closure on November 7, 2010. They were given 60 days pay and benefits. The only employees retained following the closure were the managers for both stores.

Lowe's Companies (LOW) is changing its store staffing model and will be laying off less than 1% of its workforce in the near future. The home improvement retailer will change roles for some staff and eliminate some jobs.

Lowe's Companies Inc. will close its Los Banos location in about four weeks and will lay off its 100 employees. The local store is one of 20 underperforming stores the corporation will close nationwide. The stores were determined to be 'not sufficiently profitable.' The 65 full-time and 35 part-time employees could be individually laid off anytime within 60 days. The employees were encouraged to seek openings at other locations. The closest store to the Los Banos location is more than 35 miles away in Merced. The Los Banos location opened the 117,000-square-foot building Nov. 4, 2006.

Lowe's Cos. Inc. plans to close all 99 Orchard Supply Hardware store locations nationwide by the end of this year after reassessing its company priorities. The company which also owns Lowe's Hardware Stores, chose to shutter the locations of its subsidiary in an effort to focus on the main Lowe's hardware store brand. The closures will affect locations at 111 South Orlando Ave. in Winter Park and 7603 Turkey Lake Road in Bay Hill, as well as a planned new facility under construction at Orlando Fashion Square mall that would have taken part of a former Sears location. Store closing sales for the San Jose, Calif.-based company will start Aug. 23 and operations will wind down until the end of the year. 4,300 total associates will be displaced by the closures. The Bayhill Plaza location, which opened Feb. 14, 2017, was the area's first Orchard Supply and has 45 employees. Employees will receive job placement help and there are opportunities for some to receive severance pay. Lowe's has accounted for $390 million to $475 million related to lease obligations and severance pay for employees in its estimates for next quarter.

Medtronic, Inc. plans to lay off 2,000 employees worldwide, including 70 in California, but the impact on its Sonoma County business unit was not clear. About half of the reductions will hit workers in the United States, and the other half affect workers abroad. The staff reductions primarily hit the company's cardiac and vascular group and its spine group.

CVS Health announced the drugstore chain and pharmacy benefits manager is laying off 150 people as part of an operational review. The company is eliminating the positions in December. Seventy of the job cuts are being made in Rhode Island, where the company is based.

CVS Health will permanently lay off about 117 workers at its distribution center in Medley. In a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) notice posted on February 17, 2016, the company said it will eliminate jobs at 9400 N.W. 104th St., due to the restructuring of its operations. CVS will begin the layoffs at the center April 22 and the last positions will be cut Sept. 29. Positions include drivers, inventory clerks, loaders, stock handlers and supervisors.

CVS Caremark Corporation announced that it will cut 400 jobs when it closes its Birmingham mail-order pharmacy Oct. 29, 2010. The pharmacy serves customers who choose not to go to a retail store or whose drug plan mandates automated postal refills, which the industry says saves money.

Nordstrom Inc. announced plans to close its University Mall store in Orem, Utah. Originally opened March 29, 2002, the 122,000-square foot store will close to the public at the end of business on February 24, 2012. The company will continue to operate at three nearby locations: a full-line store at Fashion Place Mall in Murray, Utah; the Sugar House Rack in Salt Lake City; and the Commons at South Towne Rack in Sandy, Utah. In addition, the company will be opening a new Nordstrom store at City Creek Center in Salt Lake City on March 22, 2012.

Nordstrom Inc. announced that it is planning to close Trunk Club fulfillment center located on Goose Island in Chicago, Illinois. With the closing, Trunk Club will integrate its operations into the Nordstrom network of fulfillment and distribution centers, located across the United States. The Goose Island facility will transition to its close by August 2017. The Goose Island closure will impact about 250 full- and part-time employees. Nordstrom will work to help employees interested in staying with the company find roles at the Trunk Club Chicago clubhouse or at nearby Nordstrom and Nordstrom Rack stores. Trunk Club is a clothing service based in Chicago and was acquired by Nordstrom in 2014.
Nordstrom is laying off 106 customer-care specialists: 30 in Seattle, 18 in Cedar Rapids, Iowa, and 58 who work from homes across the country.

Norfolk Southern Corp. planned to close its office building in Roanoke, relocating the functions handled there to Atlanta or Norfolk. The move affects about 500 employees currently working in marketing, accounting, information technology and other departments. Norfolk Southern said they will have the option to relocate with their positions. Roanoke is the headquarters for Norfolk Southerns Virginia Division. The company said it will continue operating a local switching yard and locomotive and car maintenance facilities at Shaffers Crossing and a locomotive overhaul and rebuilding facility in its East End Shops. About 1,700 people now work for Norfolk Southern in Roanoke.

Norfolk Southern announced that it plans to reduce headcount by 2,000 employees by 2020 and decrease overtime by 50% from 2015 levels. It also plans to reduce employee levels in areas affected by lower coal traffic and by the rightsizing of the company's coal infrastructure.

PG&E filed its proposal to close Diablo Canyon nuclear power plant by 2025 with the California Public Utilities Commission. The submittal now begins a formal review process before the state agency that will include the participation of the County of San Luis Obispo and the San Luis Coastal Unified School District. No schedule for the agency's review has been set, however PG&E is asking that the proceedings conclude by June 2017. The schedule could include one or more public hearings that could be held in either San Luis Obispo or San Francisco, where the agency is headquartered. On June 21, PG&E along with a coalition of labor and environmental groups proposed a joint plan to close Diablo Canyon when the plant's two federally issued operating licenses expire in 2025. The groups said the eight- to nine-year transition period will give PG&E time to replace Diablo Canyon's energy with new greenhouse gas-free electrical generation. The utility has also promised to provide incentives to retain employees during the remainder of the plant's operation as well as retention and retraining of a percentage of the employees for the decommissioning of the plant.

PG&E Corp. announced that it will get rid of eight corporate officers, 390 staff members and 800 contractors. The changes come as PG&E prepares to operate under Geisha Williams, who will take the reins as CEO March 1, 2016. Senior executives covering finance, legal and regulatory affairs, human resources, ethics and environmental matters will report directly to Williams. Executives in charge of electricity and gas operations, nuclear power, information technology and customer care will report to Nick Stavropoulos, the head of gas operations who will become chief operating officer on March 1, 2017. The company has chosen one of its other top natural gas executives, John Higgins, to be vice president of safety and health for the entire utility, reporting to Stavropoulos.
Rockwell Automation Inc. announced that to cut jobs in some locations and functions while adding jobs in other areas as part of $13 million in restructuring charges.

Sbarro Inc. will close 155 locations as the company works to overhaul its financial performance. The closings will not impact the 175 Sbarro franchisees. Most of the closings will occur in mall food courts, which have been squeezed by a sharp reduction in consumer spending since the depths of the recession.
Schlumberger is cutting more than 21,000 jobs as the global coronavirus pandemic quashes demand for energy and oil prices are routed. The company will pay more than $1 billion in severance benefits.

Sonoco Products Co. announced that it will close its Orrville, Ohio, rigid paper packaging plant by March 2010. The Orrville operation, located at 425 Collins Blvd., currently employs 84 employees and manufactures fiber cartridges for adhesives and sealants. The first phase of the plant's shutdown is expected to begin in late November and result in the reduction of approximately half the workforce. The plant will remain in partial operation until it is closed in March 2010. Sonoco will provide severance and outplacement assistance to employees.

Sonoco Products Co. announced that it will close its Orrville, Ohio, rigid paper packaging plant by March 2010. The Orrville operation, located at 425 Collins Blvd., currently employs 84 employees and manufactures fiber cartridges for adhesives and sealants. Sonoco acquired the plant in 2007 when it acquired the fiber containers and industrial plastic carriers assets of Caraustar Industries Inc. The first phase of the plant's shutdown is expected to begin in late November 2009 and result in the reduction of approximately half the workforce. The plant will remain in partial operation until it is closed in March 2010. Sonoco will provide severance and outplacement assistance to employees.

Sonoco Products Co. announced its intention to enter into consultation with the workforce regarding the potential closure of the Carrickmacross facility in November 2013. The plant makes thermoformed packages for a range of food processors primarily in Ireland and other parts of Europe. The company reported that the business had been experiencing a loss of volume and profitability over the past several years and this pattern is continuing through 2013, leaving no viable option other than to consider closure of the facility. In the event the plant does shut down, Sonoco does not expect the first reduction in jobs to occur until October 2013. After that time, the company's plan would be to gradually scale back operations, targeting a plant closure on November 1, 2013. Until and if that time comes, operations will continue as normal. Sonoco anticipates that up to 49 positions may become redundant if closure is determined to be the final decision. The company will consult with employee representatives from its Employee Forum to try and find ways to avoid the needs for redundancies, to reduce the number of employees affected and to mitigate the consequences of redundancies for employees. The company will be considering alternatives such as retirement, voluntary redundancies and possible redeployment to other Sonoco operations.

Supervalu Inc. announced that it is closing 20 underperforming grocery stores nationwide, while the struggling supermarket chain hopes to save money by allowing some employees to take unpaid vacation. The company will close 20 unprofitable stores in chains primarily centered on the East and West coasts. Supervalu's Cub Foods, the Twin Cities' largest grocery chain, is not affected by the closures.

SUPERVALU Inc. announced that the Genuardi's on Route 73 in Evesham will be out of business in the near future. The company announced that the store's employees would be offered positions at other Acmes in the area.

SUPERVALU Inc. announced plans for a streamlined independent business organization. As part of the new structure, SUPERVALU's independent business will consolidate from three regions to two regions, forming new East and West teams. The new East and West independent business regions will be located in Mechanicsville, VA and Hopkins, MN. With this new independent business organization, SUPERVALU will streamline the organization and reduce operating costs while continuing to drive sales growth with its current and prospective customers.The company also announced that to lead the new organizations, it has named Kevin Kemp president of the East region and Bill Chew president of the West region. The company anticipates reducing its employee workforce by approximately 200 positions throughout its independent business regional teams. Impacted employees will have an opportunity to apply for open positions within the new organization. The company expects to fill approximately 120 new independent business jobs resulting in a net workforce reduction in its independent business organization as a result of this consolidation of approximately 80 positions.

SUPERVALU Inc. announced that it will eliminate 1,100 corporate positions nationwide - about 600 of them in Minnesota. The cuts follow the Eden Prairie-based company's sale of five of its regional supermarket chains to a group of investors headed by Cerberus Capital Management. The deal left Supervalu at about half its original size, reducing its need for support staff at its corporate offices adding that some reductions would have been necessary regardless of whether the sale went through. The cuts represent about 3% of Supervalu's total workforce of 35,000, but they will not affect the company's roughly 18,000 in-store employees, Siemienas said, adding that most of the 600 jobs cut in Minnesota will be at Supervalu's Eden Prairie headquarters and its Cub Foods support center in Stillwater. The company employs a total of about 8,700 people in the state. The affected employees will be notified by March 27, 2013.

Chiquita Brands International, which in January announced plans to close its Charlotte headquarters, it laid off 300 workers in Latin America and saw its losses more than double in the first quarter, months after finalizing an acquisition by two Brazilian companies.

UPS plans to shut down a West Columbia billing center that employs 110 workers, primarily because of evolving technology. The center, located at 100 Enterprise Lane at Columbia Metropolitan Airport, has operated since 1996, performing financial and accounting functions.

Sprint Nextel Corp. announced that it plans to trim jobs 'in the dozens' from its wholesale division amid slowing business. The nation's third-largest wireless provider confirmed that it has begun notifying employees in the division of layoffs.
Sprint has eliminated more than 80 vice presidents, directors and managers at its Overland Park headquarters.

Sprint Corp. has given layoff notices to 829 employees at its Overland Park campus in the past 90 days. Substantial job cuts have been expected since early October when Sprint announced a $2.5 billion cost-cutting plan. The number of layoffs in operations outside the Kansas City area still hasn't been disclosed.

Sprint Corp. will lay off an undetermined number of its workers as part of a cost-cutting program. The company began drawing up layoff plans last week. The company's managers are still reviewing how many jobs they will need to cut. More details could emerge when Sprint Corp. reports its fourth-quarter earnings on Feb. 11. The purge is expected to be completed by the end of June.
Sprint Corp. has laid off roughly 50 customer care employees in the company's headquarters city of Overland Park.
Sprint has cut 247 jobs in the Denver area as part of a downsizing in which the telecom axed several hundred positions around country.

Worthington Industries Inc. plans to close the 160,000-square-foot facility at 8911 Kelso Drive in Essex by the end of its current fiscal year, which ends May 31. The Essex facility is about 13 miles from the defunct Sparrows Point steel-making complex. Employees at the Worthington plant will have the opportunity to apply for job openings at other Worthington facilities. Severance and outplacement services will be provided to employees who will not continue with the company. In 2011, Worthington closed a metal framing plant on Bethlehem Boulevard in Edgemere. The closure resulted in 59 job cuts.

Worthington Industries Inc. is combining its struggling metal framing unit with an Ohio company in a joint venture that will mean a new majority owner for the unit and several plant closures. The new venture will be composed of 13 plants, meaning Worthington will close seven of Dietrich's 13 sites over a three- to six-month period. Two Dietrich sites in Warren are among six that will be part of the new venture. ClarkWestern is closing down one site under the deal.

Worthington Industries is laying off almost half of its workers in Skiatook. The company in Skiatook employs about 100 workers and the company cut 40 jobs. The company also said it reduced its workforce at its oil and gas equipment locations in Garden City, Kansas, and in Bremen and Wooster, Ohio, impacting approximately 205 employees.

Despite higher sales and profits at most of its company lines, Astec Industries Inc. announced that it will close its facility in Loudon, Tenn., on May 31 and consolidate all of its GEFCO operations in Enid, Okla., due to the decline in oil exploration activity. The move will cut 75 jobs. The company will take a $1 million charge for the closing the 360,000-square-foot plant in the second quarter. The main products made in Loudon are oil drill rigs and pump trailers.
Zoetis planned to dismiss at least 20% of its workers, shut 10 plants and drop some of its product lines as part of plans to cut $300 million in costs.

Polaris Industries, Inc. has informed state of Wisconsin officials that it will begin the layoff of nearly 500 employees from its plants in Osceola on March 1, 2011. The company announced last May that it was exiting the Polk County operations in Osceola under a realignment of manufacturing operations that includes establishing a plant in Mexico and upgrades at factories in Roseau, Minn., and Spirit Lake, Iowa. The company said the first of the job separations in Osceola will begin March 1, and will end with the permanent closure of the plant. The company has 484 employees in Osceola.

Polaris Industries Inc. will close its manufacturing plant in Milford, Iowa, by the end of 2017, putting roughly 300 people out of a job. The plant, which opened in 2013, is the company's third-largest manufacturing facility at 460,000 square feet. It employs approximately 330 people, but some will be placed in positions at the company's plant in Spirit Lake, Iowa, or other facilities. The Milford plant is going to be turned into a storage facility to support the Spirit Lake facility, the site of production for Indian motorcycle products. The product transitions will take effect in phases between now and the end of 2017.The company is also transferring metal fabrication operations - and 40 employees - from its facility in Riverside, Calif. to its Transamerican Auto Parts facility in Chula Vista, Calif. for production of its Pro Armor aftermarket products.

Dell Inc. announced that it will close its desktop computer manufacturing plant near Winston-Salem by the end of January 2010, shedding 905 workers. The company announced that it was part of an effort to simplify operations and improve efficiency, while retaining U.S. plants in Miami, Fla.; Nashville, Tenn.; and Austin, Texas. The company had announced a drive to save $4 billion a year by 2011.

Dell Inc. is closing its Twin Falls, Idaho, customer support call center by January 2010, eliminating 500 jobs. The center opened eight years ago after millions of dollars in enticements from local and state government. The company said that about 125 employees will be offered jobs at call centers in Texas and Oklahoma or with the company's work-from-home program.

Dell Inc. shut down the production lines at its Winston-Salem plant, ending a six-year run that started with great fanfare but ultimately failed to reach its economic potential. Any further activity at the 750,000-square-foot plant would be 'part of the exiting and shut-down work required'. Dell chose not to assemble laptops here because it's less expensive to build them overseas. Production of servers - a computer system that provides essential services across a network - never materialized as hoped.

Dell Inc. announced that it is cutting jobs in the Austin area but declined to say how many workers were affected. The company described that the job cut as 'a relatively small percentage of its work force'.

Dell Inc. confirmed that it is making another round of jobs cuts at several locations this week, including its local operations. The company isn't disclosing specifics such as the number of layoffs or the exact facilities affected by the job cuts. The job cuts as part of an ongoing strategy to reduce operating costs.

About 1,000 employees at Dell face losing their jobs as the computer maker plans to shut down its call centre in Mohali, India. The US-based company is steadily eliminating employees including senior technologists, strategists, developers, and sales employees, as well as a vice-president.

Dell Inc. plant in Winston-Salem plans to lay off 55 workers, as the factory's closure has wider repercussions to the state's economy. Dell is shutting down its facility in January and laying off 900 workers. State and local officials have formed a task force to find a replacement tenant for the massive factory. But this it will eliminate 55 employees who are part of a service contract with Dell.

Devon Energy will close its office in the north Houston suburb of Spring later 2016. The closure will result in about 60 job losses, while some employees will move to the company's corporate headquarters in Oklahoma City. Cuts are expected to be made by the middle of 2016 and come as the company plans to slash 1,000 jobs nationwide. Devon Energy used the Spring office to operate its Eagle Ford Shale assets. The Spring office was launched about a year after the company announced that it would close its downtown offices as part of its Oklahoma City consolidation plan.
Devon Energy Corp. announced it laid off some employees. The company did not detail how many employees lost their jobs or which department was affected by the changes.
Devon Energy Corporation has announced that it will close its Lafayette office in September 2010 following the company's sale of its Gulf of Mexico petroleum properties.

Devon Energy announced it has cut 15% of its Canadian workforce as the company responds to lower capital spending plans. The company announced the staff reductions, completed by October 28, 2015, mean about 200 employees have been let go in all areas of the company's Canadian operations, including its Calgary offices and northern Alberta field operations. The company said that it has significantly reduced capital spending in Canada after completing some major projects such as its Jackfish heavy oil facility.

As part of back office consolidation after its $1.8 billion acquisition, BB&T Corp. announced that it has laid off 241 employees from National Penn Bancshares. The bank said it had notified the affected employees, most of who work back office operations such as finance, marketing and information technology. It said 87 jobs were affected in Allentown and 154 in Boyertown. BB&T said employees who stay through their 60-day notice period will receive severance benefits and career transition services. It also said it will continue to work during and after the National Penn conversion to help affected associates find positions either inside or outside the company. It cut 89 jobs from Susquehanna's main office in Lititz, Lancaster County and then said it would slice 140 more from a loan processing center in Hagerstown, Md. Those cuts, however, do not include those transferred to new positions, some of which paid less money. The dual acquisitions of Susquehanna and National Penn within months of one another have caused some disruption in the local banking sector. Competitors have capitalized on that by snapping up affected executives from the two sellers as well as groups of lenders that decided to switch firms.

Kindred Hospital Modesto, Modesto plans to close its doors early next year after efforts to sell the skilled-nursing facility were unsuccessful. The closure will result in job losses for 127 employees, including registered nurses, vocational nurses, nursing assistants and office personnel.

Kindred Healthcare Inc. will be closing its 45-bed Waltham hospital, the second Massachusetts facility it has shuttered in just over three years. It also said some employees of the Waltham hospital may be offered jobs at other Kindred facilities.

Opus Bank in Irvine, Calif., has reshuffled its mix of branch office locations, as it enters Arizona and expands in the greater Los Angeles and Seattle areas. The company plans to open six offices early 2013, two each in Arizona, California and Washington state. The new offices are planned for Paradise Valley and Scottsdale, Ariz.; San Rafael and Rancho Santa Margarita, Calif.; and Seattle and Tacoma, Wash.Opus is also in the process of closing eight branches, some of which were recently acquired, and all of which are located within two miles of another Opus Bank branch.

O'Charley's Inc. announced that it has closed 11 underperforming O'Charley's restaurants and five underperforming Ninety Nine restaurants. These closings permit company to focus energy and efforts on improving the performance of remaining 339 company-operated restaurants in 25 states. Eight of the 16 closed restaurants will be treated as discontinued operations in the company's financial statements.

Jones Apparel Group, Inc. announced unaudited consolidated earnings results for the first quarter ended April 3, 2010. Revenues for the first quarter of 2010 exceeded expectations and were $887 million, as compared with $891 million for the first quarter of 2009. Income available to common stockholders of the company was $37.5 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared to $0.3 million or $0.00 per diluted share for the same period last year. For the quarter, the company has reported income from operations of $76.3 million and income before provision for income taxes of $62.5 million on net sales of $876.1 million compared to income from operations of $13.7 million and income before provision for income taxes of $0.5 million on net sales of $879.4 million reported in the same period last year. The 2010 first quarter results include, among other items, costs and charges of approximately $3 million ($2 million after tax) related to the acquisition of Robert Rodriguez and other restructuring and strategic review costs. In the prior year quarter, results included, among other items, non-cash retail store asset impairment charges of approximately $21 million ($14 million after tax) related to the closure of company-operated stores and charges of $14 million ($9 million after tax) related to other cost savings initiatives. Adjusted income before provision for income taxes was $65.0 million against $36.0 million reported last year. Adjusted income available to common stockholders was $39.0 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared to $22.9 million or $0.00 per diluted share reported last year. Results for both periods exclude the impact of severance and other expenses related to the planned closure of certain company-operated retail stores, and certain other charges. Net cash used in operating activities were $86.2 million against $139.3 million and capital expenditures were $8.7 million against $8.3 million reported last year. The year-over-year improvement in cash used by operations of $53 million is primarily du

On June 10, 2010, Progress Software Corp. announced that it is restructuring its product organization as well as other functions to better optimize operations and to improve productivity and efficiency. As a result, the company expects to reduce its global workforce by approximately 140 to 160 positions, which is approximately 7 to 9% of its global workforce. The Company expects to complete most of these workforce reductions during its third fiscal quarter ending August 31, 2010, depending upon local legal requirements. These workforce reductions will occur in substantially all functional units and across all geographies in which the company operates. As a result of these workforce reductions and office consolidations, the company currently expects to incur in the aggregate a pre-tax charge in the range of approximately $11 million to $16 million. The estimated aggregate charge consists of approximately $8 million to $12 million relating to the companys global workforce reduction, consisting primarily of severance and post-employment benefits, and approximately $3 million to $4 million relating to its office consolidations. The company currently expects to record this charge primarily in its 2010 third fiscal quarter. In connection with these initiatives, the company expects to incur future pre-tax restructuring charges of between approximately $9 million to $13 million during the fourth quarter of 2010 and the full 2011 fiscal year, primarily comprising costs for severance and consolidation of facilities. Additionally, the company expects to incur additional non-recurring, pre-tax transition costs of approximately $8 million to $13 million over the next eighteen month period commencing with the companys 2010 third fiscal quarter. The company expects to meet or exceed its fiscal second quarter fiscal 2010 earnings per share guidance and be slightly below revenue guidance as provided in its first quarter earnings release.
Time Warner Inc. is preparing to make a new round of job cuts. The cuts come as the Time Warner Inc. publishing unit slashes costs in response to a slump in advertising.

Warner Media announced it was shutting down FilmStruck, the classic-films service that had garnered a hardcore following in its two years of existence. FilmStruck was launched in November 2016 as an initiative of Turner Classic Movies. The idea was not only to aggregate a wide range of films from vaunted libraries including the Criterion Collection and Janus Films ("Spartacus," "8/12," "The 39 Steps" and modern classics such as "Mullholland Drive" were available), but also to provide a curated experience of commentary and recommendations.

Starbucks Corp. has closed 19 licensed stores at Stop & Shop and Giant locations in the Northeast and Mid-Atlantic. The company announced that these stores were not performing at levels that would allow them to continue operating.

Starbucks will close all 23 of its San Francisco Bay area La Boulange bakery-cafes, saying the stores weren't sustainable (for its) long-term growth. Starbucks bought Bay Bread and the La Boulange brand in 2012 for $100 million. It was seen as a move to gain a bigger presence in the food business, particularly as chains like McDonald's improved their coffee offerings. The company would close the cafes and the two manufacturing facilities that serve them by the end of September, and will keep selling La Boulange food in Starbucks. It's also closing the Evolution Fresh retail location in San Francisco.

Starbucks Corporation will introduce new support structure at its head office in London for its Europe, Middle East and Africa (EMEA) operations to better serve an increasingly-licensed regional strategy. It will also close its support center in Amsterdam while leaving the coffee roasting facility in the Netherlands open. Starbucks plans to lay off nearly all of its 190 workers at the Amsterdam support center.

Starbucks Corporation is closing its doors in Ely. The company has had a branch in Ely's High Street for around seven years but the store is set to shut as it is not making enough profit. The business is expected to close its doors later September 2012 or at the beginning of October, 2012.

Starbucks Coffee has opened in a strip center at 5234 14th St. W., at 14th Street and 53rd Avenue West. Hours are 5:30 a.m. to 10 p.m. seven days a week. The location offers coffee, tea, prepared foods, pastries and has a drive-thru. Another Starbucks drive-thru is under construction on University Parkway west of Tuttle Avenue at 3604 84th Ave. Circle E. It is expected to open by the end of 2014.At the same time, Starbucks closed its shop at Cortez Road and 14th Street West as part of the move.
Starbucks Corporation plans to close an unspecified number of its unprofitable stores in Europe. The stores will be shut over the rest of the year.

McAfee is laying off 107 employees at its Hillsboro office Terminations are expected to occur Dec. 31, according to the filing under the Worker Retraining Notification Act of 1988. Roles affected by this layoff include software engineers, project managers and senior engineers.

Trident Microsystems, Inc. announced a key step in its turnaround efforts that will lower its breakeven point through a realignment of its workforce, from approximately 1,275 employees worldwide to approximately 1,000 employees by early 2012. According to the company, headcount will be reduced in all functional areas. As a result of the reductions in labor and other cost saving initiatives, by the first quarter of 2012 the company expects to realize annual operating expense savings of approximately $40 million to $48 million compared with the annualized run rate as of the second quarter of 2011 and to reduce its EBITDA breakeven level to approximately $340 million to $360 million in annual revenues.

AdvanSix Inc. on May 2, 2019 approved the closure of its Pottsville, Pennsylvania films plant as part of its broader strategic efforts associated with the films product line in North America to improve the Companys competitive position in providing quality products and services for its customers. The Company has also announced a strategic alliance with a third-party producer of films for the flexible packaging industry, combining the Companys channel to North America with their new manufacturing facility. The Company expects the closure to be completed during the third quarter of 2019.
PetSmart, Inc. is planning some layoffs at its corporate office. The company announced that it would cut less than 5% off its corporate workforce.

TriQuint Semiconductor, Inc. announced that it would lay off 70 workers in Florida after the company developed a less labor-intensive way to package its filter technology inside mobile phones. The company manufacturers its filters at plants in Costa Rica and the metro Orlando city of Apopka, Fla., where it will lay off 70 of its 375 workers.

Albemarle Corp. will lay off 230 workers worldwide, including somewhat less than 100 in Baton Rouge, as part of the company's restructuring to place more emphasis on research and development. But the company said it plans to add nearly 100 positions in Baton Rouge in fields such as sales and R&D. The layoffs will chop between $30 million and $35 million pre-tax from the specialty chemical maker's fourth-quarter earnings. Albemarle expects to complete the job cuts by the end of March 2013.

ITT Educational Services Inc. announced it was shutting down ITT Technical Institute following the U.S. Department of Education's decision to prevent the parent company from enrolling students who use federal financial aid. Previously, students enrolled at the for-profit ITT Tech who have not begun classes were not allowed to use federal aid, as of the Education Department's Aug. 25 ruling. Students who were already enrolled could have used federal aid as long as ITT Tech remains open but the school will cease operations immediately.

Cameron International said earlier this week in a letter to the state that it would cut approximately 56 workers at the Millbury plant. In the letter, the company said it had determined there was excess capacity within its manufacturing business and decided to make cuts to the local plant. The company said it would substantially reduce operations at the plant and move production to another facility.

Cameron International Corporation is permanently closing a manufacturing facility in Montgomery County and will begin terminating the facility's employees around July 15. The company announced in Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification Act paperwork filed with the Texas government that about 88 employees will be affected by the closure of the facility in Magnolia, west of the Woodlands. None of the employees are represented by a union, and Cameron announced that it does not have a provision to transfer, bump or reassign affected employees. However, the affected employees can apply for other open positions at Cameron.
RadiSys Corporation plans to send its remaining Oregon manufacturing to Asia by the middle of next year, cutting 80 jobs.

DaVita Inc. is laying off 109 employees at a prescription-drug distribution facility in Orlando. The layoffs come after a sale involving its DaVita Rx prescription-drug unit to pharmacy retailer Walgreens, spokesman Skip. The cuts impact workers at the facility at 2252 Commerce Park Drive in Orlando, where employees packaged prescription pharmaceuticals to be distributed to patients undergoing dialysis treatments. Employees will be let go between September 23, 2018 and December 3, 2018.

Henry Schein Inc. announced that it will trim 2% to 3% from its global workforce of about 17,000. The company said that the restructuring, part of the 2015-2017 strategic plan, would free capital to invest in new markets, such as South Africa and Brazil, and businesses like software and preventive care for the world's growing middle class.

Century Aluminum Company announced that it intends to permanently close its Ravenswood, W.V. aluminum smelter, effective immediately. The Ravenswood smelter has been idled since February 2009. The decision to permanently close the Ravenswood plant is based on the inability to secure a competitive power contract for the smelter, compounded by challenging aluminum market conditions largely driven by increased exports of aluminum from China. As a result, the economics of restarting and operating the facility are unfavorable.
Yahoo! Inc. announced the firing of around 500 employees, who were under performing.

Yahoo is planning to eliminate jobs as part of chief executive officer Marissa Mayer's effort to cut costs and revive growth at the struggling web portal. The plan will help the company streamline operations. The layoffs, which would result in more than 1,000 people leaving the tech giant, are set to affect Yahoo's media business, European operations and platforms-technology group.
Yahoo! Inc. would cut some 600 jobs, or about 4% of its global workforce, in the third wave of layoffs at the company since late 2008.
Yahoo! Inc. planned to close 50 properties that aren't contributing to the company's engagement and revenue.

Sykes Enterprises, Incorporated announced that during the fourth quarter of 2010, consistent with the long-term goals to manage and optimize capacity utilization, the company decided to close a customer contact management center in the United Kingdom and a customer contact management center in Ireland, both components of the EMEA segment, and decided to close a customer contact management center in Argentina, a component of the Americas?segment (Plan). These actions were in response to the facilities consolidation and capacity rationalization related to the ICT Group Inc. acquisition in February 2010 enabling the company to reduce operating costs by eliminating redundant space and to optimize capacity utilization rates where overlap exists. The plan was approved by the Finance Committee of the Board of Directors of the company on November 30, 2010.In connection with the Plan the company recorded non-cash impairment charges of $0.5 million in the fourth quarter of 2010.

One day after Valeant Pharmaceuticals International closed its acquisition of Salix Pharmaceuticals, the company announced it would lay off 258 workers in North Carolina. The Salix layoffs will impact a wide range of job functions; workers have been notified and layoffs began and will continue through Oct. 30, 2015.

Endo International plc announced that after completing a comprehensive review of its manufacturing network, the company will be ceasing operations and closing its manufacturing and distribution facilities in Huntsville, Alabama. The closure of the facilities is expected to take place over the next 12 to 18 months. The Huntsville location has been impacted by declining volumes of commoditized products and these restructuring actions are intended to better match manufacturing capacity to projected future demand. These restructuring actions are expected to reduce Endo's workforce by approximately 875 positions (including approximately 35 open positions) and to result in pre-tax restructuring charges of approximately $325 million, including approximately $60 million of cash charges.

Covance Inc. announced that it plans to close a $150 million laboratory it opened in Chandler in 2009 amid protests from animal rights activists. A few dozen employees worked at the lab when it opened early in 2009, with a long-term goal of nearly 2,000 jobs. The company didn't say in its filing how many workers may lose their jobs when the lab closes.

Corrections Corp. of America announced its intention to cease operations at the CCA-owned and operated Prairie Correctional Facility located in Appleton, Minnesota. The 1,600-bed facility will officially cease operations on or about February 1, 2010. During 2009, the Prairie facility has housed offenders from the states of Minnesota and Washington. However, due to excess capacity in the states' systems, both states have been reducing the populations held at Prairie. The facility currently houses about 200 offenders from the state of Minnesota. The state of Washington has removed all of its offenders from the Prairie facility, but maintains a population of approximately 125 inmates in two CCA-owned facilities in Arizona. The closure of the Prairie facility is not expected to have a material impact on CCA's financial results.

First Niagara Financial Group in Buffalo, N.Y., is laying off employees and shutting down branches as it seeks to retool its retail operations. The company plans to eliminate 170 administrative employees across its branch network. The company plans to centralize administrative functions and devote more of its branch jobs to ones that directly serve customers. It will invite the laid-off workers to apply for other positions in the company. In addition, the company plans to close 10 branches in New York and Pennsylvania in the first quarter, as part of a consolidation of branches it acquired from HSBC in 2012.

L-3 Communication Systems-West laid off about 220 workers as it adjusts to automatic federal budget cuts and downward trends in defense spending. The layoffs, about 5.5% of its workforce, add to some 200 people who accepted buyouts from the company last month, as well as 190 Utah employees who were laid off in April. The latest layoffs primarily affect the company's engineering organization.

WebMD Health Corp. announced a comprehensive program to streamline its operations, reduce costs and better focus its resources on increasing user engagement, improving customer satisfaction and driving innovation. WebMD expects these actions to result in a reduction in annualized operating expenditures of approximately $45 million, including the impact of a workforce reduction of approximately 250 positions, or roughly 14% of the company's employees. While most of the workforce reductions will be effective at the end of this year, other cost savings actions will be implemented over the course of the first quarter of 2013.

P.F. Chang's China Bistro, Inc. closed its Pearl District outlet because its lease expired. The company made a business decision not to renew in the Brewery Blocks at Northwest 12th and Couch streets. The restaurant's 51 employees were given the opportunity to work at its locations at Tanasbourne in Hillsboro and Bridgeport Village in Tigard. Thirty three opted to transfer.

Efforts to reach a fair labor agreement between UAW workers and American Axle & Manufacturing Holdings Inc. have been thwarted by the company's unwillingness to negotiate a fair labor agreement with a livable wage for 66 workers at the company's Cheektowaga gear-making plant here. Negotiations broke down July 31 when UAW Local 846 members voted 98% in favor of rejecting what American Axle said was its "last best and final proposal." During contract talks, American Axle demanded more money and benefits from workers, who have already taken concessions but were willing to negotiate a contract that helps keep jobs in the community.The company has announced plans to close its Detroit plant in February 2012. As plants in U.S. communities have been shuttered, the company has increasingly shifted its production to other countries.

Juniper Networks Inc. announced that it expects to reduce its global workforce by about 6% and consolidate its facilities, as part of efforts to streamline its business structure and focus on high-growth segments under the company's integrated operating plan. In late February, Juniper Networks came out with an integrated operating plan or IOP to refocus on key innovations as demand for High-IQ Networks and best-in-class cloud environments gain momentum.

Krispy Kreme will permanently close its only Dayton-area doughnut shop at 2001 E. Dorothy Lane in Kettering effective January 31. The store's 20 employees will receive additional pay and the possibility of transferring to another Krispy Kreme location. The closing comes as the company itself is finishing up what appears to be a relatively successful year.

Peet's Coffee & Tea has closed its downtown Baltimore store as it shifts its focus to growth markets, including Greater Washington, D.C. The Baltimore closing at 1 N. Charles St. comes less than a year after the coffee shop rebranded to Peet's from Caribou Coffee. The company is also closing stores in Pennsylvania, Ohio and Michigan. Peet's is also closing two stores in Alexandria, Va., and Bristow, Va.

FairPoint Communications announced that the company laid off 229 employees effective July 29, bringing its total employment down to 2,931 from 3,160 one year ago. It had planned to lay off 260 employees total, with 79 of those positions in Maine.

FairPoint Communications, Inc. announced workforce restructuring actions that will result in a reduction of approximately 260 positions across the 17 states in which it operates, including the closing of its call center in South Burlington, Vermont. This action, combined with other headcount reductions over the past two years, approximates the level of voice line loss the company has experienced in that period.

On November 17, 2016, FairPoint Communications announced plans to lay off 110 employees from Maine, New Hampshire and Vermont. The layoffs as "workforce restructuring" required after a loss in revenue in a letter to employees.

Kirkland's Inc. reported unaudited consolidated financial results for the fourth quarter and full year ended February 1, 2014. Net sales for the 13 weeks ended February 1, 2014, decreased 4.2% to $156.1 million compared with $162.9 million for the 14 weeks ended February 2, 2013. On a 13-week basis, comparable store sales for the fourth quarter of fiscal 2013, including e-commerce sales, were flat compared with a decrease of 2.6% in the prior-year quarter. The company reported net income of $12.3 million, or $0.69 per diluted share, for the 13 weeks ended February 1, 2014, compared with net income of $14.3 million, or $0.82 per diluted share, for the 14 weeks ended February 2, 2013. Operating income was $20,536,000 against $23,056,000 for the same period of last year. Income before income taxes was $20,540,000 against $23,060,000 for the same period of last year.Net sales for the 52 weeks ended February 1, 2014, increased 2.7% to $460.6 million compared with $448.4 million for the 53 weeks ended February 2, 2013. On a 52-week basis, comparable store sales for fiscal 2013, including e-commerce sales, increased 0.5% compared with a 3.0% decrease in fiscal 2012. For the 52 weeks ended February 1, 2014, the company reported net income of $14.5 million, or $0.82 per diluted share, compared with net income of $13.8 million, or $0.77 per diluted share, for the 53 weeks ended February 2, 2013. Operating income was $23,992,000 against $21,528,000 for the same period of last year. Income before income taxes was $23,959,000 against $21,494,000 for the same period of last year. Net cash provided by operating activities was $39,213,000 against $32,347,000 for the same period of last year.For the 52-week period ending January 31, 2015, the company expects to achieve approximately 10% square footage growth with 35 to 40 new store openings and 10 to 15 store closings. New store openings will be weighted more toward the second half of the year, and store closings will be weighted more toward the first half of the year. Total s
Kirkland's Inc. announced that it intends to close its Hixson location. The store at Oak Park Town Center is offering up to 30% off store items to clear out excess inventory.

Kirkland's, Inc. reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the thirteen weeks and thirty nine weeks ended November 3, 2018. For the thirteen weeks, the company reported net sales of $154,571,000 against $144,979,000 a year ago. Operating loss was $3,618,000 against $3,767,000 a year ago. Net loss was $2,780,000 or $0.18 per basic share against $2,362,000 or $0.15 per basic share a year ago. For the thirty nine weeks, the company reported net sales of $430,924,000 against $409,503,000 a year ago. Operating loss was $14,199,000 against $11,741,000 a year ago. Net loss was $10,377,000 or $0.66 per basic share against $7,569,000 or $0.48 per basic share a year ago.The company provided earnings guidance for the fifty two weeks ending February 2, 2019. The company expects total sales for fiscal 2018 to increase 3% to 4% compared with fiscal 2017. This level of sales performance implies flat to modest growth in comparable store sales. The company expects fiscal 2018 diluted earnings per share to be in the range of $0.50 to $0.60, excluding costs in the second half related to the hiring of a new CEO. The full year earnings projection assumes a tax rate of approximately 30%.The company expects to achieve approximately 3% to 4% square footage growth with 25 new store openings and 13 to 15 store closings.
Google's Motorola started manufacturing the Moto X domestically at a plant in Texas, the factory is shutting down; it will cease operations at some point later this year.

Google Inc. is shutting down certain services as part of an ongoing spring cleaning initiative that began in 2011. GUI Builder and five UiApp widgets for Apps Script are being axed, while CalDAV API will become available for white-listed developers but will be shut down for other developers Sept. 16. Other services that will be retired 2013 are Google Building Maker, Google Cloud Connect, Google Reader, the Google Voice App for Blackberry, Search API for Shopping and updates for Snapseed Desktop for Macintosh and Microsoft Corp.'s Windows.

Google Inc. announced that it will shut down Postini services at the end of 2013 and migrate Postini customers to Google Apps. Starting September 20, Retarus is offering Google/Postini customers a free, automated and secure switchover to their Managed E-Mail Services. Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services fulfill all business requirements, including those concerning data security, data protection and legal compliance. Furthermore, Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services clearly surpass Postini's mail service standards. Five years after Google took over Postini services, the company has now announced that it will discontinue them at the end of 2013 and no contract renewals will be accepted after October 31, 2012. Postini customers will be directed to a new service which is currently being implemented as a part of Google Apps. Companies will be able to retain their usual functions and tried-and-tested configurations, including user-specific settings, when migrating from Postini to Retarus' Managed E-Mail Services. Retarus transfers customized settings upon agreement with the customer and configures Managed E-Mail Services according to their requirements. Users will be able to continue using their mail services without any problems and benefit from additional advantages offered by Retarus. These include convenient administration, detailed monitoring, a web-based multilingual administration portal with comprehensive configuration possibilities as well as round-the-clock direct support from the service provider's qualified specialists in Germany and eleven international subsidiaries. In addition, Retarus Managed E-Mail Services provide considerable advantages as regards data security and compliance. Customers always retain control over the country-specific regulations to be observed and whether the data processed in Retarus data centers within the European Union is transferred to the United States or solely processed outside of the US. Retarus also offers a series of solutions for the secure processing of emails.

Google announced plans to shut down Orkut, its first attempt at building a social network. The platform will be formally closed on September 30, 2014 after which users will be unable to log in or export their photo albums to Google+. Orkut grew out of Google's 20% initiative, which allowed employees to use a fifth of their working week on side projects. Of course, the social network has since been supplanted by Google+, a more ambitious service that ties into many of Google's other products. The decision to close Orkut is therefore hardly surprising -the fact it took so long is probably more of a shock. Starting June 30, 2014, it will be impossible for newcomers to create a new Orkut account. Existing users can access the service as normal, however; Google says the three-month period should 'give the community time to manage the transition.' Orkut enthusiasts can also export their profile data, community posts and photos using Google Takeout. Orkut has been around for a decade and to mark its legacy, Google will preserve all of the site's public communities in an archive. It's a nice gesture, although users can choose to opt-out by decoupling Orkut from their Google account. The Orkut app will be removed from Google Play and the App Store later June 30, 2014.

Alpha Natural Resources to close a Greene County mine and lay off all the employees working there. Alpha owns Emerald Coal Resources, LP, which operated the Emerald No. 1 mine, located in rural Greene County just southwest of Waynesburg.

Alpha Natural Resources Inc. closed two thermal coal operations in Virginia that totaled more than 700,000 tons of production in 2012. Alpha closed the Red Onion surface mine in Wise County, Va., operated by Paramont Coal Co. Virginia LLC. Both closures relate to the repositioning plan announced in September 2012 that promised cuts at higher-cost Appalachian mines.

Alpha Natural Resources, Inc. announced that its Cumberland coal mine in southwestern Pennsylvania was closed by federal safety authorities after methane levels were detected in the mine. The U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration issued an imminent danger order April 8, closing a portion of the mine. On April 11, MSHA modified the order to apply to the entire mine.

Koppers Holdings announced that it is discontinuing activities at its tar plant in Clairton, Pennsylvania, due to oversupply in the industry. Koppers intends to ramp down production over the next six months as it transitions production to other facilities in both the US and Europe. It has set mid-2016 as a target date for discontinuing activities completely. The decision was driven by the continued shift of primary aluminium production to lower-cost energy regions of the world, which in turn has contributed to overcapacity in the tar distillation industry. Fifty-two employees will be impacted by the decision.

Investors Bancorp, Inc. plans to close three branch offices in its New Jersey network and one in New York. The Company estimates the branch closures will reduce its annual operating expenses by approximately USD 1.6 million.

iRobot Corporation announced that it will close its Durham plant, where it produced its Seaglider robot for defense, as part of a plan to lay off 13% of its workforce. The company is stopping production of those robots immediately and moving the unit to its Bedford, Mass. headquarters. All 80 of the company's layoffs of full-time employees are from that office, and 11 contractors were also affected.

Home BancShares, Inc. announced that it plans to close one Arkansas and three Florida locations during the fourth quarter of 2015.The company reported unaudited consolidated earnings results for the third quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2015. For the quarter, the company reported total interest income of $96,653,000 compared to $83,401,000 a year ago. Net interest income was $91,091,000 compared to $78,605,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $55,937,000 compared to $42,378,000 a year ago. Net income was $35,741,000 compared to $27,371,000 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share were $0.52 compared to $0.41 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share excluding merger expenses were $0.53 compared to $0.45 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share excluding intangible amortization were $0.53 compared to $0.42 a year ago. Book value per common share was $16.05 compared to $14.42 a year ago. Tangible book value per common share was $11.03 compared to $9.39 a year ago. Return on average assets was 1.72% compared to 1.56% a year ago. Return on average assets excluding intangible amortization, provision for loan losses, merger expenses, bargain purchase gain, gain on life insurance proceeds and income taxes was 3.24% compared to 3.08% a year ago. Return on average common equity was 13.23% compared to 11.58% a year ago. Return on average tangible common equity excluding intangible amortization was 19.76% compared to 18.46% a year ago.For the nine months, the company reported total interest income of $270,845,000 compared to $247,827,000 a year ago. Net interest income was $255,611,000 compared to $233,648,000 a year ago. Income before income taxes was $159,023,000 compared to $130,111,000 a year ago. Net income was $100,766,000 compared to $83,137,000 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share were $1.48 compared to $1.26 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common share excluding merger expenses were $1.50 compared to $1.31 a year ago. Diluted earnings per common

Dunkin' Brands Group, Inc. revised earnings guidance for the full year 2019. The company continues to expect low-single digit comparable store sales growth for Dunkin' U.S. and now expects flat to slightly negative comparable store sales growth for Baskin-Robbins U.S. The company continues to expect low-to-mid single digit percent revenue growth. The company now expects GAAP diluted earnings per share of $2.71 to $2.78 (previously $2.63 to $2.72). The company continues to expect mid-to-high single digit percent operating and adjusted operating income growth.The company continues to expect to be at the low end of the range of 200 to 250 net new Dunkin' U.S. units. It expects new Dunkin' U.S. restaurants opened in 2019 will contribute at least $130 million in system wide sales in 2019.The company continues to expect Baskin-Robbins U.S. franchisees to close approximately ten net units.The company reported impairment charges for the second quarter ended June 29, 2019. For the period, the company reported long-lived asset impairment charges of $2,000 compared to $653,000 a year ago.

Dunkin' Donuts announced that 176 Federal Street in Boston's Financial District has closed. Sean Sullivan, the company franchisee who operated the shop, would only say that the lease for the 2,000-square-foot shop that was dubbed the Federal Street Cafe expired and he was unable to come to terms on a renewal. Sullivan declined to reveal the proposed new lease term that he rejected.

Domtar Corp. announced that it would aim to cut $200 million in annual costs by the end of 2020. The company will permanently close its uncoated freesheet manufacturing operation at its paper mills in Kingsport, Tennessee, and Port Huron, Michigan. It will also close the paper machine at its mill in Ashdown, Arkansas, and its converting center at a facility in Ridgefields, Tennessee. The remaining paper machines at the Ashdown and Kingsport mills, which were temporarily closed in April as a response to the pandemic, will close permanently. The closures will result in a workforce reduction of around 780 employees.

Domtar Corporation announced that it will permanently shut down one pulp machine at its Kamloops, British Columbia facility. This decision will result in a permanent curtailment of Domtar's annual pulp production by approximately 120,000 air-dried metric tons of sawdust softwood pulp and will affect approximately 125 employees. The pulp machine, known at the mill as the "A-Line" is expected to be closed by the end of March 2013. The Kamloops pulp operation will continue to operate its remaining pulp manufacturing line with an annual capacity of approximately 350,000 air-dried metric tons of softwood kraft pulp and employ approximately 300 people. Domtar will take appropriate measures to assist employees affected by this decision in accordance with the collective agreement, Domtar policy and legislation.

Glu Mobile (GLUU) announced on August 23, 2017, that it would eliminate 46 jobs in its San Francisco and Long Beach offices to streamline its operations, which would result in pre-tax charges of $1.5 million to $1.75 million in third quarter. The company said it expected to gain operating efficiencies by decentralizing activities tied directly to game development, such as Android development, and embedding these functions within the individual game development teams.

Fiesta Restaurant Group has announced it is closing all nine Pollo Tropical locations in metro Atlanta as part of a strategic plan. The parent company of Pollo Tropical and Taco Cabana fast-casual restaurants said it would close 14 Pollo Tropical restaurants in Florida and Georgia, which include the Atlanta area closures, as well as nine Taco Cabana restaurants in Texas. Nearly all employees impacted by the Florida and Texas closures will be offered positions at nearby Pollo Tropical or Taco Cabana restaurant locations.

Fiesta Restaurant Group eliminated 49 corporate positions. The plan will cut $7.5 million in general and administrative costs in 2018, and it expects $1.8 million in savings, net of severance and other transition expenses in 2017. Closing the restaurants resulted in $32 million in non-cash impairment charges during first quarter 2017, and the company expects another $9 million to $12 million in lease and other charges during the second quarter.

Fiesta Restaurant Group, Inc. announced it will close 14 Pollo Tropical restaurants in Florida and Georgia, including all nine Pollo Tropical restaurants in the greater Atlanta metropolitan area, and nine Taco Cabana restaurants in Texas. Nearly all employees impacted by the Florida and Texas closures will be offered positions at nearby Pollo Tropical or Taco Cabana restaurant locations.

Fiesta Restaurant Group announced that it plans to close 30 Pollo Tropical restaurants in North Texas, Austin and Nashville. The closures will happen May 1, 2017, and where possible, impacted employees will be offered jobs at nearby Fiesta restaurants. Five of the locations in Texas could be rebranded as Taco Cabana units. With the closures, Fiesta will own 19 Pollo Tropicals outside of Florida, including 13 in Atlanta and six in South Texas.

Fiesta Restaurant Group, Inc. announced that it has closed 10 Pollo Tropical restaurants and will rebrand up to three of these restaurants in Texas as Taco Cabana restaurants. The decision to close restaurants was based on a restaurant portfolio examination as part of the companys strategic review process to enhance long-term shareholder value. Affected restaurants include eight in Texas, one in Nashville, Tennessee and one in Atlanta, Georgia. Nearly all employees impacted by closures will be offered positions at nearby restaurants.

Best Buy Co. -- grappling with competition from online retailers -- announced that it is closing a store in south Aurora as part of a nationwide closure of 50 full-sized stores. The store to be closed is at 15800 E. Briarwood Circle, near Arapahoe and Parker roads.

Best Buy announced that they will close their Kansas Speedway store at 10500 Parallel in Kansas City, Kan. The company released a list of 50 stores across the nation that it will close. Most of the outlets will be closed by May 2012. The company earlier this year said it would close its store at 509 N.W. Barry Road in Kansas City, North.

Fifth Third Bancorp to shutter 5 branches in Michigan. The closures are part of a plan that the company announced in June to consolidate or sell approximately 100 of its branches and approximately 30 other properties previously purchased for future branch expansion. The company is to shut five of its 248 branches in Michigan. The closures are part of a plan that the company announced in June to consolidate or sell approximately 100 of its branches and approximately 30 other properties previously purchased for future branch expansion. The branches set to be closed are in Spring Arbor, near Jackson; Orchard Plaza, near Byron Center; Hamilton, southeast of Holland; Newburgh Road in Livonia; and Waltz Road, near Flat Rock in Southeast Michigan.

Safeway announced that it is closing nine locations across metro Denver, citing non-profitability as the main reason for the decision. The nine locations will close on or about June 13, 2015. They are: 560 Castle Pines Parkway, Castle Rock, 3904 East 120th Ave, Thornton, 12900 Zuni, Westminster, 16921 E. Quincy Ave, Aurora, 22675 East Aurora Parkway, Aurora, 1955 South Sheridan Blvd., Denver, 7500 S. Pierce Street, Littleton, 1730 S. Buckley Road, Aurora and 8200 S. Quebec, Centennial.

Building Materials Holding Corp. announced that in an effort to continue to align costs with current market conditions, it will close several additional facilities. BMHC will close all of its operations located in Northern Nevada, including Reno and Sparks facilities. In Sherwood, Oregon the Company will consolidate its greater Portland market operations to its Vancouver, Washington facility, closing the Sherwood site. In Marysville, California BMHC will consolidate its lumber and building materials distribution and wall panel manufacturing operations into its existing Modesto, California facilities. Other operational consolidations will occur in Texas, Colorado and Arizona. These closures and consolidations are expected to be substantially completed during the first quarter of 2009. Approximately 260 employees in total are expected to be affected by these actions.

Republic Airways Holdings Inc. will permanently close its C-Check maintenance hangar at Port Columbus International Airport. The closure and cuts will begin June 20, or within the two weeks following. All affected employees will be paid through August 2. Republic said some employees have bumping rights within the Port Columbus International Airport hangar facility, and that all have been offered transfer opportunities.

Kraft Foods Inc. announced it will close its yogurt-making plant in Otsego County, leaving 67 employees without jobs. Kraft will have work for plant employees through April 8. The plant will then be closed with production transferred to the Kraft plant in North Lawrence in St. Lawrence County. The closing of the plant, which makes Breyers fruit-on-the-bottom yogurt, comes as part of a company restructuring plan.
